DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 1, or the fourth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: British chemist Sir Joseph Priestley announces that he has discovered oxygen.
1834: Robert Morrison, the first English missionary to go to China and translator of the Bible into Chinese, dies.
1894: War between China and Japan over the question of Korea breaks out. The Treaty of Shimonoseki was signed the next year, compelling the Ching court to pay a huge indemnity, open its seaports, recognize the independence of Korea, and cede the Liaotung Peninsula, Taiwan, and the Pescadores to Japan.
1915: The Peking government mints its silver coin, known as "Yuantatou," bearing the likeness of Yuan Shih-kai.
1926: Kwangtung University changes its name to National Sun Yat-sen University.
1927: The Chinese communists stage the Nanchang Uprising against the Nationalist government.
1928: The Central Broadcasting System is set up in Nanking by the Kuomintang.
1941: American volunteer aviators form the "Flying Tigers," with Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault as commander. They help China combat Japanese air superiority in the early stages of World War II.
1943: Lin Sen, chairman of the Nationalist government, dies at the age of 76.
1949: The Office of Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang is established in Taipei.
1958: An insurance program providing 180,000 government employees with coverage for maternity leave, illness, injury, disability and death is put into effect.
1966: The Chinese Communist Party opens a plenum meeting that declares the start of the 10-year Cultural Revolution.
1971: The Tainan Giants of the Republic of China win the Little League Asian and Pacific play-offs.
1973: The Economic Planning Council (EPC) of the Executive Yuan is inaugurated. The EPC replaces the Council for International Economic Cooperation and Development.
1973: Gen. Kao Kuei-yuan takes over from Gen. Cheng Ta-ching as the Republic of China's minister of national defense.
1976: The National Reconstruction Seminar opens in Taipei with 130 local and overseas Chinese scholars participating.
1984: ROC athlete Tsai Wen-yee wins a bronze medal in weightlifting at the 1984 Olympic Games.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves a slight increase in the premium rate of laborers' occupational injury insurance. The rates for thirty-two occupations are raised.
1987: The Council of Labor Affairs is formally established under the Executive Yuan.
1989: A foreign currency call loan market designed to make the metropolis an international financial center is established in Taipei.
1992: The National Unification Council defines "one China" as "one country and two areas each ruled separately by a different political entity."
1992: The Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters, the ROC's highest security institution, is disbanded, and the Coastal Patrol General Headquarters is established under the Ministry of National Defense.
1999: The U.S. Defense Department announces the sale of two E-2T Hawkeye 2000E airborne early warning aircraft and related equipment and services to Taiwan.
2000: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh pays a visit to New Party leader Hau Lung-bin, a move Hsieh said is aimed at showing respect to the opposition.
2000: Taiwan resident Huang You-fu becomes the 10 millionth traveler to pass through Macau International Airport.
2001: Former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang suggests that opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan visit mainland China to try to achieve a breakthrough in the currently strained cross-strait relations.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By attending to the cleanliness and purity of his person and the propriety and dignity of his dress, and in every word and act permitting nothing which is contrary to good taste and decency, that is how the ruler puts in order his personal conduct."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO BOOST BALANCED REGIONAL EDUCATION DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday the government will speed up construction of education facilities in rural and remote areas to boost balanced regional development.

Yu made the promise at a ceremony marking the upgrading of National Ilan Institute of Technology to the status of a university -- the first university to open in the northeastern county of Ilan of which Yu was once magistrate.

The premier said the transformation of the institute into National Ilan University is a response to Ilan residents' demand for more educational facilities to facilitate cultivation of human resources and to boost regional development in various fields.
The opening of National Ilan University is part of the government's efforts to balance education development around Taiwan, Yu added.

Also on Friday, President Chen Shui-bian presided over a ceremony marking the transition of National Teachers College to National Taitung University. The upgrading is welcomed by Taitung residents as a milestone in the eastern Taiwan county's development.

A day earlier, Chen officiated at a ceremony marking the transformation of the Lien-Ho Institute of Technology into National Miaoli University in the northern county of Miaoli, which has a large Hakka population.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. EXPRESSES CONCERNS ABOUT M'LAND CHINESE MISSILE BUILD-UP
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, July 31 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Washington has once again expressed its concerns about mainland China's increasing deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan.

"We've made it clear that China's rapid build-up of weapons, particularly missiles opposite Taiwan, is something that is destabilizing, " White House spokesman Scott McClellan said Thursday during a routine press briefing.

McClellan said the White House has always remained committed to the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act, which calls for the United States to sell Taiwan the weapons it needs to maintain a self-defense capability.
"We have expressed concerns directly to Beijing about their taking steps to increase their weaponry, " he said.
"The best way for the two sides (of the Taiwan Strait) to resolve their differences is through peaceful dialogue, and we encourage the parties to pursue that dialogue," he added.
McClellan made the remarks in response to a Pentagon report released the day before which warns that mainland China's modernizing military could enable it to carry out a surprise attack on Taiwan.
Answering a reporter's question about whether U.S. President George W. Bush would be willing to fulfill America's commitments to Taiwan's security, McClellan said, "Absolutely."
He added that Washington works closely with Beijing on a number of issues, including the Taiwan Strait issue and the North Korea issue.
The Pentagon report said mainland China possesses about 450 short-range ballistic missiles and is expected to add about 75 annually over the next few years.
All of these missiles are capable of being used against Taiwan and are believed to be based in the Nanjing Military Region opposite Taiwan, the report said.

"The PLA's offensive capabilities improve as each year passes, providing Beijing, in the absence of an effective response by Taiwan, with an increasing number of credible military options to intimidate or actually attack Taiwan," the report indicated.

"Should China use force, its primary goal likely would be to compel a negotiated solution on terms favorable to Beijing, " it continued, adding that "Beijing would most likely seek a rapid collapse of Taiwan's national will to preclude the United States from intervening on Taipei's behalf."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATOR URGES U.S. TO SELL OFFENSIVE WEAPONS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A legislator from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party on Friday urged the United States to address the imbalance in military development between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and sell offensive weapons to Taiwan.

Tang Huo-sheng, a member of the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee, made the appeal after the U.S. Defense Department unveiled the 2003 Annual Report on the Military Power of the People's Republic of China Wednesday.

The report said that Taiwan remains the primary reason behind Beijing's military modernization which includes the addition each year of about 75 short-range ballistic missiles targeting the island to the 450 such missiles already deployed.

Tang, who visited the United States recently and discussed related issues with U.S. officials, said that the imbalance in military development between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is a reality. He added that with the United States selling only defensive weapons to Taiwan all these years, it has rendered Taiwan without an offensive capability.

He said that as Washington has refused to sell offensive weapons to Taiwan, "the United States should bear the greatest responsibility for the imbalance in military development across the Taiwan Strait."

Tang said that even if Taiwan spends billions of new Taiwan dollars on buying such defensive weapons as the early-warning radar system and Patriot III missiles from the United States over the next several years, this will not help solve the problem of the imbalance in cross-strait military development, with Beijing maintaining the upper hand over Taiwan.
He said it would be more useful if the United States sold one or two Tomahawk cruise missiles to Taiwan instead of selling it so many defensive weapons.
He said that if the United States hopes to maintain regional security in Asia, it should not let Taiwan continue to be deficient in offensive weapons.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, PANAMA BEGIN LATEST ROUND OF FTA TALKS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Panama kicked off a 10-day round of negotiations on the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) in Taipei Friday.

The two sides have already held four rounds of FTA talks and an extra consultation meeting on agricultural issues. The fifth round in Taipei is being presided over by officials from the ROC's Bureau of Foreign Trade.

Trade officials said that both sides have reached consensus on the list agricultural items to undergo tariff cuts. Among the 23 or 24 items that are sensitive, only beef and a few others have been included in the opening list, while rice and cigars have been excluded from the tariff cut list.

The officials said that if the talks go smoothly, President Chen Shui-bian and Panamanian President Mireya Elisa Moscoso will witness the signing of the FTA when Taiwan holds a sumit meeting with five Central and Southern American countries at the end of this month.

Taiwan's FTA talks with Panama have been progressing more rapidly than those with other countries. If the agreement is signed, Panama will become the first country with which Taiwan has ever signed an FTA.

DOC.HEADLINE: MECHANISM NEEDED FOR HANDLING 'RUNAWAY' FOREIGN WIVES: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The government should pay more heed to family affairs involving "runaway" foreign wives of local citizens, an opposition lawmaker said Friday.

Legislator Hsu Chung-hsiung made the call after a local man surnamed Ku asked the Kuomintang lawmaker to help him bring back to Taiwan his two young children who were taken to Cambodia by his Cambodian-born more than three months ago.
With the number of intermarriages increasing rapidly in recent years, Hsu said the government should forge a comprehensive mechanism to handle similar cases.

"Ku's plight is not just an isolated case. Similar disputes have become increasingly common in local society. The government should not sit idly by but instead must take active steps to help resolve issues involving 'runaway' foreign spouses and children born to intermarried couples," Hsu said.

Ku, a resident of Chungli, Taoyuan County, told Hsu that he and his Cambodian-born wife, identified as "Wu Li-chu, " had gone to Cambodia in April along with their two children to visit Wu's parents. Ku returned to Taiwan alone a week later after his wife declined to return with him.

Ku and his parents have since made two visits to the Southeast Asian country -- one in May and the other in July -- to try to persuade Wu to return, but to no avail. Wu has also refused to allow the two children to be taken back to Taiwan. Ku claimed that his wife would not even let him see their three-year-old daughter and nine-month-old son.

Ku said he had sought the assistance of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) and the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) , but the two ministries were reluctant to give him any help on the grounds that the Republic of China doesn't maintain formal diplomatic ties with Cambodia and cannot seek the "extradition" of his wife.
Ku said his two children are ROC passport holders. "The government is obliged to ensure their safety and protect their basic human rights," he added.

Hsu seconded Ku's views, saying that as Ku's children do not have household registration or identity cards in Cambodia, their human rights, education rights and even physical safety could possibly be compromised there.

Since the ROC government allows intermarriages, Hsu continued, it should not turn a deaf ear to calls for assistance in settling issues involving "runaway" foreign spouses and children born to intermarried couples.

"We ought to show more concern for the plight of these intermarried couples and their children, " Hsu said, adding that the government ought to craft a legal framework and adopt various complementary measures to deal with intermarriage-related problems.
According to rough tallies, Taiwan now has more than 300,000 intermarried couples. "The government should not ignore their problems," he said.

"While drafting new immigration regulations, the government should not just focus on how to manage, supervise or plug loopholes. Humanitarian principles and cultural diversity should be given more emphasis when intermarriage issues are dealt with," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 72.17 points to close at 5,390.51.

Encouraged by a rise in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,365.73 and continued to go up later due to the good performance of electrical shares. The index fluctuated between 5,408.15 and 5,363.89 during trading.

A total of 4.06 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$103.25 billion (US$3 billion) , an increase from the previous trading session which saw 3.78 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$85.04 billion (US$2.47 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with cement stocks and foodstuff shares moving down, both at 0.7 percent.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up the most at 2.1 percent, followed by construction stocks and plastics and chemical shares, both at 1.1 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.7 percent, textile issues at 0.2 percent, and bank and insurance shares at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 458 to 194, with 106 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIPLOMACY TO BE BASED ON OVERALL NATIONAL INTEREST: MOFA

TEXT.P: National interest considerations will form the basis of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' (MOFA's) efforts in expanding relations with ROC diplomatic allies and in promoting substantial relations with countries with which the Republic of China does not maintain formal diplomatic ties, a MOFA spokesman said Friday.

Richard Shih made the remarks following wire reports that said Nauru had shut down its embassy in mainland China to pave the way for hte re-establishment of diplomatic relations with Taiwan. Shih said the MOFA would not comment on the wire reports.
Diplomatic sources pointed out that Nauru closed its embassy in mainland China due to financial difficulties but that it is unlikely to try to resume diplomatic relations with Taiwan immediately.
Nauru has a population of nearly 10,000 on a land area of around 21 square kilometers. The ROC established diplomatic relations with the country in 1980, and then severed them in July 2002.

The MOFA issued a statement at that time saying that the Nauruan president had always harbored unrealistic views about mainland China and that his decision to establish formal diplomatic ties with Beijing had not been approved by the Nauruan Cabinet. The ROC government, in view of protecting its national dignity and of not engaging in "dollar diplomacy" with mainland China, decided to severe ties with Nauru, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EASTERN TAIWAN UNIVERSITIES HELP BALANCE EDUCATION RESOURCES: CHEN

TEXT.P: The establishment of one new university in each of the three counties in eastern Taiwan Friday serves as an important milestone in the country's efforts to create a more balanced distribution of education resources, President Chen Shui-bian said Friday.

Chen said that for a long time, the Taiwan people have witnessed imbalanced regional development, with southern Taiwan as a whole enjoying less resources than northern Taiwan, and the gap between eastern Taiwan and western Taiwan being even more prominent.

Taking eastern Taiwan as an example, Chen said that although it covers about half the area of Taiwan proper, it has been considered a hinterland for decades, being nicknamed in mandarin Chinese as the "back mountain."

He said that if the government does not make efforts to redress the imbalance, eastern Taiwan will remain as the "back mountain" and continue to witness a rapid greying of its population and a migration by the younger generations out of the region.

The president made the remarks when he addressed a ceremony marking the upgrading of National Taitung Teachers College to the status of National Taitung University, making it the first university in the eastern county of Taitung, where aboriginal citizens make up nearly one-third of the population.

Chen said that the increasing number of universities in rural areas around the island is a manifestation of the government's direct response to the will of the people. It also demonstrates his administration's concern for the welfare of those living in disadvantaged areas, he said.

Following its upgrading, National Taitung University will not only continue to be a cradle of teacher nurturing, it will also become a stronghold of indigenous and Austronesian studies in Southeast Asia, Chen said.
He added that Taitung is Taiwan's most diversified county in terms of aboriginal groups, including the Puyuma, Amis, Bunun, Dawu, Paiwan and Rukai tribes.

Besides, he continued, National Taitung University will also run a sports school to train professional athletes, particularly baseball talent, taking advantage of the fact that Taitung County is the home of the famous Red Leaves baseball team which beat the Japanese World Little League Series champion decades ago when members of the Japanese team visited Taiwan.

Chen offered his appreciation to the Taitung County government for offering a scenic piece of land in Chihpeng for the newly-upgraded university. Chihpeng is known for its natural beauty, with magnificent mountains, rivers, hot springs and aboriginal cultures.

On Thursday, President Chen was in the northern county of Miaoli where he officiated at a similar ceremony marking the upgrading of the National Lien-Ho Institute of Technology to the status of a university. National United University is the first university to open in the predominantly Hakka county of Miaoli.
The president spoke at a site of expansion construction on the institute. The expansion is one of the changes taking place at the institute which was formally designated a university on Friday.
Also being established on Friday was National Ilan University -- upgraded from the National Ilan Institute of Technology. It represents the first university in the eastern county of Ilan.

The president said that the establishment of the three national universities will help meet a need in the region, which he pointed out did not have a single university prior to Friday despite the fact that the number of colleges and universities nationwide had expanded to 135 in 2001 from 67 in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED TO PROTECT FISHERMEN OPERATING AROUND PRATAS

TEXT.P: Legislators on Friday urged the administration to adopt measures to protect the rights of Taiwan fishermen operating around the Tungsha (Pratas) islands.

Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang of the opposition People First Party (PFP) said that the waters around Tungsha are rich in marine resources and are the traditional fishing grounds of Taiwan fishermen, but that Taiwan fishermen have often been bullied by neighboring countries while operating in the area.
He suggested that the government demarcate its economic territory and claim sovereignty over it to ensure the rights of Taiwan fishermen in pursuing their livelihood.

To understand the situation in the Pratas, Lu and his colleagues -- Legislator Tang Chin-chuan of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and Legislators Cheng Mei-lan and Cheng San-yuan of the PFP -- visited the Pratas Thursday for an inspection tour.

Lu said that the natural beauty of the coral atoll of Tungsha has yet to be tapped, pointing out that if the government can efficiently develop it, it will be a great contribution to Taiwan's tourism.
He suggested that the government plan Tungsha as a national "marine park" and thereby raise Taiwan's tourism quality internationally.

The Tungsha islands are located in a strategically important position along the major sea route connecting the Pacific and Indian oceans. It is now under the jurisdiction of Kaohsiung City. Related business currently under the charge of the Ministry of National Defense will be turned over to the Coast Guard Administration in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENTAGON REPORT HIGHLIGHTS MAINLAND THREAT TO STRAIT SECURITY: NSC

TEXT.P: The Pentagon's latest annual report to Congress on mainland Chinese military power has again highlighted the seriousness of the threat that Beijing poses to Taiwan Strait security and Asia-Pacific stability, the National Security Council (NSC) reported Friday.

NSC spokesman Su Chin-chiang said that although the Pentagon report has not surprised the council, which has always kept abreast of mainland China's military development, it indeed serves as a fresh reminder to the world that Beijing's stepped-up military build-up increasingly threatens security in the Taiwan Strait as well as stability in the Asia-Pacific region.

The report, released Wednesday, has also underlined U.S. concerns about Taiwan's self-defensive capabilities as Washington has recently conveyed the hope that Taiwan will increase the quantity and quality of its weaponry purchases from the United States, Su noted.

Su added that the Ministry of National Defense will undoubtedly conduct a comprehensive review on Taiwan's military and defense structures, as well as its arms procurement plans and related affairs in the light of the Pentagon report.

Noting that Presidential Secretary-General Chiou I-jen and NSC Deputy Secretary-General Ke Cheng-heng traveled to the United States recently to exchange views with U.S. officials and private think-tanks on Taiwan's arms procurement and its intentions of introducing a referendum system, Su stressed that Taiwan and the United States have maintained smooth communications and dialogue channels.
The Pentagon report said mainland China possesses about 450 short-range ballistic missiles and is expected to add about 75 annually over the next few years.
All of these missiles are capable of being used against Taiwan and are believed to be based in the Nanjing Military Region opposite Taiwan, the report said.

"The PLA's offensive capabilities improve as each year passes, providing Beijing, in the absence of an effective response by Taiwan, with an increasing number of credible military options to intimidate or actually attack Taiwan," the report indicated.

"Should China use force, its primary goal likely would be to compel a negotiated solution on terms favorable to Beijing, " it continued, adding that "Beijing would most likely seek a rapid collapse of Taiwan's national will to preclude the United States from intervening on Taipei's behalf."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN'S NAMESAKE FIRST TO APPLY FOR NEW VERSION OF PASSPORT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's namesake became the first local citizen to apply for the new version of the ROC passport Friday --the first day that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) began to accept applications.

"Chen Shui-bian," who legally changed his name to that of the president a few years ago, said he feels it is a very meaningful event for the government to issue the new version of the passport displaying the word "Taiwan" in addition to the official national designation of the Republic of China on its cover.

"Therefore, I wanted to be the first to apply for the new version of the passport, " said Chen, who is a founding member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's Yungho City chapter in Taipei County.
Chen arrived at the doors of the MOFA's Bureau of Consular Affairs (BCA) at 6: 30 a.m., two hours before the start of the bureau's regular business hours.

BCA Director Yang Sheng-chung, anticipating that there might be a large line that morning, arrived at the office at 6: 20 a.m. He gave Chen the No. 1 serial number for filing his application later to spare him from having to wait under the scorching sun for two hours.

The BCA will conduct a random, computerized drawing of the issued serial numbers Aug. 15 to decide the first 100 recipients of the new passport. Those who file applications between Aug. 1 and Aug. 14 have an equal chance of securing the coveted first new passport.

Nevertheless, many people were still anxious to file their applications. As of 11: 25 a.m., a total of 239 ROC citizens had applied, including 163 from the greater Taipei area, 35 from Taichung, 37 from Kaohsiung and four from Hualien.
The new version of the passport will be formally issued Sept. 1. Old passports can be used until their expiry dates.

In the past, the first copy of a new version of a passport was traditionally reserved for the nation's head of state. This time, President Chen Shui-bian has directed that the first copy of the new version be made available to the people since it is they who will benefit from the changes.
The serial number of the new passports will start from "210000001," Yang said, adding that "21" refers to the 21st century.
He reminded the public that some countries do not allow their visa stamps on old versions of passports to be automatically transferred to new passports.
"Those wishing to travel abroad should contact the local representative offices of specific foreign countries prior to filing an application for a new passport, " he added.

Some ROC passport holders have complained that they had encountered unnecessary inconveniences or embarrassment while traveling abroad because foreign immigration officers mistook them for mainland Chinese nationals. Mainland China's official title is the People's Republic of China or the PRC.
The addition of the word "Taiwan" on the cover of the new ROC passport will make them more distinguishable from those issued by the PRC, MOFA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AMBASSADOR TO SOLOMON ISLANDS PRESENTS CREDENTIALS
DOC.DATELINE: Sydney, Aug. 1 (CNA) (By W. H. Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: New Republic of China Ambassador to the Solomon Islands Chen Chun-hsien presented his letter of credentials Friday to Peter Kenilorea, the acting governor general of the south Pacific nation.

Ambassador Chen thanked the Solomon Islands for its long-term support for Taiwan's efforts to participate in the international community, saying that he would continue to work toward deepening relations between the two countries.

For his part, Kenilorea expressed his appreciation for the Republic of China's long-term cooperation and friendship, reaffirming that the country would support Taiwan's bid to join international organizations.
He also expressed the hope that both countries could strengthen bilateral economic, cultural, science and technology cooperation.

Ambassador Chen, who arrived in Honiara, capital of the Solomon Islands, July 29, later called on Prime Minister Allan Kemakeza and Minister of Foreign Affairs Laurie Chan. In both of these meetings, the two sides vowed to work toward strengthening bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,000 JAPANESE TO BE GIVEN FREE TRIP TO TAIWAN IN TOURISM PROMOTION
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 1 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A total of 130,000 Japanese people answered an advertisement by the Taiwan Visitors Association (TVA) to compete for 500 two-person sets of free tourism packages to Taiwan.

The TVA advertisement, placed in major newspapers around Japan July 23, offers 500 Taiwan tour packages, allowing 1,000 Japanese citizens to travel to Taiwan for a two-night, three-day tour between Sept. 1-10 for free.

The packages, featuring free round-trip air tickets, hotel and food, is part of the TVA's efforts to rejuvenate Taiwan's tourism, which has been battered by the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) between March and June.

The drawing will be held in Osaka, Nagoya and Tokyo Aug. 6, 7 and 8 to select the 500 lucky winners among the mountain of post cards sent in by 130,000 Japanese people, said officials from the TVA Tokyo Office.
Su Cheng-tian, director-general of Taiwan's Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, is scheduled to arrive in Japan before Aug. 6 to officiate at the drawing.
The names of the winners will be made public by Aug. 15, TVA officials said.

The 1,000 potential visitors will be arranged to depart Japan for Taiwan from six Japanese airports, including the new airport in Sapporo, Hokkaido; Narita Airport in Tokyo; Nagoya International Airport, Kansei International Airport near Osaka, Fukuoka International Airport and Okinawa Airport, TVA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SU-27, MiG-29 FIGHTERS TO BE SHOWN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Advanced jet fighters Su-27 and MiG-29 from Ukraine will be displayed in Taipei later this month, despite concerns from mainland Chinese authorities, local aviation sources said Friday.

The Su-27 and MiG-29 are known as the most sophisticated versions of warplanes in the former communist bloc. Mainland China has bought Russian-made Su-27s. It has expressed strong concerns about Ukraine's plan to send this type of warplanes to Taipei for public exhibition.

Aviation sources said Ukrainian authorities will uphold their plan to have four types of aircraft, including the Su-27 and MiG-29, shown at the upcoming Taipei Aerospace Technology Exhibition because it wants to promote sales of its fighter jets to Taiwan and other neighboring Asian countries.

Ukraine has assured mainland Chinese authorities that the upcoming exhibition is purely for commercial purposes, with an aim to tapping business opportunities in the Asia-Pacific region, the source said.

According to the sources, the ROC Air Force once planned to buy or lease a Su-27 fighter to serve as an enemy aircraft in its training exercises. Air Force authorities can take advantage of the Aug. 14-17 aerospace industry trade fair to look into the performance of this type of fighter plane, the sources said.

Ukraine's Kharkov State Aircraft Manufacturing Co. and Taipei's Helicopter Development Association have contributed much to pushing for a static display of the Su-27 and MiG-29 fighters in Taipei, the sources said.

Ukraine will exhibit two other types of aircraft -- the AN-74TK200 transport and the AN-140 regional commercial airliner. The two planes will be flown in demonstrations at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, some 40 kilometers south of Taipei Aug. 12-14.
All the Ukrainian planes are scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Aug. 10 for the upcoming show.

Meanwhile, media reports said several Ukrainian officials will come to Taipei along with the planes. They will meet with Taiwan officials to discuss measures to boost bilateral economic ties, the reports said.
According to the reports, Ukraine, which maintains formal diplomatic ties with Beijing, may open a trade office in Taipei.
Among former Soviet Union states, Taiwan has only opened representative offices in Russia and Belarus. In Ukraine, Taipei has only employed a Ukrainian to serve as its liaison officer.

DOC.HEADLINE: BY-ELECTION FOR COUNTY MAGISTRATE TO BE HELD IN HUALIEN SATURDAY

TEXT.P: Voters in the eastern Taiwan county of Hualien will go to the polls Saturday in a magistrate by-election widely seen as a test for the 2004 presidential election.
There are three frontrunners and 256,685 eligible voters, who will cast ballots at 265 polling stations in 13 cities and townships in the county.

The major candidates are Hsieh Shen-shan of the "pan-blue alliance" of the major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People-First-Party, You Ying-lung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and Wu Kuo-tung, a former Hualien County magistrate, who is running as an independent after being expelled by the KMT for his maverick election bid. A fourth candidate has also been fielded by a tiny political party.
The three hopefuls are widely seen as running neck and neck. Hualien is one of the strongholds of the KMT, which has kept control of the county for many years. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS MORE MEDALS AT WORLD POLICE AND FIRE GAMES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's police officers and fire fighters won four gold medals Friday in the air rifle shooting competition and five medals in other competitions in the 2003 World Police and Fire Games being held in Barcelona, Spain July 27 to Aug. 3.
Police Officers Liu Ching-yuan, Tsai Ming-wang, Lee Tung-huei, and Su Chung-she won four gold medals by finishing with a combined score of 2,200 points.

Kao Hung-ping, Cheng Tso-wei, and Hsieh Kuang-ting won a gold, silver, and bronze respectively in billiards. In the shot put competition, Wu Fu-lai won a bronze medal, while Hung Chun-yu won a silver in the woman's tennis singles competition.
The Taiwan team has so far garnered 16 gold, 10 silver, and eight bronze medals at the games. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU PROFESSOR DEVELOPS LOW-CHOLESTEROL EGG

TEXT.P: A National Taiwan University (NTU) professor said Friday he has successfully developed a method to have hens lay low-cholesterol eggs.

Pan Zu-ming, director of the NTU's Graduate Institute of Microbiology and Biochemistry, said he has used red yeast rice -- a traditional preparation from fermentation of a strain of yeast known as monascus pureus -- to feed 48 42-week-old egg hens.

Six weeks later, Pan said, he found that cholesterol levels in eggs laid by those hens had declined by 6 to 14 percent. In addition, he said, cholesterol levels in blood serum of those hens also dropped.
Pan began to do the research four years ago. His research results are carried in the latest issue of the Journal of Agriculture and Food Chemistry published by the American Chemical Society.

Pan said he is now studying the possible effects of red yeast rice in treating Alzheimer's and fighting age and fatigue. He said he is experimenting with red yeast rice's anti-fatigue effects on mice.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DENIES IT REFUSED TO LET ROC VICE PRESIDENT TRANSIT IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, July 31 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Mauro Chang)

TEXT.P: Not only did the United States not deny Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu a transit visa to New York, it was unaware that Lu was even making a trip, an official of the Department of State said Thursday.

The official, who requested anonymity, said it is Washington's long- standing policy to allow Taiwan leaders to make transit stopovers in the United States and afford them safety, comfort, convenience and treatment them with dignity. This policy will continue, he said.

The official made the comment after U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher brushed aside journalists' questions regarding Lu's trip at a regular news briefing. The official instead referred journalists to Taipei authorities for the itinerary of Lu's Latin America trip, saying his department was unaware of it.

Reports in Taipei said Lu is scheduled to make stopovers in Hawaii, Seattle and New York on her way to Latin America in August and in New York and Los Angeles on her way back, but that Washington, irritated by Taipei's disclosure of the news of the trip before alerting U. S. officials, refused to let her stop in New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC RECRUITS NEW RESEARCH STAFF

TEXT.P: The National Security Council (NSC) has recruited 19 new research fellows, including 10 doctoral degree holders and nine master's degree holders, a spokesman said Friday.
NSC spokesman Su Chin-chiang said the new recruits were selected from more than 200 hopefuls. They will begin pre-job training next week.

This is the first time that the NSC has recruited research staffers since the Legislative Yuan passed a package of revisions to the NSC organic law to allow for recruitment of more staff members to enhance the council's functions in national security counseling.

The new recruits are specializing in defense, diplomacy, cross-Taiwan Strait relations, crisis management, financial and economic affairs, Su said, adding that the council may hold a second round of manpower scouting later this year as it plans to recruit a total of 25 researchers this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMERS URGED TO APPLY FOR MAINLAND'S MULTIPLE-ENTRY VISAS LEGALLY

TEXT.P: The ROC Consumers' Foundation urged local people Friday to apply for mainland China's three-year, multiple-entry visa through legal channels to avoid falling victim to swindlers.

The foundation made the statement after it received a number of complaints about troubles people encountered while using presumably mainland China-issued multiple-entry visas that they obtained through travel agencies.

According to the foundation, mainland Chinese immigration authorities in Shenzhen, Zuhai, Guangzhou and Xiamen have uncovered many Taiwan visitors using fake three-year, multiple-entry visas in the past six months.

In Zhuhai alone, more than 100 such cases have been discovered, the foundation said, adding that mainland public security authorities said the visas were secured through travel agencies in Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau at a cost ranging between 1,000 renminbi to 15,000 renminbi (between NT$4,500 to NT$7,000).
Mainland Chinese immigration officers confiscate fake visas and fine each person 2,000 renminbi, the foundation said.

According to mainland regulations, Taiwan people who intend to obtain three-year, multiple-entry visas must travel to mainland China in person to file applications with public security offices in various mainland Chinese cities and cannot commission travel agencies or any individuals to apply on their behalf.

DOC.HEADLINE: NETHERLANDS TRADE OFFICE HEAD VISITS TAINAN

TEXT.P: Netherlands Trade and Investment Office representative Menno Goedhart paid a visit to Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsai Thursday and vowed to step up bilateral exchanges in a wide range of sectors.

Praising the ancient city in southern Taiwan as a "suitable place to settle in" because of its comfortable environment and cultural atmosphere, Goedhart said he will do his best to strengthen two-way flows in trade, commerce, investment, technology and tourism between Tainan and Holland.
The chief liaison official from Holland in Taiwan revealed that a delegation from his country is slated to visit Tainan in November.
In addition to Tainan's cultural areas, Goedhart expressed his belief that the city will also play a bigger role in Taiwan's economics and hi-tech development under Hsu's capable leadership.

For his part, Hsu thanked Holland for helping stage the exhibition titled: "Formosa: Taiwan, Holland and East Asia in the 17th Century" early this year in Taipei and currently in Tainan by lending hundreds of world-class historical documents and Taiwanese artifacts to Taiwan's museums, including the original copy of the Treaty of Surrender.

The treaty was signed in 1662 in Tainan by Cheng Chen-kung and the defeated Dutch rulers. Cheng, also known as Koxinga, was much respected by the Taiwan people for his restoration of the island from Dutch rule.

Stressing that the exhibit brings a deep emotional touch to the Tainan people for its historical importance and links with Holland, Hsu said the Tainan City Government is planning to organize a "Dutch Day" in late August to further cement two-way cultural exchanges.
Accompanied by Deputy Mayor Hsu Yang-ming, Goedhart also visited the exhibition being held at a local museum.

Voicing his happiness that the valuable 17th century Taiwanese works and documents could be displayed in Tainan -- their native land and the venue where the first contacts between the Taiwan and Dutch people took place -- Goedhart said the exhibition clearly underscores the importance of Tainan for the city's role in Taiwan's history.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIES WITH NAURU A MATTER OF NATIONAL INTEREST: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said Friday that whether the Republic of China will resume diplomatic relations with the Pacific island state of Nauru will hinge on the assessment of national interests.
Chien made the remarks in the wake of a Reuters report that said Nauru has closed its embassy in Beijing to pave the way for the re-establishment of diplomatic relations with Taiwan.
Chien noted that the nature of Beijing's diplomacy was clear when Nauru's severed diplomatic ties with the ROC. He said that the mainland used money to disrupt the ROC's diplomacy.

On whether Nauru closed its embassy because Beijing didn't deliver on its promise to give US$130 million in financial aid to the island state, Chien said, "It is inappropriate for me to comment on the question," adding that "Nauru would know better."
In fact, Chien pointed out that a lot of countries have learned that Beijing often makes a lot of promises, but may not deliver on them afterwards.

Regarding the possibility of Taiwan resuming diplomatic relations with Nauru, Chien said that future relations with Nauru will have to conform to national interests, as well as on mutually beneficial principles.
"If the relationship is to be resumed, it will be after cautious assessment," Chien said, adding that it is not appropriate for him to make any comments.

Meanwhile, legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and opposition parties unanimously expressed opposition to the idea of resuming diplomatic relation with Nauru even if the small island country wishes to.
DPP Legislator Trong Chai said that under Beijing's policy to squeeze Taiwan diplomatically, Nauru was lured to turn its back on Taiwan last year.
"Taiwan should never resume diplomatic relations with a country that switch sides because of money," Chai said.

He noted that currently, of the 24 countries that have signed investment protection agreements, the avoidance of double taxation agreement, and an ATA agreement for temporary admission of goods with Taiwan, only five are Taiwan allies. Of the 27 countries that signed air transportation agreement with Taiwan, only three are Taiwan allies.
He said that Taiwan's establishment of diplomatic ties with various small countries aims at "political recognition and support, and not reciprocal exchanges."

Chai said that Taiwan can't afford to play the "dollar diplomacy" game with mainland China, and that Taiwan should promote rectifying the island's name, so that the nation can be officially known as Taiwan internationally.
DPP Legislator Parris Chang, who is currently visiting Vienna, also said via telephone that he is strongly opposed to resuming diplomatic ties with Nauru.
Chang said that Nauru is an "opportunist" country, and will tilt toward any countries that are willing to provide it with the most resources, which he said is a country "without ideals."

Chang stressed that countries that Taiwan should establish diplomatic relations with should be ones that will help Taiwan in the areas of economy, national defense and the expansion of its maneuvering room internationally, and that Nauru does not meet any of these conditions.

Lee Chia-chin, a whip of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , said that the government has to consider the price it must pay if it wants to resume ties with Nauru, and should not just do so because it wants an increase in the number of allies.
Legislator Sun Ta-chien of the opposition People First Party said that the government should turn away from the "dollar diplomacy" it used to employ,

Sun said that the government should carefully assess the resumption of ties with Nauru, adding that the top priority should be given to whether the country can break through the diplomatic blockade imposed by mainland China.

Chien Lin Whei-jun, whip of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, said that the government should be prudent in developing future relations with Nauru and that the dollar-bought diplomatic ties are always unstable and do not last for long.

The Republic of China established diplomatic relations with Nauru May 4, 1980, and the island nation switched ties to Beijing July 21, 2000, on the day President Chen Shui-bian began concurrently serving as the chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced the severance of diplomatic ties with the tiny Pacific island state July 23 for the protection of national dignity and as a way to show its rejection of engaging in one-upmanship in "dollar diplomacy" with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER TO HEAD ROC DELEGATION TO WTO CONFERENCE IN CANCUN
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, July 31 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu will head a 35-member Taiwan delegation to participate in the biennial World Trade Organization (WTO) Ministerial Conference Sept. 10-14 in Cancun, Mexico, Taiwan's trade officials said Thursday.

The delegation will be composed of officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Finance, Council of Agriculture, Taiwan's permanent representative mission to the WTO and the country's representative's office in Mexico, the officials revealed.

It will be Taiwan's debut in any WTO ministerial conference as a full member, the officials noted, adding that the delegation will seek the greatest possible benefit for Taiwan from the forthcoming meeting.
In addition to participating in the conference activities and multilateral talks, Minister Lin will take the opportunity to hold bilateral meetings with Taiwan's main trading partners.

DOC.HEADLINE: US OFFICIAL QUESTIONS WISDOM OF TAIWAN REFERENDUM
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, July 31 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has every right to hold a referendum, but it should first thoroughly examine the necessity and wisdom of doing so, U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Richard Armitage said Thursday.

In an interview with Hong Kong's Phoenix Television, Armitage cited Chiou I-jen, the secretary-general of President Chen Shui-bian's office, as having pledged during a meeting with him last week in Washington that Chen's controversial claims that there is one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait won't appear on Taiwan's proposed referendum.

He brushed aside the question of whether a referendum in Taiwan would cross the line for Beijing, saying only that he didn't like to see the situation framed in such a way since this would limit the ability to solve problems.

Armitage admitted that there are serious differences between mainland China and the United States over the Taiwan issue, but the administrations of each country have tried to straighten out these differences in a wise and dignified way and that this process has to be kept on.
He said that he has a high opinion of Taiwan, noting that the island has come a long way in developing its democracy and increasing its freedoms.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT MISSION TO RECRUIT HI-TECH TALENT OVERSEAS IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: A talent-recruitment mission led by Minister without Portfolio Tsai Ching-yen is slated to leave for the United States and Japan in early September in search of new employees for Taiwan's hi-tech industries, an official of a Cabinet advisory group said Friday.

According to the official of the Science and Technology Advisory Group under the Executive Yuan, Tsai will lead the delegation to San Francisco, Los Angeles, Boston, Washington, D. C., Tokyo and Osaka Sept. 5-16 to meet hi-tech professionals who may be willing to work in Taiwan.
There will be about 16,441 job vacancies in Taiwan's six hi-tech industries, including the semiconductor and digital content-related sectors, during the 2003-2005 period, the group has determined.
Meanwhile, 47 local companies have enthusiastically responded to the mission's call by offering a large number of job opportunities, the official said, adding that ACM alone has provided 600.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN WATERCOLOR PAINTING SHOW OPENS IN PENGHU

TEXT.P: The 2003 Asian Watercolor Painting Show opened Friday at the gallery of the Cultural Affairs Department of the Penghu County Government in the city of Makung.
On display at the exhibition are 124 works by 119 painters from seven countries and areas, including the United States, Japan, South Korea, Indonesia, Singapore, Hong Kong and the host, Taiwan.
The exhibition which is the first of its kind ever held on the outlying islands of Taiwan will last through Aug. 12.
It is jointly organized by the Taiwan International Watercolor Painters Association and the Penghu County Government.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER TO VISIT ST. VINCENT AND THE GRENADINES

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien will leave for Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Aug. 4 to participate in the seventh meeting of foreign ministers of the Republic of China and its four East Caribbean allies slated for Aug. 8, officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday.

The meeting, which will be attended by foreign ministers of the ROC, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, St. Christopher and Nevis, Grenada and Dominica, will mainly discuss the cooperation and exchanges in the political, economic, medical, educational and cultural fields between the ROC and the Caribbean nations, the officials noted.
The annual ministerial meeting has been held alternatively in Taiwan and the Caribbean region since the first of its kind was held in St. Christopher and Nevis in 1997.

Taking the opportunity, Minister Chien will also meet leaders of St. Vincent and the Grenadines and inspect operation of the ROC embassy and technical mission stationed in the East Caribbean nation before returning home.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL REFUGEE BILL WORKED OUT BY INTERIOR MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Political refugees might be granted asylum in Taiwan according to a political refugee bill worked out by the Ministry of the Interior in consultation with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

The bill, which might be presented to the Legislative Yuan for enactment as early as September, will oblige the government to protect foreigners or stateless persons who are persecuted or under the threat of being persecuted in their home country because of their race, religion, nationality or political views.

According to the bill, a panel is to be made up of officials from the Ministry of the Interior, Ministry of the Foreign Affairs, National Security Bureau, and well-respected civilians to review applications for political asylum.
People who are granted political asylum will be able to work in Taiwan and be covered by the National Health Insurance.

Taiwan has done its part in settling cases of international refugees despite the absence of a legal framework for such individuals. The country took in 3,000 refugees from Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos in 1975 and 6,000 refugees from Vietnam in 1976.
The political refugee bill, once legislated, will bring Taiwan in line with the civilized nations in this regard, according to an official of the Ministry of the Interior.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 2, or the fifth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1100: William II, known as "William Rufus," king of England from 1087, is slain by an arrow while hunting in New Forest. He was succeeded by his younger brother, who became Henry I.
1798: A 14-vessel naval squadron commanded by Rear Adm. Horatio Nelson scores a brilliant tactical victory over a French fleet of 17 vessels in the Mediterranean.
1918: British, French, and U.S. troops try to smash Lenin's communist revolution by supporting the White Russian forces and seizing Archangel.
1921: Enrico Caruso, the Neapolitan with the golden voice known as the world's greatest tenor of his time, dies at the Hotel Vesuvio in Naples at the age of 48.
1922: Alexander Graham Bell, Scottish inventor of the telephone in 1876, dies at the age of 76.
1923: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, dies in office at the age of 58. He made several misguided appointments that led to a corrupt administration.
1924: The Kwangchow government sets up the Central Bank of China with T.V. Soong (Soong Tzu-wen) as governor.
1934: Paul von Hindenburg, German general, politician, and president of the Weimar Republic, dies at the age of 86. He was succeeded by Adolf Hitler who declared himself "Der Fuhrer."
1938: Chinese troops blow up a bank along a section of the upper Yangtze River in an attempt to slow a Japanese advance.
1939: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, writes to U.S. President Roosevelt urging him to start an atomic project.
1944: Joseph P. Kennedy Jr., U.S. Navy pilot and elder brother of John F. Kennedy, is killed when his plane explodes over the Belgian coast.
1945: The Potsdam Conference, the final Allied summit of World War II, comes to an end.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Dahomey, Niger and Upper Volta.
1961: President John F. Kennedy and visiting ROC Vice President Chen Cheng issue a joint statement in Washington, D.C., opposing the admission of mainland China into the United Nations.
1964: President Lyndon B. Johnson orders a retaliatory strike after a torpedo attack on the U.S. Navy ship Maddox in the Gulf of Tonkin.
1980: The International Telecommunications Administration inaugurates direct dialing station-to-station telephone service between Taipei and major cities in Britain, France and West Germany.
1985: Kuo Yu-hsin, former member of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, dies of illness in Washington, D.C., at the age of 77.
1986: The ROC delegation to the Aug. 4 ROC-U.S. trade talks, headed by Board of Foreign Trade Director-General Vincent C. Siew, leaves for Washington, D.C.
1990: Saddam Hussein makes good on Iraq's claim to the oil-rich state of Kuwait by invading it. Thousands of heavily armed Iraqi troops quickly cut through the defenses of their tiny Gulf neighbor and gain firm control of the capital city of Kuwait City.
1996: Michel Debre, former French prime minister, dies at the age of 84. He was Charles de Gaulle's trusted aide and the architect of the Fifth Republic.
1997: Typhoon Victor injures 32 people in Hong Kong.
1999: The ROC representative to Japan, Chuang Ming-yao, expresses his grave concern to his Japanese counterpart about a plan by a group of Japanese lawmakers to land on the Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea.
2000: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan leads a delegation of senior KMT officials to pay a courtesy call on ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh at the DPP headquarters in Taipei.
2000: The Asian Witness Center of the Guinness Book of World Records announces two of Taiwan's record-setting fathers as part of celebrations for Father's Day, which falls on Aug. 8. One of the record-breakers is Lo Tseng-wen, who has five children serving as police officers, and the other is Chang A-piao, a centenarian who is living with four generations of offspring under the same roof.
2001: The final section of the 11.307-kilometer New Kuanyin Tunnel of the North Link Railway is blasted through, making it the longest two-way railway tunnel in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By banishing all flatterers and keeping away from the society of women; holding in low estimation possession of worldly goods, but valuing moral qualities in men: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to worthy men."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times:
Candidates in Hualien magistrate by-election rally support on the eve of the vote.
The United Daily News:
Candidates hit the streets on the eve of Hualien poll.
The Liberty Times:
Race to be Hualien magistrate going down to the wire.
The Taiwan Daily:
Pan-green camp winds up campaign.
The Central Daily News:
Pan-blue heavyweights stump for Hsieh.
The China Post:
Heated Hualien race draws political stars to final rallies.
The Taiwan News:

The Taipei Times:
MOFA coy over Nauru's political return.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUALIEN VOTERS GO TO POLLS TO ELECT NEW MAGISTRATE

TEXT.P: Voters in the eastern county of Hualien went to polls Saturday to elect a new magistrate to serve out the remainder of a four-year term left vacant by Chang Fu-hsing, who died in May from lung cancer.
A total of 256,685 Hualien residents are eligible to vote in the by-election.
Polls opened at 8 a.m. and will close at 4 p.m. Voter turnout is expected to be high as the three-way race hit a fever pitch on the eve of the election day.

A large number of voters began making long lines at polling stations in the county's 13 townships. Voting has so far proceeded orderly and smoothly. The electoral result is expected to come out by 8 p.m.

You Ying-lung, a scholar-turned-politician who is representing the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the race, cast his ballot in the company of his wife. He then sang a Taiwanese folk song in honor of his wife who originally opposed her husband's participation in the by-election, but later devoted her full energies to helping with his campaign. This is You's third bid for the Hualien magistrateship.

Wu Guo-tung, a former Hualien magistrate who was expelled from the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) because of his insistence on running in the by-election, cast his ballot at around 9 a.m in the company of his daughters and several supporters. Wu has been accused of involvement in a corruption scandal which is still pending a court ruling. There has been speculation that the case might be the reason behind the KMT's refusal to nominate him for the by-election.
Wu, a Hakka political heavyweight in Hualien, has received the blessing of some politicians from the opposition People First Party (PFP) in defiance of their party's stance.

The "pan-blue" alliance of the KMT and the PFP nominated Hsieh Shen-shan, a veteran politician who once served as Cabinet secretary-general during the KMT administration and as a legislator for seven terms, to run in the Hualien by-election.
Hualien, an economic backwater in Taiwan, has traditionally been a KMT stronghold. But some observers said the split in the "pan-blue" camp this time might give the DPP a chance.

As the "pan-blue" alliance's top two leaders -- KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong -- have decided to form a joint ticket to challenge President Chen Shui-bian's re-election bid next year, political observers have said the Hualien by-election provides a good opportunity for the two camps to rehearse their campaign strategies for the 2004 presidential race. Several analysts have also said the Hualien race could serve as a litmus test of the "pan-blue" alliance's solidarity.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. STANDS FIRMLY COMMITTED TO TRA: WHITE HOUSE SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: White House spokesman Scott McClellan on Friday said that the United States is concerned about increasing deployments of weapons in mainland China, adding that Washington "stands firmly committed to the Taiwan Relations Act" and that it will help the island.

The spokesman made the remarks at a daily media briefing while responding to a question regarding whether President George W. Bush discussed the Pentagon's recent report during his Wednesday telephone conversation with Chinese President Hu Jintao.

The report, which was released Wednesday, suggests that Beijing continues to view the United States as a long-term threat and is continuing rapidly to build ballistic missiles not only capable of reaching Taiwan, but also a longer-range missile capable of reaching Japan and U.S. troops stationed in Asia.

While indicating that the purpose of the two presidents' conversation was primarily to talk about the situation in North Korea, McClellan said that Washington's position is very clear on the issue brought up by the reporter's question.

"We have made it very clear -- our concerns about Chinese increasing their weapons. And we've made it very clear that we stand firmly committed to the Taiwan Relations Act, and we will be there to help Taiwan," he said.

"And what we want to emphasize is that those parties, Taiwan and China, need to have a dialogue on this. They need to talk about these issues together, to pursue a peaceful resolution to these issues." McClellan said.

McClellan had already expressed Washington's concerns Thursday about mainland Chinese increasing deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan and said that the White House has always been committed to the Taiwan Relations Act.

According to the Pentagon's report, mainland China possesses about 450 short-range ballistic missiles and is expected to add about 75 more annually over the next few years. The report also warns that mainland China's modernizing military could enable it to carry out a surprise attack on Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMPHETAMINE PRODUCTION LAB RAIDED IN CHIAYI

TEXT.P: An amphetamine production facility was uncovered in a mountainous township in Chiayi County in southern Taiwan Saturday, the sixth discovered this year.

Two men suspected of running the operation were arrested in a pre-dawn raid at the facility in Chuchi township. Also seized were more than 90 kilograms of amphetamines and semi-finished products as well as a variety of production equipment.

Investigators said the factory originally produced tea. The two suspects, surnamed Lin and Ku, leased the property earlier this year allegedly to produce amphetamines. They used tea leaf bags to package the drugs to evade detection.
Acting on a tip-off, the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau's (MJIB) southern Taiwan branch, its Chiayi outpost and the Chiayi County Police Bureau formed a team in late June.

"Investigators have had difficulty tracking suspected drug dealers and production labs since the people involved make it their business to stay one step ahead of us," an MJIB agent said. "They are continually changing the locations of their operations and switching vehicles and modes of communication," he added.
Law enforcement agent took advantage of the current longan harvest season to dress as farmers to get closer to suspects and monitor their activities.

The investigative team arrested Lin and Ku when they came to the facility early Saturday to pick up their drugs. Investigators said that they are continuing to cast a dragnet to find others involved in the operation.
An MJIB official said the bureau raided seven amphetamine production labs in Taiwan last year. In the past seven months, 563.4 kilograms of amphetamines have been seized.

All these figures indicate that drug traffickers have again made Taiwan a production base, the official said, adding that the trend is a result of the fact that a mainland Chinese crackdown on amphetamine production in the past couple of years has prompted many from Taiwan who were producing the drugs to return home.

After MJIB agents raided a large-scale amphetamine production lab in Taipei in 1994 and arrested five suspects, nearly all of local amphetamine producing rings relocated to the southeastern mainland province of Fujian which lies opposite Taiwan. They then used fishing boats to smuggle amphetamines back to Taiwan for sales or colluded with mainland drug dealers to sell their products in mainland China or overseas. With an increasing awareness of amphetamine's health hazrads, mainland China launched an all-out campaign against the drug in 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: 34TH INTERNATIONAL PHYSICS OLYMPIAD TO OPEN IN TAIPEI SUNDAY

TEXT.P: Outstanding senior high school students from 54 countries began arriving in Taiwan Saturday for the 34th International Physics Olympiad (IPhO) to be held in Taipei Aug. 3-8.
The competition, jointly organized by the Ministry of Education and the National Science Council, has been referred to as the "Olympic Games for Physics."
The Physics Olympiad was originally scheduled to open in mid-July, but was postponed because of the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) , which hit Taiwan hardest in May and June.

Although the number of countries participating in the event has fallen from the original 68 to 54, competition is expected to remain fierce judging by the number of students pouring over books from the moment they arrived in Taiwan.
Taiwan will send five top physics students, selected from some 4,500 students, to the competition, in which a total of 240 competitors will participate.

Two world-renowned physicists of Chinese origin -- the 1976 Nobel Prize winner in physics Dr. Samuel C.C. Ting, and the superconductivity expert Dr. Paul Chu -- have been invited to deliver speeches Aug. 8.

This marks the first time that Taiwan will have organized the International Physics Olympiad. Taiwan teams have performed well in the Olympiad the last two years by gaining three gold, one silver and one bronze medal last year, and two gold, one silver and two bronze medals in 2001, which represented fifth place among participating countries.
The island organized the 1998 International Mathematics Olympiad and will organize the International Chemistry Olympiad in 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN ENGLISH TEACHERS TO BE IMPORTED INTO TAIWAN BY YEAR'S END

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) is planning to bring in over 400 English teachers from overseas by the end of this year to upgrade the standard of English teaching in Taiwan, an education official said Saturday.

Chen Ming-ying, deputy director of MOE's Department of Elementary Education, made the remarks when he accompanied Minister of Education Huang Jung-chun to Taitung, eastern Taiwan to inspect the academic proficiency tests for junior high school students there.
Chen said that the ministry is now contacting trade and economic offices and cultural centers of the United Kingdom, the United States, Australia, and Canada that are based in Taiwan.

Once the contracts are signed, the English teachers will first take a one-month class in Taiwan to learn more about the culture and educational situation in Taiwan. The minister will also ask cities and counties to have one college or university serve as a communication channel so that the English teachers can adapt to their new environment quickly.

But Chen stressed that the mission of the English teachers is to provide guidance to help upgrade English teaching standards, and will "by no means affect the employment opportunity of local English teachers. "

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TOP SARS COORDINATOR TO VISIT WASHINGTON, D.C.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 1 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Lee Ming-liang, Taiwan's top coordinator in the fight against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) , will fly into Washington, D.C. Saturday for a three-day visit.
The former Minister of the Department of Health will be in Washington, D.C. mainly to attend a health seminar sponsored by the Center for Strategic & International Studies.

Lee will also meet with U.S. health officials and express his appreciation to overseas Chinese living in the greater Washington, D.C. area who donated cash or surgical masks to Taiwan people during the height of SARS in Taiwan.

Learning of Lee's visit, a team of experts from the Atlanta-based Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) will fly to Washington, D.C. to meet with Lee and discuss Taiwan's SARS situation and experiences.
The CDC officials said that given the scarcity of negative pressure hospital wards in the United States, containing outbreaks in the United States could prove challenging.

SARS hit Taiwan in mid-March, but only sporadic cases were reported before a cluster transmission in Taipei Municipal Hoping Hospital changed the situation. The disease eventually claimed 84 lives and affected 678 people in Taiwan before it was contained in late June.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER TO LEAVE FOR U.S. ON TRADE PROMOTION VISIT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu will leave for the United States Aug. 9, at the head of a delegation seeking more trade opportunities for local companies.

Lin will make the one-week-visit amid media reports that the Unites States has suspended visits by its high-level trade officials to Taiwan because of the island's lackluster progress in protecting intellectual property rights and in fulfilling its promises made prior to its entry into the World Trade Organization.
However, Lin said earlier that communications between trade officials of both countries have always been smooth.
During his stay in the United States, Lin will visit Los Angeles, San Diego, Chicago, Wilmington of Delaware and New York.

In addition to organizing a trade symposium in Chicago, the Taiwan delegation will also visit some American companies, including DuPont and Motorola. Lin will invite these large U.S. companies to send representatives to a large trade conference slated for October in Taipei in search of more trade and cooperation projects for local and foreign businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADITION FESTIVAL TO BE CELEBRATED IN VANCOUVER

TEXT.P: People in Vancouver will celebrate the Taiwan Tradition Festival in September, during which a dragon boat contest will be held.
Four dragon boats will be shipped from Taiwan later this month for the contest. The boats will be carried to Vancouver by China Airlines.
Vancouver Mayor Royce Polland has proclaimed Sept. 5 as "Taiwan Day" in the city. There are more than 7,000 Taiwanese Americans living in the city.

Lo You-chung, director general of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Vancouver, visited Polland Friday and presented him the model of a dragon boat as a token of friendship. (by Y.K. Lin and EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: INJURED TAIWAN TOURIST UNDERGOES SURGERY IN SEOUL
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Y.C. Chiang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan tourist underwent surgery in a Seoul hospital Saturday for a shoulder fracture sustained in a tour bus accident the previous night.

Lin Li-yun, 52, was part of an 18-member group from Kaohsiung that arrived in Seoul July 31 for a five-day tour. The group was on its way to a tower in Seoul Friday night to view the city by night when the bus hit a large flower pot on the side of the road.
Seoul police are looking into the possibility of brake failure in the accident.
Eight other tourists sustained minor cuts and bruises.
Lin's husband and daughter, who were also in the group, suffered minor sprains.
The Republic of China's Representative to Seoul, Lee Tsai-fang, and other officials visited Lin at the hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG TO IMPLEMENT U.S.-INITIATED CONTAINER SECURITY INITIATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 1 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States will start talks with Taiwan for including Kaohsiung Harbor into its Container Security Initiative (CSI) which is designed to detect and deter terrorists from exploiting the vulnerabilities of container cargo, customs sources said Friday.

According to the sources, the United States has invited Kaohsiung Harbor officials to visit Washington, D.C. later this month for initial consultations and is scheduled to send a delegation to Taiwan in September to start formal negotiations.
Kaohsiung is the only one of the world's top 20 container ports that has not yet joined the CSI program. Mainland China's Shanghai and Shenzhen began implementing the CSI in late July.

The CSI program allows for targeting and pre-screening of cargo destined for the United States. Once Kaohsiung joins the program, the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) will deploy a team of officers to the port to work with host government personnel to target high-risk cargo containers destined for the United States.

The CSI consists of four core elements: 1) using intelligence and automated information to identify and target high-risk containers; 2) pre-screening those containers identified as high-risk, at the port of departure, before they arrive at U.S. ports; 3) using detection technology to quickly pre-screen high-risk containers; and 4) using smarter, tamper-evident containers.

The CSI is also a reciprocal program which allows participating countries to send their customs officers to major U.S. ports to target cargo that is being exported to their country via ocean containers.

The United States adopted the CSI after the "911" terrorist attacks in New York and Washington in 2001. The world's top 20 ports are points of passage for about 68 percent of cargo containers shipped to the United States each year.

According to data unveiled by the U.S. Homeland Security Department, the operational CSI ports include Rotterdam, Le Havre, Bremerhaven, Hamburg, Antwerp, Singapore, Yokohama, Hong Kong, Gotenborg, Felixstowe, Genoa, Vancouver, Montreal, Halifax, Shanghai and Shenzhen.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGE TAIWAN GROUP IN BEIJING TO REKINDLE CROSS-STRAIT TOURISM

TEXT.P: A large delegation from Taiwan is in Beijing to promote tourism, which was hard hit by the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

According to official statistics, Taiwan people made 7.62 million visits abroad last year. Included are the number of mainland China-bound visits via Hong Kong, Macau or other countries which reached 3.7 million.
Mainland China has become the most popular destination for tourists from Taiwan.
However, travel between Taiwan and mainland China nearly froze in March, when SARS began to affect both sides.
The delegation, composed of over 300 people, represents the largest tourism promotion group that Taiwan has sent to mainland China after the SARS outbreaks.
Due to the lifting of quarantine requirements for travelers from mainland China and discounts offered by airlines, mainland-bound air tickets are in great demand, tourist agents said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' CANDIDATE WINS HUALIEN MAGISTRATE BY-ELECTION

TEXT.P: Hsieh Shen-shan, who represented the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) in the Hualien County magistrate by-election, claimed victory in the hotly contested, three-way race Saturday.
The final vote count has yet to be released, but results available at 5:30 p.m. showed that Hsieh had the support of more than half of the eastern county's 256,685 eligible voters.

Independent candidate Wu Guo-tung has already conceded defeat. He said he will support the "pan-blue alliance's" ticket in the 2004 presidential election. KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong have formed a joint ticket to challenge President Chen Shui-bian's re-election bid next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEVELOPMENT OF PINGTUNG EXPORT PROCESSING ZONE TO FINISH IN 2005

TEXT.P: The development of an export processing zone in Pingtung County for the biotechnology and auto industries will be completed by the end of 2005, an official of the Export Processing Zone Administration said Saturday.

Occupying an area of 124 hectares, the new export processing zone is only 20 to 30 minutes away by car from the Kaohsiung Harbor and the Kaohsiung International Airport. It will become a part of the free trade harbor area of Kaohsiung, the biggest city in southern Taiwan.
The official said that the sewer system in the zone has just been completed and that the road system and the installation of electrical facilities and pipes will be completed in March, 2004. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CONGRATULATES NEW HUALIEN MAGISTRATE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian offered his felicitations to Hsieh Shen-shan Saturday on the opposition "pan-blue alliance" candidate's victory in the just-concluded Hualien County magistrate by-election.

Chen extended his congratulations in a Presidential Office news release issued immediately after the final vote count was released. Hsieh, who represented the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) in the hotly contested, three-way race, received 73,641 votes, far more than his two contenders combined.
The president said in the news release that he is satisfied with the peaceful, professional proceeding of the by-election in the eastern county.
Chen also expressed his gratitude for the devoted services of police officers and election workers who helped ensure that the election process went smoothly.
Meanwhile, Chen said he is hopeful that Hsieh can closely cooperate with the central government in boosting Hualien's development for the benefit of its residents.

Chen also spoke highly of the two defeated candidates -- You Ying-lung, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's nominee who garnered 41,513 votes in the election, and Wu Kuo-tung, a former Hualien magistrate who ran as an independent and captured 26,200 votes.
Chen encouraged the two losers to continue dedicating themselves to public service.
The by-election was held to elect a new magistrate to serve out the remainder of the four-year term left vacant by Chang Fu-hsing who died from lung cancer in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEATHER BUREAU ISSUES SEA WARNING FOR TYPHOON MORAKOT

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau issued a sea warning for Typhoon Morakot Saturday evening, the ninth tropical storm in the Pacific this year.
A bureau weatherman said the original low pressure system near Luzon Island, Philippines, had gained momentum rapidly Saturday afternoon to become a light typhoon.

At 6: 00 p.m. Saturday, Typhoon Morakot, located some 500 kilometers off Taiwan's southeastern coast, was moving northwest toward the island at a speed of 15 kilometers per hour, the weather bureau forecaster said, adding that the typhoon will be some 220 kilometers off Taiwan's southeastern coast at 2:00 p.m Sunday.
As the typhoon continued gaining strength, the forecaster warned ships operating in the Bashi Channel and along Taiwan's southeastern coast to pay special attention to weather conditions.
Typhoon Morakot is expected to bring rain to eastern and southern parts of Taiwan tomorrow.

Meanwhile, a low pressure front formed near Guam earlier than Morakot is still moving slowly toward the South Pacific island. The weather bureau is watching closely whether this low pressure front will developed into another typhoon.
