DOC.HEADLINE: CLEARING THE NAMES OF 2-28 INCIDENT VICTIMS A MILESTONE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that clearing the names of the victims of the 2-28 Incident is a milestone for the nation as its democracy and human rights mature.

The president made the remarks when he presented rehabilitation certificates to each of the victims or the representatives of the victims of the 2-28 Incident in a ceremony held at the Presidential Office. The certificates were co-signed by Chen and Vice President Annette Lu.

"The 2-28 Incident was the biggest wound of Taiwan history since World War II, " the president said. "The people of Taiwan wanted social justice and democratic reforms, but were relentlessly suppressed by the Nationalist government, resulting in heavy casualties of Taiwan elites and average civilians."
The Nationalist government, trying to cover its actions, labeled the incident a "mutiny," and the victims "mobsters," he added.

The president said that a rehabilitation certificate will not bring back past lives, but he was convinced that the incident was brought into the public consciousness only after the efforts of so many democratic forerunners.

After "scores of years of declassifying files and the investigation of oral historians, " the president said the 2-28 Incident is no longer just a "violent disturbance, " or described as "Communist China orchestrating mobsters, " but was "a protest against social injustice, a demand for democracy, and the advocacy of Taiwan people ruling Taiwan," which he said has become the "2-28 spirit" and an "asset of Taiwan's historical culture."

He stressed that to "right the wrongs, pursue historical truth and social justice is the root of a nation based on human rights, and the rehabilitation of names of the 2-28 Incident is the upholding of human rights, and a milestone for Taiwan."

He extended his apologies again to the victims and their relatives for their sufferings over the years, hoping that every one in Taiwan would "learn from the incident, and work toward making Taiwan a just, peaceful country with dignity."

Addressing the same occasion, Vice President Lu said that there should not be only concerts and flowers in memory of the incident each year, but that all generations should "learn the historical truth."
The 2-28 Memorial Foundation has agreed to do more to let the nation learn about the incident, she said.
Lu said that many international figures have asked her who was the real culprit behind the 2-28 Incident. Finding the truth is the responsibility of all citizens, she said.
Ouyang Wen, a representative of the victims, echoed Lu's views, saying that everyone should be positive about the government's efforts to clear the names of the victims.

He also said that education about the 2-28 Incident is insufficient to allow the younger generation to understand the truth and reflect on the tragedy, adding that the event should serve as a major indicator of the future direction of the nation.

The 2-28 Incident in 1947 was triggered when an elderly Taiwanese woman selling untaxed cigarettes in Taipei was severely beaten by an inspector of the Wine and Tobacco Monopoly Bureau. Faced by an angry mob, the inspector shot dead a bystander and fled to a nearly police station.

Faced by massive protests and rioting and unable to control the Situation, Taiwan Governor Chen Yi appealed for help to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in mainland China, who sent troops to the northern port city of Keeling, from where they spread out over the island, killing along the way.

In the ensuing period known as "White Terror," thousands of local people, especially doctors, lawyers and scholars, were murdered or imprisoned by the Nationalists, and many were not released until the 1980s. Public discussion of the incident was taboo until the early 1990s.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CANDIDATE CONCEDES DEFEAT IN HUALIEN BY-ELECTION

TEXT.P: You Ying-lung, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate for the Hualien County magistrate by-election, conceded defeat Saturday and reaffirmed his commitment to pushing for the county's development in various fields.

You, a scholar-turned-politician, said he accepts defeat squarely. He offered his felicitations to Magistrate-elect Hsieh Shen-shan and urged Hsieh to do everything he can to boost the eastern county's development after assuming office.
You said he had adhered to his promise to "campaign in style" and refrain from any mud-slinging tactics in the run-up to the election.
Throughout the campaign, You said he had presented many policy initiatives with a view to promoting development in Hualien which has been an economic backwater in Taiwan.

You said he feels a bit of regret that his policy initiatives have failed to win the blessing of Hualien voters. You said he will make more efforts in the future to push for the upgrading of Hualien's political culture and quality of life as well.

This was the fourth time that You lost an election in the Hualien constituency -- three for magistrateship and one for a legislative seat. You said he will not be daunted by the setbacks. He also asked his supporters not to feel bad for his latest defeat.

"Don't cry for me! My dear supporters, " an emotional You said in his concession speech. "The light in my Hualien office will never be turned off. I'll continue to work for Hualien residents' well-being."
You finished second in the hotly-contested, three-way race, with 41,508 votes. Magistrate-elect Hsieh Shen-shan garnered 73,710 votes, more than half of the total votes cast in the poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFEATED WU KUO-TUNG SAYS HE IS THROUGH WITH POLITICS

TEXT.P: Wu Kuo-tung, a former Hualien magistrate who was defeated in Saturday's Hualien County magistrate by-election, said he will no longer be involved in political affairs in the future.
Wu, who ran as an independent, was defeated by Hsieh Shen-shan, candidate of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP).
Hsieh garnered 73,710 votes, and Wu 26,205 in the election, while another main candidate, You Ying-lung, who represented the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, received 41,508 votes.

Wu, who was expelled from the main opposition KMT because of his insistence on running in the by-election, said although he failed in the election, he tried his best to serve his supporters and the defeat represents no humiliation for him.

Although expelled from the KMT, Wu said he has no complaints about KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong, who have formed a joint ticket in the 2004 presidential race, and hailed Lien as an open-minded man.
Noting that he will now return to normal life, Wu nevertheless insisted that he belongs to the "pan-blue alliance."

DOC.HEADLINE: HUALIEN ELECTION FOREBODES UPHILL BATTLE FOR PRESIDENTIAL RACE: LIEN

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , said Saturday that the Hualien by-election indicates "an uphill battle in the next seven months in the run-up to the presidential election."

Lien, who will team up with James Soong, chairman of the People First Party (PFP), for the presidential election on March 20, 2004, made the remarks after Hsieh Sheng-san, a joint candidate from the KMT and the PFP, beat You Ying-lung, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate, by a wide margin in the election to serve out the remaining term to the end of 2005 left by late Magistrate Chang Fu-hsing.
Lien said that he was convinced that Hsieh "will definitely deliver on his campaign promises and build Hualien into a happy county."

But he also said that "there are so many regrets" after the election because during the process, the DPP "made good use of its huge administrative resources," and that their "words and deeds set a bad example."

President Chen Shui-bian, who concurrently serves as the DPP chairman, Vice President Annette Lu, Premier You Shyi-kun and many DPP heavyweights stumped for You in the campaign. The Ministry of the Interior sent in large police force and set up road-side check points several days prior to the hotly contested election to try to stop vote-buying.

Meanwhile, PFP Chairman James Soong said, "Hsieh's landslide victory was a triumph of the people of Hualien and the pride of Taiwan's democracy. The undemocratic practices of the DPP backfired as evidenced by the way the people turned their backs to the party' candidate."
Soong also phoned Wu Kuo-tung, the former KMT member who ran independently after failing to get the endorsement of the party and who was eventually expelled from the KMT, after the election.

Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP's policy center, observed that Wu still has solid support at the grassroots level and his image is good. Hualien voters only switched sides after the rivalry of the ruling and the opposition camps heated up.

Chang stressed that the by-election was the first joint nomination of the PFP and the KMT, which is strategically significant, and has proved that the cooperation of the two parties will be a plus for each party.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO HUALIEN DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday the Hualien by-election result will not affect the Cabinet's commitment to boosting development in the eastern county.

Yu made the remarks after the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" candidate Hsieh Shen-shan claimed victory in the just-concluded poll which was held to elect a new magistrate to serve out the four-year term left vacant by Chang Fu-hsing who died from lung cancer in May.

Yu said the poll has provided a good opportunity for the government to review Hualien's infrastructure construction. All of the construction projects that the government has promised to undertake to improve the county's transportation system and speed up its economic development will be carried out as scheduled.

The projects include the construction of an expressway linking Hualien to Suao in Ilan County, the electrification of the North-Link Railway, expansion of the Hualien International Airport and renovation of Hualien harbor facilities.
Yu also offered his felicitation to Hsieh. The premier exhorted Hsieh to deliver on his campaign promise to turn Hualien from an economic backwater to a modernized tourist capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOTER TURNOUT IN HUALIEN BY-ELECTION STANDS AT 55.91 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Voter turnout in the Hualien County magistrate by-election Saturday was 55.91 percent, with 143,511 valid ballots among 256,685 eligible voters.

Hsieh Shen-san, who represented the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) , received 73,710 votes, accounting for 51.4 percent of the votes, while You Ying-lung from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) garnered 41,518 votes or 28.9 percent. Wu Kuo-tung, a former Hualien magistrate who ran as an independent, received 26,205 votes or 18.3 percent.
Taiwan Solidarity Union Deputy Secretary-General Chen Hung-chi on Saturday blamed the low voter turnout to the long-term apathy shown by the country's three largest political parties in the area.
Chen noted that although the election will have little impact on next year's presidential election, it represented a lesson which the ruling DPP should study.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUALIEN BY-ELECTION SEEN AS SIGN OF SUCCESS FOR 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE'

TEXT.P: The victory of Hsieh Shen-san in the Hualien magistrate by-election Saturday is a sign of success for the "pan-blue alliance" of the major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First-Party (PFP) in the 2004 presidential election, a KMT leader said Saturday.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan has selected PFP Chairman James Soong as his running mate for the presidential election and the two parties strongly supported Hsieh in Saturday's by-election.

Lee Chia-chin, a leader of the KMT caucus at the Legislative Yuan said the "pan-blue alliance" has full confidence in its ability to win the presidential election, as long as the two parties continue to cooperate.
Lee said Hsieh's victory is partly attributable to the dissatisfaction of the general public with the performance of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) over the past three years.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said that the by-election was a litmus test for the solidarity of the "pan-blue alliance, " and that Hsieh's victory indicates the cooperation between the KMT and PFP is successful.

Hsieh said the by-election is a prelude to the upcoming presidential election. He expressed the hope that the general public will use their ballots to end the chaotic DPP rule and revive the economy of Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Hsieh said at a news conference that his victory has proved that the KMT and PFP can cooperate successfully. He said he will do his best to fulfill all promises he made during his by-election campaign. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: HSIEH SHEN-SHAN WINS LANDSLIDE VICTORY IN HUALIEN BY-ELECTION

TEXT.P: Hsieh Shen-shan, the candidate of the "pan-blue alliance" of the major opposition Kuomintang and People-First-Party, won 73,710 votes, or 51.4 percent of the total ballots cast in Saturday's Hualien magistrate by-election.

He was followed by You Ying-lung, candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, with 41,508 votes, or 28.9 percent, and independent candidate Wu Kuo-tung, with 26,205 votes or 18.3 percent, according to the statistics compiled by the Hualien Election Committee.
The committee said there were 256,685 eligible voters. Voter turnout was estimated at 55.91 percent. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: HUALIEN BY-ELECTION WINNER TO INVITE RIVALS TO BUILD COUNTY

TEXT.P: Hsieh Shen-shan, joint candidate of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) and magistrate-elect in Hualien County, on Saturday urged his formal rivals to leave the election behind and join him in bettering Hualien.

Hsieh shouted "Hsieh Shen-san won, Hualien people won, KMT-PFP cooperation won" after he learned that he beat You Ying-lung, a scholar-turned-politician nominated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , by garnering 51.4 percent of the votes against You's 28.9 percent.

The third candidate, Wu Kuo-tung, a former Hualien magistrate and a veteran KMT member who was expelled from the party after he insisted on running despite failing to get the endorsement from the party, received 18.3 percent of the votes. In the five-way race, the other two candidates were considered also-rans.

Hsieh expressed his appreciation for the stumping efforts of the KMT and PFP, especially KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong who had "braced the sweltering summer heat to stump" for him over the past days.

He said that his election proves that "a clean election can still win," and highlights the quality of Hualien people as well as serving as a litmus test for the alliance between the KMT and PFP, a combination for success.
Hsieh vowed to deliver on his campaign promises. He also will call Wu Kuo-tung to learn from his rich experience in Hualien, and will invite You to help him build up Hualien.
Hsieh shouted to his supporters: "Taiwan's happiness starts from Hualien," and "Hualien's happiness starts from us."
Hsieh also said that he never said that he would only serve one term as Hualien magistrate, saying that the length of his term will be decided by the Hualien people alone.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COMPUTER APPLICATION SHOW DRAWS 200,000 VISITORS IN FOUR DAYS

TEXT.P: Taipei, Aug. 2 (CNA): The 2003 Taipei Computer Application Show has attracted more than 200,000 visitors in the past four days.
The exhibition, being held July 30-Aug. 3 at the Taipei World Trade Center, drew 66,433 visitors on Saturday, organizers of the show said.
The exhibition features new models of computers, peripherals, and computer software. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS SEE NO RELATION BETWEEN HUALIEN ELECTION AND 2004 RACE

TEXT.P: Two scholars said Saturday they see few links between the just-concluded Hualien County magistrate by-election and the 2004 presidential election.

The Hualien poll, which was aimed at electing a new magistrate to serve out the remainder of the four-year term left vacant by Chang Fu-hsing who died from lung cancer in May, was seen by many as the last chance for rivaling domestic political camps to rehearse their campaign strategies for next year's presidential election.

Two political science professors said the landslide victory of Hsieh Shen-shan, who represented the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) in the by-election, was expected to boost the alliance's morale.
Nevertheless, they said the Hualien poll was a local election whose result couldn't serve as a guide for the 2004 presidential race.

Prof. Sheng Chih-jen of Soochow University said Hualien voters account for less than 1.5 percent of the nation's total eligible voters. Moreover, he said, Hualien's population structure differs significantly from that of the whole island. In Hualien, the island's four major ethnic groups -- Hokien, Hakka, aborigines and mainlanders -- are roughly the same.

"This structure is seldom seen in other areas of the island, " he noted, adding that Hualien has traditionally been a "pan-blue" stronghold where the KMT has controlled its magistrateship uninterrupted for more than five decades. In contrast, he said, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has a limited power base in the eastern county.
Given all these elements, Sheng said, the Hualien outcome is not expected to have a decisive effect on the next presidential election.

Pro. Wang Yeh-li of Tunghai University, seconded Sheng's comments, saying that the Hualien poll was a local-level election and could only be seen as a rehearsal of campaign strategies ahead of next year's race between the "pan-blue alliance" and the "pan-green" camp of the DPP and its pro-independence ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan also stressed that the Hualien by-election was basically not a party-to-party race nor was it a prelude to the 2004 presidential election.

Lee acknowledged that the DPP campaigned all out for its candidate You Ying-lung. "We lost partly because we didn't do enough over the long term to cultivate our support base in the county, which contains a large area. Our candidate began campaigning only three weeks before the vote. We must devote more energies to building our power base in the region and fine tuning our campaign tactics in the future," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 3, or the sixth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
216: An army led by Carthaginian General Hannibal defeats a huge Roman army, seizing its supply depot in the Battle of Cannae and killing some fifty thousand Roman soldiers.
1460: Scottish King James II is killed by the English during the siege of Roxburgh Castle.
1492: A flotilla of three ships, led by Christopher Columbus, sets sail from the Spanish port of Palos de la Frontera in search of a land called India.
1867: Stanley Baldwin, British Conservative prime minister three times between 1923 and 1937, is born.
1872: Haakon VII, Norwegian monarch who refused to surrender to the Germans in World War II, is born in Denmark.
1881: William George Fargo, American pioneer of long-distance express service, dies at his home in Buffalo, New York, at the age of 65.
1904: The Dalai Lama flees Lhasa as British troops invade Tibet. The Ching court on Aug. 26 orders the Pachen Lama to take over Tibetan affairs from the Dalai Lama.
1916: German troops launch a surprise attack on British forces in the Sinai in Egypt. Some 5,000 German soldiers are killed, while British loses amount to 1,100 men.
1929: Emile Berliner, German-born American inventor, dies in Washington D.C. at the age of 78. He greatly improved the telephone and invented the gramophone in 1887.
1940: Lithuania is formally incorporated into the Soviet Union as the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic.
1958: Nautilus, the U.S. atomic submarine, becomes the first vessel to reach the North Pole under the ice.
1959: Japan Airlines formally inaugurates its Tokyo-Taipei route.
1967: The ROC Executive Yuan decides to extend the period of compulsory education from six to nine years beginning in 1968.
1969: Minister of Economic Affairs K.T. Li (Li Kuo-ting) receives the 1968 Ramon Magsaysay Award for government service.
1972: Sheng Chin-lai is appointed dean of the Engineering College at Chiaotung University.
1972: Brig. Gen. William C. Buttows, new chief of staff of the U.S. Taiwan Defense Command, arrives in Taipei.
1973: The Flying Tiger Line inaugurates air freight services between Kaohsiung and New York.
1974: Economics Minister Y.S. Sun and Paraguayan Minister of Industry and Commerce D. Ugarte Centurionuan sign an agreement in Taipei to boost economic cooperation between the Republic of China and Paraguay.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives eight members of the U.S. 14th Air Force Association, including Mrs. Anna Chennault, widow of the 14th Air Force's commander, Maj. Gen. Claire Lee Chennault.
1977: A US$100 million loan agreement is signed in Taipei between the Taiwan Power Company and 17 banks from five foreign nations.
1981: President Ronald Reagan orders the firing of 12,000 striking air traffic control workers.
1986: Construction of the Synchronous Radiation Research Center under the Executive Yuan is started at the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park. It is scheduled for completion within five to six years.
1988: Mathias Rust, a West German youth who landed his light air plane near Moscow's Red Square in 1987, is released from prison and expelled from the Soviet Union.
1999: Nine renowned scientists and former intelligence and military officials send a letter to all 100 U.S. senators calling for the prompt ratification of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty to prevent the weaponization of stolen nuclear secrets by Communist China.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian directs the ROC Air Force to draw up a forward-looking blueprint for developing a new generation of warplanes to ensure supremacy in the skies over the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By extending the powers of their functions and allowing them discretion in the employment of their subordinates: that is how a ruler gives encouragement to the high ministers of state."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
LEADING FIGURE IN TAIWAN'S ANTI-SARS CAMPAIGN VISITING U.S. CAPITAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: One of Taiwan's leading figures in its campaign against SARS, former Department of Health Minister Lee Ming-liang, arrived in Washington, D.C., Friday to an overwhelming welcome by members of the Taiwanese communities in the eastern United States.

Lee met with members of the Taiwan Benevolence Association in the U.S. capital Saturday at a discussion that recapped Taiwan's ordeals and experiences in its battle to contain severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) between April and June.

Lee, who was appointed by President Chen Shui-bian as chief of the SARS Prevention and Relief Committee and who led the people of Taiwan in the nearly three-month fight against the flu-like disease, said SARS has been contained in Taiwan, but added that the war against the potentially-deadly disease will never end as it could resurface at anytime and anywhere.

Noting that he is does not have confidence in the verity of the information and tallies on SARS epidemic and prevention from mainland China, Lee said Taiwan should announce "SARS free" or "SARS safe" only after the disease is rooted out from the Chinese mainland once and for all.

Lee, who is in Washington for a week-long visit, is scheduled to deliver a speech at the United Nations Correspondents Association Aug. 6 on Taiwan's SARS-fighting experience in his capacity as a professor at Taiwan's Tzu Zhi University and as an international public health expert.

During his stay in the U.S. capital, Lee will meet with officials from the U.S. Department of Health and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to convey Taiwan's gratitude to the United States for its timely assistance in helping the island contain SARS.
Lee is also scheduled to take part in a symposium on public health issues to be sponsored by the think tank the Center for Strategic and International Studies.
Lee received a standing ovation Saturday when he finished his speech to the Taiwan Benevolence Association members.

He said he and the Taiwan people passed through a difficult and unforgettable ordeal during the most trying two months between May 7 and July 5 after he was appointed by President Chen Shui-bian as the head of the SARS Prevention and Relief Committee. The committee has served as a supervisory body as well as a driving force in Taiwan's battle against SARS which originated in mainland China.

He recalled that he made an announcement on May 24 in which he told the Taiwan people that they could resume their normal lives from that day. He said that the announcement was a "big gamble" when the stakes were high -- namely a time when people were losing faith, the business sector was in the doldrums, shops and restaurants were closed, streets were deserted, and the SARS outbreak was showing little signs of abating.

Lee suggested that the people in Taiwan receive influenza vaccine shots beginning in October of this year to lower the risk of flu transmission as one of the ways of preventing the reemergence of SARS.

Lee also said that he does not think it is a good idea, as some Taiwanese have suggested, that Taiwan term SARS as the "Chinese pneumonia." He said that although calling SARS the "Chinese pneumonia" may help the Taiwan people vent their anger with mainland China for under-reporting the epidemic situation there, Taiwanese of Chinese origin living in non-Chinese societies will inevitably suffer in the end as a result.

He pointed to an experience he had as an example, recalling how one day when he was on a train from Baltimore at a time when the SARS outbreak in mainland China, Taiwan and Hong Kong was making headlines around the world, a young American girl sitting not far from him stared at him nervously and said to her mother: "Look at that Chinese man, I wonder if he has SARS."

DOC.HEADLINE: COA ACTIVATES DISASTER CONTINGENCY CENTER AS TYPHOON APPROACHES

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) activated its disaster contingency center Sunday as Typhoon Morakot approached southern Taiwan.
Typhoon Morakot is expected to bring torrential rainfall and strong winds to the eastern, southern and southeastern parts of Taiwan.
The COA contingency center is helping the agricultural and fishery sectors to carry out preparedness and prevention measures against the typhoon.
As of 2 p.m. Sunday, Typhoon Morakot was located some 90 kilometers southeast of Oluanpi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, moving northwest toward the island at a speed of 19 kilometers per hour.

Taiwan's stock of fresh vegetables and fruits islandwide totaled about 4,500 metric tons as of Sunday, enough to meet domestic demand for about three weeks in the event of natural disasters triggered by the approaching typhoon, COA officials said.

According to Central Weather Bureau (CWB) forecasters, Typhoon Morakot, the ninth tropical storm in the Pacific this year, has gained momentum since noon Sunday, with the Hengchun Peninsula in southern Taiwan expected to come under the "skirt" of Morakot by the evening.
The forecasters said Typhoon Morakot is expected to pass by Taiwan's southern tip Sunday night.
Morakot, originally a low pressure system when it was located near Luzon Island, Philippines, gained momentum rapidly Saturday afternoon and was upgraded to a light typhoon.

Although Morakot is not expected to make landfall directly on Taiwan, the CWB meteorologists called for ships operating in the Bashi Channel and along Taiwan's southeastern coast to pay special attention to high waves and strong winds as the typhoon continued gaining strength.

People living in low-lying areas in the Hengchun Peninsula, Orchid Island, Green Island, Taitung, Pingtung, Kaohsiung, Tainan and Penghu should keep on guard against possible floods and landslides as Typhoon Morakot is expected to bring torrential rains and strong winds to the eastern, southern and southeastern parts of the island Monday and Tuesday.

Meanwhile, a low pressure front that had formed near Guam earlier than Morakot is still moving slowly toward the South Pacific island. The weather bureau is closely monitoring whether this low pressure front develops into another typhoon, CWB meteorologists said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST HUMAN RIGHTS MUSEUM TO BE INAUGURATED IN MARCH
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first human rights museum is slated to open in March next year in Taipei, Deputy Secretary-General to the President Chen Che-nan said here Saturday.
The purpose of the museum is to educate the people about the importance of respect for human rights and to avoid tragedies arising from authoritarian rule, Chen said.

He added that the Legislative Yuan is expected to approve the setting up of the museum during the next legislative session to clear the way for its opening slated for March 2004 before the next presidential election.

Traveling at the head of a delegation, Chen flew into Geneva from Paris earlier the same day after having visited human rights museums in Holland, Belgium and France. The delegation was greeted by Yen Ching-chang, ROC representative stationed at the World Trade Organization, and Shen Lyushung, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Geneva.

Lee Yung-chih, a professor of history at National Taiwan University and director of the museum's preparatory committee, said that both the software and hardware of the European museums are worth learning by Taiwan.

Tsai Sung-lin, a national policy advisor to President Chen Shui-bian and a long-time human rights advocate, said the planned museum aims to promote education, research and study on a wide range of human rights-related issues among the people of Taiwan.
Meanwhile, the delegation will visit various international human rights establishments in Geneva during its three-day stay. The delegation is scheduled to leave for Taiwan Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CYCLIST FAMILY COMPLETES GLOBAL TROT
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Jiang Ying and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The four-member Taiwan family that has been on a globe-trotting bicycle journey since last July rode across the Golden Gate Bridge Saturday to finish the U.S. leg of their trip, formally completing their year-long around-the-world adventure.

Mounting their heavy-duty bicycles, Huang Chin-pao, a welder, along with his wife and two teenaged sons, were accompanied by 48 bicycle-riding supporters when they began the cross-bridge ride at 9 a.m.

Among the supporters were Lee Shih-min, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco, and members of the Taiwanese and Chinese communities in California, including a nine-year-old cyclist and a 60-year-old rider as the youngest and the oldest in the group.

Cycling across the Golden Gate Bridge was probably a piece of cake for the Huangs, who have been on the road around the world over the past 12 months. However, the bridge-crossing ride can be a daunting task for people who seldom or never mount a bicycle. Yeh Chu-kuo, a consultant to the ROC government in overseas Chinese affairs, said he would not have dared to attempt it if he had not practiced cycling over the last two weeks.
The Huang family, who have been the talk of the town in Taiwanese communities across America since last year, arrived in San Francisco July 31 to prepare for their last dash.
The family is scheduled to fly back to Taiwan Sunday, formally ending their 14-country, 25,000-kilometer global trek.

The Huangs are scheduled to be feted later Saturday by the Chinese-language World Journal -- a spin-off of the United Daily News in Taiwan -- which is one of the sponsors of the Huang family's cycling trip.

On the U.S. leg of their trip, the family biked some 7,000 kilometers across the northern part of the country, beginning in New York and passing through Ohio, Illinois, Minnesota, North Dakota, Montana and Washington, among other states.
The family completed their global trip about a month earlier than expected.
Before arriving in Spokane, the largest city in eastern Washington State, the Huang family passed through the rugged Rocky Mountains -- during which they cycled 170 kilometers in a single day.
On May 3, during their stay in New York, the father of the cycling family said that the adventure had made him understand how immense and wonderful the world is.
The Huangs flew into New York May 2 from the Netherlands after having pedaled 18,000 kilometers across the Asian and European continents on specially designed bicycles.

"We have endured many hardships since starting our adventurous journey 10 months ago, but we have also received enormous returns, " Huang had told a news conference held at the New York Overseas Chinese Cultural Service Center.

The Huangs kicked off their global cycling journey from Hong Kong, first pedaling across mainland China, through the Gobi Desert and into Pakistan, where they encountered armed strife between government troops and guerrilla forces.
They took a month-long break after reaching Turkey via Iran, during which time they applied for visas to continue their ride through Bulgaria, Romania, Hungary, Austria, Germany and the Netherlands.

"Along the way, we had to endure frigid winter weather and sandstorms. However, we also enjoyed marvelous delights, particularly magnificent natural scenery and the hospitality of strangers. The trip has brought us unforgettable experiences," Huang said.

Mrs. Huang seconded her husband's account, saying that what has touched her most is the friendship and assistance from strangers. " Throughout our journey, we have received warm greetings, well wishes and assistance from numerous people. When we needed help, nobody ever turned down our request, " an emotional Huang recounted.
"This saga has further solidified my belief in the goodness of human nature. Ethnic and cultural differences did not hinder people from showing us warmth," Mr. Huang said.

The two sons -- Chien-chia and Chung-fu -- said they feel lucky to be able to accompany their parents through so many countries, to see for themselves the everyday lives of people of diverse races and religions.
Chien-chia, who will enroll in a medical college after returning to Taipei this autumn, said he was impressed by the lifestyles in Islamic countries and in certain East European nations.
"Much to my surprise, I found many people in those parts of the world are very poor. I think I'm lucky to have been born in Taiwan, as I have never experienced a lack of material goods," he said.

Chung-fu, who will enter a senior high school this fall, said he was often overwhelmed by the hospitality of the people he met during their journey. Nevertheless, he acknowledged that he felt "a bit tired" from all the pedaling.

The family had to carry a total of 200 kilograms of basic daily necessities on their heavy-duty bicycles. Mrs. Huang enjoyed the privilege of carrying less than 50 kilograms as she also cooked and did the family's laundry.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SHOULD EXAMINE ITS ELECTION STRATEGIES: V.P. LU

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should thoroughly examine its election strategies and seek improvements, Vice President Annette Lu said Sunday in the wake of the DPP's setback in the Hualien magistrate by-election.

The DPP candidate, Yu Ying-lung, despite receiving all-out support from the party as well as the administrative branch, lost to Hsieh Shen-san, the "pan-blue" alliance candidate jointly fielded by the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP).
This was the third time that Yu has failed in running for magistrate in the eastern coastal county.

Pointing out that although the population composition remains an important factor in Taiwan's elections, Yu said he still hopes that the presidential election campaign in the coming months will focus on public policies, adding that the 2004 election must not become another ideological battlefield.

In Saturday's election, Yu received 28.9 percent of the 143,511 votes, finishing far behind the KMT-PFP candidate Hsieh, who grabbed 51.4 percent of the votes. Wu Kuo-tung, a former KMT member who ran as an independent, garnered 18.3 percent of the votes.
Hsieh had the advantage of the fact that over the past decades, the remote county has been a stronghold of the KMT, with all of Hsieh's predecessors coming from the party.

Meanwhile, although the DPP refrained from discussing the effect of the KMT-PFP solidarity on the Hualien election and its possible impact on the upcoming presidential election, some pro-DPP politicians have reminded the DPP of the importance of reinforcing its strength among the grass roots.

Huang Chao-tang, chairman of the Taiwan Independence Alliance, attributed the pan-blue alliance candidate Hsieh's victory to the support of PFP Chairman James Soong, who was Taiwan governor from 1993 to 1998 and is believed to have considerable influence among local politicians and the grass roots in Hualien.

Professor Chan Chung-yuan of National Chengchi University said that while drafting campaign strategies for the 2004 presidential election, political parties can take reference from the Hualien by-election in terms of grass-roots support.

He pointed out that the population composition in Hualien -- 48 percent Minnan (southern Fukien) , 21 percent Hakka, 18 percent mainlander (other than from southern Fukien or the Hakka sector in the Canton provinces) , and 13 percent indigenous people -- is comparable to that of Taiwan's overall population composition.

Although the ruling DPP has continuously sought to dissociate the local election in Hualien from the presidential election set for March 2004, ranking party officials are also emphasizing the importance of the grass roots.
DPP Deputy Secretary-General Li Ying-yuan said Saturday evening that the setback in Hualien has taught the DPP to be even more humble and diligent in cultivating its grass-roots support.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY REBOUNDING: CEPD OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Two Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) officials said Sunday that Taiwan's economy is rebounding and that gross domestic product (GDP) growth is expected to be at least 3 percent for this year.
Ho Mei-yueh, vice chairman of the CEPD, pointed out that Taiwan's stock prices have been rising significantly since early June, which he said has helped boost consumer confidence.

Hu Chung-ying, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, said the economy is likely to grow 3.44 percent for 2003 if there are no unexpected negative developments in the second half of the year. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WELCOMES PARTICIPANTS IN INTERNATIONAL PHYSICS OLYMPIAD

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Sunday attended the opening ceremony of the 34th International Physics Olympiad being held in Taipei Aug. 3-8 and extended a warm welcome to the participants.
A total of 240 outstanding high school students from 54 countries are taking part in the contest.
Chen told them that in competition, some win and some lose, "but the friendship nurtured during competition is more valuable than anything else."
This is the first time that Taiwan has ever held an international physics Olympiad.
Samuel C.C. Ting, the 1976 Nobel Prize winner in physics, is scheduled to deliver a speech during the contest. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT SINGLED OUT FOR NEW U.S. VISA RULE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Sunday that Taiwan was not singled out for the United States' new visa application rule which came into force Aug. 1.
Applications for U.S. visas are now subject to a greater degree of scrutiny than in the past. For many applicants, a personal appearance interview is required as a standard part of visa processing.

The MOFA pointed out that the new rule is applicable to passengers from all foreign countries and is part of the global anti-terrorism campaign. It is not particularly aimed at visa applicants from Taiwan, the ministry stressed.

The MOFA said that it understands the position of the United States in this regard and that it will continue to stay in contact with U.S. authorities in the hope of reducing the impact on visa applicants to a minimum. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO VISIT SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou is scheduled to leave for Singapore Monday morning for a three-day visit.

During the visit, he will meet with Singaporean public health officials to exchange experience in controlling the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), which brokeout in the two countries earlier this year.
He will be accompanied by Deputy Mayor Ou Chin-der during the trip. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: V.P. LU ENCOURAGES FOOD MANUFACTURERS TO CREATE THEIR OWN BRAND NAMES

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu encouraged domestic food manufacturers Sunday to create their own brand names in order to promote their products in international markets.
Addressing the 2003 Formosan Golden Food Awards ceremony held in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Lu said that Taiwan is famous for a great variety of delicious foods.
To further promote Taiwan's food products in international markets, domestic manufacturers should not only try to improve the quality of their products, but also to create their own brands, Lu said.
The manufacturers should be ambitious and set the goal of "Taiwanizing" the stomachs of all people around the world, she went on.

The event, organized by the Kaohsiung-based Taiwan News, was aimed at encouraging domestic manufacturers to improve the quality of their products and hence to help Taiwan's economic development by promoting sales of Taiwan food products in international markets.
Also on hand at the ceremony were Kaohsiung Vice Mayor Lin Yung-chien and Kaohsiung City Council Speaker Chu An-hsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL BANK OVERDUE LOAN RATIO DOWN IN JUNE: FINANCE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: The overdue loan ratio posted by Taiwan-based banks fell to 5.68 percent in June, the lowest figure recorded over the past two and a half years, according to statistics released recently by the Ministry of Finance (MOF).

MOF officials attributed the drop mainly to the increase of loans granted by domestic banks, which amounted to NT$14.23 trillion (US$412.5 billion) as of the end of June, up NT$233 billion over the figure in March.
Furthermore, the officials said, the banks' efforts to improve their operations and financial structure by writing off overdue loans and selling their non-performing loans have borne fruit.
As of the end of June, overdue loans owed to the various domestic banks totaled NT$809 billion, down by NT$460 billion from the first quarter's level, they noted.
Along with the recovery in Taiwan's economy, loans granted by domestic banks are expected to further increase, they predicted, adding that the overdue loan ratio is expected to continue to fall.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUALIEN ELECTION PROVIDES VALUABLE LESSONS TO POLITICAL PARTIES

TEXT.P: Saturday's Hualien county magistrate by-election has provided valuable lessons to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as well as the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) for the 2004 presidential election, political analysts said Sunday.

The election in the eastern Taiwan county has raised questions among political observers as to why Hsieh Shen-san, the candidate jointly fielded by the KMT and PFP, defeated the DPP's You Ying-lung despite the latter receiving the all-out support of the party and administration.
Hsieh received 51.4 percent of the ballots cast, finishing far ahead of You, who received 28.9 percent.

Political observers are also asking whether the Hualien election is any measure of what the outcome might be for the 2004 presidential election in which president Chen Shui-bian is set to square off against KMT Chairman Lien Chan and his running mate PFP chief James Soong.
The KMT and PFP have repeatedly emphasized that the by-election in Hualien is a rehearsal of the presidential election and a test of the unprecedented cooperation between the two parties.

The two parties urged their supporters to engineer another "power transfer" like the one in Hualien, although the late Hualien Magistrate Chang Fu-hsin whose death triggered the by-election was a KMT member.
Soong and Lien grabbed 78 percent of votes in Hualien between them in the 2000 presidential election, with Soong garnering about 60 percent and Lien receiving nearly 20 percent in the five-way race.
Both Lien and Soong stumped for Hsieh during the campaign in the hopes that their popularity would help Hsieh win.

Although Hsieh won only 51.4 percent of votes, Wu Kuo-tung, who was expelled from the KMT for insisting on running and who vowed to join the PFP if he won, garnered 18.3 percent of vote in Saturday's election. Political analysts therefore said that the two parties together still enjoy the support of roughly 70 percent to 80 percent of the Hualien voters.

The DPP, which drafted You to be its candidate only a few days before the deadline for candidate registration, has tried hard to play down the significance of the by-election, saying that it is only a local election and that the results will not have a bearing on the presidential election.
However, the DPP was out in full force throwing its support behind You during the campaign, with DPP heavyweights coming to the county to stump for him on more than 100 occasions.

You, who had already failed on four previous occasions in running for public office in Hualien, had said he was not interested in the race at all but was forced to bear the party standard after being asked by President Chen Shui-bian who doubles as DPP chairman.
Chen and his chief of staff Chiou I-jen stumped for You and gave him advice on campaign policy.

The DPP-run administration seemed to have done its utmost to canvass support for You. Cabinet members from Premier You Shyi-kun on down endorsed You's every campaign promise, including a monthly allowance to leaders of every aboriginal tribe and free dentures for senior citizens.

The heavy involvement of DPP leaders in the campaign turned what they called a local election into a showdown between the ruling party and the KMT-PFP alliance and vindicated the KMT and PFP's claims that the by-election is a harbinger of the upcoming presidential election.

The Ministry of the Interior's high-profile crackdown on vote-buying in Hualien, especially the setting up of road checks and sentinels outside aboriginal communities, backfired among the indigenous people who account for one-fourth of the Hualien voters.
An outspoken prosecutor in Hualien criticized the police's indiscriminative checks of all cars on the roads as an infringement on human rights which are enshrined in the ROC Constitution.

The controversy surrounding the extreme measures employed by police to prevent vote-buying played into the hands of the opposition parties which denounced the government for what they called contempt for aboriginal citizens.
What is worse, a suspected vote-buyer caught by police on the eve of the election day was reported to be a campaign worker for the DPP candidate, to the detriment of You's campaign.

The fact that You received fewer votes in all four rural townships of aboriginal citizens than he did in the 2001 election for Hualien magistrate seems to bear out critics' claims that Minister of the Interior You Cheng-hsien's efforts to stop vote-buying did more harm to the DPP than to the opposition.

You's defeat also shows that pork barrel politics aimed at wooing the support of special groups is no-longer a vote-getter for the ruling party because the middle-class, which makes up the bulk of the voters, has begun to question the fairness of these policies and has become tired of them.
For the KMT and PFP, the victory in Hualien is not a guarantee that they will win the next presidential election, according to Ge Youngguan, the president of a pro-Kuomintang association Mirror Club.

Speaking at a symposium on the Hualien by-election on Sunday, Ge said the makeup of Hualien's population -- divided roughly evenly between Hoklos, Hakkas, aboriginal citizens and mainland Chinese who emigrated to Taiwan after 1949 -- is different from that of Taiwan as a whole. He said that therefore, the outcome of the Hualien election might not provide any indication as to the possible outcome of a national election.
However, the election result shows that the KMT and PFP have a chance to win only when they unite, Ge added.
The reason for You's election failure lies more in the poor performance of the DPP administration than in You's unpopularity, Ge said.

Yang Jih-ching, a professor at National Chengchi University, said at the same symposium that the Hualien by-election proves that the voters have learned to vote for candidates based not only on what they have said but also on what they have done. "Empty campaign promises can hardly be sold to the voters," he added.
Yang Taishun, a professor at the Chinese Culture University, said at the symposium that Hsieh's victory proves that what matters in an election is a candidate's image, and not age.

Noting that 52-year-old Chen Shui-bian has claimed that the 2004 presidential race against Lien and Soong, who are both in their sixties, would be a competition between a young leader and two old men, Yang said the victory of Hsieh, who is 64, over You, who is 47, proves that the voters don't judge candidates simply by their age, adding that being a few years senior in age may not be that much of a liability.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK EXCHANGE TAX REVENUES FOR JULY FORECAST TO REACH NT$10 B.

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance on Sunday forecast that stock exchange tax revenues for July could reach NT$10 billion, an 18-month record high, with Taiwan's stock market showing a marked recovery over the past few weeks following months of sluggishness.

Statistics released Sunday by the ministry indicated that since the weighted index moved above 5,400 points, single-day stock trading value has reached as high as NT$190 billion. The average daily trading value of the Taiwan Stock Exchange in July was NT$128.4 billion.
Taiwan's depressed stock market was hit hard earlier this year by the U.S.-led war against Iraq and the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak.

The market has shown signs of recovery since late April, and President Chen Shui-bian's announcement in early July of a relaxation on restrictions on foreign investment in Taiwan's stock market has added stimulus to the recovery.

A market analyst with the Jardine Fleming Investment Consulting Co. said Sunday that Taiwan's stock market is expected to go up in the second half of this year, judging from the overall economic prospects and abundant capital.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development reported recently that a survey among local manufacturing industries indicated that most manufacturers consider that the economy has gradually bottomed out. The CEPD said it expects that economic growth for this year will reach 3.44 percent, which is slightly lower than its earlier forecast of 3.52 percent made at the end of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN OPENS INTERNATIONAL PHYSICS OLYMPIAD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian opened the 34th International Physics Olympiad in Taipei Sunday, emphasizing that the process rather than the results of learning is the focus of education.

Speaking at the opening of the annual competition in physics for secondary school students from around the world, the president said that students should be the center of any education system and that the purpose of education should be to teach students to be well-rounded individuals.

Noting that investment in developing the people's intelligence and mental abilities is the most valuable investment any country can make, the president said the question of how to create an education environment that inspires the student's imagination and creativity is a challenge to both governments and educators around the world.

He welcomed the 245 contestants from 54 countries taking part in the nine-day competition this year, saying that the International Physics Olympiad provides a valuable chance for students from around the world to compete against and learn from each other.
Calling the International Physics Olympiad "the Olympic Games in physics, " the president said the competition is really an arena of intelligence, where politics has no role to play.
He said that although there inevitably are winners and losers in competition, the friendship fostered in the process is more valuable than winning or losing.

The competition was originally scheduled to be held July 12-21 but was postponed to Aug. 2-11 because of the recent severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak in Taiwan. As a result, more than ten countries, including mainland China, withdrew from the event.
Taiwan, which has five members in this year's competition, has participated in the event since nine years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT-ORIENTED TAIWAN ECONOMY SAID BOTTOMING OUT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export-oriented economy is expected to rebound markedly in the second half of this year in the wake of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and the U.S.-led war in Iraq, according to major economic research institutes.

Taiwan's three leading economic research organizations -- the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) , the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CHIER) and the Institute of Economics under Academia Sinica -- unanimously made the forecasts in view of the strong demand from the international market following the two prominent events during the first half of the year.

In the domestic market, a series of government incentives, including two special budgets worth NT$50 billion and NT$57.7 billion (US$1.68 billion) , respectively, to tackle the negative impact of SARS and to expand public works projects, also are expected to fuel Taiwan's economic growth in the second half, they forecast.

The CHIER predicted that the local economy and the foreign trade sector will improve in the coming months thanks to the government's economic stimulus measures despite the possibility of a SARS comeback.
It forecast Taiwan's annual economic growth for 2003 at 3.44 percent, up from an earlier estimate of 3.02 percent, and growth for 2004 at 4.62 percent.

The TIER also adjusted upward its forecast of Taiwan's economic growth for 2003 from 3.02 percent to 3.53 percent on the grounds that the negative effects of SARS have been less than expected and because of the government's pump-priming policy.

The Institute of Economics under Academia Sinica forecast that with local business conditions likely to improve in the third and fourth quarters, government investment may post a 9.11 percent annual increase for the six-month period -- in stark contrast to the year-earlier level of a negative 10.87 percent.

At the same time, the domestic business and industry community are also optimistic about Taiwan's economic prospects for the near term, evidenced in the fact that sales, led by information industry-related sectors, are booming.
An IBM Taiwan executive said that Taiwan's export-oriented economy will undoubtedly benefit this year from an economic pickup in the United States and mainland China.

Following the SARS epidemic, local demand for personal computers will also reach a climax in the fourth quarter, leading to an industrial upgrading in the domestic industry, the IBM executive said, adding that the information industry will play the role of locomotive in fueling the expansion of the petrochemical, metal, rubber and plastics sectors.

A Taiwan agent of Japan's Toshiba Corp. is also highly upbeat about the economic outlook for the last two quarters of 2003, saying that major world-class corporate customers, such as Intel and Citibank, have been very keen on ordering new telecommunications equipment, while local demand for new models of Toshiba personal, notebook and corporate computers has also been extremely robust.
In the face of the fierce demand for facilities and equipment, a fresh wave of business takeoffs is already in sight, the source forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TYPHOON FORMED IN PACIFIC

TEXT.P: A new typhoon formed near Guam Sunday, but it is too far away from Taiwan to pose any immediate threat, the Central Weather Bureau reported.
Typhoon Etau, the tenth tropical storm reported in the Pacific area this year, is moving northwest at a speed of 17 kilometers per hour as of Sunday night.
Meteorologists said that Etau, which has a radius of 150 kilometers, is still more than 2,200 kilometers away from Taiwan and it will be 3 days before it is known if the typhoon will hit the island.

Meanwhile, Typhoon Morakot's skirt began to hit southeastern part of Taiwan Sunday night, bringing torrential rainfall and strong winds to the eastern, southeastern and southern parts of the island. Neither casualty nor damage to the property had been reported as of the press time.

However, it has affected traffics in eastern Taiwan since the afternoon with scheduled flights to and from Taitung city delayed or cancelled. All flights and ferries between Taitung city and the two outlying islands off the eastern coast, Orchid and Green islands, were suspended.
As of 4 p.m. Sunday, the typhoon was located some 60 kilometers southeast of Oluanpi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, moving northwest toward the island at a speed of 19 kilometers per hour.
The tropical storm, which has a radius of 100 kilometers, is expected to pass through Oluanpi at the midnight.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO EARTHQUAKES SHAKE TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Two earthquakes shook Taiwan Sunday, but no damage was reported.
An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 5.5 on the open-ended Richter scale rocked the island at 7:35 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau reported.
The epicenter of the quake was located about 20.6 kilometers south of the Nanao seismic station in Ilan County, northeastern Taiwan at a depth of 56.5 kilometers, seismologists said.

The quake which was felt across Taiwan had an intensity of 4.0 in Hohuanshan in central Nantou County; 3.0 in Techi of Taichung County, Kukeng of Yunlin County, Nanao of Ilan County, Hoping of Hualien County, Hualien City and Changhua City; 2.0 in Wuku of Taipei County, Shankuang of Taoyuan County, Shihtang of Miaoli County, Yuanlin of Changhua County, Chiku of Tainan County, Chengkung of Taitung County, Taichung city, Chiayi City and ports of Taichung, Suao and Hualien; 1.0 in Keelung City, Taipei City, Chupei of Hsinchu County, Miaoli City, Ilan City and Makung of the outlying Penghu County.
Another small earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 4.9 on the Richter scale jolted northeastern Taiwan in the early morning.
The epicenter of the quake was located 53 kilometers east of the Suao seismic station in Ilan County and originated 78.8 kilometers below the earth's surface.

The quake, which occurred at 2:54 a.m., had an intensity of 2.0 in Nanao of Ilan County; 1.0 in Suao of Ilan County, Ilan City, Hualien City, Hoping of Hualien County, Techi of Taichung County and Hohuanshan of Nantou County.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 4, or the seventh day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1578: The Portuguese King Sebastian and his court are killed in a failed crusade to Morocco.
1875: Hans Christian Anderson, Danish writer famous the world over for his fairy tales and stories, including "The Princess and the Pea" and "The Ugly Duckling," dies in Copenhagen at the age of 70.
1906: The Education Ministry of the Ching court promulgates a set of "regulations on education for women" governing the establishment of schools for women.
1914: World War I breaks out when German troops invade Belgium. Britain declares war on Germany as the United States declares its neutrality.
1916: Denmark sells the Danish Virgin Islands to the United States for US$25 million.
1922: Fighting breaks out in Italy between the fascists and the socialists.
1938: The Nationalist government moves its offices from Wuchang and Hankow to Chungking in order to cope with the lengthy War of Resistance Against Japan.
1940: Italian troops invade the country of British Somaliland in East Africa.
1942: David Russel Lange, New Zealand Labor politician, is born. He served as prime minister from 1984 to 1989 and was controversial for his refusal to allow nuclear-armed ships to dock in New Zealand.
1944: Anne Frank, a 14-year-old German Jewish diarist, and seven other Jews in hiding in Amsterdam, are captured by the Gestapo and sent to concentration camps.
1950: Gen. Douglas MacArthur dispatches a high-ranking aide to Taipei as a liaison officer as the United States begins providing military aid to Taiwan.
1954: The P-1 English Electronic Lightning, Britain's first supersonic fighter plane, makes its maiden flight.
1960: Chung Li-ho, a noted Taiwanese folk tale author, dies at the age of 45.
1963: The Foreign Ministry declares that the Republic of China will not recognize the border treaty signed between the Peking regime and Afghanistan.
1967: Malawian President Dr. H. Kamuzu Banda arrives in Taipei for an eight-day state visit.
1972: Ugandan President Idi Amin declares that his country will expel 50,000 Asians with British passports within three months.
1976: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang extends its "deepest sympathy" to victims of the earthquake that struck northern China.
1979: Ho Yen-sheng, former Saigon correspondent for the China Times of Taipei who had been stranded in Vietnam since 1975, arrives in Taipei from an isolated island in the South China Sea where he spent 70 days as a refugee.
1986: ROC-U.S. trade talks begin in Washington. During the five-day talks, the ROC agreed to abandon its use of duty tables as of Oct. 1, 1986.
1990: Iraq installs a nine-man puppet government in Kuwait and sets up a new "People's Army" to control the regime while 12 European Community nations ban oil imports from Iraq, impose an arms embargo on the country and suspend most trade with Iraq.
1993: Japan formally apologizes for the first time to women forced to serve as sex slaves for Japanese soldiers during World War II.
1993: The Japanese Cabinet resigns, ending 38 years of rule by the Liberal Democratic Party.
1999: British Defence Secretary George Robertson becomes the new secretary-general of NATO, succeeding Javier Solana.
1999: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Mayor Tarmile Ishoda of Majuro sign a pact of alliance in Taipei, making Majuro, capital of the Marshall Islands, the 44th sister city of Taiwan's capital.
2000: Government Information Office Director General Chung Chin says that the GIO is mapping out procedures for setting up exchanges across the Taiwan Strait of journalists for long-term postings.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By dealing loyally and punctually with them in all engagements which he makes with them and allowing a liberal scale of pay: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to men in the public service."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR MA HEADS TO SINGAPORE TO LEARN ABOUT ITS ANTI-SARS EXPERIENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Chiang Kai-sheik Airport, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou left for Singapore Monday with the goal of learning more about the Southeast Asian city-state's experience in its battle against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).

The mayor said before his departure that the purpose of his three-day visit to Singapore is to better his understanding regarding the city-state's public health policy as well as the various anti-SARS measures it has implemented.

Ma said that he will join four Taipei City Council members and some other high-ranking Taipei City Government officials who are already in Singapore learning about the city state's experience in SARS prevention.

The officials include Deputy Taipei Mayor Ou Chin-der as well as directors from the Health Department, the Fire Department, and the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission of the city government.
Mayor Ma and the municipal government officials are scheduled to head back to Taipei Aug. 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALASKAN COMPLETES AROUND-THE-ISLAND CYCLING JOURNEY OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Robert Bloomfield, also known by his Chinese name Tseng Chen-lin, had nearly been defeated by the high temperatures -- at times nearly 50 degrees Celsius -- on the road. Fortunately, he said, the hardship of riding was overwhelmed by the people's warmheartedness and the natural beauty of eastern Taiwan.

Bloomfield said he came to Taiwan to take home his adult daughter -- a Taiwan-born Mormon missionary who has been preaching around the island by riding a bicycle over the past two years -- and decided to ride around the island because he wanted to have the same experience of cycling on Taiwan's roads as his daughter has had.

He said his aim was also to pay gratitude to those people who have extended help to his daughter, particularly to a bicycle shop owner in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, for his timely repair for free of her bicycle after she had an accident.

The 53-year-old Bloomfield embarked on his 15-day, around-the-island cycling journey July 3 from the home of his Taiwan-born wife in Chunan, northern Taiwan. Cycling north, he passed through Taoyuan, Taipei County and Keelung in some of the hottest July weather in recent decades.
Well aware that he might be defeated not by his age or by fatigue, but by high temperatures, Bloomfield soon changed his riding strategy.

He changed his initial "9-to-5" riding schedule to a "dawn and dusk" schedule, cycling in the early morning hours, then starting again in the late afternoon after taking a break between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m. During the break period, he rested in the shade under big trees or near temples, churches and schools.

From Keelung, Bloomfield cycled south, passing through the eastern counties of Ilan, Hualien and Taitung, before turning right into the South-bend Highway toward the southern city of Kaohsiung. From Kaohsiung, he headed north on the west coast highway to arrive back at his starting point of Chunan.

During his journey, he met up several times with his wife, surnamed Tseng, who took buses along roughly the same route as Bloomfield's cycling route. They came together at churches where they met with their religious friends.

Bloomfield said cycling near Taroko Gorge near Tianshiang, Hualien County, was the best part of his journey. The scenery of the magnificent rocky gorge cut out by white and green brook water, with swallows chirping and cool breeze blowing, replaced all the riding hardships with pleasure and wonder, he said.

"Many people warned me about trucks passing on the road, " Bloomfield said. But to his surprise, he said, he found that truck drivers on the highways in eastern Taiwan were friendly and amusing. "They would honk three times to say hello or to cheer me up. They even slowed down to make room for me and my bike," he recalled.

He recalled how on one occasion when he was looking for a place to eat and the sun was setting in a coastal village in Fengping, Hualien, a villager invited him to his home for dinner. The villager barbecued wild boar meat and served rice wine made by aboriginal people.

He said that as a Mormon, he declined the tempting offer of rice wine, but he spent a great and unforgettable night, with the host playing guitar and them taking turns belting out songs sung by eastern Taiwan locals and those sung by people in Alaska.

Bloomfield said he and his wife, who are the adoptive parents of four Taiwan-born children, together prepared for his round-the-island journey for more than a year. He said that by memorizing at least 10 Chinese words each day, he knew several thousand Chinese words and phrases by the time he was ready to set off on his trip.

Mrs. Bloomfield said her husband is more Chinese than she is, pointing out that he likes to read the books of the ancient Chinese Taoist philosophers Lao Zi and Zhuang Zi, and that he practices calligraphy and has a black belt in kung fu.
