DOC.HEADLINE: MJIB COMPLETES TAIWAN WILDLIFE GENE DATABANK

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) has established a Taiwan wildlife gene databank, including gene maps of some endemic subspecies, to facilitate the nation's campaign against illegal animal trade, officials said Monday.

The bureau began to collate wildlife genetic data in 1993 when Taiwan came under international pressure to intensify wildlife protection and crack down on illegal trade in endangered species and their products.

At that time, some people were smuggling products made from protected animals by cutting them into slices or grinding them into powder. Customs officers had difficulty identifying the protected animal remains, and the absence of a wildlife gene bank made DNA tests meaningless.
The Council of Agriculture (COA) then sought the assistance of the MJIB which is known for its DNA testing technology and equipment in Taiwan.

The MJIB first cooperated with Taipei City Zoo which furnished the bureau with blood or saliva samples of its animals. The bureau then mapped DNA sequences of various endangered fauna species for reference.

In addition, the bureau managed to secure samples of indigenous wildlife species from Thailand, Vietnam and other Southeast Asian countries, including tiger bones, ivory, bear bile and snakes, for gene mapping work.

After more than 10 years of hard work, the MJIB has finally set up a comprehensive wildlife gene databank which includes genetic blueprints or DNA data of nearly all Taiwan endemic subspecies, such as the Formosan black bear, the clouded leopard and the Lanyu scops owl (Otus elegans botelensis).

With its detailed genetic data concerning Taiwan endemic subspecies, the MJIB wildlife gene databank has attracted wide international attention since it was linked up with major world wildlife gene libraries earlier this year.
MJIB officials said they have spent much time collecting samples of Taiwan endemic species, some of which are almost extinct.

"Sometimes, we have to travel around the island to search for specimens left from earlier times. We need only a few hairs to sort out DNA of a subspecies and build up its gene data, " an MJIB forensic expert said.
DNA is a kind of genetic fingerprint unique to each individual. It transmits hereditary characteristics from parents to offspring.

If no specimens are available, he said, the MJIB will use animal feces, feathers or skin provided by private wildlife field study teams, to find the species' DNA data and map out its genetic blueprints.
Thanks to the completion of the wildlife gene databank, the MJIB has unexpectedly discovered that some frozen beef products sold in the local market might be kangaroo, horse or even sea turtle meat.

MJIB forensic experts said they have reported the findings to the Department of Health which has directed city and county health bureaus to intensify market surveys to detect bogus beef. But so far, no such cases have been uncovered.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENGINE DEAL NOT YET DECIDED: CAL

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) management said Monday that the company has yet to decide which company it will choose to provide jet engines for its newly-ordered planes.

CAL, Taiwan's largest air carrier, is going to purchase engines for 12 A330-300 and six B747-400 jets, worth a total of US$700 million to US$800 million. Several world leading manufacturers, including General Electric and Pratt and Whitney of the United States and Rolls Royce of Britain, have expressed keen interest in securing the deal.
CAL officials said the company is still conducting an assessment on which of the three major bidders to grant the purchase order.

Noting that the decision will be made based on the best interests of CAL and that the purchase will not be affected by outside interference, the CAL officials declined to confirm news reports that GE and Rolls Royce have tried to use political influence to curry favor.

They also declined to confirm reports that Rolls Royce, which has offered a price cut as well as repair and maintenance and spare parts and components, is likely to get the deal for the 12 A330-300s, while GE will get the deal for the six B747-400s.

CAL officials also declined to comment on a newspaper report last week that British Prime Minister Tony Blair, in an extremely unusual move, wrote a letter to President Chen Shui-bian to pitch for the CAL contract on behalf of Rolls Royce.
The officials said they will base their purchase decision on the credibility, after-sales technical support service, repair and maintenance costs, as well as the price of the engines.
CAL Chairman Lee Yun-ning also has said that the purchase will be decided by the company alone and that the ROC government will issue no special instructions on the deal.
CAL officials reiterated these stances Monday in response to a spate of accusations made by the CAL Labor Union that CAL management is being arm-twisted by the government.

The CAL Labor Union criticized the possible decision by CAL management, under government influence, to introduce Rolls Royce jet engines for the new A330-300s, which the union said would lead to a skyrocketing of the company's engine maintenance costs as the existing maintenance systems, designed for HP and GE engines, would be forced to be changed.
The CAL Labor Union also lambasted CAL management for deciding to release some 36 percent of the corporation's stocks to "a certain group" of buyers at low prices.

Refuting the accusations, CAL officials said it is up to the China Aviation Development Foundation -- an organization which controls a majority stake in CAL -- to decide the share-releasing issue, and that CAL management has no say in the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROPOSAL INCLUDED IN APEC WOMEN LEADERS' MEETING DECLARATION
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By F.C. Kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan policy of helping eldery or retired women to restart their careers with government-sponsored low-interest loans was included in the Chiang Mai Declaration adopted at the closing of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum's 8th Women Leaders' Network Meeting.

Lin Fang-mei, chairwoman of Taiwan's Cabinet-level National Youth Commission, who led the 14-member Taiwan delegation to the meeting held in the northern Thai city of Chiang Mai July 31-Aug. 3, said her delegation spelled out the career restarting plan for eldery women and drew wide attention by meeting participants, who decided to have it included in the declaration to be forwarded to the APEC Summit in October for adoption.

According to the plan, Lin said, retired career women, who have rich experience in their chosen fields, will be entitled to receive the government's assistance in securing low-interest loans of up to NT$1 million (US$28.900) to restart their careers, particularly in the service sector, if their health is still good.

About 350 delegates representing the government, business, academic and non-profit sectors from 20 APEC economic entities took part in the meeting dubbed "Women Make a World of Difference: Partnerships for Gender and Development."

Thai Prime Minister Chinnawat Thaksin addressed the opening ceremony, which was followed by split panel discussions focusing on three sub-themes, namely knowledge and empowerment, security for women, and female entrepreneurship.
Conclusions and policy recommendations, included in the 2003 Chiang Mai Declaration, will be forwarded to the APEC Summit in October for adoption.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GRABS 29 GOLDS IN TOTAL AT WORLD POLICE AND FIRE GAMES

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei grabbed one more gold and two bronze medals Sunday on the final day of the 2003 World Police and Fire Games, taking home a total of 29 gold, 18 silver and 15 bronze medals in the eight events of the games held in Barcelona, Spain, officials of the National Police Administration (NPA) said Monday.
Police officer Wang Chin-wen won the gold in the men's over-30 singles badminton competition, while his compatriot, Lin Youn-long, took the bronze, the NPA officials said.
Wang and Lin also grabbed the bronze in the men's open doubles badminton competition.

With the completion of the week-long games, several Taiwanese groups in Barcelona, including the Taiwanese Association , the Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce and the Chinese Women's Association, held a celebration party for the Chinese Taipei team at a Chinese restaurant.
The Chinese Taipei team is scheduled to return home Aug. 6.
The next World Police and Fire Games in 2005 are slated to be held in Quebec, Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LAUDS ALTERNATIVE SERVICEMEN SERVING OVERSEAS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Monday praised the 36 people who recently completed their alternative military service overseas, saying that they are a testament to what can be achieved with hard work and dedication.

The president made the remarks at a welcome-home celebration sponsored by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for the servicemen who completed their 26-month alternative military service. Also in attendance were Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien and members of the diplomatic corps stationed in Taiwan.

The president said that "Taiwan reaching out" has long been his wish, noting that he first broached the idea of alternative military service when he noticed the dearth of younger agricultural experts and the fact that older people in the field were retiring from overseas agricultural missions. He said that this, teamed with the need for medical assistance in countries that maintain diplomatic ties with the ROC, made him realize the need for special, technical emissaries from Taiwan. The alternate military service met these needs, the president said.
"I am deeply moved to see these 36 honorably-discharged servicemen, knowing that they have strengthened their horizons by doing important work in 21 countries," Chen said.
The president said he was impressed to see the strength of mind and body that was required of them to endure hardships, which he described as "the spirit of Taiwan's sons."

The president also said that the alternative military servicemen have lived up to his ideal of a "volunteer Taiwan and the use of humanitarian diplomacy, " adding that he felt proud of them on behalf of the people of Taiwan for "safely completing their work."

Noting that the number of alternative military servicemen in diplomatic work has increased by 40 percent from previous years, the president said that the alternative military service policy has worked well.

The president urged the young people to think seriously of continuing their work to help others by joining the ROC diplomatic field or with international aid organizations. Chen said their contributions would be a shot in the arm for Taiwan's humanitarian diplomacy.

The 36 former servicemen, including the youngest recipient of the ROC's diplomatic friendship award, Lien Chia-en, who helped Burkina Faso build an orphanage and helped with environmental problems there; Wang Hsiang-chih who served in Chad and helped with the rehabilitation of the mother of the president of Chad; and Huang Min-nung, who served in Sao Tome and Principe and learned to speak Portuguese there.

Many of the 36 servicemen have indicated that they would like to take the foreign service exam to enter Taiwan's medical or technical missions for a chance to return to the countries where they served.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GROUPS SHOW SUPPORT TO MAINLAND CHINESE PRO-DEMOCRACY ACTIVIST

TEXT.P: Several pro-democracy groups in Taiwan urged Beijing Monday to release the U.S.-based mainland Chinese human rights fighter, Yang Jianli, after a fair and public trial.

Chien Shih-chieh, executive director of Peacetime Foundation of Taiwan, Wang Dan, a mainland Chinese student leader in the 1989 pro-democracy uprising in Tiananmen Square, and representatives of a lawyers' association, made the appeal while Yang was brought to a secret trial in Beijing.
Yang, with doctoral degrees from Harvard and Berkeley, was arrested by mainland Chinese authorities in April last year while entering mainland China on a false U.S. passport.
After being put in jail for more than one year, Yang was accused of illegally entering mainland China and spying for Taiwan, and was brought to a secret trial on Aug. 4.

Yang, 40, who has American permanent residence, participated in the 1989 pro-democracy protest and offered funds to the event. He was among the last group of Chinese students to leave the Tiananmen Square.
Since then, Beijing has refused Yang's entry into the country and informed its embassies abroad not to extend the validity of his Chinese passport.

According to Yang's wife, Yang visited Taiwan several times in the 1990s to study the island's democratization, because he thinks Taiwan's experience in democracy can serve as a good example for mainland China.
She went on that Yang had no choice but to use other people's passports as his passport cannot be extended. She said returning one's home town is a basic right of a citizen.
After Yang was imprisoned, support from all over the world, especially from the United States, flooded in, urging Beijing to release Yang without any conditions.
However, Taiwan pro-democracy activists said since Beijing insisted on a secret trial, they worried about Yang's situation.
They urged Beijing authorities to respect human rights, show sincerity in reforms, and not to harass dissidents under the guise of dealing with cross-Taiwan Strait problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF PLANS TO REVISE LAW TO ALLOW LOCAL GOVERNMENTS TO BORROW MORE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) confirmed Monday it is considering revising the public debt law to pave the way for city and county governments to borrow more money.
Nevertheless, the ministry said, no details regarding the planned amendments have been fleshed out.

The ministry was responding to media reports that the MOF plans to raise the cap on city and county governments' combined outstanding debts from the current 2 percent to 3 percent of the nation's average annual gross national product (GNP) for the past three years.

The existing public debt law imposes some restrictions on local governments' fund-raising activities, including that the annual debt a city or county government is eligible to borrow should not surpass 15 percent of its annual expenditure and that its accumulated outstanding loans must fall below 45 percent of its annual spending.
Moreover, the law stipulates that the aggregate outstanding debts of all city and county governments must not exceed 2 percent of the nation's average annual GNP for the past three years.
By the end of this year, the total debts incurred by the nation's 23 city and county governments will reach more than NT$167 billion, only NT$35 billion below the legal ceiling.
Liu Teng-cheng, director of the MOF's Department of National Treasury, said most local cities and counties have some sort of financial problems.
In view of the approaching of their accumulated debts to the legal cap, Liu said, the ministry is studying the feasibility of easing their fund-raising restrictions.
But he added that the ministry has yet to finalize a comprehensive adjustment plan.
"We may not necessarily raise the limit to 3 percent of the nation's annual GNP," Liu explained.

Under the terms of the current law, the cumulative debts of governments at all levels ought not to surpass 48 percent of the nation's average annual GNP for the past three years, with the central government given the lion's share of 40 percent; the Taipei City Government, 3.6 percent; the Kaohsiung City Government, 1.8 percent; other city and county governments, 2 percent; and township governments, 0.6 percent.
Liu said the ministry may adjust the eligible borrowing ratios for various levels of governments to allow city and county governments to borrow more money while keeping the 48 percent cap unchanged.

At the moment, cumulative debts of township governments account for only 0.1 percent of the nation's GNP, compared to Taipei's 1.7 percent and Kaohsiung's 0.8 percent. Taipei and Kaohsiung are special municipalities under the direct jurisdiction of the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: WATER SUPPLY IN KEELUNG AREA TO BE FURTHER RESTRICTED

TEXT.P: Officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs Monday decided to further restrict water supply to the Keelung area for lack of rainfall in this summer.
It has not rained for 43 days in the area and the waterline in the nearby reservoir has dropped to a low level, the officials pointed out.

The waterworks in Keelung has reduced water supply at night since July 29. On Aug. 9, it will begin to reduce water supply to heavy users-- such as owners of swimming pools and warwash stations-- by 20 percent. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON MORAKOT LEAVES TAIWAN CAUSING LITTLE DAMAGE

TEXT.P: Typhoon Morakot, which made landfall at Tawu in the southeastern Taiwan county of Taitung Sunday night, has passed over the island without causing casualties or heavy property damage.
Typhoon land warnings were lifted by the Central Weather Bureau at noon, Monday.
The light typhoon was located 60 kilometers northeast of the outlying Penghu Islands at 11 a.m. Monday, moving northwest toward Kinmen at 18 kilometers per hour.
The tropical storm brought strong winds and heavy rain to southern Taiwan but did not cause heavy damage. There have been no reports of casualties.

Some areas in Taitung and Pingtung counties received 600 and 450 millimeters of rainfall respectively Sunday night. Tsengwen and Nanhua reservoirs received only 3.77 million and 4.12 million cubic meters of water respectively Sunday and Monday.

According to a preliminary investigation by the Council of Agriculture, the typhoon has caused NT$73.88 million in losses to the farmers, especially those growing bananas, watermelons, longans and papayas.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications said no transportation systems on land were damaged, except that traffic on Highway 20 in Kaohsiung County was interrupted for a few hours by landslides.

The South-Link railway between Kaohsiung and Taitung was closed Sunday night and Monday morning. Passenger shipping services between Kaohsiung and Penghu and between Kinmen and Xiamen were suspended Monday as well.
All international flights to and from the Kaohsiung International Airport were not affected, but local airports in southern Taiwan and on outlying islands were closed Monday.

A total of 39,811 households in several cities in Taitung, Pingtung, Kaohsiung, and Tainan counties were left without electricity the night of the typhoon, according to a report by the Taiwan Power Company.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES TO HELP JOHANNESBURG POOR
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By C. C. Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Nearly 1,000 South African people received rice, cooking oil, blankets and sweaters donated by Taiwan representative office in Johannsesburg Monday.
The representative office called for donations to help poor people in the city through the winter, and Taiwanese residing in Johannesburg have responded actively.

Chuang Hsun-kai, the director of the Taipei Liaison Office in Johannesburg, told community representatives and families of 100 slain policemen, that the donations attested to the friendship between the two countries.

Wuyisile Moedi, who attended the donation on behalf of the Johannesburg City Government, expressed his appreciation and said that Taiwan's help in easing the poverty problem in Johannesburg has set an example for others to follow.
P. Naido, the Johannesburg police chief, said, "We're a family" to describe the relations between Taiwan and South Africa, adding
that it's hard to put into words the Taiwanese contributions to South Africa and their support to the South African police.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG-BOUND TRAVELERS URGED TO KEEP ALERT AGAINST FLU

TEXT.P: People in Taiwan considering traveling to Hong Kong should be aware of the increase incident of flu in the Special Administrative Region and take the necessary steps to keep healthy, Chiu Chan-hsien, interim director of Taipei City Government's Department of Health, said Monday.
Chiu gave the advice after noting the increase in flu cases in Hong Kong since June, adding that July and August are generally peak times for flu in the former British colony.
Chiu urged Hong Kong-bound people from Taiwan to avoid congested places, wash their hands frequently, or wear a surgical masks if they feel it is warranted.

Meanwhile, Chiu urged local elderly people or those with chronic heart and lung disease to get a flu shot so that doctors can distinguish flu symptoms from those of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) , as experts think that SARS could resurface this winter.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU EXPELS LAWMAKER FOR FALSE ACCUSATIONS, BAD TEMPER

TEXT.P: A policy-making body of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) decided to expel Legislator Su Ying-kuei from the party Monday, accusing him of making false charges against fellow TSU Legislator Lo Chih-min and tarnishing the party's image.
TSU Secretary-General Lin Chih-chia told a news conference after a meeting of the TSU Central Executive Committee that the decision was made by the committee unanimously.

The dispute originated from Su's public accusation last week against Lo, claiming that Lo debased himself and the party by trying to obstruct the judicial investigation of a scandal involving senior police officers who allegedly turned a blind eye to illegal video game parlors in Kaohsiung City.

A lawyer-turned legislator, Su also accused Lo funding public events through the use of money obtained by public relations departments of state-run companies such as Taiwan Power Company, Chinese Petroleum Corporation and Taiwan Water Supply Corporation. While not illegal, Su said, this sort of funding is morally incorrect since legislators should not be using corporate money to pay for community activities.
Lo denied the allegations and asked the TSU to discipline Su.

Secretary-General Lin said a document produced by Su as evidence failed to support his claims. In the document, three prosecutors at the Kaohsiung District Court, who have been tasked to investigate the scandal surrounding video game parlors in Kaohsiung City, said only that Lo called their superior, urging him to conduct the investigation fairly and not to infringe on video parlor owners' legal rights.

In addition to the damage Su's false accusation has caused to Lo and to the party, Lin said Su voted against vital bills in defiance of the TSU's party line many times and is ill-tempered, often throwing objects at party lawmakers who disagree with him in discussions of party policies.
For these reasons, the TSU Central Executive Committee unanimously decided to expel Su from the party, Lin said.
It was a difficult decision for the party, which will soon celebrate its two-year anniversary, but the party will ride out the crisis and emerge stronger than before, Lin said.
The TSU is a group consisting of followers of former President Lee Teng-hui. It had 13 seats in the 224-member Legislative Yuan before Su was expelled.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU TOUTS ORGAN DONATIONS BETWEEN MARRIED COUPLES ON LOVER'S DAY

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) Hospital held a party Monday for five people who donated either a section of their liver or one of their kidneys to their spouses.
The party took place in connection with the Chi Hsi Festival or Chinese Valentine's Day -- the seventh day of the seventh moon on lunar calendar which fell on Monday this year.

The nation's most prestigious hospital said the number of live organ donations between married couples has been increasing in recent years. Since 1988, the hospital has performed 177 organ transplants using liver sections and kidneys donated by living persons. Among them, 20 cases or 11 percent of the total involved married couples.

Tsai Meng-kun, an NTU surgeon, said that although married couples do not have blood ties, they have exchanged low levels of antigens through their long-term intimate relations which would increase their immunity to rejection after organ transplants.
Clinical studies show that the organ transplant rejection rate between married couples is far lower than that for those performed on people with no blood relations, Tsai said.

He added that the rejection rate is the lowest in cases where husbands donate organs to their wives. 'This is because the husbands' antigens could have long entered their wives' wombs through placentas during pregnancy."

Noting that organ donation will not adversely affect the donor's health nor his or her life span, Tsai said organ donation between married couples provides a new hope and new way for those who need organ transplants to sustain their lives.

Lai Ming-kun, director of the NTU's cancer department, said the hospital's 20 successful liver and kidney transplants among married couples provide the best testament to the belief that "love can fight rejection."
Among the five couples who attended the NTU party was 49-year-old Mr. Hsiao, who donated one of his kidneys to his wife in March this year.

Hsiao said he is very happy to see his wife return to normal life after her transplant. Hsiao's wife began to rely on renal dialysis 10 years ago. Although their children met the requirements to donate a kidney to their mother, Mrs. Hsiao would not accept one for fear of affecting their marriages. After many rounds of tests, doctors found that Mr. Hsiao was a fitting donor and performed the transplant in mid-March.

Also present was a couple surnamed Wu. The husband contracted an acute liver disease and lapsed into a coma in early February this year. As all of their children were younger than 18, Mrs. Wu decided to donated part of her liver to save her husband's life. A tearful Wu said at the party he was grateful for his wife's organ donation. "I want to marry you in my next life," he told her at the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ALLIANCE ALIGNING SOCIAL GROUPS TO BE FORMED AUG. 10

TEXT.P: A new alliance grouping the nation's underprivileged social organizations will be formed Aug. 10, the chief executive of the Peacetime Foundation of Taiwan (PFT) announced Monday.
"We want to pool the strength of the social activists to influence next year's presidential election," PFT Executive Director Chien Hsi-chieh said.

Chien, who once served as an at-large lawmaker representing the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for two terms, said he began to promote the formation of a new group more than six months ago.

Scores of social groups, including labor unions, elderly rights associations, educationAL reform activists, associations for the disabled, students' and women's rights activists as well as environmentalists, have decided to join the new alliance, Chien said.
Nevertheless, he added, the name and the framework of the new group have yet to be determined.
"The so-called 'Pan-purple Alliance' proposed by some people is just one of our choices," Chien said, adding that the group's formal name will be announced Aug. 10.
He said the new alliance will not be a political party. "We'll focus on promoting fair and just social welfare services and speak for disadvantaged."

Chien said the new group hopes to become a "third force" in contrast to the "pan-green" camp of the DPP and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party.
But he said the new alliance will not insist on nominating its own candidate in the 2004 presidential election.

Chien confirmed media reports that he had tried to persuade Lin Yi-hsiung, a former DPP chairman, to represent the new alliance in running for the presidency next year. "However, Lin turned down my suggestion," he added.
Chien used to be a member of the DPP's largest "New Tide" faction. "But I have not paid membership fees for more than two years. I don't know whether I'm still a DPP member."
None of his former DPP colleagues in the Legislative Yuan have contacted him since he began to push for the formation of the new alliance.

Chien said the main purpose of the new alliance is to provide a third choice for local people. "We'll present new welfare policy initiatives, spell out the aspirations and apprehensions of wage earners and the underprivileged, as well as provide options for the nation's future development," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALL THAT GLITTER IS GOLD FOR TAIWAN'S JEWELRY DESIGNERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's jewelry designers have been turning heads recently in the international market and the president of the Taiwan Jewelry Designers Association said Monday that if local designers put their heads together to come up with brand names, Taiwan jewelry would shine even brighter around the world.
Lee Yung-fu, president of the association, noted that top designers for such brand names as Gucci have come from Taiwan, showing the creativity of Taiwan's jewelry designers.

Lee said that in the prestigious Vicenza jewelry fair this year, more than 5,000 works from 1,700 participants of 52 countries took part in its Gold Virtuosi Awards. Only 100 works were selected for the awards, among them works by four Taiwan jewelry designers and Lin Hsiao-tung and Yang Pao-feng eventually won two prizes.

The Gold Virtuosi Awards, the Academy Awards of the jewelry field, were created by the World Gold Council to inspire unrestricted creativity from gold jewelry designers, to honor excellence in craftsmanship and ultimately to expand the horizons of gold jewelry worldwide.

Lee also cited the example of Taiwan jewelry designer Pei-san Hsieh, who won the grand prize in the men's first class jewelry contest in an international trade show in Paris last September, becoming the first Taiwanese to win such an award.
Lee said that the association is hoping to have more excellent designers join and establish a "creative people databank" to support the government to develop the industry.
The association is hoping to sponsor international jewelry design competitions in the future, he said.

Lee made the remarks on the eve of a seminar sponsored by the semi-official China External Trade Development Center during which it will promote the idea of establishing a jewelry design industry platform to help the development of the jewelry industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO LAUNCH ACTIVITIES TO REKINDLE TOURISM

TEXT.P: Taiwan will launch a series of promotional activities from October to rekindle its tourism, which was hard hit by the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) on the island.

In a meeting to review the progress of a national development plan, Premier Yu Shyi-kun instructed the Tourism Bureau to coordinate the actions of the tourism sector to attract more foreign travelers and strengthen contacts with European tour operators.

According to official statistics, the number of travelers to Taiwan stood at 963,882 for the first half of this year, a decrease of 31.87 percent over the same period of last year, while the hotel occupancy rate in June also dropped by 27.45 percent over the same month of 2002.
After SARS affected Taiwan, a total of 17 hotels shut down, laying off 2,621 employees.
For this, the island has readjusted its original plan to achieve three million visits to Taiwan by foreign travelers this year to 2.1 million.
Tourism businesses began to recover in late June, when SARS had been contained, with the business in July recovering to 70 percent of its original level.

In Monday's meeting, the Tourism Bureau decided on many promotional measures, including returning the tax paid by foreign tourists if they purchase goods worth more than NT$3,000 (US$87) and holding a lucky draw.
The bureau will also send delegations to five cities in North America in October to launch promotional activities, and introduce foreign tourists to Taiwan's new travel packages.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK, HANOI, SINGAPORE TO COOPERATE WITH TAIPEI IN FIGHTING SARS
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Hong Kong, Hanoi and Singapore health authorities have agreed to establish regular dialogue mechanisms with the Taipei City Government to facilitate cooperation in preventing a relapse of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).

These are among the achievements that a visiting Taipei municipal delegation has harvested during its current three-leg Asian tour aimed at exchanging SARS-fighting experiences and strengthening cooperation in relevant operations in the future, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said in Singapore Monday.

Ma arrived in the city-state earlier in the day to join the municipal delegation, headed by Deputy Taipei Mayor Ou Chin-der, on a three-day visit to Singapore. Ou's mission arrived in Singapore Sunday after having visited Hong Kong and Hanoi.

Ma said he is convinced that if SARS stages a comeback this winter, the Taipei City Government will be able to make a quicker and more effective response through the experiences learned in the past few months.

When the SARS outbreak reached its peak in Taipei in May, Ma recalled that Singaporean health officials had held a teleconference with Taipei health administrators and medical experts. Moreover, Singapore donated 100,000 N95 masks and protective garb for Taipei's frontline health care providers.
"We appreciate its assistance at our difficult time," Ma said, adding that those exchanges have laid a foundation for future cooperation between the two sides.
During his stay, Ma will meet with senior Singaporean officials to work out further details regarding bilateral cooperation in SARS-fighting campaign.

The Taipei delegation is composed of government officials and city councilors, including directors from the Health Department, the Fire Department, and the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission of the city government.
Mayor Ma and the municipal government officials are scheduled to head back to Taipei Aug. 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHETHER THERE WILL BE FURTHER WATER RATIONING TO BE DECIDED NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: Second-stage water rationing in Keelung, northern Taiwan will begin Aug. 9, and whether further restrictions will be introduced in northern Taiwan will be decided next week, a task force under the Ministry of Economic Affairs announced Monday.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming presided over a contingency task force on drought relief Monday to review the rainfall from Typhoon Morakot, which brought ample rain to eastern, central and southern Taiwan, but contribute little to the parched north.

First-stage water restrictions will continue in the greater Taipei area, meaning a reduction of water pressure off peak hours, while Keelung will implement second-stage water rationing, meaning the suspension or restriction on non-household water use.

It has not rained for 43 days in Keelung. The city's water supply at night has been decreased since July 29. On Aug. 9, water to large users, such as swimming pools and car washes will be cut by a total of 20 percent.
But whether there will be further water rationing for Keelung, and whether Taipei will impose the next stage of water rationing will be decided in another meeting Aug. 14.
Hualien, benefiting from the ample rain brought by the typhoon, will end its first-stage water rationing and resume normal water supply.

Chen Shen-hsien, director of the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said that Typhoon Morakot did not help northern Taiwan. Shihmen Reservoir is still below its minimum of 220.67 meters, while Feitsui Reservoir is just a little higher than the minimum of 141 meters.

Statistics by the Water Resources Agency showed that rainfall collected in Feitsui Reservoir was only 36.5 mm last month, or 14 percent of the average 259.9 mm in July over the past years. Shihmen Reservoir took on rainfall of 114 mm last month, or 41.67 percent of the average July rainfall of 273.59 mm.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH RAILWAY MISSION TO VISIT TAIWAN IN SEARCH OF OPPORTUNITIES

TEXT.P: A railway mission from United Kingdom will arrive in Taiwan Aug. 8 to seek trade opportunities in view of the fact that there will be numerous railway construction projects within five to 10 years on the island.

According to officials of British Trade and Cultural Office in Taipei, the delegation, including two officials from Trade Partners UK and a member of a British railway construction association, will meet members of some of Taiwan's government agencies to better understand the island's railway market.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL MUSEUM OF HISTORY FORMS ALLIANCE WITH TWO FOREIGN MUSEUMS

TEXT.P: The ROC National Museum of History has formed cooperative relations with two overseas museums, one in Mongolia and one on the West Coast of the United States, an official of the museum said Monday.

Huang Kung-nan, director of National Museum of History, said that he recently visited Mongolia and met with Sanduin Idshinnorov, the curator of the National Museum of Mongolian History, and reached consensus on promoting bilateral cultural exchanges July 30.
They then signed an agreement on cultural cooperation, hoping to enhance bilateral understanding and cooperation through the exchanges of professionals and exhibitions.
The National Museum of Mongolian History was established in 1924, and serves multiple functions relating to cultural, scientific and educational purposes.

The National Museum of History also recently signed an agreement on cultural cooperation with the Wing Luke Asian Museum of Seattle, which was established in 1967 in memory of the first Chinese city councilman on the northwest coast of the United States.
The main exhibits of the museum depict the life of Asian-Americans, and the museum is the only Asian-American cultural museum in the United States.

The museum started from questions about a pair of shoes. In 1964, a pair of Chinese shoes from the early 1900s were shown to Wing Luke, a Seattle city councilman, and Luke then thought about establishing a museum so that Asian-American could learn more about their past while trying to integrate into the mainstream society of the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO LEARN FROM HUALIEN ELECTION DEFEAT: LEGISLATIVE WHIP

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will learn bitter lessons from its defeat in the weekend Hualien County magistrate by-election, two influential DPP lawmakers said Monday.
Legislator Chen Chi-mai, a DPP legislative caucus whip, said its unfair to attribute the defeat to an all-out campaign against vote-buying initiated by Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien.

In his views, Chen said, many factors had led to the party's loss in the eastern county's magistrate by-election in which the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" candidate Hsieh Shen-san won a landslide.

"There was ample room for us to improve in publicity and manpower mobilization," Chen said, adding that both the DPP's headquarters and its election strategy panel have begun reviewing the just-concluded by-election and will come up with various adjustment initiatives.
Legislator Tsai Huang-lan seconded Chen's views saying that it's not the DPP's tradition to pass bucks one another for an electoral defeat.

"We have been accustomed to learning lessons from failures and growing stronger from hardships," Tsai said, adding that the party will work even harder in the future to listen to the "voice of grassroots people" and adjust its campaign strategies for next year's presidential election.
Meanwhile, Emile Sheng, a Soochow University associate professor, said the DPP has gradually lost its appeal to middle-class and middle-age voters.

Speaking at a meeting of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), Sheng said the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party managed to consolidate its support base in the Aug. 2 Hualien by-election, while the DPP garnered less votes than it secured in the previous magistrate election. This signaled an alarm to the DPP, he said.
Sheng said although the DPP administration made many welfare service promises in the run-up to the by-election, all those initiatives didn't seem to sway Hualien voters.
Therefore, Sheng said he believes that the electoral result will prompt various political camps to re-evaluate the effectiveness of welfare benefit promises in the future elections.

Hualien has traditionally been a KMT stronghold. The voter turnout was only about 55 percent in the weekend by-election. Sheng said the voter-turnout may have an impact on the result of next year's presidential election.
Sheng further said the "pan-blue alliance" should come up with innovative policy initiatives, project a fresh image and demonstrate a passion for reform if it wants to win the 2004 presidential race.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM HEADS FOR MEETING WITH COUNTERPARTS OF EAST CARIBBEAN ALLIES

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien left for Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Monday for an annual meeting with his counterparts from four East Caribbean states Aug. 8.
The meeting will bring together foreign ministers from St. Vincent and the Grenadines, St. Christopher and Nevis, Grenada and Dominica.
Chien will make a transit stopovers in Los Angeles and Miami.
He will return to Taiwan Aug. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT LURES NT 643 BILLION IN INVESTMENTS IN SIX MONTHS

TEXT.P: The government has lured domestic and foreign investments of more than NT$643 billion (US$18.6 billion) in the first half of this year, officials of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Monday.
The figure accounts for 50.27 percent of the target of NT$1.281 trillion set by the government for this year, the officials noted.

The Ministry of Finance tops the list of government agencies in implementing projects for wooing investments by achieving 78 percent of its annual target during the Jan.-June period, followed by the Ministry of Economic Affairs with 55 percent, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications with 43 percent, the Environmental Protection Administration with 27 percent and the National Science Council with 23 percent.

In light of the fact that many domestic and foreign businesses are prepared to increase their investments in Taiwan after severe acute respiratory syndrome outbreaks were contained in late June, the CEPD officials predicted that the total amount of investments by the private sector is expected to set a new record this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT AFFIRMS EXECUTIVE YUAN'S BUDGET FOR NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian confirmed the government budget prepared by the Executive Yuan for 2004 Monday, urging his administration to speed up financial reforms to keep the country financially healthy over the long term.

After being briefed by financial officials on the budget, the president hailed the Executive Yuan's work in compiling the budget amid limited growth in the government's revenue and ever-increasing government outlays.
Chen said the new budget was prepared in a way which accommodates both the government's important agenda and its goal of promoting economic growth.

He said the Executive Yuan has done a good job in giving priority to scientific development, public projects, defense, financial grants for local governments, pensions for elder farmers, fishermen, physically- and mentally-challenged, and retirement pensions for teachers.

In anticipating an upward turn in the economy next year -- thanks to the government's huge investment in public construction and the international economic recovery -- Chen said the Executive Yuan would take this into account while calculating the budget to make the best use of the government's limited resources.

Under the 2004 budget, the central government's revenue was estimated at NT$1.35 trillion (US$39.2 billion), with an outlay of NT$1.61 trillion (US$46.75 billion), and a shortfall of NT$259.3 billion (US$7.5 billion) which, combined with NT$56.1 billion (US$1.62 billion) for service on government's debts, will be covered through loans and the budget surplus of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE CALL FOR COOPERATION WITH MAINLAND IN CRACKING DOWN ON DRUGS

TEXT.P: A senior police officer called for close cooperation between mainland China and Taiwan to stop the smuggling of narcotics across the Taiwan Strait against the background that more and more Taiwan drug kingpins are relocating their drug-manufacture operations to the mainland.

The anonymous officer suggested a closer exchange of drug-related information with mainland China, cooperation between Taiwan and the mainland in searching, arresting, and extraditing drug manufacturers and dealers to help each other in probing drug cases.
Once the cooperation is institutionalized, the system could be expanded, said the officer.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 5, or the eighth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1100: Henry I, the youngest son of William the Conqueror, is crowned king in Westminster Abbey, three days after his brother William Rufus was killed in a hunting accident in the New Forest.
1858: The laying of the world's first transatlantic telegraph cable between Ireland and Newfoundland is completed.
1792: Frederick North, British politician known as "Lord North," dies at the age of 60. He served as prime minister (1770-1782) under George III and instituted policies that led to the rebellion of the American colonies.
1861: A national income tax is introduced in the United States, initially to fund the Civil War.
1895: Friedrich Engels, German socialist theorist and writer, dies at the age of 75. He met Karl Marx in Paris in 1844 and collaborated with him on "The Communist Manifesto" in 1848.
1930: Neil Armstrong, American astronaut and the first man on the moon, is born.
1948: The Republic of China and the United States agree to organize the Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction, with Chiang Meng-lin, James Yen and Shen Chung-han from the ROC, and Dr. Raymond T. Moyer and Dr. John Earl Baker from the United States as commissioners.
1949: The United States issues a "White Paper" on Sino-American relations, blaming the Nationalist government for the occupation of the Chinese mainland by the communists.
1950: A Kuomintang Central Reform Committee is set up in Taipei.
1950: The U.S. 13th Air Force is stationed in Taiwan to help the ROC guard against possible mainland Chinese air attacks.
1952: The first Japanese Embassy in Taiwan officially opens on Taipei's Chungshan North Road following the exchange of diplomatic notes ratifying the Sino-Japanese Peace Treaty.
1957: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Liberia.
1958: The nuclear-powered submarine Nautilus completes a historic 2,000-mile (3,200-km) underwater journey from Point Barrow in Alaska to the Greenland Sea, passing directly under the North Pole during its five-day voyage.
1958: Vice President Chen Cheng, who was appointed on July 1 to the concurrent post of Executive Yuan president, presides over a ceremony laying the foundation for the construction of the NT$3,200 million Shihmen Dam.
1971: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with the Republic of Turkey.
1973: The Hua Hsing Junior High School baseball team leaves for Gary, Indiana, to represent the Far East in the Senior League World Series.
1974: The Republic of China Amateur Big League baseball team leaves Taipei to participate in the 1974 Amateur Big League World Series in Ft. Lauderdale, Fla.
1976: The Executive Yuan approves the extension for two years of the Sino-Panamanian pact on technical fishery cooperation.
1984: Richard Burton, Welsh-born actor and twice husband of actress Elizabeth Taylor, dies of a stroke at his home in Switzerland.
1986: The Chinese Taipei women's basketball team leaves for Moscow to compete in the 10th Women's Basketball World Championships.
1991: President Lee Teng-hui receives Fijian Prime Minister Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara.
1999: The 18th International Baseball Association World Amateur Big League Baseball Championship opens in Kaohsiung County with 12 teams from Cuba, Japan, South Korea, Panama, the United States and Taiwan participating.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh announces the list of members for his inter-party task force on cross-strait relations, which he said will be an advisory body for the ROC president and not a policy-making unit.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian says that Kaohsiung Harbor will be put under the jurisdiction of the Kaohsiung city government in the future.
2001: National Defense University President Gen. Hsia Ying-tsou says that Taiwan's first state-financed military think tank, the National Center for Strategic Studies, will be inaugurated on Sept. 1.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By strictly limiting the time of their service and making all imposts as light as possible: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to the mass of the people."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The China Times:
The Hualien Prosecutor's Office chief offered to resign.
The United Daily News:
TSU expels lawmaker Su Ying-kuei for false accusation against colleague.
The Liberty Times:
Scandal-linked Hyundai chief leaps to death.
The Taiwan Daily:
TSU expels lawmaker Su to end party infighting.
The Central Daily News:
Scandal-ridden Hyundai boss jumps to his death.
The China Post:
Accused Hyundai chief Chung leaps to his death from office.
The Taiwan News:
Peacekeepers swoop into Liberia as citizens rejoice.
The Taipei Times:
TSU expels lawmaker Su Ying-kuei.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLLUTION CAUSED BY OIL SLICK FROM CAPSIZED M'LAND VESSEL NOT SERIOUS

TEXT.P: The pollution caused by the oil slick from a capsized mainland Chinese vessel is not serious, authorities on the outlying island group of Kinmen reported Tuesday.
Kinmen troops stationed on the islet of Mengfu, located between Tatan and Little Kinmen, found the platform vessel capsized about 0.48 nautical miles southwest of the islet at 11 a.m. Monday.
The coast guard then sent rescue vessels two times, but no one was found aboard the ship. Rescuers later abandoned the rescue missions due to strong winds and rough seas triggered by Typhoon Morakot.
When the mainland vessel capsized, it leaked out a large amount of light diesel fuel.

Kinmen Environmental Protection Bureau director Tsai Shih-ming, braving rough seas, headed to the scene Tuesday. Tsai noted that the oil slick was about 800 meters long Monday but that it has narrowed to about 200 meters due to the sweeping sea waves as well as evaporation.

The Kinmen coast guard said the mainland vessel is now drifting in a southwest direction after a night of rough seas and strong winds, and is about 0.9 nautical miles away from Mengfu Islet and approaching Xiamen, mainland China. They said the ship poses no immediate danger.
The coast guard said that they have contacted Xiamen authorities and that the latter have promised to tow the capsized vessel back after the rough seas become calm.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HUMAN RIGHTS DELEGATION MEETS FOREIGN EXPERTS IN GENEVA
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A delegation of human rights experts and academics from Taiwan met with senior executives of major international human rights organizations based in Geneva Monday.
The two sides remained low-keyed about their meeting and agreed not to disclose the contents of their 90-minute talks.

Lee Yung-chih, leader of the delegation who concurrently heads the preparatory office of the Republic of China's national human rights memorial hall, only told reporters that the sides had exchanged views on a range of human rights issues of mutual concern.
"The meeting lasted longer than scheduled as we passionately discussed many topics, " Lee said, adding that the meeting proceeded in an amicable atmosphere.

The delegation arrived in Geneva on the fourth and last leg of its current European tour aimed at collecting first-hand information about the latest world trends in human rights development and promotion. The group had already visited major human rights museums in the Netherlands, Belgium and France before coming to Geneva.

Chen Che-nan, deputy secretary-general to the president who is serving as honorary leader of the delegation, said education is the main purpose of the government's plan to set up a national human rights memorial hall.

"We are hopeful that the memorial hall will teach the younger generation the meaning and importance of human rights, " Chen said, adding that the project is part of the government's efforts to prevent a recurrence of the tragic 2-28 Incident of 1947.
The proposed national human rights memorial hall will be located in the National Institute of Education Resources and Research in the Nanhai Garden near the Presidential Office in downtown Taipei.

Chen said that the Presidential Office has earmarked a budget of NT$200 million for the project and that the memorial hall will be inaugurated before the next presidential election set for March 20, 2004.

The new hall will exhibit documents on major international human rights events, the 2-28 Incident, the White Terror of the 1950s, indigenous people's rights, education and cultural development, and labor rights, Chen noted.
On Monday, the delegation also visited Taiwan's representative office in Geneva as well as its mission to the World Trade Organization. It will wrap up its four-leg European tour Tuesday.

The 2-28 Incident, known as the biggest wound in Taiwan history since World War II, was triggered when an elderly Taiwanese woman selling untaxed cigarettes in Taipei was severely beaten by an inspector of the Wine and Tobacco Monopoly Bureau. Faced by an angry mob, the inspector shot dead a bystander and fled to a nearly police station.

Faced by massive protests and rioting and unable to control the Situation, Taiwan Governor Chen Yi appealed for help to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in mainland China, who sent troops to the northern port city of Keeling, from where they spread out over the island, killing along the way.

In the ensuing period known as "White Terror," thousands of local people, especially doctors, lawyers and scholars, were murdered or imprisoned by the Nationalists, and many were not released until the 1980s. Public discussion of the incident was taboo until the early 1990s.
