DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON MORAKOT BRINGS BOUNTIFUL WATER TO KINMEN

TEXT.P: Typhoon Morakot swept over Kinmen and moved toward the Chinese mainland Monday night, bringing bountiful water to the Kinmen islands without causing heavy damages.

The Kinmen county government's center for agricultural experiment said the Kinmen islands received 180 millimeters of rainfall in the past two days. All reservoirs and lakes on the islands are full of water.
All transportation services between Kinmen and Taiwan and between Kinmen and Xiamen, which were disrupted Monday by typhoon, were resumed Tuesday morning.

The Central Weather Bureau lifted the warning against Typhoon Morakot Monday night, and forecast that it may rain heavily in Kinmen and in the southern and southeastern parts of Taiwan Tuesday. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROYAL BRUNEI AIRLINES RESUMES BRUNEI-TAIPEI FLIGHT SERVICES
DOC.DATELINE: Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Royal Brunei Airlines on Tuesday resumed its Taipei-Brunei flight services, which were suspended in April due to the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak.

The airline is resuming its Boeing 757 Taipei-to-Brunei flights departing at 11 a.m. on Tuesdays and Fridays, and its Brunei-to-Taipei flights departing at 3: 15 p.m. on Mondays and Thursdays, said Pan Chian-hua, president of Royal Brunei Airlines' Taiwan operations.
The flight between Taipei and Brunei takes about three and a half hours.
To upgrade services for Taiwan visitors, Royal Brunei Airlines also plans to increase its Taipei-Brunei flights from the current two per week to three per week from this October, Pan said.
Brunei's official tourism bureau will also dispatch more personnel to Taipei to beef up tourism promotion aimed at soliciting tourists from Taiwan, according to Pan.
Brunei, a tiny sultanate located between two Malaysian states, is one of the richest countries in the world. About 100,000 tourists from Taiwan visit Brunei each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG PROCESSING ZONE BECOMES IMPORTANT LCD PRODUCTION BASE

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone (KEPZ) has gradually become an important base for manufacturing liquid crystal display (LCD) and its related products, an official of the Export Processing Zone Administration said Tuesday.
He said that, after many years of efforts to develop itself into an ideal production base for LCD and its related industries, the KEPD has been favored by many investors.

LCD and its related industries invested NT$1.21 billion (US$35.2 million) in the zone in 2002. The same kind of investors spent NT$654 million in new projects and NT$3.13 billion in expanding their production facilities in the zone in the first half of this year.
Business revenues received by the LCD and related industries in the zone amounted to NT$47.77 billion in 2002 and NT$20.41 billion in the first half of this year, the official said. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, DPP CHAIRMEN CALL ON WU AFTER HUALIEN BY-ELECTION TO BURY HATCHET

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong on Tuesday called on Wu Kuo-tung, a former Hualien magistrate who lost in Saturday's by-election, in Chian Township, Hualien, in a bid to bury the hatchet after the hotly-contested election.

Lien told Wu that "an election is only one period of time, while personal relationships are forever, " expressing the hope that they could mend the fences after any hard feelings that may have arisen from the election.
Soong said that there might have been "unpleasant feelings and conflicts during the election, " but that their meeting represents "a respect for each other."

For his part, Wu said that he would not blame Lien or Soong for not supporting him during the election, adding that what he was most dissatisfied with was President Chen Shui-bian's remarks during the campaign implying that Wu was guilty and awaiting punishment.

Wu, who was excluded from the KMT's nomination process because of his alleged involvement in a land development scandal, pointed out that he was found not guilty by an appeal court and that the case had not been closed only because of a procedural row between the court and the prosecutors.

Lien noted that the KMT's regulations governing the nomination of candidates bars the party from nominating anyone who still has legal suits pending. He expressed the hope that Wu would understand the reform mechanism of the party.
Wu reaffirmed that he "would not blame Lien and Soong" for failing to provide support.
Wu was a veteran KMT member before he was expelled from the party prior to Saturday's election after insisting on running despite failing to get the KMT's endorsement.
He finished third in the election, behind Hsieh Shen-san, the joint candidate of the KMT and PFP, and You Ying-lung, the candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
Wu, who has solid grass-roots support, garnered 18.26 percent of the vote, compared with Hsieh's 51.36 percent, and You's 28.92 percent.

Wu said right after the election that he would not blame Lien and Soong and would still support them in the presidential election next year. The remarks were generally believed to have paved the way for Tuesday's meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 117.74 points to close at 5,259.45.
The bourse opened at 5,403.84 and then fluctuated between 5,407.50 and 5,259.45 during the trading session.

A total of 3.76 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$87.57 billion (US$2.5 billion) , an increase from the previous trading session which saw 3.25 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$75.39 billion (US$2.19 billion).

All eight of the major stock categories lost ground, with cement shares and electrical issues moving down the most, both at 2.7 percent, followed by construction shares and financial issues, both at 1.4 percent, paper stocks at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.9 percent, and textile issues at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 577 to 103, with 80 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO VISIT U.S., CANADA IN MID-AUGUST

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou is set to head to the United States and Canada in mid-August to visit several cities with which Taipei has sisterhood ties.
Ma originally planned to visit earlier, but the trip was postponed due to the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak.
The mayor will head to Toronto, Atlanta and several other cities, as well as the U.S. Centers for Disease Control (CDC), to learn more about their experiences in the campaign against SARS.
During his North American visit, Ma is scheduled to give a speech to the Taiwanese Association in San Francisco Aug. 22 at the invitation of the association.
Ma will also visit several high-tech companies in Silicon Valley to discuss trade and economic cooperation with Taipei.
A long-distance running enthusiast, Ma will also take part in a marathon held by the University of California, Berkeley. (by Nocturne Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for August moved down 101 points to close at 5,269, with 37,520 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September lost 106 points to finish at 5,253, with 256 contract transactions, while December futures fell 38 points to close at 5,320, with only one contract traded.
Next March futures lost 110 points to finish at 5,260, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,370 for August, 5,359 for September, 5,358 for December, 5,370 for next March, and 5,316 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
August TE futures decreased 6.4 points to close at 234, with 4,307 contract transactions, while September TE futures lost 6.5 points to finish at 233.3, with 42 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
August TF futures moved down 9.6 points to close at 685.4, with 2,000 contract transactions, while September TF futures fell 8.2 points to finish at 685, with 73 contracts changing hands.
Next March TF futures lost 7.6 points to finish at 690, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: KETAGALAN INSTITUTE TO OPEN CLASS ON TAIWAN LITERATURE AND HISTORY

TEXT.P: The Ketagalan Institute, an academy run by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), is scheduled to open a three-month reading class on Taiwanese literature and history in September.

Ketagalan Institute president Chen Shih-meng said the Taiwanese literature and history reading class will serve as a stepping-stone on the path to deeper, more comprehensive studies of Taiwan history.

The class will also be a window on Taiwan's unique history -- which is replete with periods of colonial rule; Taiwan's unique politics -- featuring inextricably entwined political traditions and phenomena; and Taiwan's unique cultures -- which are diverse and fast changing, Chen said.
Studying Taiwanese literature and history will help the Taiwan people better understand themselves and identify more with the land and its cultures, he added.

According to Ketagalan Institute officials, three heavyweight books which are representative accounts of Taiwanese history and people during the period of Japanese colonial rule and the early years of the period of Nationalist rule will be introduced and studied during the three-month course. The books are "The Silent Spring, " which is a collection of novels related to the 2-28 Incident; the Collection of Novels by Lai Ho; and The Orphan in Asia authored by Wu Chuo-liu.

The Ketagalan officials said all interested people, regardless of their ethnicity, age, gender, profession or political affiliation, are welcome to contact the institute, at www.ketagalan.org.tw, for information about application and registration, between Aug. 6-20.
The Ketagalan Institute, the brainchild of President Chen Shui-bian, who doubles as DPP chairman, became operational in early April this year.
The academy is aimed at nurturing a new generation of politically adept professionals for public service, Chen said in his speech made during the inauguration of the school in late March.

DOC.HEADLINE: WAN-AN DRILL TO FOCUS ON ANTI-TERRORIST OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: This year's annual Wan-An civil defense drill will for the first time include practice in anti-terrorist operations, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) announced Tuesday.

MND spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng told a regular news conference that the Wan-An No. 26 defense exercise will focus on upgrading city and county governments' response to terrorist attacks as well as their disaster relief.

The Wan-An series of civil defense drills will kick off Aug. 28 with a mock anti-terrorist operation at the Formosa Plastics Group's petrochemical complex in Yunlin County's Mailiao township on Taiwan's southwestern coast, Huang said.

Similar anti-terrorist drills at selected areas in northern Taiwan, including the Shin Kong Building -- a skyscraper near the Taiwan Railway terminal in downtown Taipei -- and Chinese Petroleum Corp.'s (CPC's) Taoyuan Refinery, will be conducted Aug. 29.

Huang said the Wan-An series of drills will cover two parts -- evacuation of civilian people from landmark buildings, including shopping malls, department stores and public transport stations, as well as mock anti-terrorist operations to test local government's command and control abilities.

Huang said the military police's special service units and several army units will join the Wan-An series of drills and assist city and county governments in establishing standard operation procedures in emergency relief.
Anti-terrorist exercises will also be held in central and southern Taiwan in October at selected locations, including Makung Airport in the offshore island county of Penghu, Huang said.
Moreover, Huang said, the Wan-An series of civil defense exercises will also practice in skills to cope with sabotage, abduction and explosion.
Anti-sabotage drills will be held at major public utilities, including Suao oil depot in Ilan County, Hsiehho Power Plant in Keelung, CPC's Hushi oil depot and Chienshan Power Plan in Penghu.
"In these drills, we'll suppose that the facilities have been sabotaged by enemies who have infiltrated the island," Huang said.
Anti-abduction drills are planned at Hsinchu railway station and Hsinchu County's Taiyuan industrial park, in which mock abductions of people by terrorists will take place.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN INDUSTRIAL PARK BECOMES BASTION OF TFT-LCD MANUFACTURERS

TEXT.P: The Southern Taiwan Science Park in Tainan has become an important bastion for the island's TFT-LCD (thin film transistor-liquid crystal display) manufacturers, and the cluster effect among optoelectronics companies will help transform southern Taiwan's industrial structure, the park's director said Monday.

Tai Chien pointed out that while Taiwan's optoelectronics industry has proved its international competitiveness, the Chi Mei Electronics Corp., with a monthly output of 600,000 TFT-LCDs from its Tainan factories, has contributed greatly to the development of the optoelectronics industry in southern Taiwan.

Established in July 1997, the Southern Taiwan Science Park has accommodated manufacturers of semiconductors, optical electronics, and precision machines, as well as biotechnology firms, although the lion's share of the investments are in the optoelectronics sector.
Meanwhile, the 30-year-old Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone has succeeded in attracting some LCD manufacturers to set up production lines in the industrial zone.

A report on the export processing zone administration released Monday indicated that LCD manufacturers invested NT$1.2 billion in the zone in 2002, and another NT$654 million poured in from three local LCD manufacturers and one Hong Kong company in the first half of this year.

According to the report, the LCD manufacturing industry is becoming a main force in the industrial zone. It said that last year, the LCD companies' business turnover amounted to NT$47.7 billion, accounting for 55 percent of the industrial zone's overall revenues.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.036 to close at NT$34.466.
A total of US$635 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$34.462 and was traded between NT$34.391 and NT$34.470.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURISM BUREAU PLANNING TAX REBATE FOR FOREIGN VISITORS

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications is planning to offer tax rebates to foreign visitors as part of the government's drive to boost tourism.
Tourism Bureau Director Su Cheng-tian said the plan is still under assessment by relevant authorities and may become effective Oct. 1 after being approved.
According to the plan, foreign visitors will enjoy a 5-percent tax rebate on one-stop purchases totalling more than NT$3,000 (US$87).
The goal of doubling the number of foreign visitors to Taiwan to 5 million by 2008 remains high on the government's agenda.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ALLY WITH NATIONS THAT SHARE STANCES IN WTO MEETING

TEXT.P: Taiwan will seek to forge closer cooperation with nations sharing similar positions as Taiwan during the ministerial conference of the World Trade Organization (WTO) next month in Mexico, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Yu Chin-jung, deputy director of MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs, said that the meeting Sept. 11-14 in Cancun, Mexico, will mainly review the progress of the last round of multilateral talks in Doha, Qatar.

Yu added that on issues where the talks are stalled or falling behind, it is hoped that a policy decision can be made through the consultations of high-ranking officials, so that talks on issues from the Doha round can be completed as scheduled on Jan. 1, 2004.
Yu said that Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu, accompanied by MOFA's Director of Economic and Trade Affairs Liu Jung-ti, will lead Taiwan's delegation for the meeting.

Yu noted that the Taiwan mission will conduct bilateral talks with the ministers of major trading partners, discuss economic and trade issues, and establish communication channels with ministerial officials from other member countries to expand Taiwan's trade and diplomatic relations with them.
Taiwan will focus on such issues as agricultural and non-agricultural products access and service trade in the meeting next month, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MEETS SINGAPOREAN DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou met with Singaporean Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong Tuesday to exchange views on the fight against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).
Ma said after their talks that Singaporean officials, including Lee, have all expressed sincerity in sharing their experiences in dealing with SARS.
"We have agreed to forge a cooperative mechanism to facilitate future campaigns against SARS, " said Ma, who arrived in Singapore Monday for a three-day visit.
Both Singapore and Taipei were gripped by SARS outbreaks between March and June. Ma said Taipei has much to learn from Singapore in SARS prevention.

Ma said he was also impressed by Singapore's decision not to hold anyone responsible for in-hospital SARS outbreaks. "Lee had told me that discipline or punishment would only discourage frontline health care providers from joining the campaign against communicable diseases in the future," he added.

Several senior executives of Taipei Municipal Hoping Hospital have been disciplined or even indicted for a SARS outbreak inside its complex in late April, which led to a sudden deterioration of the SARS situation in Taiwan.

A delegation of Taipei municipal officials and city councilors, headed by Deputy Mayor Ou Chin-der, arrived in Singapore a day before Ma's arrival on the third and last leg of its three-city Asian tour designed to study how other communities handled the SARS problem. The delegation visited Hong Kong and Hanoi before coming to the city-state.

On Tuesday, Ma and the delegation members visited Tan Tock Seng Hospital -- Singapore's second-largest hospital with 1,064 beds -- to see for themselves its SARS precautionary measures and treatment facilities.

Tan Tock Seng Hospital was turned into a SARS-only facility in mid-March and it once housed more than 400 probable and suspected SARS patients at one point. The hospital now still maintains temperature-taking and other SARS-prevention measures to ward off any possible SARS relapse.

Ma said he is convinced that if SARS stages a comeback this winter, the Taipei City Government will be able to make a quicker and more effective response through the experiences learned in the past few months.

When the SARS outbreak reached its peak in Taipei in May, Ma recalled that Singaporean health officials held a teleconference with Taipei health administrators and medical experts. Moreover, Singapore donated 100,000 N95 masks and protective garb for Taipei's frontline health care providers.
"We appreciate its assistance at our difficult time, " Ma said, adding that those exchanges have laid a foundation for future cooperation.

The Taipei delegation is composed of government officials and city councilors, including directors from the Department of Health, the Fire Department, and the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission of the city government.
Mayor Ma and the municipal government officials are scheduled to head back to Taipei Aug. 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES TOTAL US 182.2 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves amounted to US$182.2 billion at the end of July, an increase of US$20.55 billion over the end of last year, the Central Bank of China said Tuesday.
The central bank in Taipei attributed the increase mainly to the influx of foreign capital and the income from the bank's deposits in foreign commercial banks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BLIND ATHLETE WINS GOLD MEDAL AT WORLD JUDO COMPETITION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Lee Ching-chung won a gold medal Tuesday in a judo competition being sponsored by the International Blind Sports Federation in Quebec, Canada, according to the Chinese Taipei Sports Federation of Disabled Athletes.
Lee won a bronze medal in the same competition held in Madrid in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ELECTRICAL MEASUREMENT STANDARDS ACCEPTED BY BIPM

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) announced Tuesday that its electrical measurement standards have been approved and registered in the Bureau International des Poids et Mesures (BIPM) -- the International Bureau of Weights and Measures.

Hsu Chang-piao, director of ITRI's Center for Measurement Standards (CMS), said that in this era of globalization, establishing measurement standards is a reflection of a country's economic and scientific prowess.

Hsu added that the registration of Taiwan's electrical measurement standards in the BIPM means that the world community will recognize the island's measurement standards for its goods in international trade.
The ITRI'S Electrical Measurement Laboratory provides traceability of electrical standards for domestic industry. It has established standards in DC/AC voltages and currents, AC power and impedance.

In additional to the electrical measurement standards, the CMS has also established standards in other areas, including temperature, time and length, and will offer technical support to other countries in need.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD ADMINISTRATION TO SET UP WHARVES, AIRSTRIPS ON ISLETS

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration (CGA) said Tuesday it will build wharves and airstrips on two Taiwan-held islets to better protect fishermen and provide maritime disaster relief.

CGA Director-General Wang Chun said the Cabinet has approved the CGA's plan to build a wharf on Tungsha (Pratas) Islands in the South China Sea as part of its efforts to strengthen protection of local fishermen operating in the region.

Speaking at an inaugural ceremony aboard the 1,951-ton CGA patrol vessel "Hohsing" for an oceanography student camp, Wang said the Cabinet has budgeted NT$40 million for the construction project to be launched in 2004.
Moreover, Wang said, the CGA is also planning to build a pier and an airstrip on Pengchiayu, a small isle off the northern Taiwan port of Keelung.

"Once the project is completed, CGA patrol ships and airborne police helicopters will be able to land on Pengchiayu while carrying out relief operations in waters farther away from Taiwan," Wang said.

Responding to criticism that the government has not fulfilled its duty of protecting fishermen, Wang said the CGA has stepped up patrols in waters north and south of Taiwan to offer timely assistance to Taiwan fishermen operating in those regions.

Since Feb. 15 this year, Wang said, the CGA has conducted two-day patrols per week in waters off Taiwan's northern coast. Patrols in waters off the southern Taiwan coast, particularly areas adjacent to the Philippine economic zone, have also been intensified since April. Starting last week, the number of patrols in the regions has been increased to two per week, he added.
Wang also urged local fishermen not to operate in other countries' waters to avoid unnecessary trouble.

More than 30 college students and teachers took part in the weeklong workshop aimed at bettering their understanding of the CGA's missions in thwarting smuggling of humans and contraband goods as well as protecting marine resources, dealing with pollution and providing disaster relief.
Wang said he hopes the program will help local people "know, love and protect the seas."

The "Hohsing" will cruise around the nation's three northern islets -- Pengchiayu, Mienhuayu and Huapingyu. From July 28 through Aug. 29, the CGA will offer 36 such voyages for 641 college students and teachers under its training program.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPELLED TSU MAVERICK LAWMAKER NOT CONSIDERING JOINING OTHER PARTY

TEXT.P: One day after being expelled from the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), Legislator Su Ying-kuei said Tuesday that he is not currently thinking of joining any other party.
Su, an outspoken, maverick legislator, said, "I thank those from other parties and even independent legislators, but I will not be considering the matter for the time being."

Su denied that he threw a tantrum during party consultations while reviewing a draft bill regarding real estate sales divisions, saying that he only threw some paper cups and plates. He said that "when you look at the fist fights of other legislators, it is preposterous to accuse me of being violent."
Su described the decision to expel him as "chaotic, " citing a TV poll Monday evening that indicated that the public overwhelmingly support him.
Su said that he wished the TSU the best, expressing the hope that the party will be "maturer, " adding that any party which wishes to have long-term development must have rightiousness.

Su, a lawyer-turned-legislator, has won recognition for his conscientious efforts in the legislature and was voted one of the top 10 best-performing legislators by Taipei Society, an organization comprised of scholars. But he was said to have offended more of his fellow legislators in the pan green camp -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the TSU -- than the pan blue camp, meaning the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP), because he had targeted individuals close to the party, including Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh and Legislator Cheng Chao-ming, both of the DPP.
The DPP, which is an ally of the TSU, has kept a low profile regarding Su.
Chen Chi-mai, DPP party whip, said that he had not discussed inviting Su to join the DPP, saying that this "will have to wait for all the flap to die down."
But Chen said that he believed that Su would still stand by the pan green camp on political and other issues.
KMT party whip Lee Chia-chin said Tuesday that if Su can identify with the ideals of the KMT, the party welcomes him.

Lee said that Su's performance at the legislature is recognized by all, and if he, after discussing with his friends and family, decides to identify with the ideals of the KMT, the party will welcome him with "open arms."

PFP party whip Chung Shao-he said that he had "deep talks" with Su a few days ago, and the expulsion by the TSU is just "stepping on a talented person, " adding that there is the possibility of cooperation between the PFP and Su.
TSU party whip Chien Lin Whei-jun said that the party "respects Su's freedom to decide his future direction, and will not interfere with him."

On speculation that the TSU acted rashly to expel Su, Chien said that Su had never toed the party line, and his allegations against fellow legislator Lo Chih-ming had not been substantiated by hard evidence, and was "the last straw."
On whether the TSU will accept Su back, Chien said that it all depends on Su, saying that he had always looked down on his fellow legislators, believing them to be not conscientious enough.

The dispute between Su and Lo originated from Su's public accusation last week against Lo, claiming that Lo tried to obstruct the judicial investigation of a scandal involving senior police officers who allegedly turned a blind eye to illegal video game parlors in Kaohsiung city, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SARS TSAR THANKS OVERSEAS CHINESE IN U. S. FOR THEIR HELP
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Former Department of Health Minister Lee Ming-liang Monday thanked overseas Chinese living in the United States for their assistance and donations to Taiwan in the fight against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).

Lee, who was appointed by President Chen Shui-bian to serve as the chief coordinator of a national task force to tackle the potentially deadly disease, hailed the compassion of overseas Chinese during a luncheon with Chinese community representatives from the greater Washington, D. C. area and Baltimore at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Washington.
Representative Chen Chien-jen, Taiwan's de-facto ambassador to the United States, sponsored the gathering.
Lee also awarded citations to various domestic Chinese community groups in recognition of their assistance and contributions.

Lee also said he appreciated the help and care from the United States authorities after SARS broke out in Taiwan, noting that the purpose of his current tour is to learn something from the U. S. side for setting up a safety mechanism in Taiwan in the wake of SARS. He has met officials from the U.S. Department of Health and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention since his arrival over the weekend.

The Chinese community leaders lauded Lee's achievements in containing SARS in Taiwan and described him as a "SARS killer" and a "Taiwan savior" for his leadership and work in leading Taiwan through the difficult times.

Meanwhile, Lee is slated to meet reporters Wednesday at the United Nations Correspondents Association to talk about Taiwan's SARS-fighting experience, in his capacity as a public health expert and a professor at the Tzu Chi University based in eastern Hualien County.

DOC.HEADLINE: CITY GOVERNMENT TO SANCTION AUTO RACE TRACK IN TAIPEI NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: If all goes well, the first small-scale auto race track will open in Taipei in the first half of next year, an official of the Taipei City Government said Tuesday.

Wu Chin-ki, director of the Department of Education, said that the race track could be ready in May or June at the earliest. Hopefully, this will promote legal leisure activities and address the nagging problem of car and motorcycle racing on public roads.
Wu made the remarks after the Taipei City Council passed regulations regarding the commissioned management of small-scale racing tracks Tuesday.
Wu said that Taipei City Government has chosen a riverside park at Fuyuan Street, in the Sungshan district in Taipei to build the first legal small-scale race track in Taiwan.
Wu said that the track will accommodate go-karts, motorcycles, and will have a special area for children.
The maximum fees for racing cars will be NT$300 per 10 minutes and NT$100 for motorcycles per 10 minutes, he said.
The operators must take full responsibility for their own safety and that of those watching, as well as purchasing insurance.
Wu said that the Taipei City Government will immediately start to invite members of the private sector to join in the bidding to operate the race track.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEN AS HOMEMAKERS ON THE RISE: POLL

TEXT.P: Men accepting the role of homemaker is no longer taboo in Taiwan thanks to the growing awareness of gender equality, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.

The 9999 Pan-Asia Manpower Bank conducted the poll in connection with Father's Day which falls on Aug. 8 in Taiwan. The manpower bank distributed questionnaires to local fathers through parents' associations around the island. A total of 1,768 valid replies were collected.
The survey found that 14.25 percent of the respondents said they manage their households and care for their children while their wives work.
Meanwhile, 33.71 percent said they work while their wives manage their households; and 41.63 percent said both they and their wives work and baby sitters or relatives look after their children.
Asked whether child rearing has affected their work, 72.96 percent said "yes," with 27.04 percent saying "no."

Just over 65 percent said they have never felt remorse for having children; 21.72 percent said they felt a bit of regret; and 12.44 percent said they feel remorseful and that if they could make a choice again, they would not have children.

As to how children affect their work, 59.07 percent said their moods at work are affected by their children's situations; 46.82 percent said that they couldn't get to work on time because of taking children to see doctors or delivering articles to their children at school; 34.57 percent said children have forced them to cut back on their work time; 26.51 percent said children have forced them to reduce their socializing time; and 7.91 percent said children have affected their career promotions.

According to the poll, 54.41 percent of fathers complained that day care or baby-sitting charges are too expensive; 42.08 percent said after-school care fees are too high; 41.63 percent said skyrocketing tuition fees are a headache; and 31.45 percent said communication with their children is a problem for them.

The poll also found that the traditional concept that children must finance their aging parents' living expenses is fading, as 57.8 percent said they don't want their children to support them after they get old. Only 11.54 percent uphold that concept, while 30.88 percent said if their children want to support them, they will take pleasure in accepting their aid but will not force them to do so.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS NOT OBLIGED TO ATTEND LEGISLATURE'S SARS COMMITTEE MEETING

TEXT.P: Officials from the Executive Yuan chose not to attend a meeting of an ad hoc committee of the Legislative Yuan regarding the budget allocated to prevent severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) since attending such a meeting is not required by the ROC Constitution, Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Tuesday.

He said the Constitution, which is the supreme guideline for the relationship between the Executive Yuan and the Legislative Yuan, obligates officials to attend only meetings of the standing or special committees of the Legislative Yuan during legislative sessions.

Noting that the Committee for the Prevention of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) is neither a standing nor a special committee under the Organic Law of the Legislative Yuan, and the legislature is now in recess, Lin said there is no legal requirement for officials to answer questions from lawmakers from the SARS committee.

The SARS committee, formed by lawmakers to overlook the government's NT$50 billion budget for the prevention of SARS, met for the fifth time Tuesday; however, government officials summoned by the committee failed to show up.
Angered by what they called contempt for the legislature, members of the committee blamed the Executive Yuan for evading the supervision of the legislature and preempting the committee's work.

Instead of resorting to bad-mouthing, Lin urged the legislators to engage the Executive Yuan in compliance with the law, saying that "neither loud voices, nor dramatic action will give you the upper hand in this case."

He made the comments after a group of opposition lawmakers from the SARS committee went to the Executive Yuan to unfurl a banner, protesting the absence of officials for the third time in a row from their meetings.
They went to the Executive Yuan to protest, and were met only by a staff member of the premier. They then went to the Control Yuan to ask them to intercede.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMER PRICE INDEX DROPS IN FIRST SEVEN MONTHS OF THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) in the first seven months of this year dropped by 0.28 percent over the same period last year, officials of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Tuesday.

According to DGBAS statistics, the CPI in July stood at 98.8, a drop of 0.98 percent over the same month last year, which the DGBAS attributed to a discount campaign presented by the garment industry.

Meanwhile, the wholesale price index in July rose by 0.11 percent over June, which DGBAS officials said was due to the price hike of several products, including petroleum, natural gas, steel products and DRAMs.

DGBAS officials attributed the drop in the CPI in the first seven months to the country's entry into the World Trade Organization, which pushed tariff reductions onto many imported products, the fierce price competition among domestic products, as well as the economic recession, which was aggravated by the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome on the island.

People doubt whether Taiwan will experience deflation as has been seen in Japan. Chen Chang-hsiung, a section chief of the DGBAS, admitted that Taiwan may have a drop in CPI this year, but added that the rate of fall may slow in the second half of this year as economists predict better economic prospects during that time.

According to DGBAS statistics, in the first six months, the CPI in the United States rose by 2.5 percent; South Korea was up by 3.7 percent; Malaysia was up by 1.1 percent; while the CPI in Japan dropped by 0.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOWNSHIP, VILLAGE LEADERS OPPOSE 'CONSULTATIVE REFERENDUM'

TEXT.P: A group of grassroots township and village leaders asked the central government Tuesday at an annual gathering to lay a legal basis before holding a national referendum.

Pointing out that the leaders would not hold a government referendum without a legal framework in place, central Fengyuan Mayor Chang I-cheng, who is also the chief executive officer of the National Association of Townships and Village Leaders, said the motion he introduced was unanimously approved by his counterparts with a round of applause.
Members of the association held an annual conference at the Legislative Yuan, in which opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong were invited to take part.

Arguing that the central government should focus their efforts and attention on issues of major public interest and concern, Chang said a vast majority of grassroots township and village leaders are opposed to the government's plan to hold a "consultative referendum" on issues about the fate of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant and Taiwan's need to join the World Health Organization as an observer.
Chang said the association approved a six-point resolution demanding the central government take concrete measures to improve Taiwan's rising unemployment and worsening law and order.

Although the central government claims that holding a referendum is a normal practice in a democracy in which human rights must be fully respected, Chang said allowing a public vote without adequate complementary measures in Taiwan may create chaos because of the country's delicate political situation.
Holding a referendum now in Taiwan will only deviate the government's efforts to improve the economy, further deteriorating law and order in society, Chang stressed.

Amid the public's strong expectations that the government should effectively revive Taiwan's economy, the grassroots authorities could not abide by the central government's referendum plan if it wishes to force it into practice with just an administrative decree, while overlooking the need and justice to forge a legal framework, he warned. By Flor Wang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S DIPLOMACY IS BASED ON DEMOCRACY, HUMAN RIGHTS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's diplomacy is based on democracy and human rights when seeking international support and friendship, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Richard Shih said Tuesday.

Speaking at a workshop on Taiwan's current diplomatic work and overall diplomacy held at the Executive Yuan's southern Taiwan office in Kaohsiung, Shih said that Taiwan will try to increase its substantial relations with friendly nations around the world through economic cooperation for mutual benefits and to further safeguard the national security and status by peaceful diplomatic strategies.

He also explained President Chen Shui-bian's and Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien's concepts and ideas on diplomacy, the MOFA's organization and functions, the international situations facing the country, Beijing's obstruction against Taiwan's participation in international organizations and countermeasures taken by the MOFA at the meeting which was attended by local government officials, scholars, representatives of civil organizations and students in southern Taiwan.
Shih encouraged the general public to support or join the government's efforts in increasing Taiwan's visibility in the international arena.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH WINNERS OF SOFTWARE DESIGN COMPETITION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met Tuesday with a student team from the National Taiwan University (NTU) that won first place in an international computer software design competition.

The president hailed the student team's success at the Fourth Computer Society International Design Competition held by the United States Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) , saying they have given a good account of the excellence of Taiwan's education.

Noting that his administration is transforming Taiwan from a giant manufacturer of information products into a center for software development, the president said this endeavor relies on talented individuals such as the members of team from the NTU Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering.

The competition drew more than 170 teams from around the world. Organizers selected the top 25 projects from the participants base on their reports. A judging panel then met May 16-17 to choose the top 10 projects.
In the final stage, the top 10 teams were invited to present their projects in Washington, D.C., June 29-July 1.
The NTU team was selected by an international panel of experts as the number one project.
The software that the team developed deals with a platform for teacher-student interactions using wireless tablet PCs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TIES KEY TO TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT: LEE KUAN YEW

TEXT.P: Singapore's Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew said Tuesday that whether Taiwan's economy can recover in the second half of this year hinges on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait ties.
Lee made the remarks at a meeting with visiting Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who was on a three-day visit aimed at studying Singapore's experience in fighting severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).
Lee told Ma that he was very concerned about Taiwan's economic problems, especially the unemployment, adding that he hopes to see more economic development next year.
Judging from the changing international situation, Lee noted that Taiwan should use its unique advantage in developing its economy.

Meanwhile, the Singaporean politician stressed that a direct relation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait would be of great help to Taiwan's economy. However, he added, this should be decided by the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TO BEGIN TOUR TO PARAGUAY AUG.7

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu announced at a news conference Tuesday that she will lead a delegation to Asuncion, Paraguay as President Chen Shui-bian's envoy to the inauguration of president-elect Nicanor Duarte on Aug. 15.
Lu and her 43-member entourage will leave Taipei on Thursday, and visit Hawaii, Los Angeles and Panama on her way to Asuncion.
While in Panama, her Panamanian counterpart Dominador Kaiser Bazan Jimenez will honor her by awarding her a medal.
During her stay in Paraguay, the vice president said she will give one speech each at the parliament and Asuncion University.
On her way back to Taiwan, the vice president said she will visit Seattle.

Lu denied local reports that Washington, angered by Taipei's unilateral disclosure of Lu's planned stopover in New York, had refused to let her make a transit stop in that city, saying that she chose to make stopovers in western America to promote an international conference to be organized by Taiwan in September for leaders of cities around the Pacific Rim.
Furthermore, she said: "Most American leaders are out of the United States for the time being. The chance of meeting any heavyweight U.S. politicians in eastern America is slim."
She is slated to return to Taipei on Aug. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TIMETABLE FOR EXPRESS SHIPPING LINKS WITH MAINLAND: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun told a group of European businessmen in Taiwan Tuesday that there is no timetable for the launch of an express shipping link with mainland China.

In a meeting with members of the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (EEET), Yu said Taiwan is trying to open a quick shipping link with mainland China as a substitute for direct shipping links which is impossible because of political differences between Taipei and Beijing, but Beijing's refusal to negotiate with Taiwan makes it impossible for Taiwan to set up a timetable on its own.
The EEET has recommended that Taipei authorities allow foreign ships ply directly between Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF PROMISES CLEAR POLITICS IF ELECTED PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, who is set to run in the next presidential election, promised to create a better society and government if elected.

Speaking at the launch of one of his campaign groups in Taipei, Lien promised to create a clear political environment, an efficient administration, a booming economy, a society with justice, and a peaceful relationship with mainland China.
All in all, Lien said, he wants to give back to the public and businessmen hope and prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ACCEPTS RESULTS OF HUALIEN MAGISTRATE BY-ELECTION: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) accepts the results of last Saturday's Hualien magistrate by-election and that his administration will continue to push ahead with construction projects in the eastern county.
Chen made the remarks when he presided over the weekly meeting of the DPP Central Standing Executive Committee in his capacity as the party chairman.
He said that the election is over and the central government's efforts to develop Hualien and the eastern part of Taiwan will not be changed by the election results.

The government has attached much importance to the people's welfare and local construction of Hualien and has launched various construction projects in the eastern county over the past three-plus years.

Chen also congratulated Hsieh Shen-shan, winner of the by-election who was jointly fielded by the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party, and wished him great success in managing the county's administration.
He pledged that the central government will continue to work closely with the Hualien County Government to build the county into a "beautiful garden of Taiwan."

The Hualien by-election was the main topic discussed in the DPP Standing Central Executive Committee meeting which reviewed the electoral campaign by the party's nominated candidate You Ying-lung who was beaten by Hsieh with 73,710 against 41,508 votes, or 51.4 percent to 28.9 percent of the total ballots cast in the election.
Wu Kuo-tung, an independent candidate in the race, captured 26,205 votes or 18.3 percent of the total ballots cast.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 6, or the ninth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1806: Holy Roman Emperor Francis II is forced to resign due to the third defeat in the war against Bonaparte Napoleon.
1825: Bolivia declares independence from Peru.
1890: A murderer named William Kemmler is the first prison executed by electric chair in the United States.
1914: Yuan Shih-kai declares China's neutrality in World War I.
1932: The first international film festival opens in Venice, Italy with 29 motion pictures from the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Soviet Union and Italy being shown.
1945: U.S. plane drops the first atomic bomb in Hiroshima, Japan, killing more than 90,000 and injuring over 9,000.
1949: At the invitation of Korean President Syngman Rhee, President Chiang Kai-shek flies to Chinhae, Korea to discuss the formation of a Pacific alliance.
1962: Jamaica declares independence from Britain.
1997: Nicaraguan President Arnoldo Aleman Lacayo arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1997: A South Korean Boeing 747-300 jetliner crashes in Guam, killing 234 on board.
2001: After careful planning, prayer rooms are formally opened at CKS International Airport. The three adjacent prayer rooms have one room equipped with rush mats for kneeling, another fitted with rows of chairs and still another with mattresses and a mark to show the direction of Mecca.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO ALLEGED SPIES BEING HELD INCOMMUNICADO

TEXT.P: A middle-rank technician with the military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST) and the chief executive officer of a private firm were held incommunicado Wednesday on charges of spying for mainland China.

Chen Shih-liang, a technician at the CIST's Electronics Research Institute, and Yeh Yu-chen, a technology firm CEO, were arrested Tuesday on suspicion of espionage. After questioning the two overnight, prosecutors applied to have them detained for further investigations. The Taiwan High Court approved the application early this morning.

A third member of the alleged spy ring, Hsu Hsi-tse, a U.S. citizen of Chinese origin, was also arrested Tuesday when he landed at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport. The Public Prosecutors' Office at the Taiwan High Court was still questioning him as of the press time. He is expected to be held incommunicado like his two alleged accomplices later in the day.
The trio were accused of joining up to steal Taiwan's defense secrets and purchasing strategic high-tech products in the United States and then sending them to mainland China.

The Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) claimed that Yeh, 54, had collected classified information about the CIST's defense technology research programs through Chen, including the theater missile defense system, anti-submarine equipment and the timetable for procurement of P-3C anti-submarine aircraft. Yeh then allegedly brought the secret data to mainland China.

Moreover, investigators said, Yeh had collected information about Taiwan's military cooperative projects with the United States through Hsu, a retired Boeing Co. engineer. Hsu, 57, allegedly had hacked into the U.S. government's classified files through the Internet to steal information about F-16 fighters' night-time weaponry system and strategic data links.

Worse still, MJIB agents claimed that Yeh had counterfeited the CIST's "end-user certificates" for Hsu to purchase sophisticated strategic night-vision equipment for mainland China. Those devices were sent to Taiwan first and then brought to the mainland by Yeh himself.
Investigators said Yeh and Chen, 52, had been under close surveillance since 2001. They decided to round up the three after learning that Hsu would arrive at CKS Airport Tuesday evening.
MJIB sources said Chen is a high-school graduate who joined the CIST in 1979. He handled the application and compilation of general materials.

The CIST issued a statement Tuesday evening saying that the institute has started an evaluation of the possible damage to national security inflicted by the espionage case. "We have also adopted countermeasures to contain the possible damage, " it added in the statement.
