DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WANTS KAOHSIUNG HARBOR'S INCLUSION IN CSI: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Washington is eager about the progress of its Container Security Initiative (CSI) -- a plan highly conducive to U.S. national security -- and has already invited Kaohsiung Harbor to take part, Taiwan's top envoy in the United States said Tuesday.

Taiwan's southern port city of Kaohsiung is expected to be linked up to the CSI, a global anti-terrorism seaport network initiated earlier this year, after mainland China's Shanghai and Shenzhen, said Chen Chien-jen, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States.

The CSI was announced by the U.S. Customs Service Feb. 22, 2002, as a means of strengthening port and maritime security without interrupting the flow of trade. The plan, initiated after the 9-11 terrorist attacks on New York City and Washington, D.C., is aimed mainly at protecting the United States from possible dangers arriving on the more than 8,000 ships that enter the country from all over the world each year.

During a meeting with the press at the Twin Oaks Garden, Chen said U.S. and Taiwan authorities have agreed on a schedule, within this month, for bilateral talks on matters pertaining to Kaohsiung's CSI inclusion. He did not elaborate on the location for such talks.
Chen noted that as far as he knows, the Taiwan side would have hoped that the talks could have been held "a little bit later."
Kaohsiung Harbor is among the top 20 ports around the world that have been mapped to be included in the first-phase implementation of the port safety plan.

According to officials from the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau, the U.S. Customs Service has hoped that Taiwan will sign the CSI agreement as soon as possible. Failure to do so could jeopardize Taiwan containers' rights to be processed speedily at U.S. ports, U.S. Customs Service sources have warned.

Kaohsiung Harbor is the world's fifth-largest container port, handling 8.4 million containers last year. Of that total, 500,000 to 600,000 standard containers headed to the United States, including some transshipped to other countries, according to Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau officials.

Of the world's top 20 seaports listed by the U.S. Customs Service in terms of volume of container traffic destined for the United States, Kaohsiung Harbor ranks fourth, behind Shanghai, Hong Kong and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 33.62 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Wednesday, with the weighted index moving down 33.62 points to close at 5,225.83.
Market turnover amounted to NT$63.2 billion (US$1.84 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and then fluctuated on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 33.62 Points to close at 5,225.83.
The bourse opened at 5,214.09 and fluctuated between 5,251.91 and 5,207.61 during trading.
A total of 2.78 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$63.2 billion (US$1.84 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with plastics and chemical shares moving up 0.2 percent.

The other major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 4.1 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 2.5 percent, textile issues at 1.9 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.6 percent, cement stocks at 1.4 percent, electrical shares at 0.8 percent, and bank and insurance stocks at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 492 to 169, with 94 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO N.Y. STOPOVER FOR LU A ROC-U.S. CONSENSUS: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The decision that Vice President Annette Lu will not make a stopover in New York on her way to or from Latin America during her upcoming trip was a consensus reached by authorities from Taiwan and the United States, Taiwan's top envoy in the United States said Tuesday.

Chen Chien-jen, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States, said the matter is clear and understandable to authorities from both sides, discounting allegations that Washington, angered by Taipei's unilateral disclosure of Lu's planned stopover in New York, had refused to let her make a transit stop in that city.
Chen also denied rumors that the decision was made as a result of Taiwan's plans to hold a referendum next year.
He made the remarks during a chat with the media at the Twin Oaks Garden Tuesday.

Chen also confirmed that Lu, who will lead a Taiwan delegation to Asuncion, Paraguay, as President Chen Shui-bian's envoy to the inauguration of president-elect Nicanor Duarte on Aug. 15, will make a short refueling stop in Houston, Texas, on her way back to Taiwan.
Lu and her 43-member entourage are scheduled to leave Taipei on Aug. 7, and then visit Hawaii, Los Angeles and Panama on her way to Asuncion.
During her two-day transit stop in Hawaii, Lu is scheduled to meet with Hawaiian Governor Linda Lingle and high ranking corporate officials from Microsoft, according to Chen.
While in Panama, which maintains formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan, Lu's Panamanian counterpart Dominador Kaiser Bazan Jimenez will honor Lu by awarding her a medal.
During her stay in Paraguay, the vice president will give a speech at the parliament and at Asuncion University.
According to Chen, the vice president will visit Seattle and stay for two days there on her way back to Taiwan Aug. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved down 27 points to close at 5,242, with 20,216 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September lost 20 points to finish at 5,232, with 202 contract transactions, while December futures plunged 120 points to close at 5,200, with 3 contracts traded.
March futures fell 90 points to finish at 5,170, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,269 for August, 5,253 for September, 5,320 for December, 5,260 for March, and 5,215 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
August TE futures moved down 0.6 points to close at 233.4, with 2,432 contract transactions, while September TE futures decreased 0.3 points to finish at 233, with 42 contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.
August TF futures gained 1 point to close at 686.4, with 1,448 contract transactions, while September TF futures remained unchanged at 685, with 53 contracts changing hands.
December TF futures rose 2.4 points to close at 687, with 3 contract transactions, while March TF futures fell 1 point to finish at 687, with 6 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June TF futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SEIZE LARGE CACHE OF COUNTERFEIT AND BANNED DRUGS

TEXT.P: Police seized a large cache of counterfeit and banned drugs in several northern Taiwan cities and counties early Wednesday.

The seized goods are estimated to have a street value of more than NT$1 billion, police said, adding that this is believed to be the largest cache of illegal drugs ever seized in a single raid in Taiwan.

Eight people suspected of involvement in the production of counterfeit brand-named drugs and contraband drugs were arrested in midnight raids at makeshift labs in Keelung City, Taipei City, Taipei County, Taoyuan County and Miaoli County.
Acting on a tip-off, Keelung police officers launched the raid around midnight under the leadership of prosecutors from Taipei.

The seized goods include more than 1 million tablets of counterfeit Viagra and weight-loss drug Reductil as well as nearly 2 million pills of the second-grade contraband drug MDMA and various rape drugs. Also confiscated were a variety of drug production equipment and semi-finished products.

Lee Su-ching, the suspected mastermind behind the drug trafficking ring, told police that they planned to take advantage of the current summer vacation to sell the illegal drugs to local students or export the products to Southeast Asian nations.
Police said they will make further investigations to bring other ring members to justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SEIZE LARGE AMOUNT OF SMUGGLED HEROIN

TEXT.P: Police seized a large amount of high-grade heroin smuggled from Thailand to Taiwan in Sanchung, Taipei County, Wednesday.
Two suspected drug traffickers, identified as Chen Fu-lai and Ho Chi-fang, were arrested in a midnight raid at a warehouse in Sanchung on the outskirts of Taipei.

Also seized were 7,200 kilograms of cylindrical heroin bricks packed in plastic bottles originally designed to contain hair care lotion. The drugs are estimated to have a street value of more NT$100 million, investigators said.

The Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) said it formed a special team to probe the case three months ago when it was tipped off that a drug trafficking ring had smuggled cylindrical heroin bricks from Thailand to Taiwan for sale.
After scrutinizing much data and many documents, the team discovered that Chen had made frequent visits to Thailand. The team then began to closely monitor his activities.
Chen returned to Taipei July 26 after his latest trip to Bangkok. MJIB agents decided to take action when Chen was engaged in a drug deal with Ho late Tuesday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0.020 to close at NT$34.446.
A total of US$347 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's low of NT$34.412 and hit a high of NT$34.469 during the trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH ENVOY MEETS WITH TAIPEI COUNTY CHIEF

TEXT.P: Great Britain's top liaison officer in Taiwan, Derek Marsh, paid a courtesy call on Taipei County chief Su Chen-chang Wednesday to exchange views on a wide range of topics.

Marsh and Su exchanged opinions on matters pertaining to the prospects for the development of Taipei Harbor, as well as a mass rapid transit system linking the greater Taipei area with Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan County, and the Taipei MRT expansion project.
Su also helped Marsh gain an insight into the latest political and economic developments in Taiwan.

Pointing to the defeat of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate in the recent Hualien magistrate by-election, Marsh asked Su whether the DPP is also having difficulty maintaining grass-roots support in Taipei County.

Su, a member of the DPP Central Standing Executive Committee, answered that the Hualien magistrate by-election was only a single election in a rural area and that it was by no means a litmus test of the 2004 presidential election.
The Taipei magistrate, however, told the British envoy that the DPP will take the Hualien election as a lesson and modify its strategies in order to win the next presidential election.

During the talks, Marsh also asked Su about the prospects for British companies to win any contracts for Taiwan's major infrastructure development projects, such as Taipei Harbor, the airport MRT system and the planned circular Taipei MRT lines.

It was learned that the Trade Partners U.K. (TPUK) , the United Kingdom's export promotion and outward investment body, is leading the U.K. Railway Scoping Mission to visit Taiwan Aug. 4-7 to explore the railway project opportunities in Taiwan and to find out what else the British government can do to support U.K. companies that are interested in the Taiwan rail projects.

The British Trade and Cultural Office in Taipei is rendering assistance to the U.K group to tap the Taiwan market, particularly the rail sector, which is going to have a number of expansion and renewal projects in the next five to 10 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD CALLS FOR UNITY IN OPPOSITION ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan on Wednesday called for unity among members and supporters of the KMT and its ally the People First Party to win the next presidential election to be held in March 2004.

Lien urged KMT members not to be complacent about the KMT's victory in the recent Hualien magistrate by-election, in which KMT stalwart Hsieh Shen-shan beat his rival from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), You Ying-lung.
Noting that the 2004 presidential election will be a much harder battle, Lien said "all the pan-blue alliance members should be even more firmly united."
Lien made the call at the first KMT Central Standing Committee meeting held after the Hualien magistrate by-election last Saturday.

Also speaking at the meeting was KMT Vice Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung, who said that there is no room for complacency for the KMT over the victory in the Hualien election, which he said has stark differences in election structure from that of a presidential election.

Wu, nevertheless, noted that the Hualien magistrate by-election indeed serves as an inspiration for all members of the opposition alliance and as an affirmation of the fact that the voters have cool and clear judgment.
Wu called for the ruling DPP not to use its administrative resources as electioneering tools for any party or individual any longer.

Meanwhile, Wu also pointed out that any party which is conducive to Taiwan's social and political stability, better cross-Taiwan Strait relations, and fast-rekindling domestic economy will be able to win the 2004 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN BRIDES REQUIRED TO RECEIVE SUPPLEMENTARY EDUCATION

TEXT.P: Following Premier Yu Shyi-kun's instruction, the Ministry of Education (MOE) sponsored a meeting Wednesday on the topic of compulsory supplementary education for foreign brides.
The premier asked the MOE to implement the policy of compulsory education for foreign brides after taking in suggestions from a women's rights promotion committee of the Ministry of the Interior.
Attending the meeting sponsored by the MOE's Social Education Department were scholars on adult education and representatives of various cities and counties.

Education officials said that the budget for the proposal will not be a problem as it will be financed by the subsidy for adult learning. But they pointed out a thorny issue will be deciding whether mainland Chinese brides who have high school education or above will be required to receive the compulsory education.

The officials estimated that there are around 250,000 foreign brides in Taiwan, among whom more than 160,000 come from mainland China. Even if mainland brides have college education, their diplomas are not recognized in Taiwan, the officials said.
If they are forced to receive supplementary education, it will be meaningless and a waste of money, he added.

The officials said they are therefore in favor of letting some foreign brides take tests that if they pass will mean they will not be required to receive the compulsory education before obtaining their IDs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET HAS OPTIONS IN CASE TOWNSHIPS BOYCOTT REFERENDUMS: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet has drafted countermeasures in case local governments boycott a planned referendum because of political interference, a senior official said Wednesday.

Cabinet spokesman Lin Chia-lung made the remarks after an association of local government administrators announced a day earlier that it will not hold consultative referendums demanded by the central government unless the Legislative Yuan passes a referendum bill.

Lin said the Cabinet has been pushing for the opposition-controlled legislature to complete referendum legislation as soon as possible to facilitate the ability of local people to exercise their legitimate rights.

But if the legislature continues to stonewall the passage of a referendum bill, Lin said, the Cabinet is determined to take active steps to allow citizens to exercise their referendum rights, which is prescribed in the nation's Constitution.
Lin said the Cabinet has formed a referendum promotion committee to prepare for holding a referendum on certain public issues before or on the next presidential election day on March 20, 2004.

Lin said the committee has drafted a comprehensive package of regulations governing the holding of referendums in case the legislature fails to pass a referendum bill during its next session which will open in September.

The draft proposals authorize the central government to commission relevant public agencies or private organizations to handle consultative referendums, Lin said, adding that the Cabinet will adopt countermeasures to ensure that referendums are carried out smoothly in case city, county or township governments deliberately boycott the event for political reasons.
Stressing that participating in a referendum is a legitimate right of all ordinary citizens, Lin said any boycott or interference with holding it would not be supported by the public.

Since the Constitution clearly states that all ROC citizens have a right to participate in a referendum, Lin said holding a referendum based on an administrative decree is not unconstitutional nor is it illegal.
"We should not continue denying our people the right to taking part in a referendum simply because the legislature drags its feet on relevant legislative work," Lin added.

President Chen Shui-bian announced in June that his administration would definitely hold a referendum before or on the next presidential election day to clear up whether construction on a half-built nuclear power plant should be scrapped or continued.

During its annual meeting Tuesday, the National Association of Townships Government Chiefs announced that its members will not coordinate with the central government in holding such a referendum if the legislature doesn't pass a bill to flesh out all technical details. Most of the island's 319 cities and townships under county governments are controlled by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

Both KMT Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong were present at Tuesday's township government chiefs meeting. Lien and Soong have decided to team up to challenge President Chen's re-election bid next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLAN TO RELAX RULES ON SHORT SALES OF STOCKS: FINANCE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance at the moment has no plan to relax the regulations on short sales of stocks when stocks are priced below the closing prices of the previous transaction day, Minister of Finance Lin Chuan said Tuesday.

Lin said that since President Chen Shui-bian announced last month to further open Taiwan's stock market to qualified foreign institutional investors (QFII) , many market observers have been expecting more market relaxation measures, including those related to short sales, price fluctuation ranges and trading times.

Referring to a report that the government is considering allowing Taiwanese companies in mainland China to become listed companies on Taiwan's stock exchange, Lin said that before a supervisory mechanism on the capital outflow is established, the government will not lift the ceiling of capital flow to mainland China.

Since the free flow of capital is a prerequisite for Taiwan businessmen expecting to raise funds from Taiwan's stock market for their investments on the mainland, Lin said that he doubted that many Taiwanese companies across the Taiwan Strait would be interested in issuing their stocks here.

While cross-strait capital flow remains a rigid area, the minister said that in recent years, the government has adopted measures to liberalize the domestic capital market to meet the requirements of the international market.

Since the Central Bank of China in Taiwan has agreed to advance the implementation of the QFII system, which was originally planned to be realized two years from now, the finance ministry is working on the timetable of further relaxing stock transactions, Lin added.

While the management of the Resolution Trust Company (RTC) fund remains an important task of the ministry, Lin said that the ministry is determined to tackle the problems of the monetary system, despite that only NT$40 billion of the NT$140 billion fund is left after delivering a series of rescue packages to ailing monetary institutions.

The minister said that in order to swiftly and effectively help problem financial institutions and to avoid a crisis of confidence, the fund should provide guarantee to all depositors as well as other creditors of the problematic financial institutions handled by the fund.

As the government's financial business tax revenue and deposit insurance premium income received from the financial sector remain the only resources of the RTC fund, Lin said that with insufficient funds, the ministry found it difficult to implement its tasks.

Since the RTC fund was established in June 2001, the government has been levying a 2 percent tax on business revenues of monetary institutions. While the originally planned time span for monetary institutions to pay business taxes is four years, from 2002-2005, the minister suggested that the time be extended to an unspecified period in order to boost the amount of the RTC fund to the ministry's target of NT$1.05 trillion.

Regarding the structural problems of budget deficits, Lin said that the finance ministry is planning to draft an amendment of the Public Debt Law. While the existing law limits the government's debt to 15 percent of the nation's gross domestic product (GDP) , the minister suggested that the ceiling be lifted.

The minister said that the nation's budget deficit continued to accumulate since 1991. While the government's policy to expand public spendings as a stimulus to the economy has been somewhat effective, accumulated public debt has put an extra burden on the nation's finances, he added.

Lin said that the government has no immediate plan to push a reform of the taxation system, though the ministry is expecting that the legislature will discuss the amendments of certain tax regulations in the autumn session.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO TALK WITH JAPAN ON MANAGEMENT OF TIAOYUTAI FISHERY RESOURCES

TEXT.P: The government is hoping to talk with Japan in the next one or two months on the management of the fishery resources of the controversial Tiaoyutai Islands, the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday.

Fishery officials said that after a dozen consultations over the past seven years, Taiwan and Japan reached a tentative understanding on the Tiaoyutai Islands this June. Both sides agreed that they would shelve political disputes on sovereignty issues to protect the interests of the traditional fishing grounds of both countries, and would only discuss the management of fishery resources.
Taiwan is now actively contacting the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, and Fisheries of Japan, hoping that a new round of talks can be held in Taipei in August or September, the officials said.

The officials said that the Tiaoyutais are the traditional fishing grounds of Taiwan fishermen who catch around 50,000 to 60,000 tons of fish every year, accounting for one-fourth of the fish haul caught near the shore.
Taiwan and Japan have disputed the sovereignty of the Tiaoyutais for years. Taiwan began using naval and coast guard vessels to escort its fishing ships since major disputes erupted again in 1996.

To resolve the dispute, the two countries began consultations through the Interchange Association of Japan, with the ROC's Ministry of the Interior, the COA and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications all taking part in the consultations with the Japanese government department in charge of marine resources.

Fishery officials said that the mutual understanding is that they would shelve the disputes on sovereignty and would only discuss issues of fishery resources on which regions should be managed by Taiwan or Japan. On those regions that are overlapping, if they are managed by Taiwan, Japanese fishing vessels will have to get prior approval from Taiwan when entering for operations and vice versa.

How to demarcate the regions will be high on the agenda on the new round of talks, with Japan hoping for the establishment of a medium line, while Taiwan hopes that it will be a balanced point according to international law and practices, meaning taking into consideration the fishery population of both countries and historical factors.

The Tiaoyutais lie in the East China Sea about 200 kilometers east of Taiwan and 300 kilometers west of the Japanese island of Okinawa. The islands, called the Senkakus in Japanese, have been claimed by Japan since 1895, while Chinese claims are centuries old.

When the United States returned Okinawa -- along with the Tiaoyutais -- to Japan in the early 1970s, it sparked a "Baotiao [protect the Tiaoyutais] movement" in both Taiwan and mainland China and over the years, sovereignty disputes over the island group have flared up from time to time.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE ALLEGED SPIES BEING HELD INCOMMUNICADO

TEXT.P: Three men, including a middle-rank technician with the military-run Chungshan Institute of Science, were held incommunicado Wednesday on charges of spying for mainland China.

Chen Shih-liang, a technician at the CIST's Electronics Research Institute, and Yeh Yu-chen, a technology firm CEO, were arrested Tuesday on suspicion of espionage. After questioning the two overnight, prosecutors applied to have them detained for further investigations. The Taiwan High Court approved the application early this morning.

A third member of the alleged spy ring, Hsu Hsi-tse, a U.S. citizen of Chinese origin, was also arrested Tuesday when he landed at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport. The Public Prosecutors' Office at the Taiwan High Court approved his detention in the afternoon.
The trio were accused of joining up to steal Taiwan's defense secrets and purchasing strategic high-tech products in the United States and then sending them to mainland China.

The Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) claimed that Yeh, 54, had collected classified information about the CIST's defense technology research programs through Chen, including the theater missile defense system, anti-submarine equipment and the timetable for procurement of P-3C anti-submarine aircraft. Yeh then allegedly brought the secret data to mainland China.

Moreover, investigators said, Yeh had collected information about Taiwan's military cooperative projects with the United States through Hsu, a retired Boeing Co. engineer. Hsu, 57, allegedly had hacked into the U.S. government's classified files through the Internet to steal information about F-16 fighters' night-time weaponry system and strategic data links. U.S.-made F-16s along with French-made Mirages and locally built IDFs form the backbone of Taiwan's air force fleet.

Worse still, MJIB agents claimed that Yeh had counterfeited the CIST's "end-user certificates" for Hsu to purchase sophisticated strategic night-vision equipment for mainland China. Those devices were sent to Taiwan first and then brought to the mainland by Yeh himself.
Investigators said Yeh and Chen, 52, had been under close surveillance since 2001. They decided to round up the three after learning that Hsu would arrive at CKS Airport Tuesday evening.
MJIB sources said Chen is a high-school graduate who joined the CIST in 1979. He handled the application and compilation of general materials.

The CIST issued a statement Tuesday evening saying that the institute has started an evaluation of the possible damage to national security inflicted by the espionage case. "We have also adopted countermeasures to contain the possible damage, " it added in the statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER 'COMFORT WOMEN' TRAVEL TO JAPAN TO PROTEST

TEXT.P: Three Taiwanese women who were forced to serve as sex slaves, euphemistically known as "comfort women," by the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II, headed for Tokyo Wednesday to protest Japan's lack of sincerity in taking responsibility for the cruelty the women suffered.

Wang Ching-fong, a lawyer and former chairwoman of the Taipei-based Women's Rescue Foundation, who is accompanying the three former Taiwanese comfort women during the trip, said that they will protest together with seven former Korean comfort women Aug. 7 at the House of Councillors of the National Diet and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's residence and attempt to present petitions.

The former comfort women, who are on average 82 years old, decided to fly to Japan to protest because the Japanese government has yet to take responsibility for the cruelty they suffered during World War II, Wang said prior to boarding a plane for Tokyo.
The former comfort women urged the Japanese government to publicly apologize and compensate them, Wang added.

At least 200,000 Asian women, including 1,200 Taiwanese, were forced to serve as sex slaves by the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II, according to the Women's Rescue Foundation, which is helping the Taiwanese comfort women in their fight for an apology and compensation.
However, only 43 Taiwanese comfort women were accounted for in 1992, when the foundation started helping them, and only 30 of them were still alive in 1997.

Japan's government, which has never admitted its responsibility for the country's crimes during World War II, set up a private fund -- the Asian Peace and Friendship Foundation for Women -- in 1995 to offer compensation of two million yen per person to the surviving comfort women, but this attempt to heal the wounds of the women was rejected by the Taiwanese comfort women, who also want an apology from the Japanese government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U. S. WORKING VISITS BACK TO NORMAL AFTER SARS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Exchanges of working visits between officials of Taiwan and the United States have become as frequent as in the past in the wake of outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) , Republic of China Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen said Tuesday.

Chen made the remarks while answering questions from reporters during a meeting with the press at the Twin Oaks Estate -- the site of the ROC's former embassy in the United States and currently a cultural center after the two nations cut formal diplomatic ties in 1979.

According to the de facto ambassador from Taiwan to the United States, exchanges of working visits between officials of the two countries have remained normal, especially now that the potentially deadly disease is no longer the threat it was.
Chen also confirmed a report that Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu and Minister of Finance Lin Chuan will soon visit the United States to attempt to attract investment to Taiwan.

Commenting on a media report that the U. S. side has banned ranking trade and economics officials from meeting their Taiwan counterparts in response to Taiwan's failure to adequately protect the intellectual property rights (IPR) of U.S. products, Chen said, "It takes two to tango, " adding that trade and economic issues are not settled only by officials from the same sector.

Regarding U. S. concerns about Taiwan's performance in protecting IPR, Chen said Taiwan has actually made noticeable progress in this field but pointed out that Taiwan needs to strengthen two-way communication to allow the United States to have a better understanding of Taiwan's efforts.
The United States could be more aware of Taiwan's improvements if Taipei could settle the IPR issue with Washington as quickly as possible, he suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND LOSES APPEAL FOR RETURN OF PENSION PAID TO DEFECTOR'S FAMILY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense has lost an appeal for the return of pension funds paid to the family of an ROC Army officer who defected to mainland China 24 years ago, judicial sources said Wednesday.

The defense ministry filed a lawsuit with the Taipei High Administrative Court June 2002 against the family of Lin Yifu, who went "missing" May 16, 1979 when he was serving as an ROC Army company leader on the frontline island of Kinmen.
The defense ministry said in its appeal that it had paid NT$475,000 in pension to Lin's family in several installments after Lin "disappeared" for unknown reasons.

In May 2002, however, it came to light that Lin had actually fled to mainland China from Kinmen 24 years ago. Lin, whose original name was Lin Cheng-yi, filed an application from Beijing in May 2002 to return to Taiwan to attend his father's funeral. Lin admitted in many television interviews that he swan across the channel separating Kinmen and Xiamen in mainland China's Fujian province on May 16, 1979 to seek a new life and new career.

The defense ministry said Lin's action constituted the offenses of surrendering to the enemy, treason and desertion from the front line, all of which carry the maximum penalty of death. It asked the administrative court to compel Lin's family in the northeastern county of Ilan to repay the money that the military had paid the family for Lin's "disappearance" plus interest.

During the court hearing, Lin's family claimed that the defense ministry was well aware of the fact that Lin had defected from the outset. Furthermore, the family said that the defense ministry had listed Lin as "missing in action" mainly because it was afraid that the case might affected the morale of Taiwan's troops and the confidence of ordinary citizens. At that time, Taiwan was still under martial law.

Lin's family claimed that the defense ministry had forced Lin's wife, Chen Yun-ying, to coordinate with it to conceal the truth of Lin's defection to the mainland. Moreover, Lin's family said the defense ministry had given it the minimum amount of pension possible to express its dissatisfaction with Lin's defection.

After a comprehensive study, the administrative court turned down the defense ministry's appeal and upheld the payment of the pension in full. The court said in its verdict that the administrative litigation system is aimed at providing remedies for individual persons who deem that their rights or legal interests are violated by an unlawful administrative action.

Noting that the administrative court is not supposed to mete out a decision or take action on behalf of an administrative agency, the verdict said that since the defense ministry itself gave up its right to file charges against Lin 24 years ago, the court need not protect its right to reclaim the pension already paid to Lin's family.
Under Taiwan's "two-level and two-instance system" administrative litigation system, the defense ministry can appeal the case to the Supreme Administrative Court.
Lin started a new career as an economist in mainland China after he fled Kinmen in 1979, eventually becoming the director of Peking University's China Economic Research Center.

Taipei authorities approved his application to return to attend his father's funeral last year but warned that he could face the legal consequences of his defection. As a result, Lin sent his wife to Taiwan to attend the funeral on his behalf. Lin's wife established contact with her husband several years after her husband's flight and went to the mainland to be reunited with him in the late 1980s.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAUSE OF TAA CARGO PLANE CRASH YET TO BE DETERMINED: ASC

TEXT.P: The Cabinet's Aviation Safety Council (ASC) said Wednesday it has yet to determine the cause of the crash of a Macau-bound TransAsia Airways (TAA) cargo plane last December which killed two pilots.
The ASC was responding to media reports that the Civil Aeronautics Administration's (CAA's) failure to issue a bad weather warning was to blame for the plane crash Dec. 21, 2002.

Chou Kuang-tsan, an ASC official in charge of flight mishap investigations, said the council is still collecting data regarding the crash and is not expected to come up with a detailed report until October.
Noting that a plane crash usually involves a combination of complex causes, Chou said the time is not yet ripe to reach a conclusion on the reasons behind the crash of the ATR-72 cargo plane.

Local media reports quoted a retired CAA official as saying that both Hong Kong and Japanese aviation authorities had issued SIGMET warnings to aircraft in the Taiwan Strait both before and after last December's air tragedy.
The SIGMET (significant meteorology) reports are designed to provide information concerning en-route weather phenomena which may affect an aircraft's safety.
But the CAA failed to issue similar alerts before the ATR-72 TransAsia Airways cargo aircraft plowed into the Taiwan Strait in bad weather Dec. 21, the unidentified CAA official claimed.
The ATR-72 aircraft, powered by twin propellers, left Chiang Kai-shek Airport in northern Taiwan headed for Macau at 1: 05 a.m. but disappeared from radar screens at 1:56 a.m.
Neither the CAA nor TransAsia would make any comment on the reports. Chou also refrained from divulging whether the CAA had issued a SIGMET alert.

Chou said both flawed flight safety control and aircraft maintenance could lead to a plane crash. "Even if the CAA indeed didn't issue a SIGMET, we ought to probe why it didn't do so. We should not lightly reach a conclusion based on a simple or a single element," he added. (by Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: ESPIONAGE CASE COULD COMPROMISE TAIWAN'S ELECTRONIC WARFARE

TEXT.P: The effectiveness of Taiwan's electronic warfare programs could be severely damaged by the three individuals who were detained recently and have been charged with spying for mainland China, a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday.

Legislator Trong Chai was referring to the arrest of three people Tuesday in Taiwan accused of spying. The three are: Chen Shih-liang, a technician with the Republic of China military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology's (CIST's) Electronics Research Institute; Yeh Yu-chen, the CEO of private technology company in Taiwan and Hsu Hsi-tse, a U.S. citizen of Chinese origin.

Chai said that people from CIST are very talented and have contributed to the development of Taiwan's electronics technology. CIST staff are involved in the ROC military's key electronic warfare systems, Chai said, adding that if the results of their research and development have been stolen, it is possible that Taiwan's edge in electronic warfare could be eroded.
Chai urged the CIST to safeguard its people and technology so that the company will not be unknowingly penetrated by mainland Chinese operatives.

Chai cited an ROC military general as saying that if the fruits of the research and development of the CIST have been stolen, the military's edge in electronic warfare, which has cost more than NT$10 billion (US$289.85 million) to build up over nearly a decade, could be swiftly compromised.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MEETS SINGAPOREAN PRIME MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Visiting Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou met with Singaporean Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong Wednesday to exchange views on the fight against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).
Ma said after the meeting Goh agreed with the establishment of a a cooperative mechanism among cities initiated by Taipei to facilitate future campaigns against the potentially deadly disease.

Through the proposed cooperative mechanism, Ma explained, one of the partner cities could inform the others by direct communication channels on the situation of SARS outbreaks at the same time when it reports the flu-like epidemic to other government agencies of their own country.
The establishment of such a cooperative mechanism is aimed at sharing information and experiences in containing the atypical pneumonia and to control the outbreaks as soon as possible, Ma stressed.

Ma is heading a delegation of Taipei municipal officials and city councilors to Singapore, the third and last leg of the group's three-city Asian tour designed to study how other communities handled the SARS problem. The delegation visited Hong Kong and Hanoi before coming to the city-state.

Ma and his delegation also visited Singapore's Ministry of Health and various medical facilities to exchange views with their officials and experts and to collect information on the Southeast Asian city-state's fight against SARS.
Both Singapore and Taipei were gripped by SARS outbreaks between March and June. Ma said Taipei has much to learn from Singapore in SARS prevention.
Ma and his delegation are scheduled to head back to Taipei Aug. 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR PUBLIC COOPERATION TO TACKLE WATER SHORTAGE

TEXT.P: This year's typhoon season has so far failed to bring adequate rains to the north of Taiwan and Premier Yu Shyi-kun asked the public Wednesday to conserve water at a weekly Cabinet meeting.

Officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs reported in the meeting that a water shortage was possible in northern Taiwan although the last typhoon to sweep by the island last week, Morakot, brought plentiful rain to the southern regions.

The premier demanded that the economics ministry adequately manage water resources and requested relevant authorities to compensate within two months farmers who have been forced to leave their rice paddies fallow.

According to economics ministry officials, rainfall in July across Taiwan has been extremely limited. Northern Keelung and eastern Ilan have received no rain during past 43 days and 42 days, respectively.

At the same time, the Feitsui Reservoir in northern Taipei County, which is the major supplier for the greater Taipei area, took in only 36.4 millimeters of rainfall for the whole of last month, a record single-month low and a new low for July since its operation. Southern Chiayi, Tainan and Kaohsiung regions also saw historical lows of rainfall in July.
Meanwhile, Central Weather Bureau officials have forecast that the current high pressure front in the Pacific will remain strong through this month, curtailing the usual torrential afternoon rains.

Because of the continued dry spell, residents in northern Keelung, Taipei, Taoyuan and Hsinchu regions are under the first of a four-phase set of water limits -- the reduction in water pressure during off-peak hours -- since March 6. Meanwhile, the island county of Penghu has been under the second phase of water restrictions since May 10, with Keelung soon to join its ranks this coming Saturday.

According to the set of water restrictive measures worked out by a national anti-drought task force in March, the second-phase limit comprises a 20-percent reduction in water supply to large-volume consumers such as car washes, saunas and swimming pools.
The northern regions of Taiwan, especially Taipei, were hit hard by an acute drought in the first half of last year, the worst-ever in Taiwan's history.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HAILS SMALL BUSINESS SECTOR AS BACKBONE OF TAIWAN ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun praised Taiwan's small- and medium-sized businesses Wednesday as the backbone of the country's economy, which has weathered the impact of the U. S.-led war in Iraq and the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).

Yu made the remarks at a conference of the Republic of China Small and Medium Business Association, in which officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of Finance and the Council of Labor Affairs also took part. The premier also participated in the meeting last year.

Despite the negative effects of the Iraq War and the potentially deadly epidemic, the premier cited government statistics as saying that Taiwan exports and imports grew by 7.3 percent and 11.8 percent, respectively, in the first half of this year as compared to levels posted in the same period last year.

At the same time, machinery equipment imports increased by 19.5 percent year-on-year during the January-June period, while orders placed by foreign buyers with Taiwan companies also rose by 8.4 percent in value, he said.

In June alone, the value of export orders jumped by 11.7 percent from a year ago, the largest monthly growth rate in three years, which he said is an indication that normal trade and economic activities have gone back to normal since June after SARS had been effectively controlled.

Stressing that the government pays a greater heed to the needs of small- and medium-sized businesses, Yu said loans released by banks to the sector have started to grow recently amid the steady economic recovery since the beginning of this year.

The government has attracted NT$644 billion in investments from the private sector in the first six months of this year, Yu added and expressed the hope that the figure for the whole of the year would amount to NT$1.2 trillion (US$34.8 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ALLIES AGAIN PUSHES U.N. TO CONSIDER TAIWAN'S MEMBERSHIP BID

TEXT.P: Fifteen of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies have again pushed the United Nations to consider the issue regarding Taiwan's representation in the world body, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Wednesday.

The ROC allies sent a joint letter recently to U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan demanding that the 58th U.N. General Assembly, which is scheduled to open in September, discuss Taiwan's membership bid, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Kao Ying-mau said.
It was the 11th consecutive year that Taiwan's diplomatic allies have urged the United Nations to mull Taiwan's representation at its annual General Assembly.

Kao said that the proposal describes that Taiwan desires to join the United Nations using the name of "the Republic of China (Taiwan), "the same as a similar proposal sent to the U.N. Secretariat last year.
"It is a pragmatic description because it covers both Taiwan's legal status and its reality, " Kao noted, adding that the official designation of Taiwan is the Republic of China.

However, this year's proposal features an explanatory annex in which the ROC allies pointed out new reasons for which the UN's 1971 Resolution No. 2758 failed to resolve Taiwan's representation issue, Kao said.

Noting that the U.N. resolution gave China's seat in the U.N. to Beijing and expelled Chiang Kai-shek's representative, Kao stressed that Chiang Kai-shek died long time ago and is no longer able to send representatives to the world organization.
Since 1993, the ROC's diplomatic allies have annually pushed the U.N. to consider the issue of Taiwan's representation in the world body.
Over the past 10 years, mainland China has consistently blocked the proposal from making the General Assembly's agenda at the U.N. Steering Committee discussions stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TIMETABLE FOR THREE DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT LINKS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday that there is no timetable for opening direct cross-Taiwan Strait trade, transport and mail links, but that it will happen sometime in the future.

Speaking at a round-table meeting with trainees of national policy studies, Yu said that problems related with the so-called "three links" should be resolved through discussions by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Besides, he went on, the government must take into account every possible scenario regarding the national development in formulating policies, including the impact on national security and the economy.
Government policies should be based on the overall interests of the nation and aimed at promoting social and economic development while safeguarding national security, he emphasized.

DOC.HEADLINE: MODERATE EARTHQUAKE SHAKES EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 5.1 on the open-ended Richter scale rocked Hualien, eastern Taiwan Wednesday, cutting the power supply to some 15,000 households for 20 minutes.
The epicenter of the quake was located about 3.3 kilometers south-southwest of the Hualien seismic station at a depth of 8.1 kilometers, the Central Weather Bureau reported.

The quake, which occurred at 8:23 p.m., had an intensity of 5.0 in Hualien City and neighboring Jian village; 4.0 in Hualien Harbor area; and 2.0 in Techi of Taichung County in central Taiwan and Nanshan of northeastern Ilan County.
No casualties or damage to property were reported except for the temporary suspension of power in parts of Hualien City and Jian village, officials of the Hualien Fire Department said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 7, or the 10th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1858: Queen Victoria chooses Ottawa as the capital of the Dominion of Canada.
1903: Louis Leakey, British anthropologist, is born. He uncovered crucial evidence of man's early evolution, including a 1,750,000-year-old skull.
1904: Ralph Johnson Bunche, American diplomat, is born. He helped found the United Nations and won the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the 1949 Arab-Israeli truce.
1912: Japan and Russia sign an agreement determining their spheres of influence in Manchuria and Mongolia.
1913: Samuel Cody, American aviator, becomes Britain's first air fatality when his plane crashes at Famborough.
1942: U.S. marines land on Guadalcanal in the Pacific during World War II.
1945: The Soviet Union declares war on Japan seven days before the Japanese surrender in World War II.
1948: The Yangtze River overflows its banks, forcing three million people into homelessness.
1952: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves the designation of July 1, instead of January 1, as the beginning of the fiscal year.
1957: The ROC Navy sinks four Communist Chinese warships south of Kinmen.
1957: Oliver Hardy, the husky one in the Laurel and Hardy comic-duo who made more than 100 films from 1926 until 1950, dies of a stroke at the age of 65.
1959: The worst floods in more than 60 years hit central and southern Taiwan, killing 1,075 people, injuring 852, and causing more than NT$3.4 billion in property damage.
1974: Pingtung's Mei Ho Senior Little League baseball team leaves for Gary, Indiana, to participate in the 1974 Little League World Series.
1974: Paul Hogberg, president of the International Handball Federation, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: Vice Foreign Minister H.K. Yang meets with President Alfredo Stroessner in Paraguay.
1976: Kin Aziwa, newly-appointed deputy chief of the Japanese Interchange Association, Taipei Office, arrives to assume his post.
1983: Communist Chinese air force pilot Sun Tien-chin flies his MiG-21 jetfighter to South Korea to seek political asylum. He arrived in Taipei on Aug. 24.
1987: The leaders of Nicaragua, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Costa Rica sign a 14-page peace plan in Guatemala City aiming to settle a 10-year-old conflict in the region.
1990: President George Bush orders U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia to defend against Iraq.
1992: Beijing signs an agreement with Washington promising to probe any allegations that goods produced by prison labor are being shipped to U.S. markets.
1998: Bombs explode almost at the same time outside the American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, killing more than 80 people and injuring over one thousand others.
1999: The Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew ends a five-day visit to Macedonia after a meeting with his Macedonian counterpart Ljubco Georgievski.
2000: Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng says the KMT is happy that President Chen Shui-bian has decided to hold a multiparty roundtable meeting to discuss major national issues with the heads of the opposition parties.
2001: The third cross-strait symposium about sports terms opens in Taipei, with sports representatives from Taiwan and mainland China sitting down to discuss the "unification" of various sports terms between the two sides.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a man should beware of in the three stages of his life. In youth, when the constitution of his body is not yet formed, he should beware of lust. In manhood, when his physical powers are in full vigor, he should beware of strife. In old age, when the physical powers are in decay, he should beware of greed."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The China Times:
Taiwan-U.S. ring spying for mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER RULES OUT 'DOLLAR DIPLOMACY'
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By Chiang Ying and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will not engage in "checkbook diplomacy, " Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said in San Francisco Wednesday.

Chien, heading a five-member delegation, made the remarks while making a transit stop in San Francisco on his way to the Caribbean nation of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines to attend an annual meeting of foreign ministers from the ROC and its four East Caribbean diplomatic allies.

Commenting on recent media reports that the Pacific island nation of Nauru is about to cut its diplomatic ties with the People's Republic of China in preparation for re-establishing relations with the ROC, Chien said national interests have been the government's top concern in developing Taiwan's foreign relations.
"We are more than willing to boost exchanges and cooperation with other countries based on the principles of equality and reciprocity, but we'll not embark on 'dollar diplomacy,'" Chien stressed.

Asked about his views on a recent Pentagon report claiming that mainland China is expanding its military muscle and that it has deployed more missiles against Taiwan, Chien said Taiwan has been pushing mainland China through various channels, including the U.S. administration and Congress, to ease tension in the Taiwan Strait and reduce the number of its missiles targeting Taiwan.
