DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES UP BY 33.24 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Thursday, with the weighted index moving up 33.24 points to close at 5,259.07.
Market turnover amounted to NT$92.26 billion (US$2.68 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: ISSUE OF NEW PASSPORT VERSION MAINLY FOR FUNCTIONAL PURPOSES: MOFA

TEXT.P: The issue of the new version of the ROC passport is mainly for functional purposes, a senior official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

Yang Sheng-chung, director of the MOFA's Bureau of Consular Affairs, made the remarks while briefing staff members of various airlines and immigration officers at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport -- Taiwan's main gateway -- on the reasons behind Taiwan's decision to issue a new version of the passport.

Yang said the only difference in the new version of the passport is the addition of the word "TAIWAN" in Roman script to the cover in order to enable foreign immigration officers to more easily understand where the passport holder hails from.
The contents of the passport and the official national designation of the Republic of China on the cover all remain unchanged, Yang said.

Some ROC passport holders have complained that they had encountered unnecessary inconveniences or embarrassment while traveling abroad with the old version of the ROC passport because foreign immigration officers mistook them for mainland Chinese nationals. Mainland China's official title is the People's Republic of China, or the PRC.
The addition of the word "TAIWAN" on the cover of the new ROC passport will make it more distinguishable from that issued by the PRC, Yang said.
He pointed out that the MOFA conducted nine public opinion polls before deciding to issue the new version of the passport.

"The results of the polls all showed majority support for the addition of the word 'TAIWAN' to the passport cover, " Yang said, adding that the legislative branch has made a similar directive on the modification of the passport cover.

Asked whether local citizens should apply for the new version of the passport, Yang said it's up to them to decide. "All old versions of the passport will remain valid until their expiry dates, " he explained.
Nevertheless, Yang reminded the public that some countries do not allow their visa stamps on old versions of passports to be automatically transferred to new passports.
"Those wishing to travel abroad should contact the local representative offices of specific foreign countries prior to filing an application for a new passport, " he added.

To help foreign immigration officers understand that the ROC will issue the new version of the passport, Yang said, the MOFA has ordered all overseas embassies and representative offices to inform relevant authorities of their host countries of the event and explain all details.
The Bureau of Consular Affairs began to accept applications for the new version of the passport Aug. 1, and many people have already applied, Yang said.

The bureau is scheduled to conduct a random, computerized drawing of the issued serial numbers Aug. 15 to decide the first 100 recipients of the new passport. Those who file applications between Aug. 1 and Aug. 14 have an equal chance of securing the coveted first new passport.
The serial number of the new passports will start from "210000001," Yang said, adding that "21" refers to the 21st century.
The new version of the passport will formally begin to be issued from Sept. 1 of this year.

In the past, the first copy of a new version of a passport was traditionally reserved for the nation's head of state. This time, President Chen Shui-bian has directed that the first copy of the new version be made available to the people since it is they who will benefit from the changes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 33.24 points to close at 5,259.07.
The bourse opened at 5,257.56 and then fluctuated between 5,286.99 and 5,193.18 during trading.
A total of 3.86 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$92.26 billion (US$2.68 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with construction stocks moving down the most at 0.9 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 0.3 percent.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up the most at 0.8 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.7 percent, cement stocks and bank and insurance shares, both at 0.2 percent, and textile issues and plastics and chemical shares, both at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 317 to 316, with 126 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were generally higher on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved up 21.93 points to close at 5,281, with 40,148 contracts changing hands,
TAIEX Index futures for September gained 40 points to finish at 5,273, with 343 contract transactions, while December futures rose 5 points to close at 5,230, with 11 contracts traded.
March futures lost 20 points to finish at 5,200, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for June futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,242 for August, 5,233 for September, 5,225 for December, 5,220 for March, and 5,188 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
August TE futures moved up 1.8 points to close at 235.2, with 4,607 contract transactions, while September TE futures rose 1 point to finish at 234, with 75 contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.
August TF futures fell 0.4 points to close at 686, with 1,492 contract transactions, while September TF futures gained 0.2 points to finish at 685.2, with 70 contracts changing hands.
December TF futures rose 3.4 points to close at 689, with 3 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS EXPRESS CONCERNS ABOUT MILITARY, HIGH-TECH SECTOR INFO LEAKS

TEXT.P: Legislators on Thursday expressed concerns that mainland China may have used money and women to infiltrate Taiwan's military and high-tech industries to obtain valuable information.

Legislator Trong Chai of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said in a press release that mainland China has collected the background information of the pilots of Taiwan's new generation of fighter planes. He added that mainland China has placed the information on the pilots of Taiwan's Mirage fighters at a Hsinchu air base as well as that of their family members in a file called "Flying Dragon."

Speaking on the source of the information leak, Chai said that in addition to discharged soldiers and officers, mainland Chinese women in the sex trade around the base as well as mainland brides are possible suspects.

Chai noted that whenever the government catches illegal female mainland Chinese immigrants, it invariably says they have come to Taiwan to engage in prostitution. Chai asked whether infiltrating Taiwan's military to collect intelligence information for mainland China might be another purpose for some of them coming to Taiwan.
"Money and women are commonly used by enemies for infiltration purposes," Chai added.

Chai noted that there is a science-based industrial park as well as an air base that is home to a Mirage fleet in Hsinchu, adding that the Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology is also nearby. As the sex trade shops in Hsinchu employ mostly mainland Chinese women, it is suspected that they may represent a potential threat regarding the leaking of military and technology secrets, he pointed out.
Chai called on the government to be on guard against this suspected threat and to take substantial action to plug up any holes in the security system.

Meanwhile, a subgroup in the Legislature called for heightened alert against the suspected use by mainland China of woman to entice Taiwan's newly rich in the technology sector in its attempts to obtain technology secrets or military information.

The Alliance Against Selling Out Taiwan noted that Hsinchu has recently become the hangout of the newly rich in the technology sector, with night clubs and sex trade shops emerging rapidly in the city. The alliance called for the government to be on guard against mainland Chinese brides or illegal immigrants being employed in the shops for the purpose of gaining access to Taiwan's technology or military information.
Legislator Chiang Chao-yi of the DPP and independent Legislator Lin Chin-hsin said that the government should attach great importance to the issue.

Lin said mainland gangsters and Communist Party members were found to be among the recently rounded up illegal immigrants who had come to Taiwan to work for a construction company and had sneaked into military barracks, or had run shops near the military barracks to try to collect information. Some were even found to have counterfeit Kinmen or Matsu birth certificates with the purpose of applying to settle in Taiwan and then enter military service.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPA STEPS UP SEARCH FOR MISSING U.S. CITIZEN

TEXT.P: The National Police Administration (NPA) said Thursday that it has stepped up efforts in the search for a U.S. citizen who went missing in Taiwan in late May.

NPA officials said that Fryderyk Mieszko Frontier arrived in Taiwan May 20 to take up an English teaching job at a branch of the Hess Educational Organization in Chungho, Taipei County, but that he did not show up for a Hess pre-job training program May 25 as originally scheduled.

According to NPA probes, Frontier stayed at Taipei Hostel after his arrival in Taiwan. He had told a hostel information desk staffer that he was going to take a leisure trip to eastern Taiwan before reporting to Hess for work. Frontier left his luggage at the Hess Chungho branch before departing for the eastern county of Hualien.
NPA officials said Frontier stayed at a Catholic hostel in Tienhsiang in Taroko National Park from May 21 through May 24. He checked out of the hostel May 25 and has not been heard from since.

The NPA said it has directed the Hualien County Police Bureau and the Taroko National Park police squad to step up the search for Frontier. Moreover, it urged local citizens to come forward with any information they might have regarding the whereabouts of Frontier.

"Anyone who has information about the whereabouts of Frontier is welcome to contact the NPA's foreign affairs office at (02) 2393-0989 or (02) 2394-0238, or the Hualien County Police Bureau at (03) 738-2000," an NPA official said.
He said Frontier stands 186 cm tall, weighs 96 kilograms, and has curly brown hair.

According to a press release issued by the American Institute in Taiwan in mid-July, Frontier called his roommate in the United States on May 22, saying that he was going to visit a national park and return to Taipei May 25. He also expressed an interest in going hiking and visiting the southern city of Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: STAFF OF ROC REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN MANILA SAFE: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) confirmed Thursday that a bomb had reportedly been placed in the building where its representative office in downtown Manila, capital of the Philippines, is located, but that all personnel of the office were evacuated to safety.

MOFA officials said that at around 10 a.m. Thursday, Manila police notified those in the building that a bomb had been placed in the building and asked the personnel in the representative office on the 28th floor to evacuate immediately.
The Manila police then conducted a thorough search of every floor, the MOFA officials said, adding that no bomb had been found as of the press time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CHINESE FOOD FAIR OPENS

TEXT.P: The annual Taipei Chinese Food Exhibition opened Thursday at the Taipei World Trade Center, with the Main Theme Pavilion featuring tasty tomato dishes and foods of special significance in Taiwan folk ceremonies.
The 2003 food fair focuses on foodstuffs of special significance in various traditional festivals in Taiwan and features many dishes of different tastes and meanings, organizers said.
In addition, the Gourmet Avenue in the trade fair is offering more than 50 kinds of delicious Taiwanes-style foods, snacks and sweets for sale.
The exhibition, which runs through Aug. 10, is a good opportunity to learn more about various types of Chinese cuisine.
(by Nocturne Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: YU CALLS FOR MORE INVESTMENT FROM PRIVATE SECTOR IN PUBLIC WORKS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun on Thursday called for more investment in public construction projects from the private sector in order to reduce the government's financial burden.
Yu made the appeal at a trade fair aimed at attracting more private investment in public construction projects.
He noted that the private sector's participation in public construction projects can not only reduce the government's costs, it can also increase the efficiency and services of the public works.

Presented at the trade fair, a total of 57 BOT (build-operate-transfer) construction projects worth a total of NT$223.9 billion (US$6.5 billion) were opened to the private sector. Among the projects, the initial phase of a mass rapid transit system for the greater Taipei area accounted for a large piece of the construction pie.
Other investment projects offered to the private sector at the trade fair included construction of tourism, cultural, education, and sports facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LU LEAVES FOR PARAGUAY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu left for Paraguay Thursday to attend the inauguration of President-elect Nicanor Duarte on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.

Accompanied by Joseph J. Wu, deputy secretary general of the Presidential Office; Chang Fu-mei, minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission. and other officials, Lu and her entourage will make a stopover in Hawaii and Los Angeles before arriving in Asuncion. While in Paraguay, Lu will also deliver speeches at the University of Asuncion and the Paraguayan parliament.
After attending President Duarte's inauguration, Lu will visit Panama before returning to Taipei on Aug. 20. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR REMAINS UNCHANGED ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar closed at NT$34.446 on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, the same as the previous day.
A total of US$365 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$34.460 and dipped to a low of NT$34.432 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MEDICAL SYSTEM NEEDS REVIEW: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's medical system maintains high standards, but still has room for improvement, despite its success in containing the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), the head physician to President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday.

Chen Kai-mo made the comments after Lee Ming-liang, the nation's top SARS coordinator, spoke to foreign media at the United Nations in his capacity as a public health expert. Lee reported how Taiwan dealt with SARS, which claimed 84 lives, including several medical staff, and affected 678 people.

"It is worthwhile for Lee to share Taiwan's experience in fighting SARS with the international community, " Lee said, but added that the country still needed to make improvements in its medical system or "the sacrifice of those in the battle against SARS will have been in vain."

Chen said that the inclusion in a hospital of negative pressure wards, which are primarily used for communicable tuberculosis patients, was one of the criteria for assessing the quality of a medical facility, but that Taiwan generally did not include such equipment in its assessments of hospitals until after SARS began to break out on the island.

Chen, who is the superintendent of Cathay General Hospital, said that the situation regarding resident doctors and health insurance payment ought also to be reviewed, saying that since health insurance payment for pediatricians and surgeons are not high, the number of people wishing to enter these fields is dwindling.

Furthermore, the department of communicable diseases plays a vital role in hospitals, but because the pay is low for physicians and there are few patients, only a few doctors are willing to be a part of these departments, Chen said.

Chen expressed the hope that the government will work out measures so that hospitals will not only focus on increasing revenues, but will dedicate themselves to attracting more talented medical personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIPLOMATIC ALLIES OF ROC ASK U.N. TO DISCUSS TAIWAN'S ADMISSION
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By E. Tseng and EH)

TEXT.P: Fifteen diplomatic allies of the Republic of China Wednesday requested the United Nations to include the issue of the Republic of China's representation in the agenda of the 58th U.N. General Assembly.

The 15 countries said in an explanatory memorandum attached to the request that it is necessary for the U.N. to reconsider the issue of admitting the Republic of China (Taiwan) to the world body, because U.N. Resolution No. 2758, adopted during the 26th General Assembly, did not answer the question of Taiwan people's representation. The 58th U.N. General Assembly will open in New York next month.
Meanwhile, the representatives of Tuvalu, Nicaragua and The Gambia attended a news conference Wednesday to highlight their support for Taiwan's bid to join the U.N.

Sosene Sopoaga, representative of Tuvalu in the U.N., said many U.N. member countries strongly believe that U.N. Resolution 2758 is unfair and erroneous, and has not been corrected by the world body. He stressed that the 23 million people on Taiwan have made great contributions to the world. If the world recognizes their contributions, the Republic of China (Taiwan) should be admitted to the world body. He said Tuvalu will cooperate with other U.N. members in supporting Taiwan's bid to join the world body.
The Gambia's representative, Grispin Grey Johnson, said if any country is excluded from the U.N., the world body is incomplete and is unable to fully fulfill its responsibilities.
Johnson said that every country has the right to join the U.N. and that The Gambia will continue to push the U.N. to accept the Republic of China (Taiwan) as a member.

Representative Eduardo Sevilla of Nicaragua said that, although Taiwan's bid to join the U.N. has been repeatedly shot down, Taiwan has not been defeated. The world body will be enriched when Taiwan's hope to join the U.N. is fulfilled, he said.

Andrew L. Y. Hsia, director-general of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, said at the news conference that Beijing's "one China" policy cannot block Taiwan people's efforts to join in international activities and that the Republic of China will persevere in trying to attain its goal of becoming a full U.N. member.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGIONAL COALITION TO FIGHT SARS SHOULD BE FORMED SOON: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: A regional coalition to prevent the reoccurrence of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) will be set up soon among Taipei, Hong Kong, Singapore and Vietnam, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday.
Ma, who returned earlier the same day from a four-day visit to Singapore to elicit support for the planned coalition, made the remarks at a news conference.

Ma met Singaporean Prime Minister Goh Ghok Tong and Ministry of Health officials to discuss views and exchange opinions on forming a coalition to combat and prevent the potentially deadly disease, while a delegation led by Deputy Major Ou Chin-der got together with Ma in Singapore after having visited Hong Kong and Hanoi for the same purpose.

According to Ma, details pertaining to the establishment of the joint defense network will be worked out following an international conference slated for late September in Taipei in which officials from Hong Kong, Singapore and Vietnam will be invited to take part.

Commenting on the possibility of a SARS resurgence this coming autumn or winter, the Taipei mayor said municipal authorities have taken measures to improve the training of caregivers and staff at hospitals to fend off any outbreaks inside medical facilities.
SARS spread faster in Taiwan from late April as a result of a large outbreak at the Taipei Municipal Hoping Hospital.
The hospital was sealed off April 24 to ward off a further spread.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO BROTHERS ARRESTED AT CKS AIRPORT TRYING TO SMUGGLE HEROIN

TEXT.P: Two brothers were arrested Thursday afternoon at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport after police found heroin in their shoes.

Police searched the two brothers after finding them walking peculiarly in the airport and found 809 grams of heroin in their shoes. They told police that they returned to Taiwan via Macau after purchasing the drug in Shenzhen, Guangdong province.

The two brothers, 27 and 30, were identified by the surname Lo. They said both the heroin and the shoes were purchased from a drug dealer in Shenzhen, a special economic zone in southeastern mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TOUTS ACHIEVEMENT IN IMPROVING INVESTMENT ENVIRONMENT

TEXT.P: The government has worked hard to improve Taiwan's investment environment and has succeeded judging by the increased amount of foreign investment expected to flow into the country this year, President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday.

Speaking at the annual conference of the textile industry, the president said the country has attracted NT$649 billion (US$15.58 billion) in foreign investment in the first half of this year. This validates the confidence of foreign investors in Taiwan's economic potential.

Furthermore, the president said, his administration is pushing for new programs to cut the cost of land in local industrial zones, and moving to speed up cross-strait shipping times in the absence of direct shipping links. All of these will make Taiwan a more attractive place for foreign investment, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC HEALTH MINISTER DELIVERS SPEECH AT U.N. HEADQUARTERS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By S. C. Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former ROC Department of Health (DOH) Minister Lee Ming-liang delivered a speech on Taiwan's campaign against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) at the United Nations headquarters in New York Wednesday.

Lee, a medical expert who is now a professor at Tzu Chi University in the eastern Taiwan county of Hualien, delivered the speech at the invitation of the United Nations Correspondents Association (UNCA) which is housed in the U.N. headquarters.
Andrew L. Y. Hsia, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, and several other Taiwan officials were present at the gathering.

It marked the first time in more than three decades since the Republic of China's exclusion from the United Nations that former and incumbent ROC officials were able to attend an event held inside the U.N. headquarters.
Some 70 foreign ambassadors and journalists posted at the U.N. headquarters attended the gathering to listen to Lee's speech on Taiwan's SARS-fighting experiences.

Lee, a U.S.-trained physician who once practiced medicine and conducted research in the United States, served as Taiwan's top SARS-fighting coordinator when the outbreaks reached a crest in Taipei in May.

The soft-spoken scholar said the first lesson Taiwan learned from its battle against SARS was that flawed management of an outbreak of a communicable disease could lead to a national disaster. Lee was referring to cluster SARS transmissions inside the Taipei Municipal Hoping Hospital in late April that led to a sudden deterioration of the SARS situation in Taiwan.

Noting that the campaign against SARS requires interdisciplinary expertise and concerted efforts of both the public and private sectors, Lee said Taiwan didn't form an inter-ministerial committee to fight the potentially deadly disease until after the Hoping outbreak.
One of the main purposes of his current visit to the United States is to learn from the U.S. experience in establishing a comprehensive public health and disease prevention framework, Lee said.

He further said health education and social mobilization are critical in battling communicable diseases like SARS. Moreover, he said, news media should refrain from giving sensational, speculative reports about epidemics because such reports could trigger public misgivings and panic.

Lee also emphasized the importance of international cooperation in epidemic prevention and control. He said the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention had offered Taiwan much assistance in its SARS-fighting campaign.

He said the World Health Organization's (WHO) assistance to Taiwan came a bit late. If the WHO had extended a helping hand earlier, he said, Taiwan's SARS outbreaks could have been contained more quickly. Nevertheless, he said, Taiwan was still grateful for the WHO's help.

Lee said epidemics are public health problems which should never be "politicized." Politics should not interfere with public health issues and all countries around the world should work hand-in-hand in containing outbreaks of communicable diseases, he said, adding that Taiwan is more than willing to share its SARS-fighting experiences with other countries, including mainland China.

In his view, Lee said SARS is not as terrible as some imagine. Its death rate ranges between 10 percent and 15 percent, far lower than many other diseases. With prudence and confidence, he said, SARS can be brought under control even if it stages a comeback this winter.

After his speech, Lee also fielded questions from his audience. His professional replies won him much acclaim. Even mainland Chinese journalists present at the meeting said they were impressed by Lee's professionalism and modesty.
UNCA President Tony Jenkins said he was impressed by Lee's intelligent and informative speech and hoped to invite Lee to give speeches on other topics in the future.

Permanent U.N. ambassadors from 10 of the ROC's diplomatic allies, including The Gambia, Grenada, Tuvalu, Nicaragua, Senegal, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, the Commonwealth of Dominica, the Dominican Republic, Burkina Faso, and Sao Tome and Principe attended the meeting. The audience also included correspondents of major news media, including CNN, CBS, BBC, the Financial Times, Japan's Asahi Shimbun and Nihon Keizai Shimbun as well as mainland China's People's Daily and the Xinhua News Agency.
Meanwhile, Lee said in an interview with CNA after the speech that mainland China should invite Taiwan to attend a SARS seminar to be held in Beijing in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO HELP KINMEN DEVELOP LEISURE FISHING

TEXT.P: The government will help the outlying island of Kinmen develop leisure fishing to give a boost to the declining fishing industry, an official of the Council of Agriculture said Thursday.
Hu Shin-hwa, director of council's Fisheries Administration, made the remarks while attending a ceremony to mark "fishermen's day" in Kinmen.

During the ceremony, fishery officials welcomed the government's decision to end its control of the Tatan and Urtan Islets, which had been home to major military outposts. The officials said that this should help improve the climate for leisure fishing, but that the military should also consider easing its control along coastlines to help the growth of tourism.

Hu said that Kinmen used to be under military command with little money coming in from other sources, but with the change in the fishing regulations, the government can now help Kinmen map out strategies to enhance its leisure fishing. The fishing industry will cooperate with fishing villages and fishermen to work toward improving the ecology of Kinmen and the livelihood of its residents.
Meanwhile, two more Zodiac-style inflatable boats from the Coast Guard Administration were sent to Kinmen to help protect the seas around Kinmen.

Four similar vessels were sent to Kinmen May 19 to help patrol the seas and stem the spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) by stopping illegal entry into the island. The boats patrol shallow bays to deter mainland fishing ships from crossing the Kinmen's boundary or engaging in smuggling or transactions on the beaches.

With the reopening of direct trade and transportation between Kinmen and Xiamen after SARS, the cases of mainland China vessels crossing the boundary are becoming more frequent, and illegal trade more rampant, so the two additional inflatable boats were requested to help maintain the order.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER IN SAINT VINCENT AND GRENADINES FOR MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien arrived in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Wednesday to attend an annual meeting with the foreign ministers from the ROC's four diplomatic allies in the East Caribbean.

Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs Louis Straker and many other Saint Vincent and the Grenadines officials greeted Chien and his entourage at the airport.
Shortly after his arrival, Chien and Straker jointly presided over a ceremony marking the completion of refurbishment of the Republic of China Embassy in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines.
Addressing the ceremony, Straker expressed his gratitude for the long-term assistance the ROC has extended to his country.

In the evening, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Governor Frederick Ballantyne hosted a dinner in honor of Chien and his entourage. Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Ralph Gonsalves and many other officials of the country were present at the occasion to welcome Chien.
On behalf of the ROC government, Chien will donate 120 wheelchairs and US$100,000 in cash to Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Thursday for the purchase of other medical equipment.

The ROC-East Caribbean foreign ministers meeting will be held Friday, with the participation of Chien and his counterparts from Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, the Federation of Saint Kitts and Nevis, Grenada and the Commonwealth of Dominica. A joint comunique will be issued at the end of the annual conference. Chien will depart for home Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHERMEN REQUEST LIFTING OF BAN ON HIRING MAINLAND FISHING CREWS

TEXT.P: More than 100 fishermen gathered at the Legislative Yuan Thursday, appealing for lawmakers' help in doing away with a government ban on hiring mainland Chinese workers to man Taiwan vessels.

Lin Sheng-sheng, the secretary-general of the Fishermen's Association in Wanli, Taipei County, said the Council of Agriculture forbid local fishermen to hire mainland crews for their boats in late April when both Taiwan and southern China were dealing with severe acute respiratory syndrome.
However, one month after both Taiwan and mainland China have been cleared by the World Health Organization of the disease in early July, the ban remains unchanged, Lin complained.

Since direct trade and transportation links between the country's two frontline islands and mainland China have been resumed, Lin complained, he see no reason why the ban on hiring mainland fishing crews should be kept in place.
Local fishermen have appealed to the Council of Agriculture for help, but were told the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) didn't agree to lift the ban, Lin said.

In a meeting with fishermen in southern Taiwan recently, Lin said President Chen Shui-bian promised to end the ban, but a dozen days have gone by and there has still been no action from the government, Lin complained.
An official from the MAC said mainland Chinese officials, who refuse to contact their Taiwan counterparts, should be blamed. However, the MAC will be ready soon to make a decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PROCESSING ZONES TRYING TO CONFORM TO FREE TRADE ZONE RULES

TEXT.P: The Economic Processing Zone Administration is thoroughly reviewing and re-drafting its regulations to conform to the requirements for inclusion in free trade port zones, Director-General Joseph Y. Chou said Thursday.

Chou said the move is aimed at paving the way to upgrade and enhance the functions of Taiwan's economic processing zones (EPZs) in line with the government's goal of building Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific business operations center.

The revisions of the current EPZ regulations are expected to be complete by the end of this month, a move which Chou claimed will facilitate the inclusion of the EPZs into the planned free trade port zones and greatly sharpen the EPZs' competitive edge amid robust global competition.

The provisions on the management of the free trade port zones was signed into law by President Chen Shui-bian July 23 after being approved by the Legislative Yuan. In compliance with its terms, those EPZs can be included into nearby free trade port zones as long as they meet some key conditions.
The set of provisions was one of the six major economic and financial bills which the Executive Yuan had been pushing to clear the legislature to revive Taiwan's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE MINISTER HAILS TAIWAN'S SUCCESSFUL EDUCATIONAL REFORMS
DOC.DATELINE: Chiang Mai, Thailand, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China's Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang hailed the island's successful educational reforms Thursday, which have created numerous entrepreneurs in small- and medium-sized enterprises (SME).
Shih made the remarks at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum's 10th Small and Medium Enterprises Ministers meeting, which opened Thursday in Thailand.

Transformed from an educational system that stuffed students with as much as knowledge it could without stressing creativity, Taiwan's educational reforms have nurtured many young and excellent entrepreneurs in small- and medium-sized enterprises, Shih said.
He said that the number of Taiwan's universities has increased from 50 in 1991 to 139 in 2002, with the rate of people with higher education surging from 2.27 percent to 4.88 percent.
Taiwan is trying to become the entrepreneurship development center in Asia by helping entrepreneurs to obtain capital.
The island's idea was supported by other APEC economies in a forum held in Taipei at the end of last month.

Meanwhile, in his speech in the opening ceremony, Thai Minister for Industry and SMEs, Somsak Thepsuthin, indicated that small- and medium-sized companies play an important role in Asia and the Pacific region as they account for 98 percent of total enterprises in the area, offering 30 percent of the total employment and creating 50 percent of the transactions.
At the sidelines of the SME Ministers meeting, the organizer also held a SME forum and a Women Leaders' Network meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOCUMENTARY FEATURING LIVES OF ADOPTED TAIWAN CHILDREN TO BE SHOWN

TEXT.P: A preview on a film documenting the lives of Taiwan children adopted by foreign families will be shown at Rebar Crowne Plaza in Taipei Friday, Cathwell Service, a Catholic charitable organization, said Thursday.

A spokeswoman for Cathwell Service, which is dedicated to helping unwed mothers and other disadvantaged people, said the documentary, which features the lives of nine Taiwan children in their adoptive Dutch families, is aimed at promoting "open adoption."

"Open adoption is the healthiest form of adoption where birth families and adopted children enjoy an ongoing, personal relationship, " the spokeswoman said, adding that adoption happens best in a progressive, non-profit agency setting.

Over the past 13 years, the spokeswoman said, Cathwell has cooperated with the Meiling Foundation of the Netherlands in arranging for Dutch families to adopt a total of 225 Taiwan children, both healthy ones and those with mental and physical disabilities.
The Meiling Foundation is the only Dutch organization authorized by the Netherlands to handle adoption services in Taiwan, the spokeswoman said.

Cathwell staff visited the Netherlands last year to look into the lives of Taiwan children adopted by Dutch families. "We have produced a documentary on their daily lives, " the spokeswoman said, adding that the preview on the documentary will be shown in connection with Father's Day, which falls on Aug. 8 in Taiwan.
She said all of Cathwell staff members took great delight in seeing all Taiwan children grow up healthy and happy in their new families.

Among those children was Ju-ju, who was born prematurely to an impoverished family 11 years ago. Worse still, she has extremely short arms which are almost useless. Through the arrangement of Cathwell and the Meiling Foundation, a Dutch couple -- Henk Veldhuizen and Elizabeth Roersen -- adopted Ju-ju when she was eight months old.

According to Cathwell staff, the couple live on a noted vacation island off Holland's northwestern coast. Ju-ju is the only Oriental child on the island. Neighbors and schoolteachers are all friendly to her.

With enormous patience and love, the couple has helped Ju-ju grow up strong, confident and optimistic. Ju-ju, now 12 years old, can use her feet to play the piano, write, paint, use a computer and ride a bicycle.

With the help of Cathwell, Ju-ju has maintained regular contacts with her birth family in Taipei County's Sanchih township. In the company of her adoptive parents and an older brother, Ju-ju returned to Taiwan for the first time in late July. Ju-ju has had a happy reunion with her birth family.

Ju-ju and her adoptive parents and older brother will attend the preview of the special documentary, the Cathwell spokeswoman said, adding that they will end their Taiwan trip and return to the Netherlands Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ENCOURAGES BUSINESS SECTOR TO HELP PROMOTE FOREIGN TIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian encouraged the business sector Thursday to help the government promote the nation's foreign relations.

Addressing the Fourth Congress of the Taipei-based Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association (CIECA) , Chen said that it is one of his administration's goals to promote Taiwan's foreign relations and to increase its participation in international activities.

The president said that he has made three overseas trips since he took over the presidency of the Republic Of China in May, 2000, which took him to Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Latin America and Africa.
On every overseas trip, Chen said, he was always accompanied by business leaders who have made great contributions to consolidating the bilateral ties and friendship between Taiwan and its allies.

He also encouraged CIECA members to pool their forces with those of the private sector and to make use of its communication channels with commercial and industrial organizations of more than 50 countries around the world to help the government promote foreign trade, economic cooperation and friendship.
Chen revealed that he is planning to visit Taiwan's diplomatic allies again in the near future and invited domestic entrepreneurs to join his upcoming overseas trip.

Established Aug. 9, 2000, CIECA promotes bilateral trade, foreign investments, strategic alliances, technology transfers and substantive relations between Taiwan and foreign nations. It now has 132 groups and individual members from leading enterprises and business organizations of all major sectors of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S IMPORTS DECREASE IN JULY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's imports stood at US$10.37 billion in July, a decrease of 2.6 percent over the same month last year, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) Thursday.

MOF officials said the fall in imports was mainly due to fewer imports of information and telecommunications products from abroad and a reduction in the importation of airplanes from the United States.

However, the island's exports in July reached US$11.64 billion, an increase of 4.5 percent over the same month last year, leaving a trade surplus of US$1.27 billion -- a growth of 152.4 percent on a year-to-year base.

The officials noted that the country's foreign trade has recovered and has been steady since the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome were contained in June in light of the figures posted in July.
The statistics also show that exports in the first seven months rose by 6.8 percent over the same period last year, while imports increased by 9.4 percent.
MOF officials estimated that the country's foreign trade will increase by 6 percent in the third quarter of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN HAS BUNGLED REORGANIZATION EFFORTS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has bungled its efforts to reorganize itself, and must tap the enterprise and ideas of private businessmen to improve its efficiency, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.

Opening an exposition of governmental projects at Panchao, Taipei County, the premier said the Executive Yuan's plan before the Democratic Progressive Party took power in 2000 to turn itself into a business-like group has fallen through.

Noting that there are 36 ministries and Cabinet-level councils and agencies under the Executive Yuan, the premier said, "If the Executive Yuan is a company and I were the general manager, it would be impossible for me to command and oversee the work of 36 managers."

He urged the Cabinet members to rejuvenate the government with businessmen's creativity and new ideas while encouraging private businessmen to chip in and help the government's management with their entrepreneurial flair.

The exposition put on by the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission, was aimed at soliciting private businessmen's bids for building public projects with their own money and get their investment back through operating the projects for a certain period of time.
At the exposition, the government presented 60 public projects which need to be invested in by the private sector.
These projects, with a combined price tag of NT$220 billion (US$6.39 billion) , will be farmed out to private bidders who will contribute a total investment of NT$130 billion (US$3.67 billion).
The investors will be responsible for the building of these projects and will be rewarded with a franchise to operate the projects before turning them over to the government.
Under this program, the government may harness the private sector's capital and managing ability to complete public projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECCT MEMBERS VISIT KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A group from the European Chamber of Commerce, Taipei (ECCT) toured the southern port city of Kaohsiung Thursday at the invitation of the Kaohsiung City Government.

Accompanied by Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh and several municipal bureau chiefs, the 37 executive officials from world-class multi-national companies stationed in Taiwan, including ECCT Chairman Dirk Sanger, paid fact-find visits to a seashore industrial park, the city's mass rapid transit train construction sites, a distribution center run by the state-run Taiwan Sugar Corporation, as well as a multi-function trade and economic park and Kaohsiung Harbor.

Hsieh gave a speech in English to welcome the European multi-nationals' executives and expressed his hope that European-based companies would invest in Kaohsiung. With the launch of various key public works projects in Kaohsiung, the port city is undergoing a profound change to reemerge with diversified facets.
In addition to the many construction projects, Hsieh said Kaohsiung is also a city full of energy which has a promising outlook for cultural and creative industries.

For his part, Sanger said he was deeply impressed by Kaohsiung's progress and its emotional pulse. The ECCT chairman said he strongly believed that bilateral exchanges will be closer and more frequent in the future.

The tour was the first and a part of the activities planned by the municipal Bureau of Redevelopment and the authorities of the Kaohsiung multi-functions trade park in an effort to pitch what Kaohsiung has to offer foreign investors.
Following the outdoor activities, the foreign guests were treated to a local movie show and a tea party on the riverbanks of the Ai River -- a famous tourist spot in Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TRADE PROMOTION DELEGATION SCORES GOOD RESULTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade promotion delegation has scored solid results in its first stop in Ecuador, and is expected to obtain orders worth US$7.69 million within a year, officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.

The delegation, headed by Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the MOEA, is one of largest trade promotion tours abroad organized by MOEA after the containment of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), the officials said.
The entrepreneurs participating in the delegation said they were quite satisfied with the results in Ecuador.
The delegation was composed of manufacturers of computer peripheral products, electrical apparatus, stationery, hardware, medical equipment, and sports and textile products.
The foreign trade between Taiwan and Ecuador totalled US$78 million last year, an increase of 19.8 percent over the previous year.
With great potential in tourism, construction, and agricultural processing industries, Ecuador welcomes foreign investment in these areas.
Some Taiwan businessmen dedicated to the cultivation of shrimp in Ecuador have benefited significantly from exports to Taiwan.
After the stop in Ecuador, the delegation will continue its tour to Costa Rica, Colombia and Mexico.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-PFP COMES UP WITH FIRST CAMPAIGN SLOGAN FOR PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: A joint presidential campaign team for Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong came up Thursday with the slogan: "Putting Taiwan first, reviving its prosperity."

KMT spokesman Tsai Cheng-yuan said the catch phrase will be the two parties' answer to President Chen Shui-bian's claim that the 2004 presidential election will pit those who believe "there is one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait" against those who support Beijing's claims that there is only one China.

Tsai said the KMT-PFP approach towards Beijing is to table political differences with mainland China over "the content of 'one China, '" and the difference within Taiwan over "what is the one country President Chen claims exists in Taiwan?"
Only by putting these disputes on the back burner can the country preserve the status quo and focus its energy on keeping the island competitiveness in various fields, Tsai said.
The spokesman also said Lien and Soong will reveal their campaign logo -- two figures riding a tandem bicycle -- at a news conference Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS EIGHTH IN WEF'S GLOBAL CREATIVE ABILITY

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been ranked eighth in terms of creative ability by the Switzerland-based World Economic Forum (WEF), officials of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Thursday.
Citing the WEF's global competitiveness report for 2002-2003, CEPD officials said that Taiwan's ranking is the second-highest of the Asian nations, next only to Japan, which is ranked fifth.
The top 10 of the 80 economies evaluated by the WEF in this field are the United States, the United Kingdom, Finland, Germany, Japan, Switzerland, Sweden, Taiwan, Canada and Singapore, they added.
The WEF is an independent international organization committed to improving the state of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 8, or the 11th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1549: France declares war on England.
1588: The Spanish Armada is defeated by the British.
1900: The first Davis Cup tennis tournament, named after Dwight Filley Davis, begins in Brookline, Massachusetts.
1901: Ernest Lawrence, the American physicist who won the Nobel Prize for physics in 1939, is born. He invented the first subatomic particle accelerator and the color television tube.
1918: The Battle of Amiens begins when Allied forces advance against 20 German divisions and take 16,000 prisoners in two hours.
1919: A peace conference between India and Afghanistan results in the signing of the Treaty of Rawalpindi.
1923: Esther Williams, the American actress and former champion swimmer, is born. She became best-known for her appearance in "Bathing Beauty."
1944: Adolf Hitler has four of his top men hanged with piano wire for attempting to assassinate him.
1945: The United States drops its second atomic bomb, "Fat Man," on the Japanese city of Nagasaki, days after devastating Hiroshima with "Little Boy," the first such device ever used.
1957: General Chow Chih-jou is appointed governor of Taiwan, succeeding C.K. Yen.
1957: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Jordan.
1961: Mei Lan-fang, noted Beijing opera actor, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 67.
1963: In one of the most audacious holdups of all time, robbers involved in "The Great Train Robbery" net an estimated 2.5 million pounds (US$4.6 million) in unused bank notes from a night mail train traveling between Glasgow and London.
1963: The United States, Britain and the USSR sign the nuclear Test Ban Treaty in the Kremlin.
1967: The "Bangkok Declaration" is signed by the foreign ministers of Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. The declaration led to the formation of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN).
1974: Richard Nixon makes history as the first U.S. president to resign from office.
1977: The Interior Ministry reports that at the end of June, the population of Taiwan reached 16,655,140 and that of Taipei hit 2,113,030.
1983: A military coup led by Defense Minister General Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores overthrows President Efrain Rios Montt of Guatemala.
1988: ROC swimmer Wang Han and a six-man team swim across the English Channel in relays in 14 hours and 31 minutes.
1988: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa announces the decision to build a new highway linking Ilan and Nankang in Taipei County.
1990: National Defense Minister Chen Li-an announces that the Red Cross Society of the ROC will handle the repatriation of illegal mainland entrants in the future.
1994: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait sign and make public a joint announcement confirming the results of the second round of talks between Chiao Jen-ho and Tang Shubei.
1999: The Fifth Asia Children's Literature Convention opens in Taipei with 300 authors of children's literature from Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Malaysia and the ROC attending.
2000: The Asian Witness Center of the Guinness Book of World Records names 109-year-old Hu Chin-yao as Taiwan's oldest father.
2000: Chinese Taipei captures the Bronco League World Series baseball championship for the third consecutive year, beating Puerto Rico 16-7 at Monterey, California.
2001: Officials from Taiwan and Australia gathers in Taipei to participate in a two-day conference on mineral and energy resources.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If those in authority have not the confidence of those under them, government of the people is an impossibility."
