DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND RESEARCH SHIP SPOTTED AGAIN NEAR TAIWAN'S WATERS

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese research vessel that has been detected intruding into Taiwan's economic waters on several occasions was spotted doing so again near southern Taiwan this week, Coast Guard Administration (CGA) sources reported Friday.

The "Xiangyanghong No. 14," a research ship belonging to mainland China's State Oceanic Administration, was spotted Wednesday night in waters near Orchid Island located off Taiwan's southeast coast, gradually approaching the 24-nautical-mile limit of Taiwan's territorial waters offshore Oluanpi, the southernmost tip of the island, CGA officials said.

Upon spotting the "Xiangyanghong No. 14, " the Republic of China Navy immediately dispatched two Perry-class frigates to the adjacent waters to monitor the mainland Chinese vessel and informed the CGA about the discovery.

The CGA dispatched three coastal patrol vessels to follow the mainland Chinese research ship. Some four hours of cat and mouse ensued, with the "Xiangyanghong No. 14" being chased some 70 nautical miles away from Oluanpi before the CGA vessels ceased their pursuit.

During the pursuit, according to CGA officials, the "Xiangyanghong No. 14" sent a message to the CGA vessels through an international telecommunications channel to ask the Taiwan patrol vessels to "leave" in order to avoid "accidents" from occurring.

According to Ministry of National Defense (MND) authorities, mainland Chinese maritime research vessels, including those of the "Xiangyanghong, " "Yuanwang" and "Haiyang" series, were discovered operating in areas very close to Taiwan's economic waters on more than 10 occasions last year, with some technically being incursions into Taiwan's 12-mile territorial waters.

Since the mainland research vessels were not military and were on international research missions, the ROC Navy was not in a position to interfere, MND officials said. They added that the best Taiwan could do was to chase them away using the civilian CGA vessels despite knowing that the mainland vessels were on espionage missions collecting security-related maritime intelligence.
The 2,894-ton "Xiangyanghong No. 14" is not armed but is equipped with various antennas. It operates in the Taiwan Strait all year round.
CGA officials said they suspect that the ship has repeatedly navigated close to Orchid Island not only to conduct oceanic research but also to intercept Taiwan's communications.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENGINE DEAL YET TO BE FINALIZED: CAL

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL), Taiwan's largest air carrier, said Friday that it has yet to come to a decision on which company it will purchase jet engines from for its newly-ordered planes.

CAL was responding to reports by the China Times, a mass-circulation local newspaper, that General Electric and Pratt and Whitney of the United States have secured the lucrative deal to provide engines for 12 A330-300 and six B747-400 jets, respectively, worth a total of around US$600 million.

Rolls Royce of Great Britain, which has eyed the deal for the 12 A330-300 engines, was shut out of the deal, according to the reports which added that political trade-offs were involved in the decision.

The reports suggested that the recent U.S. visit by Presidential Secretary-General Chiou I-jen as well as the U.S. transit stops by Vice President Annette Lu on her current Latin American trip and those scheduled for President Chen Shui-bian on his overseas trip in October are linked to the CAL deal.
Han Liang-chung, a CAL public relations official, said that he could not comment on the reports.
"The purchase deal is still under professional assessment and negotiation," Han added.
Sources said that with the huge amount of money involved in the repair and maintenance of the engines, the United States and Britain have both tried to use political influence in the CAL deal.
Both General Electric and Pratt and Whitney are the current engine providers for CAL, while Rolls Royce is a newcomer.

Meanwhile, Chen Chi-mai, DPP party whip in the Legislature, said Friday that the purchase deal has yet to be finalized, adding that the deal should be based on professional assessment and the company's overall business interests. He said that there should not be any political interference in the deal.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIALS BOARD N. KOREAN FREIGHTER ON U.S. INTELLIGENCE TIP OFF
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Officials from the Ministry of Finance Kaohsiung Customs Bureau (MFKCB) boarded a North Korean freighter on Friday on suspicions that the ship is transporting illicit and dangerous chemical materials.

MFKCB officials searched the "Be Gaehung, " which arrived in Kaohsiung Harbor Thursday from Bangkok, Thailand, to unload some 2,000 metric tons of aluminum powder, after being informed by U.S. intelligence authorities that the freighter might be carrying a batch of dangerous chemicals which could be used as materials in the production of nuclear weapons.

If any illicit or dangerous chemicals are discovered, the MFKCB said, it will then collaborate with authorities from the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to jointly tackle the matter.

The "Be Gaehung" has already completed unloading of the 2,000 metric tons of aluminum powder, and another much smaller quantity of goods registered as "commodities only for transit" are the target of the inspection, according to the MFKCB

The Kaohsiung customs officials said that the harbor is taking a highly cautious attitude toward the matter. The bureau will act in accordance with international trade practices if any illicit chemicals are found which may impair the security and safety of the port, the officials said.

According to a report by the Chinese-language United Daily News, the 6,500-ton "Be Gaehung" is suspected by U.S. intelligence authorities of transporting about one metric ton of hydrafil, or aluminum hydroxide compound, with North Korea as the final destination.

Hydrafil, widely used in aluminum refining, as an additive, or as a reinforcer in rubber and plastic processing, is not dangerous in itself. However, if combined with other chemicals, it can be processed into alumina which can be used in making the outer shells of missiles and other related materials, according to the daily report.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 26.52 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Friday, with the weighted index moving down 26.52 points to close at 5,232.55.
Market turnover amounted to NT$96.57 billion (US$2.8 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 26.52 points to close at 5,232.55
The bourse opened at 5,270.95 and then fluctuated between 5,315.18 and 5,232.55 during the trading session.

A total of 3.98 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$96.57 billion (US$2.8 billion) , an increase from the previous trading session which saw 3.86 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$92.26 billion (US$2.68 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction shares moving up the most at 3.3 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.6 percent.

The six other major stock categories lost ground, with paper stocks moving down the most at 1.7 percent, followed by electrical shares at 0.8 percent, cement stocks at 0.5 percent, plastics and chemical issues and financial stocks, both at 0.4 percent, and textiles issues at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 404 to 234, with 129 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GRABS GOLD AND SILVER AT IBSA GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By Wu Hsien-kuang and Nocturne Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has won a gold and a silver medal at the InternationalBlind Sports Federation (IBSA) games being held Aug. 1-12 in Quebec, Canada.
Lee Ching-chung won a gold in the men's 60-kilogram judo competition, while Hu Hsin-chung grabbed a silver medal in the women's 200-meter breast stroke competition.
Meanwhile, Liang Keng-chin was qualified for the final race of the men's 100-meter dash event but did not win a medal.
In the men's javelin competition slated for Sunday, Chiang Chih-chung has a chance to grab another gold medal for Taiwan, officials of the Taiwan delegation said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower on Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for August moved down 75 points to close at 5,206, with 28,664 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September lost 63 points to finish at 5,210, with 325 contract transactions, while December futures fell 30 points to close at 5,234, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,281 for August, 5,273 for September, 5,264 for December, 5,200 for next March, and 5,227 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
August TE futures decreased 3.1 points to close at 232.1, with 3,205 contract transactions, while September TE futures lost two points to finish at 232, with 58 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
August TF futures moved down nine points to close at 677, with 1,633 contract transactions, while September TF futures fell 2.8 points to finish at 677.8, with 210 contracts changing hands.
December TF futures lost 6.2 points to finish at 677, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: V.P. LU ARRIVES IN HAWAII EN ROUTE TO LATIN AMERICA
DOC.DATELINE: Honolulu, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By Tsai Su-rong and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu and her entourage arrived in Hawaii Thursday on the first stop of her "Democratic Pacific" tour, with the main destination being Latin America.

Lu was met at the Honolulu International Airport by Taiwan's top representative in the United States, Chen Chien-jen, and officials from the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , the de facto U.S. embassy in the ROC in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.

At her hotel room, the vice president received Manuel Menendez, a Honolulu government official in charge of economic development affairs, who is representing the mayor of Honolulu as the host of Lu and her entourage during their two-day stay in Hawaii.
Lu then visited Hawaii's East West Center, one of the top research think tanks in the United States, where Lu was met by acting center director Nancy Davis Lewis.

Lu told her host group that she has been actively promoting the establishment and operations of the Democratic Pacific Union, an organization that she envisages serving as an international stronghold upholding and bolstering democratization in the Pacific Rim.

The vice president invited the East West Center and Hawaiian Governor Linda Lingle to take part in the first Democratic Pacific Assembly slated to be held in Taipei next month, which she said is expected to usher in the arrival of the genuine "Era of the Pacific."
Political, academic and business leaders from 20 Pacific Rim countries and areas are expected to attend the assembly, Lu said.

Vice President Lu and her entourage are scheduled to meet with Calvin Say, speaker of the Hawaiian State House of Representatives, and Daniel Akaka, a U.S. federal congressman from Hawaii, respectively, Friday.
The Taiwan delegation is scheduled to depart Hawaii for Los Angeles Saturday for a two-day transit stay before heading to Panama.
Lu, who departed Taipei Thursday, is leading the 43-member delegation to Asuncion, Paraguay, as President Chen Shui-bian's envoy for the inauguration of president-elect Nicanor Duarte on Aug. 15.
While in Panama, which maintains formal diplomatic relations with the ROC, Lu's Panamanian counterpart Dominador Kaiser Bazan Jimenez will honor Lu by awarding her a medal.
The ROC vice president is also scheduled to give a speech at the parliament and at Asuncion University.
On her way back to Taiwan Aug. 20, Lu is scheduled to make a transit stop in Seattle for two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved down against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, giving up NT$0.031 to close at NT$34.415.
A total of US$210 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$34.412 and fluctuated between NT$34.401 and NT$34.427 during the trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN YOUTHS TO JOIN XIAMEN COUNTERPARTS FOR CHINESE VALENTINE'S DAY

TEXT.P: A group of young men and women from Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen headed to mainland China's port city of Xiamen Friday for Chinese Valentine's Day, travel sources said.

Nine Kinmen unmarried men and women, led by Yang Tsai-ping, secretary-general of the Kinmen Tourism Development Association, boarded the Kinmen ferry "Star of Orient" Friday morning for Xiamen, a port city located opposite Kinmen across a narrow stretch of water in the Taiwan Strait.

The nine young men and women are scheduled to take part in the "1.000 people hand-holding party" to be held Saturday night in Xiamen, being sponsored by the Xiamen City Government to mark Chinese Valentine's Day, or "qixi, " the seventh day of the seventh month on the lunar calendar, according to Yang.

Yang said the "mini three links" -- an initiative taken by the Republic of China government in January 2001 to open direct trade and shipping links between the ROC's outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and Fujian province's port cities of Xiamen and Fuzhou -- has served as a bridge allowing Kinmen youths to cross the Taiwan Strait to join other single people on the mainland.
Kinmen and Xiamen collaborated in a cross-strait fireworks display last year during Lantern Festival, an important festival which has been observed by all Chinese people for thousands of years.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING OFFICIALS MEET WITH TAIWAN ABORIGINES
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo) (By C.L. Tseng and EH)

TEXT.P: The 70-member mission was first received by Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council Thursday afternoon soon after their arrival in Beijing from Hainan Island, where they visited Aug. 3-6.
The mission will visit some tourist attractions in Beijing before returning to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT OF STEEL PRODUCTS FROM TAIWAN TO MAINLAND CHINA INCREASING

TEXT.P: Taiwan exported 20.4 million tons of steel products in 2002, an increase of 12.4 percent over 2001, according to statistics compiled by the Industrial Development Bureau of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Of the 2002 exports, 56.4 percent was exported to mainland China, where 211 million tons of steel was consumed in the same year.
Thirty-eight percent of Taiwan steel exports went to mainland China in 1999. The percentage increased gradually to 56.4 percent in 2002, the statistics showed. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AIRWAYS AND SHANGHAI AIRLINES COOPERATE IN CARGO SERVICES

TEXT.P: EVA Airways of Taiwan and Shanghai Airlines of mainland China have begun to cooperate in providing cargo transportation services, using Macau as a relay point, the Hong Kong Standard newspaper reported Friday.

The report quoted EVA General Manager P. S. Lin as saying that, under the cooperation plan, EVA operates three cargo flights between Taipei and Macau, which are connected with Shanghai Airlines' three flights between Macau and Shanghai.
He said the cooperation plan, which came into force Wednesday, will greatly increase business for the two airlines and save time and money for their customers. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE RAID COUNTERFEIT BANKNOTE OPERATION IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: Police raided a small counterfeit banknote printing house Friday in Taichung City, arresting two suspects.
An officer of the Taichung Police Station said that police also seized one computer, three laser printers, and other instruments and tools as well as more than 600 bogus NT$1,000 banknotes.

According to a preliminary police investigation, the two suspects -- Ho Chin-teh and Chuang Wei-kuo -- began to forge banknotes in January. They have laundered approximately NT$20 million (US$0.59 million) so far.
The police officer said the counterfeit money looks very similar to real notes except that there is a small difference in the texture of the paper. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: SAINT VINCENT AND GRENADINES REAFFIRMS SOLID TIES WITH ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Ralph E. Gonsalves reaffirmed Thursday that relations between his country and the Republic of China are solid and that Taiwan has contributed a lot to the development of his country.

Gonsalves made the remarks while hosting a dinner in honor of ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien and his delegation, with the foreign ministers from the four East Caribbean ally nations attending.

Gonsalves stressed that friendship between the two countries is firm, saying that his country is satisfied with all the support Taiwan has provided the country in the past, including the cooperation in agricultural technology.

He also said that Saint Vincent and the Grenadines attaches great importance to Taiwan, and he will speak for the ROC's rights whenever there is a chance, whether it is in the United Nations or in the World Health Organization.

Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs Louis Straker also said that his country will give full support to Taiwan on any international occasion, as the ROC is a very friendly ally, and his country has the obligation to support Taiwan.

Minister Chien visited ROC agricultural missions in the afternoon. He said that the mission was quite successful, citing as an example that under the assistance of the mission, pork supply in the country is now self-sufficient, instead of having to rely on imports.

He said that Saint Vincent and Grenadines also has some agricultural exports with the assistance of the mission, completely changing the outlook of local people on agricultural products. The mission has successfully grown guavas and wax apples, and is now trying to grow pomelos and starfruits. Many of the fruits grown there now have added the name "Taiwan" on the produce.

In the afternoon, Chien also donated 120 wheelchairs and a check for US$100,000 to Saint Vincent and the Grenadines for the purchase of medical equipment on behalf of the ROC government and the people.
Chien arrived in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Wednesday to attend an annual meeting with the foreign ministers from the ROC's four diplomatic allies in the East Caribbean.

The ROC-East Caribbean foreign ministers meeting will be held Friday, with the participation of Chien and his counterparts from St. Christopher and Nevis, Grenada, the Commonwealth of Dominica and the host, St. Vincent and the Grenadines. A joint comunique will be issued at the end of the annual conference. Chien will depart for home Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEMPERATURE IN TAIPEI HITS RECORD HIGH AT 38.7 DEGREES CELSIUS

TEXT.P: Affected by a persistent high pressure front in the Pacific and the effects of a typhoon north of Taiwan, the temperature in Taipei rose to a record 38.7 degrees Celsius (101.7 Fahrenheit) Friday, a spokesman for the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported.

The temperature was not only the highest for Taipei, Taiwan's largest city, since the beginning of this year, it was also the historical high in more than a century since 1897 in the city, when the municipal authorities began to monitor temperatures, the spokesman said.

CWB officials attributed the large rise in Taipei's temperature to Typhoon Etau, which was heading toward Japan and producing a foehn effect and a robust hot snap because of a subsidence flow in northern Taiwan while moving north.

The high temperature was registered at 1: 05 p. m., after a high of 38.4 degrees Celsius appeared earlier the same day at 11: 53 a. m. Taipei's second-highest temperature of 38.6 degrees was posted July 31 in 1921.
Following Typhoon Imbudo, which skirted southern Taiwan, Tamsui in suburban Taipei also saw a high temperature of 38.5 degrees on July 25.
Taiwan's highest temperature ever of 39.6 degrees was registered on May 7, 1988 in Tawu of eastern Taitung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-PFP REVEALS JOINT CAMPAIGN LOGO OF PAIR RIDING TANDEM BICYCLE

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong jointly revealed a logo for their 2004 presidential election campaign Friday. It depicts two figures riding a tandem bicycle.

At a news conference called to reveal the logo, Lien, who will be the candidate for president, said the two figures, one in the KMT's color of blue, the other in the PFP's color of orange, represent the cooperation between the two parties.
"Nothing is impossible when all the people of Taiwan work together," said Lien.
Soong said the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was stunned when the KMT and the PFP decide to work together.
Calling the DPP's rule a disaster, Soong urged the public to give the KMT-PFP alliance an opportunity to rebuild the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT POISED TO BUILD MRT LINE BETWEEN CKS AIRPORT, TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The government has not deviated from its policy on building a mass rapid transport train system between Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport and Taipei, Executive Yuan spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Friday.

Stressing that no changes have been made to the policy, Lin said that the government will take charge of building the line's major structures with the full support from President Chen Shui-bian, Executive Yuan President Yu Shyi-kun and Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san.
According to the Cabinet spokesman, the government has earmarked budgets to phase in the project.

As to the line's surrounding buildings, such as stations and shops, the government will instead adopt the build-operate-transfer (BOT) model to allow for investment from the private sector, he said, reiterating that the government is poised to carry out the plan in order to meet the strong public expectation as a result of a delay of 2ix years.

Lin's remarks came on the heels of a newspaper report that said the Executive Yuan has made a U-turn regarding the plan and has asked the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to reassess the possibility of constructing the line on the BOT model.

President Chen declared in June that the government will assume the responsibility of accomplishing the project after the Evertransit International Co. lost its top priority right to build the line for failing to collect the required fund late last year.
The construction plan linking CKS Airport and Taipei was slated to kick off in the second half of next year and be completed in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXAMINATION YUAN PRESIDENT IN LONDON TO STUDY BRITISH PENSION SYSTEM
DOC.DATELINE: London, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China's Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen arrived in London Thursday night for a five-day visit aimed at studying British civil servant training and the retirement pension system.

Yao is one of the few high-ranking officials from Taiwan to have visited the United Kingdom in the last few years. In May last year, Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng visited England to gain more understanding of Britain's judicial system.
Yao's London visit is also to encourage qualified British financial institutions to bid on Taiwan's pension fund investment operations.

He stressed that any financial institution company of long-term good credit, which has a client service team in Taiwan, is qualified to bid in the investment operations. Yao said the opening of pension fund investments to foreign companies is to diversify the risk of investment.

Meanwhile, Yao's wife, Legislator Chou Ching-yu, who is also a psychology expert, will visit British institutions to study the European country's strategies on household violence, sex crimes and parole.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, PANAMA COMPLETE FREE TRADE AGREEMENT TALKS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has completed the last round of negotiations with Panama on the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) in Taipei Friday, marking the first such agreement that Taiwan has completed with a foreign nation.

ROC Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu and Panamanian Minister of Commerce and Industry Joaquin Jocome signed a joint statement on the completion of the FTA talks on behalf of their respective governments.
Lin said that the last and fifth round of talks started Aug. 1 in Taipei and were completed earlier than expected after both sides displayed the utmost sincerity and flexibility.

Both countries are to base the agreement on the principles and spirit of the World Trade Organization to promote trade liberalization to continue to upgrade bilateral trade relation and economic growth.

The architecture of the bilateral free agreement will promote more than trade relations; it will strengthen the countries' strategic alliance, while enhancing investment, encouraging interaction between their peoples and raising the social well-being, he said.
At the same time, a strategic trans-Pacific alliance will be cultivated through which each country will be able to facilitate the expansion of its products and service in the other's region.

For his part, Jocome said that this was the second FTA that Panama has signed. He noted that Taiwan and Panama have good trade and economic relations, especially because Taiwan has invested heavily in his country.
He expressed the hope that the signing of the FTA will strengthen bilateral trade relations as well as diplomatic ties.

He also said that Panamanian President Mireya Elisa Moscoso is a good friend with ROC President Chen Shui-bian, and that they share the same ideals in ruling their countries. Panama will continue to support the ROC's bid to enter the international community and is hoping to make inroads into the Asian market with the assistance of Taiwan, he added.
Taiwan and Panama began FTA talks last year and have conducted five rounds and a special session of negotiations on agricultural issues.

Working teams from both sides started the fifth round of talks Aug. 1 in Taipei, verifying the opening list of agricultural products and service industries. The most sensitive agricultural issues were addressed in a constructive and pragmatic manner.
The last round of talks were, therefore, able to close Friday, two days earlier than the scheduled day on Sunday.

The ROC-Panama FTA represents a comprehensive and balanced supra-WTO agreement that contains chapters covering specific issues, such as market access, services and investment, telecommunications, intellectual property rights, competition policy and dispute settlement mechanisms which are consistent with WTO guidelines.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs plans that when Panamanian President Mireya Elisa Moscoso visits Taiwan later this month to attend the summit meeting of the leaders of Republic of China, Central American, the Dominican Republic and Belize, she and President Chen will co-sign the FTA agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORKFORCE IN TAIWAN'S EPZS INCREASES

TEXT.P: The number of employed people in Taiwan's economic processing zones is increasing, a sign that the country's economy is recovering stably, the Economic Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) said Friday.

Officials of the EPZA under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said the number employed in the country's five major economic processing zones reached 63,102 in July, an increase of 44 individuals, or 0.07 percent, over the same month of last year.
The increased workforce was mainly in the electronics and precision instrument sectors, according to the EPZA officials.
The manpower in the five major economic processing zones accounts for 2.74 percent of the island's total workforce in the manufacturing sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPREME COURT ORDERS RETRIAL OF HSICHIH TRIO

TEXT.P: The Supreme Court ordered a retrial of the "Hsichih Trio, " who were found not guilty and set free on Jan. 13 by the Taiwan High Court after spending more than 10 years on death row for the double murder and rape of a couple in Hsichih, Taipei County in 1991.

The Supreme Court threw out the not guilty verdict given by the three Taiwan High Court judges, saying that they had evaluated evidence in the case in defiance of time-tested rules, had defied logic, and had failed to observe legal guidelines and had not done a thorough investigation into the case before rendering a verdict.

The Taiwan High Court's determination that the trio's confessions were inadmissible because of 13 inconsistencies among the suspects' accounts was inappropriate because the confessions should have been considered as a whole and should have been examined in reference to other evidence.
The three defendants, Su Chien-ho, Liu Bing-lang and Chuang Lin-hsun, were accused of killing Wu Ming-han and his wife Yeh Ying-lan, and gang-raping Yeh with an accomplice, Wang Wen-hsiao.
Wang, who was a soldier when the crime was committed, was sentenced to death by a military court and executed in 1992.

The three were tried in civilian court and convicted of robbery, murder and rape and were sentenced to death. The sentence was upheld in all subsequent appeals until the Taiwan High Court cleared them of all charges and set them free in January 2003 to the delight of the country's human rights advocates. Many observers have claimed that the three were set up by police in charge of the investigation.
The prosecutors appealed the not guilty verdict to the Supreme Court on behalf of the victims' families.

A lawyer for the three said the new trial, to be conducted by the Taiwan High Court -- with different judges -- is the beginning of another ordeal for the defendants, but he vowed to defend the three's innocence once again.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC SME MINISTERS MEETING CONCLUDES IN THAILAND
DOC.DATELINE: Chiang Mai, Thailand, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A joint statement issued after the 10th Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) Ministerial Meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum hailed Taiwan's organization of successful activities and forums that have benefited other economies.

The SMEs Ministerial Meeting concluded Friday in Chiang Mai, Thailand, with ministers calling for APEC member economies to strengthen networking between business owners, trade promotion agencies and SMEs focused on financial institutions.
In the statement, the ministers highlighted the courageous and critical role played by SMEs and micro-enterprises.
The ministers also highlighted the challenges brought about by globalization and the role APEC member economies have to play in dealing with these pressures.

"To cope with the challenges of globalization, APEC economies should focus on developing networks among micro, small and medium enterprises (MSME) and promotional agencies, MSME banks and MSME associations.
In the joint statement ministers also highlighted the role of education in promoting business development.
Representatives at the meeting were also concerned about the impact of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) on SMEs, and the difficulties faced by women in SMEs.
The ministers also hailed Taiwan for its successful organization of the APEC Incubator Forum in Taipei last month, and supported a second such forum to be held on the island next year.

APEC's members economies include Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, mainland China, South Korea, the United States, the Philippines, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, Russia, Singapore, Thailand, Taiwan and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS PROMOTE TAIWAN TOURISM IN TOKYO, NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By C. C. Huang, C. S. Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A promotion delegation led by Tourism Bureau Director-General Su Cheng-tien under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications sponsored a seminar Friday in Tokyo, trying hard to sell Taiwan as a tour destination to the Japanese public in the wake of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).

Nearly 300 representatives from Japan's media and tourism sectors took part in the activity, in which a movie was showed to represent the everyday life in post-SARS Taipei streets and to declare 2004 as a "Taiwan Tourism Year" with a tourist arrival target set at 1.09 million.

Su expressed his hope that the number of tourists to Taiwan would rebound to normal levels by the end of this year and that the promotional efforts made by his bureau would help lure more foreign visitors to Taiwan.
According to Su, arrivals to Taiwan during the April-June period totaled about 200,000 when SARS was rampant, a large fall from the 750,000 posted for the first three months of this year.

Promotional activities offered by the Tourism Bureau include a cash bonus of NT$3,000 to the first batch of 5,000 Japanese tourists applying to tour Taiwan and a planned tax-rebate treatment for foreign visitors.

Republic of China Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chuan and Su, as well as two representatives from the Japanese side, drew tickets for 270 pairs of two-night free trips to Taiwan. Another 230 pairs were already offered the same treatment also through a lucky draw over the past two days out of a total of more than 130,000 entrants.

Meanwhile, officials of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in New York, led by director Andrew L Y. Hsia, also hosted a gathering to advocate Taiwan tourism with representatives from the local Chinese-language media and tourist agencies, as well as officials of Taiwan's two largest carriers -- China Airlines (CAL) and EVA Airways (EVA Air) -- at a Chinese restaurant in Manhattan.

Announcing that 2004 has been appointed by the Executive Yuan as the "Taiwan Tourism Year, " Hsia said the Taiwan authorities have designed a series of promotional activities to court foreign visitors, such as 30-day visa-free treatment for U. S. passport holders and a tax-refund privilege, and a string of folk festivals back at home in cities and townships across Taiwan.

In addition to free fact-finding trips to Taiwan available for tourist agency operators and reporters attending the gathering, the Tourism Bureau will also offer a certain number of foreign tourists from across the globe a free tour of Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Taiwan-based tourist agencies are cooperating with CAL and EVA Air to launch economy package tours featuring local attractions and flavors, such as in-depth tours focusing on food, ceramics and sailing, a TECO official said.

As long as Taiwan knows where to move and strike, Taiwan has much more potential to court foreign tourists than Singapore, which already is a model of success, an official from the Tourism Bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD YOUTH BASEBALL CHAMPIONSHIP OPENS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The XI "AA" World Youth Baseball Championship opened in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan Friday with the participation of nine teams who represent the United States, Cuba, Japan, Korea, Indonesia, Australia, the Czech Republic, South Africa and the host, the Republic of China.
Addressing the opening ceremony, ROC Premier Yu Shyi-kun extended a warm welcome to the young baseballers and guests from around the world and wished them great success.
Yu also encouraged the young baseballers to do their best not only to win but also to form friendships with their rivals in the tournament.

On hand at the ceremony were President of the International Baseball Federation Aldo Notari, President of the Baseball Federation of Asia Eiichiro Yamamoto, President of the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association Tom C.H. Peng, ROC Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien and Lin Teh-fu, chairman of the National Council for Physical Fitness and Sports.
Prior to the opening ceremony, the Czech Republic beat South Africa 15-8 in the first game of the championship.
Chinese Taipei blanked Japan 6-0 in the second and last game played during the day following the opening ceremony.
The championship will run through Aug. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AND PANAMA TO REDUCE TARIFFS ON EACH OTHER'S EXPORTS

TEXT.P: Under a free trade agreement already concluded between Taiwan and Panama, the two countries will cut tariffs on each other's products beginning next year when the pact takes effect, Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long said Friday.

Under the agreement, to be inked on Aug. 21, Chen said Taiwan will do away with tariffs on 6,200 items from Panama, which account for 71 percent of all items produced in that country, while Panama will impose no tariffs on 4,160 items from Taiwan, consisting 48.49 percent of all items from Taiwan.
Notable among the Panama products to be imported free of tariff is beef. Panama's fine sugar, cube and crystal, will be given an import quota of 5,000 tons.
Over the next 10 years, the items to be imported from Panama tariff-free will be increased by another 1,301 to 7,133, or 97 percent of all items of Taiwan's.
On the part of Panama, the number will increase by 1,098 to 7,063, or 95 percent of all of Panama's items.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PROMISES PINGTUNG COUNTY INDUSTRIAL AND CULTURAL PARKS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun promised to set up an industrial park and a cultural park in Pingtung County, in south Taiwan while traveling there Friday.
Visiting a farm owned by the state-run Taiwan Sugar Corporation, the premier said his administration will turn the 250-hectare farm into Asia's biggest agricultural bio-tech industrial park.

Yu said he will personally see to it that a proposal to set up a preparatory organization for the industrial park to be approved by his Cabinet within a week and hopefully the park will begin to take in companies in 2006.
Drawing on the rich experience his administration has in developing industrial parks, Yu promised that this park will be completed in an unprecedentedly short period.

Vice Chairman of the Council of Agriculture Lee Jen-chyuan, who accompanied Yu on the trip, said in a briefing that the park is the brainchild of the National Agriculture Conference in March. It will harness hi-technology to agricultural production.
Later Friday, Yu visited a site set aside for a Hakka cultural park in Pingtung County.

Yu said the park, promised by President Chen Shui-bian during his 2000 presidential campaign, will begin first-stage work on Sept. 20, and second-stage work on Oct. 20. The whole park will be completed and opened in 2005.

Chairperson of the Council of Hakka Affairs Yeh Chu-lan, who accompanied Yu on the trip, said President Chen attached great importance to the Hakka culture, and the Pingtung Hakka park will be the window of Hakka culture in south Taiwan.

Quoting an analysis made by Yeh's council, Yu Shyi-kun said that no country in the world except for Taiwan gives this much emphasis to Hakkas, and no person except for Chen Shui-bian cares this much about Hakkas.
The Pingtung Hakka park will be built earlier and much better than a similar park in north Taiwan. It will be the best Hakka culture park not only in Taiwan but also in the world, Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Panamanian President Mireya Elisa Moscoso will visit Taiwan Aug. 19-22, Panamanian Minister of Foreign Relations Harmodio Arias said Thursday.

Arias said that the main purpose of Moscoso's visit to Taiwan is to sign the free trade agreement between Taiwan and Panama and to attend the fourth summit of the heads of states and governments of the Republic of China, Central America, the Dominican Republic and Belize to be held in Taipei.
Meanwhile, Panamanian media reported that when Moscoso visits Taiwan, First Vice President Arturo Ulises Vallarino will visit Beijing.

ROC Ambassador to Panama David Hu commented that Vallarino's visit to Beijing is private in nature and that the stance of Panama is that Panama has no diplomatic ties with mainland China but its officials will visit the mainland to promote business.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 9, or the 12th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1794: General Napoleon Bonaparte is arrested in France on suspicions of Robespierrism.
1814: Under the terms of the Treaty of Fort Jackson signed between the U.S. government and the native Creek tribe, the Creeks lose 9.3 million hectares of land -- over half of Alabama and part of southern Georgia -- to the United States.
1842: The United States signs the Webster-Ashburton Treaty with Britain, establishing the boundary between the U.S. and Canada from Maine to the Great Lakes.
1867: John Harrison Surratt is arrested for being an alleged conspirator in the assassination of President Abraham Lincoln.
1902: Edward VII, 64, is crowned King of Great Britain and Ireland after a six-week delay due to an emergency appendectomy.
1903: Giuseppe Sarto becomes Pope Pius X following the death of Pope Leo XIII.
1919: India concludes a secret pact with Britain, recognizing Britain as India's protector after Britain promised India a major role in its own government.
1928: Italian divers find precious diamonds in the wreckage of "Elizabethville," a Belgian ship sunk during World War I.
1937: Japanese troops clash with Chinese forces at Hungchiao airport in Shanghai.
1938: Rod Laver, Australian tennis star, is born. He won the singles title at Wimbledon four times.
1942: Mohandas K. Gandhi, leader of the Indian National Congress, is arrested in Britain for his "Quit India" campaign, which demands that the British should withdraw from India.
1945: Soviet troops enter Manchuria after the Soviet Union declares war on Japan.
1946: Henry Pu Yi, who was enthroned as the "Emperor of Manchukuo" in Changchun by Japanese militarists on Mar. 1, 1934, arrives in Tokyo to testify before an international court against Japanese war crimes committed during the invasion of China.
1954: The Republic of China Navy sinks 12 Communist Chinese ships at Tungshan seaport, Dongshan Island, near Fukien province.
1965: Singapore is separated from Malaysia and becomes an independent state within the Commonwealth of Nations.
1973: Ku Cheng-kang, honorary chairman of the World Anti-Communist League, leaves for Washington to attend a WACL Executive Committee meeting.
1974: Gerald R. Ford is sworn in as the 38th president of the United States after the resignation of Richard Nixon.
1979: Councilors in the English seaside town of Brighton cause a furor by agreeing to allow naturalists to bare all on "Cliff Beach," one of the less popular beaches in the district.
1990: Communist China's first airship, with a length of 40 meters, makes its maiden flight over Hupei province.
1994: The U.S. government announces trade sanctions against the ROC under the Pelly Amendment, placing a ban on imports of Taiwan wildlife products effective from August 19, 1994.
1999: The China External Trade Development Council signs a memorandum of understanding on technological cooperation with the Agency for International Development of Technology and Trade under the Trade and Industry Ministry of France.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui says the main reason he voiced the "special state-to-state relations" statement regarding cross-Taiwan Strait ties the previous month was to elucidate the fact that the Republic of China exists in the world.
2000: The Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association is established to promote Taiwan's trade and cooperation with the international community.
2000: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou signs the "Manifesto 2000" to throw his support behind the United Nations campaign for the development of a culture of peace and non-violence.
2001: The 2001 International Software Show kicks off in Taipei with the participation of nearly 200 software companies manning 600 display booths.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to gain confidence for one's authority. If a man is not trusted by one's friends, he will not gain the confidence for his authority."

DOC.TEXT:
