DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER TO HEAD FOR U.S. ON TRADE PROMOTION TOUR

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu will leave for the United States Sunday at the head of a delegation to seek more trade opportunities for local companies.

Lin will invite senior executives of noted U.S. firms to attend an international trade fair set to open in Taipei Oct. 19 as well as try to attract them to launch new investment projects in Taiwan, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Saturday.

The delegation is composed of officials from the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau and departments in charge of investment and technological development affairs. The Industrial Technology Research Institute and the China External Trade Development Council will also send staff members to join the mission.

During the week-long U.S. visit, the group will host presentations on Taiwan investment regulations and general market trends for the biotechnology, telecommunications, information and digital industries, respectively, in various U.S. cities.

Group members will also pay courtesy calls at the headquarters of major U.S. business groups to invite them to invest in Taiwan or to forge joint-venture deals with their Taiwan counterparts. The companies on the group's itinerary include General Electric, Corningware, Motorola, Gateway and Becton, Dickinson and Co., according to MOEA sources.

MOEA officials said the ministry plans to attract at least NT$724.5 billion in new investments this year. "This goal has been half reached, with new investments amounting to NT$398.3 billion in the first six months of this year, " an official with the MOEA's Investment Commission said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 8 DRUG TRAFFICKING SUSPECTS ARRESTED

TEXT.P: Police arrested eight men and women suspected of drug trafficking in a pre-dawn raid at an apartment in Taipei's Hsinyi district Saturday.
Also seized in the raid were a pistol, more than 30 rounds of ammunition and a large cache of contraband drugs worth an estimated NT$5 million.
The seized drugs included marijuana, as well as MDHM, GHB and other Ecstasy pills, police said.

The suspected mastermind of the drug trafficking ring was identified as Chou Shih-hsiu who has a criminal record including drug abuse and gambling convictions. He is accused of selling ecstasy pills and other banned drugs to pubs and KTV arcades in the greater Taipei area.
Police said they began to monitor Chou's activities in April this year after receiving a tip-off.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEELUNG IMPLEMENTS SECOND-PHASE WATER RESTRICTIONS

TEXT.P: The northern Taiwan port city of Keelung on Saturday implemented the second-phase water restrictions due to scarce rainfall in the last few months.

With the second-phase water restrictions in place, water usage for fountains and street cleaning and for sectors where water use is non-essential is prohibited. At the same time, water supply is reduced by 20 percent to heavy water users, except hospitals, including pools, car washes and saunas.
The first-phase water restrictions, in which water pressure is reduced during the night time, were implemented in Keelung in late July.

As the amount of water in Keelung's Hsinshan Reservoir totaled only 4.24 million tons as of Saturday, with the water level continuing to drop, the city government has coordinated with the Taipei Water Department to help in supplying water in the remote areas of Keelung.
In northern Taiwan, the first-phase water restrictions, in which water pressure is reduced during off-peak hours, have been in place since March 6.

According to the Taipei Feitsui Reservoir Administration Bureau, the water level at Feitsui Reservoir -- the key source of water supply for the Greater Taipei area -- stood at 139.14 meters as of 2: 00 p.m. Saturday, down 0.39 meters from the level registered at 1: 00 a.m. the same day.
Last year, Taiwan suffered its most serious drought in recorded history, with all areas of the island implementing strict water rationing measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO PROMOTING HAKKA CULTURE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed his commitment Saturday to promoting Hakka culture as part of his administration's efforts to boost cultural diversity in Taiwan.

Chen made the reaffirmation while attending the inaugural ceremony for a Hakka cultural festival in Taoyuan County's Pingchen township, some 45 kilometers south of Taipei. Pingchen boasts a large Hakka population.

Chen said the inauguration of an all-Hakka television channel and a graduate institute of Hakka culture and social customs at National Central University earlier this year indicates his administration's determination to promote Hakka culture.
"And our promotional campaign will not stop there. We'll make continued efforts to help local people understand the essence of Hakka culture," Chen said.
The president further said he took delight in seeing colorful Hakka-style floral cloth become main decorative items at the cultural festival organized by the Taoyuan County Government.
Chen said he is convinced that the success of the Pingchen Hakka cultural festival will inspire other townships to sponsor similar activities to showcase their own unique cultural heritage.
The festival features a wide variety of programs, including singing, dancing and theatrical performances as well as a Hakka food trade fair.
Many senior officials, including Yeh Chu-lan, chairwoman of the Council for Hakka Affairs and Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun, were also present at the opening ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OFFICIAL TO KICK OFF OVERSEAS PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGN IN S.F.
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Chiang Ying and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Lee Ying-yuan, deputy secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , will preside over a "flag-presentation" ceremony for a support group for President Chen Shui-bian in San francisco Saturday on behalf of Chen.
The group is composed of "pan-green camp" supporters residing in northern California. The "pan-green camp" refers to the DPP and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
The activity in San Francisco is expected to kick off an overseas campaign of the DPP for President Chen's bid for reelection in March 2004.

With the presidential election just months away, heavyweights from the "pan-green camp, " as well as those from the "pan-blue alliance, " of the opposition Kuomintang and its ally the People First Party, are expected to converge in cities in California such as Los Angeles and San Francisco.
In addition to Lee from the DPP, Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Legislator Wu Den-yih from the Kuomintang are also expected to head to California in the next few months.

Overseas Chinese in northern California have always been concerned about political developments in Taiwan. In every presidential election, they have donated generously and organized groups to return to Taiwan to campaign for their favorite candidates.

Lee, who served as former Republic of China deputy representative to the United States, has visited San Francisco several times. He is expected to attend the DPP solidarity alliance ceremony. He is also scheduled to join Tsai Ming-hsien, current deputy ROC representative to the United States, to speak on the topics of the presidential election and Taiwan-U.S. relations at a summer camp for Taiwanese on the U.S. west coast.
DPP sources in San Francisco confirmed that a group of some 200 people will be organized to return to Taiwan to campaign for President Chen during the presidential election next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXAMINATION YUAN HEADS CALLS FOR CIVIL SERVANT NEUTRALITY
DOC.DATELINE: London, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen said in London Friday that Taiwan should continue to strive for making its civil servants maintain neutrality in carrying out their administrative affairs.

Yao, who is in London for a five-day visit aimed at studying the British civil servant training and pension systems, made the remarks in a symposium held at the University of London's School of Oriental and African Studies.
"Taiwan is now a free, fair and democratic society, " Yao noted, adding that the Taiwan people enjoy the freedom of expression and the right to make speeches and to form political parties.

He said Taiwan should try to dump the old tradition in which the affairs of the ruling party and those of the government are intertwined, calling for the government system to belong to the nation and not to any single political party.
Yao also said that Taiwan should seek the international position which it deserves, as well as guarantee the island's security and sovereignty, while maintaining its prosperous economy.

Noting that the ROC Constitution which was drawn up by the Nationalist government more than five decades ago is out of date, Yao said that Taiwan now needs a constitution that fits its needs to streamline its administrative systems.

Accompanied by his wife, Yao arrived in London Thursday night. His London visit is also aimed at encouraging qualified British financial institutions to bid on Taiwan's pension fund investment operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP COMPLETES 'GREEN PAPER' ON CHEN ADMINISTRATION'S PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: With the presidential election only months away, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has completed a "green paper" on the performance of President Chen Shui-bian's administration over the past three years, DPP sources said Saturday.

The performance report details the central government's subsidies to the local governments and President Chen's delivery on his campaign promises to voters. Even the central government's subsidies to local small-scale construction projects are included in the report.

DPP sources said that the paper will be distributed to DPP legislators so that they can clearly explain the government's performance to the grass-roots voters and solicit their support for President Chen's bid for re-election in March 2004.

The 419-page report, prepared by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, is an analysis of the government's performance in the cities and counties, stressing the idea that "the rule of the DPP is the guarantee of quality."

The "green paper" gives a breakdown of the government's performance regarding each of the 25 cities and counties in Taiwan, analyzing the central government's subsidies and the implementation of projects.

There are nine major categories -- subsidies, transportation network, water resources facilities, social welfare, education and culture, agricultural development, environment and health, tourism and leisure, and others.
Taking Taipei County as an example, the report cites the projects to improve water supply in Panchiao and Hsintien, as well as the Taipei Harbor development project.

For the southern city of Kaohsiung, the report cites the president's promise to make the improvement of water quality a top priority. In the central county of Nantou, it cites the promotion of the relocation of villages that are vulnerable to mud slides.

The legislators received the parts of the report concerning their respective constituencies so that they will have the "hard evidence" to back up their rhetoric that the government has indeed attached great importance to the development of cities and counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HARBOR DETAINS NORTH KOREAN FREIGHTER

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau on Saturday asked that a North Korean freighter in the harbor in southern Taiwan be temporarily detained in order to allow for a thorough check for possible dangerous chemicals on board.
The 6,500-ton freighter "Be Gae Bong, " arrived in Kaohsiung Harbor Thursday from Bangkok, Thailand, to unload some 2,000 metric tons of aluminum powder.

After being informed by U.S. intelligence authorities that the freighter might be carrying a batch of dangerous chemicals which could be used as materials in the production of nuclear weapons, harbor officials boarded the vessel Friday to conduct a search.

As the ship is suspected of transporting about one metric ton of hydrafil, or aluminum hydroxide compound, with North Korea as the final destination, Kaohsiung Harbor detained the vessel according to international trade regulations.
Harbor Bureau officials have asked that approval for the ship's application to leave the harbor be delayed in order for a thorough search to be carried out.

Hydrafil, widely used in aluminum refining, as an additive, or as a reinforcer in rubber and plastic processing, is not dangerous in itself. However, if combined with other chemicals, it can be processed into alumina which can be used in making the outer shells of missiles and other related materials.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC DEBUNKS MEDIA REPORT ON POTENTIAL HOLE IN NATION'S SECURITY SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The National Security Council (NSC) on Saturday debunked a media report that one of its staff members responsible for mainland China-related intelligence has business interests on the mainland.

The Apple Daily claimed in a front-page article that NSC Secretary-General Kang Ning-hsiang's personal aide, Chang Pei-chen, holds a stake in a Hong Kong-based company which cooperates with a firm owned by mainland China's Ministry of Railways in operating land development business in Shanghai. The report said the NSC's recruitment of Chang could be a potential hole in the nation's security system.

The NSC said in a press release that the Apple Daily report was not true. For one thing, it said, Chang had never dealt with any classified information about mainland China during her work at the council.
The council also noted that it accepted Chang's resignation earlier in the day.

According to the NSC statement, Chang had devoted herself to research on the mainland economy for 20 years at the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research before she joined the NSC April 1 this year. She provided counseling in mainland economic affairs during her stint at the NSC, the statement said, adding that Chang's work had nothing to do with intelligence.

Moreover, the NSC said, Chang had not had any links with the company mentioned by the newspaper before she was hired by the NSC to serve as a mainland affairs specialist in April. It stressed that Chang's work at the NSC had nothing to do with the disputes related to her husband's business operations in mainland China.
The NSC further said it has a stringent internal security control system and has consistently made an immediate response whenever any security concerns have arisen.

Chang's husband, Chang Jui-meng, resigned from the chairmanship of a local security service firm in late July after he returned from a business trip to Shanghai where he reportedly had trade disputes with his business partners.

Meanwhile, the opposition Kuomintang's legislative caucus demanded that the NSC investigate whether Chang Pei-chen had ever leaked national secrets or classified information to mainland Chinese authorities during her stint at the NSC. It also pushed the Democratic Progressive Party administration to review its public functionaries loyalty check mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANIMAL PROTECTION GROUP LAUNCHES DOG 'ADOPTION' PROGRAM

TEXT.P: An animal protection group on Saturday launched a program where people can "adopt" a stray dog for NT$20 (US$0.57) a day.
The Animal Protection Association of the Republic of China said that the campaign will provide a new option for people who would like to have a pet dog but cannot because of other considerations.

Legislator Tsai Chia-fu of the opposition Kuomintang, who concurrently serves as the president of the association, said that most people don't have the time or space in their homes to have a pet dog. He said that for NT$20 a day, or NT$600 a month, they can now adopt one of the many stray dogs being housed at an animal shelter in Taipei County.

Tsai said the dog lovers can visit their adopted dogs on weekends and holidays and take them for a walk or ride. In this way, "they can have all the pleasures of having a pet dog without the troubles of raising them," he pointed out.

He noted that the association set up a shelter for stray animals in 1988 and then later relocated it to Pali, Taipei County, due to cramped quarters. He said the shelter has at times accommodated more than 2,000 stray cats and dogs at one time.
The association decided to kick off the "adoption" program to provide better care for the stray and abandoned animals.
Association officials said that those who are interested in taking part in the program can call (02) 2704-0809 or visit www.apaofroc.org.tw online to obtain more information and to apply.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, PANAMA TO INFORM WTO COMMITTEE FOLLOWING COMPLETION OF FTA TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Following the completion of negotiations between Taiwan and Panama on the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) Friday, the two sides will inform the Committee on Regional Trade Agreements (RTA) under the World Trade Organization (WTO) for further examination.

According to WTO regulations, every free trade agreement or regional trade agreement should be examined by the committee to see whether the contents violate the regulations that govern multilateral trade agreements.

Yen Ching-chang, the Republic of China's permanent representative at the WTO, said that once signed, the free trade agreement between Taiwan and Panama will be the first of its kind that the island has achieved under the framework of the WTO.

Recently, the signing of free trade agreements and regional trade agreements has become a trend among WTO member economies, with almost all the WHO members, except for Taiwan and mainland China, having some form of free trade agreement with other countries.
If the trend continues, the number of FTAs or RTAs will exceed 300 within two years, WTO sources said.

According to a recent report from the WTO's Committee on Regional Trade Agreements, the committee has received 267 notices for examining RTAs as of June, and the committee is currently examining 138 of those.
Asked about whether other countries can ask for similar favorable treatment that Taiwan granted to Panama in their free trade agreement, Yen said no problems exist in this regard.

However, he stressed that Taiwan had made significant concessions upon its entry into the WTO, saying that other countries therefore should not ask for even more concessions from the island because of its free trade agreement with Panama.

Meanwhile, according to Panamanian government sources, President Mireya Elisa Moscoso is scheduled to visit Taiwan Aug. 19-22 to sign the free trade agreement, in addition to attending a summit meeting of the heads of state of the ROC, the Dominican Republic, Belize and other Central American countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT MEETS HAWAIIAN LAWMAKERS
DOC.DATELINE: Honolulu, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Tsai Su-jung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Vice President Annette Lu, who is currently on a transit stop in Hawaii on her way to Panama, met with influential Hawaiian politicians Friday for wide-ranging talks.
Lu exchanged views with Hawaiian State House of Representatives Speaker Calvin Say and Sen. Daniel Akaka (D-Hawaii) in separate meetings at her hotel room on matters of mutual interest.

During her talks with Akaka, Lu briefed her guest on Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on certain public issues, including its bid to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the World Health Organization's (WHO's) governing body -- as an observer.

Lu said mainland China has never apologized for the spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) to Taiwan. Worse still, she said, mainland delegates publicly humiliated Taiwan during this year's WHA conference in Geneva in May and spared no efforts to block Taiwan's observership bid.
The planned referendum is aimed at letting the world understand the necessity for Taiwan to be included into the WHO system and the Taiwan people's determination to realize this goal, Lu said.

Despite mainland China's perennial military threat, Lu said, Taiwan has managed to create "an economic miracle and a political miracle" while maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait. With all these achievements, she said, Taiwan deserves more international support for its cause. Lu said once Taiwan is admitted to the WHO, it will be able to make even more contributions to the world health regulatory body.
Lu invited Akaka to attend the first Democratic Pacific Conference to be held in Taipei later this year.

Akaka whose grandfather moved from mainland China's Fujian Province to Hawaii in 1850 said he will accept Lu's invitation if his work schedule permits. Akaka said he has fond memories of his last visit to Taiwan in 1994. He lauded Lu for her efforts to promote freedom, democracy and human rights.
Earlier in the day, Lu discussed tourist, foreign labor and education issues with the Hawaiian State House of Representatives speaker.
Hawaii is noted for its tourist industry and is experienced in handling foreign laborer issues. Lu said Taiwan has much to learn from Hawaii in promoting tourism, ethnic harmony and globalization.
Lu, who departed Taipei Thursday, is leading a 43-member delegation to Asuncion, Paraguay to attend the inauguration of the new Paraguayan president, Nicanor Duarte, on Aug. 15.
Lu and her entourage will leave Hawaii for Los Angeles Saturday for a two-day transit stay before heading to Panama.

While in Panama, Lu will meet with senior Panamanian officials to discuss measures for further boosting bilateral cooperation. Panamanian Vice President Dominador Kaiser Bazan Jimenez will honor Lu by awarding her a medal.
In addition to attending the presidential inauguration, Lu will deliver speeches at the Paraguayan parliament and at Asuncion University.
On her way back to Taiwan Aug. 20, Lu is scheduled to make a transit stop in Seattle for two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR COUNTRIES CONFIRM SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN'S BID TO JOIN WORLD BODIES

TEXT.P: The foreign ministers of Dominica, Grenada, Saint Christopher, and St. Vincent on Friday reiterated their strong support for the Republic of China's bid to join international organizations.

They made the pledge in a communique issued at the end of a conference attended by them and ROC Foreign Minister Eugene Chien in Kingstown, St. Vincent. They said the Republic of China on Taiwan has the legitimate right to join world organizations, particularly the United Nations and the World Health Organization.

In the communique, the five countries also pledged to strengthen their cooperation in international politics as well as in the agricultural, economic, education, technology and other fields on the basis of mutual benefits.
In the communique, the five foreign ministers also condemned international terrorism.
At the conference, Chien thanked the governments of the four countries in the eastern Caribbean for their long-term support for the Republic of China in the international community. (by L. Huang, EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: MEMORY OF TAIPEI ZOO ELEPHANT 'LIN WANG' TO LIVE ON: MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that stuffing the late Taipei City Zoo elephant "Lin Wang" will immortalize the Asian elephant that had brought so many fond memories to the Taiwan people.

Mayor Ma made the remarks when he attended a press conference for the late Lin Wang at the Taipei City Zoo to express his appreciation to Yulon Motor Co. for financing the preservation project. Lin Wang died this February at the age of 86.
Ma noted that "grandpa" Lin Wang was brought to Taiwan half a century ago and that "while Lin Wang watched zoo visitors grow up, zoo visitors watched Lin Wang grow old."

Ma noted that while some people are against the decision to have the elephant stuffed, he believes the project will "help keep Lin Wang's memory alive and foster the concept of friendliness toward animals among the Taiwan people.

Taipei City Zoo officials noted that the legendary elephant, born in Myanmar, was captured by the Republic of China army from Japanese troops in the Southeast Asian country at the height of World War II. The elephant was about 26 yeas old at the time. He was later brought to southern Taiwan from mainland China in 1947 and then donated to the Taipei City Zoo by Gen. Sun Li-jen in 1954.
A fixture at Taipei City Zoo for many years, Lin Wang brought much joy and happiness to countless visitors to the zoo for almost half a century before his passing away this February.
The zoo wanted to preserve the elephant, but did not have enough money until Yulon Motors donated NT$5 million to make the project possible, the officials said.
Yen Kai-tai, deputy chairman of Yulon Motors, said that the company believes that Lin Wang's specimen will create more happy memories for many people in Taiwan.

Yen and the mayor later unveiled a mini-scale wood carving of Lin Wang to mark the formal start of the preservation project. The wood carving was produced by a Taiwan sculptor living in Japan with the same name of Lin Wang. The carving will be placed xxxxxx for visitors to the zoo to see.
Mayor Ma also presented a footprint woodcut of Lin Wang to Yen to express his appreciation to Yulon Motors for the donation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. AND S. KOREA BIGGEST WINNERS AT 34TH INT'L PHYSICS OLYMPIAD

TEXT.P: The United States and South Korea were the biggest winners at the 34th International Physics Olympiad, with each of them winning three golds and two silvers, according to a report by the contest organizer National Taiwan Normal University.
The United States also won all three special awards for best theory, best experiment and best female student.
Taiwan ranked third with three golds, one silver and one bronze. A total of 239 students from 54 countries took part in the competition held Aug. 3-9.

Meanwhile, the International Physics Olympiad Committee on Saturday reelected Dr. Waldemar Gorzkowski of Poland as president of the committee for another five-year term. The 35th International Physics Olympiad will be held in South Korea next year.

Education Minister Huang Jong-tsun said he is very proud of the five Taiwan students who took part in the contest. The five are Chu Yen-ju of Wulin High School in Taoyuan, Lu Kang-hau of Chienkuo High School in Taipei, Chen Tze-yu of Taichung First High School in Taichung, Wu Po-chuan of Wulin High School, and Wu Tze-yu of Kaohsiung High School. Chu, Lu and Chen were all gold medalists at the competition.
The committee will confer a total of 20 golds, 39 silvers, 38 bronzes and 56 honorary awards at the closing ceremony Sunday afternoon. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD NUMBER OF PEOPLE JOIN 30-HOUR FAMINE CAMPAIGN TO HELP AFRICANS

TEXT.P: A record number of people took part in this year's 30-Hour Famine campaign launched by World Vision Taiwan to raise funds to help impoverished families at home and abroad, organizers said Saturday.
A total of 4,000 people from around the island registered for the 30-hour fasting activity at National Chunghsing University in the central city of Taichung.
"The number is the largest since we began holding the activity annually 14 years ago," a World Vision Taiwan spokesman said.

The participants began their fast at noon Saturday, and they will go without food until 6 p.m. Sunday. In addition to the fast, the participants donated money to help starving children in famine-stricken African countries and reconstruction projects in war-torn Iraq and Afghanistan as well as local families affected by unexpected disasters.

The youngest participant is a two-year-old boy, Yu Chih-hau. Yu's parents said they are not worried about their son's health because the participants are allowed to drink water or milk. The eldest participant is an 87-year-old woman Ko-Wu Han-shiao. Despite her senior age, Ko-Wu said she is very healthy and can endure the 30-hour fast. The average age of the participants is 19 years, younger than last year's 22 years.

Organizers have prepared a variety of singing and dancing performances help the participants take on the fasting challenge. Actor Fan Chih-wei will speak on his experience during his recent trip to the famine-stricken African state of Ethopia.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PROCUREMENT PLANS TO BE BASED ON DEFENSE NEEDS: MND

TEXT.P: The nation's arms procurement plans will be based on defense needs and overall military buildup policy, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Saturday.
The ministry was responding to media reports that two major U.S. defense contractors are vying for Taiwan's order for early warning radar systems.

According to media reports, Raytheon Co. had arranged for a Taiwan legislative group, headed by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, to view its "Pave Paw" early warning radar systems now in service in the U.S. military during the group's recent U.S. visit. The reports said the arrangement was part of Raytheon's efforts to court for Taiwan's order for such equipment.

The reports further said another U.S. weaponry manufacturing firm Lockheed Martin is planning to send retired American generals and defense experts to Taiwan to lobby for the order which is expected to worth more than NT$40 billion.
The MND would not make direct comments on the reports. It instead said its arms procurement plans are aimed at safeguarding national security and will not be affected by pressure from the outside.

"We have no intention of engaging in an arms race with mainland China. We'll chart our weaponry purchase programs in terms of the threat we face. Our ultimate goal is to establish an elite deterrent force to defend our national security," said an MND official who preferred anonymity.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 10, or the 13th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1821: Missouri is admitted as the 24th state of the United States.
1846: The Smithsonian Institute is established in Washington as a center for scientific research with a bequest from English scientist James Smithson.
1874: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, is born. His belief in individual freedom led him to reject federal relief for unemployment during the Depression and lost him the 1932 election to Franklin D. Roosevelt.
1894: Varahagiri Venkata Giri, president of India from 1969 to 1974, is born. He was prominent in India's labor movement.
1904: During the Russo-Japanese War, the Russian fleet suffers heavy loses when the Japanese fleet blocks it from escaping from Port Arthur in the Battle of the Yellow Sea.
1913: The Treaty of Bucharest is signed, ending the second Balkan War and partitioning Macedonia among Serbia, Greece, Romania and Bulgaria.
1926: Northwest Airlines is established in Chicago.
1944: Yicheng County in Hupei Province changes its name to Chihchung County in memory of the bravery of Gen. Chang Chih-chung who died in action during the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1944: American forces recapture Guam from the Japanese after three weeks of fighting in which only 500 of the 18,000 defending Japanese troops survived and surrendered.
1945: Robert H. Goddard, American pioneer of rocket science, dies at the age of 63. He conducted the first successful launch of a liquid-propellant rocket in 1926. The rocket climbed 184 feet (56 meters) into the air at a speed of about 60 miles (97 kilometers) per hour.
1946: Gen. George C. Marshall, a special envoy of U.S. President Harry Truman to China on a mission to mediate the civil war between the Nationalists and the Chinese communists, issues a statement declaring that his efforts have failed.
1950: U.S. State Department official Karl L. Rankin arrives in Taipei as charge d'affaires of the U.S. Embassy.
1961: Britain applies to join the European Economic Community.
1966: Orbiter I, the first American moon satellite, is launched from Cape Kennedy.
1975: Flight service between the Republic of China and Japan resumes after the ROC government announced on April 20, 1974 the termination of the Taiwan-Japan flights of China Airlines and Japan Airlines.
1979: The newly completed Keelung-Suao Highway is opened to traffic.
1981: The joint meeting of the Second Asian Conference of the International Association for Cross-Cultural Psychology and the First Asian Conference of the International Council of Psychologists opens in Taipei.
1990: The ROC government declares its support of a United Nations call for world sanctions against Iraq over its invasion of Kuwait.
1993: The New KMT Alliance breaks with the ruling Kuomintang and forms the New Party.
1993: Shih Yueh-po, a Chinese passenger, hijacks a mainland Chinese Boeing 767 passenger plane to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan.
1998: Some 2,000 people die in floods in mainland China.
1998: Prince Al-Muhtadee Billah, eldest son of Sultan Hassan Bolkiah of Brunei, is proclaimed heir to the throne.
1999: The Republic of China inaugurates Asia's first flight recorder laboratory, allowing local personnel to analyze aircraft flight recorder (black box) data rather than having to send such data to a third country for analysis.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian accuses Beijing of hypocrisy in terms of its definition of "one China," and reiterates Taiwan's rejection of Beijing's demand that it embrace "one China" on Beijing's terms.
2001: After being on death row for almost 10 years, mainland Chinese hijackers Cho Chang-jen and Chiang Hung-chun are executed at the Taipei Prison for kidnap and murder.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to be trusted by one's friends. If a man does not command the obedience of the members of his family, he will not be trusted by his friends."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DIGITAL CONTENT INSTITUTE TO TRAIN 900 PEOPLE IN SIX MONTHS

TEXT.P: Taipei, Aug. 10 (CA) The Digital Content Institute (DCI) under the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) will coordinate with local universities and multimedia educational centers to sponsor training programs in the latest technologies, and 900 people are expected to be ready for the fast-growing digital content industry in the next six months.

DCI project manager Huang Wan-hua said that while the highly promising digital content industry demands increasing numbers of talented individuals in the fields of games, 3D computer animation, e-learning, audio-visual applications, digital content, Internet services, software and digital publications, the industry is facing a serious shortfall of specialists.

According to Huang, starting August, the institute will begin a series of training programs, with the support of National Chiao Tung University in Hsinchu, Soochow University in Taipei, Southern Taiwan University of Technology in Tainan, the Education and Training Center and the Multimedia Experimental Center of the Institute for Information Industry in Taipei, as well as the Chinese Internet and Multimedia Association, the NuArt Institute and EC Multimedia Technology Corp.

He added that courses offered by the educational establishments will center on creative design, audio-visual design and program design in relation to computer games and 3D computer animation, and marketing and management.
While local digital content companies are encouraged to use the program for their on-the-job training, Huang said that the DCI will cover 60 percent of the tuition for the 900 trainees.

With such promising prospects, the digital content industry has been pinpointed as a strategic industry by the Cabinet. In 2002, the production value of Taiwan's digital content industry amounted to NT$153.7 billion, an increase of 15.2 percent over the preceding year, according to IDB statistics.
The IDB estimated that between 2003 and 2006, the industry may achieve an annual growth above 20 percent, and by 2006, the production value will reach NT$370 billion.

Currently, there are nearly 1,700 digital content companies in Taiwan, with overall employment of around 33,000. The IDB forecast that by 2006, the number of digital content companies will reach 3,000 and the number of employees will total 70,000.
At the moment, export value only accounts for 12 percent of the industry's production value. The IDB has set a target of 30 percent by the year of 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: NINE SOCIAL WELFARE GROUPS ALIGN UNDER BANNER OF 'PAN-PURPLE ALLIANCE'

TEXT.P: The Alliance of Fairness and Justice, a new association grouping nine of the country's social welfare organizations, was formally established Sunday. The alliance hopes to marshal its resources for the benefit of the underprivileged.

Alliance head Chien Hsi-chieh said at a founding ceremony that the alliance has chosen purple as its signature color to distinguish itself from the "pan-green" camp of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party.

Chien said the Alliance of Fairness and Justice, which will also be known as the "pan-purple alliance, " will focus on promoting fair and just social welfare services and speak for the underprivileged, including those who are becoming disadvantaged because of social injustices.

Noting that the purpose of political democratization is to better people's lives, Chien called for both the pan-green and the pan-blue camps to shift their presidential election campaign policies and vow to rebuilding social welfare and security.
Chien, who once served as an at-large DPP lawmaker for two terms, said the new group hopes to become a "third force, " which will jump-start a new wave of social and civil movements in Taiwan.

He urged all segments of Taiwan society to do some soul-searching on the ethics and values of how campaigning is carried out in Taiwan and push the ruling and the opposition parties to pass responsible election legislation.

Chien said if Taiwan society does not capitalize on the opportunity of the 2004 presidential election to steer politicians in the right direction, the people of Taiwan will always be the ultimate losers after petty political squabbles between opposing parties.

Formerly a member of the DPP's largest faction, the "New Tide, " Chien said that his association with the DPP will have no impact on the work of the "pan-purple alliance, " which will seek fairness and justice for Taiwan society.

"Pan-purple alliance" officials said it is still too early to speculate whether the alliance will eventually be transformed into a political party, and the alliance currently has reached no consensus on whether it will nominate its own candidate for the 2004 presidential election.

Chien confirmed media reports that he had tried to persuade Lin Yi-hsiung, a former DPP chairman, to represent the new alliance as a presidential candidate. "However, Lin turned down my suggestion, " he said.

Members of the Alliance of Fairness and Justice include the women's interest group the Awakening Foundation, the National Teachers' Association, the Taiwan Laborers' Front, the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, and the Elders' Welfare Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT'S BRIGHTEST LIGHTS COULD DIM LIEN'S PRESIDENTIAL BID: LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: The most charismatic and well-known Kuomintang (KMT) politicians may in fact be the Achilles's heed for the presidential bid of KMT Chairman Lien Chan since they are descendants of mainland Chinese, an issue divisive for Taiwanese voters, particularly in the south of the island.

Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung's has warned KMT Chairman Lien Chan that he should distance himself from three KMT political luminaries who are descendants of mainland Chinese has struck a chord with many KMT lawmakers.

Campaign staffers for Lien have floated the idea, but the idea was met with skepticism from Wu, who said that this would reinforce the public impression that the KMT favors those of mainland descent over those from Taiwan. Wu said that this would go down particularly poorly among Taiwanese in southern Taiwan.

The three KMT politicians -- Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun and Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu -command considerable support, but they are also all descendants of mainlanders who emigrated to Taiwan after 1949. About 17 percent of the island's population is made up of such people.
Lien, who is set to pair up with People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, who is also a descendant of mainlanders, was himself born on the mainland but of a Taiwanese father.
KMT Legislative Yuan whip Lee Chia-chin said Ma, Chu and Hu are all rising stars of the KMT and can help Lien win local support.

Lee emphasized that the KMT does not discriminate against mainlanders or their descendants; however, the party should address Wu's concerns and avoid giving Taiwanese the impression that the party is skewed toward mainlanders.
Instead of the party turning its back on its important elected officials just because of their origins, Lee said the KMT should be concentrating on grooming Taiwanese politicians.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng is a good example, Lee said. Elected from a supporter base in Kaohsiung County, Wang is someone with the potential to be a national political leader and would be able to significantly expand the KMT's popularity in southern Taiwan, Lee said.

Others legislators such as Lin Yi-shih from Kaohsiung County, Lee Chuan-chiao from Tainan County and Chuo Poh-yuan from Changhua County are all young politicians with clean images and could be the vanguard of the party's new rallying point for the Taiwanese vote, he said.

Legislator Huang Chao-hsun, who was the first KMT lawmaker to criticize the mainland Chinese backgrounds of Ma, Chu and Hu, claiming it would offend Taiwanese in the South, shares Lee's point of view. He concurred that Legislative Yuan President Wang could be vital to ensuring a victory for Lien in 2004.

"Lien should make Wang the director of his presidential campaign to appeal to voters in the South, " Huang said, adding that two other KMT vice chairmen, Wu Poh-hsiung and P. K. Chiang, are excellent native Taiwanese leaders who can canvass Taiwanese voters for Lien.
Another reason why Lien may wish to reconsider becoming too involved with the three well-known KMT politicians has more to do with cross-party mistrust between the KMT and the PFP than ancestry.

KMT Legislator Chen Hung-chang said Lien should be very wary of aligning himself too closely with Ma, Chu and Hu because this is exactly what the PFP wants: a KMT perceived as catering to the interests of its own and being seen as becoming a party of mainland Chinese.

Besides, Chen pointed out, Ma and Hu are politicians of some account, but Chu is only a political rookie whose strength is far from certain and may turn out to be a minnow when it comes to pulling in votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW SOCIAL WELFARE ALLIANCE VOWS TO REFORM POLITICAL MINDSET

TEXT.P: The newly established Alliance of Fairness and Justice, also known as the "pan-purple alliance, " vowed at its inauguration Sunday that Taiwan society would say goodbye to political short-sightedness and instant gratification.
In its founding declaration, the alliance said that a fair and just society is not a predator who exploits others financially, socially and environmentally.
A fair and just society will not allow the social welfare system to be reduced to a bank ATM and passbook relationship, the alliance said.

The Alliance of Fairness and Justice was formally established Sunday aligning nine of Taiwan's social welfare organizations, which include the Handicapped Union of the Republic of China, the women's interest group the Awakening Foundation, the National Teachers' Association, the Taiwan Laborers' Front, the Eden Social Welfare Foundation, and the Elders' Welfare Union.

In its founding vows, announced by Wang Jung-chang, secretary-general of the Handicapped Union of the Republic of China, the alliance demands the resumption of a "rich man's tax, " and that presidential candidates should spell out their policies on how national debts will be repaid as part of their campaign promises.

The alliance advocates a universal pension system for all elderly citizens of the country and the repeal of the existing retirement payment systems, which will in turn be included under the universal pension system.

The alliance trumpets the establishment of a national social aid system, offering social and financial aid to underprivileged people in the ratio of 3 percent out of the entire population from the current ratio of 0.75 percent.
It also suggests that the government improve its welfare policy toward "new immigrants" to the country, allowing them access to better work and education opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNET PORNO THREATENS YOUTHS' DEVELOPMENT: HUMAN RIGHTS GROUP

TEXT.P: There are a large number of pornographic and sexually explicit Internet sites that may impair the normal growth of the nation's youths, a human rights activist group said Sunday.

After monitoring Internet Web site activities in May and June, the End Child Prostitution, Child Pornography and Trafficking of Children for Sexual Purposes (ECPAT) released its study results Sunday and called for Web site operators to be responsible and screen the contents of their pages and refrain from polluting society. The group said that those running Web sites should pay particular attention to keeping racy content from youngsters.

According to the ECPAT study, PCHome is the "sexiest" among three major Taiwan portals, with 14 percent of its membership-only contents being related to salacious material, followed by Yahoo! with 13 percent, and the local Yam.com with 2.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. STILL UNCONVINCED OF NEED FOR TAIWAN REFERENDUM: KMT AIDE

TEXT.P: Washington remains deeply concerned about Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum, despite a recent visit by a ranking government official to the United States to explain the matter, an official of the major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Sunday.

Chang Jong-kung, deputy director-general of the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee and head of the Mainland Affairs Department, said U. S. concern about Taiwan's referendum plan has remained unchanged following a visit by ROC Presidential Secretary-General Chiou I-jen to Washington earlier this year to try to clarify Taiwan's position regarding the issue.

The United States has not seen enough reasons for Taiwan to hold a referendum on the fate of the disputed Fourth Nuclear Power Plant or its need to join the World Health Organization under the framework of "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait" advocated by President Chen Shui-bian, he said, adding that Washington is even more worried that a referendum on Taiwan's future will escalate tensions across the Taiwan Strait.

Chang pointed out that relations between Taiwan and the United States have showed signs of souring despite Chiu's U. S. trip, as evidenced by U. S. authorities claim in late July that the Taiwan question must be resolved with the consent of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and that ties between the United States and mainland China are in their best shape ever.

According to Chang, the statement made by U. S. Deputy Secretary of State Richard Amitage to Director Chen Yunlin of the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council about "the consent of the people on both sides" represents a big change from the previous stance of the United States, which had been "with the consent of the Taiwan people."

This indicates that Taiwan's space for self-determination has been squeezed and the administration led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party must not overlook this significant change or evade its responsibility in the face of the deterioration in two-way relations, Chang said.

As to the remarks made by U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell that U. S.- mainland China ties are in their best-ever shape in decades, Chang urged the government to pay adequate attention to this viewpoint, which reflects an upgrading to an official stance from a purely academic opinion in the past.

At a time when Washington needs Beijing's coordination and help to resolve the problems on the Korean Peninsula, Taiwan's use of a populist approach to deal with its links with the United States will not benefit Taiwan, he argued, warning that "it in turn will reduce Taiwan's leverage in the triangular Taipei-Beijing-Washington ties."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHIP ATTACKED IN MALACCA STRAIT TO ARRIVE IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: A Taiwan cargo ship attacked by pirates in the Strait of Malacca Friday has escaped and will arrive in Singapore Monday, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Sunday.

Lin Shung-huan, director of the Department for East Asian and Pacific Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said the ministry's representative office in Singapore has made arrangement for Lo Yin-hsiung, the injured captain of the ship, the "Tungyi, " to be admitted to a hospital once he reaches the city-state.

Two boats camouflaged as oil rig tug boats approached the "Tungyi" and strafed the ship with automatic gun fire. During the two-hour attack the captain was hit in the knee but managed to contacted the ship's owner in Kaohsiung, who alerted local authorities to send help.
The attack left the "Tungyi's" steering system disabled.
The chase ended at about 7 p.m. Except for the captain, all 33 crew members of the vessel were unhurt.

The 3,000-ton "Tungyi" left Kaohsiung on April 22 to carry fish from a port in the Indian Ocean and was slated to return to Taiwan later this month. It was on its way to Singapore to unload part of its 1,200-ton fish load when it came under attack.
The Strait of Malacca is notorious for pirate attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOOSTING PUBLIC SPENDING BEST HEDGE AGAINST DEFLATION: SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: With the commodity price index continuing to fall over the past few months and Taiwan's Central Bank of China's low-interest rate policy doing little to stimulate the interest of private investors or consumers, several scholars believe that boosting public spending might be the only way to ward off deflation.

The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Cabinet reported Sunday that the commodity price index in July stood at 98.8 with 1996 as the base year, indicating a drop of 0.42 percent from that of June. In the first seven months of this year, the commodity price index dropped by 0.28 percent as compared with the same period of the preceding year.

Forecasting negative growth in the consumer price index for this year, the DGBAS said that Taiwan is still facing the threat of deflation. In May the International Monetary Fund (IMF) warned that Taiwan, Germany and Hong Kong were at risk of deflation.

When faced with deflationary pressures, many countries seek to apply a loose monetary policy as a stimulus to private consumption and investment willingness, Professor Chu Hao-ming of National Chengchi University said, adding that since the Central Bank of China over the past few months has lowered the basic interest rates several times, the low-interest rate monetary policy is losing its effectiveness as a solution.

The professor suggested that boosting public spending might be more effective right now. However, with mounting public debt, the government must spend the money on projects that can contribute significantly to the nation, and not on quick-fix social welfare schemes.

He added that in the long run, the government needs to improve the domestic investment environment by ensuring good infrastructure, including water and electricity supplies, and making further relaxations on regulations governing cross-Taiwan Strait trade.
Chen Tien-chih, president of the Chung Hua Institute for Economic Research, agreed that boosting public spending might be the only resort for the government to avert deflation.

Chen said that the worst situation would be that consumers might speculate upon further price declines as the commodity price index continues to go down. This would make it even more difficult for the economy to rebound, he added.

The scholar suggested that the government consider raising salary levels of public servants. When the private sector follows suit, commodity prices might gradually go up, as consumers' purchasing power would be on the rise.

As to investment willingness, Chen said that the serious overdue loan problem of many local banking institutions has led to an ever more conservative loan policy in Taiwan's banking system, and a rigid capital market would weaken the interest of private investments.
He said that the government should implement its monetary reform and resolve the overdue loan problem as soon as possible.

Referring to the magnitude of public spending, Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Taiwan ThinkTank, said that using a three-year plan, at least NT$300 billion would be needed, and a five-year plan, at least NT$500 billion.

Chen pointed out that in case only an additional NT$20 billion to NT$30 billion is set aside for public reconstruction projects, in comparison with the annual government budget of NT$1.5 trillion, the additional budget would be too small to have much effect on the economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG YOUTHS IN TAIWAN ON TOURISM PROMOTION TOUR

TEXT.P: One hundred youths from Hong Kong arrived in Taiwan Sunday as "ambassadors" of the Tourism Bureau to promote Taiwan's tourism.

The 100 Hong Kong youths, aged between 8 and 15, were selected from 5,470 candidates who answered quizzes provided by the Tourism Bureau via the Internet about Taiwan Feb. 18-March 16, Tourism Bureau officials said.
Of the 5,470 Hong Kong youths, 2,866 got perfect scores on the quiz, which entitled them to be entered in a drawing for the 100 opportunities to win a three-night, four-day tour of Taiwan for free.
Twenty-one parents of the 100 youths accompanied them on the Taiwan tour.

The group is scheduled to visit tourist attractions in central and northern Taiwan. The itinerary of their travels will include visits to the National Museum of Natural Sciences in Taichung, the Flying Cow Range in Miaoli, the "Window of the World, " the Leofoo Safari Park, the Taipei Zoo, the National Palace Museum and the pottery and ceramic street in Yingko, Taipei County, Tourism Bureau officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT LU ARRIVES IN LOS ANGELES FOR STOPOVER
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By L. Chu and EH)

TEXT.P: ROC Vice President Annette Lu arrived in Los Angeles Saturday afternoon from Hawaii on her way to Asuncion to attend the inauguration of Paraguayan President-elect Nicanor Duarte on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.

She was greeted at the airport by Therese Shaheen, chairwoman of the American Institute in Taiwan, and Chen Chien-jen, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States.

When she arrived at her hotel, she was enthusiastically welcomed by leaders of overseas Chinese organizations in the greater Los Angeles area, including the Association of Overseas Friends of Chen Shui-bian, the Taiwan Association in Los Angeles, the Los Angeles Branch of the Formosan Association for Public Affairs, and the Southern California Branch of the Taiwan Women's Association in North America.

Lu is scheduled to stay in Los Angeles for three days. She will meet with overseas Chinese community leaders, visit the Reagan Library and other cultural and economic establishments before leaving for Paraguay Aug. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: COOPERATION BETWEEN ROC AND FOUR CARIBBEAN COUNTRIES SEEING RESULTS
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By L. Huang and EH)

TEXT.P: The foreign ministers of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Grenada, Saint Christopher and Nevis, and Dominica said Friday in a news conference that the cooperation between the Republic of China and their countries has been constructive.
They also said that the four countries will continue to support the ROC's bid to join international organizations, especially the United Nations and the World Health Organization.

They made the remarks on the eve of ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien's departure for Taiwan from Kingstown, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, where he attended a conference of foreign ministers Friday.

Louis Straker, vice premier and foreign minister of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, said the ROC has been very helpful to his country, especially in agricultural development. For example, he said, through the help of ROC agricultural experts, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines is now able to produce pineapples and bananas for export and produce enough pork to meet domestic demand. The ROC is now helping his country raise chickens. The ROC has never reduce her aid to Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, even during economically difficult times, he said.
Chien is scheduled to return to Taipei Monday evening via Miami and Los Angeles.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE ECONOMY WILL COLLAPSE SOONER OR LATER: TAIWAN SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By S. C. Chang and EH)

TEXT.P: The economy of mainland China will collapse sooner or later; therefore, it would be wise for businessmen to stay away, since there will be no escape when the end comes, a leading Taiwan economist said in New York Saturday.

Chang Ching-hsi, professor of economics at National Taiwan University, made the remarks in his speech titled "Watch the World Situation and Chinese Economy from Taiwan, " at a meeting of the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace in New York.
He said the economic fundamentals of mainland China point to the eventual collapse of the economy.

Chang said that he has no intention of "talking down" the Chinese economy, and that he has based his observations on the fact that many big problems in mainland China have been left unresolved for a long time. These unresolved problems will become even thornier and harmful in the years to come.
He said the unresolved problems lie in the rural economy, the financial system, unemployment, uneven distribution of wealth, political and institutional corruption, and moral bankruptcy.

During the first stage of the "reform and openness" campaign initiated by former paramount leader Deng Xiaoping between 1979 and 1996, China followed the steps of the Soviet Union in developing its economy. Since then, the Chinese economy has been growing by at least 7 percent every year.
Chang pointed out that the economic prosperity in mainland China is only superficial, and that Chinese economic statistics are often unreliable.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REITERATES COMMITMENT TO REFERENDUM BY 2004

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated his commitment to holding a referendum before 2004 and his belief that there is one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait in an meeting with Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) officials in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan, Sunday.

Chen was quoted as telling DPP officials in Chiayi that his administration will take into account the opposition parties' opinions and compromise on some issues, but will never compromise on its claim that Taiwan and the mainland are separate countries on different sides of the Taiwan Strait.

That means the DPP administration will never accept Beijing's claim that there is only one China made up of both the mainland and Taiwan, Chen was quoted as saying in the closed-door meeting by DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Chin-yung.
"It is the bottom line we will stick to, " Chen reportedly told the DPP officials.

Citing Hong Kong as an example, Chen said six years after it was handed back to Beijing, the former "pearl of the Orient" has lost its luster and its people took to the streets to defend their freedom on July 1.

He also reiterated his promise to carry out the country's first referendum by 2004 on at least two issues; whether the country should join the World Health Organization and whether the partially built Fourth Nuclear Power Plant should be scraped.

The president also blamed the country's media for their constant criticism of his administration, branding it a practice not seen in any other place in the world, especially the many talk shows on cable stations, with anchormen "picking holes in everything done by the government all day long and all week long, even on weekends."

However, the president remained undaunted. Lee cited him as telling DPP officials that "as long as we persevere in our pursuit of democracy and freedom, the people will sympathize with us eventually."

DOC.HEADLINE: N. KOREAN FREIGHTER URGED TO UNLOAD CHEMICAL MATERIALS IN KAOHSIUNG
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Officials of the Ministry of Finance Kaohsiung Customs Bureau (MFKCB) have urged the North Korean freighter "Be Gaehung" to willingly unload the 158 barrels of phosphorus pentasulfide on board before it leaves Kaohsiung Port, shipping industry sources said Sunday.
The MFKCB has decided to confiscate the chemical materials, which are believed to be used for military purposes, the sources who asked not to be identified said.
It is believed that the phosphorus pentasulfide can be used for producing rocket fuel.

However, the agent of the North Korean ship at Kaohsiung argued that the phosphorus pentasulfide is a general chemical product and that the chemicals in question are registered as "commodities in transit." The authorities have no reason to confiscate them, the agent claimed.

The 6,500-ton "Be Gaehung, " which arrived in Kaohsiung Harbor Thursday from Bangkok, Thailand, is in Taiwan to unload some 2,000 metric tons of aluminum powder. It remains berthed in Kaohsiung although it completed its loading and unloading operations at the port Saturday.
The next destination of the "Be Gaehung" is Nanpo, North Korea according to its itinerary.
MFKCB officials boarded the North Korean freighter on Friday on suspicions that the ship was transporting illicit and dangerous chemical materials.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO FURTHER RESTRICTIONS IN WATER USE IN TAIPEI BY END OF AUGUST

TEXT.P: There will be no further restrictions in water use for Taipei residents by the end of this month, but the public should still cooperate in conserving water due to falling water levels at major local reservoirs, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday.
Although rainfall last month registered record lows in northern Taiwan, Ma said there will be no stiffer restrictions in water use for residents in the greater Taipei area through August.

"This year's situation has been a little better than last year's, " Ma noted, despite the fact that it only rained a record low of 50 millimeters in July -- approximately one tenth of the year-earlier level, in the water catchment area of the Feitsui Reservoir, the main water supplier for the greater Taipei area.

Taiwan, especially the northern regions, was hit hard by an acute drought last year -- the worst in Taiwan's history. Amid scarcer rainfall since the beginning of this year, a restrictive measure has already been imposed in the greater Taipei area since early March that consists of a reduction in water pressure during off-peak hours.
July and August are traditionally rainy months for Taiwan, during which approaching typhoons usually bring a large amount of rainfall to the entire island.
The water level of the Feitsui Reservoir dropped to 138.71 meters as of 5: 00. p.m., a slide of 0.42 meters from the level posted at 1:00 a. m.

The level is close to the 137-meter mark, which has been designed by a national anti-drought task force as the point of which the second-phase water restrictions begin -- a 20-percent reduction in water supplies to large-volume users such as car washes, swimming pools and saunas.

The water level of the Shipmen Dam in neighboring Taoyuan County has dipped to 216.07 meters, close to the extremely low level of 210 meters, prompting local authorities to warn the public that water rationing will be implemented if no rain falls by the middle of this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LU SUGGESTS BEIJING TO WELCOME TAIWAN'S PARTICIPATION IN WHO

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu suggested Beijing Saturday to welcome Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization (WHO).

Addressing a dinner party hosted by overseas Chinese and Taiwanese communities in Los Angeles in her honor, Lu said if Beijing really cares about the health of the people of Taiwan, it should openly announce that it welcomes Taiwan's participation in the WHO.

To hold a referendum on whether Taiwan should join the WHO is to show the world the determination of the island's people to join the world's top health body, Lu stressed, expressing the hope that the United States will support Taiwan's position on the issue.
It will not be necessary for Taiwan to hold a referendum on the island's bid to join the WHO if Beijing welcomes Taiwan's participation in the world body, Lu continued.

Lu also told the overseas Chinese and Taiwanese who were present at the dinner party the progress made by President Chen Shui-bian's administration in the economic, political and social fields over the past three years although there still exists room for further improvement.
She urged the general public to give President Chen and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party more time to implement their reform programs and to build a better Taiwan.
Lu arrived in Los Angeles Saturday afternoon from Hawaii on her way to Asuncion to attend the inauguration of Paraguayan President-elect Nicanor Duarte on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.

On hand at the dinner party were also Therese Shaheen, chairwoman of the American Institute in Taiwan, U.S. Congresswoman Hilda Solis, Los Angeles Deputy Mayor Joy Chen and ROC Reresentative to the U. S. Chen Chien-jen.

Invited to speaking on the occasion, Joy Chen, who once served as an aide to Lu when she served as a legislator, praised her former boss as an outstanding stateswoman with many characteristics of a leader. She described Lu as a "shinning example."

Lu is scheduled to stay in Los Angeles for three days. She will meet with overseas Chinese community leaders, visit the Reagan Library and other cultural and economic establishments before leaving for Paraguay Aug. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: USA, CUBA LEAD WORLD YOUTH BASEBALL CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: Both the United States and Cuba scored their second consecutive wins and took the leading positions in their respective groups Sunday in the XI "AA" World Youth Baseball Championship being held in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.
The U.S. defeated the hosting Chinese Taipei 8-5 in a nine-inning game, while Cuba overpowered Korea 4-3 in an extended 11-inning match.
In another match played on the same day, Japan beat the Czech Republic 14-4 in a seven-inning called game.

A total of nine countries, including the United States, Cuba, Japan, Korea, Indonesia, Australia, the Czech Republic, South Africa and the host, the Republic of China, participate in the championship that opened in Kaohsiung Aug. 8.
The tournament is divided into two groups in the preliminary competitions and the two best teams of each group after completing round-robin competitions will advance to the next round.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 11, or the 14th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1858: Christiaan Eijkman, the Dutch physician who won the 1929 Nobel Prize for medicine for his discovery of Vitamin B, is born.
1863: The French, who occupy southern Vietnam, make Cambodia a protectorate.
1919: Scottish-born American industrialist and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie dies at the age of 84. He amassed a fortune in the steel industry and donated millions of dollars for the benefit of the public.
1921: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, formally invites China, Japan, Britain, France and Italy to join a disarmament meeting in Washington, D.C. to cope with an increasingly dangerous international situation after World War I.
1930: Britain goes broke. The United States and France each lend it US$46 million, while American bankers extend another US$111 million.
1932: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, says it is time to scrap Prohibition. He lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt later that same year.
1936: Nationalist Chinese forces of Chiang Kai-shek enter Canton after foiling a rebellion led by Chen Chi-tang in the city in southern China.
1945: The Allies inform Japan that its surrender offer is acceptable.
1945: Communist "Yenan General Headquarters" orders Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the Republic of China government.
1950: The U.N. Security Council rejects a Soviet proposal for the immediate expulsion of the ROC delegation. The Russian delegation walks out in protest.
1960: Chad gains independence from France.
1960: The ROC recognizes the Ivory Coast and Chad.
1966: A peace treaty is signed in Jakarta, ending three years of hostilities between Malaysia and Indonesia.
1972: President Richard M. Nixon completes his "Vietnamization" of the Vietnam War by pulling out the last 92 American soldiers from the Southeast Asian country.
1973: The Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League opens its three-day 19th Conference in Taipei.
1975: The first meeting of the Asian and Pacific Congress on Health, Physical Education and Recreation opens in Taipei with 250 experts from 17 nations and areas attending.
1976: The industrial and commercial panel of the National Reconstruction Seminar opens a three-day meeting to make recommendations to the government.
1986: Sixteen people are killed and 87 others injured in an accidental explosion aboard the tanker SS Canari which is waiting to be scrapped in a shipwrecking yard in Kaohsiung Harbor.
1992: The United States, Canada and Mexico reach an agreement to set up a North American free-trade zone that would rank as the world's largest single trading bloc.
1993: The ROC Cable Television Law goes into effect.
1997: An international meeting called to shore up the shaky Thai economy offers loans of US$16 billion to the financial crisis-hit country.
1999: Taiwan's China Airlines signs an agreement with Boeing Co. of the United States to buy 13 B747-400 cargo planes for an estimated US$2.5 billion.
2000: A group of bankers urge the ROC government to take effective measures to crack down on credit card crime in order to prevent Taiwan from becoming an "Asian financial crime center."
2000: A "Tzu Chi Village" in South Africa built by Taiwan's Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, a charity organization, is formally inaugurated. Meanwhile, the Tzu Chi Medical Center announces the 99th and 100th overseas cases in which it has supplied bone marrow for transplant operations.
2001: The Bureau of Monetary Affairs under the Finance Ministry and the Central Deposits Insurance Corp. take the initiative to put 36 faltering local financial institutions under supervision, the first phase of a "Monetary Reconstruction Fund" action to consolidate the operations of local banks and farmers as well as fishermen's cooperatives.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to command the obedience of the members of one's family. If a man looking into his own heart is not true to himself, he will not command the obedience of the members of his family."

DOC.HEADLINE: 12 STOLEN CAMRY CARS SHIPPED BACK FROM SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Through the joint efforts of police, customs and immigration authorities, 12 stolen new Toyota Camry sedans were shipped back from Singapore over the weekend, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said Monday.
The CIB was tipped off in early July that a car theft ring was planning to ship stolen cars to Thailand and Cambodia via Singapore for sale.

After scrutinizing a large pile of container loading documents, shipping firms data and customs clearance reports, investigators uncovered two containers holding eight brand new Camry cars at a container terminal at the Keelung Harbor in late July.
Through a further analysis of relevant documents, they concluded that three other containers holding 12 stolen cars had been shipped to Singapore's Keepel port.
The CIB asked the Singaporean customs service to assist in intercepting the containers. CIB and local customs officers then traveled to Singapore to arrange for shipment of the cars back to Taiwan.
According to CIB investigations, the 20 new Camry sedans were stolen in Tainan, Taichung, Hsinchu and Taoyuan between July 4 and July 9.

As the car theft ring adopted a stringent division of labor system, ring members responsible for stealing, container loading, shipment and overseas sales didn't know each other. CIB officials said they will investigate further to gain a better understanding of the ring's operations and bring all of those involved to justice.
