DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE GROUP IN BEIJING TO PUSH FOR SPEEDY CARGO TRANSPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Tseng Chun-liang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A large Taiwan trade delegation, organized by the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI), is currently in Beijing to push for an early realization of quick and convenient cross-Taiwan Strait cargo transportation.

The group, headed by CNFI Chairman Hou Chen-hsiung, arrived in Beijing Sunday on the first-leg of its market-inspection visit to mainland China that will also take it to other cities with large numbers of Taiwan investors.

The delegation, composed of more than 40 senior industry executives, is the first Taiwan trade mission to visit the mainland since the waning of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) which afflicted both sides of the Taiwan Strait between March and June this year.

The group is scheduled to meet with top mainland Chinese leaders Tuesday afternoon. Hou, who concurrently serves as a national policy adviser to ROC President Chen Shui-bian, said he will take advantage of the meeting to ask mainland authorities to adopt measures to pave the way for speedy and convenient cross-strait cargo transportation.

Following the containment of SARS, Hou said, cross-strait commercial exchanges have regained momentum. Mainland China should coordinate with Taiwan in improving cargo transport services between the two sides, he added.

Moreover, Hou said he will urge mainland authorities to take effective steps to better protect Taiwan businesspeople's property and property safety. A spate of murders of Taiwan businesspeople operating on the mainland earlier this year has led to widespread concerns about mainland China's public order and safety measures.

Hou's mission met with Beijing Mayor Qishan Monday morning, and it will pay a courtesy call on Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under mainland China's State Council or Cabinet, later in the day.

The group will leave for Shanghai Wednesday to meet with Shanghai municipal officials and Taiwan business community leaders in the city. The group will also visit Nanjin and Kunshan before returning to Taipei Aug. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 17.95 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Monday, with the weighted index moving down 17.95 points to close at 5,214.6.
Market turnover amounted to NT$66.01 billion (US$1.92 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 17.95 points to close at 5,214.6.
The bourse opened at 5,239.17 and then fluctuated between 5,239.17 and 5,174.77 during trading.
A total of 2.72 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$66.01 billion (US$1.92 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with plastics and chemical shares moving up the most at 0.5 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.1 percent.

The other major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 1.9 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 0.8 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.6 percent, cement stocks at 0.5 percent, textile issues at 0.3 percent, and electrical shares at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 464 to 199, with 100 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were generally higher on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved up 45 points to close at 5,251, with 23,672 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September rose 37 points to finish at 5,247, with 461 contract transactions, while December futures lost 66 points to close at 5,168, with 5 contracts traded.
March futures gained 95 points to finish at 5,220, with 4 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,206 for August, 5,210 for September, 5,234 for December, 5,125 for March, and 5,125 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also generally higher.
August TE futures moved up 2.4 points to close at 234.5, with 3,030 contract transactions, while September TE futures rose 2 points to finish at 234, with 94 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
August TF futures remained unchanged at 677, with 1,366 contract transactions, while September TF futures fell 7 points to finish at 670, with 2 contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: VEEP CALLS TAIWAN BEACON FOR MAINLAND CHINA'S DEMOCRATIZATION
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Tsai Su-jung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Vice President Annette Lu said in Los Angeles Sunday that Taiwan is a beacon of hope for mainland China's democratization.

Lu, who arrived in L.A. Saturday for a three-day transit stop on her way to Asuncion to attend the inauguration of Paraguayan President-elect Nicanor Duarte on behalf of ROC President Chen Shui-bian, made the remarks while meeting with Rep. Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.)
Rep. Rohrabacher concurrently serves a co-chairman of the Congressional Taiwan Caucus -- a pro-Taiwan group in the U.S. Congress.

Lu said Taiwan's existence can exert pressure on mainland China to move toward democracy. She urged mainland Chinese leaders to cooperate with Taiwan in pushing for peaceful cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges for the benefit of the people of both sides.
The outspoken vice president also asked Beijing not to block Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO).
"Beijing should instead publicly welcome Taiwan's participation in the WHO to substantiate its claim that it cares about the Taiwan people's health and well-being," Lu said.
She also expressed thanks to Rohrabacher for his staunch support for Taiwan's cause over past years.

Rohrabacher said he personally supports Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum to signify its determination to join the WHO. He said the U.S. government should offer more support for Taiwan and should not sit idly by and let Beijing bully Taiwan's democratically elected government.

The influential Republican congressman from California's Orange County said he plans to come up with an initiative urging the Bush administration to invite Taiwan's president and vice president to deliver speeches in the United States.

Later in the day, Lu paid a visit to the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library and Museum in the company of Chen Chien-jen, ROC representative to the United States, and Therese Shaheen, chairwoman of the American Institute in Taiwan -- the top U.S. liaison officer to Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties between the two countries.
Former U.S. first lady Nancy Reagan sent a letter to Lu extending a warm welcome to Lu's visit to the Reagan library and museum.

Nancy Reagan said in her letter that Taiwan contributed much to the inauguration of the Reagan library and museum in 1991. She expressed her heartfelt gratitude for Taiwan's support for the project in recognition of her husband's career achievements. She added that she believes Lu's visit will encourage more Taiwan people to visit the library and museum.

Taiwan donated funds for construction of the Reagan library and museum which showcases many documents and photos featuring President Reagan's eight years in the White House. Over the past decade, many Taiwan political heavyweights and celebrities in various fields have visited the library. Among the visitors have been former ROC President Lee Teng-hui and his wife.

In the afternoon, Lu met with five members of the California State House of Representatives, including Judy Chu, Mervyn Dymally, Alan Lowenthal and Ronald S. Calderon. Lu's guests also included California State House of Representatives Speaker Robert Hertzberg. Lu exchanged views with Californian state lawmakers on a range of issues of mutual concern. They also discussed measures to further boost cooperation between Taiwan and the state of California.
Lu will visit Irvine which maintains sisterhood ties with Taiwan's Taoyuan County, of which Lu used to be magistrate, as well as Broadcom, a California-based high-tech firm.
Lu will leave for Panama for an official visit after having a lunch meeting with the Irvine mayor Tuesday noon.

While in Panama, Lu will meet with senior Panamanian officials to discuss measures for further boosting bilateral cooperation. Panamanian Vice President Dominador Kaiser Bazan Jimenez will honor Lu by awarding her a medal.
In addition to attending the Paraguayan presidential inauguration Aug. 15, Lu will deliver speeches at the Paraguayan parliament and at Asuncion University.
On her way back to Taiwan Aug. 20, Lu is scheduled to make a transit stop in Seattle for two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'CLEAN UP THE WORLD' DRIVE TO KICK OFF SEP. 20

TEXT.P: The global "Clean Up the World" drive is set to kick off in Taiwan Sep. 20, the Good Neighbor Cultural and Education Foundation (GNCEF), which organizes the island's clean-up activity, announced at a news conference Monday.
GNCEF Chairman Lai Tung-ming said some 50,000 will participate in the clean-up effort at 800 locations countrywide.

More than 183 local enterprises and organizations have expressed willingness to join the clean-up campaign in Taiwan this year, Lai added, adding that volunteers are expected to take part and work together carrying out the local clean-up activities.
Hao Lung-pin, administrator of the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration, also attended the news conference to throw his support behind the clean-up drive.
Hao said last year's clean-up campaign was very successful, with many schools, enterprises and organizations supporting the activity.
Only through the efforts of everyone can we maintain a clean environment and prevent the spread of diseases, Hao said. (by Nocturne Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OFFICIAL VOICES CONFIDENCE ABOUT 2004 PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Chiang Ying and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Lee Ying-yuan, deputy secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , on Sunday reaffirmed that his party is confident about winning the next presidential election.
Lee made the remarks while speaking on the March 2004 presidential election at a summer camp for Taiwan people residing on the west coast of the United States.
Lee said that although the DPP candidate lost in the recent Hualien magistrate by-election, he is confident that the party will win the upcoming presidential election.

Some people view the Hualien election result as a harbinger of the presidential election outcome. However, Lee noted that the Hualien by-election was a local election and different from a presidential election. He said the issues, electorate, and the strategies to be employed will all be different.

Lee noted that the DPP needs to double its efforts over the next seven months, saying that "economic prosperity, democratic credentials and reform determination will be key points that influence the next presidential election.

Lee also stressed that following Taiwan's legislative reform and implementation of popular presidential elections, referendums are inevitable in the island's democratization process, adding that a referendum ought to be held prior to the presidential election.

Tsai Ming-hsien, deputy Republic of China representative to the United States, also spoke on the importance of Taiwan holding a referendum. He said that faced with mainland China's continuing efforts to isolate it internationally, Taiwan has to bravely speak out on its own and solidify its internal strength in order to achieve international respect.

Tsai said that the Taiwan people could express their desire to join the World Health Organization via referendum, and "let Beijing see that its continued obstruction of Taiwan's WHO bid runs counter to the wish of the Taiwan people."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DECLINES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar declined against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, giving up NT$0.026 to close at NT$34.389.
A total of US$215 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$34.419 and was traded between NT$34.370 and NT$34.429.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHIP ATTACKED BY PIRATES ARRIVES IN SINGAPORE
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan fish transport ship arrived in Singapore Monday evening after being attacked last week in the notorious Strait of Malacca where pirates are rampant.
Singapore has already approved the ship to anchor offshore, but the ship will not enter the harbor Tuesday as port authorities have to quarantine the Kaohsiung-registered vessel.
The top priority Monday was to send the injured captain, Lo Ying-hsiung, to the hospital, Taiwan's representative office in Singapore said.

The 3,300-ton "Tungyi" was carrying more than 1,500 tons of fish catch from a port in the Indian Ocean and was slated to return to Taiwan later this month. It was on its way to Singapore to unload fish load when it came under attack.

Two boats camouflaged as oil rig tug boat approached the "Tungyi" and strafed the ship with automatic gun fire. Lo was shot in the left leg, and the ship was riddled with bullet holes. Some instruments in the ship were damaged, but the crew, except for Lo, which included nine Taiwan fishermen, and 24 others from the Philippines, Vietnam and mainland China, were safe.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERDUE LOAN RATIO OF LOCAL BANKS AVERAGES 5.68 PERCENT AT END OF JUNE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Central Bank of China said Monday that the average overdue loan ratio of domestic banks was 5.68 percent, down 0.43 percentage points from March.

Breaking this down, the private manufacturing sector accounted for 19.25 percent of the overdue loans, the private businesses sector accounted for 10 percent, the private construction and real estate sector at 16.82 percent, individuals at 46.45 percent, and others accounted for 7.48 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: WATER SUPPLY TO TAIPEI, KEELUNG COULD BE FURTHER RESTRICTED

TEXT.P: If the drought continues, water supply to Taipei and Keelung will be further restricted, an official of the Water Conservancy Agency of the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Monday.

He said it has not rained for 49 days and the water in the nearby reservoir is dropping. If the dry spell continues, the water conservancy agency will stop supplying water to certain districts in Keelung on certain days by rotation. The new measure may begin next week. Water supply to the city is already being restricted at night.

Water supply to heavy users -- such as owners of saunas, swimming pools, and public bathrooms -- will be reduced by 20 percent in Taipei, beginning by the end of August. Water supply to industrial districts will be reduced by 5 percent, but the supply to hospitals will not be restricted, he added.
Water supply to the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park will not be reduced until the end of October, because the two reservoirs in the area still have sufficient water.
The water levels in Shihmen Reservoir and Feitsui Reservoir, the two major sources of water in northern Taiwan, are dropping steadily, the official said.
The southern half of the island has already received sufficient rainfall this summer. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMICS MINISTER IN U.S. TO PROMOTE INVESTMENT IN TAWIAN

TEXT.P: A Taiwan economic and investment promotional mission, led by Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu, arrived in Los Angeles Monday on the first leg of a weeklong visit to San Diego, Chicago, Delaware, Philadelphia and New York.
While in those cities, the mission will hold seminars on investment in Taiwan and meet with American business leaders.

The mission is composed of officials from industrial, economic, and trade promotional organizations, including the Industrial Development Bureau of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the China External Trade Development Council, and the Industrial Development and Investment Center of the economics ministry.
The purpose of the trade mission is to invite American industrialists to invest in Taiwan. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: NORTH KOREAN FREIGHTER STILL IN KAOHSIUNG OVER CHEMICAL SUSPICIONS

TEXT.P: The departure of the North Korean freighter "Be Gae Bong" from the southern Taiwan harbor of Kaohsiung has been postponed at the request of Kaohsiung Harbor authorities due to concerns over possibly dangerous chemicals aboard.

The Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau and Kaohsiung Customs Bureau wanted to delay the departure of the cargo ship after receiving reports that it might be carrying a kind of chemical that can be used for military purposes. The ship arrived in Kaohsiung Aug. 7 from Bangkok, Thailand on its way to Pyongyang, North Korea.
The suspected cargo has been unloaded and stored in a warehouse in the harbor for inspection by authorities.

An official of the harbor bureau said the cargo may be confiscated according to international trade law if it is a controlled, dangerous material; otherwise, it will be immediately allowed to leave the harbor. The cargo weighs 39,500 tons. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE TO EXCEED 3 PERCENT THIS YEAR: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday his administration's economic stimulus drive has paid off, with the domestic economy regaining momentum and expected to register 3 percent to 3.5 percent growth this year.

Chen made the remarks while presiding over the second meeting of a presidential economic advisory panel headed by Vincent Siew, a former premier and an incumbent vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, who concurrently serves as chairman of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CHIER).
Quoting official tallies, Chen said, all major domestic economic indicators, ranging from export and import trade, financial market indexes to private consumption, have shown signs of recovery.
Against this backdrop, Chen said, major local economic think tanks forecast that this year's economic growth rate will exceed 3 percent and that the rate will be even higher next year.
Chen said the higher-than-expected growth rate indicates that the government's efforts to revitalize the economy and overhaul the financial system have paid off.

During the meeting, Siew delivered a CHIER-prepared report on Taiwan's agricultural modernization plan and another advisory panel member, Wu Rong-i, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, reported on the nation's present economic situation and its future development prospects.

After listening to their reports, Chen gave several directives for future government work, including phasing out unnecessary restrictions on economic activities and capital flow to buoy the nation's economic vitality and sharpen its overall competitive edge.

Chen said the government should release unused or seldom-used land and other resources for more efficient use, accelerate infrastructure construction, step up banking reforms, establish free trade harbor zones and build high-quality recreational facilities to boost tourism.
As for the much-anticipated agricultural modernization, Chen said Taiwan must pay more heed to "species, quality and brand" in agricultural and fishery production.

"The government should help local farmers and aquaculture operators in selecting high value-added species or strains for cultivation and breeding and build up unique brand names for their products," Chen said.

Noting that Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) has brought both challenges and opportunities, Chen said the government should pool its resources with farming groups and academic institutes in developing biotechnologies to upgrade competitiveness of local agricultural and fishery industries.

Through joint efforts of county governments, local universities and agricultural and fishery associations, Chen said, several unique cluster production areas, such as the Pingtung tropical agricultural park, the Changhua floral industry park, the Tainan orchid farm and the Ilan marine resources park, have gradually taken shape.

"All these clusters are a model for our future agricultural development, " Chen said, adding that agricultural production must be associated with research, entrepreneurship and tourism to reinvigorate rural development.

Chen said his administration will contribute more funds and energies to helping farmers and fishermen establish computerized databanks on farm produce and fishery products production and consumption as well as modernize marketing, warehousing and distribution services.
As the first step, Chen said, the government will select orchids, wax apples and mangoes as "flagship" products to be subject to intensified export promotion.

Other members of the advisory panel, including Taiwan Thinktank Chairman Chen Po-chih and CHIER President Chen Tien-chih, also attended the meeting. Other participants included Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i, National Security Council Secretary-General Kang Ning-hsiang, and Chiou I-jen, secretary-general to the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: NORTH KOREAN FREIGHTER FREE TO LEAVE KAOHSIUNG HARBOR

TEXT.P: North Korean freighter "Be Gae Bong" was given permission to leave the southern Taiwan harbor of Kaohsiung Monday afternoon after a suspected cargo was unloaded for inspection earlier in the day.

Harbor and customs authorities in Kaohsiung wanted to delay the departure of the cargo ship after receiving reports that it might be carrying a kind of chemical that can be used for military purposes. The ship arrived in Kaohsiung on Aug. 7 from Bangkok on its way to Pyongyang, North Korea.
The cargo will also be allowed to leave, if it is found not a controlled, dangerous material, an official of the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau said. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS TAIWANESE BUSINESS LEADERS MEET IN MANAGUA

TEXT.P: Nicaraguan President Enrique Bolanos Geyer and a high-ranking Taiwan official attended an annual conference of Taiwan Chambers of Commerce in Central and South America Sunday in Managua, Nicaragua.
More than 200 leaders of Taiwan Chambers of Commerce from Central and South American countries and other parts of the world attended the meeting.

In the conference, President Bolanos praised Taiwanese businessmen for their contribution to the development of the economy in his country, pointing out that Taiwan investors in Nicaraguan export processing zones have created more than 25,000 job opportunities. He also thanked them for their donation of 260 wheelchairs to Nicaraguan hospitals.

Chuang Suo-hang, vice minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission in Taipei, lauded the Taiwanese entrepreneurs for their success in business and their support for the government and people of the Republic of China on Taiwan. He also briefed them on the improvement of the investment environment in Taiwan. (by L. Huang and EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-MAINLAND WILL REUNITE WHEN BOTH ARE DEMOCRATIC: ROC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Chen Yi-ping and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The time for Taiwan's union with mainland China will come when democracy and freedom have taken root in the mainland, Su Chin-chiang, adviser to Republic of China's National Security Council said in Kuala Lumpur Monday.

Giving a speech to an association of ethnic Chinese businessmen, Su said the ROC has moved on a path towards democracy and more freedom since its establishment in 1911, and its legitimacy has been uninterrupted in Taiwan.
Democracy will also help stabilize the situation across the Taiwan Strait, which will in turn contribute to the stability in the region, Su went on.

Since the Soviet Union collapsed in 1990, people around the globe have been pursuing freedoms and the people on the mainland and Taiwan are no exceptions. Their common pursuit will help narrow the political gap between them and facilitate negotiations with each other.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO WATER SHORTAGE FOR HSINCHU SCIENCE-BASED PARK TO END OF OCTOBER
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: There will be no water shortages at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park up to the end of October, a park official said Monday.

Hsu Chia-li, head of a team overseeing water and electricity supply for the companies in the park, said that water levels of major suppliers to the park, namely the Paoshan and Yunghoshan reservoirs, are holding steady. Paoshan is nearly 90 percent full.
"There will be enough water to supply the 125,000-ton daily consumption of the park up to the end of October," he said.
Hsu said that the team has asked companies in the park to report their amount of daily water consumption, as well as to implement conservation measures to make good use of every drop.
In addition, the second crop rotation for farmers will finish at the end of August, and some of the water earmarked for them will be transferred back to the park.

The current drought in northern Taiwan will have no bearing on the park for the time being, Hsu said, but if there is still no rain by the end of September, then the team will begin to map out plans to deal with the situation.

On whether it would be possible to transport water from southern Taiwan, Hsu said that one water transport vehicle can only carry 30 tons. Judging from the fact that there are 20 eight-inch and 12-inch wafer plants in the park, that would mean that 3,000 tons of water would have to be sent daily. This would not be economically feasible, he said.

He noted that water shortages have yet to be a problem in the park, but with the economic rebound and companies in the park expanding their production capacities, water could be a problem someday. He urged the government to address the issue by exploring for new water sources for the park.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T DEDICATED TO TAKING CARE OF UNDERPRIVILEGED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Monday that his government is dedicated to improving the nation's economy and taking care of the underprivileged.
Premier Yu made the remarks while touring Chilan Mountain in eastern Taiwan and listening to the progress on a proposed Makao National Park.

Responding to criticisms by the "pan-purple alliance, " which was formed over the weekend by several groups helping the underprivileged, Yu said that the government is willing to accept any suggestion on improving the governance of the country.

Yu said that since he assumed the premiership in February 2002, the Cabinet has been dedicated to problem-solving, and that there has been much success, adding that this is the "harvest season" for his Cabinet.

He noted that the administration led by President Chen Shui-bian is the "common people's government of the new generation." Yu said that he and President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu have all come from common families, and that his government is especially concerned about the lives of the common people.
The premier stressed that "common people, Taiwanization, democracy and justice" have been the core values of his government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUBERCULOSIS MOST SERIOUS COMMUNICABLE DISEASE IN TAIWAN: CDC

TEXT.P: The incidence of tuberculosis is declining in Taiwan, but it is the island's most serious communicable disease partly because of local people's ignorance of the malady, an official with the Department of Health (DOH) said Monday.

According to tallies released by the DOH's Center for Disease Control (CDC) , a total of 1,277 local residents died from tuberculosis last year, making the disease the island's 12th-largest cause of death for the year.
In four administrative districts -- Taitung County, Keelung City, Kaohsiung City and Changhua County, tuberculosis ranked among the top 10 killers for their residents last year.
CDC statistics also showed that the death rates for tuberculosis patients were the highest in Taitung County, Hualien County, Pingtung County and Changhua County, in descending order.
Shih Wen-yi, the CDC's deputy director, said both death and incidence rates of tuberculosis have fallen steadily in Taiwan in the past few decades.

But he acknowledged that the rate of infection of the disease might increase due to local people's ignorance of the disease and patients' failure to complete six months of medication required to beat the disease. Those who stop medication prematurely pose a threat to tuberculosis prevention and control as they could develop a resistance to tuberculosis-fighting drugs and spread the disease, Shih said.

Commenting on a media report that the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) between March and June this year might worsen the island's tuberculosis situation as many patients dared not visit hospitals during the period, Shih said the report was speculative.

Shih stressed that the CDC has stepped up efforts to fight against tuberculosis. "There has not been any delay in our tuberculosis-fighting programs," he said, adding that the installment of many negative pressure isolation wards at local hospitals during the SARS period can now be used to accommodate tuberculosis patients.
According to CDC tallies, Taiwan's tuberculosis incidence rate was 10 times higher than that in the United States in 2001 and double that recorded in Japan in the same year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIES WITH LIBERIA REMAIN INTACT: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Although Liberia's President Charles Taylor has been forced to step down and will be replaced by his vice president, Moses Blah, the Republic of China's diplomatic ties with the African state remained intact, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Monday.

Kao An, deputy director for Information and Cultural Affairs Department under the ministry, said that as a long-time ally of Liberia, the ROC will not interfere with it's domestic affairs and hope order and peace will be restored there soon.

ROC ambassador to Liberia Chen Yeong-cho and two staff members are now in Ivory Coast waiting for Taipei's instructions. They will return to Monrovia as soon as fighting subsides there. The diplomatic channel between the two countries remains open, Kao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE TO RESPECTS CONTROL YUAN DECISION: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office will respect whatever decision the Control Yuan may reach about a flight control mishap at the dual use military-commercial Tainan Airport in southern Taiwan in March this year, a spokesman said Monday.

James Huang, director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department, was responding to a media report that the nation's supreme watchdog body will hold a meeting Tuesday to decide whether to impeach Huang Chai-tien, the incumbent deputy head of the Presidential Office security force, over the Tainan Airport mishap.
Huang Chai-tien was the leader of the Air Force's Tainan-based 443 Wing when the incident took place. The Tainan Airport is under the jurisdiction of the 443 Wing.

In March, a TransAsia passenger plane clipped an airport engineering vehicle after landing at the Tainan Airport. Although the impact didn't cause serious damage nor casualties, it exposed flaws in airport safety controls.

The Control Yuan, which overseas government operations, formed an investigative team to investigate the incident earlier this year. According to the media report, all the team's six members have reached a consensus on impeaching Huang Chai-tien for the flawed airport safety control.

Huang Chai-tien was promoted to his current post May 1. James Huang said President Chen Shui-bian didn't give any instruction after learning of the media report. He added that the Presidential Office respects the Control Yuan and would not make any comment on the case since it is now subject to Control Yuan investigation.
James Huang said the Presidential Office and Huang Chai-tien will respect whatever decision the Control Yuan may make regarding the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESERVOIRS TAKE IN LITTLE OR NO WATER DESPITE RAINFALL IN NORTH

TEXT.P: Much-expected precipitation which fell Monday afternoon in northern Taiwan did not bring relief to the parched region since the rain did not add to local reservoirs, a spokesman for the Water Resources Agency (WRA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said.

As a result, a national task force under the economics ministry formed in March to address the drought issue will meet Thursday to decide whether to mandate stiffer measures in the greater Taipei and Keelung areas.
The heavy rain Monday afternoon did not fall on the catchments of the region's major reservoirs and contribute little or nothing to their water levels.

If significant rain does not fall in the coming days, third-phase restrictions -- water rationing according to districts -- may be imposed in the Keelung area by Aug. 20, while second-phase measures may be put in place for the greater Taipei area by the end of this month. The Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park will be spared from this wave of water conservation efforts.

Although it rained heavily Monday in the greater Taipei area -- 102.5 millimeters in Gunguan in downtown Taipei and 92 millimeters in Hsintien in Taipei County -- the Feitsui Reservoir in Taipei County took in only four millimeters, while the Shihmen Dam in Taoyuan County received a mere 6.6 millimeters. The Hsinshan Reservoir in Keelung was completely missed by the showers.

Residents in the greater Taipei, Taoyuan and Hsinchu areas have been bracing for the first of a four-phase set of water conservation measures since March 6 -- a reduction in water pressure during off-peak hours. Keelung residents began the second-phase of measures last Friday -- a 20-percent reduction in water supply to large-volume users such as car washes, swimming pools and saunas.

Northern Taiwan was plagued by an acute drought in the first half of last year-- the worst in the island's history. However, the dry spell continues to threaten the northern regions this year, with Keelung, a port city traditionally famous for its rainy weather, going through 51 rainless days as of this afternoon.
As the situation at major local reservoirs has not improved, WRA officials urged the public to do their part to prevent a water shortage by cooperating to conserve water.

As of 10: 00 a. m. Monday, the water level of the Feitsui Reservoir stood at 138.72 meters, close to the extreme warning level of 117.5 meters. The Shihmen Dam's level was 215.88 meters, less than six meters from its dangerously low level of 210 meters.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN GETS SUSPENDED JAIL TERM FOR SPITTING IN MAYOR'S FACE

TEXT.P: A man who spit in the face of Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou got a suspended jail term of three months.
The three-month jail term handed down by the Taipei District Court to Tung Hsiu-yung, is to be suspended for three years. It can be converted into a fine of NT$300 per day.
Tung, a radical opponent of Ma's Kuomintang, spit in Ma's face in a public gathering in Taipei City on Feb. 28. The incident was caught on live television.
Although Ma said he didn't want to pursue the incident, Tung was booked by police on the spot. He was later charged by a prosecutor on the grounds of insulting a public official.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN MAN UNDERGOES SUCCESSFUL SPINE CORRECTION SURGERY

TEXT.P: A 24-year-old Indonesian man who suffered from a severe spinal deformity is able to walk erect again thanks to a successful operation last month at a military hospital in Taichung, central Taiwan.

Dr. Chang Kao-wha, director of the International Spine Center at Armed Forces Taichung General Hospital, performed the surgery on the Indonesian man, born of a Indonesian father and a Taiwanese mother.
Before the surgery, the young man was seriously deformed and stood 140 cm tall, but after the surgery he was nearly restored to his previous height of 180 cm, hospital sources said.
The sources said that the surgery set two world records: the implant of 26 of the longest (6.5 cm) and widest (0.7 cm) pins and the greatest improvement in height -- a 38-cm enhancement.

The patient, from Surabaya, Indonesia, was 180 cm tall before he got sick and diagnosed six years ago with ankylosing spondylitis (AS) , which is a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by pain and progressive stiffness. He became more and more hunchbacked until he stood only 140 cm and could barely walk.
The patient first went to Singapore to have hip joint surgery, spending a lot of money without seeing any improvement. He also went to Beijing and Sichuan for treatment, but all to no avail.
The patient then learned about the excellent spine correction techniques at Armed Forces Taichung General Hospital and came to Taiwan July 7.

He was operated on for six hours July 11. He was able to leave his bed and walk three days later. He returned to Indonesia Aug. 5 after making a full recovery. The medical bill came to less than NT$500,000 (US$14,483).

Dr. Chang said that AS is a hereditary disease and Chinese are more prone to the disease than other peoples. Generally speaking, the rate is about 0.1 percent for Chinese, and men are more likely to suffer from AS than women.

As patients usually can't prevent or treat the disease by drinking milk and food, and the only way to ease the pain is to do a lot of stretching exercises very often to slow the bone deterioration, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPERATIONS AT KAOHSIUNG OFF-SHORE TRANSSHIPMENT HUB ON THE RISE

TEXT.P: Operations of the cross-Taiwan Strait off-shore transshipment center at the Kaohsiung Port in southern Taiwan are gradually improving as a result of growing indirect trade between Taiwan and mainland China, a spokesman for the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau said Monday.

The cross-strait off-shore transshipment center, set up by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications at the port to fuel two-way exchanges in the lack of direct trade and transportation links, has dealt with a total of 2.64 million containers since its operations in April 1997, the spokesman said, adding that it handled over 362,000 containers in the first seven months of this year, up by 12.5 percentage points from the year-earlier level.

Kaohsiung, Taiwan's largest port, was allowed to conduct the 20 weekly freight runs in connection with the Xiamen and Fuzhou ports in mainland China's Fujian province to transship products from the mainland to a third country or area.

Four Taiwan-based shipping companies, including Evergreen Marine Corp. (Taiwan) Ltd. and Yangming Marine Transport Corp., are authorized to exchange services with various mainland-based counterparts. Taiwan's shipping sector has repeatedly suggested the mainland authorities to make Guangzhou, Dalian and Shanghai available for the service.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PROMOTE FRUITS, VEGETABLES IN SOUTHEAST ASIA

TEXT.P: The government is going to organize a delegation to Southeast Asia to promote fruits and vegetables from southern Taiwan, the Executive Yuan decided in a meeting Monday.
Cho Chun-ying, executive director of the Executive Yuan's service center in southern Taiwan, presided over the meeting in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

Nearly 30 participants, which included representatives from the Economic Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and fishermen's and farmers' associations in southern Taiwan, planned the content of the Taiwan fruit and vegetable fairs in Malaysia and Indonesia.

They are planning to introduce various species of mangoes, processed milkfish products of Tainan County, guavas and fishery products from Kaohsiung County, high quality pineapples and wax apples from Pingtung County.

The delegation is scheduled to visit Kuala Lumpur and Sabah in Malaysia and Medan in Indonesia Sept. 2-8, taking advantage of an EPZA's plan to set up a Taiwan industry and commerce distribution center in Kuala Lumpur early next month.

Cho said that she believed that the trip will bring substantial benefits to southern Taiwan, open an export market for farmers in southern Taiwan and help ease the overproduction of fruits and vegetables in bumper years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WON'T INTERFERE WITH CAL'S PURCHASE OF AIRCRAFT ENGINES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian won't interfere with China Airlines' (CAL) purchase of engines for its new airplanes, a Presidential Office spokesman said Monday.
Huang Chih-fang, director of the Public Affairs Department at the Presidential Office, said CAL can decide what engines will best serve its interests.
He made the comment after British representative to Taipei Derek Marsh and European Union's representative to Taipei Brian McDonald jointly called on Chen's chief of staff, Chiou I-jen.

Chiou refused to impart what transpired in his talks with the two European officials, but a local newspaper, the China Times, said Monday that Marsh and McDonald wanted to see Chiou to expressed their concerns that British jet engine builder Rolls Royce was being unfairly shut out of the deal.

The China Times said CAL preferred to purchase Rolls Royce's engines for its 12 Airbus A330-300s but was told by authorities to order the engines from U.S. manufacturers General Electric or Pratt and Whitney because of the country's close political ties with Washington.

In a related development Monday in Geneva, Switzerland, EU ambassador to World Trade Organization (WTO) Carlo Trojan met his Taiwan counterpart Yen Ching-chang, urging his government not to meddle with CAL's decision in choosing airplane engines.
Without mentioning the name of Rolls Royce, Trojan appealed to Taiwan to abide by WTO rules and give political factors no consideration while making commercial decisions.
Trojan told Yen EU trade officials in Taipei will raise the issue with Taiwan officials too.
In Taipei, a spokesman for CAL dismissed all news reports about the purchase as groundless speculations, adding that talks about the deal were still going on.
As the country's largest carrier, CAL is controlled by the government, which names its chairman and has a final say in its major business decisions.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO PROMOTE EXPORTS OF AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: Economic advisors to President Chen Shui-bian proposed Monday that the government should take measures to promote exports of Taiwan's agricultural products, according to officials of the Presidential Office.

The officials said after a meeting between Chen and members of his economic advisory panel that the advisors suggested the government establish an organization similar to the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) to promote exports of the country's agricultural products.

They also suggested the government provide credit guarantees for agricultural products export loans based on export orders and that credit guarantees be operated by a proposed national agricultural bank.

It is a pressing need for Taiwan's agricultural development to establish an effective marketing and distribution network to solve the enduring problem of the imbalance between supply and demand facing the agricultural sector, the officials quoted the advisors as saying.
In addition, they said, the modernization of Taiwan's agriculture should be commercialized, globalized and knowledge-based.

On commercialization, the advisors proposed that the government help farmers transform their conventional farming ways and means into modernized business operations and help them acquire farm lands while simplifying the application for establishing agricultural production facilities.

On globalization, they proposed the establishment of an export-oriented agricultural production system in which large-scale agricultural enterprises will be the core of marketing and distribution of agricultural products.

On knowledge acquisition, the advisors recommended the government help farmers conduct research and development into new agricultural products and to post the latest information on new species and on related markets on the government's Web site, facilitating farmers to get new technologies and information they need.

The presidential economic advisory panel is headed by Vincent Siew, a former premier and an incumbent vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, who concurrently serves as chairman of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CHIER).
Other members of the advisory panel are Taiwan Thinktank Chairman Chen Po-chih, CHIER President Chen Tien-chih and Wu Rong-i, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research.

DOC.HEADLINE: GHOST FESTIVAL TURNED INTO TAIWAN'S CULTURAL ACTIVITY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The Ghost Festival, which falls on Aug. 12 this year, has developed from a day devoted to pleasing the spirits into a cultural activity unique to Taiwan and observed by all ethnic groups, President Chen Shui-bian said in Keelung, northern Taiwan Monday.
Presiding over a Ghost Festival celebration in the port city, Chen said he wished good luck to all people on the island and for the whole country.
Ghost Festival falls on the 15th day of seventh month on the lunar calendar and is observed by local people to please homeless spirits.

DOC.HEADLINE: USA, CUBA REMAIN UNDEFEATED IN WORLD YOUTH BASEBALL CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: The United States defeated the Czech Republic 19 to 1, and Cuba beat Indonesia, 38 to zero, in the fourth day of the XI "AA" World Youth Baseball Championship being held in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan Monday.
Both the United States and Cuba scored three wins out of three games in the Championship thus far and took the leading positions in their respective groups.
In another match Monday, Japan overpowered South Africa, 12 to 2. Japan now had won two out of four games in the Championship. The standings as of Monday are as follows:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 12, or the 15th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1099: The Crusaders defeat the Egyptians at Ascalon on the Palestine coast in the First Crusade.
1813: Austria declares war against Napoleon.
1848: George Stephenson, the British railway pioneer who built the first passenger railway in 1825, dies at the age of 67. He also developed the first practical steam locomotive, the "Rocket."
1877: A group of people witness a public demonstration of a new device, a phonograph that records the human voice, at Thomas Edison's "invention factory" at Menlo Park, New Jersey.
1881: Cecil B. De Mille, the American film director, is born. He is legendary for his large-scale Biblical and historical epics such as "The Ten Commandments," "Samson and Delilah" and "Cleopatra."
1898: The United States and Spain sign a protocol ending the Spanish-American War, with Spain relinquishing Cuba and ceding Puerto Rico to the United States. In addition, the Hawaiian Islands are formally annexed by the United States.
1908: The Ford Motor Co. introduces its Model T car, a sturdy, black, four-cylinder number that comes in two versions: tourer and roadster. Both retail at incredibly low prices: the roadster at US$825 and the tourer for just US$25 more.
1912: William Booth, a Methodist minister who founded the Salvation Army in London in 1865, dies of illness in London at the age of 83. The Salvation Army works to foster a love of God and to provide for the needy. It offers its services to people of any race, creed, sex or age.
1914: Britain declares war on Austria-Hungary.
1946: The stolen body of dictator Benito Mussolini is found in northern Italy.
1948: The United States recognizes South Korea.
1954: The last batch of United Nations forces in the Korean War pulls out of Korea.
1961: Chen Chia-keng, an overseas Chinese from Singapore and founder of Amoy University, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 88.
1970: The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and West Germany sign a non-aggression pact in Moscow.
1970: A China Airlines (CAL) passenger plane of the Republic of China crashes into a mountain on its way from Hualien in eastern Taiwan to Taipei, killing or injuring 31 people.
1978: Taiwan's fastest electrified train, the Tzu Chiang Express, makes a test run between Taipei and Taichung.
1978: Mainland China and Japan sign a treaty of peace and friendship in Beijing.
1985: A Japan Airlines Boeing 747 Jumbo jet crashes into Mount Osutaka on its way from Tokyo to Osaka, killing all but four of the 524 people aboard.
1990: Beijing's attempt to restore its tarnished image after the slaughter in Tiananmen Square receives a severe setback. Official documentation of the disturbances now reveals that more than 450 were killed, the majority by bullets, while 750 were injured and 3,000 were detained.
1991: Two mainland journalists arrive in Taipei, marking the first-ever visit to the ROC by the mainland Chinese press.
1995: The United States government decides to stop all nuclear testing.
1996: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan departs for the Dominican Republic to attend the Aug. 16 inauguration of President Leonel Fernandez.
1999: CAL signs an agreement with Airbus Industrie of Europe for a US$1.8 billion order for seven A340-300 passenger jets, with an option for one more A340-300 and four A330-300s.
2000: Yeh Chu-lan, ROC minister of transportation and communications, accepts the resignation of Chunghwa Telecom Co. Chairman Steven Chen and names MOTC Vice Minister Mao Chi-kuo to fill the chairmanship of the state-owned firm.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh urges mainland China to produce a president through popular elections so as to bridge the gap between the political systems and public opinion on either side of the Taiwan Strait.
2001: The Taiwan Solidarity Union, a political party formed by some of former President Lee Teng-hui's followers is formally inaugurated, with a written congratulatory message from President Chen Shui-bian read out at the ceremony.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way for a man to be true to himself. If he does not know what is good, a man cannot be true to himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LABORERS WON'T BENEFIT FROM HIGHER TAXES ON RICH: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Higher taxes on the rich will only lead to capital flight and will not benefit Taiwan laborers, a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday.

Lin Cho-hsui made the remarks in the wake of a suggestion by the Alliance of Fairness and Justice that the government reimpose a "capital gains" tax on the rich so as to balance the tax burden between entrepreneurs and average workers.

The "pan purple alliance," a new association grouping nine social welfare organizations in Taiwan which was formed Sunday, aims to speak for the underprivileged, including those who are becoming disadvantaged because of social injustice.

Due to globalization, Lin said, enterprises have the ability to shift to anywhere in the world to obtain the best profits. If Taiwan imposes higher taxes on the rich, they will flock to other countries, he claimed.
Noting that globalization is widening the gap between rich and poor around the world, Lin said that any country that tries to tackle this problem single-handedly will face difficulties.
"The alliance aims to help Taiwan's laborers, but it could end up making the lives of laborers more miserable," he said.
Meanwhile, Premier Yu Shyi-kun, commenting on the suggestion for hgiher taxes the previous day, also said that it is not "feasible."

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU SLAMS 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' FOR BLOCKING 'LOYALTY CHECK' BILL

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) legislative caucus slammed the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) Tuesday for stonewalling the passage of a "national loyalty check" bill.

Worse still, the TSU caucus said the two major opposition parties pushed for amending the existing civil servant employment law in 2002 to delete the provision requiring loyalty checks for all government employees.
The TSU caucus claimed that the "pan-blue alliance's" moves have created holes in the nation's security system and left room for mainland Chinese agents to infiltrate Taiwan.

The TSU caucus was responding to its KMT and PFP counterparts' recent criticism of National Security Council (NSC) Secretary-General Kang Ning-hsiang for employing a person with alleged business interests in mainland China to serve as his personal aide.

The "pan-blue alliance" said Kang's employment of Chang Pei-chen to provide counseling in mainland economic affairs could lead to the leaking of Taiwan's classified information to mainland authorities.

Chang, who had devoted herself to research on the mainland economy for 20 years at the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research before she joined the NSC this April 1, resigned from her NSC post last Saturday.

Her resignation came after a local newspaper reported that her husband had used her name to set up a company in Hong Kong which cooperated with the business arm of mainland China's Ministry of Railways in operating land development deals in Shanghai.

TSU legislative whip Chien-Lin Huei-jyun said at a news conference Tuesday that Chang's case as well as the alleged involvement of a middle-rank technician at the military-run Chungshan Institute of Technology and Science in a ring that spied for mainland China have exposed problems in the nation's security system.
Chien-Lin said the "pan-blue alliance" which controls more than half of the seats in the legislature is to blame for the loose security checks conducted on the nation's civil servants.

She pointed out that the TSU came up with a basket of draft bills in May 2002 with a view to tightening protection of military intelligence and other national secrets. The package included a national loyalty bill, an intelligence agency neutrality and supervisory bill, and a national intelligence supervision bill.

However, Chien-Lin said, the KMT and the PFP had boycotted screening of these bills. For instance, she said, the two parties had 17 times stonewalled the transfer of the TSU-drafted national loyalty bill to the legislature's Legal Affairs Committee for deliberation.
Without the enactment of this bill, Chien-Lin said, government agencies cannot conduct stringent loyalty checks on would-be civil servants.
"It's hypocritical of KMT and PFP lawmakers to criticize the NSC for its failure to conduct loyalty checks on Chang Pei-chen, " Chien-Lin claimed.
She urged the two main opposition parties to support the passage of the TSU-drafted national loyalty bill in the new legislative session set to open in September.

In response, KMT legislative whip Lee Chia-chin said his party support loyalty checks on officials involved in national security affairs. "However, we are opposed to loyalty checks on other civil servants. This stance remains unchanged," Lee said, adding that security officials must be subject to stringent loyalty checks.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOLEN CAR DETECTION SYSTEM TO BE INSTALLED ON ROADS NEXT MONTH

TEXT.P: A new system that detects stolen vehicles on roads will be installed around the island next month to help stem the serious problem of car theft.
Taipei County Police on Tuesday unveiled the "electronic police" system which will sound an alarm signal whenever the license plate of a stolen car being driven on the road is spotted.

Chen Ying-chieh, an information official of Taipei County Police, said that the system can detect cars driving at speeds of up to 200 km per hour, adding that the system's accuracy rate is up to 95 percent.

Chen said that the system, which will be installed at road intersections, will be able to detect within 0.6 seconds the license plates of cars that are listed in the stolen car data bank of the National Police Administration.
Police officer Chang Chia-ming said that the system will operate in tandem with traffic lights.

He explained that the license plates of cars passing along the road will be shown on monitors at police stations. Whenever a plate that is listed in the stolen car data bank is spotted, an alarm signal will sound, and the car type, color and license plate number will be displayed. Traffic lights in the vicinity will then immediately turn red, giving police time to race to the location and intercept the car and driver.

While reviewing the new system, Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien said that the problem of car theft and the ensuing extortion of the original car owners has caused much resentment among ordinary citizens. He expressed the hope that the new system will help in the crackdown on car thieves.
Car and motorcycle theft has become a nightmare for vehicle owners in Taiwan, with statistics showing that 50,000 cars and more than 200,000 motorcycles were reported stolen in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WELL PREPARED FOR SUMMIT MEETING NEXT WEEK: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that the Republic of China has prepared well for the visit of the heads of state of the ROC's Latin American diplomatic allies for the summit meeting in Taipei next week.
The president made the remarks when he met with Carlos Larios Ochaita, president of the Judicial System and the Supreme Court of Justice of the Republic of Guatemala.

President Chen noted that Larios, who had served as a lawyer, a professor and a grand justice before his present job, has rich experience in politics. Chen expressed the hope that his first visit to the ROC will help promote bilateral cooperation in judicial matters between the two countries.

As the ROC's first president who studied law, Chen said, he shares a similar background with his visitor. He added that when Guatemalan president-elect Portillo Cabrera Alfonso Antonio was inaugurated in January 2000, it was Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng who represented him to attend the inauguration ceremony.

Chen noted that Weng happened to be his mentor when he was studying law at National Taiwan University, adding that Weng also witnessed his swearing-in ceremony when he was inaugurated as ROC president in May 20, 2000.

President Chen also expressed his appreciation for Guatemala's steadfast support for the ROC over the years, especially for the ROC's bid to join the United Nations and other international organizations.

The fourth meeting of the heads of states and governments of the Republic of China, Central America and the Dominican Republic will take place Aug. 21, with the heads of state of Panama, Belize, Honduras, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Guatemala, the Dominican Republic, and the host ROC taking part.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA RULES OUT INTERFERENCE WITH CAL'S PURCHASE OF AIRCRAFT ENGINES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs won't interfere with China Airlines' (CAL's) purchase of engines for its new aircraft, a senior official said Tuesday.

MOFA spokesman Richard Shih said the ministry has conveyed the concerns and opinions expressed by the British and American representative offices in Taipei about CAL's aircraft engine procurement plans to relevant Taiwan government agencies.
Nevertheless, Shih said, the MOFA has not meddled in CAL's decision-making process.
"We respect CAL's decision based on commercial and professional evaluations, " Shih said, adding that the MOFA hasn't had any role in CAL's decision-making process.
Since CAL's aircraft engine procurement plan was unveiled, Shih said, the British and U.S. representative offices have on many occasions expressed their concerns about the plan.
"They have expressed their hopes that their companies would be given equal opportunities in a fair and just competition for CAL's order, " Shih said.

Shih made the remarks a day after British representative to Taipei Derek Marsh and E.U. representative to Taipei Brian McDonald jointly called on President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff, Chiou I-jen, to express concerns that British jet engine builder Rolls Royce was being unfairly shut out of CAL's aircraft engine deal.
Chiou refused to talk about what transpired in his talks with the two European officials.
Presidential Office spokesman James Huang said last evening that the Presidential Office won't interfere with the deal. "CAL can decide what engines will best serve its interests," he added.

According to media reports, CAL originally planned to purchase Rolls Royce's engines for its 12 Airbus A330-300s but later decided to order engines from U.S. manufacturers General Electric or Pratt and Whitney because it would have to pay an additional US$20 million in aircraft airworthiness certification fees should it use Rolls Royce engines.

Media reports said Airbus informed CAL last week that it will have to pay the engine certification fee if it wants to use Rolls Royce's TREND768 engine. Currently, only Indonesia's national airlines uses this type of engine. If CAL decides to use the TREND768 engine, it will have to obtain U.S. and E.U. certification, and it will have to foot the certification bills, Airbus reportedly told CAL.
CAL debunked all media reports about its engine deal as groundless speculation. "The deal is still under discussion, and no final decision has been reached yet," a spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices rose on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 40.64 points to close at 5,255.24.
The bourse opened at 5,250.45 and then fluctuated between 5,272.96 and 5,245.09 during trading.

A total of 3.14 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$72.96 billion (US$2.12 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 2.72 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$66.01 billion (US$1.92 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with cement issues moving up the most at 1.4 percent, followed by construction shares at 1.1 percent, electrical stocks at 1.0 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.9 percent, financial issues at 0.5 percent, and foodstuff issues and textile stocks, both at 0.1 percent. Paper stocks remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 427 to 194, with 144 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T NOT DOING ENOUGH FOR SOUTHERN TAIWAN: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that the current administration has indeed attached greater importance than the previous administration to the balanced development of northern and southern Taiwan, but added that it still falls short of the people's expectations.

Hsieh made the remarks in the wake of media reports that Tainan City Mayor Hsu Tien-tsai blasted the central government for only "paying lip service" to narrowing the gap between northern and southern Taiwan.

Hsieh said that compared with the previous administration, President Chen Shui-bian's administration has indeed paid more attention to southern Taiwan, but it "still falls short of the expectations of the people in southern Taiwan, " adding that "it is also true that we have higher expectations."

He noted that the central government has talked about a balanced development of southern and northern Taiwan, but the problem is that the southern and eastern parts of Taiwan have been ignored for so long that even if equal treatment is given to all parts of Taiwan, it still is not fair to some areas.

Citing the allocation of government revenues as an example, Hsieh said that Taipei received NT$1.3 billion (US$37.68 million) this year, while Kaohsiung received NT$900 million. He said that although this may seem fair on the surface, his city is about to start construction on a mass rapid transit system and a tap water improvement project, while other major projects such as shifting part of the railway system underground and several performing arts center projects are planned.
Noting that all these projects will require large amounts of money, Hsieh said that "overall, the amount of the government allocation to Kaohsiung is still not fair."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DECLINES ON TAIPEI FOREX

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TAIEX Index futures for September surged 13 points to finish at 5,260, with 562 contract transactions, while December futures gained 45 points to close at 5,250, with one contract traded.
