DOC.HEADLINE: 2003 INT'L CHILDREN'S FILM FESTIVAL TO KICK OFF IN ILAN AUG. 22

TEXT.P: The 2003 International Children's Film Festival is set to kick off Aug. 22 in the northeastern county of Ilan, featuring movies and cartoon films from Taiwan, Japan, Korea, Iran, the Czech Republic, Denmark, the United States and France, organizers said Tuesday.

The film festival, being co-sponsored by the Ilan County Government and the Chinese Taipei Film Archive (CTFA) , will open with a screening of "Badu's Homework," a film directed by Cheng Wen-tang of Taiwan.

"Badu's Homework", chosen as the best picture at the 2003 Taipei Film Festival held March 9-22, is a fairy-tale story told through the eyes of aboriginal children. The theme is of an aboriginal culture gradually eroded by modern life.

The sponsors of the festival, which is the first children's film festival to be held in Taiwan, also plan to establish a seed teacher training program and a creative writing program in Ilan, CTFA officials said. (by Nocturne Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE ELECTRONICS STOCKS EXPECTED TO BE ADDED TO MSCI TAIWAN INDEX

TEXT.P: Taiwan securities houses are expecting that more electronics issue will be included in the Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) Taiwan index since Morgan Stanley is making an evaluation of the current Limited Investability Factor (LIF) applied to the MSCI Taiwan Index constituents

The MSCI announced in late July that it was making a formal review regarding the relaxation of restrictions on foreign portfolio investors in Taiwan and its effects. The review may lead to a higher LIF for the MSCI Taiwan Index constituents, according to the announcement.

The MSCI has applied the LIF in Taiwan as an instrument to reflect market restrictions and obstacles to foreign investment. Currently, the MSCI applies to LIF of 0.55 to the free float-adjusted market capitalization of all constituents in the MSCI Taiwan Index.

While the MSCI is scheduled to announce changes to the MSCI Standard and Small Cap Index Series, the MSCI Global Value and Growth Index Series on Wednesday, analysts of the Jih Sun Securities Co. said that four electronics stocks -- Chunghwa Telecom, Nanker, Sunplus and EZfone -- are likely to be selected as additional constituents to the MSCI Taiwan Index.
Out of the 91 issues included in the MSCI Taiwan Index, 38 are electronics stocks.
The analysts said that the MSCI weightings adjustment would stimulate foreign investors' interest and induce a capital flow into Taiwan's stock market.

They pointed out that at the end of 1997 when South Korea announced its intention to allow foreign investors having higher percentage of company shares, from 50 percent to 55 percent, MSCI announced on Feb. 5, 1998 to elevate the weightings of the South Korea Index constituents and the market capitalization factor (MCF) applied to the free float-adjusted market capitalization of the constituents were elevated from 0.5 to 1.
The South Korea stock market enjoyed a brisk season during the period between the government announcement of relaxing market regulations and the MSCI weightings adjustment, according to the analysts.

Judging from the comparable development of Taiwan's stock market and that of South Korea's, the analysts foresee an investment zest in the issues of the Taiwan Stock Exchange, especially the weighted stocks in the MSCI Taiwan Index and the newly added constituents.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA VISIT AIMED AT CEMENTING BILATERAL TIES: ROC VICE PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Tsai Su-jung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Vice President Annette Lu arrived in Panama City Monday for a three-day official visit aimed at cementing relations between the Republic of China and Panama.

Accompanied by a 43-member entourage, Lu flew into the Panamanian capital from Los Angeles to a warm welcome from senior Panamanian officials, ROC Embassy staff and executives of major Taiwan trade associations in Panama.
Lu said aboard a chartered plane taking her from Los Angeles to Panama City that she hopes her visit to Panama can help consolidate bilateral diplomatic relations.

With the number of mainland Chinese immigrants to Panama increasing rapidly in recent years, Lu said the Chinese community population structure has undergone significant changes. At the moment, Panama has about 80,000 mainland Chinese immigrants and 50,000 ethnic Chinese while the number of new immigrants from Taiwan is only about 300.

Against this backdrop, Lu said, Taiwan must step up efforts to boost exchanges and cooperation with Panama. President Chen Shui-bian originally planned to make a state visit to Panama in June, but his travel plans will be postponed to later this year as Taiwan was gripped by severe acute respiratory syndrome between March and June.
With a view to enhancing bilateral ties, Lu said President Chen asked her to make a brief visit to Panama on her way to Paraguay to attend its new president's inaugural ceremony on Chen's behalf.

Lu will meet with Panamanian Vice President Dominador Kaiser Bazan Jimenez Tuesday for wide-ranging talks. Bazan will honor Lu by awarding her a medal. Lu will also meet with Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso and attend a ceremony marking the completion of a Taiwan-financed facelift of the building that houses Panama's Ministry of the Interior.
Before coming to Panama, Lu made transit stops in Hawaii and Los Angeles where she met with American lawmakers and state and city officials to discuss a range of topics.

After the Panama visit, Lu will fly to Asuncion to attend the Paraguayan presidential inauguration Aug. 15. While there, Lu will deliver speeches at the Paraguayan parliament and at Asuncion University.
On her way back to Taiwan Aug. 20, Lu is scheduled to make a transit stop in Seattle for two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD AIDS TAIWAN BOAT CAPTAIN THREATENED BY MAINLANDER CREW

TEXT.P: A Coast Guard vessel came to the assistance of a Taiwan fishing ship Tuesday which asked for help after claiming it was threatened by the mainland Chinese crew on board.

The Tungkang-registered fishing ship, "Chinhaifu No. 12, " sailed out from Tungkang, Pingtung, for the Pacific Ocean for operations June 19. The captain of the ship is from Taiwan; there were two Indonesians and five mainland Chinese fishermen aboard.

Captain Huang Teh-chuan urgently called a fishery broadcast station in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan Monday, saying that he had been threatened by the mainland Chinese fishermen since sailing out and that the mainland fishermen also tried to control his movements. Huang added that he's now returning to Taiwan for fear of his life.
Huang expressed the hope that Taiwan would send a rescue vessel.
The Coast Guard vessel spotted the "Chinhaifu No. 12" at 5: 40 a.m. and found the captain and the crew safe. The military escorted the ship back to Kaohsiung Harbor for further questioning.
Meanwhile, another fishing ship registered in Pingtung, the " Chang Tsung Cheng, " that had been out of communications for the past 12 days remained missing, a fishery broadcasting station said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL CHILDREN'S FILM FESTIVAL IN ILAN AUG. 22

TEXT.P: The 2003 International Children's Film Festival is set to kick off Aug. 22 in Ilan and will feature movies and animation from Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, Iran, the Czech Republic, Denmark, the United States and France.
The film festival, being co-sponsored by the Ilan County Government and the Chinese Taipei Film Archive (CTFA), will open with a screening of "Badu's Homework," a film directed by Cheng Wen-tang.

"Badu's Homework, " chosen as the best picture at the 2003 Taipei Film Festival, is a fairy-tale story told through the eyes of aboriginal children. The theme is of an aboriginal culture gradually eroded by modern life.

The sponsors of the festival, which is the first children's film festival to be held in Taiwan, also plans to establish a seed teacher training program and a creative writing program in Ilan, CTFA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST HALF BUSINESS REVENUES OF HI-TECH PARK GROW 11 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Business revenues of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan -- the country's Silicon Valley -- hit NT$368.4 billion in the first half of this year, up by 11 percent over the year-earlier level, the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration reported Tuesday.

Despite the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in March through May, operations of the six industries based in the park were not affected in the first six months, administration officials said, adding that the park's business turnover could reach between NT$800 billion and NT$850 billion (US$24.7 billion) for the whole of 2003.

Of the six major hi-tech industries with shops in the complex, the IC sector registered a business revenue of NT$245.4 billion in the first six months, accounting for 66.6 percent of the park's total and representing a 14 percent increase year-on-year. The high contribution rate made the IC industry the leading driver of the park's development.

The optoelectronic industry posted 23.7 percent growth, while the telecommunications and biotechnology increased by 5.4 percent and 8.9 percent, respectively. Computer peripherals and the precision machinery sector also expanded by 2.6 percent and 4.4 percent, respectively.
As of the end of June, the 347 companies headquartered in the park employed a total of 98,794 workers, marking a growth of 7.4 percent and 1.2 percent, respectively.

A total of 34 companies were allowed to open shops in the compound during the January-June period, channeling in NT$12.74 billion worth of investment. Meanwhile, an additional 24 enterprises are waiting for approval of capital increment worth NT$157.33 billion, a 26 percent jump over the level set for the same period of last year, administration officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUCCESSFULLY CLONES DAIRY COW

TEXT.P: Taiwan has successfully cloned a dairy cow, which is now five months old, the Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Tuesday.

COA Chairman Lee Chin-lung said at a news conference held at the COA's Taiwan Livestock Research Institute (TLRI) in Tainan County's Hsinhua township in southern Taiwan that it marks a step forward in Taiwan's cloning technology development.

Taiwan has successfully cloned goats and pigs, but this is the first time the island has succeeded in cloning a dairy cow. In September 2001, the TLRI cloned a calf with birth defects, which survived for only six days.
The newly cloned calf, named Ju-yi, was cloned from ear-derived somatic cells of an adult Dutch dairy cow raised on a ranch in the southern county of Kaohsiung.
Ju-yi was delivered by Caesarian section May 22. At the birth, the cloned cow had a urinary problem. The situation was corrected surgically on the 38th day after her birth.
TLRI researchers said Ju-yi is now more than 140 centimeters tall and weighs 145 kilograms. The clone eats feed and grass.
Lee said cloning from somatic cells marks an important milestone in the development of biotechnology. "It's like a key to a brave new world," he said.

Lee said the technology used in cloning dairy cows could eventually be applied to improving livestock species, creating genetically modified livestock, breeding endangered animal species and even be used in clinical medicine.
The TLRI successfully cloned twin dairy goats -- Paochi and Paohsiang -- last year. The clones have been growing well and celebrated their first birthday last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO LEAD JOURNALISTS ON TOUR AROUND TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will lead the editors in chief of local media on a two-day tour around Taiwan Wednesday to show them the country's economic development, one of his staff said Tuesday.

Huang Chih-fang, director of the Department of Public Affairs at the Presidential Office, said on the tour's first stopover at Kaohsiung City, south Taiwan, the president and his group will visit two state-run corporations which have turned from debt-laden enterprises into profit-making companies, thanks to the reorganization carried out in the last three years.
Huang didn't reveal the names of the two state-run companies.

The president and his entourage will also visit two private companies in central Taiwan-- one from a labor-intensive industry and the other employs hi-tech workers -- which have heeded the president's call by keeping their roots in Taiwan, Huang said.

Without mentioning their names, Huang said the two companies have validated the president's claim that even labor-intensive companies can thrive in Taiwan if they know how to turn their know-how to good account.
The president will also visit the Wuji Station of the high-speed railway, which is still under construction, to give the journalists a glimpse into how the country will be in the future.
The tour will give the public, through the country's media, a clear view of the government's achievements, which are often clouded by partisan politics in the Legislative Yuan, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. LOOKS FORWARD TO SMOOTH ROC 2004 PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION: LU
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Tsai Su-jung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Vice President Annette Lu said Monday the United States looks forward to seeing the top leaders of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait exercise self-restraint to ensure a smooth proceeding of the island's 2004 presidential election.
Lu made the remarks aboard a chartered plane taking her from Los Angeles to Panama for a three-day official visit.

During her transit stops in Hawaii and Los Angeles, Lu said, she had met with a number of American politicians, including Hawaii Governor Linda Lingle, Sen. Daniel Akaka, Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, Rep. Hilda Solis and Los Angeles Deputy Mayor Joy Chen.

Lu said she feels that American authorities are rather concerned about Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum, the Taiwan Strait security situation, Taiwan's arms procurement plans and its presidential election next year.

Lu said the Bush administration is fully aware why President Chen Shui-bian is determined to hold a referendum on certain public issues before or on March 20, 2004 -- the next presidential election day.

Nevertheless, Lu said, the United States hopes that Taiwan can abide by the rule of law. Therefore, Lu urged Taiwan's opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan to pass a referendum bill as early as possible to set detailed terms for holding a referendum and avoiding any possible adverse impact on Taiwan's political stability.

While the United States calls for self-restraint of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in the run-up to Taiwan's next presidential election, Lu said she has taken advantage of her talks with American officials and lawmakers to push the Bush administration to adopt "preventive diplomacy" and not to give Beijing any excuse to take action against Taiwan during the campaign period.

Lu said she had assured U.S. politicians that both President Chen and herself will be prudent in dealing with cross-strait affairs. "Both the president and I have endured hardships in promoting Taiwan's democratization. We are responsible. We treasure Taiwan's hard-won democratic achievements," she stressed.

According to Lu, the United States is very concerned about Taiwan's security and hopes Taiwan can upgrade its defense capabilities. "They said Taiwan should be more pragmatic in arms procurement, with the goal of withstanding a first strike by Beijing," Lu said.
She went on to say Taiwan-U.S. relations have made significant progress in the past few years.

"Since I assumed the vice presidency more than three years ago, this was the third time that I made transit stops in the United States. In the past, I could only stay one day in a U.S. city and the number of ROC expatriates allowed to greet me was restricted to no more than 30. This time, I was able to stay for two to three days in each city and hundreds of overseas Chinese were allowed to meet me. At a dinner party in Los Angeles, our national flag as well as the U.S. national flag flew at the venue and on the dinner tables. All these are signs of improvement in our bilateral relations," Lu said.
Lu added she believes when President Chen makes transit stops in the United States on his overseas travel later this year, he will receive even better treatment.

Before leaving California for Panama City Monday afternoon, Lu visited Irvine, California, which maintains sisterhood ties with Taiwan's Taoyuan County, of which Lu used to be magistrate, as well as Broadcom, a California-based high-tech company.

Three U.S. federal congressmen -- Reps. Christopher Cox, Loretta Sanchez and Marilyn N. Musgrave -- sent representatives to read welcome letters to greet Lu when she arrived at the Irvine City Hall. She later held a lunch meeting with the city's mayor.

While in Panama, Lu will meet with senior Panamanian officials to discuss measures for further boosting bilateral cooperation. Panamanian Vice President Dominador Kaiser Bazan Jimenez will honor Lu by awarding her a medal.

After her three-day visit in Panama, Lu will leave for Asuncion to attend the Paraguayan presidential inauguration Aug. 15. She will also deliver speeches at the Paraguayan parliament and at Asuncion University.
On her way back to Taiwan Aug. 20, Lu is scheduled to make a transit stop in Seattle for two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEIZURE OF CHEMICALS ABOARD N. KOREAN FREIGHTER LEGITIMATE: BOFT

TEXT.P: Taiwan authorities' seizure of a batch of chemicals on board the North Korean freighter "Be Gae Hung" in Kaohsiung Port, southern Taiwan, was legitimate, officials of the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Tuesday.
The chemicals have been identified as phosphorus pentasulfide, which is listed as a strategic high-tech commodity (SHTC) and should be controlled according to the law, the officials explained.

North Korea is listed by Taiwan as an area where SHTCs should be controlled. The consignee of the phosphorus pentasulfide should have applied with the BOFT in advance for transit permission through Taiwan.

Although the chemicals in question are registered as "commodities in transit, " Taiwan authorities decided to seize them because the consignee failed to complete the legal process, the officials added.
The BOFT will discuss with various government agencies as soon as possible to decide how to deal with the detained chemicals, which are stored in a warehouse at Kaohsiung Harbor, they said.
The 6,500-ton "Be Gae Hung, " arrived in Kaohsiung Harbor Thursday from Bangkok, Thailand to unload some 2,000 metric tons of aluminum powder.
The vessel was allowed to leave for North Korea Monday after unloading the 150-plus barrels of phosphorus pentasulfide at Kaohsiung Port.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALA JUDICIAL LEADER AWARDED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President of the Judicial Yuan of the Republic of China Weng Yueh-sheng conferred a medal Tuesday on his Guatemalan counterpart Carlos Larios Ochaita in recognition of his contribution to the promotion of judicial exchanges and cooperation between the two countries.
Speaking at the conferring ceremony, Weng praised Larios for his outstanding performance and achievements in the judicial field and for his efforts in promoting the ROC-Guatemalan relations.
Larios arrived in Taipei Monday for a five-day visit. He will also meet President Chen Shui-bian and other government officials before departing on Aug. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ENJOYS US1.96 BILLION TRADE SURPLUS IN JULY

TEXT.P: Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$1.96 billion in July, a monthly record since August 2002, according to statistics released Tuesday by Taiwan's Central Bank of China.

Taiwan earned US$13.898 billion from its exports and spent US$11.923 billion for imports in July, an increase of 5.8 percent and 9.9 percent respectively on a year-to-year basis, the statistics showed.

During the Jan.-July period, Taiwan's exports amounted to US$89.523 billion and its exports totaled US$80.798 billion, up 11.8 percent and 15.1 percent respectively from those of a year ago, leaving a surplus of US$8.725 billion for the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TOUTS DIPLOMATIC AND ECONOMIC ACHIEVEMENTS

TEXT.P: The upcoming summit in Taipei between the Republic of China and its eight allies in central America will be a significant diplomatic event, President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday.

Presiding over a meeting of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, of which Chen is the chairman, the president said the Fourth Summit of the Heads of States and Governments of the Republic of China, Central America, the Dominican Republic and Belize, to begin in Taipei Aug. 21, is a marvelous diplomatic achievement for Taiwan in view of Beijing's all-out efforts to dissuade other countries from engaging Taiwan.

He thanked the eight countries, including Panama, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador, Guatemala, the Dominican Republic, and Belize for their support for Taiwan in defiance of Beijing's threats or bribery.
On the sidelines of the summit, Chen said he will sign a free trade agreement with Panama President Mireya Moscoso, which will be the first of its kind for Taiwan.
Chen, who has been on three overseas trips to the ROC's allies in central America and Africa since taking power in 2000, said he has done his utmost to cement ties with ROC allies.

Also in the meeting, Chen credited his administration with turning four loss-making state companies, Taiwan Sugar Company, Taiwan Salt Industrial Corporation, Kaohsiung Ammonium Sulfate Corporation Ltd., and Tang Eng Iron Works, Co., into turning a profit.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY CONFIRMS ADVANCE PAID BEFORE PURCHASING MIRAGES

TEXT.P: The ROC Air Force paid 1.2 billion francs (US$206.68 million) to the French builder of Mirage jet fighters in 1992 before any budget for the purchase by Taiwan of 60 Mirage 2000s was passed, major-general Huang Suey-sheng, a spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense, admitted Tuesday.

He confirmed a report of the Control Yuan, Taiwan's supreme government overseer, which concluded that the money was paid to Dassault Aviation before any budget on the deal was approved by the Legislative Yuan - an unusual move.

Huang explained that during talks with Dassault, the aircraft manufacturer requested that the ROC Air Force pay the amount as "good faith" money to prove its seriousness in acquiring the French-made jet fighters.
The ROC Air Force deposited the funds in a French bank as requested by French negotiators in July, 1992, Huang said. He refused to comment whether the transaction was in line with regulations.
The funds were later credited towards the price of the 60 Mirage-2000s when the deal was concluded in November, 1992.
The 60 jet fighters as well as the 1,440 missiles used to arm them cost Taiwan NT$167.6 billion (US$4.88 billion) at the time.
The Control Yuan began examining the deal after allegations in Paris surfaced that kickbacks were involved in the deal.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OFFICIAL DENIES REPORT ON PROMISE OF NO 'ONE SIDE, ONE COUNTRY'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff never told U.S. authorities that Chen would never again describe the current state of cross-Taiwan Strait relations as "one side, one country," a ruling party official said Tuesday.

Legislator Chen Chung-hsin, who concurrently serves as director of the China affairs department of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , was responding to media reports that Chiou I-jen, secretary-general to the president, had assured U.S Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage that President Chen will not ruffle Beijing's feathers again by mentioning the "one side, one country."

Chen Chung-hsin, who accompanied Chiou on his recent trip to Washington, D.C., said Chiou's visit was mainly aimed at exchanging views with American officials on a range of issues of mutual concern, including Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on certain public issues before or on March 20, 2004 -- the next presidential election day.
"Throughout our meetings with relevant U.S. officials, including talks with Armitage, we never touched on the so-called 'one side, one country' topic," said Chen Chung-hsin.

President Chen used the term "one side, one country" to describe the current cross-strait relations for the first time in his speech delivered to the annual meeting of the pro-independence World Federation of Taiwanese Associations in Tokyo last year via satellite. His speech drew broadsides from Beijing.

A Hong Kong-based satellite television channel claimed last week that Armitage said in an interview with its correspondent in Washington July 31 that Taiwan had assured him that President Chen will not mention the "one side, one country" statement again.

According to the transcription of Armitage's interview with the Hong Kong TV channel provided by the American Institute in Taiwan, Chen Chung-hsin said, Armitage had not raised the so-called "one side, one country" issue in the interview.
"The transcription didn't contain anything regarding 'one side, one country,'" Chen Chung-hsin stressed.

Noting that Taiwan's official title is the Republic of China and the other side of the Taiwan Strait calls itself the People's Republic of China, Chen Chung-hsin said President Chen's description of "one side, one country" reflects the stark reality of cross-strait relations.
"As the ROC's head of state, President Chen must defend the ROC's dignity and status," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ENCOURAGES YOUTH TO FACE CHALLENGES WITH COURAGE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun encouraged the youth of Taiwan Tuesday to face challenges with courage and to always pursue their ideals.
Yu made the remarks at a meeting with young citizens organized by the Cabinet-level National Youth Commission in Taipei to mark the International Youth Day.
"A person can only be effective when he has sufficient vision and lofty, yet achievable, ideals," Yu stressed.
He spoke of his personal life as an example and answered questions from the audience.

Raised in a poor tenant farming family in Tungshan, Ilan County, Yu said that he worked very hard during his childhood and was not content to give up his opportunity to get an education even when he was forced to quit junior high school to work full-time as a farmer for five years.
Graduating from the department of politics at Tunghai University at 37, Yu said that he dedicated himself to politics to better serve the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: STIFFER WATER CONSERVATION MEASURES MULLED FOR NORTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Residents in Taipei, Keelung and Taoyuan in northern Taiwan may soon face harsher water conservation measures if significant rain does not fall in the coming days, Water Resources Agency Director Chen Shen-hsien said Tuesday.

Chen said a consensus has been reached among relevant government agencies that the second of a four-phase, anti-drought measures may begin in the greater Taipei area by the end of this month when the water level of the Feitsui Reservoir falls to 131 meters, while the third-stage measure will begin in the Keelung area on Aug. 20, if rainfall does not contribute to catchments before then.

The second-phase restriction is also expected to be imposed in the Taoyuan area when the water level of the Shihmen Reservoir drops to 210 meters, he added, pointing out that it is only less than six meters away from this dangerously low level.

According to the fourth-phase set of measures devised by a national task force set up in early March by the Ministry of Economic Affairs to tackle a possible drought, the first-phase measure sees a reduction in water pressure during off-peak hours, and the second stage will curtail supply for large-volume users such as car washes or swimming pools.
The third phase will see water rationing according to district, while the fourth phase will provide limited amounts of water only during certain hours for the general public and industrial use.

Meanwhile, the water catchment of the Feitsui Reservoir -- the main supplier for the greater Taipei area -- took in 30 millimeters of rainfall Tuesday evening, thanks to torrential afternoon rains the last two days, especially the precipitation which fell Tuesday afternoon in the catchment.

The water level of the Feitsui Reservoir stood at 138 meters as of 8: 00 p.m. and is holding only 31.9 percent of its total capacity, the Taipei Feitsui Reservoir Administration Bureau statistics showed.

Bureau Director Kang Shih-jen said the rainfall contributed to the largest single-day level increase at the reservoir since June 21. It helped bring in around six million tons of water for the reservoir, or about three-day's consumption for the greater Taipei area.

The recent sparse rainfall has been useless toward ending the current dry spell. The only hope left is typhoons, which usually bring plenty of rain to Taiwan in the June-September rainy season, Kang added.

Meanwhile, the Taipei Water Department announced that water rationing will start first from Wednesday for Yangmingshan and Peitou in suburban Taipei, affecting more than 2,700 households in the neighborhood for a lack of mountain spring and underground water -- the major sources for the two mountainous districts.
Department Director Kuo Jui-hua said it rained only 37 millimeters in Yangmingshan since June until now, a dramatic slide from 900 millimeters posted during the same period of last year.

Meanwhile, water supplies for central and southern Taiwan will remain normal through October after the landing of Typhoon Imbudo early this month, which brought large amounts of rainfall to the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT STICKS TO STATEMENT ABOUT TAIWAN'S SEPARATION FROM CHINA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian stuck to his assertion that there is one state on each side of the Taiwan Strait Tuesday, although his view was challenged by a member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Presiding over a meeting of the DPP, of which Chen is the chairman, the president said his statement about Taiwan's status might not be the theme of his presidential campaign in 2004, but it is the bottom line of the DPP and neither he nor his party would renounce the concept.

The president's "one state on each side" is a keynote of his 2004 presidential campaign, whereby Chen has declared that the election will be a clash between the followers of mainland China's "one China" principle and those of Chen's ideology.
His declaration was criticized by his fellow party member, Legislator Chang Chun-hung, who said the statement will doom Chen's campaign instead of boosting his popularity.
Speaking at Tuesday's DPP meeting, Chang said Chen's statement was out of date and would not appeal to the public because it offers them no vision.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE TO EXCEED 3 PERCENT THIS YEAR: VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: The ROC's economic growth rate will undoubtedly top 3 percent this year, Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i said Tuesday.

In a speech to students of National Taipei University, Lin said the rate could hit 3.09 percent if 90 percent of the government's NT$57.7 billion special budget, set aside to stimulate the economy, is used by the end of this year.
Meanwhile, Lin said, unemployment is expected to decline to below 4.5 percent in December, which would bring the jobless rate for the entire year down to 4.83 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: USA, TAIWAN AND AUSTRALIA SCORE WINS IN YOUTH BASEBALL CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: The United States, Taiwan and Australia scored wins Tuesday in the fifth day of the XI "AA" World Youth Baseball Championship being held in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan .
The United States blanked South Africa 16-0, Taiwan beat the Czech Republic 29-2, and Australia defeated Korea 7-4.
There is no game Wednesday, and a cross-group competitions will begin Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 13, or the 16th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: The British formally take over the colony at the Cape of Good Hope, located at the southernmost tip of the African continent, from the Dutch.
1860: Annie Oakley, the American sharpshooter who could hit the edge of a playing card at 30 paces, is born as Phoebe Anne Oakley Moses.
1898: American forces led by George Dewey capture Manila during the Spanish-American War.
1899: Hollywood film director Alfred Hitchcock is born in England. He directed such classics as "Psycho" and "The Birds."
1910: Florence Nightingale, the British nurse known as "the Lady with the Lamp," dies at the age of 90. She organized and directed a unit of field nurses during the Crimean War and is considered the founder of modern nursing.
1923: Mustafa Kemal Ataturk is elected president of Turkey.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, commander in chief of China's Nationalist Revolutionary Forces, resigns in order to bring about solidarity between the Nanking and Hankow factions of the Kuomintang.
1927: Japanese troops launch a major attack on Shanghai and are met with stiff resistance from Chinese defenders.
1942: The United States and Britain decide to carry out joint research on the atomic bomb.
1949: Mao Zedong names Beijing as Communist China's capital.
1960: The Central African Republic gains independence from France.
1961: Communist East Germany begins the erection of the Berlin Wall, drawing strong protests from Western nations.
1967: Fifteen grand justices nominated by President Chiang Kai-shek are approved by the Republic of China's Control Yuan.
1969: Communist China and the Soviet Union accuse each other of sending troops across their Central Asian border and inflicting heavy casualties.
1974: Mort Young, deputy editor-in-chief of Hearst Newspapers in the United States, arrives in Taipei for a two-week visit.
1975: An eight-member Taiwan dance troupe leaves for La Paz to perform at celebrations marking Bolivia's independence day.
1976: Over 140 youths from 20 nations join in the opening ceremony of the International Youth Recreation Tour to the Republic of China sponsored by the China Youth Corps.
1976: The ROC Cabinet approves extension of the Sino-Uruguayan Agreement on Agricultural Cooperation for two years.
1978: A building serving as the Beirut headquarters of the Palestine Liberation Front and containing the offices of their rivals, Al-Fatah, is ripped apart by a bomb, leaving some 150 people dead.
1984: Six mainland Chinese freedom seekers freed by the Korean government arrive in Taipei. The six hijacked a Communist Chinese Trident plane from Shenyang, Manchuria, to Seoul, South Korea, on May 5, 1983.
1989: Two hot air balloons collide in the worst-ever hot air balloon disaster in Australia, with one of the balloons plunging 182 meters to the ground, killing 12 people.
1993: A hotel collapses in Thailand, killing over 120 people.
1999: The Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan estimates that the ROC's economic growth rate will reach 5.5 percent for the year.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian and his 200-member entourage leave Taipei, beginning a 13-day visit to six states in the Caribbean, Central America and Africa.
2001: Academia Sinica member George C. Tiao becomes the first scholar and the first ethnic Chinese to receive both the prestigious Wilks Memorial Award and the Julius Shiskin Award in statistics in the same year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Trust is the law of God. Acquired truth is the law of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. LAUDS TAIWAN FOR SEIZURE OF CHEMICALS ABOARD N. KOREAN FREIGHTER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department lauded Taiwan Tuesday for forcing the North Korean freighter "Be Gae Hung" to unload a batch of a controlled chemical before allowing it to leave a Taiwan port for North Korea.

State Department deputy spokesman Philip Reeker said during a regular press briefing that the chemical, identified as phosphorus pentasulfide, could have been used to make chemical weapons if transported to North Korea.
He said Taiwan authorities seized 158 barrels of phosphorus pentasulfide from the vessel at Kaoshiung Harbor in southern Taiwan several days ago, adding the case is being investigated.
Reeker commended Taiwan's efficient action in stopping materials from being transporting to arms proliferators.
The 6,500-ton "Be Gae Hung" arrived in Kaohsiung Harbor last Thursday from Bangkok, Thailand, to unload batches of chemical materials, including aluminum powder.

Kaohsiung Customs Bureau (KCB) officials asked to inspect the "Be Gae Hung" after being informed by U.S. intelligence authorities that the North Korean freighter might be carrying a batch of dangerous chemicals which could be used as materials in the production of nuclear weapons.
The freighter's captain, surnamed Kim, refused the KCB officials' request, forcing the KCB to detain the "Be Gae Hung" to conduct a search.
During their search, KCB officials discovered the 158 barrels of phosphorus pentasulfide, which had been listed by the ship's captain as "commodities in transit."

KCB officials said their seizure of the chemical was legitimate, noting that phosphorus pentasulfide is listed as a strategic high-tech commodity (SHTC) subject to controls according to international law.

North Korea is listed by Taiwan as an area subject to SHTC controls. The consignee of the phosphorus pentasulfide should have applied with the Bureau of Foreign Trade in advance for transit permission through Taiwan, KCB officials said.
Although the phosphorus pentasulfide was registered as "commodities in transit, " the KCB decided to seize the batch because the consignee failed to complete the legal process, the officials added.

The BOFT will discuss the issue with various government agencies as soon as possible to decide how to deal with the detained phosphorus pentasulfide, which is being stored in a warehouse at Kaohsiung Harbor, they said.
The vessel was allowed to leave for North Korea Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Tsai Su-jung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso reaffirmed her support for the Republic of China Tuesday while meeting with ROC Vice President Annette Lu.
Moscoso told Lu that she had pledged support for the ROC on her first day in office. "I'll uphold this commitment until the last day of my term (Aug. 31, 2004)."

According to the Panamanian Constitution, Moscoso cannot run for a second consecutive term. But Moscoso said she is convinced that her successor will continue to maintain formal diplomatic relations with the ROC.

Moscoso is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Aug. 21 for a state visit. During her stay, she will sign a free trade agreement with ROC President Chen Shui-bian to further boost trade and economic cooperation between Taiwan and Panama.

Panamanian Second Vice President Dominador Kaiser Bazan will also head a delegation to visit Taiwan in September, and President Chen is scheduled to make an official visit to Panama in early November. All these exchanges of visits of high-level officials attest to the cordial ties between the two countries, Lu said.
Nevertheless, Lu expressed concerns about Panamanian First Vice President Arturo Vallarino's plan to visit mainland China later this month.
In response, Moscoso said it won't be Vallarino's first trip to mainland China. Moscoso said she had advised Vallarino not to visit the mainland as he is Panama's vice president.
"Vallarino told me he will visit the mainland in his private capacity, " Moscoso said, adding that she has expressed her stance on Vallarino's travel plan and must respect his personal will.
Moscoso further said Lu's concern about Vallarino's mainland travel plan is understandable. But she stressed that Panama has long been supportive of the ROC and will continue to do so in the future.
The Panamanian head of state said she will clearly explain her country's stance on maintaining formal diplomatic ties with the ROC when she visits Taiwan next week.

During their talks, Lu came up with a proposal that Taiwan and Panama jointly operate a farm to tap the international agricultural market, with Panama providing land and manpower and Taiwan offering biotechnology and technicians.
Moscoso threw her full support behind Lu's proposal, saying she hopes this project can be realized during her tenure.

Earlier in the day, Lu gave interviews to Panamanian news media and toured the Panama Canal and a folk culture center. Panamanian Vice President Bazan hosted a luncheon in honor of Lu and presented her with a medal in recognition of her contribution to promoting Taiwan's democratization and its relations with Panama.
On Tuesday morning, Lu and Bazan also jointly presided over a ceremony marking the completion of a Taiwan-financed face lift of the building that houses Panama's Ministry of the Interior.
Accompanied by a 43-member entourage, Lu arrived in Panama City Monday for a three-day official visit after transit stops in Hawaii and Los Angeles where she had met with many U.S. politicians.
Lu told Taiwan reporters covering her current overseas journey that she hopes her visit to Panama can help consolidate bilateral diplomatic relations.

With the number of mainland Chinese immigrants to Panama increasing rapidly in recent years, Lu said the Chinese community population structure has undergone significant changes. At the moment, Panama has about 80,000 mainland Chinese immigrants and 50,000 ethnic Chinese while the number of new immigrants from Taiwan is only about 300.
Against this backdrop, Lu said, Taiwan must step up efforts to boost exchanges and cooperation with Panama.

After the Panama visit, Lu will fly to Asuncion to attend the Paraguayan presidential inauguration Aug. 15 on behalf of President Chen. Lu will also deliver speeches at the Paraguayan parliament and at Asuncion University.
On her way back to Taiwan Aug. 20, Lu is scheduled to make a transit stop in Seattle for two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: HORIZONTAL LEFT-TO-RIGHT STYLE TO BE USED FOR OFFICIAL DOCUMENTS

TEXT.P: The Chinese writing format for official documents in Taiwan will gradually be changed to the standardized horizontal left-to-right format over the next three years, the Executive Yuan reported Wednesday.
The Executive Yuan on Wednesday passed an amendment to regulations governing the standard form for official documents, authorizing the change from the current vertical right-to-left writing format.
The change is being made to cope with the increasing prevalence of computers and to come into line with the international trend in writing style, Executive Yuan officials said.

The Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission drafted the official document format alteration plan in May in response to Premier Yu Shyi-kun's calls early this year for the government to gauge whether to introduce the horizontal left-to-write writing style for official documents as he said the style is an international trend.

Yu said the question of whether to use the left-to-right or the right-to-left style in the horizontal format has been an issue in Taiwan for quite some time. He added that as the government is promoting the use of English and as some official documents are written both in Chinese and in English, a standard horizontal Chinese writing style is necessary.
A standardized horizontal official writing style is expected to have an influence on private publications, Executive Yuan officials said.
The vertical right-to-left writing style had been the main style used by the Chinese people for thousands of years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 187.03 points to close at 5,442.27.

Encouraged by a rise in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,319.3 and continued to go up later due to heavy purchases by investors. The index fluctuated between 5,454.36 and 5,318.53 during trading.
A total of 5.31 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$133.01 billion (US$3.87 billion).

All the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemical shares moving up the most at 4.3 percent, followed by electrical stocks at 3.9 percent, bank and insurance shares at 2.9 percent, construction stocks at 2.3 percent, textile issues and cement stocks, both at 2.2 percent, and foodstuff shares at 1.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 650 to 62, with 60 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER ARRIVES IN CHICAGO ON SECOND LEG OF U.S. VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Chang Sheng-chao and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu flew into Chicago from Los Angeles Tuesday afternoon for the second leg of his week-long U.S. visit aimed at attracting more investment to Taiwan.

Earlier, while in southern California, Lin and his entourage visited Gateway Inc., a direct retailer selling its own brand consumer electronics, in San Diego, as well as Simax Technologies Inc., a manufacturer of high accuracy electro-optics alignment components, in Irvine. Both companies have plans to expand their trade activities with Taiwan.

Gateway president Ted Waitt disclosed that the company will boost its purchases from Taiwan to the amount of US$1 billion this year. Gateway is also planning to set up a product development center in Taiwan, he added.
At the Simax headquarters, Lin was told by a company executive that Simax is studying the feasibility of moving its production lines to Taiwan to lower the company's production costs.

Lin said that the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs will provide the necessary assistance and incentives for foreign investment to help the California-based company realize its Taiwan investment plans.
Lin will attend a briefing in Chicago on Wednesday to explain the investment incentives offered to foreign investors as well as government procurement procedures in Taiwan.
On Thursday, Lin will meet local manufacturers in the states of Delaware and New Jersey, while his schedule for Friday includes a visit to CorningWare Co. in upstate New York.

Another important aim of Lin's U.S. trip is to attract more U.S. businesspeople to Taipei to attend an international trade fair to be held from Oct. 19-22 at the Taipei World Trade Center, according to a Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York source.
The source said that the minister is due to return to Taiwan on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFORM HOLDS KEY TO ECONOMIC SUCCESS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday sweeping reform holds the key to economic success.

Chen made the remarks after heading a delegation of editors-in-chief of local news media to tour two state-owned companies in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, both of which have witnessed a remarkable turnaround in their fortunes over the past three years through extensive corporate restructuring.

Noting that reform and economic prosperity were the keynotes of his campaign platform back in the 2000 presidential election, Chen said the turnaround of Tang Eng Iron Works Corp. and China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) serves to prove that reform is the cornerstone of economic success.

Chen said he chose the two state-owned enterprises as the first stops of his current two-day round-the-island tour mainly to enable local media executives to see for themselves his administration's achievements in economic reform over the past three years.

When he took office in May 2000, Chen recalled, only five of the nation's 12 state-owned enterprises were in the black. Tang Eng and the CSBC were the most deeply in debt, with each of them burdened with a debt of more than NT$11 billion.

"Through corporate restructuring, overhauling of management, staff downsizing and productivity upgrading, the two corporations have turned from debt-laden money losers to profit-making enterprises, " Chen said.

According to Chen, the CSBC earned more than NT$350 million last year, and its earnings are expected to exceed NT$360 million this year, while Tang Eng posted a profit of NT$410 million in 2002, and its 2003 earnings are forecast to hit NT$1.5 billion.
"All these figures attest to the success of our reform efforts, " Chen said.
The CSBC has received orders for building 42 vessels of various types for local and overseas customers. Its production line has been fully booked until the second quarter of 2007.

The president and his entourage were scheduled to visit two private companies in central Taiwan in the afternoon -- one from a labor-intensive industry, and the other employing hi-tech workers -- which have heeded the president's call by keeping their roots in Taiwan.
The two-day tour itinerary also includes a visit to Wuji Station of the high-speed railway in central Taiwan, which is still under construction, to give journalists a glimpse into the future Taiwan.

The tour will give the public, through the country's media, a clear view of the government's achievements, which are often clouded by partisan politics in the Legislative Yuan, a Presidential Office spokesman said a day earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2ND-PHASE WATER RATIONING COULD BE POSTPONED: WATER AGENCY

TEXT.P: The implementation of second-phase water rationing measures in the greater Taipei area could be postponed to early September, thanks to torrential afternoon rains over the past several days, the Water Resources Agency reported Wednesday.

Torrential afternoon rain showers on Tuesday allowed the water catchment of the Feitsui Reservoir -- the main supplier for the greater Taipei area -- to take in 57.9 millimeters of rainfall in a single day, greatly easing water shortage pressure in Taipei City, Water Resources Agency officials said.

Tuesday's 57.9 millimeters of rainfall -- which brought in some 13 million metric tons of water into the Feitsui Reservoir -- was the second highest single-day level of rainfall this year, and the highest since June 15, according to Feitsui Reservoir Administration Bureau officials.
The Feitsui Reservoir water catchment is expected to take in about the same amount of water Wednesday following an afternoon shower, the bureau officials said.

The Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs reached a consensus with relevant agencies recently that the second-phase water conservation measures will be imposed in the greater Taipei area if the water level at the Shihmen Reservoir drops to 210 meters or the water level at the Feitsui Reservoir falls to 130 meters.
With limited rainfall in northern Taiwan since mid-June, the Water Resources Agency had expected that the second-phase water rationing measures would likely be imposed by the end of August.

Luckily, the torrential rainfall over the past three days in northern Taiwan has significantly alleviated water shortage pressure and thus helped push back the schedule of the second-phase water rationing measures, Water Resources Agency officials said.
The water catchment of the Shihmen Reservoir took in 10.3 millimeters of rainfall Tuesday.

Although the torrential afternoon rainfall over the past several days has greatly quenched the dry spell, whether sufficient and sustainable water levels at the Feitsui Reservoir can be maintained will depend on whether rains are brought by seasonal typhoons, Feitsui Reservoir Administration Bureau officials said.

Meanwhile, water supplies for central and southern Taiwan will remain normal through October after the landing of Typhoon Imbudo early this month, which brought large amounts of rainfall to the region.

The Water Resources Agency temporarily ruled out the possibility of having water from central Taiwan transported to Taipei, as some people have suggested, in consideration of distance and other inconveniences, the Water Resources Agency officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOO MANY GRADUATE SCHOOLS OF SUBSTANDARD QUALITY: LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: The number of institutes offering graduate studies has increased from 841 in 1998 to the current 1,904, and quite a few of these institutes are under-staffed, Legislator Cheng Jhen-long said Wednesday.
The legislator also said that the academic standards of many institutes is questionable. According to his report, 195 graduate institutes have no more than three full-time teachers each.
He added that it is not rare to find that an institute with only two or three full-time teachers has admitted dozens of graduate students.

While the tuitions of graduate schools are relatively high, in comparison with the nation's per capita income, Cheng said there is no justification for many graduate schools to provide low-quality education at such high costs.

Saying that some universities have made their graduate schools diploma-mills, Cheng called on the Ministry of Education to review its regulations on the establishment of graduate schools to prevent the deterioration of quality at institutes of higher education.

DOC.HEADLINE: FBI OFFICIALS TO VISIT TAIWAN TO LOOK INTO ESPIONAGE CASE

TEXT.P: The U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) will send staff members to Taiwan to look into an alleged defense technology espionage case that involved a Chinese-American engineer, a senior official said Wednesday.

Tsui Sheng-hsiang, deputy director of the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB), made the remarks at a public hearing on national security, organized by opposition People First Party Legislator Chin Hui-chu.

Tsui said U.S. authorities are rather concerned about the MJIB's recent raid on a ring that allegedly spied for mainland China. Three suspects -- Chen Shih-liang, a technician at the military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST) in northern Taiwan; Hsu Hsi-tse, a U.S. citizen of Chinese origin who once worked at Boeing Co.; and Yen Yu-chen, the owner of a private company -- have been arrested on charges of espionage and treason.

The ring was suspected of having hacked into a U.S. government-owned Internet Web site to steal classified military files, particularly those related to F-16 jet fighter's nighttime combat equipment and its command and control datalinks. Taiwan has bought 150 F-16s.
Worse still, the ring was accused of having counterfeited the CIST's "end-user certificates" for Hsu to purchase sophisticated strategic night-vision equipment for mainland China.
Tsui said the case is still being investigated. "Investigations won't be closed until after all suspicious points are clarified and all relevant data is collected," he added.

Noting that the United States is concerned about the case, Tsui said FBI headquarters will send at least three staff members to Taiwan to collect first-hand information. Moreover, he said, the U.S. Department of Justice may also send officials to Taiwan for similar purposes.
According to Tsui, the FBI agents may arrive in Taiwan later this week.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC ADVISOR SAYS MAINLAND CHINA POSES LARGEST THREAT TO REGION
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By F. C. Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Mainland China poses the biggest threat to peace in the Asia-Pacific region because it is a hegemonic regime which has no respect for freedom, peace and human rights, Su Chin-chiang, an advisor of the Repubic of China National Security Council (NSC) said in Bangkok Wednesday.

Su made the remarks while giving a keynote speech on Taiwan's values at a forum sponsored by the branch of the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace in Bangkok, the last leg of his Southeast Asian tour, which also brought him to destinations in Indonesia and Malaysia.
The Chinese communist regime, which possesses a strong military power, may wage war against Taiwan, posing a great threat to regional peace, Su said.

Stressing that the people of Taiwan do not look for war, Su said what lies ahead for the Taiwan people to decide is whether they are willing to accept mainland Chinese rule. That has nothing to do with the independence-unification problem, he added.

Turning to Taiwan's plans to hold a referendum on the fate of the disputed Fourth Nuclear Power Plant and the need to join the World Health Organization, Su said a referendum to allow the people to decide the course of public polices is a normal practice of human rights in a democratic society.
It is immoral to smear the government's referendum plan, Su criticized, and pointed out what is awful are the factors behind the opposing side. They are against Taiwan's democratization, he argued.
Su is slated to leave for Taiwan Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REAFFIRMS POSITION ON GIVING GRACE PERIOD FOR NEW WTO MEMBERS
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's permanent representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO) on Tuesday reaffirmed the island's position of supporting the expansion of markets for non-agricultural products but called for a grace period to new WTO members in lowering their tariffs.

Yen Ching-chang made the remarks at a meeting for WTO delegation chiefs, which formed part of the frequent negotiations held in Geneva prior to the annual WTO Ministerial Conference to be held in Cancun, Mexico, in early September.

WTO member countries are deliberating on a proposal submitted by the United States, the European Union and Canada for big reductions in tariffs in the highest tariffs ranges as part of the current round of trade liberalization negotiations, a suggestion which is said to be more beneficial to developed countries.
The U.S. delegation in Geneva is seeking Taiwan's support by arranging meetings with Taiwan's WTO delegation to explain their proposal.
Taiwan, a major exporter of industrial products, will generally benefit from big reductions in tariffs on goods among member economies.

Although supporting the expansion of markets for non-agricultural products in global trade, Yen stressed that any proposal should consider the special needs of new members; therefore, Taiwan maintains the position that new members should be given a longer grace period to implement the results of the new round of trade talks.
Meanwhile, officials of Taiwan's WTO delegation said that the big task for Taiwan is to protect its "sensitive industries" while expanding its export market.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGN TO FOCUS ON SOCIAL AND LIVELIHOOD ISSUES

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) will make social, economic and livelihood issues the focus of its 2004 presidential campaign, ignoring President Chen Shui-bian's claim that the election will be a decisive conflict between pro-Taiwan people and pro-China supporters, according to a KMT official Wednesday.

KMT spokesman Chou Shou-hsun quoted KMT Chairman Lien Chan as saying in a weekly meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee that his party will preempt Chen's claims with a "proper response" and take wind out of his sails in the campaign.

As to the Executive Yuan's proposal to give voters two ballots in the next election for legislators, one for a candidate and one for a party, Chou quoted Lien as saying that the KMT will respect whatever changes are made to the election system, although the party feels that single-seat constituencies are the answer to many of the problems facing the legislature.
Chou said the KMT will respond to the Executive Yuan's proposal after studying it carefully.
It was also decided at the KMT meeting to hold the party's third plenary conference of its central committee members on Sept. 6-7.

The 211 members of the KMT Central Committee will reshuffle the party's Central Standing Committee by electing its 31 members. As the party's policy-making group, the Central Standing Committee will hold great power if the KMT wins the 2004 presidential election and becomes the ruling party.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN REFORM PROGRAM NOT YET FINALIZED: CABINET

TEXT.P: The Cabinet has yet to flesh out all details regarding a much-anticipated reform of the nation's Legislative Yuan, a senior official said Wednesday.

Cabinet spokesman Lin Chia-lung was responding to a newspaper report that the Cabinet has drafted amendments to the existing Election and Recall Law which will allow voters to cast two votes in next year's legislative election while the current constituencies will not be subject to any adjustment.
Lin said the report was not correct. "The so-called 'two-votes, no constituency adjustment' formula is only one of the many options being discussed," he explained.
At the moment, Lin said, the Cabinet is still working on an amendment package to the Election and Recall Law of the "single seat constituency and two-vote" principle.

The draft revisions are still subject to discussion by a panel composed of officials from various ministries and agencies, Lin said, adding that the draft bill must be approved by the legislature before it can be implemented.
As for the proposed 50 percent cut of the number of legislative seats, Lin said, that would require amendments to the ROC Constitution.
"Given all these factors, we simply cannot predict at this moment whether a new electoral system can be adopted for next year's legislative election," Lin said.

Meanwhile, the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) to support a proposal to hold an extraordinary legislative session to deal with legislative reform bills and relevant constitutional amendment proposals.
DPP legislative whip Chen Chi-mai said the DPP supports the proposals to halve the number of legislative seats and adopt a "single seat constituency and two-votes" legislative election formula.

According to the Additional Articles of the ROC Constitution, the Legislative Yuan has 225 members. Any reduction in the number of seats will require an amendment to the Additional Articles of the Constitution.

In response to the DPP's call, PFP Legislator Chou Hsi-wei said the "pan-blue alliance" will come up with a comprehensive legislative reform package, including to the electoral system, legislative disciplinary regulations and relevant "sunshine bills, " in September or early October to improve the legislature's operational efficiency and establish clean politics.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA VOWS TO UPGRADE TIES WITH ROC: LU
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Tsai Su-jung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday that Panama's ruling and opposition parties have all promised to further upgrade relations with the Republic of China.

Lu made the remarks at a dinner party hosted by the Panamanian government in her honor. Panamanian Second Vice President Dominador Kaiser Bazan, many other Panamanian officials, parliamentarians and social celebrities, including Ruby Moscoso, the elder sister of Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso, attended the party to welcome Lu and her entourage.
Lu said the ROC and Panama have a longstanding relationship because the two countries have shared values in promoting freedom, democracy, human rights and gender equality.

During her meeting with the Panamainan president earlier in the day, Lu said Moscoso has reaffirmed her firm support for the ROC. "Moscoso told me that she had pledged support for the ROC on her first day in office and will uphold this commitment until the last day of her term (Aug. 31, 2004)," Lu said, adding that Moscoso has also promised to take active steps to further boost cooperation with Taiwan during her tenure.
Lu said all of the three hopefuls intending to run for the Panamanian presidency have also promised to strengthen ties with Taiwan should they win the election.

According to the Panamanian Constitution, Moscoso cannot run for a second consecutive term. Moscoso said she is convinced that her successor will continue to maintain formal diplomatic relations with the ROC.

Moscoso is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Aug. 21 for a state visit. During her stay, she will sign a free trade agreement with ROC President Chen Shui-bian to further boost trade and economic cooperation between Taiwan and Panama.

On Tuesday morning, Lu gave interviews to Panamanian news media and toured the Panama Canal and a folk culture center. EArlier in the day, Lu and Bazan also jointly presided over aceremony marking the completion of a Taiwan-financed face lift of the building that houses Panama's Ministry of the Interior.
Lu told Taiwan reporters covering her current overseas journey that she hopes her visit to Panama can help consolidate bilateral diplomatic relations.
