At the moment, Panama has about 80,000 mainland Chinese immigrants and 50,000 ethnic Chinese while the number of new immigrants from Taiwan is only about 300.
Against this backdrop, Lu said, Taiwan must step up efforts to boost exchanges and cooperation with Panama.

After the Panama visit, Lu will fly to Asuncion to attend the Paraguayan presidential inauguration Aug. 15 on behalf of President Chen. Lu will also deliver speeches at the Paraguayan parliament and at Asuncion University.
On her way back to Taiwan Aug. 20, Lu is scheduled to make a transit stop in Seattle for two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT ON ALERT AGAINST COMPUTER WORM

TEXT.P: A panel under the Executive Yuan has warned all government agencies to be alert against a computer worm which began hitting computers Monday that run Windows operating systems, Lin Chia-lung a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Wednesday.
Lin said government agencies were told to scan their Web sites around the clock.
So far, there have been no reports of problems in Taiwan from what has been dubbed "LovSan," which penetrates Windows by exploiting a flaw in the software.
Microsoft posted a free patch on its Web site to prevent LovSan and similar viruses on July 16, but many Windows users didn't install the patches until it was too late.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA GIVES VICE PRESIDENT LU MEDAL FOR CONTRIBUTIONS TO DEMOCRACY
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 13 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu was given the Gran Cruz Medal of Manuel Amador Guerrero Tuesday by the Panamanian Second Vice President Dominador Kaiser Bazan in recognition of her contributions to democracy and human rights.

Saying that she felt deeply honored to have received the highest symbol of Panama's national honor from Bazan, Lu stressed that she will continue seeking to cement the common ground -- democracy, peace and prosperity -- as the philosophy jointly aspired by the two governments to rule their states.

Lu stated that Taiwan highly treasures its relations with Panama, which will sign a free trade agreement with Taiwan soon. She also expressed the hope that Taiwan and Panama will upgrade and enhance two-way cooperation in the pursuit of democracy and progress.

According to Lu, Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso will travel to Taiwan next week on her third visit to the country, while President Chen Shui-bian has been invited to take part in Panama's 100th founding anniversary on Nov. 3. Such frequent contacts indicate that the people and governments are closely connected, she added.

For his part, Bazan voiced his gratitude for Taiwan's assistance and help to Panama, and reiterated his country's full support to the ROC government. He pledged to continue promoting mutually-beneficial ties.
Bazan will participate in a democratic conference slated for mid-September in Taipei at Lu's invitation.

Leading a 43-member entourage, Lu arrived in Panama City Monday for a three-day official visit. The vice president will proceed to Asuncion, where she will attend the inauguration of Paraguayan President-elect Nicanor Duarte Friday on behalf of President Chen.
Lu is slated to return to Taiwan Aug. 20 via the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DIPLOMAT SAYS REFERENDUM HAS NOTHING TO DO WITH INDEPENDENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's deputy representative to the United States, Tsai Ming-shian, stressed on Tuesday that holding referendums is one of the basic human rights of the people of Taiwan and it has nothing to do with Taiwan's independence or possible unification with mainland China.

Tsai, who made the remarks in a radio interview on the "Voice of America," said Taiwan plans to hold a referendum on or before the day of the next presidential election -- March 20, 2004 -- on three topics -- the fate of the island's partially completed Fourth Nuclear Power Plant, Taiwan's bid to enter the World Health Organization, and the downsizing of the country's legislature.
He noted that the referendum is to allow the world, especially Beijing, to hear the voice of the people of Taiwan.

Asked about media reports from mainland China that criticized Taiwan's holding of a referendum as only a way to gradual introduce Taiwan independence, Tsai said the Republic of China on Taiwan is already an independent country with sovereignty.
Taiwan and mainland China are two sovereign countries as were East Germany and West Germany before their unification, he said.

Tsai stressed that it is unreasonable and unfair that mainland China, which has not governed Taiwan for even a single day, has repeatedly tried to force the island to accept Beijing's definition of "one China" and its "one country, two systems" formula, which has been shown to be a failure in Hong Kong.

According to Tsai, ROC President Chen Shui-bian has said on many occasions that Taiwan can open talks on any topic with mainland China, including cross-strait economic and trade cooperation, or even political integration, as long as Beijing does not impose preconditions on the talks.

After the exclusive interview, Tsai, who also received call-in questions from mainland Chinese, said he hopes that mainland people can one day express their opinions through referendums like Taiwan people will be able to.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SEARCHES COMPANY IN FRUITLESS EFFORT TO RETRIEVE STOLEN CHIPS

TEXT.P: Police led by a prosecutor searched an electronics company in Taipei Wednesday to try to retrieve a batch of central processing units (CPU) stolen from Intel, but came away empty-handed.

Acting on a tip-off from U.S. law enforcers, police officers from the Criminal Investigation Bureau, raided the company in Taipei City, and questioned its owner. There was no sign, however, of the 50,000 stolen CPUs. The name of the company was withheld.
The chips, sold by Intel to a British company, disappeared while being airlifted to London in July.

At the same time, U.S. law enforcers were alerted by a U.S. company that a broker had offered to sell them a batch of CPUs of unknown origin. U.S. law enforcers relayed the information to their Taiwan counterparts and prompted Wednesday's search. Police officers close to the investigation doubted the CPUs would be stored in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PREDICTS CROSS-STRAIT TALKS TO BE RESUMED AFTER NEXT MARCH

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian predicted Wednesday that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will gradually resume talks and exchanges in all aspects after next March.

Chen told a group of editors in chief of local media who are accompanying him on a two-day tour around Taiwan that Beijing's insistence on its "one China" principle is the reason for the current cross-strait stalemate.

Over the past years, he emphasized, many reliable surveys have showed that an overwhelming majority of the people in Taiwan back the principles of equality, security and dignity in cross-strait exchanges and that the "one China" principle is not acceptable.

Noting that his assertion of "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait" is a description of cross-strait reality, he explained that the official designation of Taiwan is the Republic of China and the other side of the Taiwan Strait calls itself the People's Republic of China.

There exists no room for Taiwan to accept the "one China" principle and "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait" will be an unavoidable topic that every candidate for next year's presidential election will face in his campaign. Candidates will have to clearly express a stance on the issue, Chen said.

Beijing should adjust its position toward Taiwan if it wants to resume normal cross-strait exchanges, Chen added, saying that he believes that mainland Chinese leaders will gradually understand Taiwan's position on this issue and will eventually deal with cross-strait affairs in a pragmatic manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST HOLDING COMPANY CHAIRMAN RESIGNS

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Lin Chuan confirmed Wednesday the resignation of First Holding Company Chairman Chen Chien-lung, citing "personal career plans" as Chen's reason for stepping down.

Speaking at a news conference, Lin said Chen submitted his resignation to the Ministry of Finance a day earlier on the grounds that he had completed his mission at the company and that it was time to move on to "personal career projects."

Lin said he fully respects Chen's decision and that Lin's resignation has nothing to do with the company's recent issuing of global deposit receipts to collect US$515 million in funds from abroad, which was harshly criticized for allegedly trying to benefit a vested group at home.

Lin denied the accusation and hailed Chen's efforts and performance over the past three years. The minister said bilateral communication has been smooth and Chen's decision to leave is not necessarily linked to the matter.
Chen's resignation sent ripples through the political and financial sectors because of his close links with President Chen Shui-bian.
Chen was originally slated to fly to Hanoi later Wednesday to preside over the opening of a branch of the First Commercial Bank Friday. The trip has been canceled.
Meanwhile, First Holding Company General Manager Tung Ruei-pin also handed in his resignation in a gesture of solidarity with his superior.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY TO REQUEST MASSIVE SPECIAL BUDGET FOR ACQUIRING ARMS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense will request a special budget of NT$520 billion (US$15.15 billion) next year to acquire arms already offered from the United States.

An anonymous defense official told the Central News Agency Wednesday that the defense ministry will need the funds to acquire six batteries of Patriot Advance Capability, or PAC-3, missiles, two long range radar systems, eight diesel submarines, and 12 P-3 Orion sub-hunting surveillance aircraft.
The United States has agreed to sell these weapons to Taiwan, but Taipei has had difficulty coming up with the funds to buy them all.
The special budget will be more than double the current defense budget of NT$260 billion (US$7.62 billion) for 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: GENERAL ELECTRIC GETS ORDER FOR CAL'S NEW PLANES' ENGINES

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san confirmed Wednesday evening that China Airlines (CAL), Taiwan's largest air carrier, will order engines from General Electric (GE) for its 18 newly purchased aircraft.
Lin said CAL executives had only informed him of their decision by telephone, and that he has no idea about other details of the purchase plan.

Sources from CAL said the company has obtained quite favorable conditions for the deal, including a considerable discount in price, the transfer of technology, as well as improvement in repairs and maintenance.

According to CAL executives, after thorough evaluations on the quality, price, maintenance and technology transfer, CAL decided on the engines from GE for its newly ordered 12 A330-300s and six B747-400s, as they will most fulfill CAL's needs.
CAL executives also thanked the government for giving them full negotiation power in the deal and allowing them to decide on the purchase plan purely based on commercial interests.

Officials of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said the same day that they believe CAL's decision is based on commercial and technical evaluations and denied a planned visit to the United States by Taiwan's leader was sanctioned in exchange for the US$600 million deal.

Meanwhile, the British Trade and Cultural Office in Taipei, which represented another engine manufacturer -- Rolls Royce -- expressed great disappointment, saying that they are very concerned whether there are political considerations surrounding the deal as rumored by media reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U.S. RELATIONS BEST IN MORE THAN TWO DECADES: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that he had confidence in the relations between Taiwan and the United States, saying that relations are the best they have been in more than two decades.
The president made the remarks while speaking with editors in chief of news media in Changhua, central Taiwan after the first full day of a two-day trip dubbed "witting the progress of Taiwan."
The president noted that though there are differences between Taiwan and the U.S., communication channels between the two sides have been open, although he couldn't elaborate on some points.
The president cited as an example the recent visits of Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, and other ranking officials to the U.S, saying such visits are "significant."
"I'm satisfied with this pattern of contact and dialogue, " he added.

He said, "Relations between Taiwan and the U.S. are the best they have been since 1979, including the exchanges and cooperation in the areas of military and national defense, " and that it was "hard in the past to imagine that there would be such close relations."
There is tacit agreement and consensus between Taiwan and the U.S, and differences between the two sides have gradually narrowed, he said, adding that he has every confidence in the relationship.

On cross-strait relations, he said, "Though there are criticisms, many things are not as bad as you may imagine, " adding that Taiwan has been relentlessly squeezed diplomatically, but "many things that happened before aren't happening now."
He said that the government has adopted a "cautious" attitude to handling cross-strait relations, and the bottom line is to "stand fast to one's stance and move forward pragmatically."

He stressed that without the persistent efforts of this government, there would be no current cross-strait relations, adding that some have said that the government had no experience in dealing with cross-strait relations when it was inaugurated in 2000, but he said that his government's "performance over the past three years is by no means inferior to past administrations."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN UNVEILS THREE STEPS TOWARDS DIRECT TRANSPORTATION LINKS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian, who has resisted opening direct transportation links with mainland China on Beijing's terms, unveiled a three-step program Wednesday towards creating these links.
Speaking with a group of editors in chief from local media in Changhua Wednesday night, the president said the three steps are preparation, negotiation and realization.

The first step is already going on, the second step of negotiation will begin after the presidential election on March 20, 2004; hopefully, the third step will be realized sometime before the end of 2004, Chen said.

Noting that surveys show 75 percent of the people in Taiwan believe direct transportation links should be launched only on the basis that Taiwan's safety is guaranteed and its dignity is preserved, the president warned that the government is trying to prevent any negative impacts from the direct links, such as the flight of local capital, hi-technology and skilled technicians to the mainland, and a surge in the unemployment rate.
A detailed assessment of the impacts will be included in a report to be released by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) in a couple of days, Chen said.

In the current absence of negotiations between Taiwan and mainland China, the president said a practical substitute for direct shipping links is a way to speed up the indirect shipping links between Taiwan and the mainland which could be done by Taiwan on its own.
Details of this measure will also be revealed by the MAC in a couple of days, Chen said.
The president also reiterated his claims that there is one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait, and that Taiwan is a country separate from mainland China.
Chen arrived in Changhua Wednesday night for an overnight stop on his two-day trip around the island with a group of editors in chief of local media.
The MAC is slated to make public its report about direct transportation links with mainland China on Friday.

Chen's direct links declaration immediately drew fire from the opposition Kuomintang. The party's whip at the Legislative Yuan, Lee Chia-chin, dismissed Chen's statement as lip service intended to woo the support of Taiwan businessmen operating in the mainland.

"If he really believes direct transportation links will serve Taiwan's interests, he should take action to realize it now. Otherwise, he should keep resisting it even after the presidential election," Lee said in Taipei.

Taiwan Solidarity Union Secretary-General Lin Chih-chia gave conditional support to the president's declaration on the links, but warned that the links should be opened only as international ones between country and country, and when Taiwan's safety and dignity is duly preserved.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REMAINS TIGHT-LIPPED ABOUT RUNNING-MATE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian refused to be nailed down Wednesday on his choice of running-mate for the 2004 presidential election.

Arriving in Changhua Wednesday night for an overnight stop on his two-day tour around the island, the president told a group of journalists accompanying him that he is not looking for a running-mate in hopes that his or her popularity will boost his campaign; rather, he wants to search for one who will be a valuable member of his future ruling team.

Although he made no secret of his ambition to run for re-election, the president said he has not yet been named by his Democratic Progressive Party as its candidate for the 2004 presidential race, and is not in a position to pick any running-mate.
"I am not in a hurry; hopefully others will not be in a hurry either," Chen said. 22y Maubo Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESSMEN WELCOME CHEN'S STEPS TOWARDS DIRECT TRANSPORT LINKS

TEXT.P: Businessmen welcomed President Chen Shui-bian's three-step program toward direct transportation links with mainland China Wednesday.
Theodore Huang, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce said the sooner the links are opened under the president's terms the better.
Chen Cheng-yi, secretary-general of the Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China, said the president's three-step program will meet businessmen's greatest desire.
Both China Airlines and EVA Air, the country's two leading air carriers, lauded the program as the best plan to accommodate the political situation and the economic interests of the nation.

President Chen said in Changhua Wednesday night that his administration will launch the direct transportation links, hopefully by the end of 2004, through preparation, negotiations and realization -- the three steps -- although his term expires in May, 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC LIBERALIZATION NECESSARY: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that Taiwan's economy has to move toward more liberalization and it is necessary to have further deregulation.

The president made the remarks over a talk with editors in chief of news media after the first full day of a two-day "witnessing the progress of Taiwan" journey during which the president led the media on a tour of two state-owned enterprises that turned around their operations to become profitable in southern Taiwan and two private companies in central Taiwan which have heeded the president's call to keep the roots in Taiwan.

The president said that Taiwan's economy needs further deregulation to ensure its protection and a niche on the world stage. "The lifting of restrictions is not enough now, " the president said, adding that "there is still room for further deregulation."

The president said that he had every confidence in Taiwan's competitive edge, adding that his goal has always be clear, which is to give the people a better life, and that he has focused on improving the economy and engaging in major reforms.

He noted that Taiwan is absolutely the most powerful support base of Taiwan businessmen, saying that without such solid support, Taiwan businessmen couldn't have the preferential treatment in the mainland, adding that the continued sustainable development of Taiwan will ensure Taiwan businessmen the best treatment in the mainland and the world.
He said that the government will work with and support Taiwan businessmen making inroads into the mainland China and the world.

As long as Taiwan businessmen keep their headquarters and research and development in Taiwan, or their roots in Taiwan, the president said the mainland Chinese market will also be "our foothold, " adding that Taiwan should be ambitious enough to earn money from mainland China and the world and make investments in Taiwan the top priority.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DEFENDS POLICY OF RAISING PUBLIC DEBT FOR CONSTRUCTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian defended his policy Wednesday of increasing the public debt to finance infrastructure construction.

Chen told a group of editors in chief of local media who are accompanying him on a two-day tour around Taiwan that the outstanding debt of the central government accounts for 33 percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP), according to Taiwan's Central Bank of China.

The ratio is far lower that of many developed countries around the world, he said, adding that there will be no problem for the country if the government borrows an additional NT$1 trillion (US$28.9 billion).

The government recently announced a plan to invest NT$500 billion in five years to finance 10 major construction projects, Chen revealed, adding that to step up public investment is aimed at revving the domestic economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 14, or the 17th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1811: The British occupy Java.
1811: Paraguay proclaims independence from Spain.
1900: Forces of eight powers -- Britain, Japan, the United States, Germany, Russia, France, Austria and Italy -- march from Tientsin and scale the walls of Beijing, relieving the foreign legation besieged there since the start of the Boxer Uprising two months earlier.
1917: The Beijing government declares war on Germany and Austro-Hungary.
1937: The Republic of China Air Force shoots down nine of 18 Japanese aircraft which are bombing Hangchow, capital of Chekiang Province in eastern China.
1945: Japan surrenders unconditionally, ending World War II.
1945: The Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance is signed in Moscow.
1945: Nationalist leader Chiang Kai-shek invites Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong to come to Chungking for a conference.
1947: Pakistan gains independence from Britain.
1949: Konrad Adenauer becomes the first chancellor of West Germany.
1951: Randolph W. Hearst, the newspaper publisher known as the king of America's "yellow press," dies at the age of 88. Beginning with the San Francisco Examiner in 1887, he built the world's largest publishing empire comprising 28 major newspapers.
1951: Seamen aboard the Ta Han, a 2,000-ton mainland Chinese freighter, defect to Taiwan, sailing their ship to the port of Kaohsiung.
1958: The ROC Air Force shoots down three Communist Chinese MiG-17s over Matsu.
1958: The United States decides to maintain an embargo on trade with Communist China, North Korea and North Vietnam, despite NATO's announcement of a relaxation of trade restrictions with the Soviet bloc and Communist China.
1971: Ground for the construction of Taiwan's north-south freeway is broken near Linkou.
1973: Over 300 Chinese and foreign computer scientists meet at the Academia Sinica for the First International Symposium on Computers.
1974: The Taipei Century Symphony Orchestra leaves for the United States on a three-week goodwill tour.
1977: The ROC Air Force celebrates the 40th anniversary of its victory over the Japanese at Hangchow, with Gen. Szetu Fu presiding.
1979: Wang Yun-wu, senior advisor to the president of the Republic of China, dies of heart failure at Veterans General Hospital at the age of 92.
1980: More than 360 scholars from home and abroad take part in the International Conference on Sinology at the Academia Sinica.
1985: The ROC Executive Yuan issues a report on the investigation of official administrative responsibilities regarding the 10th Credit Cooperative scandal. Fifteen financial officials are reprimanded, given demerits or dismissed.
1988: Major racial conflict breaks out in the African country of Burundi, with more than 24,000 people being killed in the conflict.
1999: The United States defeats Chinese-Taipei 10-9 to win the 18th International Baseball Association Big League Championship in Kaohsiung.
2000: Premier Tang Fei instructs the Ministry of Justice to review and revise relevant laws and regulations so as to enable the government to effectively crack down on the types of crimes that are increasingly harming Taiwan society.
2001: Former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez, a 1987 Nobel Peace Prize winner, says in Kinmen that Taiwan and mainland China should engage in dialogue to ease the tension across the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who intuitively apprehends truth is one who, without effort, hits what is right, and without thinking understands what he wants to know; whose life is easily and naturally in harmony with the moral law. Such a one is what we call a saint or a man of divine nature."

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA SHOULD SAY 'NO' TO BEIJING: LU
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 13 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu on Wednesday called for the Panamanian government to say "no" to Beijing whenever the mainland Chinse regime makes unreasonable requests to Panama.
Solid and sustainable relations between nations are not based simply on interests, Lu said, noting that it is more important for two nations to maintain ties based on common principles and values.

Panama's maintaining of friendship with the ROC on Taiwan is in line with the interests of the Panamanian people, Lu said, adding she believes that whoever is elected the next president of Panama in the future will value and further strengthen bilateral relations between the two countries.

Lu made the remarks prior to her departure for Paraguay after a three-day official visit in Panama, during which she met with Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso and had cordial and pleasant conversations. Lu said Moscoso told her that she had pledged support for the ROC on her first day in office. "I'll uphold this commitment until the last day of my term (Aug. 31, 2004)."

According to the Panamanian Constitution, Moscoso cannot run for a second consecutive term. But Lu said Moscoso told her that she is convinced that her successor will continue to maintain formal diplomatic relations with the ROC.

Moscoso is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Aug. 21 for a state visit. During her stay, she will sign a free trade agreement with ROC President Chen Shui-bian to further boost trade and economic cooperation between Taiwan and Panama, according to Lu.

During her stay in Panama, Lu also met with her Panamanian counterpart, Panama's Second Vice President Dominador Kaiser Bazan. Bazan hosted a luncheon in honor of Lu and presented her with a medal in recognition of her contribution to promoting Taiwan's democratization and its relations with Panama.
The two jointly presided over a ceremony marking the completion of a Taiwan-financed face lift of the building that houses Panama's Ministry of the Interior.

Bazan will also head a delegation to visit Taiwan in September, and President Chen is scheduled to make an official visit to Panama in early November. All these exchanges of visits of high-level officials attest to the cordial ties between the two countries, Lu said.

During a tour of the Taiwan-Panama Cultural Center in Panama City, Lu appealed to all members of the Taiwan communities in Panama to throw their support behind President Chen Shui-bian for a second term in office.

Lu and her 43-member entourage left Panama City at noon Wednesday for Asuncion to attend the Paraguayan presidential inauguration Aug. 15 on behalf of President Chen. Lu will also deliver speeches at the Paraguayan parliament and at Asuncion University.
On her way back to Taiwan Aug. 20, Lu is scheduled to make a transit stop in Seattle for two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 5.52 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Thursday, with the weighted index moving down 5.52 points to close at 5,436.75.
Market turnover amounted to NT$148.02 billion (US$4.31 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 5.52 points to close at 5,436.75.
The bourse opened at 5,463.54 and then fluctuated between 5,488.82 and 5,410.12 during trading.

A total of 6.1 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$148.02 billion (US$4.31 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 5.31 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$133.01 billion (US$3.87 billion).

Half of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 2.4 percent, followed by construction stocks at 2.1 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1 percent, and bank and insurance stocks at 0.8 percent.

The other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff shares moving down the most at 2.8 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.6 percent, electrical shares at 0.5 percent, and textile issues at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 461 to 201, with 112 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP PRESIDENTIAL AIDE FORESEES BETTER CROSS-STRAIT TIES NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: A top aide to President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that relations between Taiwan and mainland China will be better after the presidential election next year.

Chiou I-jen, Presidential Office secretary-general, made the remarks when he elaborated on President Chen's talks on "three steps" toward direct transportation links with mainland China the previous day.

The president said the three steps are "preparation, negotiation and realization," adding that the first step is already going on, the second step will begin after the presidential election set for March 20, 2004, and the third step will be realized sometime before the end of 2004.
Chiou said that the president, based on four reasons, is sure about the further development of cross-strait relations.

The first reason is that the president is sure of his re-election next year, saying that Beijing, regardless of whether it likes a president from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which has in the past advocated a pro-independence stance, will have to deal with him for another four years, according to Chiou.

Secondly, the president said that cross-strait relations have been going on smoothly over the past three years, adding that although verbal exchanges may be tense, cross-strait relations have in reality seen more progress during his administration than during the previous administration of the Kuomintang (KMT).

Chen noted that his administration has done everything it can within its power to improve cross-strait relations, saying that it has implemented 17 related measures, or almost one new measure every two months, since coming to power. He cited the examples of direct links between the Taiwan-controlled offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu and two ports in the mainland province of Fujian, as well as working rights for mainland Chinese women married to Taiwan citizens.
Thirdly, Chiou said, Beijing and Taipei under the Chen administration, after more than three years of dealing with each other, have accumulated some experience in this regard.

Although the "one country" principle cherished by Beijing has hindered the development of cross-strait relations, he said, the two sides have actually had close enough contacts with each other to be able to see the completion of aviation agreement talks between Taiwan and Hong Kong and to conduct illegal mainland immigrant repatriation operations, among other things.

Lastly, Chiou said, mainland China has also been making some adjustments in dealing with the DPP-led government in Taiwan. For example, Beijing originally insisted that the issue of direct cross-strait transportation links was an "internal matter, " but last year, the then mainland Chinese vice premier, Qian Qichen, used the term cross-strait routes in referring to the direct transportation links.

Chiou concluded by saying that he is certain Beijing will not do or say anything in the DPP's favor before the presidential election, and as a result, it is unlikely there will be any dramatic improvement in cross-strait relations prior to the election.
He added, however, that he DPP is confident that after the presidential election next year, cross-strait relations will only turn for the better.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT PREPARED FOR OPENING OF DIRECT TRANSPORTATION LINKS: YU

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday that the administration has made the preparations for coping with the opening of direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait.

As the direct cross-strait transportation links plan has been under consideration by the administration for two years, the Executive Yuan has mapped out policies and measures for coping with the needs that are expected to arise once the direct links are opened, Yu said.

Major features of the plan include measures to sharpen the Taiwan business and industrial sectors' competitive edge; ways to enable the industrial sectors of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to fairly share their manufacturing niches in a complementary way; and methods to prevent the Taiwan job market from being compromised under the impact of the opening of direct links, Yu noted.
Yu's remarks came on the heels of an announcement made by President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday that he will see to it that direct cross-strait transportation links are implemented by the end of 2004.

Meanwhile, Chen Ming-tong, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , the top governmental agency in charge of formulating Taiwan's mainland China policy, said the MAC will publicize the timetable for the opening of direct links in two days.

Describing it as "crucially important, " Chen said the opening of direct links is a development that will change not only the cross-strait business and trade structure but also the structure of Taiwan's economy and society.
Since the opening of direct links is crucially important in the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Chen said, the two sides should discuss the issue in a rational and peaceful manner.
Chen added that the seven months between now and the next presidential election in Taiwan would be a perfect period for the two sides to conduct bilateral discussions on the opening of direct links.
He also urged Beijing to recognize and accept the reality of "one country on either side of the Taiwan Strait" in order to contribute to an acceleration in cross-strait interactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were generally lower on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted index for August moved down 5 points to close at 5,466, with 33,255 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September gained 5 points to finish at 5,475, with 3,433 contract transactions, while December futures fell 58 points to close at 5,403, with only one contract traded.
March futures lost 14 points to finish at 5,426, with 11 contract transactions, while June futures increased 53 points to close at 5,470, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,471 for August, 5,470 for September, 5,461 for December, 5,440 for March, and 5,417 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
August TE futures moved down 1.7 points to close at 243.3, with 3,927 contract transactions, while September TE futures fell 1.85 points to finish at 242.65, with 518 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
August TF futures gained 9.4 points to close at 706.4, with 3,413 contract transactions, while September TF futures rose 9 points to finish at 705, with 1,461 contracts traded.
December TF futures moved up 6 points to close at 699, with 6 contract transactions, while March TF futures increased 0.4 points to finish at 700, with 2 contracts changing hands.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPLEMENTATION OF 2ND-PHASE WATER RATIONING IN TAIPEI PUT OFF

TEXT.P: The implementation of second-phase water rationing measures in the greater Taipei area and third-phase measures in Keelung have been temporarily postponed, the Water Resources Agency (WRA) reported Thursday.

Torrential afternoon rains in recent days have allowed the water catchment of Feitsui Reservoir -- the main supplier of water for the greater Taipei area -- to take in 82.5 millimeters of rainfall over the last three days, greatly easing water shortage pressure in Taipei City, WRA officials said.

The third-phase water rationing measures for Keelung and the second-phase measures for the greater Taipei area were originally expected to be implemented by the end of August and in early September, respectively.

The water level at Feitsui Reservoir stood at 138.25 meters at 8 a.m. Thursday, up slightly from the level of 138.16 meters at the same time the previous day, marking the first rise in the water level since July 2, the agency officials said.
They added that the water catchment is expected to take in about 13 million metric tons of water Thursday following an afternoon shower.

Although the torrential afternoon rains over the past three days have helped quench the dry spell, the water level at the Feitsui Reservoir is still about ten meters lower than the average level seen over the years, the officials noted. (by Nocturne Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: RAILWAY WORKERS VOTE TO STRIKE ON DAY OF MOON FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railway Labor Union voted Thursday to strike on the day of the upcoming Moon Festival as a means of protecting railway workers' rights.

A total of 274 railway labor union representatives from around the island took part in an extraordinary general meeting Thursday, during which they vowed to carry out the strike on the day of the Moon Festival -- one of the three major holidays for Chinese people.

The railway workers also vowed that the labor union would not hold any dialogue with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) before the Moon Festival, which falls on Sept. 11 this year. The Chinese people have for centuries observed the Moon Festival, also known as the Autumn Festival, on the 15th day of the eighth month of the lunar calendar.

Taiwan Railway Labor Union Chairman Chang Wen-cheng said that 12,000 out of the 14,000-odd Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) staff have given their signatures to endorse the notion that they will take a leave on Sept. 11 to take part in a general meeting.
Noting that although the strike may sound radical, Chang said that the decision has been finalized and that the strike is the only way to draw the government's attention to their appeals.

He added that since the TRA Labor Union declared on June 12 that it would hold its general meeting -- the first of its kind in Taiwan railway history -- on the day of the Moon Festival, the MOTC has continuously expressed "goodwill" in an attempt to seek reconciliation with the railway workers.

However, Chang said, this "goodwill" has been full of empty promises, adding that the MOTC even announced unilaterally on Aug. 11 that after useful dialogue with the labor union, the two sides had reached a consensus that the TRA Labor Union general meeting would be held on Sept. 11 as scheduled but that railway transportation services would not be suspended on that day.
Chang said the MOTC announcement was unilateral and was aimed at splitting the labor union members so that the Sept. 11 strike would be aborted.

The labor union members are expected to make known their appeals once again on the Sept. 11 general meeting day that they are opposed to the TRA's privatization, to the profiteering plans for the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp., and to plans to ultimately put an end to the TRA, Chang said.
The MOTC has asked the TRA management to complete the company's privatization process before July 1, 2004.

Meanwhile, TRA Deputy Director General Hsu Tah-wen said Thursday that railway services will be maintained at normal levels on, before and after the day of Sept. 11, in stark contrast to what has been announced by the TRA labor union.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ENTER NEW ERA OF HIGH-SPEED TRAVEL BY 2006: MOTC MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan will enter a new era of high-speed travel by 2006, with the completion of the highway network and the start of Taiwan High Speed Rail service, Minister of Transportation and Telecommunications Lin Lin-san said Thursday.

In a briefing on the island's transportation system to President Chen Shui-bian and media executives, Lin said that since the inauguration of the 372.7-kilometer First North-South Freeway from Keelung to Kaohsiung in 1978, the convenience in travel and transportation has stimulated economic activities along the west coast.

In order to establish a highway network to allow people around the island high-speed travel, the government has undertaken a series of transportation construction projects over the past decade, including the Second North-South Freeway from Keelung to Pingtung, 12 east-west highways connecting cities and townships on both sides of the island, and the West Coast Highway, according to Lin.

He said that while several sections of the Second North-South Freeway have been opened to traffic since early last year, construction of the 372.3-kilometer freeway is expected to be fully completed at the end of this year.
As to the 12 east-west highways and the West Coast Highway which have also been partially opened to traffic, people can expect full-line operations by the end of 2005, the minister said.

He added that when the Taiwan High Speed Rail becomes operational at the end of 2005, Taiwan residents' mobility and travel speed will be further enhanced with the integrated high-speed travel network.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTRY TO RE-ALLOCATE SCHOLARSHIPS FOR OVERSEAS STUDIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education will re-allocate government scholarships for overseas studies by offering more set-amount scholarships while reducing the quota of full-coverage funding for graduate studies, a ministry official said Thursday.

The official elaborated that under the new practice, the ministry will offer 42 graduate students scholarships for their advanced studies abroad. Instead of taking an examination, the candidates should submit applications to the ministry.
The set-amount scholarship for a student in countries which are tuition-free will be US$10,000, while a student in countries of pay education will be given US$20,000.

The official said that a person studying abroad on a government scholarship is obliged to return to Taiwan after completing his or her studies. The person is also required to work in Taiwan for the same period of time as compared with the years he has spent abroad. These principles remain unchanged, he added.

Currently, the NT$200 million government scholarship fund managed by the MOE offers four categories of scholarships for overseas studies -- three- to four-year full-coverage funding for masters or doctoral degree programs, two-year funding for post-doctorate programs, scholarships for short-term research programs, and scholarships for selected research programs for science and technology specialists.

Statistics released by the MOE showed that in the past year, 1,464 candidates vied for the 85 first-category scholarships; 89 contested the 20 scholarships for post-doctorate programs; and 39 took the examination for the 10 scholarships for short-term research programs.

The official said that under the ministry's plan, only 55 full-coverage scholarships will be offered to the first-category candidates, with the introduction of the set-amount scholarships. A student on the full-coverage scholarship is awarded around NT$1 million for tuition and books, board and lodging, air fares, and health insurance.

MOE statistics indicate that currently, nearly 40 percent of the people studying abroad on government scholarships are in the United States, 30 percent in the United Kingdom, and around 20 percent in continental Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.002 to close at NT$34.387.
A total of US$352 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$34.415 and was traded between NT$34.356 and NT$34.450.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VISITS HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY CONSTRUCTION IN CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian visited the construction site of a high-speed railway station in central Taiwan Thursday in the company of journalists on the final day of a two-day " witnessing the progress of Taiwan" trip around the island.
The president showed the editors in chief of local media the Wuji Station in Taichung County to promote the first high-speed railway system in Taiwan.
The president was also accompanied by Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san and Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. Chairwoman Nita Ing.
Minister Lin said that this was the second time the president had visited Taiwan's high-speed railway system construction; Chen made an inspection tour in Tainan, southern Taiwan last month.
Lin said construction of the 340-kilometer high-speed railway connecting Taipei and Kaohsiung is nearly half completed, and should be inaugurated as scheduled in October 2005.

Ho Nuan-hsuan, director-general of the Bureau of Taiwan High-Speed Rail under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, said that once the line is completed, the western part of Taiwan will be transformed into a "one day traffic network."

Ho said that with the completion of the high-speed railway, it will take 40 minutes to travel from Taipei to Taichung, 45 minutes from Taichung to Kaohsiung, and less than 90 minutes from Taipei to Kaohsiung.

With trains departing Kaohsiung from 6 a.m. to midnight every day, residents in western parts of Taiwan will save time and the increased flow of passengers will stimulate the economy of the entire island, ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT ASKS OVERSEAS CHINESE TO SUPPORT PRESIDENT CHEN
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 13 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu appealed to overseas Chinese Wednesday to support President Chen Shui-bian, saying that a second four-year term will give Chen the opportunity to improve upon his work.
Lu made the remarks while paying a visit to the Republic of China-Panama Cultural Center. She had met a group of Panamanian elite woman executives in a breakfast gathering earlier the same day.

Pointing out that President Chen has done his best to wipe out corruption since assuming the presidency in May 2000, Lu said she strongly believes that Chen will do a better job if he is given the chance to serve a second term. The vice president called for continued backing for Chen from ROC nationals abroad, and said Taiwan will have a brighter future under Chen's leadership.
Despite her staunch campaigning to sell Chen, Lu also said overseas ROC nationals must have confidence in the government no matter who is elected head of state next year.

"Taiwan expatriates should have faith in the choice of their compatriots at home through an election and continue backing the government," she said, because "the foundation of the ROC government is built upon democracy and progress and a transition of power is a normal practice in a full-fledged democratic society."

Lu also thanked local ethnic Chinese and people from Taiwan for their long-standing concern for Taiwan, particularly the donations they made after the country was devastated by the Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake.
Chen Wu-hu, chairman of the Taiwan Businessmen's Association in Panama, pledged firm support for Taiwan and said Lu's visit has helped consolidate two-way relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDICATORS POINT TO ECONOMIC RECOVERY FOR TAIWAN: CEPD

TEXT.P: The economy of Taiwan is taking a turn for the better, with economic growth expected to reach 3.52 percent this year, an official of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Thursday.

CEPD Vice Chairwoman Ho Mei-yueh said in a briefing to President Chen Shui-bian on the current economic situation that Taiwan's economy is recovering, as can be seen from such indications as growing export trade, increasing investment in Taiwan by overseas Chinese and foreign investors, declining unemployment rates, and the improvement of the financial system.
The CEPD official predicted that the economic growth rate in 2007 will reach 5.01 percent, and per capita income will climb to US$15,212 the same year.
The government is taking steps to expand public spending, make good use of its resources, and sharpen the competition edge in world markets, she said. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI AEROSPACE TECHNOLOGY SHOW OPENS

TEXT.P: The Taipei Aerospace Technology Show opened Thursday with 61 aerospace companies from the United States, the United Kingdom, France, the Czech Republic, Malaysia, Thailand, Singapore, and Taiwan participating.

Speaking at the opening ceremony of the four-day exhibition, Minister without Portfolio Tsay Ching-yan of the Executive Yuan encouraged foreign aerospace companies to set up their research and development centers in Taiwan.

He said that Taiwan's aerospace and national defense industries employ more than 30,000 people, and that Taiwan is very suitable for producing a great variety of precision spare parts in small quantities for the aerospace industry. He also said that Taiwan has earned some experience in producing these parts from the production of Taiwan's own Ching Kuo jet fighters.

Exhibitors at 345 booths at the Taipei World Trade Center showed various kinds of new aerospace vehicles, aircraft engines, aviation guidance systems and equipment, flight controls and monitoring systems, aerospace industrial materials, airport facilities, and national defense equipment and technologies. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT TO BE ESTABLISHED IN CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The government plans to develop Ching Chuan Kang Air Base in Taichung County into an international airport, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said Thursday.

Speaking at a briefing to President Chen Shui-bian on the government's plan to develop a north-south high-speed railway network, Lin said the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan will continue to serve as Taiwan's main international airport. The new one in central Taiwan will serve as an auxiliary international airport.

The new airport will be developed in three stages, Lin said. When the first stage of development is completed in January, 2004, the Shui Nan Airport in Taichung City will be closed and replaced by the new airport. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAY RECONFIRMS FRIENDSHIP AND SUPPORT FOR ROC

TEXT.P: Paraguayan President-elect Nicanor Duarte Frutos said Wednesday that his country will continue to support the Republic of China in the international community.

Duarte, who will be inaugurated as President of Paraguay on Aug. 15, made the pledge during a banquet he gave in honor of ROC Vice President Annette Lu, who is in the country to attend Duarte's inauguration on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.
Duarte said Paraguay will enter a new era when he assumes the duty of president.
He said that Paraguay and the Republic of China have long been friends and that the Paraguayan government and people appreciate the assistance given by the Republic of China in the past years.
Paraguay has supported the Republic of China in the world community for a long time, and will continue to do so out of a sense of justice, he said.

Vice President Lu said it is the honor of the Republic of China to be able to cooperate with the Paraguayan government and people in striving for a bright and common future. "We will work hand in hand with one heart," she said. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO INCREASE PRODUCTION OF FLAT PANEL DISPLAY

TEXT.P: The production of flat panel display (FPD) in Taiwan amounted to NT$310 billion (US$9.01 billion) in 2002, and is expected to increase to NT$1.37 trillion in 2006, a high-ranking official said Thursday.

Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i said at a seminar on Taiwan's FPD-manufacturing industry that the government has attached great importance to the development of the industry and has mapped out plans to facilitate its development.
The government is planning to establish a science-based industrial park in Taichung and a new industrial zone in Taipei county to accommodate the FPD-producing industry, he added.
The government is trying to encourage foreign companies to invest in the new industry, he said. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION OF IC DESIGNERS TOPS AMONG HSINCHU SCIENCE PARK WORKERS

TEXT.P: The average production of IC designers in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park reached NT$9.37 million (US$272,000) in the first half of this year, the highest among high-tech specialists working in the industrial park.

According to statistics compiled by the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration, the average production of the workers in the park stood at NT$3.73 million, an increase of 8 percent over the same period last year.

Among the six major industries in the park in northern Taiwan, the average production of a worker in the sector of computers and peripherals topped the list at NT$4.75 million in the first half of the year, followed by telecommunications at NT$4.1 million, IC related products at NT$4.03 million, precision machinery at NT$2.91 million, optoelectronics at NT$1.94 million, and biotechnology at NT$1.16 million.
In the IC industry, the average production of an IC designer reached NT$9.37 million, while that of a worker in wafer production totaled NT$3.77 million.

Among the newcomers in the park during the last half year, 18 companies were dedicated to the IC industry, eight were in computers and peripherals, three were in biotechnology, two were in telecommunications, two were in optoelectronics, and one was in precision machinery.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUMS ARE THE RIGHT OF A SOVEREIGN NATION: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that faced with mainland China's continued efforts to box in Taiwan, Taipei must travel its own path and hold a referendum.
The president made the remarks while leading editors in chief of local media to Miaoli, northern Taiwan on the final day of his two-day "witnessing the progress of Taiwan" tour.
The president said that if Taiwan can participate in the World Health Organization (WHO) as it wishes, then of course there would be no need to hold a referendum on the issue.

He stressed that health care should know no borders, and that it is only natural that Taiwan should participate in the WHO, but mainland China has used every means to block Taiwan's entry. "We have to pursue our own road, " Chen said, adding that participation in the WHO is the right of the 23 million people on Taiwan.
The president also said that a referendum is a basic human right, but that referendums in Taiwan will not include a vote on sovereignty -- an issue which the United States has expressed concern over.

The president said that after Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, traveled to the United States recently to explain the referendum issue, Washington expressed its understanding and respect.

He said that as an independent, sovereign state, it is only natural for Taiwan's people to exercise their basic human rights. "The United States will not interfere with our internal affairs, " Chen said.

The president has made it clear that his administration will hold a referendum on the fate of the partially completed Fourth Nuclear Power Plant and Taiwan's participation in the WHO to show the world clearly the will of the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SAYS ACHIEVEMENTS ARE FOR THE PEOPLE, NOT FOR VOTES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that projects that his administration has undertaken have been solely for the good of the people and had nothing to do with winning political support.

On the final day of his two-day tour of Taiwan with a group of journalists, the president disputed his critics' claims that his political agenda has been aimed more at winning voters' support than serving the interests of the nation as a whole.
Chen said the central idea of his political philosophy is that "The majority should take care of the minority and the privileged should take care of the underprivileged."

Boasting that he set up the country's first Aboriginal Affairs Council at the Taipei City Government while he served as mayor, Chen said, " The Central Government followed suit by setting up a similar council only nine month later. The Kaohsiung City Government and the Taiwan Provincial Government also set up similar organization after that."

Chen said that these acts did not translate into votes in any election. The president also cited another example: the establishment of the Council for Hakka Affairs under the Executive Yuan and the launch of an all-Hakka television station.
The president said he is very pleased with the results of the things that he has done for minorities, regardless of the impact on the popularity of his party or himself.

Opening these new agencies went against the basic principle of the administration to simplify the structure of the government and improve its efficiency, but taking care of minorities takes precedence over these considerations on the government's agenda, the president said.

The president also gave the efficiency of his administration glowing reviews, saying that his government has done its best to ensure the success of the country's first high-speed railway, which was contracted out to a private company to build and operate with its own capital, and he is pleased that the project is progressing well and is on schedule.
Chen also pointed to the Taipei-Ilan Highway, which he said will open in 2005 because of the good management of his administration.

Although neither the high-speed railway project nor the highway were started during Chen's term as president, he said he was glad his administration has been doing its part to ensure their timely completion.

This, the president said, also highlights the need for his re-election. Only by continuing on as president can he oversee the completion of the many important projects that his administration has begun.
Citing Su Chen-chang, the magistrate of Taipei County, as an example, the president said many of Su's best achievements emerged only during his second term.

As to the widening gap between the rich and the poor, the president laid the blame on the changing social structure: the increasing number of elderly and single parent families, and the emergence of new hi-tech industries which create a class of nouveaux riches.
However, Chen said his government has effectively addressed this problem in many ways. The president did not elaborate but to say that education is the best investment to overcome poverty.

The president, who once lambasted the nation's journalists for being biased against him, urged the group of editors in chief to pay more attention to the positive side of all of Taiwan's society and not simply gather news from the isolation of their Taipei offices. The editors should be keeping their fingers on the pulse of the nation to better reflect the views of the public, Chen said.
The president and the chief editors ended their trip late Thursday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WILL NOT TAKE MILITARY ACTION AGAINST NORTH KOREA: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that he believes that the situation on the Korean Peninsula will remain stable and that the United States will not take military action against North Korea.

Chen said that according to information he has received thus far, the United States will not take military action but use diplomatic means to solve the standoff with North Korea over Pyongyang's suspected development of nuclear weapons.
The president was replying to questions in Miaoli from editors in chief who have been accompanying him on a two-day, around-the-island tour.

Discussions on the North Korean situation will be undertaken by six nations Aug. 27-29 in Beijing, which Chen said indicates the willingness of the international community to address the issue in a peaceful manner.
Representatives from the United States, Russia, Japan, mainland China, and North and South Korea will participate in the talks.
He also said that Taiwan has a full range of opinions regarding regional security with the United States, Japan and other countries.
The president added that his administration has contingency plans in place to deal with any possible scenario.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOURTH ROC-CENTRAL AMERICA SUMMIT SLATED TO OPEN AUG. 21

TEXT.P: The Fourth Summit of the Heads of States and Governments of the Republic of China, Central America, the Dominican Republic and Belize is slated to open Aug. 21 in Taipei, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien announced Thursday.

In a prelude heralding the largest summit to be held by the grouping to date, Chien said the ROC government hopes to devise concrete measures with the participating countries to help the ROC take part in international organizations, including in the System of Central American Integration as a non-regional member, to forge closer ties with friendly countries.

Ambassadors from eight ROC diplomatic allies in Central America were also present to stump for the event, which will bring together heads of state from Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Nicaragua and Panama, as well as the prime minister of Belize, the vice president of Honduras, and the presidential secretary-general of the Dominican Republic on behalf of their respective presidents.

The heads of state and envoys will sign a joint communique following the summit, while President Chen Shui-bian will also ink a free trade agreement (FTA) with Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso -- the first-ever for Taiwan.

Costa Rican Ambassador Oscar Alvarez Araya said Central American countries are negotiating FTAs among them and with the United States, but added that signing such an accord with Taiwan has always been high on the agenda of these countries to boost prosperity and progress -- the theme of the upcoming summit.
On the sidelines of the summit, a "2003 Central American Coffee Festival" will be held, adding an exotic atmosphere and flavor to the political activity.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO BE MORE RATIONAL AFTER TAIWAN'S ELECTION: DPP OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Mainland China will talk with Taiwan more rationally after the next presidential election next year, an official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Thursday.

Chen Chung-hsin, director of the DPP's Department of Chinese Affairs, made the remarks while elaborating on President Chen Shui-bian's statement that his administration will consult with mainland China on direct transportation links after the presidential election, and that cross-strait links could be realized by the end of 2004.

Chen Chung-hsin brought up one of the president's "five-noes" as pronounce in his inaugural speech -- no referendum on the future status of the nation-- and said that Taiwan has consistently promoted reconciliation with Beijing. He also said that cross-strait direct transportation links are a path to be pursued in a national economic conference, and the president's recent remarks are only a reiteration of his long-held stance.
He noted that mainland China is only paying lip service when they say that they want direct trade, postal and transportation links.
He said that this is because mainland China would not want cross-strait relations to make any progress before the presidential election in March 20, 2004.

Chen Chung-hsin said that the president believes that after the presidential election, Beijing will have to face squarely Taiwan's leader with a new mandate of the people and will only then adopt a more rational attitude to consultations with Taiwan.
Taiwan cannot accept that the links be defined as "domestic routes" under Beijing's "one China" policy, he added.
The DPP wants to shelve political squabbles now so that negotiations on direct transportation links can be conducted smoothly, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF CONTAINERS HANDLED AT KAOHSIUNG HARBOR ON THE RISE

TEXT.P: The number of containers handled at southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung Harbor in the first seven months reached 5.09 million, an increase of 6.9 percent over the same period last year, according to statistics released by the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau.
Bureau officials said they believe that the total number of containers handled at the harbor will break the nine million mark this year.

The statistics showed that the number of ships arriving at and leaving from the port in the first seven months totaled 21,770, while the weight of cargo handled at the port reached 247.05 million tons, a growth of 7 percent over the same period of 2002.

As the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau is planning to expand the port's second container yard, the officials estimated that once completed, the port can increase the annual number of containers handled by 620,000, creating some 1,600 additional jobs.
After completing this project, the officials said, they will be more confident in facing strong competition from rival ports -- Busan in South Korea, and Shanghai and Shenzhen in mainland China.

Meanwhile, the number of containers handled in the first seven months at Taiwan's northern Keelung Harbor reached 1.13 million TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent units) , an increase of 3.8 percent over the same period last year, while the weight of cargo managed totaled 52.62 million tons, a growth of 4.28 percent over the same period in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CHAIRMAN APPOINTED FOR FIRST FINANCIAL HOLDING COMPANY

TEXT.P: Hsieh Shou-fu, general manager of the Taishin Financial Holding Co., will assume the post of chairman of the First Financial Holding Co., Minister of Finance Lin Chuan announced Thursday.
Hsieh, 64, will take over the post Friday from Jerome Chen, whose resignation was approved by Lin a day earlier.

Lin said his choice of Hsieh from the private banking sector was aimed at injecting a new lease on life to First Commercial Bank, one of the oldest state-run banks in Taiwan and an offshoot of First Financial Holding Co.

The minister expressed his hope that Hsieh, a veteran but low-key financial expert who had worked in leading private companies, such as Taishin International Bank, Texas Instrument and others, would create broader and fresher horizons for First Financial Holding Co.
Lin had said Wednesday after confirming Chen's resignation that he would look for a visionary successor with an international outlook to replace Chen.

Lin's approval of Chen's surprise resignation sent ripples through the political and financial sectors because of his long-time close links with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and President Chen Shui-bian.
Chen tendered his resignation to Lin Tuesday, offering to step down from the post in which he had served for more than three years due to "personal careers plans."

Rumors have circulated that Chen's resignation had something to do with the company's issuance of global deposit receipts to collect US$515 million in funds from abroad. The move was harshly attacked by the outside world as trying to benefit a vested group.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER THANKS TAIWANESE NGOS FOR ASSISTANCE TO IRAQ

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien bestowed a citation to representatives of Taiwan's 19 non-governmental organizations (NGOs) Thursday for their assistance to Iraqis made refugees from the U.S.-led war.

Among the people who attended the informal gathering organized by Chien were representatives from Taiwan's 19 social groups and Mercy Corps, a U.S.-based charitable organization which helped arrange in May the transport of materials donated by Taiwan people to Iraqi refugees.

Chien noted that through this campaign, dubbed "Love from Taiwan" to war-torn Iraq, it has established a cooperation mechanism between the government and the private sector in offering humanitarian assistance to the world.

Representatives from Lions Clubs International and Kiwanis International ROC District said they were pleased to have the opportunities to send love to Iraq, and hoped that the love from Taiwan will continue in other places around the world.
By the joint efforts of the 19 NGOs and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the first stage of "Love from Taiwan" campaign was initiated in April 9 and concluded in May with a warm response.
The campaign has collected NT$32 million (US$930,000) in cash and 13 TEU (twenty-foot equivalent units) containers of relief goods, including mineral water, powdered milk, salt, sugar and blankets.

Those donated materials, which have arrived in Turkey, will be shipped to northern Iraq, and the Mercy Corps will be responsible for the distribution of the relief goods, while the donated cash will be used in the reconstruction work in some Iraqi communities, in which members of Taiwan's NGOs will personally participate.
Furthermore, Chien, on behalf of ROC government, signed a memorandum with Mercy Corps representatives to donate 5,000 metric tons of rice to Ethiopia, where many people die of famine.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLAWED EDUCATION REFORM A VESTIGE OF FORMER ADMINISTRATION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that flaws in education reform are a result of the previous administration over which he had no control, but that the current government has been making inroads into getting the reforms on track.

Chen said that the reform program was instigated years before he took office and that this three-year-old administration has been examining and reviewing education policies to fine tune where needed and to revamp when necessary.

The president also pointed out that his government did not introduce the reform plans and has been merely trying to patch up a less-than-perfect system. The public should be aware that laying the blame for problem areas in the education system should not be laid at the doorstep of the current administration, Chen said.
However, Chen said, his government would not shirk its responsibility to fix the system.

The president also mentioned tuition costs, which have been rising. This, he said, was also a problem inherited from the previous administration, but that actually over the last three years, tuition has only increased by an average of 3 percent for public universities and 0.8 percent for private universities.

Contrast this with the average rise of 10 percent for public universities and 3 percent for private universities in the decade before he took office and the public can see that the current administration is tackling the issue effectively, Chen said.
The president said that his administration had not aggravated the tuition problem; instead, it has gone to great lengths to solve it, such as persuading banks to offer low-interest loans to students.

Turning his attention to cross-strait affairs, the president said that critics were incorrect when they said that his policies toward mainland China were "zigzagging." He said he has always been both firm and pragmatic when dealing with Beijing.

Chen pointed out that his promise in his inaugural speech that he would not seek independence for Taiwan hinged on the condition that mainland China renounce any intention to take the island by force.
Unfortunately, Chen said, Beijing has never given up this attitude and the 350-odd missiles targeting Taiwan across the Strait is glaring evidence of this. "We should never ignore this," he said.

The president said his statement that "there is one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait" is based on the fact that Taiwan - using whatever name you wish -- is a sovereign state and not a part of the People's Republic of China. "Why should we be afraid to speak the truth?" he asked.

However, the president said, his insistence on Taiwan's sovereignty should not be misunderstood as reluctance to normalize the country's ties with mainland China, because his pragmatist view in terms of dealing with Beijing.

Noting that the market value of Taiwan's stocks fell 40 percent during his three years in office, Chen said the island has held its own against other countries, such as the United States, whose stocks listed on the NASDAQ have given up two-thirds of their value during the same time.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN SCIENCE PARK EXCEEDS NT DOLLAR 1 TRILLION

TEXT.P: A total of 112 manufacturers have been approved to invest in the Southern Taiwan Science-based Industrial Park in Tainan so far this year, with investments worth NT$1.114 trillion (US$32 billion).
According to the Southern Taiwan Science-based Industrial Park Administration, among the more than 100 high-tech companies, 46 have begun production.

In the 29 companies dedicated to optoelectronics, Japanese companies account for eight. In the IC industry, UMC has begun mass production of their 12-inch wafers, while its biggest rival -- Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. - is still deliberating their operational plan.

The statistics from the park also showed that the combined sales of the companies in the park reached NT$60.87 billion in the first half of this year, an increase of 25 percent over the same period of last year. Administration officials estimated that the total sales this year will grow by 50 percent over 2002.

Among the major categories, the sales of the optoelectronics industry totaled NT$35.57 billion in the first half of this year, accounting for 58.4 percent of the total sales and a growth of 38.44 percent over the same period of last year, followed by the IC industry at NT$23.53 billion, accounting for 38.6 percent of total sales.
Meanwhile, sales of precision machinery, and the telecommunications and biotechnology sectors have risen significantly and are posed to be the star industries in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOT TO BE DOWNGRADED IS TAIWAN'S BOTTOM LINE ON CROSS-STRAIT LINKS

TEXT.P: Not to be downgraded nor marginalized is Taiwan's bottom line in cross-strait talks on opening transport, trade and mail links between the two side of the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan's top mainland policy planner said Thursday.

Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , made the remarks following an announcement of three steps toward the opening of these links by President Chen Shui-bian a day earlier.

The Republic of China, which is the official designation of Taiwan, is an independent and sovereign nation and is separate from the People's Republic of China, Tsai said, adding that President Chen's assertion of one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait is a description of reality and is aimed at preventing Taiwan from being downgraded.
Based on this assertion and the principle of equality, she continued, Taiwan has actively promoted the opening of direct cross-strait transport links.
Taiwan will never accept the opening of the "three links" under the "one China" principle set by Beijing, she reiterated.

She described the three-step program announced by President Chen as very pragmatic and suggested that if Beijing really wants to open the links with Taiwan it should first set aside its political prerequisite to pave the way for holding cross-strait talks.

Speaking with a group of editors in chief from local media, Chen said Wednesday in Changhua, central Taiwan that the three steps are preparation, negotiation and realization, which will lead to the opening of the "three links" by the end of next year.
The first step is already going on, the second will begin after the presidential election on March 20, 2000 and hopefully the third will be realized sometime by the end of 2004, according to Chen.

The timetable for the three steps may not be as clear cut as the order in which the president spoke of them, Tsai said, adding that they may overlap and that opening the links can be done little by little while cross-strait talks are going on.
An evaluation report on opening the so-called "three links" in Chinese and English by the MAC will be made public Friday, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, USA AND JAPAN SCORE WINS IN YOUTH BASEBALL CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: Taiwan, the United States and Japan scored wins Thursday in the intermediate round of the XI "AA" World Youth Baseball Championship being held in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.
Taiwan won over its arch rival Cuba 14-8 in the nine-inning competition, while the United States beat Australia 15-4 and Japan blanked Indonesia 24-0 in the cross-group games.
The championship, which opened Aug. 8, was attended by nine teams from nine countries divided into two groups in the first round of competitions.
