DOC.HEADLINE: AMPHETAMINE FACTORY UNCOVERED IN KAOHSIUNG ALONG WITH 126KG OF DRUGS

TEXT.P: An underground factory turning out amphetamines was uncovered in Kaohsiung County Thursday. The owner of the factory, Lin Tai-hsiang, was taken into custody and 126 kilograms of the illegal drug was seized.
Agents from the Investigation Bureau and the Taipei Military Police Squad raided the factory located in an upper-class apartment in Niausung, Kaohsiung County Thursday.

It is the seventh illegal amphetamine factory discovered by the Investigation Bureau this year. The amphetamines seized by the bureau during the last month and a half has reached more than 1,500 kilograms.
Drug agents believed many drug kingpins have relocated their amphetamine factories in mainland to Taiwan recently because of mainland authorities' crackdown on drugs.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER MEETS TAIWAN'S TEAM TO COMPETE AT WORLD UNIVERSITY GAMES

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun gave his blessings Thursday to Taiwan's team for the 2003 World University Games, or Universiade, to be held in Daegu, South Korea.
After giving them a national flag, the premier urged them to do justice to their country.
The team has already been training for a month. They will leave Aug. 17 for Daegu for the games, which will open Aug. 21 and close on Aug. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 15, or the 18th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1057: Macbeth, King of Scotland who ascended to the throne after killing his cousin King Duncan in battle in 1040, is killed by Duncan's son Malcolm at Lumphanan, near Aberdeen. The legend of his rise to power and his reign are the basis of Shakespeare's tragedy "Macbeth."
1769: Napoleon Bonaparte, military leader and the emperor of France from 1804 to 1815, is born in Ajaccio, Corsica.
1900: The Kuang Hsu Emperor and his aunt, the Empress Dowager Tzu-hsi, flee to northwestern China from Beijing as the capital is captured by the forces of eight foreign powers during the Boxer Uprising.
1914: The 82-km-long Panama Canal, connecting the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, is opened after 35 years of construction.
1945: The Republic of China Legislative Yuan unanimously approves the United Nations Charter.
1947: India gains independence from Britain with Jawaharlal Nehru as the first prime minister.
1948: President Syngman Rhee formally proclaims South Korea as the Republic of Korea.
1949: A Southeast China Governor's Office is established in Taipei with Gen. Chen Cheng as governor.
1959: The ROC Army receives Nike-Hercules surface-to-air missiles from the United States under a military aid program.
1960: The Council of Grand Justices of the Judicial Yuan rules that, according to Article 77 of the ROC Constitution, courts of all levels shall be placed under the jurisdiction of the Judicial Yuan.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes the Congo (Brazzaville) Republic.
1962: The Netherlands signs a treaty agreeing to Indonesian rule of Irian Jaya (Netherlands New Guinea).
1967: Kung Hsiang-hsi, former ROC premier and finance minister, dies in the United States at the age of 88.
1974: South Korean President Park Chung Hee's wife is shot dead by an assassin in an attempt on Park's life.
1976: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo urges college students to contribute their wisdom and energy to the country as he presides over the closing ceremony of the summer vacation military training program of college students at the Cheng-kung base in Taichung.
1979: Direct dialing service to the United States, Hong Kong and Singapore is initiated by the Taiwan Telecommunications Administration.
1980: The wreckage of the Titanic, the British luxury liner which sank after hitting an iceberg during its maiden voyage to New York on April 14, 1912, is found laying on the ocean floor 3,657 meters below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean.
1981: The First ROC-Indian Cultural and Economic Seminar on India's 34th Independence Day is held in Taipei.
1981: The Republic of China and Saint Vincent establish formal diplomatic relations.
1985: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa accepts the resignation of Finance Minister Loh Jen-kong.
1986: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa, in an interview with Saudi Arabian journalists from the Okaz Daily and Al-Bilad Daily, points out that the achievements of the ROC over the past thirty-odd years has won the nation international recognition and made it an indispensable force against communist expansion in the Asia-Pacific region.
1990: President Mikhail Gorbachev restores Soviet citizenship to Nobel Prize-winning author Alexander Solshenitsyn, who was exiled to the West in 1974 for his novels attacking Stalinism.
1995: The Chinese mainland begins eleven days of tactical guided missile exercises by firing live artillery shells into the sea 136 kilometers north of Taiwan.
1999: Chiao Jen-ho, chairman of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Commission, donates US$100,000 and 20 computers to the Chinese Benevolent Federation in San Francisco.
2000: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture announces that beef imports from Argentina and Paraguay will be temporarily banned due to an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in the two South American countries.
2001: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party formally establishes the Taiwan-Japan Goodwill Association to further bolster bilateral ties between the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who acquires truth is one who finds out what is good and holds fast to it."

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET UNVEILS ASSESSMENT ON DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT TRANSPORT LINKS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet unveiled the nation's first official assessment report on the impact of opening direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait Friday.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun presided over a news conference where the 20,000-word evaluation report was formally released. Senior officials, including Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-lung, Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Tuei, were also present.

The report stressed that the most important issue regarding direct cross-strait transportation doesn't lie in whether the links should be established or not. It instead lies in how such links should be forged, the report said.
According to the report, direct cross-strait transportation cannot not be subject to any experiment because at stake is Taiwan's survival.
Well-preparations and a step-by-step approach are the key strategies in tackling the direct links issue, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS CLAIM BEIJING USING TAIWAN FISHING VESSELS FOR SPYING

TEXT.P: A legislative subgroup on Friday urged the government to be on alert against what it called the systematic use by mainland China of Taiwan fishing vessels to collect military information.

The Alliance Against Selling out Taiwan said in a press release that Beijing has already recruited several Taiwan fishing vessels to spy on Taiwan's upcoming major military exercises, the Hankuang No. 19 exercise, in Ilan, northeast of Taiwan.

Legislator Trong Chai of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , who is a member of the alliance, said that security authorities, while checking on the activities of fishing and commercial ships, unexpectedly discovered that some Taiwan fishing and commercial ships have been bribed and used by mainland authorities.

He said that some of the Taiwan ships that have carried out spy missions for the mainland provide to Beijing such information as the most vulnerable spots in Taiwan's seashore defenses and the most easily accesible spots for making landings.
The ships also engage in such illicit operations as transporting illegal immigrants and other smuggling activities, he said.

DPP Legislator Chiang Chao-yi, another member of the alliance, said that Beijing registers all Taiwan fishing ships that have accepted spying missions and allows them to travel freely to any mainland fishing, commercial or military harbors.
DPP Legislator Lee Cheng-nan noted that Taiwan's security authorities suspect that a lot of Taiwan gangsters have traveled in and out of Taiwan through this channel.
Independent Legislator Lin Chin-hsin urged the government to be on guard against possible spying activities by some Taiwan fishing ships during the upcoming Hankuang No. 19 exercise in Ilan.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE IN DENMARK URGE KOFI ANNAN TO HELP TAIWAN'S U.N. BID
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By M.T. Liu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A group of six overseas Chinese associations in Denmark recently sent a joint letter to U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan, urging him to help Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations.

In the letter, the associations requested that the U.N. chief use his influence to manifest the spirit of equality and rights set forth in the U.N. charter and to support Taiwan's activities for joining the leading international organization.

The letter said that Taiwan's 15 diplomatic allies have jointly requested that the issue of the island's right to representation in the United Nations should be placed on the provisional agenda of the organization's 58th general assembly scheduled to kick off in mid-September.

The letter also again reminded the world that it should pay proper attention to the rights of the 23 million people of Taiwan and to the importance of upholding the founding aims of the United Nations.

While explaining why Taiwan should be included in the United Nations, the letter said that according to the U.N. charter's principle of universality regarding membership, Taiwan has the right to participate in the organization because it is a democratic and peace-loving country.

It also noted that U.N. Resolution 2758 gave Beijing a seat in the United Nations but that the question of Taiwan's representation in the organization has still not been dealt, leading to island being the only country excluded from the organization. It added that this not only violates the spirit of the U.N. charter, it also deprives the Taiwan people of their rights.

The letter stressed that neither Taiwan nor mainland China is under the jurisdiction of the other. It also noted that Taiwan has long respected the U.N. idea and has always done it utmost to support all matters in line with the founding goals of the organization, adding that the island has also provided many countries with humanitarian assistance.
If Taiwan can join the United Nations, the island, with its important strategic position, will certainly contribute to international peace and security, the letter said.

The United Nations should not disregard Taiwan's existence and should not exclude the island from the organization, the leaders of the associations also said in the letter, expressing the hope that the U.N. secretary-general would support Taiwan's bid to join the organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANCE OF RAIN IN NORTHERN AND NORTHEASTERN TAIWAN INCREASES

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau said Friday that, due to the arrival of a weather front, the chance of rain in the northern and northeastern parts of Taiwan will increase on Friday.

The weather bureau forecast that on Friday there is a 70 percent chance of rain in the northern part of the island and 60 percent in central and southern Taiwan. The temperatures may reach 33 degrees Celsius in northern Taiwan and 34 degrees in the central and southern parts of the island. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT TRANSPORT LINKS WILL BE CATALYST FOR 'THREE LINKS': MAC

TEXT.P: The opening of direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait will be a catalyst for the "direct three links, " Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Friday.
The "direct three links" refers to direct cross-strait trade, postal and transportation links.

The opening of direct cross-strait transportation links will also be conducive to an overall normalization of business and trade relations between the two sides of the strait, Tsai said at a news conference where the MAC-drafted Assessment Report on the Impact of Direct Cross-strait Transportation was released. Premier Yu Shyi-kun presided over the press conference.

Tsai said, however, that whether and when Taiwan will implement the direct transportation links will only be decided after comprehensive and careful assessments on every aspect concerned are carried out.

She added that the issue of direct transportation links is not purely a business problem and that it also involves issues concerning political and economic security. Technically, she added, the relevant flag and port usage issues also need to be tackled through negotiations.
The opening of direct cross-strait transportation links is a crucial issue concerning Taiwan's existence and development, and it is by no means subject to experiment, said the assessment.
Crucially important as it is, the issue of direct cross-strait transportation links should thus be handled as carefully and prudently as possible, according to the assessment report.
Preparations should continue and actual implementation should be carried out in a step-by-step manner so that the nation's interests and the people's welfare can be secured, the report said.

Prominent figures of Yu's team at the press conference also included Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min; Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei; Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long; and National Security Bureau Deputy Director-General Wang Chin-wang.

The publicizing of the assessment report came on the heels of an announcement made by President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday that he will see to it that direct cross-strait transportation links are implemented by the end of 2004.

President Chen said the MAC has completed an assessment report on direct cross-strait transportation links, which features a three-phase implementation plan, including preparation, negotiation and implementation phases.

According to Chen, in the "preparation" phase, both sides of the strait will face squarely the planning for cargo interlinks across the Taiwan Strait, while the "negotiation" phase is envisaged as kicking off after the March 20, 2004 presidential election, and the "implementation" phase will begin by the end of 2004.
Earlier Friday morning, MAC Chairwoman Tsai briefed Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and legislative caucuses of various political parties on highlights of the assessment reports.
Tsai said that the opening of direct transportation links is not an issue of "whether or not," but a question of "how."

She said the president's forecast regarding the implementation of the direct links by the end of next year is rational and reasonable as following the 2004 presidential election, there should be less political overtones surrounding cross-strait negotiations on direct links and the talks can be expected to be conducted more smoothly.

She added that Taiwan's four international ports are all included in the direct transportation links map, while Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan and Hsiaokang International Airport in Kaohsiung will be the designated airports for handling direct transportation links affairs.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng commented later that the assessment report had not provided the legislators or the nation with details about the "three-phase" implementation plan as President Chen mentioned Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPPORTING MEASURES ARE IMPORTANT TO DIRECT TRANSPORTATION: YU

TEXT.P: The opening of direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait will bring fresh opportunities for Taiwan's development as long as the program is conducted with well-devised supporting measures, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday.
Supporting measures will include cross-strait dialogue conducted under the principles of equality and dignity, Yu said.
Yu made the remarks at a press conference during which the Executive Yuan publicized the report on the Assessment of the Impact of Direct Cross-Strait Transportation.

The chiefs of the relevant ministries were present at the press conference. They included Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , which formulates Taiwan's mainland China policies; Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min; Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long; Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei; National Security Bureau Deputy Director General Wang Chin-wang; and others.

Yu said that actively promoting the normalization of cross-strait relations and the building of a framework for stable and peaceful exchanges across the strait have been major administrative targets of President Chen Shui-bian, adding that the president explicitly spelled out his "direct cross-strait transportation links" policy last September.
The targets have since served as a guide for the Cabinet, which has in turn completed planning and materialized relevant policies step by step, Yu noted.
Quoting a public opinion poll conducted by the Executive Yuan earlier this year, Yu said a majority of the people in Taiwan support "conditional" direct cross-strait transportation links.
The poll revealed that most of the Taiwan people have a certain degree of concern about the potential impact of direct cross-strait transportation, Yu said.

He added that the poll finding also indicated that it is the government's duty to conduct a thorough and comprehensive assessment of every aspect of the issue and to devise coping measures to meet the people's needs and requests.
He said preparatory work and transitional measures are crucial to allow Taiwan to accumulate skills and experience before actually kicking off the direct cross-strait transportation links.

For the preparatory work, Yu noted that relevant agencies of the Cabinet have started to work in five major areas: namely amending statutes and regulations concerning cross-strait links; solidifying Taiwan's national security network; stepping up readjustment of Taiwan's industrial and business structures; building a social security network; and strengthening quarantine policy and measures.

Also commenting Thursday on the imminent publicizing of the Assessment of the Impact of Direct Cross-Strait Transportation, Yu said that the Executive Yuan has mapped out policies and measures for coping with the needs that are expected to arise once the direct links are opened.

Major features of the plan include measures to sharpen the Taiwan business and industrial sectors' competitive edge; ways to enable the industrial sectors of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to fairly share their manufacturing niches in a complementary way; and methods to prevent the Taiwan job market from being compromised under the impact of the opening of direct links, Yu noted.
Yu's remarks came on the heels of an announcement made by President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday that he will see to it that direct cross-strait transportation links are implemented by the end of 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRAIGHT FLIGHT BAN UNDER DIRECT LINKS WON'T HAVE IMPACT: AIRLINES

TEXT.P: Two major Taiwan air carriers said Friday that the ban on straight flights across the Taiwan Strait after direct cross-strait transportation links are implemented will not have a significant impact on their operations.

China Airlines (CAL) and EVA Airways made the remarks following the unveiling of an Executive Yuan assessment report earlier in the day on the implementing of direct cross-strait transportation links in which it said straight flights across the strait will be banned out of national security considerations.

The two airlines said they are glad to see that the government is determined to push for the direct cross-strait transportation links and that the ban on straight cross-strait flights will not be a problem.

Han Liang-chung, a CAL public relations official, said that except for flights to Fuzhou, Fujian Province, where direct cross-strait flights would be the shortest, all other flights to destinations in mainland China, such as to Beijing or Guangzhou, have to head northwards or southwards anyway, and the ban will not make that much of a difference.

Nieh Kuo-wei, vice president of EVA Airways, said that direct cross-strait air links will save more time and fuel than landing on the third places, while the ban on flying straight across the strait won't make much difference as there are many air routes from which to choose.

Commenting on the choosing of CKS International Airport as the priority airport for direct cross-strait air links in the assessment report and the listing of Sungshan and Hsiaokang airports as second considerations, Nieh said that CKS airport has good facilities, but that Sungshan Airport in Taipei will be more convenient for passengers.

Han said that if CKS airport is designated as the direct air links airport, it will not only bring benefits to both sides of the Taiwan Strait, it will also help in efforts to transform the airport into an Asia-Pacific operations center.
When air exchanges across the Taiwan Strait become brisk, this is bound to attract transit stops of passengers and cargo between mainland China and the United States and Europe, Han added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 51.99 points to close at 5,488.74.
The bourse opened at 5,491.85 and continued to go up later due to heavy purchases by investors. The index fluctuated between 5471.60 and 5540.0 during trading.
A total of 4.96 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$121.22 billion (US$3.52 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction shares moving up the most at 4.4 percent, followed by cement stocks at 3.2 percent, textile shares at 2.2 percent, plastics and chemicals at 1.7 percent, and electrical issues and foodstuff stocks, both at 1.1 percent. Paper stocks remained unchanged, while financial and insurance issues declined 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 422 to 217, with 132 stocks remaining unchanged. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TAIEX Index futures for September gained 15 points to finish at 5,490, with 6,493 contract transactions, while December futures rose 25 points to close at 5,462, with three contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PUSHES FOR KNOWLEDGE-BASED AGRICULTURE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday Taiwan must develop knowledge-based agriculture to survive ever-growing foreign competition.
Addressing the opening of the 2003 Taiwan Food Carnival, Chen said his administration has devoted much energy to promoting the modernization of local agriculture over the past few years.

Following Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization, Chen said, local farmers have faced strong competition from their foreign counterparts as the domestic food market has been opened wider to foreign products.

Against this backdrop, Chen said, local governments should cooperate with research institutions as well as farmers' and fishery associations in upgrading production technology, marketing, warehousing and distribution systems.

Noting that crop types, quality and brand are key to enhancing added value of agricultural products, Chen said Taiwan must step up development of biotechnology and environment-friendly agricultural technology. "Namely, we must develop knowledge-based agriculture to sharpen our competitive edge," he said, adding that local farmers should not be afraid of market liberalization and competition.
Chen further said his administration is determined to invest more in modernizing agricultural production and developing ecotourism in rural areas to increase farmers' income.
The president also said he hopes the current international food fair can help local farmers tap into overseas markets and expand domestic sales.

More than 200 local foodstuff manufacturers are taking part in the food trade fair, attracting a large number of chain stores operators from Japan, South Korea, Singapore, Hong Kong and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WILLING TO HOLD DIRECT LINKS TALKS ANYTIME IF M'LAND SINCERE: MAC

TEXT.P: A high-ranking mainland affairs official said Friday that Taiwan is willing to hold consultations with mainland China at any time as long as Beijing is sincere.

Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , made the remarks while talking about President Chen Shui-bian's comments Wednesday that he is confident talks between Taipei and Beijing regarding direct transportation links will kick off after next year's presidential election in Taiwan scheduled for March 20.

Tsai said that the president's comments were based on the observation that holding cross-strait consultations before the presidential election might be clouded by politics factors and therefore more difficult to conduct.

While indicating that the sovereignty dispute across the Taiwan Strait can hardly be resolved within a short period of time, the MAC head said that direct transportation links are necessary and should proceed in the short to medium term.

She noted that the government has an obligation to find a formula for direct links consultations and expressed the hope that without harming Taiwan's sovereignty, a flexible formula can be found in the future.

Tsai also expressed the hope that consultations will be held with Beijing on the principles of direct links before December of next year and that consultations on the technical aspects will be conducted after that.

Meanwhile, the MAC head said that the government has gradually opened up Taiwan to mainland Chinese tourists and that talks need to be held with Beijing before Taiwan's tourist market is completely opened to mainland citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITUNG-TAITUNG TOURIST TRAIN KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The "South Bend Star" tourist train linking the southern port city of Kaohsiung to Taitung in eastern Taiwan made its maiden trip Friday.
Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said at an inaugural ceremony that the start of the new train service marks the completion of a round-the-island tourist train program.
The round-island tourist train service is in line with the government's plan to double tourist arrivals to the island by 2008, Lin said.
As part of the program, the Taipei-Fangliao "Kenting Star" tourist train and the Taipei-Taitung "Hot Spring Princess" tourist train began services earlier this year.
The "South Bend Star" tourist train will make stops at Pingtung, Fangliao and Chipen along the way from Kaohsiung to Taitung.

The Taiwan Railway Administration will cooperate with local travel agents in organizing one-day tour packages to attract southern Taiwan residents to sightseeing spots, including many hot springs, in Taitung County, an official said. (by Nocturne Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT TRANSPORTATION MUST BE POINT-TO-POINT: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Direct cross-Taiwan Strait transport links must follow the "point-to-point and fixed route" principles, Defense Minister Tang Yiau-min said Friday.

Speaking at a news conference where the nation's first assessment report on the impact of direct cross-strait transportation was unveiled, Tang said straight shipments or flights across the Taiwan Strait will have a grave impact on Taiwan's security as mainland China has never forsaken its hostility toward Taiwan.

According to Beijing's defense white paper, Tang said, mainland authorities will never renounce the use of force against Taiwan and will not allow the current separation of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to continue indefinitely.
Worse still, Tang said, mainland China has adjusted its military deployment by placing emphasis on its southeastern coastal region that lies opposite Taiwan.

Tang said mainland China has deployed more guided ballistic missiles and new types of fighters, warships and submarines in its southeastern provinces, and the People's Liberation Army has conducted three-dimensional combined services drills targeting Taiwan regularly.
Mainland China's capability to launch an attack on Taiwan has reached a level that can no longer be overlooked.
Noting that the Taiwan Strait provides a natural shelter to Taiwan, Tang said straight cross-strait flights will pose a grave threat to Taiwan's security.

Tang pointed out that the distance between Taiwan's Hsinchu and mainland China's Pingtan in Fujian Province is only 70 nautical miles. It would take only three to five minutes for mainland jet fighters to reach Taiwan should Beijing launch a surprise air strike against Taiwan, Tang said.

For the sake of maintaining national security, Tang said opening direct cross-strait air links must abide by the "point-to-point and fixed routes" principles under which cross-strait flights are banned and detours are required.
Meanwhile, Ministry of National Defense (MND) officials said opening direct cross-strait transportation will have a great impact on national security.

Initial estimates show that the MND will have to dispatch at least 1,500 troops to be stationed at Taiwan's airports and harbors once direct cross-strait shipping and flight services kick off. Moreover, they said, there will be many other tangible and intangible security costs.

For one thing, the officials said, the military must adjust its overall strategy, combat plans, operational regulations and troop deployments to cope with the new situation where mainland aircraft and ships will be able to directly enter Taiwan's territorial waters and airspace.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOOL DROP-OUTS TAKE 'WALK OF REMORSE' AROUND-THE-ISLAND

TEXT.P: For the group of former school drop-outs who used to be drug abusers and street drag racers, nothing could be better than plodding under the scorching sun on sizzling highway roads or in stormy weather on an across-the-island walk of remorse.
This is what the 25 teenaged boys wanted to do -- to toil on the road like ancient ascetic monks -- as a means to show remorse for their past sins and ultimately seek personal rebirth.

The group, which set off from Taichung in central Taiwan July 30, has trudged through the Chiayi-Tainan Plain, down to Kaohsiung and Pingtung before crossing the South-Bend Highway and turning to the eastern counties of Taitung, Hualien and Ilan on Aug. 15.
From Ilan City, the group has headed north, aiming to reach Taipei this weekend before hitting the south-bound roads to return to the starting point in Taichung, hopefully around Aug. 23.

During the 25-day journey, all the group members are on vegetarian diets, walking at least 12 hours a day and seeking accommodations at road-side temples, according to Hsu Chen-jung, a temple operator from Taichung, who serves as director and lecturer of the group.
No alcohol, no dirty words and no short tempers are allowed during the journey, Hsu said, adding that even with blisters on their feet and cramps in their legs, none of them has dropped out.

Hsu said he has operated the "walk of remorse" for drop-outs for ninth consecutive years. Over the past years, he has seen defiant, angry or distressed teenagers rediscover themselves after the 25-day, laborious around-the-island walking.

Hsu, who also maintains a Taoist folklore performance troupe, said many of the young men who took part in the walking journeys also have learned in his troupe performance arts dedicated to god-worshipping activities.
Hsu said his troupe has been invited to travel to Canada at the end of August to give performances in Toronto and Vancouver to showcase Taiwan's religious folklore.

Highly recommending the around-the-island walking journeys, Prof. Lin Mao-hsien from the Department of Taiwan Literature of Providence University said the journey is a daunting task challenging the teenagers' patience and physical capabilities.
By going beyond what they thought was their limit, the young men rediscover themselves, Lin said.
Chen Shih-ming, 19, who dropped out school during his second year in junior high, was a street drag racer who had a notorious name in all of central Taiwan.

Chen was attracted to the performances given by Chen's temple activity troupe and joined the group three years ago. Since then, he has become a polite young man and a drummer who plays the troupe's oriental drums.
Huang Yung-lun, 17, was a drug abuser who began to use amphetamines at the age of 13. A frequent visitor to police departments and jail cells, Huang was expelled from school at 14.
The first several months were torture without drugs and nothing to substitute but physical toil, Huang said. But after conquering the most trying period, the days were happy and rewarding, he said.
Now also a drummer, Huang said he has been gaining weight, learning his trade and thinking only about the positive side of life.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DECLINES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar declined against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, losing NT$0.029 to close at NT$34.358.
A total of US$433.5 billion changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$34.402 and dipped to a low of NT$34.336.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI RESIDENT SECURES COVETED FIRST NEW 'TAIWAN' PASSPORT

TEXT.P: A Taipei resident will secure the coveted first copy of the new version of the ROC passport to be formally issued Sept. 1, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Friday.

The MOFA's Bureau of Consular Affairs (BCA) conducted a random, computerized drawing of the issued serial numbers earlier in the day to decide the first 100 recipients of the new passport. Those who filed applications between Aug. 1 and Aug. 14 had an equal chance of securing the coveted first new passport.

A total of 3,017 Taiwan citizens filed applications during the 14-day period. Along with a number of ardent applicants, MOFA officials and journalists, the first applicant drawn out by the computer was Kuo Yi-ming.

BCA Director Yang Sheng-chung immediately informed Kuo of his good luck by telephone. Kuo said he was excited to get the very first new passport. "It came as a surprise to me. I'm more than happy," he said by phone.
President Chen Shui-bian's namesake, who was the first to apply for the new version of the passport on Aug. 1, secured No. 46.

"Chen Shui-bian, " who legally changed his name to that of the president a few years ago, once said he felt it was a very meaningful event for the government to issue the new version of the passport displaying the word "TAIWAN" in addition to the official national designation of the Republic of China on its cover. Therefore, he said he wanted to be the first to apply for the new version of the passport.

A 55-year-old man, identified as Chen Yun-ching, who came to the BCA office to witness the computerized drawing, said he was disappointed at failing to secure one of the first 100 copies of the new passport. "This is the first time that I have ever applied for a passport," he said.
Yang said he will present the first copy of the new version of the passport to Kuo Yi-ming in a formal ceremony Sept. 1.
The serial number of the new passports will start from "210000001," Yang said, adding that "21" refers to the 21st century.

In the past, the first copy of a new version of a passport was traditionally reserved for the nation's head of state. This time, President Chen directed that the first copy of the new version be made available to the people since it is they who will benefit from the changes.

Some ROC passport holders have complained that they had encountered unnecessary inconvenience or embarrassment while traveling abroad because foreign immigration officers often mistook them for mainland Chinese nationals. Mainland China's official title is the People's Republic of China or the PRC.

The addition of the English word "TAIWAN" in capital letters on the cover of the new ROC passport will make them more distinguishable from those issued by the PRC, MOFA officials said. Old passports will remain valid until they expire.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROOM TO ADJUST SHIPPING ROUTES, PORTS CRUCIAL: SHIPPING OPERATORS

TEXT.P: Shipping operators expressed the hope Friday that direct shipping across the Taiwan Strait would be opened as soon as possible, and that there would be flexibility regarding what routes and which ports would be available.
The shipping operators made the comments on the heels of the Executive Yuan's unveiling of its assessment of direct transportation links between Taiwan and mainland China.

A spokesman for Wan Hai Lines Ltd., a near-sea cargo transport operator, said that direct cargo transportation links should be based on a liberal approach, adding that it would not be very worthwhile to open only fixed shipping routes and ports.
For cargo transport, it is most important for operators to have free reign to adjust their shipping routes, the spokesman said.

The operators also expressed the hope that direct shipping would allow them free movement to more shipping points without restrictions. If the operators are given more leeway in the adjustment of their shipping lines and points, then the efficiency of cargo transport will be greatly enhanced, they said.

Meanwhile, some Taiwan businessmen operating in the mainland lauded the government's plan for direct cross-strait transportation links, believing that it will greatly enhance the government's goal to upgrade national competitiveness.

However, the businessmen said that talks with the mainland on the issue would go nowhere if the government on Taiwan could not find a way to deal with the situation creatively and avoid getting mired in political dogma.

The businessmen were responding to an assessment report released earlier in the day by the Cabinet that said direct cross-strait transportation links will have to be negotiated through bilateral consultations and the signing of agreements that are in the best interests of the nation.

The reports stated that the government will insist on "national sovereignty" and "will never budge on this point." The government will also preside over the talks and will not fall into the so-called "united front tactic" of having to accept Beijing's "one China" principle or accept the links as an "internal affair" of mainland China's.

The businessmen said that it was still unclear whether President Chen Shui-bian's remarks on a three-step approach for the realization of direct cross-strait transportation links were just "election rhetoric" prior to the presidential vote in March 2004, or an honest intention to upgrade national competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: NORTH KOREA MAY BE ASKED TO EXCHANGE NUKE PROGRAM FOR ADB MEMBERSHIP

TEXT.P: The Japanese daily Yomiuri Shimbun reported Friday that the United States, Japan and South Korea would consider helping North Korea join the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the World Bank if Pyongyang agrees to give up its nuclear weapons program.

The report quoted informed sources as saying that the United States has considered bringing up the proposal at the planned six-nation talks scheduled to open in Beijing Aug. 27. They said North Korea might accept the proposal because the two organizations may give it financial aid to tide over its economic difficulties.
The three countries also hope to place North Korea under international surveillance by including it in the world economic framework, the report said.

The report said North Korea expressed its desire to join the ADB soon after its food shortage crisis surfaced in 1996. North Korea may be asked to make public its economic indicators and financial circulation system when the three countries help it join the international financing organizations, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH DEPARTMENT HOPES SARS DIAGNOSIS AVAILABLE BEFORE AUTUMN

TEXT.P: The Department of Health of the Executive Yuan hopes that a medical system for diagnosing severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in three hours will be established in early October, an official said Friday.

Su Yi-jen, director-general of the Center for Disease Control, said a new diagnostic system will be useful in distinguishing cases of SARS from flu, especially in autumn, when approximately one million people in Taiwan suffer from colds and flu each year.

He said the establishment of such a system could help prevent the recurrence of SARS outbreaks this autumn. Researches are being done at home and abroad to make an early establishment of the system possible, he said.

To prevent any recurrences, the government will encourage people to stay at home for three days when they have cold symptoms or those of the flu. They should seek medical treatment if they have symptoms of pneumonia or have difficulty in breathing. In addition, he said, feverish travelers to Taiwan may be asked to go into quarantine, beginning Oct. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TOP SPORTS OFFICIAL HONORS CYCLING FAMILY

TEXT.P: The nation's top sports official praised the sportsmanship of the four members of a Taipei cyclist family Friday who recently returned to Taiwan after their 13-month, 23,600-kilometer globe-trotting journey.

Chairman Lin Teh-fu of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports said that the family pedaled their way through countries in Asia, Europe and America, adding that it would be an amazing feat even by car, not to mention by bicycle.
Lin said the family traveled through extremes -- from 50-degree Celsius heat to sub-freezing 30 below, and from 5,000-meter highlands to the 150 meters below sea level.
"Such is the spirit of sportsmanship which dares to face adversity and venture ahead, " Lin said as he presented them with a plaque and a check for NT$600,000 (US$17,390).

Saying that the family's globe-trotting was a form of trailblazing, Lin said that his council will actively promote cycling activities and expand the construction of cycling paths in cities since cycling is an environmental friendly sport.
In addition, the council will also sponsor an islandwide cycling activity Sept. 11-21 so that graduate students can learn more about Taiwan before finding work or continuing their studies, Lin said.
Lin also invited the cycling family to take part in the islandwide cycling activity.

The family is comprised of Huang Chin-pao, a welder, his wife and two teenaged sons. The elder son, Huang Chien-chia, wrote a two-volume book called "Going after your dreams by pedaling around the world" based on his observations along the way.
Chien-chia said that the two volumes chronicle their hardships, laughter and tears during the trip, adding that the close-knit family had been able to complete the journey by supporting each other.
He said, "Through my own observations, I was able to get a glimpse of the immense world and my world vision has been broadened."
The council bought 3,000 copies of Chien-chia's book as a form of encouragement.

The Huangs kicked off their global cycling journey from Hong Kong, first pedaling across mainland China, through the Gobi Desert and into Pakistan, where they encountered armed strife between government troops and guerrilla forces.

They took a month-long break after reaching Turkey via Iran, during which time they applied for visas to continue their ride through Bulgaria, Romania, Hungary, Austria, Germany, Belgium, and the Netherlands.
The Huangs flew into New York May 2 for their last leg in the United States after having pedaled 18,000 kilometers across the Asian and European continents.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER ENSURES SAFE ELECTRICITY SUPPLY FOLLOWING U.S BLACKOUT

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) instructed its various departments Friday to ensure a sufficient and safe supply of electricity following a power outage that struck cities in northern United States and Canada Thursday afternoon.

Taiwan also suffered a massive blackout that darkened almost the entire island on July 29, 1999. The widespread power outage was caused by the collapse of a transmission tower in Tainan County, as a result of a landslide due to heavy rainfall in the region.
The transmission tower's collapse triggered a domino effect among the island's connected transmission systems, causing serious losses to local industries.
Taipower spokesman Lee Ching-tien said Friday that the reserve capacity of the island's electricity supply system has reached 14.7 percent this year, a considerable improvement over last year.

In addition, with the completion of the company's new power transmission system around the island, Lee assured that there will be no shortage of electricity supply this summer as long as no natural disasters hit the island.
Lee stressed that Taipower's emergency task force is already ready to face any contingency.
Elsewhere, Chunghwa Telecom noted that northern America's power outage has so far not affected the international telephone lines between the United States and Taiwan.

Meanwhile, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Kao An, said the ROC's diplomats and their relatives are quite safe and calm for the time being in spite of some panicked calls to Taiwan's representative offices.
Kao noted that only the representative offices in New York and Toronto have been affected by the power outage, with their staff walking home since traffic was snarled.

In the air, only a New York-bound domestic flight from Seattle by EVA Airways suffered a two-hour delay, and a flight from New York to Taipei by China Airlines is expected to be delayed Friday because of the disordered airport ground operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CASTRO CALLS FOR PEACEFUL SETTLEMENT OF CROSS-STRAIT ISSUE: LU
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By Tsai Su-jung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting ROC Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday that Cuban President Fidel Castro has expressed his hope for a peaceful settlement of disputes between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Lu said she had amicable conversations with Castro while attending a dinner party hosted by outgoing Paraguayan President Luis Angel Gonzalez in honor of foreign dignitaries who are in Asuncion to attend the inauguration of the new Paraguayan president Friday.

"The 77-year-old Cuban leader is friendly and talkative, " Lu said, adding that Castro was curious about how Lu has managed to emerge as the ROC's first female vice president from a political dissident who was imprisoned for six years during Taiwan's martial law era.

Lu said they also spoke of relations across the Taiwan Strait. "Castro repeatedly told me that he is opposed to any military conflict and hopes to see cross-strait issues be resolved peacefully, " she said, adding that she has invited Castro to visit Taiwan and asked him to help advise Beijing to renounce its use of military threats against Taiwan.
Also present at the gala party were presidents of Argentina, Chile, Brazil, Venezuela, Ecuador and Bolivia as well as senior officials from many other countries.

Lu, heading a 43-member entourage, arrived in Paraguay Wednesday after a three-day official visit to Panama. Lu will attend Paraguayan President-elect Nicanor Duarte Frutos' inaugural ceremony on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.
Earlier in the day, Lu addressed the Paraguayan Congress, calling for enhancing bilateral economic cooperation by forging strategic alliances.
Lu said the two countries should cooperate in operating agricultural farms and industrial parks, with Taiwan providing technology and technicians while Paraguay offering land and manpower.

Lu said Taiwan once donated funds for building homes for impoverished Paraguayan families. In appreciation of Taiwan's assistance, those Paraguayan people re-designated a major street in their neighborhood as "Taiwan Street" and their village as "Taiwan Village."
If necessary, Lu said, Taiwan is willing to build a "Taiwan town" in Paraguay in the future.

The ROC government has donated US$20 million for Paraguay to build a new building to house its congress. Nearly all members of the Paraguayan Senate and House of Representatives showed up to listen to Lu's speech to express their gratitude for Taiwan's generous aid.
Paraguayan Senate Speaker Carlos Mateo Balmelli said the two countries have enjoyed a longstanding relationship because they have shared values in freedom, democracy and human rights.
Mateo said the Paraguayan government will continue to support Taiwan's bid to join major international organizations and will also take concrete measures to boost bilateral ties.
Lu had made transit stops in Hawaii and Los Angeles en route to Panama. On her way back to Taiwan Aug. 20, Lu is scheduled to make a transit stop in Seattle for two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: TECHNICAL ISSUES NOT KEY TO DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT LINKS: PROFESSOR

TEXT.P: Issues pertaining to law enforcement and public perception, rather than technical problems, are the keys to opening direct cross-Taiwan Strait transport links, a mainland China affairs expert said Friday.

Chang Wu-yueh, a professor with the mainland studies graduate school at Tamkang University, said technical matters related to law enforcement and how the public views the situation are the major barriers to the establishment of direct cross-strait transport links, because both Taiwan and mainland China are weighing their own political objectives and considerations.

Although President Chen Shui-bian reiterated that direct cross-strait links must be built upon security, reciprocity and dignity, and the mainland claimed that the two sides can put aside the 'one China' dispute and other political issues, Chang predicted that it will be impossible to forge the links if political issues, such as the crucial law enforcement and sovereignty, are avoided.

Should mainland China seek to achieve its "one China" goal through the links or view the links as Taiwan's tool to display Chen's stance that "there is one country on each side of the Strait," neither side will give in to the other to start talks, Chang said, pointing out that "this is the major thorny point toward setting up the links."

If the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are willing to reduce the political weight they give the issue, all technical issues regarding the links will not be major problems, Chang said, but he predicted a long process of bilateral negotiations.
Chang's remarks came after Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen published earlier the same day a report on the assessment of the impact of direct cross-strait transport links.
President Chen claimed Wednesday that direct transport services between Taiwan and mainland China will be implemented in three stages by the end of 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSPORT LINKS WITH MAINLAND, A DOUBLE-EDGED SWORD: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Direct transport links with mainland China is a double-edged sword in economic terms -- it can both benefit and hurt the island, Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council said Friday.

Unveiling a government assessment on the impacts of possible direct transport links with the mainland, Tsai said the links would certainly decrease the cost of transporting people and goods to and from the mainland.

She estimated that direct transport links would cut cargo shipping costs by about NT$820 million a year, and cut shipping time by half. For air traffic, it would cut NT$13.2 billion in costs and 8.6 million hours in time a year for passenger loads. For cargo, there would be savings of NT$810 million in costs and 260,000 hours in time each year.
The reduced costs and time would boost local business's competitiveness and help the economy, she said.

However, the links could speed up the outflow of Taiwan's capital, hi-technology and technicians to the mainland and, therefore, aggravate the economic slowdown and drive up the unemployment rate in Taiwan.

The flight of local capital as well as the relocation of many people to the mainland would also dampen the real estate market. Once the country has lost its edge in ready capital and hi-technology, its industries will lose their competitiveness and Taiwan will be marginalized.
How to preserve the advantage while preventing the disadvantages is a serious challenge facing the country if it expects to successfully open direct transport links, Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPLEXITY OF DIRECT LINKS BEYOND ASSESSMENT: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Although the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has tried its best to outline the pros and cons that direct cross-Taiwan Strait transport links could have in Taiwan, many complications are difficult to assess now and must be resolved through two-way negotiations, an official said Friday.

Fu Don-cheng, director of the MAC's Economic Affairs Department, who was responsible for writing the report about an overall assessment of the impacts on Taiwan of opening direct transport services across the Strait, said many problems are hard to evaluate in advance and that they must be settled at the negotiating table in the future.

For instance, direct transport links between the two sides will fuel the number of mainland-bound tourist and business trips among the Taiwan people by 1.6-fold over the combined level since 1991 -- the equivalent of an additional 45 million trips worth more than billions of New Taiwan dollars, Fu pointed out, adding that the negative impact on Taiwan's economy should not be underestimated.
Nevertheless, Fu said, proper complementary measures can be devised through two-way talks to allow the people from mainland China to enter Taiwan to help balance the trend.

The MAC stressed in the assessment report that the focal point for Taiwan now is how to adequately conduct direct cross-strait transport links. It also said that Taiwan cannot rashly engage in the links simply out of wishful thinking. The links must be set up under the principles of dignity, security, prosperity and reciprocality.

According to MAC officials, "one country on each side" is Taiwan's bottom line in future negotiations with mainland China on the links issue. Taiwan will try to be flexible based on this framework while negotiating with the mainland, they added.

MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen published earlier the same day a report on the assessment of the impact of direct cross-strait transport services on Taiwan at a news conference called by Premier Yu Shyi-kun, after President Chen Shui-bian said a day earlier that direct transport links between Taiwan and mainland China would be completed in three stages by the end of 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT WILL NOT SACRIFICE NATIONAL SECURITY FOR TRANSPORT LINKS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said on Friday that the government is serious and determined to promote direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait, but stressed that it will not sacrifice the nation's security in exchange for such links.
Yu made the remarks in a news conference after Cabinet officials unveiled an official evaluation report on the opening of direct transportation links between the two sides of Taiwan Strait.

Also present were high-ranking officials responsible for technical problems relating to the links, including Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-lung, and Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Tuei.
The premier noted that the release of the evaluation report represented his administration's seriousness and determination in promoting direct transport links with mainland China.

The report was unveiled following the remarks made by President Chen Shui-bian on Aug. 13 that his administration will promote the opening of direct cross-strait transportation links under a three-stage program.

Regarding the criticism describing Chen's three-stage program as an empty campaign promise, Yu stressed that the opening of direct transportation links with mainland China is a serious topic that should be implemented step by step.

Yu pointed to Chen's many policies, including a more open approach toward Taiwan investment in mainland China to replace a policy of curtailing investment and the opening of direct shipping links between Taiwan's several offshore islands and mainland Chinese ports, which he said can demonstrate the government's sincerity in promoting close relations with mainland China.
In order to show Taiwan's good faith in opening the links with mainland, Yu said his administration will not set any conditions on future negotiations with Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: CZECH REPUBLIC BEATS INDONESIA IN YOUTH BASEBALL CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: The Czech Republic beat Indonesia, 22-3, Friday in the XI "AA" World Youth Baseball Championship being held in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.
In another game, which was suspended after the eighth inning because of rain, Korea and South Africa were tied 9-9. They will continue Sunday morning.
Still two other games, one between Chinese Taipei and Australia, the other between the United States and Cuba, were rescheduled for Saturday morning because of rain.
