DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC GROWTH FALLS TO 0.08 PERCENT IN SECOND QUARTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth fell to minus 0.08 percent in the second quarter, thanks to the ravages of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), a statistics official from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said Friday.

Citing data compiled by his office, the anonymous official said SARS drove down the rate by taking a bite out of the island's exports and dampening consumption in the private sector, which has witnessed a unprecedented downward growth of 1.8 percent.
As a result, both the production in the sectors of industry and service dipped and the economic growth fell far short of the 1.2 percent forecast.

However, he said, the prospects for the second half of this year are quiet bright because of the global economic recovery, the island's booming exports, and the upturn in private consumption and private investment.
He predicted a growth of 3.96 percent for the third quarter and 4.67 percent for the fourth quarter, which will push the whole year growth rate up to 3.06 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING WILL SUFFER BY SNUBBING TAIWAN'S APPEAL TO OPEN DIRECT LINKS

TEXT.P: Beijing will miss an opportunity if it ignores Taiwan's appeal for talks on opening transport links across the Taiwan Strait after next March, Kang Ning-hsiang, secretary-general of the National Security Council said Friday.

Kang made the comment after the Executive Yuan unveiled an assessment on impacts of possible direct transportation links with mainland earlier in the day and two days after President Chen Shui-bian said that his administration will begin negotiations with Beijing over the issue after the next presidential election in March.
The chief security official said the Executive Yuan's painstaking assessment was revealed at a time best for Taiwan, the United States and mainland China.

Kang said Taiwan is slated to hold a presidential election on March 20, while the Americans will choose their president in November, and the last thing they will see during this period is any disturbance in Asia, especially across the Taiwan Strait.
Beijing leaders will oblige their U.S. counterparts by starting to negotiate with Taiwan, which will considerably ease the tensions in the whole Asian region, Kang said.

A stable situation across the Taiwan Strait will also contribute to mainland Chinese economic development, which is Beijing's current top priority, not to mention the opportunity Beijing will have after the links are launched to tap Taiwan's capital and technology to speed up its economical development, Kang went on.
Beijing will lose a valuable chance to prove that it is a responsible power and a steady force in the region if it passes over the chance to talk with Taiwan, Kang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WOULD BE "VERY NERVOUS" IF ROC RENAMES ITSELF: BELLOCCHI

TEXT.P: Washington would be "very, very nervous" if the Republic of China were to decide to rename itself, and the United States would quietly try to persuade it from doing so, although legally the United States has no say in the matter, Natale Bellocchi, a former chairman of the American Institute (AIT) in Taiwan said Friday.

In a speech to a group of political followers of former President Lee Teng-hui, Bellocchi said the divisive views among people in Taiwan about how their country should deal with the sovereignty issue makes it difficult for Washington to lay down a long-term policy towards Taiwan.

From Washington's point of view, Taiwan lacks the willingness to defend itself. Reports about Taiwan's politicians rubbing shoulders with Beijing leaders led U.S. political observers to believe they lack loyalty to their own country, and complicated the U.S.' role in defending Taiwan.

Furthermore, Bellocchi said, the administration of U.S. President George W. Bush is very serious about its obligation to help Taiwan defend itself, but was puzzled by the fact that Taiwan authorities have been decreasing the defense budget while mainland China is aggressively increasing theirs.

As to the topic of referendums in Taiwan, the former AIT chairman said, in the eyes of Washington and Beijing, referendum is associated with a provocation from Taiwan, and Beijing's response will be "verbal threats."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 16, or the 19th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1777: Americans led by Gen. John Stark defeat the British at the Battle of Bennington during the American Revolution.
1825: Bolivia declares its independence from Spain.
1909: Japanese Chutaro Kido discovers an iron mine in Anshan, Liaoning Province, located in Manchuria, where Japan has extensive economic privileges. The Southern Manchuria Railway later sets up a steel plant in Anshan.
1913: Menachem Begin, Israeli prime minister from 1977 to 1983, is born in Russia. He shared the 1978 Nobel Peace Prize with Anwar Sadat of Egypt.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who had participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty, organizes a revolt in Tahu, Hsinchu County, against Japanese rule of Taiwan in the so-called Miaoli Incident. He was executed after the uprising failed.
1923: Lee Kuan Yew, prime minister of Singapore from 1959 to 1990, is born.
1923: Shimon Peres, Israeli prime minister from 1984 to 1986, is born in Poland.
1937: The Supreme National Defense Council decides at a meeting that the Nationalist government should authorize Chiang Kai-shek as generalisimo to lead the Republic of China armed forces in the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1948: George Herman Ruth, known as "Babe" Ruth, the most famous baseball player of all time, dies in New York City at the age of 53. He broke the Major League home run record in three consecutive seasons (1919-21), and then again in 1927 with a staggering 60 home runs.
1949: Margaret Mitchell, the author of "Gone with the Wind," dies after being hit by a car two days earlier. She was 49.
1950: Taiwan, formerly comprising eight counties and nine cities, is re-divided into 16 counties and five cities.
1960: The new republic of Cyprus comes into being, with Archbishop Makarios as its first president.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Gabon.
1968: The first Poseidon missile is launched.
1974: Wu Kuan-hsiung, secretary-general of the China External Trade Development Council, and Ahmad Sowaidi, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of Qatar, sign a trade cooperation memorandum.
1975: The Republic of China and Nauru sign a civil aviation agreement.
1977: Elvis Presley, the king of rock and roll, dies of heart failure at the age of 42 after collapsing in his mansion in Memphis, Tenn.
1978: Cardinal Yu Pin dies of a heart attack in Rome at the age of 77.
1979: John G. Diefenbaker, Canadian politician who served as prime minister from 1957 to 1963, dies at the age of 84. The Progressive Conservative government he headed lost the 1963 general elections because of opposition to his proposals to build nuclear weapons in Canada.
1990: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq warns U.S. President George Bush that thousands of the troops he has sent to the Gulf will return home in coffins.
1996: Leonel Fernandez becomes the 100th president of the Dominican Republic.
1999: Two Republic of China warships, the Hui Yang and the Han Yang, are decommissioned after almost 30 years of service, bringing to 10 the total number of naval vessels decommissioned by the ROC.
2000: Visiting ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his delegation take part in the inauguration of Dominican Republic President Hipolito Mejia held at the Parliament Building.
2000: ROC Premier Tang Fei unveils a proposal to transform Taiwan into a knowledge-based economy that is on par with those of the world's most advanced nations within ten years.
2001: The 24th William Jones Cup International Basketball Tournament opens in Fengshan City, Kaohsiung County, with President Chen Shui-bian tossing the ceremonial opening jump ball in a game between Chinese Taipei and South Africa.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In order to acquire truth, it is necessary to obtain a wide and extensive knowledge of what has been said and done in the world; to critically inquire into it; to carefully ponder over it; to clearly sift it; and to earnestly carry it out."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times:
No straight flights across the Taiwan Strait will be allowed even after direct transportation is opened, while cross-strait shipment will follow the "point-to-point, fixed route and fixed time" principles.
The United Daily News:
Straight flights and navigation will remain taboo after direct cross-Taiwan Strait transportation links are forged.
The Liberty Times:
Blackout blamed on many causes; Ohio disputes claim.
The Taiwan Daily:
Prosecutors apply for detention of disgraced business tycoon for probes into NSB slush funds.
The Central Daily News:
The 'pan-blue alliance' blasts the MAC-drafted direct links report.
The China Post:
Premier says government willing to start talks on 'direct links.'
The Taiwan News:
Security will not be sacrificed for links, Yu claims.
The Taipei Times:
Cabinet unveils cross-strait links plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREAN ENVOY BRIEFS ROC LEGISLATIVE HEAD ON CANCELED MEETINGS

TEXT.P: Singapore's representative to Taiwan has briefed ROC Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng on the major reasons behind Singaporean Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong's decision to cancel a planned meeting with Wang, legislative sources said Saturday.

Ker Sin Tze, director of the Singapore Trade Office in Taipei, paid a courtesy call on Wang at the latter's residence Friday to explain why Goh and Singaporean Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew had canceled plans to meet Wang during his planned trip to the Southeast Asian city-state, the sources said.

Wang was originally scheduled to visit Singapore and Malaysia from Aug. 11-15. After Ker informed Wang of the Singaporean leaders' decision to cancel their planned meetings with Wang last week, Wang dropped his two-leg overseas travel plan.

Both Ker and Wang remained low-keyed about their meeting. According to previous media reports, the Singaporean leaders had decided to cancel their meeting plans with Wang mainly because of pressure from Beijing.

The reports claimed that Beijing was annoyed by President Chen Shui-bian's repeated describing of the current state of cross-Taiwan Strait relations as "one state on each side of the strait" and consequently pressured senior Singaporean officials not to engage any influential Taiwan politicians like Wang.

Wang said in private that Beijing's pressure was only one of the factors that had prompted Singaporean leaders to cancel their plans to hold talks with Wang. He declined to divulge any details regarding his talks with Ker a day earlier.

Because of Beijing's diplomatic efforts to isolate Taiwan internationally, senior Taiwan officials have had difficulties traveling abroad freely. Early this year, Thailand declined to grant a visa to Legislative Yuan Vice President P.K. Chiang reportedly due to pressure from Beijing. Chiang was then forced to cancel his Southeast Asian travel plan that included a stop in Bangkok.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEERS ON ONLINE GAMES TOURNAMENT COMPETITORS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian visited the site of the 2003 HiNet Online Games Tournament at the Shin Kong Mitsukoshi Department Store in Taipei Saturday, cheering on the competitors in the championship event and telling them to "play hard."

According to the online games tournament organizer, Chunghwa Telecom, the winner of the third annual tournament will represent Taiwan to compete in the upcoming world online games championship tournament.
Online games have taken Taiwan by storm in recent years, with people of all ages catching the fever, as evidenced by the participation of a 70-year-old finalist in this year's tournament.
President Chen told the participants that online game players, like baseball athletes, can also represent Taiwan to gain honor in international competition.

Noting that the online game players can also design online games software, Chen said he was pleased to learn that many universities and colleges have already established online games-related departments.

Encouraged by the remarks by Chen that online games are worth being promoted as a national leisure activity, Ho-Chen Tan, Chunghwa Telecom chairman of board, said he might consider organizing an online games tournament for Cabinet ministers to further promote online games.

Ho-Chen stressed that online games are not just for fun, they can also help teach people how to properly use the Internet. In addition, online games can also create tremendous business opportunities, he said.
The two-day 2003 Hinet Online Games Championship Tournament is scheduled to wrap up Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES MAINLAND LEADERS TO ACCEPT VALUES OF DEMOCRACY, PEACE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the mainland Chinese leadership Saturday to accept the universal values of freedom, democracy, peace and human rights.

Chen made the appeal in his speech delivered at the opening session of an international seminar on Hong Kong's development under the Beijing-initiated "one country, two systems" formula. The seminar was organized by the Taiwan Advocates, a private think tank headed by former President Lee Teng-hui.

Since Hong Kong's reversion to mainland Chinese rule in July 1997, Chen said, the former British colony has not seen an economic boom as many had expected through its integration with the mainland. On the contrary, he went on, Hong Kong has witnessed an accelerated industrial "hollowing out" and a significantly higher unemployment rate over the past six years.

On the political front, Chen said, Hong Kong is facing a regression in democracy. Chen said the Hong Kong people's civil liberties have been restricted to some extent due to Beijing's concerns. For instance, the Hong Kong people face various kinds of restrictions in commemorating the Tiananmen Square massacre and practicing Falun Gong spiritual cultivation due to pressure from Beijing.

More than 500,000 Hong Kong citizens took to the streets July 1 to protest the Hong Kong government's plan to enact an anti-subversion bill which, if passed, would further restrict the Hong Kong people's civil liberties and rights, Chen said. The massive protest forced the Hong Kong government to delay the legislation. A week later, more than 30,000 Hong Kong people staged a sit-in in front of the territory's Legislative Council calling for political reform and direct election of its chief executive.

All these developments caused international concern about the level of Beijing's sincerity in honoring its "one country, two systems" promise to maintain Hong Kong's current lifestyle and system for 50 years, Chen said.

Noting that the Hong Kong people's protest against the anti-subversion bill indicated their desire for freedom and full democracy, Chen said Beijing should respect and protect the Hong Kong people's right to make choices based on free will.
Chen said democracy has been the cornerstone of Taiwan's political and social stability and the island's most precious asset to ensure its role in the international community.

"We ought to treasure our hard-won democratic achievements and throw our full support behind the Hong Kong people's efforts to safeguard their basic human rights and freedom, " Chen said, adding that Taiwan must serve as a beacon of hope for Hong Kong's and mainland China's democratic development.
More than 700 scholars and experts from home and abroad attended the seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING, OPPOSITION PARTIES EXCHANGE ACCUSATIONS OF 'VOTE-BUYING'

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) traded attacks Saturday, accusing each other of offering programs aimed at winning over voters in the run-up to the presidential election set for March 20, 2004.

Legislator Lee Chia-chin, the KMT party whip in the Legislature, noted that the DPP administration has put forward a series of welfare benefit initiatives totalling around NT$1,700 billion (US$49.27 billion) since the end of last year.
Lee and his legislative colleagues Lo Shih-hsiung and Huang Chien-ting of the KMT released the results of a poll conducted by the party's think tank the National Policy Foundation Aug. 11-12.
A total of 1,068 valid responses were collected in the survey which is said to have a margin of error of 3 percentage points.

In the poll, 58 percent of the respondents said they believe the series of programs announced by the administration during the campaigning for the Aug. 2 Hualien magistrate by-election were put forward mainly for the purpose of winning more votes. At the same time, 55 percent of the polled said they think President Chen Shui-bian's promise to increase pensions for elderly farmers by NT$1,000 to NT$4,000 is a form of vote-buying.

Meanwhile, 77 percent of the respondents said they believe that the series of welfare programs recently announced by the president and the Cabinet were put forward with the next presidential election in mind, the poll showed.

Some 56 percent said they agree with the notion that the government should ban the issuing of various kinds of stipends prior to the presidential election, while 78 percent said they would not support the ruling party just because of their receiving a stipend or subsidy.

Interpreting the results of the survey, Lo said the poll shows that the people have the wisdom to tell which programs are aimed at winning over voters. Legislator Huang said that all the political parties should refrain from using pork-barrel programs to lure voters and from passing the bill onto future generations.

Lee said the KMT caucus will try to regulate the candidates of the various parties to keep them from introducing new welfare programs, unless they are financially feasible, in the period prior to a presidential election through a revision of the law or through legislation of a special law to prohibit such "vote-buying" practices.
Meanwhile, a DPP official rebutted Lee's accusations, saying that it is the KMT that is trying to win votes with its own proposals.

Chen Chi-mai, DPP party whip in the Legislature, said that the programs alleged by the KMT to be pork-barrel programs include the Resolution Trust Company (RTC) Fund, the expansion of public construction and job creation programs. Chen pointed out that these programs are aimed at reconstructing the nation's financial order, stimulating the economy and increasing employment, which he said are goals that will benefit the nation, and not any specific groups.

Regrettably, Chen said, the opposition parties were opposed to these programs during the review process simply for opposition's sake. He added that even after the implementation of the programs, the opposition parties have tried to smear the DPP by saying the administration is only trying to win votes.

Chen claimed that it is the KMT that tries to win voters under the guise of promoting welfare programs, saying that the KMT over the past 50 years, in order to maintain what he called its authoritarian rule, had appropriated an exorbitant budget for certain groups of people. He cited as an example the more than NT$500 billion put toward the renovation of residential complexes for military personnel and their dependents.

He also said that it is "stunning" to see that the KMT has over the past two months rashly proposed a series of programs, including stipends for elderly farmers and subsidies for students of NT$5,000 per month, which he claimed would cost the government NT$286 billion per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN ATTENDS KETAGALAN GRAD CEREMONY OF 1ST GROUP OF WOMEN GRADS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that he hopes the first group of female graduates from the Ketagalan Institute, an academy run by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), will become reform pioneers in Taiwan.

Chen made the remarks at the graduation ceremony of the first group of women leaders to graduate from the Ketagalan Institute. The aim of the institute, established in April this year, is to cultivate future leaders of the country.
Addressing the ceremony, Chen told the women graduates that the level of a country's gender equality is an indicator of how developed a country is.

Chen noted that in the male-dominated Taiwan society of the past, women were asked to take care of family affairs and were discouraged from getting involved in public affairs, and without knowing it, were deprived of the opportunity to strive for their rights. He stressed that once given a fair chance and equal footing, women can perform as well as men.
Chen urged the female graduates to join hands in reforming society.
The first group of 45 women leaders to graduate from the Ketagalan Institute includes lawyers, medical doctors, government officials, lawmakers and business executives.
Among them, the movie-star-turned-businesswoman Chou Tan-wei and orthopedist Lin Ching-yun grabbed a lot of media attention.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAP BETWEEN RICH AND POOR NARROWS

TEXT.P: The average income of Taiwan households has increased while the gap between the rich and poor has narrowed, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday.

The premier made the comments following the release of statistics on household income by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) the previous day as he visited Taipei County to inspect the implementation of the government's job creation initiative.

The statistics showed that the average disposable income of Taiwan households was NT$73,000 (US$2,116) per month last year. The average disposable income of the top 20 percent of households, at NT$1,799,733, was 6.16 times that of the bottom 20 percent of households, slightly lower than the figure of 6.39 registered for 2001.

DGBAS Director General Liu San-chi attributed the decline to the government's job creation initiative, which has helped middle-aged and older people find jobs, resulting in a decrease in the number of households where no member is working or earning money.

The economy has also rebounded from the previous year's doldrums, and the income of low-income and medium-income families has increased, while the income of rich families has decreased because of low interest rates, Liu pointed out.
Premier Yu said that the average income of the bottom 20 percent of households for 2002 was 5.1 percent higher than that of the preceding year.

Taiwan's economy registered growth of 3.6 percent for last year, higher than the U.S. economy's 2.4 percent and the E.U. economy's 0.1 percent, showing that Taiwan's economic performance is above average, the premier said.

He also said the gap between the rich and poor in Taiwan based on a comparison of the top 20 percent of households and the bottom 20 percent was smaller than that of South Korea, Singapore, the United States or Hong Kong, although it was larger than Japan's.

The DGBAS statistics showed that higher education also brings higher income. Those who have graduate school education or above have a yearly income of more than NT$1 million on average, while those who have no formal education or are illiterate only earn about NT$110,000 per year. Those who have college or university education have a yearly income of NT$750,000 on average.

In terms of cities and counties, Taipei continued to top all others last year with an average annual household income of NT$1.51 million, followed by Hsinchu City at NT$1.3 million, and Hsinchu County, Taoyuan County, Taipei County, Taichung City and Kaohsiung City, in that order.
The offshore island of Penghu was at the bottom of the list in 2001, but Chiayi County dropped to last place for 2002 with an average annual household income of NT$730,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGALS FROM M'LAND COULD THREATEN TAIWAN'S DISEASE CONTROL: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The steady stream of illegal mainland Chinese immigrants could pose a threat to Taiwan's disease control system, a local official said Saturday.

Lai Hsieh-yi, director of the detention center for illegal mainland Chinese immigrants that is located in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, said medical care for illegal immigrants from the mainland has become a heavy financial burden for the detention center.

According to Lai, the Hsinchu center specializes in holding female illegal immigrants from mainland China. Before last week when 129 of the detainees were sent to the frontline island of Matsu for repatriation, the center held 835 detainees.

"The vacancies have all been filled over the past few days, " Lai said, adding that many of the newcomers are sick or suffering from emotional problems. Some of them had even tried to kill themselves while being detained at police offices in various parts of the island, he added.

Noting that repatriation has been hindered by mainland China's reluctance to cooperate, Lai said 115 detainees have been held at the center for more than six months and that 15 have been held for more than a year. "We have always had a packed house," he complained.

Among the detainees, 52 are venereal disease patients, 32 are pregnant and 14 have recently given birth. The center now has 15 babies, including a pair of twin boys. Worse still, Lai said, two of the detainees have been confirmed to be carriers of HIV -- the virus that causes AIDS.
"The center doesn't have a medical service office. We have to rely on the government-owned Hsinchu Hospital to offer outpatient clinical services for the illegal immigrants," Lai said.
"The hospital sends staff members to the center twice a week. Medical care is a heavy financial burden for us," he noted.

As all medical services for detainees are free of charge, Lai said some mainland people have allegedly entered Taiwan mainly for medical reasons. According to Lai, some illegal immigrants from the mainland surrendered themselves to local police stations immediately after landing on the island.

"They are then able to receive free medical treatment at the detention center and recover before being repatriated," he said, addign that they don't need to spend a dime and that some of them gain a lot of weight during their stay at the detention center.

Lai recalled how two inmates who had to receive insulin injections each day to treat their diabetes vowed before being repatriated earlier this year to make every possible effort to "return" to Taiwan.

In 2001, he said, the center spent more than NT$1 million on medical treatment for its detainees. "The amount surged to NT$2.04 million last year, and the total medical bill for the first seven months of this year hit NT$1.5 million."
Government tallies show that a total of 2,286 illegal immigrants from mainland China, including 380 males and 1,904 females, are currently being held at various detention centers around Taiwan.

Lai said he is worried that more illegal mainland Chinese immigrants remain at large in Taiwan. "These people might be carriers of certain diseases and could pose a threat to the nation's disease prevention and control system," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO GIVE PRIORITY TO BILL CONCERNING CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) caucus leader in the Legislative Yuan said Saturday that the party will give priority in the next legislative session to the revisions to a bill concerning relations between the two sides of Taiwan Strait.

Legislator Lee Chia-chin said the move is to correspond to the promise made recently by President Chen Shui-bian that his administration will push for the opening of direct transportation links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait under a three-stage program.

An Executive Yuan assessment report on the impact of opening such links was unveiled Friday following Chen's promise to show the determination and sincerity of the administration in pushing for direct transportation links with mainland China.

However, Lee noted that Chen's remarks on the opening of cross-strait transport links in three stages has caused mixed reactions among the pro-Taiwan independence faction in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Lee said he believes that the DPP might support the links with mainland China openly but oppose it in secret to calm down the pro-independence faction.

To test the sincerity of the DPP in pushing for the cross-strait links, Lee said the KMT, which is still gauging the order of hundreds of bills, will place the revisions to the statute governing the relations of people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait as their priority in the next legislative session which will open in September.

Chen's remarks have caused mixed reactions, with businesspeople with operations in mainland China expressing their support and opposition parties calling for negotiations for the opening of such links to start immediately instead of after next year's presidential election in March as promised by Chen.

The opposition parties have opined that Chen's three-stage program for the links, for which he promised to launch negotiations with Beijing after the presidential election and to implement by the end of next year, is an empty campaign promise.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENTS PROTEST U.K.'S VISA EXTENSION CHARGE
DOC.DATELINE: London, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese students in the United Kingdom have been collecting signatures to protest against a British government decision to charge a fee to foreigners applying to extend their stay in the country.

The Home Office of the British government announced in July that from Aug. 1, foreign nationals living in the United Kingdom that apply for an extension will have to pay an application processing fee.
Postal applications will cost 155 pounds (US$248) , with premium 'same day' service for those applying in person costing 255 pounds, the office announced.

After receiving the notice from the Home Office, the Taiwanese students presented their complaint to the office, arguing that the tuition paid by foreign students in the United Kingdom is several times higher than that paid by British nationals, and the visa extension charge will represent an additional financial burden.
They expressed the hope that the British government will reconsider the decision. However, the Home Office has not made any response to the call.
The Students' Union of the Republic of China in the United Kingdom is encouraging more foreign students to protest the move to the Home Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD URGES BEIJING TO READ ASSESSMENT REPORT ON DIRECT LINKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in charge of mainland China policy said Saturday that direct cross-strait transportation links will be mutually beneficial and urged Beijing to first read Taiwan's assessment report on such links before making a response.

Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , made the remarks after Zhang Mingqing, a spokesman for Taiwan Affairs Office under mainland China's State Council, commented the previous day that Taiwan is not sincere about implementing the cross-strait direct transportation links despite the assessment report.

Despite President Chen Shui-bian's announcement earlier this week of wanting to implement the links by the end of 2004, Zhang noted that Chen had said the same thing three years ago but failed to deliver. Zhang said that Chen's words are insignificant and lack sincerity.

On Zhang's comment that the ban on straight flights across the Taiwan Strait under the direct links as put forward in the assessment means the direct flights would not be direct but instead detoured, Tsai said that the ban was included out of national security considerations and that the Ministry of National Defense insisted on this point.

"The government is serious about the establishment of cross-strait transportation," Tsai said, asking Beijing "not to have too much political consideration" and to cast aside considerations of the presidential election in Taiwan set for March 20, 2004 in order to get negotiations started as soon as possible.
"Cross-strait transportation links will be beneficial to both sides," Tsai said, urging Beijing to seriously consider the issue.
Tsai made the remarks after speaking on cross-strait relations at the Ketagalan Academy, a school run by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to nurture future leaders of the nation.

Tsai said at the institute that cross-strait relations have changed in nature, pointing out that the DPP administration has in fact renounced the goal upheld by previous KMT administrations of reclaiming mainland China, and that it is now seeking a new policy.
She said that the DPP administration is handling cross-strait relations well and that the relations are basically stable.

Tsai also said that faced with increasing business and trade exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, the administration is focusing on reasonable exchanges and on revising the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, as well as working out possible cross-strait developments over the next five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CALLS ON BEIJING NOT TO REJECT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Aug. 15 (CNA) (By Tsai Su-jung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Vice President Annette Lu urged the mainland Chinese leadership Friday not to reject Taiwan and instead to pay more heed to Taiwan's cause.
Lu made the call while attending a dinner in Asuncion, Paraguay, given by the members of the local Chinese community in her honor.

Noting that she originally planned to visit Boeing Co. during her upcoming transit stop in Seattle on her way back to Taiwan, Lu said that to the best of her knowledge, mainland China has pressured Boeing to refuse her visit.
Referring to the mainland leadership as "stingy" for such behavior, Lu said that Beijing's efforts to isolate Taiwan in the international arena will only alienate the people of Taiwan.
Mainland China has consistently spared no effort in pressuring foreign governments not to accept visits from the ROC's president and vice president.

"And now, they have expanded their scope to even private corporations, " Lu lamented, adding that as a country with a population of 1.3 billion, mainland China should be more generous and more broad-minded.

Lu said the mainland leadership should learn from Cuban President Fidel Castro who told Lu a day earlier that he is opposed to war and hopes to see the two sides of the Taiwan Strait resolve their disputes peacefully.

Earlier in the day, Lu signed a joint statement with new Paraguayan Vice President Luis Alberto Castiglioni reaffirming their governments' commitment to further boosting bilateral exchanges and cooperation.

The statement said the two countries will work together to promote world peace, democracy, human rights and sustainable development. It further said the two countries will forge a strategic alliance to facilitate cooperation in various fields.
The Paraguayan government also pledged continued support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and other major international organizations.
Meanwhile, Castiglioni accepted Lu's invitation to visit Taiwan in the near future. The itinerary will be finalized in the next few weeks, Lu said.

Lu, heading a 43-member entourage, arrived in Paraguay Wednesday after a three-day official visit to Panama. She attended Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte Frutos' inaugural ceremony on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian Friday morning. A total of 95 foreign delegations, including many top leaders of Latin American countries, attended Duarte's inauguration.
On Friday afternoon, Lu met with Panamanian First Vice President Arturo Vallarino for wide-ranging talks. Vallarino was in Argentina when Lu visited Panama earlier this week.
Vallarino, who is scheduled to make a private visit to mainland China later this month, assured Lu that Panama will not switch its diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing.

Vallarino said his upcoming mainland visit is primarily aimed at promoting commercial exchanges with the mainland. As Panamanian businesspeople hope to tap the vast mainland market, Vallarino said he will travel to the mainland with some Panamanian trade promoters to inspect the general market trends there.
Vallarino said his visit will by no means undermine Panama's diplomatic relations with Taiwan.
Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso and Panama Second Vice President Dominador Kaiser Bazan made similar assurances to Lu during her visit in Panama.

Moscoso will visit Taipei next week to sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with ROC President Chen Shui-bian. Vallarino said he hopes the two countries will boost cooperation in export processing zone operations after the FTA is signed.
Lu said Taiwan is more than willing to assist Panama in exporting agricultural and fishery products to the United States once the FTA is signed.
Later in the day, Lu also met with Guatemalan Vice President Franciso Reyes who assured Lu that his country will continue to support Taiwan's U.N. bid.
Lu will wrap up her Paraguay visit after giving a news conference and touring a children's day care center Saturday morning.
She had made transit stops in Hawaii and Los Angeles en route to Panama. On her way back to Taiwan Aug. 20, Lu is scheduled to make a transit stop in Seattle for two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG WILL GET READY FOR DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT LINKS

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said Saturday that his city government will step up efforts to get the Kaohsiung International Airport and Kaohsiung Harbor ready for direct cross-strait flight and shipping services.
He said the central government plans to open direct transportation links between Kaohsiung and mainland Chinese cities next year. "Kaohsiung will get everything ready by then," he said. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S 'ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS' FORMULA UNACCEPTABLE: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Saturday that it has always been the policy of his party to safeguard the sovereignty of the Republic of China.
He said the KMT position is that Taiwan's future should be decided by the people of Taiwan.
"We will not accept the 'one country, two systems' formula of mainland China, and we will not be subservient to the United States," he said.
"We will enhance Taiwan's security and development with the Hakka spirit of perseverance," he added.
Lien made the remarks at a meeting sponsored by the Taiwan Hakka Forum Association. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: MAKING TAIWAN A WORLD CENTER OF HAKKA CULTURE A KMT POLICY: LIEN

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan said Saturday that it is his party's policy to help Taiwan become a world center of Hakka culture.
He made the remarks when delivering a speech titled "Hakka Culture and National Development" at a meeting sponsored by the Taiwan Hakka Forum Association.

He said that the Hakka people have their roots in mainland China and that they are noted for their traditional spirit of perseverance and hard work. It is important to preserve and promote Hakka culture, he added.
Lien said it is a policy of the Kuomintang to promote Hakka culture by various social and educational means. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO COMMERCIALLY UTILIZE DEEP-SEA WATER

TEXT.P: The government has decided to set up an industrial complex in Taitung in eastern Taiwan to use deep-sea water in aquaculture and manufacturing of health drinks and cosmetics, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) oficial said Saturday.

The official from the MOEA's Water Resource Agency (WRA) said the ministry will first build a research center in Taitung to study the sea water 200 meters below the surface and ways to develop products using deep-sea water.

According to the official, deep-sea water accounts for 95 percent of total sea water. "Deep-sea water refers to sea water 200 meters to 1,000 meters below the surface," the official said, adding that deep-sea water is clean and rich in nutrients and minerals.
Deep-sea water is almost bacteria-free and can be used for multiple purposes, the official said.

Noting that Taitung is located near a continental shelf, the official said the eastern Taiwan county is an ideal location to house the island's first industrial complex using deep-sea water for commercial purposes.

The official said the WRA will come up with a blueprint for commercially utilizing deep-sea water next March and unveil a package of regulations governing investment in the new industrial park and management of companies using deep-sea water by the end of June next year.
In the initial stage, the official said, the deep-sea water industrial complex will accommodate aquaculture farms, health drinks and foodstuff processing facilities as well as cosmetic firms.
The industrial complex will also cooperate with tourist operators in developing ecotourism in eastern Taiwan, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS' NOT SUITABLE FOR TAIWAN: FORMER AIT HEAD

TEXT.P: A former top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties said in Taipei Saturday that the "one country, two systems" formula cherished by mainland China is not at all suitable for Taiwan.

Nat Bellocchi, former chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, made the comments at an international seminar on Hong Kong's development under Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula. The seminar was sponsored by the Taiwan Advocates, a private think tank headed by former ROC President Lee Teng-hui.

Bellocchi said that there are similarities between Taiwan and Hong Kong in terms of their relations with mainland China, but he added that the similarities are only on the economic level, not the political level.
He pointed out that both Taiwan and Hong Kong pump production technology and capital into the mainland, saying both places have contributed significantly to mainland China's high economic growth.
But he said that there are more differences than similarities between Taiwan and Hong Kong.

In terms of historical background and political systems, the "one country, two systems" formula is not suitable for Taiwan, he said, adding that the Taiwan people have to reflect deeply on the differences between this system and Taiwan's present system.
Noting that freedom is the top priority in Taiwan's democratic system, he said the Hong Kong people want to seek more freedom but are subjugated by the regime in Beijing which is against democracy.
Meanwhile, a Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council official and an economics expert pointed out on the same occasion that the "one country, two system" formula is unlikely to succeed.
Chen Min-tong, MAC vice chairman, said that the formula is contradictory in nature, noting that an authoritarian regime cannot uphold a free and open society.

On whether the Hong Kong people will be able to elect their chief executive someday, Chen said that democracy will not come in a single day. He expressed the hope that Hong Kong will learn from Taiwan's experience and that it will adopt a gradual and evolutionary method in prying open political room and help in the dawning of democracy in mainland China.

Chang Jung-feng, vice president of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, observed that the power of the Hong Kong chief executive comes from Beijing, and not from Hong Kong people, pointing out that Beijing is pulling the strings in Hong Kong behind him.
Chang said that from observing Hong Kong, one can see that even the most basic freedoms are threatened.
He concluded by saying that only after Taiwan and Hong Kong move toward freedom and democracy can they push mainland China to forego its authoritarian rule.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S METAMORPHOSIS ATTRIBUTABLE TO 'DE-LINKING' WITH CHINA: LEE

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said Saturday Taiwan's successful economic reform and political transformation could be attributed to its forsaking unrealistic links with mainland China.

In a keynote speech delivered at an international seminar on Hong Kong's development under the Beijing-initiated "one country, two systems" formula, Lee said Taiwan has managed to liberalize its economy and democratize its political system over the past decade mainly because it has pragmatically developed its own national identity and based its policy purely on the well-being of the island's 23 million people.

If Taiwan had continued claiming itself as the sole legitimate representative of China in the past decade, Lee said, Taiwan would not have been able to complete a series of economic and democratic reforms.

Nevertheless, Lee acknowledged that Taiwan still faces challenges in developing its independent national identity. While Beijing continues pressing Taiwan to accept its "one China" principle which downgrades Taiwan to a province under Beijing's jurisdiction, Lee said, pro-unification forces inside Taiwan will also hinder the island's pursuit of a separate national identity.

Lee further said Taiwan must not solely rely on the mainland market for its economic growth. "We must instead step up domestic investment, accelerate industrial upgrading and technology development as well as globalize business operation in order to sustain our economic growth," he urged, adding that the mainland market should serve as only one of local enterprises' overseas investment destinations.

Touching on Hong Kong's current economic and political plights, Lee said, the former British colony has gradually lost its independent identity and become increasingly reliant on the mainland since its reversion to Beijing's rule in 1997.
Under the "one country, two systems" formula, Lee said, Hong Kong will lose its momentum for pursuing its own goal in the long run and its current liberal lifestyle will also be at stake.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI BEATS AUSTRALIA IN YOUTH BASEBALL CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei beat Australia, 6:3, Saturday in the 11th "AA" World Youth Baseball Championship being held in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.
In another game Saturday, the United States beat Cuba 2:1.
Chinese Taipei will compete with the United States for the championship Sunday, while Australia will face Cuba for third place. The standings of each team in the game are as follows:
