DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 17, or the 20th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1424: The English defeat the Scots and the French at the Battle of Verneuil during the Hundred Years' War.
1786: Davy Crockett, American frontiersman and politician, is born. He was a U.S. representative from Tennessee who joined with Texan revolutionaries fighting against Mexico. He died at the siege of the Alamo in 1836.
1892: Mae West, American comedy actress and international sex symbol known for her sultry stage persona during the 1930s, is born. She wrote most of her own stage productions and film scripts.
1896: A massive influx of prospectors to the Yukon Territory of Canada is expected after the discovery of a major gold field at Bonanza Creek on the Klondike River.
1896: The first pedestrian to be killed by a car is knocked down in Croydon, England, by a car traveling at just 6.4 kilometers per hour.
1908: The world's first animated cartoon premiers in Paris.
1943: U.S. forces under Gen. George S. Patton liberate Messina, Italy, arriving just hours ahead of Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British Eighth Army.
1945: After the end of Japanese occupation, Indonesia declares itself a republic under the leadership of Dr. Sukarno.
1946: After ordering Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the government on Aug. 11, 1945, the communist Yenan General Headquarters issues a second mobilization order instructing all communist forces to launch a full-scale war against the Nationalists.
1960: Gabon gains independence from France.
1961: The polio vaccine developed by American researcher Albert B. Sarbin is approved for use in the United States.
1975: Europe's first particle accelerator is formally inaugurated in Geneva, Switzerland.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks Mindanao in the Philippines, killing some 8,000 people.
1982: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement urging the United States to recognize Beijing's ambitious attempt to take over Taiwan, following the issue of the "Aug. 17 Joint Communique" by the United States and mainland China. The ministry also asks the United States to implement the Taiwan Relations Act.
1987: Rudolf Hess, Adolf Hitler's close friend and deputy leader of the Nazi party, commits suicide in his cell in Spandau Prison in West Berlin at the age of 93.
1988: Gen. Zia ul-Haq, Pakistan's iron-fisted ruler for the previous 11 years, dies at the age of 64 when his camouflaged C-130 Hercules plane crashes shortly after takeoff from Bahawalpur.
1989: An Australian airliner becomes the first commercial plane to fly nonstop from London to Sydney.
1993: The ROC and Australia sign two memoranda, one protecting industrial property rights and the second promoting investment and technical cooperation.
1995: A French supersonic jetliner completes a round-the-globe trip in 31 hours 27 minutes and 49 seconds, faster than the previous record by one hour and 20 minutes.
1995: ROC Control Yuan President Chen Li-an announces his candidacy for the 1996 presidential election, one day before renouncing his KMT membership, which he has held for 42 years.
2000: Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso expresses her warm welcome to Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is in Panama for a two-day visit.
2000: Chen Yi-song, leader of the Agriculture Technical Mission to the Republic of the Gambia, says that ROC agriculture technologists have transformed the Gambia River basin, which used to yield nothing but peanuts, into the "rice bowl of West Africa" over a period of five years.
2001: Taiwan's two major paper makers -- Yuen Foong Yu Paper and Chung Hwa Pulp -- sign a merger agreement and promise that there will be no layoffs in the new company.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you learn, but once learning a thing, you must never give it up until you have mastered it."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
TAIPEI MAYOR LEAVES FOR TORONTO AND FIVE U.S. CITIES

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will leave for Toronto Sunday afternoon to begin his 11-day visit to six major cities in Canada and the United States, an official of the Taipei City Government said.

After visiting Toronto, he will proceed to Boston, Washington, Atlanta, Phoenix, and San Francisco. While in these cities, he will visit hospitals and disease control organizations to study their measures to control severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). He will also meet with business leaders in these cities. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU SUPPORTS IN PRINCIPLE KMT-PFP ABSENTEE VOTING PLAN

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) agreed in principle Sunday with a "pan-blue alliance" proposal to allow Taiwan voters to cast ballots in the upcoming presidential election even if they are not residing where they were registered to vote.
The solidarity ends there, however, as the two disagree about how to deal with Taiwan residents living in mainland China and dual passport holders living abroad.

The "pan-blue alliance, " composed of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) , want to include these two classes of potential voters in the absentee voter plan, but the TSU wants them excluded.

Cheng Jhen-long, a TSU party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said all ROC citizens have the right to vote and their rights should not be taken way because they are away from the places where they registered.

However, Cheng pointed out that those potential voters living in mainland China and those who live elsewhere around the world and are dual passport holders should be excluded to protect the integrity of their votes. Cheng said that the exclusion would prevent the absentee voters from being unduly influenced by outside forces.

Cheng said dual passport holders should be excluded because of the questions that could arise surrounding their loyalty to the country, while mainland-based Taiwanese business people should also be excluded based on the fact that Taiwan and mainland China are technically in a hostile state and that Taiwan maintains no organizations in mainland China that have public credibility.
Not everyone agreed with the proposal on absentee voting, however.

Chen Chi-mai, a legislative party whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said he was against the idea, saying that the program would not be viable, at least currently, since there is no way to know whether the absentee voters were marking and mailing their own ballots.
The KMT and PFP will introduce the proposal in the new Legislative Yuan session in September.

The "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers are also planning to propose additional legislation in the form of an amendment to the Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law to allow different political parties to jointly field one ticket in the 2004 presidential election.
There is currently nothing on the books prohibiting such a coalition, but the "pan-blue alliance" hopes to get the amendment passed to solidify the legitimacy of their bi-party presidential ticket.

If the two amendments are passed in the next legislative session, the mainland China-based Taiwanese business people, numbering about 500,000, would be included in the March 20, 2004 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT LINKS WOULD HAVE 'GRAVE IMPACT', SAYS ROC DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait will have a grave impact on Taiwan's security since mainland China has never forsaken its hostility toward Taiwan, Minister of National Defense Tang Yiau-min said over the weekend.
Tang said direct cross-Taiwan Strait transportation links must follow the "point-to-point and fixed route" principle to avoid having Taiwan's national security compromised.

Speaking at a news conference Friday where the nation's first assessment report on the impact of direct cross-strait transportation was unveiled, Tang said the military would face daunting challenges in talks about opening direct shipping or flights across the Taiwan Strait.
It is, therefore, the military's responsibility to come up with well-devised measures to meet the needs arise from the opening, Tang noted.

According to Beijing's defense white paper, Tang said, mainland authorities will never renounce the use of force against Taiwan and will not allow the current separation of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to continue indefinitely.
Worse still, Tang said, mainland China has adjusted its military deployment by placing emphasis on its southeastern coastal region that lies opposite Taiwan.

Tang said mainland China has deployed more guided ballistic missiles and new types of fighters, warships and submarines in its southeastern provinces, and the People's Liberation Army regularly conducts combined services drills with Taiwan as the objective.

Although the Taiwan Strait provides a natural buffer for Taiwan, Tang said direct cross-strait flights will pose a grave threat to Taiwan's security as it takes only three to five minutes for mainland Chinese jet fighters to reach Taiwan should the fighters take off from Pingtan in Fujian province heading to Hsinchu. The distance between the two points is only 70 nautical miles, Tang said.
Ministry of National Defense officials said there were examples in the West where military fighters camouflaged as civilian passenger airplanes were used to attack and bomb countries during wartime.
Officials wondered who would guarantee that mainland Chinese airplanes or ships crossing the Strait are not equipped with monitoring equipment for military espionage.

Meanwhile, many Taiwan academics and scholars who are familiar with national defense and related affairs said the nation should attach equal importance to defense preparedness and direct cross-strait transportation links.
The scholars said they support increased budgets for the military to avoid opening direct cross-strait transportation links at the cost of Taiwan's national security.
Prof. Chang Wu-yueh from Tamkang University said the armed forces should be prepared for any military situation, whether there will be direct cross-strait transportation links or not.
The people's psychological defense, which could be reduced once direct cross-strait transportation links are opened, is a more important issue to tackle, Chang noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTRY DELEGATION TO RETURN AFTER U.S. SWING

TEXT.P: A trade promotion delegation led by Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fun will return to Taiwan Monday following a week-long tour in the United States, which has allowed the ministry to gain business worth US$130 billion, according to ministry officials.

The delegation, which departed for the United States Aug. 9, visited 11 companies based in Los Angeles, San Diego, Chicago and New York, including DuPont, General Electric, Corning, Gateway, BD, DeAmertek, Simax, ITW, and Quest Pharmaceutical Services.

Lin also invited their executives to take part in the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference stated for Oct. 19-22 in Taipei, with most of the companies agreeing to send officials to the event, the first of its kind, the officials noted.

According to the officials, the economics ministry delegation also sponsored seminars in the Chicago area to introduce Taiwan's overall investment climate and the development of its telecommunications, biotechnology, digital content and the information sectors, successfully attracting potential investors for these domestic industries.
Members of the delegation come from the Industrial Development Bureau, Industrial Technology Research Institute and China External Trade Development Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION PARTIES RESERVED ABOUT SPECIAL BUDGET FOR ARM PURCHASE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense's request for a special budget of NT$520 billion (US$15.15 billion) next year to acquire arms already offered from the United States was greeted with reservation Sunday from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP).

The defense ministry will need the funds to acquire six batteries of Patriot Advance Capability, or PAC-3, missiles, two long-range radar systems, eight diesel submarines, and 12 P-3 Orion sub-hunting surveillance aircraft.

The United States has agreed to sell these weapons to Taiwan, but Taipei has had difficulty coming up with the funds to buy them all. It prompted Washington officials to doubt Taiwan's determination to defend itself.

The special budget, more than double the current defense budget of NT$260 billion (US$7.62 billion) for 2003, is expected to be present to the Legislative Yuan for approval in the next legislative session beginning September.
Legislator Lee Wen-chung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said it is better for the Legislative Yuan to approve this budget before the presidential election in March, 2004.

Noting that the military balance across the Taiwan Strait will tilt toward the mainland in the next two to four years, Lee said the armed forces needs some time to be trained to use any new equipment and integrate it into the defense system, and that there is no time to waste.

Furthermore, Taiwan will choose a new president next March, which is certain to preempt any defense issues in the Legislative Yuan, and the budget will be further delayed if a new administration emerges after the election, but the country's security cannot be postponed.
His view was questioned by PFP Legislator Chiu Yi, who said the Legislative Yuan should not deal with such a huge budget before the presidential election.
If the election results in a new government, it is better to leave the question to the new government and give it a free hand in dealing with it.

PFP whip at the Legislative Yuan Lin Yu-fang said the budget for arms acquisition would be better prepared as an ordinary budget rather than a special budget so that the legislature could examine its details easier.

The Executive Yuan should not avoid the legislature's supervision of the arms purchase by hiding it in a special budget as all budgets are financed by the government's revenues and should be monitored by the legislature.

Lawmaker Lee Chia-ching, the KMT whip at the Legislative Yuan, also questioned the appropriateness of purchasing arms with a special budget. Lee warning that the country's has already run up a debt of NT$4.79 trillion (US$139.52 billion) and additional debt of NT$520 billion, which has to be raised through loans, could be crippling for the government and the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ELECTRONICS MANUFACTURERS NEED TO ADVANCE R&D AND LOGISTICS

TEXT.P: Taiwan electronics manufacturers operating in mainland China need to advance their research and development capabilities and logistics to maintain their advantages in that market, according a survey report released by the National Science Council Sunday.

The report says that the electronics industries on both sides of the Taiwan Strait are closely correlated, with 70 percent of the mainland electronics manufacturers doing business directly or indirectly with their Taiwanese counterparts.

While most Taiwanese electronics manufacturers decided to move their production lines to the mainland to cut down production costs and to have easier access to the market, in recent years, increasing numbers of Taiwanese investors have made the efficiency of local government and the living environment their major elements of consideration, according to the report.

In terms of market strategies, most of the Taiwanese manufacturers on the mainland delivered their products as OEMs (original equipment manufacturers) and ODMs (other design and manufacturers) for international brand companies. The profit margins of the Taiwanese companies were squeezed whenever these international corporation engaged in a price war, according to the report.

The report points out that the Taiwanese manufacturers should watch closely the market developments on the mainland, as the electronics industry there has gradually developed its own supply chain of parts and components.

For many years, the electronics manufacturers on the mainland, including Taiwanese investments, purchased the lion's share of parts and components from Taiwan for their assembly plants. With the establishment of its own supply chain, electronics manufacturers on the mainland have reduced their reliance on Taiwan, according to the report.
The report suggests that the electronics industry in Taiwan must advance its capabilities in research and development and maintain its advantages in logistic management.

While many Taiwanese electronics manufacturers have kept their operational headquarters in Taiwan after moving their production lines to the mainland, logistic expertise, including inventory management and other backups, remain an advantage for Taiwan's electronics industry.
In order to maintain their international competitiveness, the Taiwan electronics manufacturers must advance their capabilities in global logistics, the report says.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEDGE FUND OFFERING IS LONG-TERM TREND: INSTITUTIONAL INVESTOR

TEXT.P: Foreign institutional investors suggested that as Taiwan's monetary market becomes more and more internationalized and liberalized, the long-term trend will see authorities allowing hedge funds.

An executive of a foreign investment and trust company said Sunday that since the government announced in July that as a deregulation approach of the capital market, the qualified foreign institutional investors (QFII) system will be suspended by the end of this year, foreign institutional investors are very concerned about the possibilities of offering hedge funds in Taiwan.

A hedge fund is a fund that can take both long and short positions, use arbitrage, buy and sell undervalued securities, trade options or bonds, and invest in almost any opportunity in any market where it foresees impressive gains at reduced risk.
Hedge funds are not approved by authorities in many parts of the world, including Taiwan, especially after the Asian crisis when hedge funds were mostly associated with negativity.

An executive of an European investment and trust company said that currently, daily buying and selling in the Taiwan stock exchange by foreign institutional investors amounted to tens of billions of NT dollars on the average, while at least 10 percent of the money was managed by hedge funds with detour methods.
He said that it is anticipated that with the lifting of the QFII restrictions, hedge funds will become ever more active in Taiwan's capital market.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG SERVES AS A MIRROR FOR TAIWAN: FORMER PRESIDENT LEE

TEXT.P: Hong Kong serves as a mirror for Taiwan of the failure of the "one country, two systems" formula that has been imposed on the former British colony since its reversion to Beijing rule in 1997, former President Lee Teng-hui said Sunday.

Through this mirror, Taiwan sees only disillusion and danger in terms of "one country, two systems, " said Lee during the second day of an international seminar which opened Saturday on Hong Kong's development under Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula which. The seminar was sponsored by Taiwan Advocates, a private think tank headed by Lee.

Lee said Hong Kong's political and economic quagmire over the past six years is a testament to the depletion of Hong Kong's sovereignty and autonomy that has been caused by the "one country, two systems" formula.

Under the program, Hong Kong has no other option but to be controlled under the "one country, " framework, Lee said, adding that the illusion of "two systems" has contributed nothing to Hong Kongers but only helped reduce their pursuit of the goal of self identification.
From observing Hong Kong, Lee said, one can see the differences that Taiwan can make for itself.

Lee said Taiwan has managed to liberalize its economy and democratize its political system over the past decade mainly because it has pragmatically developed its own national identity and based its policy purely on the well-being of the island's 23 million people.

If Taiwan had continued claiming itself as the sole legitimate representative of China in the past decade, Lee said, Taiwan would not have been able to complete a series of economic and democratic reforms.

Lee said if Taiwan had not chosen to promote pragmatic diplomacy and advocated that Taiwan represents the 23 million people living on the island, Taiwan would have no room for international development.

If Taiwan continued to rely on the mainland Chinese market for its economic growth, Taiwan would eventually end up being a satellite manufacturing plant of China, and would be known as the "world's factory," Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: H.K. LEGISLATORS DENOUNCED AFTER SPEAKING AT SEMINAR IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Hong Kong Legislative Council Members James To and Emily Lau were denounced Sunday after they spoke Saturday in an international seminar on "Hong Kong under 'one country, two systems'" in Taipei.

The pro-Beijing Hong Kong daily Ta Kung Pao reported Sunday that To, Lau, and three scholars "talked down" Hong Kong and the "one country, two systems" formula. They said the proposed enactment of Hong Kong's state security law, also known as Article 23 of the Basic Law, will have an impact on human rights and freedom of the press and effectively gag the news media in Hong Kong.

The report said Li Gwojiang, a committee member of the mainland Chinese National People's Consultative Conference, "condemned these irresponsible remarks for putting a negative label on the "one country, two systems" formula." They were accused of attempting to promote Taiwan independence and smear the formula for national unification. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: CUBA BEATS AUSTRALIA IN "AA" WORLD YOUTH BASEBALL FOR THIRD PLACE

TEXT.P: Cuba beat Australia 10-9 Sunday to win the bronze medal on the last day of the 11th "AA" World Youth Baseball Championship being held in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

The teams were tied at 7-7 in the sixth inning. Cuba had three runs in the third inning, two runs each in the fifth, sixth, and eighth innings, and one run in the seventh. Australia scored six runs in the fifth inning, two runs in the seventh, and two more in the eighth.
Each team had 12 hits. Cuba made one error, while Australia made five.
Australia was placed fourth. The competition will come to an end after Chinese Taipei and the United States compete for the championship Sunday afternoon. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI WINS CHAMPIONSHIP AT U.S. AMATEUR BASEBALL GAME

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei won the championship of the American National Baseball Conference (NBC) World Series Saturday in Wichita, Kansas, an official of the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association said here Sunday.
Chinese Taipei defeated the Santa Barbara Foresters from California, 5-0, and became the first foreign team to win the championship in its 69-year history, the anonymous official said.
Chinese Taipei's pitcher, Tu Chang-wei, allowed only one hit in nine innings and struck out 14.
Chinese Taipei opened an early lead by scoring three runs in the first inning.

The NBC World Series is the biggest amateur baseball tourney in the United States. It brought more than 40 teams from around the world to compete against each other in Wichita from Aug. 2-16 this year.
Chinese Taipei will travel around the United States before going to Canada for another baseball champion on Aug. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT LEE REPORTEDLY OFFERING TO COOPERATE IN PROBE

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui is reportedly offering to cooperate with investigators looking into an alleged slush fund at the National Security Bureau, according to a lawmaker from the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), a political party founded by Lee's followers.

TSU lawmaker Chien Lin Hui-chun quoted Lee as saying that he has no knowledge about a secret fund at the National Security Bureau, not to mention allegations that part it was channeled secretly to the Taiwan Research Institute where Lee was head after he was president.
Chien Lin quoted Lee as claiming that he learned of the secret fund only from newspaper reports and has no idea how the fund was used, if it indeed existed.

Chien Lin came to the defense of Lee one day after Liu Tai-ying, president of the Taiwan Research Institute and Lee's confidant, was questioned by prosecutors for 10 hours over allegations that the National Security Bureau transferred some US$7.5 million form the secret fund to the Taiwan Research Institute in 1994 while Lee served as ROC president.
Investigators suspected that Liu used the fund to line his own pockets, an allegation denied by Liu.
Liu was quoted as telling investigators that he received the money and used it according to Lee's instructions.
A prosecutor in charge of the investigation asked that Liu be detained but the request was turned down by the court Saturday morning.
Lee was not available for comment Sunday.

Liu was detained Feb. 10 in connection with allegations that he took bribes from a local businesswoman. He was released on bail June 7 after being indicted on a dozen counts of bribery-related charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES TO BE FOCAL POINT IN 2004 PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Cross-Taiwan Strait issues are set to become the focal point in the 2004 presidential campaign, as comments recently made by President Chen Shui-bian on Taiwan-mainland ties were criticized by the opposition parties, political observers said Sunday.

Major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chang and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong have in a low-key fashion responded to Chen's claims made last week that "there is one country on either side of the Taiwan Strait" and that "direct cross-strait transportation ties will be completed in three stages by the end of 2004."

Criticizing Chen's direct transportation links promise as a "rubber check, " Lien declared that he would immediately launch two-way negotiations on the issue as long as he wins the next presidential election.

The KMT chairman said he would work to forge the much-expected direct transportation links across the Strait without any hesitation if elected president because it is an issue that is very much in the interests of the Taiwan people.
Soong called Chen's claims "sheer election language, " and said if the president was sincere, why not make the move now instead of waiting until the end of next year?

Chang Hsien-yao, head of the cross-Taiwan Strait political affairs task force under the KMT-PFP alliance, said Chen's statements about "one country on either side" and "direct links" are a two-pronged strategy with which the president is trying to secure the support of the traditional pro-independence backers while at the same time garnering greater backing from "middle of the road" voters.

According to Chang, the KMT and the PFP are working actively on a "Taiwan development blueprint, " in which the two parties will clearly outline the goals of bilateral economic relations, the measures to protect Taiwan business interests on the mainland and a concrete timetable on the direct transportation links.

Former Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi said Chen has launched an ideological strike against the KMT and warned the KMT not to dance to Chen's tune. He urged Chen to make it clear which country he was referring to when talking about "one country on either side."

KMT legislative whip Lee Chia-chin said Chen's strategy to tie in the "one country on either side" concept with the direct links issue will make the links impossible to be realized, despite an apparent fact that his direct links promise is aimed at soliciting ballots from mainland-based Taiwan businessmen and their families.

Stressing that a legal framework is required to carry out the direct transportation links, Lee expressed the hope that the MAC would devise a timetable and include it into the revised draft of the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, which is waiting for approval by the Legislative Yuan in the next session.

Echoing the comments by MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung that national and economic affairs, rather than foreign affairs, will have greater leverage in a presidential race, analysts said delicate cross-strait issues will unavoidably become the focus of the debate between the ruling and opposition camps prior to the coming presidential poll in March 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNITED STATES WINS CHAMPIONSHIP IN YOUTH BASEBALL

TEXT.P: The United States won the championship Sunday in the XI "AA" World Youth Baseball Championship being held in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.
It wass the third-straight time that the United States has won.
The United States beat Chinese Taipei 11-7 in the final.

Chinese Taipei took the early by scoring two runs in the top of the first inning, but the United States turned the tables on the host country by scoring four runs in the bottom of the first and widened the lead by adding one run each in the second and third innings, and lead the game 6-2 at the end of the third inning.

Chinese Taipei scored two runs in the fifth inning, but the United States scores four runs, including a three-run home run, in the same inning. The Chinese Taipei scored two runs in the sixth inning, and the United State scored another run in the seventh inning.
In the top of the ninth, Chinese Taipei scored one run with two out, and had to settle for second place in the championship. It is the sixth time Chinese Taipei has finished second.
In the semifinal, which was played earlier, Cuba defeated Australia 10-9 to take third place.
The championship, from Aug. 8-17, involved nine teams. In addition to the four teams in the semifinal and final, there was
Japan, the Czech Republic, South Africa, South Korea and Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 18, or the 21st day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1227: The Mongol ruler Genghis Khan, who through conquest created a vast empire that extended from the Pacific to the Dnieper River, dies after falling from his horse. He was 65.
1503: Pope Alexander VI, originally Rodrigo Borgia, Spanish-born pontiff since 1492, dies in Rome at the age of 72 after succumbing to a fever. He was noted as a patron of the arts and for his corrupt papacy.
1759: The British led by Adm. Boscowen defeat a French fleet at Lagos, Portugal.
1825: Scottish explorer Alexander Gordon Laing becomes the first European to reach Timbuktu, located in present-day Mali.
1830: Franz-Joseph I, the Austro-Hungarian emperor who invaded Serbia and helped initiate World War 1, is born.
1917: Casper Weinberger, American statesman and secretary of defense for President Ronald Reagan, is born.
1932: Scottish aviator Jim Mollison makes the first westbound transatlantic solo flight, from Portmarnock, Ireland, to Pennfield, New Brunswick.
1945: Henry Pu Yi steps down as emperor of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed in China by the Japanese in 1932. He was nabbed by Russian troops two days later.
1946: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, declares that he had written a memo to President Franklin D. Roosevelt asking the president not to use the atomic bomb against Japan.
1966: Some one million Red Guards hold a huge demonstration in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in celebration of the "great proletarian cultural revolution" launched by Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong.
1974: Taiwan baseball teams for the first time win the Little League, Senior League and Big League world titles in the same year.
1984: South Africa is banned from taking part in the Olympic Games because of its policy of apartheid.
1985: A ship sinks near Harbin in northeastern China, leaving 171 people dead or missing.
1987: Terrorists throw grenades into the Congress of Sri Lanka, killing two people and injuring 16 others, including Prime Minister Ranasinghe Premadasa.
1988: The Mainland Affairs Task Force is established under the Republic of China Executive Yuan.
1989: Colombian presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan is assassinated. The Colombian government takes immediate action by launching a nationwide crackdown on drug dealers.
1991: Vice President Li Yuan-zu of the Republic of China leaves for a state visit to Costa Rica, Nicaragua and Honduras and to attend the 23rd Plenary Meeting of the World League for Freedom and Democracy in San Jose, Costa Rica.
1992: The Department of Anti-Corruption is established under the ROC Ministry of Justice.
1994: An earthquake rocks the Mascara region of western Algeria, killing more than 120 people.
1995: A referendum is held in Bermuda, with 73 percent of the voters in the British dependency voting against independence.
1997: Typhoon Winnie hits Taiwan, killing some 40 people and injuring 81 others.
2000: The Paraguayan embassy in Taipei requests that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs lift an import ban on beef from Paraguay, saying that there have been no cases of foot-and-mouth disease reported among the country's livestock.
2000: The Taiwan Journalists' Association issues a statement expressing its disappointment and regret over the appointment of former Kuomintang Youth Commission Director Lai Kuo-chow to chair the board of directors of Taiwan Television Enterprises, Ltd.
2001: Core members of the pro-unification opposition New Party visit the Yuanshan Martyrs Shrine in protest of Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's recent visit to a controversial war memorial.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you inquire into, but when you inquire into a thing, you must never give it up until you have thoroughly understood it."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VOLUNTEER GROUP ARRIVES IN GAMBIA TO PROVIDE MEDICAL SERVICE

TEXT.P: A volunteer group organized by the Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps (TRMPC) has kicked off a 10-day tour of providing free medical service in the West African state of Gambia, a spokesman for the Taipei-based charity organization said Monday.

The 21-member group, headed by TRMPC President Liu Chi-chun, arrived in Banjul, Gambia's capital, early Monday, the spokesman said, adding that the delegation will begin providing free medical service in Fatoto, one of the farthest inland villages in Gambia, after meeting with Gambian Health Minister Yankuba Kassama later in the day.

Gambia is a malaria-stricken area and has limited medical facilities and professional health care staff. Only those who contract mild ailments can receive treatment in Gambia, while those afflicted with major diseases are usually sent to European countries for treatment. Gambia's infant mortality rate is 0.85 percent, and its life expectancy is only about 44 years.

During its 10-day tour, the spokesman said, the TRMPC group will offer free medical services in densely populated townships near Banjul as well as in remote villages, including one village that borders Senegal.

The group includes four physicians, three dentists, two pharmacists, four nurses and several other volunteer workers. Many of them have rich experience in offering volunteer medical services in Liberia, Swaziland, Bolivia, Paraguay and Peru. The group is scheduled to return to Taiwan Aug. 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO PUSH FOR ABSENTEE VOTING

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will push for the implementation of absentee voting to allow Republic of China voters to cast their ballots in the 2004 presidential election even if they are away from the places where they registered, the KMT legislative caucus said Monday.

The KMT caucus will push for the passage of an amendment to the Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law so as to allow the some 1 million ROC voters residing overseas, including those in mainland China, to cast absentee ballots via correspondence, said Lee Chia-chin, a KMT party whip at the Legislative Yuan.
Lee said it is hoped that the amendment will be introduced and passed in September when the new Legislative Yuan session begins.

Noting that voting is one of the basic rights of ROC citizens aged 20 and over, Lee said their right to elect the president should not be compromised because they are away from the place where they registered.

KMT Legislator Lee Chuan-chiao, a former party whip, said this is not the first time that the KMT has proposed the absentee voting plan. Actually, he said, the KMT has made similar proposals many times before at the Legislative Yuan, but all have been killed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

If the absentee voting amendment is again ambushed during the upcoming legislative session, Lee said, the KMT will demand that the administration at least allow the opening of "voting chartered flights" across the Taiwan Strait in the days prior to the presidential election day, set for March 20, 2004, to facilitate mainland China-based Taiwan businesspeople voting. Mainland-based Taiwan businesspeople currently number about 500,000.

Lee, meanwhile, noted that the KMT will also push for the opening of faster and more convenient transportation links between Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen and the mainland Chinese port city of Xiamen in Fujian Province as another channel to facilitate voting by the mainland-based voters.

KMT Legislator Wang Chung-yu urged the government to build up an absentee voting system as quickly as possible to allow the 1 million ROC citizens who have endeavored to live overseas and have contributed to Taiwan's economic prosperity, to enjoy their right to vote.

The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , an ally of the ruling DPP, said Sunday that it agrees in principle with the KMT proposal to allow ROC voters to cast ballots in the upcoming presidential election via correspondence, but only on the condition that those living in mainland China and those with dual citizenship living abroad be excluded.

Cheng Jhen-long, a TSU party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said these ROC citizens should be excluded in order to protect the integrity of their voting rights, claiming that their exclusion would prevent the absentee voters from being unduly influenced by outside forces.

Cheng said dual passport holders should be excluded because of the questions that could arise surrounding their loyalty to the country, while mainland-based Taiwan businesspeople should also be excluded based on the fact that Taiwan and mainland China are technically in a hostile state and that Taiwan maintains no organizations in mainland China that have public credibility.

Chen Chi-mai, a legislative party whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), on Sunday voice his opposition to the idea, saying that the program would not be viable, at least at the present time, since there would be no way to verify whether the absentee voters were marking and mailing their own ballots.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES UP BY 28.06 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Monday, with the weighted index moving up 28.06 points to close at 5,516.8.
Market turnover amounted to NT$101.58 billion (US$2.96 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT GURU TO PRESENT POLICY INITIATIVES TO PREMIER

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) Chairman Wang Yung-ching said Monday that he cannot understand why the government will wait until late next year to open direct cross-Taiwan Strait transportation links.

Wang was referring to President Chen Shui-bian's announcement last week that his administration has come up with a three-phase plan to promote direct cross-strait transportation, with the goal of opening direct shipping and flight services by the end of next year.

Wang, widely known as a management guru, didn't go into detail about his views on Chen's announcement. Instead, he said he plans to present a letter to Premier Yu Shyi-kun in the near future offering some policy initiatives.

During the previous Kuomintang administration, Wang once presented a 10,000-word letter to then-President Lee Teng-hui calling for an overhaul of the cherished "go slow, be patient" policy toward mainland China and for an early opening of direct cross-strait transportation links.

On Monday, Wang said he would urge the current Democratic Progressive Party administration to halt construction on the controversial Fourth Nuclear Power Plant and to scrap the state-owned Taiwan Power Co.'s project to build a natural gas-powered electricity generation plant in Taoyuan County's Tatan township.

In his view, Wang said, the cost of building a coal-fueled thermal power plant is much lower. Moreover, he said turning the Tatan plant into a coal-fueled power plant will contribute to the development of Taoyuan's Kuantang into a commercial harbor with metropolitan Taipei as its service market.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and then fluctuated on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 28.06 points to close at 5,516.8.
The bourse opened at 5,528.09 and fluctuated between 5,539.02 and 5,480.64 during trading.
A total of 4.68 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$101.58 billion (US$2.96 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with electrical shares moving down 0.2 percent.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 5.6 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 3.3 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 2.4 percent, foodstuff shares at 2 percent, cement stocks at 1.8 percent, textile issues at 0.7 percent, and plastics and chemical stocks at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 456 to 222, with 98 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were generally higher on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved up 49 points to close at 5,539, with 22,105 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September gained 49 points to finish at 5,539, with 10,556 contract transactions, while December futures lost 5 points to close at 5,510, with 11 contracts traded.
March futures fell 5 points to finish at 5,520, with 9 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,490 for August, 5,490 for September, 5,515 for December, 5,525 for March, and 5,494 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stock, were higher.
August TE futures increased 0.8 points to close at 246, with 2,561 contract transactions, while September TE futures rose 0.75 points to finish at 245.5, with 1,463 contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.
August TF futures moved up 18.4 points to close at 723.4, with 3,038 contract transactions, while September TF futures gained 16.2 points to finish at 720.8, with 3,571 contracts traded.
December TF futures rose 15 points to close at 720, with 6 contract transactions, while March TF futures surged 30.8 points to finish at 723, with only one contract changing hands.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN CHILDREN'S CHORUS HEADS TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Kinmen Children's Chorus headed for mainland China's Xiamen Monday aboard a ferry boat to participate in a children's music camp, the Kinmen Education Bureau (KEB) said.
The chorus' visit marked the first cross-Taiwan Strait cultural exchange via the "three mini links" since the containment of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS,) KEB Director Lu Chih-huei said.
The three mini links refers to direct trade, shipping and postal links between Taiwan's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the mainland Chinese ports of Xiamen and Mawei.

The Kinmen Children's Chorus, which took part in a music contest in Xiamen last August, will participate in a children's music summer camp in Quanzhou near Xiamen in Fujian province from Aug. 18 through Aug. 22, Lu said.

Meanwhile, Lu said, the Kinmen County government plans to invite elementary and junior high school basketball teams from Xiamen to participate in a friendly competition in Kinmen later this year. (by Nocturne Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: YU PROMISES NT 3.2 B. FOR GUGGENHEIM CONSTRUCTION IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun promised Taichung Mayor Jason Hu Monday that the Executive Yuan will allocate NT$3.2 billion (US$93 million) to cover part of the costs for the construction of a Guggenheim Museum in the central Taiwan city.
Yu said the Executive Yuan has decided to foot the bill for half of the initial costs for the Guggenheim Museum project in Taichung.

He added that if more funds are needed, further allocations will require discussions by the Council of Cultural Affairs, the Council for Economic Planning and Development, as well as the governments of several neighboring cities and counties surrounding Taichung City.

Quoting Premier Yu, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Liu Shih-fang said at a press conference held after a meeting between Yu and Hu at the premier's office that the Taichung mayor had asked for a subsidy of NT$5.2 billion from the central government for the construction of a Guggenheim museum, an international project.

The Executive Yuan will make further assessments on the project before deciding whether the Guggenheim Museum project in Taichung should be annexed to a sub-project of the three-year, NT$300 billion infrastructure development plan to develop a cultural park in central Taiwan. If the Executive Yuan does decide to, the Guggenheim project may have a chance to be subsidized with more funds from the government, Liu noted.

For his part, Hu said he would like to offer his appreciation on behalf of Taichung City to Premier Yu for the subsidy promise, adding that he and Taichung City would be glad to wait for another three weeks, as the Executive Yuan promised, to receive an answer as to whether added funds will be possible for the project.

Hu said he is equally appreciative toward President Chen Shui-bian, who said during a recent inspection visit in Taichung that the Guggenheim Museum is an international development project and that he will see to it that the Executive Yuan financially supports the project.

An opposition Kuomintang stalwart, Hu, who has maintained useful and constructive interactions with President Chen and his ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said last year that he is dedicated to building Taichung City into a "city of culture."

Hu traveled to Spain in July 2002 to sign an agreement with the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao -- where the prestigious New York-based museum has a branch -- to conduct a feasibility study on setting up a branch in Taichung.
He said he has also envisaged building an amphitheater and a national opera house in Taichung City to enable it to become a "city of culture."

The New York-based Guggenheim Museum, a prestigious museum known for its modern and contemporary international art collections and related museum activities, also operates affiliated museums in Las Vegas, as well as Berlin, Germany.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL ECONOMIC ADVISER LEAVES FOR JAPAN TO BOLSTER TIES
DOC.DATELINE: CKS International Airport, northern Taiwan, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Vincent Siew, an economic advisor to President Chen Shui-bian, left for Tokyo Monday on a mission aimed at bolstering science and technology cooperation between Taiwan and Japan.

Siew, accompanied by Tsai Ching-yen, a minister-without-portfolio, is visiting Japan in his capacity as director of the Science and Technology Committee under the Association of East Asian Relations (AEAR)

The AEAR is an intermediary body established to handle exchanges between Taiwan and Japan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations. Its Japanese counterpart agency is the Taipei office of the Interchange Association.

The government is reportedly attaching great importance to Siew's visit to Japan. During the five-day visit, Siew will take advantage of his long-time personal ties with Japan's official and private sectors in efforts to advance Taiwan-Japan exchanges in the field of science and technology.

Siew, head of the presidential economic advisory panel, is a former premier and an incumbent vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang. He also concurrently serves as chairman of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER UNVEILS ROSTER OF REFERENDUM PROMOTION COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun on Monday unveiled the roster of a special committee in preparation for holding a referendum on several major policy issues before or on March 20, 2004 -- the day of the next presidential election.

The new committee comprises 14 members, including eight private representatives and six government officials, Yu said, adding that the formation of the committee marks an important step in preparatory work for the holding of a referendum.
The eight private representatives include Tai Sheng-tung, president of the ROC National Association of Small and Medium Enterprises, three lawyers and four university professors.

The six government representatives are Minister-without-Portfolio Hsu Chih-hsiung; Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien; Central Personnel Administration Director-General Lee Yi-yang; Government Information Office Director-General Huang Huei-chen; Director-General Liu San-chi of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics; and Lin Chia-cheng, chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission.

Yu said Hsu, who played a leading role in the drafting of a comprehensive package of regulations governing the holding of referendums in the event that the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan continues stonewalling the passage of a referendum bill, will serve as chairman of the new committee.
The committee will hold its first meeting next Monday to set a detailed work agenda, Yu said.

The package of referendum regulations, released July 17, authorizes the Cabinet to hold referendums and set up a special committee to screen topics to be subject to referendums and relevant technical details.

According to the regulations, the committee can comprise 11 to 15 members, with each serving a two-year term. The premier is authorized to name one of them to serve as committee chairman. The number of members from any one political party should not exceed 50 percent of the total number of members.

Four of the committee members belong to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, while the remaining 12 are independents. The three major opposition parties -- the Kuomintang, the People First Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- do not have any representatives in the new committee.
