DOC.HEADLINE: CURRENT TAIWAN-S. KOREA SCHOLARS' MEETING GOOD FOR TIES: FORMER VP
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China Vice President Li Yuan-zu on Monday expressed hope that the current meeting of scholars from Taiwan and South Korea can help strengthen substantial ties and mutual understanding between the two countries.

Li, who is now senior adviser to the president and adviser of the ROC-South Korean Culture Foundation, made the remarks in a speech delivered at the annual scholars' convention between the two countries, which severed diplomatic ties in 1992.
This year's meeting will focus on education in both countries, problems related to being admitted to a university, the cultivation of teachers, as well as education on environmental protection.
Conclusions reached at this, the 24th meeting of its kind which has been held alternately in Taipei and Seoul every year, will be sent to government agencies of both countries for reference.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMAN ARRESTED AT CKS AIRPORT TRYING TO SMUGGLE 2.32 KG OF HEROIN

TEXT.P: A woman surnamed Wu was arrested at CKS International Airport for trying to smuggle in 2.32 kilograms of heroin from Thailand.
Aviation police said that X-rays revealed suspicious cans of hair rinse in Wu's check-in luggage.

Wu, a 24-year-old woman working as an escort in a club, said that she was earlier asked by a friend to travel to Thailand for pleasure, and was asked to carry hair rinse upon her return. She claimed that she didn't realize that heroin was in the bottles.
Police turned Wu over to the Taoyuan Prosecutors' Office after being arraigned.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT OVER-RELYING ON NATURAL GAS FOR POWER GENERATION: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The head of the Formosa Plastics Group's call for Taiwan to replace natural gas with coal as a fuel for power plants was dismissed by an official of the Ministry of Economic Affairs Monday.

Formosa Plastics Group Chairman Wang Yung-ching on Sunday said that using natural gas to generate electricity is too expensive and will seriously affect the nation's industrial competitiveness. He suggested that the government scrap natural gas power plants and replace them with ones that use coal.

However, Wang Yun-ming, deputy secretary-general of the economics ministry's Energy Commission said the commission welcomes any suggestions, but noted that current energy policy is based on resolutions reached at a national energy conference in 1998, and that the construction of all power plants has been carried out considering the features of each kind of energy source. The nation's power production does not center on coal or natural gas exclusively, he said.
The 1998 conference decided that natural gas plants would generate between 27 and 29 percent of the nation's total electricity.

Currently, natural gas plants generate only 20 percent of the total, but after a major power plant in Tatan, Taoyuan, is completed, the percentage of natural gas generated electricity will fall within the range agreed upon in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO-METER PYTHON CAPTURED IN TAINAN PARK TRYING TO SWALLOW CAT

TEXT.P: Residents near a Tainan park were awaken in the middle of the night Monday to the loud screams of a cat. When help arrived they discovered the problem: a two-meter python was trying to swallow the cat.

Officials of the Tainan City Fire Fighting Department sent two individuals experienced in capturing snakes to the park, located in front of the Tainan Arts Center. It was the largest snake the pair had ever seen.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS OF ASIAN RURAL MANPOWER ORGANIZATION VISIT KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A group of farmers from the Asian Rural Manpower Development Organization visited the Kaohsiung County Government Monday to see how the government is helping farmers cushion the impact after Taiwan joined the World Trade Organization.

The farmers from Indonesia, the Philippines, Vietnam, South Korea, Thailand, Japan, Nepal and Cambodia were told by Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsin that there are 250,000 farmers in his county, and that the government has taken steps to help farmers grow such high-value fruits as bananas, pineapples, wax apples, longans, mangoes, rice and litchis for export. The government also helps farmers develop their domestic and foreign markets.
Taiwan has been successful in exporting small quantities of fruits to the United States, Canada, Singapore and mainland China. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUNG MOTHER DOZES AFTER DRINKING WINE WHILE INFANT BOY DROWNS

TEXT.P: A woman apparently fell asleep Monday after drinking alcohol-fortified sesame chicken soup while bathing her infant boy. She awoke and found the child drowned.
Police arrested the woman, who was subsequently released on NT$20,000 bond Monday.
The baby was less than one year old.
Alcohol-fortified sesame chicken soup is a traditional food for nursing mothers.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE REFORM ALLIANCE CALLS FOR TWO-VOTE SYSTEM

TEXT.P: A legislative reform action alliance urged the Legislative Yuan Monday to complete revisions to the election and recall law during its next session to pave the way for implementing a two-vote balloting system in future legislative elections.

The alliance, composed of major women's and labor rights groups, also demanded that the deposit each presidential hopeful is required to pay for entering the race be lowered to enable underprivileged aspirants to run for the presidency.

Under the terms of the current election and recall law, each presidential hopeful must pay a deposit of NT$17 million (US$492,753.6) while registering his or her candidacy. The amount will be retained in case the hopeful fails to garner a specified percentage of the vote cast in the election.
The alliance said the high deposit has discouraged competent people with limited financial resources from joining the race.

"This 'wealthy president' provision should be abolished," said Ku Chung-hua, the convener of the action alliance who is also a senior executive of the Taipei Society -- a self-proclaimed watchdog group overseeing government operations.
Ku said at a news conference that the alliance hopes to see a state-funded electoral system be installed as early as possible.
Ku said the amendment of the election and recall law to allow for a two-vote legislative electoral system will only mark the start of the nation's long-delayed legislative reform.

"We need many other reform measures that require amendments to our Constitution, such as halving the number of legislative seats and lowering the minimum suffrage age from the current 20 to 18, " Ku said.

Therefore, he added, the alliance is demanding that the legislature form a special committee during its next legislative session set to open in September to begin preparations for necessary constitutional amendments.

"Even though constitutional amendments require complex and difficult procedures, we should not dodge our duties, " Ku said, adding that the alliance will continually push major domestic political parties to come up with amendment proposals for discussion and comparison.

Speaking on the same occasion, Chien Hsi-chieh, convener of the newly formed Alliance of Fairness and Justice, said Taiwan's current electoral system has not only impinged on underprivileged people's political participation but has also nurtured a money-polluted election culture.

Quoting the results of a survey of candidates in the last legislative session, Chien said many respondents acknowledged that their campaign fees reached NT$100 million and that only a few of them said they spent about NT$20 million on campaign activities. On average, he said, each candidate had to spend at least NT$42 million on campaign bills.

"Against this backdrop, we cannot expect competent and virtuous people to emerge as victors in those hotly contested elections," said Chien, who one served as an at-large legislator representing the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Chien said the legislative reform action alliance will push for elimination of vote-buying and other bad campaign practices, such as offering banquets to woo voters, displaying lots of campaign banners and distributing large numbers of publicity leaflets.

"We'll advocate state-funded elections, with the government integrating print and electronic media resources for campaign forums and policy debates among candidates in all of the nation's political elections," Chien said. (by Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HAS MUCH FAITH IN NEXT YEAR'S PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A high-ranking official of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday that since the government has done well in the fields of diplomacy and economy, the party is confident of winning next year's presidential election.

Lee Ying-yuan, the DPP's deputy secretary-general, made the remarks at a gathering of veteran members of the party, where he hailed the contributions of DPP supporters in helping the democratization of Taiwan and encouraged them to have faith in next year's election.
Lee noted that President Chen Shui-bian's claim that there is one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait has gained the support of many.

Based on this principle, Taiwan has scored well in its diplomacy, Lee said, citing as examples the first lady's visits to the United States and Europe in recent years, Vice President Annette Lu's current visit to Latin America, as well as the upcoming 2003 Democratic Pacific Conference to be held in Taipei in September with the purpose of establishing an alliance to unite Pacific Rim democratic countries.
Regarding economy, Lee said the DPP government has helped several state-run companies that were in the red to begin making a profit -- such as China Shipbuilding Corp. and Tang Eng Iron Works Corp.

Taiwan's economic growth has outperformed that of many countries, the stock and real estate markets are booming, and foreign reserves will reach US$180 billion at the end of this year, an increase of US$70 billion over that of the previous government, Lee noted.
In addition, Lee said, the DPP government will push for the downsizing of the Legislative Yuan.
Lee also stressed that in the past, the topic of referendum was a taboo, while now more than 50 percent of the people support the idea.

The DPP government plans to hold a referendum on several major policies, including the fate of the country's Fourth Nuclear Power Plant, Taiwan's bid to participate in the World Health Organization and the reduction of the number of legislators, before or on the day of next year's presidential election -- March 20, 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIVE LARGE FIRMS IN U.S. AGREE TO INVEST IN TAIWAN: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Five large U.S. companies have agreed to invest in Taiwan as a result of a weeklong promotional mission by Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu to the United States, the ministry reported Monday.

Lin headed a delegation that departed for the United States Aug. 9. During his stay in the United States, he visited Los Angles; San Diego; Chicago; New York and Wilmington, Delaware. He called on 11 companies, including DuPont, General Electric, Corning, Gateway, BD, DeAmertek, Simax, ITW, and Guest Pharmaceutical Services, and secured business worth US$130 million.
He also said that five companies, including Gateway, have confirmed that they intend to invest in Taiwan, although he did not elaborate.

The delegation also sponsored seminars in the Chicago area to introduce Taiwan's overall investment climate to U.S. businesses in the areas of biotechnology, telecommunications, information and digital content.
Lin invited U.S. companies to take part in the 2003 Taiwan Business Alliance Conference Oct. 19-22 in Taipei, with most of the companies agreeing to send officials to the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATIONS TO BE EXPANDED: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The government will expand Double Ten National Day celebrations this year and invite more overseas Chinese to return to Taiwan to mark the occasion, a senior official said Monday.

Wu Hsin-hsing, vice minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs (OCAC), said the Democratic Progressive Party administration will hold the largest-ever scale of Oct. 10 National Day celebrations since its inauguration in May 2000.

More than 5,000 overseas Chinese representatives will be invited back to Taiwan to attend the festivities, Wu said, the OCAC will focus on inviting the second- and third-generations of overseas Chinese to come to Taiwan along with their parents to see for themselves Taiwan's progress and democratization in recent years.
In addition to a traditional gala party on the eve of Double Ten National Day, Wu said, an unprecedented large-scale rock concert will also be held to cater to the taste of young people.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT SLAMS BOEING OVER CANCELLATION OF VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Seattle, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Tsai Su-jung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Vice President Annette Lu lashed out at Boeing Co. in Seattle Sunday for canceling her visit to their company due to pressure from mainland China.

Lu, who wrapped up her two-leg Latin American visit Saturday and is currently on a two-day transit stop in Seattle on her way back to Taipei, was originally scheduled to tour Boeing Co. Sunday. However, Boeing yielded to Beijing's pressure and canceled Lu's visit.

Addressing a dinner banquet hosted by major local Chinese community groups in her honor, Lu said it was shameful for a world-renowned company like Boeing to kowtow to Beijing's unreasonable demand against Taiwan, one of America's best partners.

Lu, the Republic of China's first female vice president, said Boeing's cancellation of her visit was tantamount to snubbing the ROC. "It's an insult to Taiwan. We must defend our national dignity and express our indignation over this snub," she said.

Noting that Boeing won a lucrative aircraft order from Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL) last year, Lu said it was disheartening to see Boeing collaborate with mainland China to bully Taiwan. "Do you think Boeing will announce a decision to give up its contract with CAL? " she asked.
Lu further said Boeing's action has undermined America's image in the world arena. She said she has expressed the ROC's stance on the issue to U.S. authorities.
Barbara Schrage, deputy managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan, which handles U.S.-ROC relations in the absence of diplomatic ties, was present at the dinner party.

Touching on her official visits to Panama and Paraguay, Lu said Taiwan should devote even more efforts to cementing its diplomatic ties with Latin American countries. Fourteen of the ROC's diplomatic allies are located in Central and South America and the Caribbean.

Lu said Taiwan can use its "soft power" of love and technological expertise to forge a democratic Pacific alliance with its Latin American allies. Moreover, Lu said she will encourage Taiwan people to sponsor children from impoverished families in Latin American countries or build homes for them. Taiwan can also invite Latin American troupes to perform on the island to boost cultural exchanges, she added.

Earlier in the day, Lu met with Washington State Lieutenant Governor Brad Owen for wide-ranging talks. Owen said mainland China is not in a position to oppose Taiwan's plan to hold a referendum on some major policy issues because it is an internal issue.

Owen, who concurrently serves as speaker of the Washington State Senate, told Lu that he will head a state congressional delegation to visit Taiwan in September to boost exchanges and cooperation in trade, education and cultural development.

Lu will meet with Seattle Mayor Greg Nickels and several other Washington state officials as well as visit Microsoft Corp. headquarters and the Seattle harbor bureau Monday. She is scheduled to leave for home at midnight.
Lu, heading a 43-member entourage, attended Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte Frutos' inaugural ceremony on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian Friday morning.

Before arriving in Paraguay, Lu made a three-day official visit to Panama where Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso assured Lu that her country will continue maintaining diplomatic relations with the ROC.
On her way to Panama, Lu made transit stops in Hawaii and Los Angeles where she met with many American political figures for wide-ranging talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING PARTY LAWMAKER SPEAKS OUT AGAINST ABSENTEE VOTING

TEXT.P: Allowing citizens of the ROC to vote even if they are not residing where they registered cannot be considered because of constitutional issues, and so the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has ruled out such a move for the time being.

Secretary of the DPP caucus at the Legislative Yuan Chen Chi-mai said Monday he could not agree with a Kuomintang (KMT) proposal to allow absentee balloting - including giving the right to vote to Taiwan citizens living in mainland China and those living overseas with dual passports.
The KMT proposed a day earlier doing away with the requirement that people must vote in the districts or areas where they were originally registered and allowing citizens to mail in ballots.
Chen pointed out that an article in the Additional Articles of the Constitution provides that Republic of China citizens who live overseas "must return to the country" to cast their votes.
Unless this phrase is deleted, Taiwanese businessmen who live in the mainland or overseas Chinese could not be allowed to vote by post.

Furthermore, current law requires that voting be done in secret to ensure that voters act out of their own free will. How this principle would be preserved in absentee voting needs to be carefully considered, Chen said.
The DPP cannot support the KMT's idea of bringing in an absentee ballot system before these questions can be straightened out, Chen added.

Chen dismissed as a whim the KMT's another proposal of using charter planes that would fly nonstop from the mainland to Taiwan to ferry Taiwan businessmen back to vote in the forthcoming presidential election. Chen said the KMT is trying to use the excuse of the presidential election to make direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait a fait accompli, although the legal framework for such links is not yet in place.
The DPP's political ally in the legislature, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), was reserved about the KMT's idea.
TSU lawmaker Chien Lin Hui-chun said her party believes there is no hurry to introduce absentee voting as more careful studies about ways to prevent vote-buying via the mail are needed.

Citizens who are absent from their voting districts are likely to be tempted or threatened to mark their ballots in such a way that does not reflect their true intent, she said, adding that only a well though out bill can prevent these kind of problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG, VLADIVOSTOK PORTS FORGE SISTERHOOD TIES

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau and the Port of Vladivostok signed an agreement on sisterhood ties Monday with both sides agreeing to increase cooperation and exchanges, according to information received by the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau Monday.

Huang Chin-teng, director of the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau, signed the agreement with his counterpart, Mikhail F. Robkanov of Port of Vladivostok. Chen Jung-chieh, the Republic of China's representative to Moscow, and representatives from harbor and shipping industry from both sides also attended the signing ceremony.
Huang said that both harbors will increase cooperation and exchanges in port construction, planning, development, operation management, information and staff to promote the development of both ports.

Huang noted that Vladivostok is Russia's most important commercial harbor in the Far East, while Kaohsiung is the largest commercial port in the Republic of China and a major container harbor of the world.
He expressed the hope that both harbors can promote mutual prosperity through information sharing and professional technical exchanges.
Robkanov noted that Taiwan is one of the largest trading partners in Asia and Pacific area of Russia, and the signing of Monday's sisterhood ties will enable further bilateral relations.
He expressed the hope that more cargo ships will visit each other's harbors and that mutual relations will continue to grow.
Vladivostok became the 14th sister harbor of Kaohsiung and the first sister harbor in the West Pacific.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 50% OF TAIWAN PEOPLE VISIT INTERNET VIA BROAD-BAND CONNECTION

TEXT.P: Nearly half the population of Taiwan uses a broadband connection to surf the Internet, according to a survey released Monday.

The results of the survey conducted by Taiwan Network Information Center in July showed that the number of people who frequented Internet totaled 11.75 million as of July, accounting for 57.23 percent of Taiwan's population.

Of this figure, 9.37 million people had broadband connections, with 30 percent of the households which have not yet been connected to the Internet said they will be hooked up within the next six months.

The survey also showed that 3.51 million households in Taiwan have connected to the Internet, accounting for 54 percent of the total number of families and about 70 percent of them visited the Internet via broadband connections.

Among these families, 64.4 percent of them surfed the Internet via ADSL, followed by those hooked up with cable modem, and community network. A total of 25 percent of the families connected to the Internet still go on-online with dial-up connections.
Speed and price are the main reasons why people chose broadband connections, with 53 percent of users saying that the monthly fee of under NT$750 (US$21) is reasonable.

With ADSL connections, 84 percent of the households opted for Hinet provided by Chungwha Telecom, followed by Seednet at 5.52 percent, while other Internet service providers share the remaining market.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER RETURNS FROM INSPECTION TOUR TO SPRATLY ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien returned to southwestern Taiwan Monday after visiting the Nansha (Spratly) Islands in the South China Sea over the weekend.
Minister Yu, on behalf of Premier Yu Shyi-kun, led government officials to land on Taiping Island, the biggest island of the Nansha group, Saturday.

Yu said that his major purpose in going to Nansha was to reaffirm the nation's sovereignty over the Nansha Islands, cheer up the personnel stationed on the islands, increase the voice of Taiwan in issues related to the South China Sea, and establish a location for global satellite positioning measurements.
Yu stressed that various countries have claimed that they own part or all of the Nansha, and that Nansha is now a potential flashpoint in Asia.

But he added that the government's consistent stance on the conflict in the South China Sea has been to solve conflicts through peaceful consultations and that countries should jointly develop the natural resources in the South China Sea.

Using this principle, Yu said that the work should start with transportation construction, and move toward developing tourism resources to turn Taiping Island and the Tungsha (Pratas) Islands into national marine parks and tourist destinations.
After Taiping Island, Yu traveled to Chungchou Island, which is near a sand bar controlled by Vietnam and a sensitive sea area. Yu planted the national flag of the Republic of China there.

Chungchou is about two nautical miles from Taiping and 4.5 nautical miles from Vietnam's controlled sand bar. Coast Guard officials said that Vietnam had troops stationed on the spit who are ready to shoot anyone that approaches them.

Yu led ranking officials from the Council For Economic Planning and Development, Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, and Coast Guard Administration to board a military vessel from the Tsoying Navy Harbor in southern Taiwan last Thursday. Another ROC Navy vessel and vessels from the Coast Guard Administration escorted them to the Nansha Islands. After 45 hours of journey on sea, Yu and other officials took rubber boats to land on Taiping Island because the wharf is too dilapidated to allow big ships to dock.
The Ministry of National Defense considered the trip a kind of military mission amid the tense situation in the South China Sea, and Yu's trip was conducted throughout in tight security.
Upon their returning to the southwestern part of Taiwan, the ROC Navy also had four navy vessels, including three Lafayette-class ships, conduct anti-submarine exercises Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGES PARTY PUBLIC OFFICIALS TO STAY AWAY FROM DPP CELEBRATION

TEXT.P: Given the competition between different political parties, it is inappropriate for Kuomintang (KMT) public officials to participate in the celebration of the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) founding anniversary, KMT spokesman Tsai Cheng-yuan said Monday.

Asked to comment on Monday's reports that the DPP, which will celebrate its 17th founding anniversary in Taichung City on Sept. 28, is trying to invite KMT Taichung Mayor Jason Hu to attend the political gala as chief of the host city, the spokesman said it would be somewhat inappropriate for a KMT public official to attend a celebration of the KMT's political rivals.
"If invited, KMT officials would be better to turn the offer down," Tsai said.

As to Hu's recent calls on DPP government leaders to appeal for more central government funds for Taichung City, Tsai said this was business rather than politics, and since the KMT is not concerned about it, outsiders should follow suit.

Earlier that day in Taichung City, Hu shrugged off questions about whether he will attend the DPP's anniversary celebration, saying that it would be begging the question to comment since he has not even been invited.
DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan said in Taipei that his party usually invites the administrative chief of the place where the celebration takes place to their annual get-together.

Hu was seen associating closely with DPP leaders recently. He called on President Chen Shui-bian at Chen's office last week to talk about the development of Taichung City, and was present at a dinner given by Chen to a group of journalists in Taichung City when the president stopped there on a trip around the island.

Hu called on Premier Yu Shyi-kun at the premier's office in Taipei earlier in the day and was given a promise from the Executive Yuan that it would share part of the costs of an art gallery in Taichung City.
It raised speculation in political circles that the DPP is trying to win over the KMT mayor's support in the 2004 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO LAUNCH 1-MILLION-SIGNATURE CAMPAIGN TO PUSH FOR REFORMS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will soon start a collect-a-million-signature campaign to promote legislative reforms by cutting one-third of the Legislative Yuan seats, a DPP official said Monday.
Lee Ying-yuan, DPP deputy secretary-general, said that the party will use a series of major events, including the party's anniversary, in September, to launch the campaign.

The DPP is hoping to collect the signatures and easily pass the threshold for proposing to revise the ROC Constitution under a DPP version of the referendum draft bill. About 780,000 signatures would be required to start the procedure, Lee said.

He said that the "call Taiwan, Taiwan" movement will sponsor a big rally in Taipei Sept. 6, the DPP will be celebrating its party anniversary in Taichung Sept. 28, and DPP Legislator Trong Chai is organizing a rally in Kaohsiung Oct. 28 to build up momentum for a referendum in Taiwan. The DPP will collect signatures during all of these occasions, he added.

Lee noted that the DPP reaffirmed in a Central Standing Committee meeting Feb. 25 that the party would push for legislative reform by cutting the seats from the current 225 to 150, and DPP Chairman Chen Shui-bian said at the time that the reform should be a national campaign, and would require support from all quarters and across the political spectrum.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 19, or the 22nd day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1662: Blaise Pascal, the French mathematician, physicist and religious philosopher, dies in Paris at the age of 39.
1871: Orville Wright, the American aviation pioneer, who, with his brother Wilbur, made the first powered and controlled flight, is born.
1878: Manuel Luis Quezon y Molina, first president of the Philippines Commonwealth established under U.S. tutelage in 1935, is born.
1901: Shang Tai, the last monarch of the Ryukyu Kingdom, dies in Tokyo at the age of 58.
1904: Japanese troops launch a disastrous attack on Russian-held Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China during the Russo-Japanese War. Of the 51,000 troops involved, only about 35,000 survived.
1934: Nearly 90 percent of Germans vote to give Adolf Hitler the presidency in addition to his position as chancellor.
1936: Kwangsi rebels in China set up an independent regime in Kweilin.
1936: A total of 16 senior members of the Soviet Communist Party are executed after Josef Stalin orders a purge of the party to get rid of followers of Leon Trotsky, a leader of the Bolshevik Revolution.
1945: Forces led by Ho Chi Minh and the Viet Minh begin the August Revolution against French colonial rule in Vietnam.
1946: Chinese Communist Party leader Mao Tse-tung announces that communist forces will launch a full-scale war against the Chinese government.
1946: Bill Clinton, the 42nd president of the United States, is born. He served as governor of Arkansas from 1978 to 1980 and again from 1982 until he was elected U.S. president in November 1992.
1960: The Soviet Union sentences U-2 spy plane pilot Gary Powers to 10 years in detention.
1966: An earthquake rocks eastern Turkey, killing more than 2,000 people.
1979: Pol Pot, ex-dictator of Cambodia, is sentenced to death in absentia for genocide by the Cambodian government.
1989: Poland becomes the first country in Eastern Europe to end one-party rule, as Solidarity's Tadeuz Mazowiecki takes office as prime minister.
1990: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein offers to release all Western hostages in exchange for a U.S. withdrawal from the Gulf region and an end to the blockade.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader who gave a nervous world two words of hope -- "glasnost" and "perestroika" -- is toppled, just one day short of the scheduled signing of the Union Treaty, a document hated by the hardliners because it signals the beginning of the end of the Soviet empire they know and love.
1995: The Republic of China Foreign Ministry issues a position paper entitled "Why the U.N. Resolution No. 2758 Adopted in 1971 Should be Re-examined Today." The paper stresses that the resolution, which excluded the ROC from the United Nations, is obsolete and unjust.
1996: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan visits the Ukraine.
1996: Niger switches diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
1999: The Taiwan Independence Party nominates its chairman, Cheng Pang-chen, as its candidate for the ROC's next presidential election slated for March 2000.
2000: James Soong, chairman of the People First Party, urges the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to draw inspiration from the development and integration of the 15-member European Union.
2000: An agreement sending International Cooperation and Development volunteers from the ROC to Nicaragua is passed during a regular meeting of the Executive Yuan.
2001: A 36-hour course on conducting election campaigns launched by the newly-established Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), Taiwan's 95th political party, begins at the Grand Hotel Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to figure out, but once you try to figure out a thing, you must never give it up until you have got what you want."

DOC.HEADLINE: 23 FEMALE MAINLANDERS NABBED OFF KEELUNG

TEXT.P: Twenty-three mainland Chinese citizens suspected of attempting to illegally enter Taiwan were discovered hiding onboard a Taiwan fishing vessel and arrested off Keelung by Taiwan coast guard forces early Tuesday morning.

The coast guard reported that they had been tipped off that a smuggling ring was trying to use Taiwan fishing vessels to transport mainland Chinese citizens to Taiwan illegally. The coast guard then sent three cutters to patrol the northern sea area.

The coast guard officers spotted the suspicious fishing vessel, the Taipei County-registered "Tayi No. 168, " off Pitou, Keelung, and then boarded it at 2 a.m. to conduct a thorough search. They discovered the mainlanders, all of them women, hiding in a secret compartment of the vessel.
They then escorted the vessel back to Shenao Harbor, Keelung, and questioned Han Chung-hua, captain of the vessel, as well as a Vietnamese fisherman and the 23 mainlanders.

In the questioning, the coast guard forces discovered that the mainland women had boarded a mainland fishing vessel Sunday night and then later transferred to the Taiwan vessel. The women, most of them minors, with the youngest being 15 years old, were chic in appearance.

Most of them came from Pingtan, Fujian Province, but some came from as far away as Harbin city in northeast mainland China. They said they had been introduced by mainland Chinese men to "work" in Taiwan, paying fees ranging from 20,000 renminbi to 75,000 renminbi (US$2,416-US$9,060) that they were expected to repay after landing on Taiwan and engaging in prostitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T DENIES LU PROMISED TO DELAY PARAGUAY'S LOAN REPAYMENT SCHEDULE

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office issued a press release Tuesday denying that Vice President Annette Lu has ever promised to consider delaying the loan repayment schedule for Paraguay.
The Presidential Office issued the press statement at the request of Lu who is now on a transit stop in Seattle after a two-leg Latin American tour to Panama and Paraguay.

Some local media claimed Monday that Lu said during an international news conference held in the Paraguayan capital of Asuncion last Saturday that Taiwan would consider extending the interest-free period for loans to Paraguay and delaying its loan repayments schedule.
The media report was not true, the press statement said, adding that Lu regrets that such an irresponsible, misleading report was made.

During the Asuncion press conference, the statement said, some Paraguayan journalists asked Lu whether the Republic of China government is likely to extend a helping hand as the new Paraguayan government is unable to repay its debts to the ROC.

In response, the statement said, Lu clearly stated that the loans in question were purely commercial deals between the Paraguayan government and two private Taiwan banks -- the International Commercial Bank of China and Chinatrust Commercial Bank. "I'm convinced that the two Taiwan banks will handle the repayment issue properly," Lu was quoted as having said at the news conference.
The statement stressed that Lu did not make any comment regarding the ROC government's possible response to the loan issue, as some local media had reported,
Lu attended the inauguration of new Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte last Friday on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian. She is scheduled to return to Taipei early Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: EMPLOYERS, BROKERS URGED NOT TO HIRE RUNAWAY FOREIGN LABORERS
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Aug. 19 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taichung County government on Tuesday asked that employers and brokers in the county not hire runaway foreign laborers, or else face steep fines.

Taichung County Government officials issued the warning after the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) , out of concerns that runaway foreign laborers may pose a threat to social order, notified local city and county governments to conduct a three-month campaign against runaway foreign laborers starting Sept. 1. The aim of the campaign is to locate and repatriate runaway foreign laborers.
To encourage the reporting of runaway foreign laborers, CLA officials also said that they will award informers NT$3,000 (US$87) for each case reported.
Taichung County labor officials noted that the number of foreign laborers in the county amounts to nearly 25,000, with caregivers accounting for more than one-third of that total.
According to Taichung County police statistics, 488 foreign laborers ran away in the county between January 1 and Aug. 16 of this year.

Labor officials urged employers not to hire run-away foreign laborers, or else be subject to fines of between NT$150,000 and NT$750,000. Foreign laborer brokers should also not introduce run-away foreign laborers to potential employers, or else they will face fines of between NT$300,000 and NT$1.5 million, the officials added.

They said that foreign laborers on the run have a hard life and that they mostly just want to return home to their own countries, but they continue hiding in Taiwan because they are not familiar with the channels of assistance open to them or because they are afraid of possible trouble.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR CALLS ON CANADIAN HEALTH OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, currently visiting Toronto, Canada, called on a health official Monday and visited a community hospital where a SARS cluster transmission was reported earlier this year, Taipei City Government's Information Department said Tuesday.

Ma met with Phil Hassen, Ontario's deputy minister of health and long-term care, and other health officials over breakfast, and exchanged views on the battle against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).

Ma broached the idea of Toronto and Taipei, both hit hard by SARS between March and June of this year, joining hands to inform each other on the latest SARS information. His proposal was positively received by the Canadian health officials.

Ma said while discussing the SARS issue with the health officials that the important things to think about are how to respond quickly if the disease resurfaces, whether to handle the disease in a different way than the first time it appeared, whether it is necessary to impose large-scale quarantine measures, and whether communications between the various levels of governments can be improved.
Ma later on Monday visited Scarborough Grace Hospital, which was the first hospital to report a SARS cluster transmission, in early March.
Mayor Ma departed Taipei Sunday for a 11-day visit to six major cities in Canada and the United States.

After his stay in Toronto, Ma will visit Boston, Washington, Atlanta, Phoenix and San Francisco. While in these cities, he will visit hospitals and disease control institutions to study their SARS containment measures. He will also meet with business leaders in these cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEATHER BUREAU ISSUES LAND AND SEA WARNINGS FOR TROPICAL STORM VAMCO

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a sea and land warnings at noon Tuesday for tropical storm Vamco, the eleventh in the Pacific this year.

Tropical storm Vamco was located some 360 kilometers southeast of Hualien, moving northwest toward Taiwan at a speed of 26 kilometers per hour as of 3: 30 p.m. Tuesday, a CWB meteorologist said, adding that the radius of Vamco's storm-force winds had reached 100 km, with maximum wind speeds of 65 kph.

The CWB issued a land warning for the areas of Ilan, Hualien, Keelung, Taipei, Taoyuan and Hsinchu at 12:30 p.m., and at the same time issued a sea warning for Taiwan's northeastern, southeastern and northern coasts, as well as the Bashi Strait, Matsu, and the northern part of the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, Taipei City Government officials urged the public to remain on alert and make preparations against the typhoon, adding that they will form a natural disaster emergency task force later in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUGGENHEIM PROJECT RECEIVES WARM RESPONSE FROM TAICHUNG CITIZENS

TEXT.P: The plan to build a Guggenheim museum in the central Taiwan city of Taichung has received warm response from local citizens, a spokesman for a project promotional alliance said Tuesday.
The Guggenheim Museum Promotion Alliance, composed of major Taichung-based cultural organizations, launched a signature campaign in support of the ambitious plan in late July which ended Monday.
Over the past three weeks, the spokesman said, more than 16,900 Taichung citizens have thrown their support behind the project.

"We'll send the signatures, news clippings featuring the promotional campaign and recommendations for the project to the city government and council and the Guggenheim Foundation to express our support for the new museum project," the spokesman said.
The project to build a Guggenheim museum in Taichung will call for an outlay of about NT$6.4 billion and the central government has promised to foot half of the bill.
The New York-based Guggenheim Museum, a prestigious museum known for its modern and contemporary art collections, also operates affiliated museums in Las Vegas and Berlin. (by Nocturne Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 4.64 points to close at 5,512.16.
The bourse opened at 5,586.43 and then fluctuated between 5,594.93 and 5,498.38 during the trading session.

A total of 5.18 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$119.34 billion (US$3.47 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 4.68 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$101.58 billion (US$2.96 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.0 percent, followed by electrical stocks at 0.3 percent.

The other six major stock categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 3.0 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 1.6 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.5 percent, financial stocks and textile shares, both at 0.7 percent, and cement stocks at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 403 to 262, with 114 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA EXPRESSES REGRET OVER BOEING'S CANCELLATION OF LU'S VISIT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed its regret Tuesday over Boeing Co.'s abrupt cancellation of ROC Vice President Annette Lu's visit to its Seattle office under pressure from Beijing.
MOFA spokesman Richard Shih said a visit to Boeing Co., one of Taiwan's longtime trade partners, was included in Lu's itinerary before she left Taipei Aug. 7 for her current overseas tour.

Unexpectedly, Shih said, Boeing Co. informed the MOFA Aug. 11 that the itinerary of Lu's visit had to be changed. After difficult negotiations, Shih said, Boeing still would not maintain the original plan, resulting in the cancellation of Lu's visit to the giant aircraft company.

According to Shih, Lu was originally scheduled to visit Boeing's factory, with its vice president to brief Lu on the details of the company's operations. However, the company backed out of its original promise and asked Lu to visit its downtown office instead. The company also canceled its promise to have its vice president receive Lu personally.
Shih said it is regrettable that Boeing has failed to honor its promise.

Apart from the "Boeing incident, " Shih said, the ROC government is grateful for the Bush administration's handling of Lu's transit stops in Hawaii, Los Angeles and Seattle on her way to and from Latin America based on the principles of "safety, comfort, convenience and dignity."

As to whether the MOFA will force China Airlines (CAL) to cancel its aircraft purchase contract with Boeing Co., Shih said the government will respect CAL's decision based on commercial requirements and professional assessments. Boeing won a big contract with CAL last year.
Asked whether President Chen Shui-bian's overseas travel plan later this year will be affected by the "Boeing incident, " Shih said the president's travel plan has yet to be fleshed out.
Lu arrived in Seattle Sunday for a two-day transit stop on her way back to Taipei after a two-leg Latin American tour to Panama and Paraguay. She is scheduled to return to Taipei early Wednesday.
Addressing a dinner banquest hosted by major Chinese community groups in Seattle Sunday, Lu upbraided Boeing for its crude manner in snubbing her request to visit a company office.
"Shame on Boeing! Rejecting me is rejecting the ROC and Taiwan. We need to guard our dignity and express our anger and give Boeing a warning," Lu said.

Lu went on to say that during her transit stops in the United States, there are at least 100 corporations that have welcome her as the representative of the ROC. "But Boeing bowed to pressure from Beijing and bullied Taiwan, a close a U.S. ally," she regretted.
Lu, heading a 43-member entourage, attended Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte Frutos' inaugural ceremony on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian Aug. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for August moved up 16 points to close at 5,555, with 17,262 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September gained 20 points to finish at 5,559, with 21,856 contract transactions, while December futures rose 43 points to close at 5,565, with six contracts traded.
Next March futures gained 30 points to finish at 5,521, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,539 for August, 5,539 for September, 5,522 for December, 5,491 for next March, and 5,543 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
August TE futures gained 1.65 points to close at 247.65, with 2,490 contract transactions, while September TE rose 1.5 points to finish at 247, with 2,805 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
August TF futures moved down 4.0 points to close at 719.4, with 1,941 contract transactions, while September TF futures fell 2.8 points to finish at 718, with 3,363 contracts changing hands.
December TF futures gained 8.2 points to finish at 723.6, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DIVERSITY VISA PROGRAM REGISTRATION TURNS ELECTRONIC

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said Tuesday that starting this year, all persons registering for an opportunity to apply for a U.S. immigrant visa under the diversity lottery will have to do so electronically through a designated Internet website.
The AIT said the U.S. State Department is implementing the new electronic system in order to improve efficiency in the diversity visa petition process and make the process less prone to fraud.

Applicants from eligible countries petition the Department of State for the opportunity to apply for one of 55, 000 immigrant visa made available annually. Only those selected at random and notified by the Department of State will then be eligible to apply for an immigrant visa. Previously, all registrations were submitted by mail. Starting this year, only electronic submissions will be accepted.

Persons submitting a request for entry in the diversity visa lottery will use a specially designated website which will have a standard petition form that will be filled out and sent electronically. They will also be required to include digital photographs, the AIT said. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE COUNCILOR DECORATED FOR PROMOTING TIES WITH ROC

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian decorated Motoo Shiina, a member of the Japanese House of Councilors, Tuesday with the Order of Brilliant Star with Violet Grand Cordon in recognition of his efforts to promote Taiwan-Japan ties over the past decades.

Chen said he took great pleasure in decorating Shiina on behalf of the Republic of China government and people as the Japanese Diet member has contributed much to the crafting of a framework to maintain peace and stability in Asia and to the promotion of substantive Taipei-Tokyo relations.

With far-sightedness and a strong conviction, Chen said, Shiina overcame many difficulties in the 1980s in pushing for consolidation of a U.S.-Japanese defense alliance to help lay a solid foundation for peace and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region over the past two decades.

More admiringly, Chen said, Shiina has spared no efforts to help pave the way for Taiwan to take part in the U.S.-Japanese defense cooperative mechanism, which has in turn helped safeguard peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

Praising Shiina as a generous and modest man, Chen said, Shiina had declined to receive any decoration during former President Lee Teng-hui's administration. Over the years, Chen said Shiina has made remarkable contributions to cross-strait peace and regional security and prosperity through his quiet, selfless efforts.

For his part, Shiina said it's a great honor for him to receive an ROC government decoration. Despite the absence of official diplomatic ties, he said, substantive Taiwan-Japanese relations have continued to grow through concerted efforts of the quasi-official Japanese Interchange Association (JIA) and Taiwan's Association of East Asian Relations.

While U.S.-Japan defense cooperation is growing steadily, Shiina said he is hopeful that Taiwan can expand its participation within this mechanism and that triangular Taipei-Tokyo-Washington relations will be further upgraded on the current basis.

Former President Lee and his wife attended the decoration ceremony. It was the first time since he finished his presidency in May 2000 that Lee has made a visit to the Presidential Office. Also present at the occasion was Katsuhisa Uchida, director of the JIA Taipei Office, which represents Japanese interests in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG YUNG-CHING ADVOCATES USING COAL AS FUEL IN POWER GENERATION

TEXT.P: Wang Yung-ching, chairman of the Formosa Plastics Group, said Tuesday that he will soon urge the government to use coal instead of natural gas as fuel in power generation.

He said it is not sustainable for Taiwan to use natural gas as fuel in power generation because natural gas is very expensive and is limited in supply. Natural gas is good for household use, not for use in power plants.
Wang said coal-fired power generators may release large quantities of carbon dioxide to pollute the air, but this negative effect on the environment may be neutralized by forestation.

He said that Kuan Tang, a coastal town in the northern Taiwan county of Taoyuan, can be developed into an international harbor, and that a four million kilowatt coal-fired power plant can be built at low cost in the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: H.K. LEGISLATORS' REMARKS IN TAIWAN NOT A CRIME: H.K. SECURITY CHIEF

TEXT.P: Hong Kong's security chief, Ambrose Lee, said Tuesday that Hong Kong people enjoy freedom of expression and that the comments made by Hong Kong Legislative Council members Amily Lau and James To Saturday in Taipei do not constitute a crime.

The two legislators said Saturday in an international seminar on "Hong Kong under One Country, Two Systems" in Taipei that the proposed enactment of Hong Kong's state security law, also known as Article 23 of the Basic Law, will have an impact on the human rights and freedom of the press and effectively gag the news media in Hong Kong.

Lee made the remarks after the English-language China Daily carried a signed article Monday accusing the two legislators of publicly advocating Taiwan independence in their capacity as members of the Legislative Council.

The article said Amily Lau may even go so far as to advocate a referendum on Hong Kong's independence from mainland China. If so, she may commit the crime of separating the country, the article said. For this reason, the article called for the early enactment of Article 23 to nip the crime in the bud. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LU HAS A BUSY DAY IN SEATTLE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu had a busy day in Seattle Monday, visiting American leaders and companies and meeting with overseas Chinese leaders in the area.

Lu is in Washington on her way home after visiting Panama and Paraguay last week. While in Asuncion, she attended the inauguration ceremony of President Nicanor Duarte Fruto on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.

In Seattle Sunday, Lu met with Seattle Mayor Greg Nickels and Washington Attorney General Christine Gregoire. She also visited Microsoft Corp. and the Seattle Harbor Bureau, and met with American business leaders from the Seattle area.

She was unhappy with Boeing Co. after the American aircraft giant canceled her scheduled visit to the company Sunday, allegedly due to opposition by Beijing. Lu spoke highly of Microsoft's achievement in developing high technologies and its courage in resisting Beijing's pressure to cancel her visit.
In her conversation with the American leaders, she also emphasized her idea to establish a "Democratic Pacific Alliance" and a "Democratic Pacific University."
Lu and her entourage are scheduled to return to Taipei Wednesday morning. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE MEXICANS ARRESTED ON CHARGES OF THEFT

TEXT.P: Three Mexican citizens, including two men and one woman, were arrested in Taipei Tuesday on charges of theft, police said.

The suspects were nabbed after they stole a brand-name leather handbag in a fashion boutique on Taipei's Linshen N. Road. The shop's owner first detected their action. Two police officers happened to be patrolling the region and managed to arrest the three.
Initial investigations showed that the trio arrived in Taipei Aug. 13 from the Malaysian capital of Kuala Lumpur on tourist visas. They had rented a car.

The case has been transferred to the prosector's office for further investigation, police said, adding that they have asked the immigration office to put them on a list of foreigners subject to special entry control.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN SOONG LEAVES FOR THREE-NATION EUROPEAN TOUR

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong left Taipei Tuesday for a three-leg European tour that will take him to Holland, Belgium and Luxembourg.
Soong said prior to his departure that a Dutch culture and education foundation organized his European visit, which will last for eight or nine days.

Asked about his views on Boeing Co.'s cancellation of Vice President Annette Lu's visit to its office in Seattle under Beijing's pressure, Soong said the government should be more pragmatic in handling international relations and development in exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
Soong, a former Taiwan governor, will serve as Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's running mate to challenge President Chen Shui-bian's re-election bid next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 68 PERCENT OF NEW GRADUATES HAVE YET TO FIND WORK: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The job market remains tight, with 68 percent of newly graduated university and college students this summer having yet to find work, according to the results of an Internet survey released Tuesday.
The Internet opinion poll, conducted by www.9999.com.tw -- a local online job bank -- Aug. 3-14, received 19,378 valid responses mainly from university and college students who graduated this summer.
The survey found that 58.2 percent thought that it was extremely difficult to find a job this year, while only 2.56 percent said they could easily find work.
Just over 44 percent said they are not working because they have not found a job they like; the same percentage thought they were not qualified for available work.
Among those who have never had a job, 54.86 percent live with money from their parents, 3.31 percent depend on their savings, while 9.8 percent live off borrowed money.
For those who have found work, 62.72 percent said they were not satisfied with their job, while only 37.28 said they were.
A total of 23.82 percent said they will change jobs immediately after they find a new one, while 5.32 percent said they will change jobs in three months.
An official of the job bank admitted that the job prospects are bleak this year due to more graduates and fewer jobs.

In addition, the executive added, potential employers are more conservative in their talent recruitment, with many companies perfering those who are skilled and experienced than inexperienced newly graduates to reduce costs in training them.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar declined against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, giving up NT$0.005 to close at NT$34.353.
A total of US$446 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$34.311 and was traded between 34.306 and NT$34.365.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI AUTHORITIES TO RESPOND TO AIRPORT ASSESSMENT

TEXT.P: The Taipei municipal authorities will publish an overall assessment next week of the impact on the city of the central government's option to use an airport to serve as the direct air link across the Taiwan Strait, Information Department Director Wu Yu-sheng said Tuesday.

Wu said Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou has instructed the Bureau of Transportation and the Bureau of Commerce and Economy to study the impact on the city's economy, trade, investment and tourism of the central government's choice of Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan County to conduct cross-strait air travel should Taiwan and mainland China agree on opening direct transport links.

Ma claimed last week after learning of the development that he will continue to ask the central government to include Taipei Sungshan Airport in the initial stage of direct cross-strait air travel to help sharpen the city's international competitiveness.

Ma is currently on a tour of the United States and Canada to seek inter-city cooperation on the prevention of a reoccurrence of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in the coming autumn or winter.

A public opinion survey made by the Bureau of Transportation in January on cross-strait charter service showed that 51.53 percent of the respondents thought CKS International Airport to be the most suitable airport to ply direct cross-strait flights, while 47.85 percent preferred Sungshan airport to open the service.

However, the public's choice is closely linked to their residence locations, as the poll indicated that 63 percent of the respondents living in Taipei City and Taipei County were in favor of Sungshan Airport, while as many as 89 percent of the citizens living in the rest areas of Taiwan backed the CKS airport.

The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) made public Aug. 15 an assessment report on Taiwan's establishment of direct transport links with mainland China, in which it designed CKS airport as Taiwan's top choice to conduct direct air links with the mainland.
The MAC report came after President Chen Shui-bian unveiled his blueprint early this month that direct cross-strait transport links will be forged in three stages by the end of 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PROCUREMENT PLAN NOT FINALIZED YET: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) is still working on its arms procurement package and therefore has yet to come up with any relevant budget plan, a Cabinet spokeswoman said Tuesday.

Cabinet Secretary-General Liu Shih-fang was responding to opposition lawmakers' claim that the MND will propose a NT$520 billion special budget plan for pruchasing conventional submarines, early warning radar systems and Patriot missile defense systems from the United States.

Opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang said earlier in the day that the MND's special budget plan violates major arms procurement procedures and the prices offered by the United States are unreasonably high.
In response, Liu said Lin's comments are sheer speculation. At the moment, she said, the MND is still carefully evaluating the nation's defense needs in terms of mainland China's military threats.

"The MND has yet to finalize a comprehensive procurement package, not to mention a budget plan to finance the procurement," Liu said, adding that the MND has on many occasions declared that it will work out a phased arms procurement project based on defense demands and the nation's financial situation.
At present, Liu said, the Cabinet has no plan to present a special arms procurement budget proposal to the Legislative Yuan for scrrening in its next legislative session set to open in September.

Nevertheless, Liu said, she would not rule out the possibility of presenting such a budget plan in the future. "Anyway, we must follow legal procedures. When the MND finalizes the procurement plan, we'll seek the legislature's approval of relevant budget proposals," she explained.
Liu further said since the Democratic Progressive Party adminsitration was inaugurated more than three years ago, it has spared no efforts to enahnce transparancy in weaponry procurement.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER URGES CAL TO REQUEST EXPLANATION FROM BOEING

TEXT.P: It would be in the national interest for China Airlines (CAL) to put aside business considerations and lodge a strong protest to the Boeing Company for its eleventh-hour cancellation of a planned visit by Vice President Annette Lu to the company's Seattle, Washington plant, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said Tuesday.
Boeing's breach of promise to receive Lu was a snub, said Lin. As the nation's flag carrier, CAL should defend the country's dignity.

Lin, who doubles as chairman of a government fundation which is the largest stockholder in CAL, stopped short of saying that CAL should protest against Boeing's flip-flop on Lu's visit to its Seattle plant by cancelling a 2002 contract to buy 10 jet planes from Boeing. He said instead that Boeing at least owes Taiwan an explanation.

Lu was in the United States on her way back to Taiwan from a trip to Paraguay and was scheduled to visit Boeing in Seattle Sunday. However, Boeing refused to let her into the facility without giving a reason.
Angered at being turned away, Lu said that Boeing should be ashamed of itself, and dared the aircraft builder to abandon CAL's order for 10 airplanes.
The incident caused political shock waves in Taipei Tuesday, with lawmakers across the political spectrum criticizing Boeing.
Legislator Chen Chih-mai of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged CAL to divert its order from Boeing to another aircraft builder.
He also blamed Beijing for twisting Boeing's arm behind the scene.

The DPP's political ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), had similar sentiments. TSU Secretary-General Lin Chih-chia said the incident should drive home to the people in Taiwan that Beijing will stop at nothing to isolated the country.
Beijing blocks Taiwan's engagement with not only foreign governments but also foreign private companies, Lin said.

Opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang said either Boeing should be blamed for backpedaling on its promise to receive Lu, or the Ministry of the Foreign Affairs should be blamed for believing by mistake that Boeing agreed to receive the vice president.
Lin said the DPP administration should learn a lesson from this incident -- money cannot buy friendship, and don't curry favor with U.S. private companies at the cost of the country.

The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) was conspicuously low key Tuesday. An AIT spokeswoman in Taipei said that Lu's activities in the United States were private and unofficial in nature. Her dealing should be disclosed by Taiwan authorities or Boeing and not by AIT.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER URGES GOVERNMENT TO SCREEN ITS FOREIGN AID

TEXT.P: A lawmaker from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party urged the government Tuesday to strictly screen its aid to allies to avoid being used as a pawn by other countries in a game of money.

Parris Chang made the remarks following reports that Panama's second vice president, Arturo Vallarino, will visit mainland China by the end of August while President Mireya Moscoso is coming to Taipei to attend a summit meeting among heads of state of the Republic of China and its Central American allies and sign a free trade agreement with President Chen Shui-bian.

In a news release, Chang, a member of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Relations Committee, said he appreciates Moscoso's efforts in strengthening ROC-Panama ties during the last four years, but at the same time he is unsure what the point is in Vallarino's expected visit to Beijing. It is unclear, he said, whether Panama is actually sitting on the cross-strait fence.

Chang stressed that Taiwan has been offering considerable economic aid to Panama for years; however, by sending its vice president to mainland China, the Central American ally is sending a message to Taiwan that it appears to be playing both sides against the middle.
He called on the government to be completely aware of how it deals with countries that have diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN PUBLIC MANDATE TO MAKE BEIJING MORE FLEXIBLE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new public mandate following next year's presidential election will steer Beijing into being more flexible and pragmatic in its dealings with Taiwan, creating a mutually beneficial "win-win" situation for both sides of the Taiwan Strait, President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday.

Chen made the remarks in a weekly policy-making meeting of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) after Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen gave a keynote speech regarding an MAC assessment of direct cross-strait transport links and its impact on Taiwan.

Noting that cross-strait ties have long been a grave concern for the international community and a vital relationship for Taiwan's 23 million people, Chen said the administration has been working on arrangements and preparations, including revising the law, enhancing national security and law and order mechanisms, and improving quarantine control since he took power May 20, 2000.

The DPP-led administration has also made many adjustments and revisions on the financial and economic fronts in respect to mainland China in the hope of achieving the ultimate goal of sharpening Taiwan's competitiveness, Chen said, adding that the direct cross-strait transport links he proposed early this month are aimed at building a favorable climate for the two sides.
"The DPP now has a greater confidence and a soldier foundation to handle the many cross-strait issues, including direct links, " he said.

Stressing that the government has remained firm on its pragmatic and progressive basic stance toward mainland China over the past more than three years, Chen said Taiwan's security, dignity and interests are the most important guidelines for the government in its handling of the direct links issue.

The president said he strongly believes that only the DPP will make Beijing fully realize that the Taiwan people will never accept its "one China" principle and that the two sides will be able to reach a mutually beneficial agreement on the direct links only when Beijing is willing to forswear its dogma.

Commenting on next year's presidential race, a confident Chen said that the new public mandate in Taiwan will undoubtedly force Beijing to make better and prospective adjustments in its dealings with Taiwan due to fresh political situations in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOEING RENEGED ON LU'S VISIT BECAUSE OF BEIJING'S PRESSURE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Boeing had in fact agreed to host Vice President Annette Lu on a visit to its plant but reneged on its promise because of political pressure from Beijing, an official at the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Tuesday.

The anonymous official who was in charge of arranging Lu's trip said the ministry's Seattle office approached Boeing July 18 over Lu's possible visit to the company and was told on July 21 that Boeing would welcome Lu's visit and that one of its vice presidents would greet Lu when she arrived.

However, the Boeing plant was to be closed for the Aug. 16-17 weekend, the two dates first proposed by Lu's staff. The visit was rescheduled for Aug. 18, between 3 p.m. and 5 p.m., according to the official.

The ministry's representative in Seattle, Chiang Kuo-chian, reconfirmed the details of the visit with two Boeing executives by phone on Aug. 7 and agreed to call up the two on Aug. 11 to see in person the receiving line they were arranging for the vice president.

However, one of Chiang's Boeing contacts called him on Aug. 11 asking to change Lu's visit because the vice president who was to greet Lu was going to be preoccupied with other business on Aug. 18 and the plant would be busy working on a batch of 747 airplanes. The contact offered, on the following day, a substitute plan for Lu to visit the company's headquarters in downtown Seattle.

Stunned by the sudden change, Chiang called Boeing on Aug. 12. His contact apologized for the unexpected change, but shrugged off Chiang's question of whether the cancellation was because of Beijing's interference, saying only, "You know better than I."

Since Lu's planned visit to Boeing had the blessing of the State Department, Chiang asked his contact if the State Department ever urged the company not to cancel Lu's trip. The answer was yes, but "The decision had been made, " according to the official at the foreign ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE LEADERS OF CENTRAL AMERICAN STATES ARRIVES FOR SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Three leaders of Central American states arrived in Taipei Tuesday night for a summit between leaders of Republic of China and its allies in Central America on Thursday.
The three leaders are Costa Rica President Abel Pacheco and his wife, Nicaragua President Enrique Bolanos and his wife, and Honduras Vice President Alberto Diaz and his wife.
They were greeted at the airport by Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien.
Prime Minister Said Musa of Belize and his wife arrived earlier in the day for the summit.

The summit will also bring together El Salvador President Francisco Flores, Guatemala President Alfonso Portillo, Panama President Mireya Moscoso and Secretary-General to the President of the Dominican Republic, Sergio Grullo.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 20, or the 23rd day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1741: Danish explorer Vitus Bering discovers Alaska on a mission sponsored by Russia.
1833: Benjamin Harrison, the 23rd president of the United States, is born. The first Pan-American Conference took place (1889) during his administration, which passed the Sherman Anti-Trust Act in 1890.
1860: Raymond Poincare, French statesman and president from 1913 to 1920, is born.
1905: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who had been exiled for his involvement in the anti-Ching movement, organizes the Revolution Alliance in Tokyo. The organization, headed by Dr. Sun, sponsored an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1912: William Booth, British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army in 1878, dies at the age of 83.
1925: Liao Chung-kai, one of a 16-member steering committee that established a national government in July 1925, is assassinated in Canton, five months after the demise of Dr. Sun Yat-sen in Peking. Liao was 47.
1928: Both the Wen River and the Mi River in the province of Shantung overflow their banks, drowning 18,000 people and leaving some 30,000 others homeless.
1940: A total of 153 Japanese military aircraft carry out a heavy bombing raid on Chungking, the war-time capital of the Republic of China.
1940: Radar is used for the first time, with the British employing it during World War II.
1940: Leon Trotsky, one of the leaders of the Russian Revolution, is stabbed to death by a Spanish communist with an alpine ax in his home in Coyoacan, near Mexico City. He was 61.
1944: Representatives of China, the United States, the United Kingdom and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics meet in Washington, D.C., to discuss the establishment of a world organization after World War II.
1944: Rajiv Gandhi, former Indian prime minister, is born. The son of Indira Gandhi was assassinated on May 21, 1991.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek sends a second invitation to Mao Tse-tung after inviting him to come to Chungking for a conference on Aug. 14, 1945.
1955: Gen. Sun Li-jen, chief military aide to the president, submits a request for disciplinary action against himself as a gesture of self-reproach in regard to a communist espionage case involving Kuo Ting-liang.
1967: A total of 247 people, including Taipei City Councilor Lin Shui-chuan, are arrested for attempting to stage an armed rebellion for Taiwan independence.
1968: Soviet and Warsaw Pact troops begin the invasion of Czechoslovakia in an attempt to crush the "Prague Spring" reforms.
1972: The Republic of China Mei Ho baseball team defeats a U.S. team from California 9-0 to win the Senior League world title.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Lugar, chairman of the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Lugar says that the U.S. government has not changed its basic support of the Republic of China and that he hopes the ROC will open its markets to reduce the ROC-US trade deficit.
1988: A U.N.-mediated cease-fire between Iran and Iraq takes effect, ending nearly eight years of war.
1995: An express train collides with another train in northern India, killing nearly 300 passengers and injuring more than 200 others.
1999: The Central Bank of China announces that Taiwan's second-quarter balance of international payments surplus amounted to US$5.47 billion, the highest single-quarter total in 12 years.
2000: Chinese Taipei captures the Pony League World Series title by defeating a team from West Covina, California 8-3, giving Chinese Taipei its fourth championship in seven years.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his delegation arrive in Gambia at the start of his one-week, three-nation African tour which will also take him to Burkina Faso and Chad.
2001: Taiwan's Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation makes its 300th bone marrow donation, with the recipient a college student in Hangzhou City, in mainland China's Zhejiang Province.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to sift out, but when you once try to sift out a thing, you must never give it up until you have sifted it out clearly and distinctly."

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT WRAPS UP HIGH-PROFILE LATIN AMERICAN TOUR

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu returned to Taipei early Wednesday after a high-profile two-leg Latin American visit to Panama and Paraguay.
Lu, heading a 43-member entourage, attended the inauguration of new Paraguay President Nicanor Duarte in Asuncion Aug. 15 on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.
During her visit to Panama Aug. 11-13, Lu met with Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso who assured Lu that Panama will adopt measures to further boost exchanges and cooperation with Taiwan.

On her way to and back from Latin America, Lu made transit stops in Hawaii, Los Angeles and Seattle where she met with many American political figures for wide-ranging talks, including ways to promote bilateral cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: LU URGES TAIWAN PEOPLE TO PAY ATTENTION TO BEIJING'S OBSTRUCTION
DOC.DATELINE: Chiang Kai-shek airport, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged the Taiwan people Wednesday to pay attention to Beijing's obstruction that she said led to Boeing Co.'s recent refusal of her visit, pointing out that this is an alarm signal to Taiwan's diplomacy.

The vice president made the remarks after returning to Taipei early Wednesday after a two-leg Latin American visit to Panama and Paraguay, during which she made transit stops in Hawaii, Los Angeles and Seattle.
Lu, at the head of a 43-member delegation, attended the inauguration of new Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte in Asuncion Aug. 15 on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.

She said while receiving greetings from people of Taoyuan County at CKS International Airport upon her return to Taiwan that her mission to represent President Chen in attending the new Paraguayan president's inauguration was accomplished and that she was well received during her transit stops in the United States.

Noting that she had met with officials and council members of the local governments during her short stays in the U.S. cities, the vice president said that she also met with overseas Chinese and representatives from leading U.S. enterprises.
Talking about Boeing's refusal of her visit, Lu said that it was only a small episode and did not affect her overall journey which she said was well arranged.
Nevertheless, Lu warned that the Taiwan people should pay attention to what she said was Boeing's giving in to pressure from Beijing.

Pointing out that the target of Beijing's attempts to isolate Taiwan internationally seems to have spread beyond governments to private companies, Lu said Boeing's refusal should be seen as a warning signal to Taiwan's diplomacy. She cautioned that if the Taiwan people don't pay heed and take preventative measures, it will result in an endless flow of disasters for Taiwan.
She also stressed that the aircraft manufacturer's refusal of her visit was also an insult to the 23 million people of Taiwan.
