DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES UP BY 31.45 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Wednesday, with the weighted index moving up 31.45 points to close at 5,543.61.
Market turnover amounted to NT$86.23 billion (US$2.51 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and then fluctuated on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 31.45 points to close at 5,543.61.
The bourse opened at 5,548.84 and fluctuated between 5,562.95 and 5,525.45 during trading.
A total of 3.59 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$86.23 billion (US$2.51 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with construction stocks moving up the most at 2.7 percent, followed by electrical shares at 0.9 percent, and bank and insurance stocks at 0.7 percent.

The other major stock categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues, foodstuff shares, and textile issues moving down the most, all at 0.4 percent, followed by cement stocks stocks at 0.3 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 335 to 284, with 157 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were generally lower on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved down 35 points to close at 5,520, with 8,075 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for September lost 36 points to finish at 5,523, with 18,369 contract transactions, while December futures fell 45 points to close at 5,520, with 4 contracts traded.
March futures gained 15 points to finish at 5,520, with 2 contracts changing hands. No transactions were recorded for June futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,555 for August, 5,559 for September, 5,565 for December, 5,505 for March, and 5,559 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
August TE futures moved up 0.35 points to close at 248, with 1,220 contract transactions, while September TE futures lost 0.75 points to finish at 246.25, with 2,535 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
August TF futures fell 4.2 points to close at 715.2, with 1,371 contract transactions, while September TF futures gained 0.2 points to finish at 718.2, with 3,591 contracts traded.
December TF futures rose 3.2 points to close at 721, with 23 contracts changing hands. No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR ARRIVES IN WASHINGTON, D.C.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 19 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou arrived in Washington, D.C., Tuesday on the second leg of his current Canada-U.S. visit aimed at promoting cooperation in the campaign against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).
Ma paid a visit to the U.S. Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) shortly after his arrival from Toronto, Canada.
Ma exchanged views with FEMA officials on emergency response, including measures to cope with terrorist attacks.
Later in the day, Ma visited the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services to collect information about its health care and disease control systems.
In the evening, major Chinese community groups in the greater Washington area hosted a dinner in honor of Ma and his entourage.
A large number of local Chinese community members attended the dinner party to greet Ma, one of the most charismatic political stars in Taiwan's opposition camp.
Asked whether he would run for the ROC presidency in the future, Ma said he won't think about the question until his current mayoral term ends in 2006.
As a two-term mayor, Ma said, he must accomplish "some things" before his departure from the post. "Given eight years in office, I would have no excuse if I were to leave with a poor score sheet."
Ma told his overseas supporters that his top concern at the moment is to deliver on his campaign promise to build Taipei into a world-class metropolis in style.

Ma departed Taipei Sunday for an 11-day visit to six major cities in Canada and the United States. He has already visited Toronto to learn from its SARS-fighting measures. Both Toronto and Taipei were hit hard by SARS between March and June this year.
Ma will also visit Boston, Atlanta, Phoenix and San Francisco before wrapping up his current tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T ASKS OVERSEAS CHINESE TO HELP IN LOCATING WANTED COUPLE
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 19 (CNA) (By L.S. Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The government has asked overseas Chinese to help in its efforts to locate the whereabouts of a couple wanted in Taiwan, the Republic of China representative office in Los Angeles said Tuesday.

The Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Los Angeles said that Liu Kuan-chun, former chief accountant of the National Security Bureau, is wanted on charges of embezzling more than NT$192 million (US$5.565 million), while his wife, Meng Wen-hua, is wanted for allegedly assisting Liu in embezzling the money and in engaging in money laundering.

Liu and his wife sneaked out of Taiwan on Sept. 3 and Sept. 4, 2000, respectively. Sources said that Liu first went to mainland China and hid in Shanghai, with his whereabouts later becoming a mystery. Meanwhile, Meng took their two children to Toronto, Canada, with the trio cutting off contact with the outside world in January 2002.

Recent overseas media reports said that the Lius could be hiding in North America, possibly in southern California. The Investigation Bureau of the ROC Ministry of Justice then activated its alert mechanism and asked overseas Chinese to help in tracking down the couple.

The ROC representative office in Los Angeles said that anyone with information concerning Liu and his family can contact the office at (213) 389-1215, or write to the Investigation Bureau at P.O. Box 60000 in Hsintien, Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON VAMCO FAILS TO BRING SUFFICIENT RAINFALL TO NORTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Typhoon Vamco failed to bring the much-expected large amounts of rainfall to northern Taiwan after slightly skirting eastern Ilan at 2: 30 a.m., a Central Weather Bureau spokesman said Wednesday.

The Feitsui Reservoir in Taipei County -- the major water supplier for the greater Taipei area -- took in just a combined 33 millimeters of rain Tuesday through Wednesday morning, with its water level rising slightly from 137.23 meters at 4 p.m. Tuesday to 137.5 meters 10:00 a.m. Wednesday.
The current water level at the reservoir is more than 10 meters lower than the average level of about 150 meters for this time of year.

The Shihmen Dam in neighboring Taoyuan County received only 4.6 millimeters of rain as of 10: 00 a.m. Wednesday, with its water level falling to 214.66 meters, only less than five meters above the 210-meter serious warning level.

Meanwhile, the bureau lifted its sea warning at 5:30 a.m. and its land warning at 11:30 a. m. for Vamco, which was losing momentum and downgrading to a tropical storm while moving northwest off Ilan at a speed of 28 kilometers per hour toward Fujian Province in mainland China.
The little rainfall produced by Vamco was far from sufficient to ease the lingering water shortage problem in the Keelung, Taipei, Taoyuan and Hsinchu areas in northern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, giving up NT$0.055 to close at NT$34.298.
A total of US$615 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$34.301 and fluctuated between NT$34.286 and NT$34.320.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-CENTRAL AMERICA SUMMIT TO OPEN THURSDAY IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The fourth summit meeting between the Republic of China and its diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean will open in Taipei Thursday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday.

The one-day conference will bring together ROC President Chen Shui-bian and top leaders from six Central American countries -- Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and Panama -- as well as their counterparts from two Caribbean states -- the Dominican Republic and Belize.

The agenda will include reviews of political, economic, trade, investment and tourism developments as well as regional integration in Central America. Other major topics to be discussed will be bilateral and multilateral cooperative projects between the ROC and its Central American and Caribbean allies, MOFA officials said.

Meanwhile, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said the meeting will also discuss how the Central American and Caribbean allies can help the ROC join major international organizations, particularly the System of Central American Integration (SICA).

Noting that SICA Secretary-General Oscar Santa Maria will travel to Taipei to attend the ROC-Central America summit meeting, Chien said he hopes the ROC can become a SICA member outside Central America to facilitate cooperation with all Central American countries.
A joint communique will be signed at the end of the summit, Chien said.

Moreover, Chien said President Chen and Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso will sign a free trade agreement (FTA) on behalf of their two governments, with other summit attendees witnessing. It will be the first FTA that Taiwan has ever signed with any of its major trading partners.

Attendees at the summit will include Costa Rica President Abel Pacheco, Nicaragua President Enrique Bolanos, El Salvador President Francisco Flores, Guatemala President Alfonso Portillo, Panama President Mireya Moscoso, Honduras Vice President Alberto Diaz, Belize Prime Minister Said Musa, and Sergio Grullo, secretary-general to the president of the Dominican Republic.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO VISIT CENTRAL AMERICA IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that he will make the trips to several Central American countries that were postponed due to outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) on the island earlier this year.

Chen made the remarks at a gathering in the Presidential Office with several leaders of Central American countries, including Costa Rica President Abel Pacheco, Honduras Vice President Jose Alberto Diaz, Belize Prime Minister Said W. Musa, who have arrived in Taipei to attend the summit of heads of state of the Republic of China and Central American countries Thursday.

In his talks with the Costa Rican president, Chen said he was sorry that he could not attend the inauguration ceremony of a bridge built with the assistance of Taiwan due to SARS, but said that he hopes President Pacheco can accompany him to witness the splendor of the bridge when he visits in November.
The bridge, which connects the main territory of Costa Rica with the Nicoya Peninsula, was inaugurated in late July.

Meanwhile, Chen expressed gratitude to the Costa Rican government for its staunch support for the ROC's bid to enter the United Nations and the World Health Organization, adding that he was pleased to know that president Pacheco will personally attend this year's U.N. Assembly in September to speak in favor of Taiwan's cause.
In addition, Chen said he will push for the signing of a free trade agreement between the ROC and Costa Rica, which he said will benefit both countries.

In his meeting with Belize's prime minister, Chen expressed gratitude to the efforts by Musa in strengthening ties with the ROC. He noted that Musa was foreign minister when the two countries established diplomatic ties in 1989.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICA WILL CONTINUE SUPPORTING ROC'S U.N. BID: PACHECO

TEXT.P: Costa Rican President Abel Pacheco said Wednesday in Taipei that his country will continue its support for the Republic of China's bid to enter the United Nations and the World Health Organization.
Pacheco made the remarks at a meeting with President Chen Shui-bian on the eve of a summit between heads of state of the ROC and Central American countries to be held Thursday in Taipei.

The Costa Rican president noted that both the people and the government of his country have been quite satisfied with and grateful for various cooperation projects with the ROC, and hope that both countries can further strengthen cooperation in tourism and environmental protection.

For his part, Chen expressed gratitude to Pacheco for his personal attendance to a WHO ministerial meeting last year to speak in favor of Taiwan's participation in the organization. Pacheco will also personally attend this year's U.N. General Assembly in September to push for ROC's reentry to the organization.
Noting that medical cooperation should have no boundaries, Chen stressed that the ROC aspires to be a WHO observer to assume its responsibility in the world community.

Meanwhile, Chen said he was sorry that he could not attend in July the inauguration ceremony of a bridge in Costa Rica built with the assistance of Taiwan due to outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) on the island earlier this year.
However, he added that he hopes President Pacheco can accompany him to witness the splendor of the bridge when he visits several Central American countries in November.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED TO ADDRESS TRADEMARK REGISTRATION PROBLEM IN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng on Wednesday asked the government to address the problem of rogue Taiwan businessmen trying to register similar names of popular Taiwan products first in mainland China.

Lee made the remarks after Kinmen Kaoliang (sorghum) Liquor, one of the most popular Kinmen products of the outlying island, passed the initial review of mainland China's Trademark Bureau of the State Administration for Industry and Commerce, and is expected to be launched in the mainland by the end of the year.

Lee noted that mainland authorities passed the initial review Aug. 7 of Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor produced by the company of the same name for registration. It is now undergoing a public announcement period and if no one comes forward to contest the name in the next three months, it could become the first Taiwan tobacco and wine product to be registered in the mainland that has the name of a Taiwan location on it.

Lee, as well as Legislator Wu Cheng-dian of the opposition New Party, and Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor Inc. Chairman Lee Jung-wen held a press conference to announce the passing of the initial review of the registration.
But they also urged the government to come up with measures to deal with rogue Taiwan businessmen trying to register similar names of popular Taiwan products in the mainland.

Lee noted that to have Kinmen Kaoliang making inroads into mainland China has been one of his major goals, adding that the company has been applying to register with the mainland since July 7, 1999, but was rejected three times, with one of the reasons being that mainland Chinese trademark law prohibits the use of the name of county-level administration regions as a trademark.

Fortunately, Lee said, after four years of efforts, mainland China finally concluded that Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor has "already been used for some time, " and is a brand name with "a certain influence, " in passing the initial review.

Lee said that Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor's registration in the mainland was also delayed because some rouge Taiwan businessmen had maliciously registered similar names, such as "Kinmen King" and "Kinmen" liquors that were not even produced in Kinmen to fool consumers.

Lee said that "Kinmen King" trademark was revoked, but some rogue Taiwan businessmen are still trying to block the registration work of Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor, with even Taiwan Beer possibly falling victim to such malicious intentions.

Lee said that since relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are unique, and authorities in charge with trademark matters across the Taiwan Strait have not been able to effectively protect intellectual property rights and other information through exchanges, the rogue Taiwan businessmen have the chance to reap profits from registering a similar trademark.
Lee urged the effective management of rogue Taiwan businessmen's illegal practice in the mainland China.

He also expressed the hope that after the successful launch of Kinmen Kaoliang Liquor in the mainland, passing bogus Kinmen liquor will stop, and will pave the way for Taiwan's Beer to enter the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN SATISFIED WITH ROC-NICARAGUA RELATIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed his satisfaction Wednesday with the relations between the Republic of China and Nicaragua and hoped that the two nations will sign soon a free trade agreement.

In a meeting with visiting Nicaraguan President Enrique Bolanos at the Presidential Office, Chen said that bilateral exchanges and cooperation between the ROC and Nicaragua have been increased remarkably since the two countries resumed diplomatic ties in 1990.

Bolanos has visited Taiwan four times since 2000 in his capacity as vice president, a presidential candidate and as president of the republic, Chen noted, adding that it represents the close relationship between the two nations.
Chen expressed the hope that ROC-Nicaragua relations will be further strengthened under the Bolanos administration.

He also thanked Nicaragua for the support it has extended to Taiwan in the international arena, particularly in Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization, and urged Bolanos to voice support for Taiwan in the upcoming U.N. General Assembly in September.
Bolanos is in Taiwan to attend the fourth summit of the heads of states and governments of the ROC, Central America, the Dominican Republic and Belize to be held in Taipei Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRIA CRITICIZED FOR NOT TREATING TAIWAN NATIONALS FAIRLY

TEXT.P: Legislator Sun Kuo-hua of the opposition Kuomintang on Wednesday criticized Austria for not treating Taiwan nationals fairly in issuing visas.

Sun said that the Republic of China has already provided all members of the Schengen Agreement, which includes Austria, the convenience of visa-free stay of 30 days in Taiwan, and he wondered why Taiwan people have to produce documents to show financial status when applying for a visa from the Austrian office in Taiwan, which he termed as "strikingly unfair."

Sun said that when he and legislators Parris Chang and Hung Chi-chang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party applied to the Austrian Trade Delegation to attend a major overseas Chinese conference in Austria in July, they were asked to provide copies of their credit cards.
The application of Chang Fu-mei, chairwoman of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, was even rejected because she was suspected of trying to engage in political activities, according to Sun.
Sun said that this was when he realized how unfairly Austria had been treating Taiwan nationals.
Sun said that compared with the convenience provided by Taiwan to all Schengen Agreement members, Austria has not reciprocated.

Sun later went to the Austrian Trade Delegation to lodge a protest and urge Austria and other Schengen Agreement members to revoke the regulations on providing credit card copies to prove the applicants' financial status.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANG GUNG HOSPITAL COMPLETES TAIWAN'S FIRST SPLIT-LIVER TRANSPLANTS

TEXT.P: A brain-dead donor liver was split between two critical patients at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Linko, Taipei County last month, saving the lives of both patients in only the 36th successful operation of its kind in the world, a hospital spokesman said Wednesday.
Chang Gung chief surgeon Lee Wei-chen said his team split a donor liver from a brain-dead woman, which was transplanted into the bodies of two men whose livers were seriously diseased.

Lee said split-liver transplants where one donor liver is used to transplant to two recipients can help save the lives of more patients. But he said precise evaluation is needed before the surgery to ensure that the donor liver is big enough to support two recipients.

In the Chang Gung case, the donor weighed about 55 kilograms, while the two male recipients weighed 61 kilograms and 58 kilograms, respectively. After a careful assessment, Lee said his team decided to perform the split-liver transplants in operations that lasted 10 hours.
Lee said the pieces of liver transplanted into the two recipients have regenerated to several times their original sizes and are functioning normally.
"The donor family's selflessness has helped save the lives of these two people," Lee said.
The two recipients, identified as Lin Ching-piao and Hsiung Chen-hsing, were discharged from the hospital last week in good health.
They returned to the hospital Wednesday for physical checkups and to attend a news conference along with the medical team to make public the new domestic medical achievement.
Lin, 52, said he lapsed into a coma shortly after he checked into Chang Gung in June because of acute liver disease.

"After I regained consciousness, I found I was lying beside a stranger in an isolation ward. Later on, a doctor told me that I had undergone a liver transplant with a piece of liver from a brain-dead woman and that my 'neighbor' had also received a transplant with a piece of liver from the same donor," Lin recalled.

Hsiung, 39, who was also critically ill with cirrhosis before the transplant, said he has developed a close friendship with Lin as they shared the same donor liver and had both endured the discomfort of surgery and the risks of complications and rejection.
Both Lin and Hsiung expressed their heartfelt gratitude to the donor and pledged to do volunteer work during their leisure time for the rest of their lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEALTH GAP TO BE FURTHER NARROWED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said the government has successfully narrowed the income gap between the rich and the poor through a combination of measures, including boosting economic growth, creating jobs and improving welfare benefits.

Yu made the remarks at a weekly Cabinet meeting after listening to an analytical report on local hosuehold incomes in 2002, jointly prepared by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) and the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

According to the report, the average disposable income of the top 20 percent of households, at NT$1,799,733, was 6.16 times that of the bottom 20 percent of households, slightly lower than the figure of 6.39 registered in 2001.
Yu said the government has consistently given priority to enhancing economic growth, creating jobs and increasing welfare services for the disadvantageous.

"These efforts have paid off as the income gap has been narrowed and the average income of local households has increased over the past year," Yu said, adding that the government will continue its efforts to promote equitable distribution of wealth and sustain economic growth.

Meanwhile, the CEPD predicted that the income gap between the richest 20 percent of local families and the poorest 20 percent can be further narrowed to 6.05 times in 2003 in case the nation's economic growth rate reaches 3.06 percent, social welfare expenditure accounts for 3.8 percent of GDP and the unemployment rate drops to 4.8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUNGSHAN UNLIKELY TO BE PART OF DIRECT AIR LINKS WITH MAINLAND: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Although the Executive Yuan prefers to start direct flights with the mainland from Hsiaokang Airport in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan and Chiang Kai-shek Airport in Taoyuan, at first, other airports have not been ruled out, Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council said Wednesday.

However, Tsai said Taipei's Sungshan Airport, which cannot accommodate Boeing 747 cargo flights, would not help the country's efforts to develop itself into a business hub in the region even if it was opened for direct links.

She made the comment in response to a request made by Liu Pao-kui, deputy secretary-general of the Taipei City Government, at a weekly Cabinet meeting. Liu urged the Cabinet to make Sungshan one of the airports linked with the mainland by direct flights.

Liu said that metropolitan Taipei has more than 900,000 people flying to and from the mainland every month, and the Sungshan Airport, which is used for domestic flights, still can take in 157 more flights a day, and even more after the island's high-speed railway is completed in 2005. All these make Sungshan an appropriate airport for direct flights to and from the mainland.
In addition to economic considerations, an official from the Ministry of National Defense opposed the idea of making Sungshan a direct-flights airport.

The officer argued that it will open the capital's many government office buildings to possible terrorist attacks such as the one that took place in New York on Sept. 11, 2001 when hijackers commandeered airplanes and rammed them into the World Trade Center towers.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou made direct flight links from the Sungshan Airport to the mainland one of his promises while campaigning for reelection in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: BELIZE SUPPORTS TAIWAN'S PARTICIPATION IN WORLD ORGANIZATIONS

TEXT.P: Belize Prime Minister Said W. Musa said Wednesday that his country supports the decision of the people of Taiwan on their own fate as well as the Republic of China's attempts to enter international organizations.
Musa made the remarks at a meeting with President Chen Shui-bian on the eve of a summit of heads of state of the ROC and Central American countries to be held Thursday in Taipei.
Musa, who has visited Taiwan several times, said he can see the progress on the island every time he visits.

Expressing gratitude for the ROC's contributions to economic cooperation projects and its agricultural technology assistance to his country, Musa said he looks forward to President Chen's visit to Belize.
Chen thanked the government of Belize for its long-term support for the ROC's bids to join international organizations.

The president added that his original plan to visit several Central American countries in June was interrupted due to outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) on the island earlier this year, and he hopes that he can visit Belize some time after October.

Noting that Taiwan, an island country, has been through many earthquakes and typhoons, including a devastating 7.6-magnitude temblor in 1999, Chen said it is now working hard to recover from the aftereffects of SARS.

The disease affected Taiwan seriously by making numerous commercial activities stop and by shrinking consumption, with the island registering a negative economic growth of 0.08 percent in the second quarter, Chen noted.

However, the president added, with SARS contained, the country recovered very rapidly. "We have faith that economic growth will reach 3.9 percent and 4.6 percent in the third and fourth quarters, respectively, and the growth for the whole year will be maintained at more than 3 percent," Chen said.

Musa hailed Chen's leadership and the ROC government's efficient measures in controlling the disease, saying that he hopes the summit among ROC and Central American leaders can find remedies and ideas on topics of mutual interest.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER EXPRESSES SYMPATHY FOR VICTIMS OF IRAQ EXPLOSION

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien offered condolences to United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan on the death of U.N. workers in Tuesday's car bomb attack in Baghdad, Iraq.
In a letter to Annan, Chien said he was stunned by the cruel attack and expressed sympathy to the victims and their families.
The minister also reiterated the country's willingness to take part in any U.N. and international programs to help Iraqis rebuild their country.
The attack caused by an explosive-loaded truck parked outside the U.N. office in Baghdad, killed at least 17 people, including U.N. representative in Baghdad Sergio Vieira de Mello.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER GIVES CAL FREE HAND TO DECIDE FATE OF BOEING CONTRACT

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun condemned Boeing's cancellation of a planned visit to the company's factory in the United States by the ROC vice president, but said Wednesday that whether to negate a contract with the airliner manufacturer to purchase a number of aircraft would be up to the government foundation that owns China Airlines (CAL).

Although all companies, both private and state-owned, should give the nation's interests priority over their profit margins, Yu said that the government- owned China Aviation Development Foundation, the largest stockholder of CAL, will decide whether to terminate CAL's purchase contract with Boeing to protest the airliner manufacturer's behavior toward Vice President Annette Lu.
"Business should be separate from politics," Yu said, adding that it was regrettable that Boeing impolitely turned the country's vice president away because of "political reasons."

He dismissed opposition parties' criticism that Lu's bungled visit to Boeing was a diplomatic set-back for the administration, saying that critics should speak out against Boeing and, more specifically, Beijing, who forced Boeing to spurn Lu.

Lu was scheduled to visit Boeing's plant in Seattle on Aug. 18 but Boeing canceled the visit six days earlier. Angered by what was perceived as a snub, Lu said in a public speech in Seattle on Monday that Boeing should be ashamed of itself.

In related developments Wednesday, a lawmaker from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Lee Chun-yi, said he and his DPP colleagues will ask CAL to terminate its contract with Boeing in the next legislative session unless Boeing apologizes.

The opposition Kuomintang (KMT), which seldom see eye to eye with the DPP on anything, showed their sympathy for Lu. However, KMT whip at the Legislative Yuan Lee Chia-chin said Taipei's diplomatic struggles with Beijing date back five decades, and the DPP administration should not be caught off guard by Beijing's underhanded dealings.
Lee said he hopes similar incidents will not happen when President Chen Shui-bian makes a transit stop in the United States in October on his way to visit Central America.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN APPROVES CENTRAL GOVERNMENT BUDGET FOR FISCAL 2004

TEXT.P: A Cabinet meeting agreed on the central government's budget plan for fiscal 2004 Wednesday, with education, scientific and cultural expenditures accounting for the bulk of total expenditures.
The budget plan will be submitted to the Legislative Yuan for approval by the end of August.
According to the plan, the expenditures and revenues for fiscal 2004 will be set at NT$1.61 trillion (US$46 billion) and NT$1.35 trillion, respectively, leaving a deficit of NT$257.40 billion.

On expenditures, NT$309.9 billion will be allocated to education, scientific and cultural spending, accounting for 19.2 percent of total expenditures and representing an increase of NT$16.7 billion over the previous fiscal year, followed by social welfare projects at NT$285.6 billion (17.7 percent of total expenditures) , national defense costs at NT$251.9 billion (15.6 percent) , and economic development spending at NT$247.9 billion (15.4 percent).
Premier Yu Shyi-kun asked Cabinet officials to strengthen communication with the legislature and implement financial reform projects to balance the country's finance.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN APPRECIATES RELATIONS WITH HONDURAS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed his appreciation Wednesday for the Republic of China's relations with Honduras and thanked the Central American ally for its support in the international arena.
Receiving Honduran Vice President Jose Alberto Diaz at the Presidential Office, Chen said that the ROC and Honduras have maintained diplomatic ties for more than 60 years.
The two nations also signed a memorandum of understanding on cooperation in January to further increase exchanges and friendship based on the existing foundation, Chen noted.
"The long-term friendship between the ROC and Honduras is based on a common belief shared by the two countries in the universal values of democracy, freedom, human rights and peace," Chen stressed.
The president also asked his guest to convey his condolences to the Honduran people and government and the family of former president Carlos Roberto Reina who died a day earlier.

Diaz is in Taiwan to attend on behalf of Honduran President Ricardo Maduro the fourth summit of the heads of states and governments of the ROC, Central America, the Dominican Republic and Belize to be held in Taipei Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER VOWS TO PUSH FOR SCIENTIFIC COOPERATION WITH JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Former Premier Vincent Siew, who now serves as President Chen Shui-bian's chief economic adviser, said in Tokyo Wednesday that Taiwan would do all it could to form closer scientific and technological cooperation with Japan.
Siew, who arrived in Tokyo Aug. 18 for a five day visit, met with Japan business leaders at a dinner hosted by Taipei's representative to Japan, Lo Fu-chuan, Wednesday.

Speaking to journalists posted in Tokyo by Taipei-based media after the dinner, Siew said he was impressed by Japan's determination to catch up with leading Western countries in science and technology by pumping 40 percent more funds into research and development over the next five years.
The former premier said he could feel the earnestness of Japanese businessmen to cooperate with their Taiwan counterparts during his last two days in Japan.
"The cooperation will help Japan foster closer ties with Taiwan and help Taiwan upgrade its industries." Siew said.

Siew also heads a science and technology committee under the Association of East Asian Relations, a semi-government organization established to deal with Tokyo on behalf of the Republic of China in the absence official ties with Japan. He said his committee will try to establish new channels for exchanges of scientific and technological information with Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADERS OF EL SALVADOR AND GUATEMALA ARRIVE IN TAIPEI FOR SUMMIT

TEXT.P: El Salvador President Francisco Flores and Guatemala President Alfonso Portillo arrived in Taipei Wednesday night to attend a summit between the leaders of the Republic of China and its eight Central American allies Thursday.
They were greeted at the airport by Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien.

The two leaders will join Costa Rica President Abel Pacheco, Nicaragua President Enrique Bolanos, Belize Prime Minister Said Musa, Panama President Mireya Moscoso, Honduras Vice President Alberto Diaz and Secretary-General to the president of the Dominican Republic, Sergio Grullo in Thursday's summit with ROC President Chen Shui-bian,
All of the leaders except Francisco Flores and Alfonso Portillo took part in a reception hosted by Vice President Annette Lu earlier in the day in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TROPICAL STORM FORMS IN PACIFIC

TEXT.P: A tropical storm, the 12th this year, formed in Pacific Wednesday, according to the Central Weather Bureau.
The storm, Krovanh, with a gale-force winds and a 100-kilometer radius, is located at sea some 1,200 kilometers east-northeast of Manila.
Moving at a speed of 11 kilometers per hour on a westward path, the storm is not expected to affect Taiwan until this weekend.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INTERNATIONAL PAYMENT SURPLUS TOPS US 5.82 BILLION DOLLARS IN 2Q

TEXT.P: Taiwan's international payment surplus amounted to US$5.82 billion in the second quarter of this year, thanks to the increase of trade surplus registered in the same period, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Taipei-based Central Bank of China (CBC).
CBC officials said that both imports and exports in the April-June period registered a moderate growth rate, with a trade surplus of US$5.68 billion.
With regard to the current account, Taiwan enjoyed a surplus of US$6.58 billion at the same time, while the monetary account registered a deficit of US$2.08 billion.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's investment in foreign securities totaled US$12.46 billion against a foreign capital inflow of 5.31 billion into the local bourse, leaving a net capital outflow of US$7.15 billion for the capital account, a quarterly record.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 21, or the 24th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1754: Scottish engineer William Murdoch is born. He pioneered the use of coal-gas for lighting in 1792 while working with James Watt and Matthew Bouton on their steam engines.
1902: Manufacturer Martin Leland starts his luxury car venture by naming his new automobile after Antoine de la Motte Cadillac, the French colonial administrator and Detroit's founding father.
1908: Orville Wright, American aviation pioneer, and his brother Wilbur make the first military aircraft for the United States.
1930: Princess Margaret, sister of British Queen Elizabeth II, is born.
1944: Representatives from China, Britain, Russia and the United States meet at Dumbarton Oaks near Washington, D.C. to plan for the formation of the United Nations.
1937: The Treaty of Non-Aggression between China and the Soviet Union is signed in Nanking.
1959: The Baghdad Pact is formally renamed the Central Treaty Organization (CENTO) following Iraq's withdrawal earlier in the year.
1959: Hawaii becomes the 50th state of the United States.
1963: South Vietnam declares martial law after raids on Buddhist pagodas and the arrest of hundreds of Buddhist monks.
1976: Prince Maphevu Harry Dlamini, prime minister of the Kingdom of Swaziland, accompanied by Madame Dlamini and a party of eight, arrives in the Republic of China for a seven-day visit.
1982: King Sobhuza II of Swaziland dies at the age of 83. He was one of the world's longest-reigning monarchs, having been on the throne sine 1921.
1982: Republic of China Economics Minister William Y.T. Chao announces the partial lifting of an import ban on 842 types of Japanese consumer goods.
1983: Benigno Aquino, leader of the anti-Marcos faction in the Philippines, is gunned down as he steps onto the asphalt at Manila Airport after returning from a three-year sojourn in the United States. He was 51.
1984: A massive demonstration is held in Manila to mark the first anniversary of the assassination of Benigno Aquino.
1985: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Robert C. Chien as the new finance minister, succeeding Loh Jen-kong who resigned on Aug. 15.
1986: A cloud of toxic gas is released from the volcanic Lake Nyos, near Wum in northwest Cameroon, killing more than 1,200 people.
1990: An ROC Air Force B-1900 air transport plane crashes in Tungshih Village in Yunlin County, killing all 16 people aboard, including three major-generals and nine colonels.
1990: The Indian Parliament approves presidential rule in Jammu and Kashmir and gives the armed forces special powers in the riot-torn state.
1991: President Mikhail Gorbachev arrives back in Moscow after the collapse of a coup attempt by hardliners.
1991: Latvia declares its independence from the Soviet Union.
1997: Abdur Rahim Gaffurzai, the newly appointed prime minister of Afghanistan, is killed along with 13 others in a plane crash.
1999: Over 96 percent of the Kuomintang's party delegates vote to support Vice President Lien Chan as the party's candidate in the following spring's presidential election.
2000: Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui proposes the establishment of an Asian monetary fund to promote economic cooperation in Asia.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his Gambian counterpart Yahya Jammeh sign a joint communique pledging to continue enhancing close cooperation between the two countries.
2001: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reiterates while meeting with visiting Paraguayan Foreign Minister Jose Antonio Moreno Ruffinelli that the ROC government will abide by the memorandum of trade and investment signed by the ROC and Paraguay to further cement the established ties between Taipei and Asuncion.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to carry out, but when you once try to carry out a thing you must never give it up until you have done it thoroughly and well."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-CENTRAL AMERICA SUMMIT MEETING OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday he is convinced that "heads of state diplomacy" or "summit diplomacy" is an effective way to boost exchanges and cooperation between countries.
Chen made the remarks at the opening of the fourth summit meeting of top leaders of the Republic of China and its allies in Central America and the Caribbean.
Chen said he is scheduled to make his third state visits to Central American countries in November to bring Taiwan people's love and friendship to people there.

The annual summit meeting brings together of top leaders of the ROC, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, Panama, Belize and the Dominican Republic to discuss measures to boost bilateral and multilateral ties.
A joint communique will be issued at the end of the conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The China Times:
The government will ask state-owned enterprises to return unused properties.
The United Daily News:

The 'one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait' description of cross-strait ties to be a hot topic in the run-up to the 2004 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: FILIPINO CONJOINED TWINS HEAD HOME AFTER SEPARATION SURGERY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Filipino pair of conjoined twins joined at the chest and abdomen returned to the Philippines Thursday after undergoing successful separation surgery in Taiwan.
The infant girl twins, accompanied by their mother and a volunteer from the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, boarded a Philippine Airlines flight to Manila in the morning.
The Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, the largest charity organization in Taiwan, had arranged for the operation in its hospital.

While boarding the plane back home, the mother of the twins, Marieta Awel, held one of the baby girls in her arms, while the Tzu Chi volunteer held the other girl. The mother said she was full of happiness and gratitude for Tzu Chi's help in giving her daughters the opportunity to have independent lives.

The two infant girls, Lea and Rachel, were born July 1, 2000, in the province of Kalinga in the northern Philippines. The father works on a farm, earning only about NT$32 (US$0.92) a day, while the mother is a housewife. The two girls are their first children. As the family was too poor to afford to care for the twins and had to solicit the assistance of their local government.

The babies were sent to a children's hospital in Manila, where Tzu Chi volunteers first met them in January this year and reported to Master Cheng Yen, founder of the Tzu Chi foundation, who expressed great concern.

The Tzu Chi Buddhist General Hospital then took over the matter and performed the separation surgery June 28. Doctors reported that the most difficult part of the procedure was dealing with the conjoined liver.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES UP BY 68.25 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Thursday, with the weighted index moving up 68.25 points to close at 5,611.86.
Market turnover amounted to NT$105.78 billion (US$3.09 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 68.25 points to close at 5,611.86.
The bourse opened at 5,545.97 and then fluctuated between 5,612.15 and 5,522.42 during trading.

A total of 4.31 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$105.78 billion (US$3.09 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 3.59 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$86.23 billion (US$2.51 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with construction stocks moving down 2.4 percent. Bank and insurance shares remained unchanged.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up the most at 1.7 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 1.6 percent, cement stocks at 1.1 percent, textile issues at 0.6 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.5 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 385 to 260, with 137 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEED TO WORRY ABOUT RESURGENCE OF SARS: HEALTH OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The government has taken the initiative in guarding against the possible reemergence of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), and the public can rest easy, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Thursday.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director general of the DOH's Center for Disease Control, made the remarks in the wake of wire service reports that a SARS-like disease had swept through a nursing home in Vancouver, Canada, killing six residents so far.
The Associated Press reports said that the disease looks like SARS and acts like a milder version of SARS, which has killed 44 people in Canada, but officials doubt the respiratory illness is SARS.

Shih said Taiwan has already taken the initiative in implementing SARS detection and prevention measures, and he assured the public that they need not be concerned about a resurgence of SARS in Taiwan, adding that the likelihood of the SARS-like disease seen in Canada appearing in Taiwan is low.

Shih noted that if SARS does hit Taiwan again, it will most likely first strike those who are older and more frail. He said nursing homes in Taiwan kicked off a health self-management mechanism July 15 to prevent the reemergence of SARS. Any of the nursing home residents who are found to have the symptoms of fever will be sent to hospital immediately to avoid any transmissions.

Shih said that the DOH has also taken the initiative to begin random checks on 50 patients per week in Taiwan hospitals, taking blood samples of those with fever to test for possible dengue fever, Japanese encephalitis or SARS.
Starting from November 15, the checks will increase in frequency, with the DOH staff checking 50 patients with fever each day, targeting influenza and SARS especially, he said.
He noted that there have been no suspected SARS cases registered so far and that the public can rest assured because of the government's series of stringent preventive measures.
SARS hit Taiwan hard between March and late June this year, claiming 84 lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT INTEGRATION AIMED AT PEACE, DEMOCRACY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday his appeal for economic and cultural integration between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is mainly aimed at creating peace, democracy and prosperity on both sides of the strait.

Addressing the opening session of the fourth summit meeting of top leaders of the Republic of China and its diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean, Chen said he hopes to resolve cross-strait political disputes through increased economic and cultural exchanges and integration.

Chen urged mainland China to renounce the option of military force in resolving disputes and to work together with Taiwan in creating peace, democracy and prosperity for the benefit of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
He added that this is also the basis of the ROC's thinking in actively participating in the process of Central American integration.
"We are more than willing to work with our Central American allies in boosting democracy, prosperity, peace and equitable distribution of wealth in the region," he said.

Since the first ROC-Central America summit meeting was held in 1997, Chen said, the event has laid clear direction for bilateral and multilateral cooperation between the ROC and its allies in the region.

"With co-prosperity, cooperation and development as the main themes, I'm convinced that the current meeting will further consolidate the foundation for our future cooperation and sustainable development," Chen said.
He also took advantage of the occasion to thank the Central American and Caribbean diplomatic allies for their firm support for Taiwan's cause in the international community over the years.
"We appreciate your unswerving support for our bid to join major international organizations, including the United Nations and the World Health Organization (WHO)," Chen said.

Noting that the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) earlier this year has signified the importance of international cooperation in disease control and prevention, Chen said Taiwan's bid to join the WHO has thus received more sympathy and support this year.

Because of Beijing's opposition, Chen said, Taiwan is still shut out of the WHO. Chen said the ROC will not be daunted by the setback and will make continued efforts to realize its goal to join the world health body for the sake of enhancing health care for its people and making a greater contribution to world health.

Thanks to a series of pump-priming projects adopted by his administration, Chen said, Taiwan has gradually recovered from the adverse impact brought by the SARS outbreak between March and June this year.

Despite Beijing's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, Chen said, Taiwan is by no means an isolated island. On the contrary, he said, Taiwan is a "global island" with extensive ties with the rest of the world.
While diligently developing its economy and carrying out democratic reforms, Chen said, Taiwan has also spared no efforts in fulfilling it obligations as a member of the global community.

Through its democratic reforms, human rights protection, and active participation in international humanitarian relief programs and the global anti-terrorist campaign, Chen said Taiwan has received ever-increasing world recognition. Countries around the world can no longer ignore Taiwan's existence and must face up to its presence in the international community, he added.

Chen also reaffirmed the consistency and continuity of the ROC's diplomatic policy, saying that his administration will abide by all the country's agreements and treaties with other countries and will honor its promises to its allies.
Chen said he hopes the current summit meeting will chart concrete programs and measures to further boost cooperation.

Meanwhile, Chen said he is scheduled to make his third state visits to Central American countries in November to bring Taiwan people's love and frienship to ROC allies in the region. He added he believes that "heads of state diplomacy" or "summit diplomacy" is an effective way to promote international relations.

A joint communique will be signed at the end of the summit. Moreover, President Chen and Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso will sign a free trade agreement (FTA) on behalf of their two governments, with other summit attendees witnessing. It will be the first FTA that Taiwan has ever signed with any of its major trading partners.

Attendees at the summit nclude Costa Rica President Abel Pacheco, Nicaragua President Enrique Bolanos, El Salvador President Francisco Flores, Guatemala President Alfonso Portillo, Panama President Mireya Moscoso, Honduras Vice President Alberto Diaz, Belize Prime Minister Said Musa, and Sergio Grullo, secretary-general to the president of the Dominican Republic.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were generally higher on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved up 88 points to close at 5,611, with 45,103 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index futures for October gained 74 points to finish at 5,624, with 78 contract transactions, while December futures rose 50 points to close at 5,570, with 5 contracts traded.
March futures remained unchanged at 5,520, with only one contract traded. No transactions were reported for other months.
Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,523 for September 5,550 for October, 5,520 for March, and 5,524 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also generally higher.
September TE futures moved up 7.15 points to close at 253.4, with 4,989 contract transactions, while October TE futures lost 0.4 points to finish at 248.8, with 3 contracts traded.
December TE futures surged 11.1 points to close at 253.8, with 5 contract transactions, while March TE futures rose 7 points to finish at 250, with 2 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
September TF futures gained 3.6 points to close at 721.8, with 3,207 contract transactions, while October TF futures rose 5.4 points to finish at 724.6, with 22 contracts traded.
December TF futures increased 4 points to close at 725, with 2 contract transactions, while March TF futures moved up 0.2 points to finish at 715, with only one contract traded.
