DOC.HEADLINE: 'AUG. 23 BATTLE' TO BE COMMEMORATED

TEXT.P: A parade and an evening party will be held in downtown Taipei Friday to commemorate "the Battle of the Taiwan Straits," which started on Aug. 23, 1958.
The commemorating activities will be sponsored by the major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the "Confederation of Veterans of the Aug. 23 Battle."

On Aug. 23, 1958, Communist Chinese troops began to shell the Kinmen island (Quemoy). In the first 36 hours, the island was battered by 94,000 rounds of gunfire. In the following 42 days, some 400,000 additional shells rained down on the island, which is only 131 square kilometers in area. The Communist attack was finally repulsed. The situation in the Taiwan Strait became stable after the battle.

A KMT spokesman said the battle symbolizes an honor to serve in the armed forces to defend Taiwan. He said the battle has a very important meaning, but the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has ignored it.

Organizers of the activities said some 8,000 veterans of the battle and a few legislators of the KMT and the People First Party will participate in the parade from Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to the 228 Memorial Park, where they will hold the evening party. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SHOULD LET HONG KONG HAVE MORE DEMOCRACY: EDITORIAL

TEXT.P: The Washington Post said in Thursday's editorial that mainland China should let Hong Kong people have more democracy.

In the editorial, titled "Democracy for Hong Kong," the newspaper said the massive demonstrations last month in Hong Kong in support of democracy and against a Beijing-backed anti-sedition law do not seem to have shocked China's Communist rulers enough to accept the remedy for the dilemma, which would be more democracy.
Instead, they are following a more familiar Communist script: "Make short-term concessions to popular anger while vilifying and seeking to isolate democracy movement leaders," the editorial said.

This tended to confirm the prediction of an American columnist last week that Beijing would follow "classic united front tactics," pressuring some democracy proponents back into the fold while ostracizing and vilifying those who can't be pressured. The columnist said, "The demonization of the democrats,... will alienate the majority of Hong Kong."

The editorial said that, in the long run an effort to rein in Hong Kong can only sour U.S.-China relations. If China really wants to understand their views and complaints, it should let Hong Kong's people express those views through the ballot box. (by J. Kuo and EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON KROVANH UNLIKELY TO HIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Typhoon Krovanh was formed Wednesday night to the south of the Philippines, but it is unlikely to hit Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau said Thursday.

CWB forecasters said the typhoon, located at 18.8 degrees north and 129.2 degrees east as of 8:00 a.m. Thursday, is unlikely to reach Taiwan. However, it may bring heavy rains to the southern part of the island. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADERS IN ROC-CENTRAL AMERICA SUMMIT DISCUSS COOPERATION

TEXT.P: The fourth summit meeting of the heads of state of the Republic of China and its diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean opened in Taipei Thursday, with the topics of political and economic cooperation dominating the first part of the one-day meeting.
President Chen Shui-bian presided over the opening ceremony at 9 a.m. Afterwards, the participants entered into a roundtable room which accommodates 40 people.

The first part of the morning meeting centered on the giving of reports and discussions on political issues. After President Chen gave a brief report, Honduran Vice President Alberto Diaz gave a report on regional integration in Central America. Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso then gave a report on security, focusing on anti-terrorism and the battle against drug trafficking.
President Chen affirmed the efficacy of Central America's regional integration, adding that he is happy to see the Central America region's development and cooperation.

The president said that since the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in the United States, the world has begun to attach greater importance to the question of security, pointing to the passage of U.N. Resolution 1373 in 2001 which states that the Security Council unanimously adopted a wide-ranging, comprehensive resolution with steps and strategies to combat terrorism.

Although the Republic of China is not a member of the United Nations, it will devote itself to cooperating in the international battle against the crime, Chen said, earning an enthusiastic response from the participating countries.

Reports and discussion on issues related to the economy and cooperation made up the second part of the morning meeting. President Chen first gave a report on cooperation relations, then Guatemalan President Alfonso Portillo gave a report on the cooperation and trade relations between the ROC and Central America, with participating countries expressing appreciation for the assistance provided by the ROC to Central America and the Dominican Republic.

President Chen noted that Central America has excellent geographical position and abundant natural resources. After a free trade zone in America is established, the region's potential for development will be enormous, he added.
The participating heads of state expressed their affirmation about the ROC's economic might, and said they hope that they can make inroads into Asian markets by using Taiwan as a springboard.

The biennial summit meeting brings together the heads of state of the ROC, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, Panama, Belize and the Dominican Republic to discuss measures to boost bilateral and multilateral ties.
The meeting continued in the afternoon, with a joint comunique being issued at the end of the one-day summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar declined against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, giving up NT$0.060 to close at NT$34.238.
A total of US$731 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$34.246 and was traded between NT$34.225 and NT$34.356 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADIES OF CENTRAL AMERICAN COUNTRIES VISITS GLASS ART MUSEUM

TEXT.P: First ladies of Central American and Caribbean nations who are currently on a visit in Taipei along with their husbands toured a local glass art museum in suburban Taipei Thursday.

While their husbands were attending the fourth summit meeting of the top leaders of the Republic of China and its diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean, the first ladies of Costa Rica and El Salvador and wives of senior leaders of Central American and Caribbean countries visited the Tittot Glass Art Museum in Peitou, founded by Heinrich Wang, a pioneer in Taiwan's glass art development.

Both Costa Rican first lady Leila Rodriguez and El Salvadoran first lady Lourdes Rodriguez de Flores said they were impressed by the glass art works on display. The collection comprises masterpieces created by Wang and other local and foreign artists.

The visitors said they were particularly interested in many of Wang's works that feature traditional Buddhist artistic concepts. They also took a glimpse into glassmaking procedures at the Tittot workshop in the museum complex.

Other visitors included Joan Musa, wife of the Belize prime minister; Lila Maria Bolanos Chamorro, a granddaughter of the Nicaragua president; Maria Elena Marinakys de Diaz, wife of the Honduras vice president; and Lourdes Isabel Mejia de Grullon, wife of the secretary-general to the Dominican Republic president.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER TO VISIT U.S. TO PROMOTE INVESTMENT IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Lin Chuan will lead a 46-member delegation to the United States Friday to promote investment in Taiwan.
Minister Lin will mainly visit New York and Boston, sponsoring a forum on investment in Taiwan, as well as delivering speeches in the two cities.
During his visit in New York, Lin and the delegation will first visit a plant of Formosa Plastic Group in the U.S. and visit major financial institutions such as Fidelity, Citibank and Merrill Lynch.

After the end of the first forum in New York, American International Group (AIG) , the parent company of Taiwan's Nan Shan Life Insurance Co., will hold a press conference to promote investment in Taiwan.
AIG chairman is scheduled to preside over the press conference to talk about its investment plans in Taiwan.
After the forum in Boston, Lin will also meet with several Taiwan banks which have set up footholds in the U.S.
In addition, Lin will also witness the signing of memorandum on cooperation between Taiwan Securities Central Depository Company and the Depository Trust and Clearing Corporation of New York.

The 46-member delegation will include financial leaders from the Bank of Taiwan, Cathay Financial Holding Co., China Development Financial Holding Corp., Chinatrust Financial Holding Co., Land Bank of Taiwan and Polaris Securities, as well as leaders from high-tech industries. The delegation is expected to return to Taiwan Aug. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY DENIES S-2T FORCED LANDING REPORT

TEXT.P: The ROC Navy General Headquarters (NGH) debunked media reports Thursday that a navy anti-submarine aircraft made a forced landing at Shuinan Airport in the central Taiwan city of Taichung earlier in the day.
The NGH said in a press release that the S-2T was on a post-maintenance test flight when its pilot spotted an engine fire warning signal.

The pilot immediately made an emergency landing, the press statement said, adding that thanks to the pilot's appropriate handling, the plane landed safely and didn't veer off the runway as some media reports claimed.
The NGH further said the plane's smooth emergency landing should not be described as a forced landing. It also dismissed as "misleading" media reports that the S-2T was stranded on the runway.
The NGH stressed that the emergency landing didn't disrupt Shuinan Airport operations.

According to airport regulations, fire engines and other emergency engineering vehicles were mobilized while the S-2T was making an emergency landing. The mobilization might have cause a false alarm, NGH sources said.

The ROC Air Force transferred 20-plus S-2T anti-submarine aircraft to the navy a few years ago under a military restructuring plan. As the S-2Ts are aging, the military has sought to buy a new generation of anti-submarine aircraft. The United States has agreed to sell 12 P-3C long-range anti-submarine aircraft to Taiwan. The navy has yet to detail a procurement plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIRPLANE GLIDES ONTO RUNWAY AT KINMEN AIRPORT

TEXT.P: A passenger airplane from Taipei glided onto a runway at Shangyi Airport on Kinmen Island Thursday while trying to land amid a heavy downpour, forcing the airport authorities to shut down the facility.

The MD82 passenger airplane of Far East Air Transport Corp., which departed from Taipei at 11: 14 a.m. with six crew members and 147 passengers on board, landed at 12: 03 p. m. while seeking to make a landing at Shangyi Airport on the front-line island in heavy rain and a tail wind.

The plane was mired in a large amount of mud but no one was injured aboard. The passengers were transported to the terminal by shuttle buses after more than 10 fire engines and ambulances came to the rescue.
The airport was re-opened later the same day.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAP BETWEEN STUDENTS COMMON PROBLEM OF ENGLISH TEACHERS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: English teachers in Taiwan said Thursday that the most common problem they encounter in classrooms is the gap between students in urban and rural areas and the different levels of students.

They made the remarks at a press conference which was held in the wake of two workshops sponsored by the College Board, a New York-based U.S. education institution that is specialized in nurturing English teachers.
The three-day workshops were held in Taipei Aug. 14-16 and in Kaohsiung Aug. 18-20, with 154 English teachers from junior and senior high schools attending.

The two teaching experts and two staff of the College Board, who were invited by the Ministry of Education to come to Taiwan, said that the ideal situation would be around 20 students in a class, although most of the English teachers said that they have to deal with far more students than that.

A survey of the participants of the workshops found that up to 90 percent of the teachers said that the workshop has helped them, with some also suggesting that there will be advanced courses in the future and that they could receive guidance on how to effectively teach a class that has strikingly different levels of students.
Fang Huei-chin, an English teacher in a Taipei County junior high school, said that English teaching tends to focus on reading under the present examination system in Taiwan.

Fang said that she had spent a lot of time comparing the English teaching materials on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and found that the materials used in the mainland seek to upgrade the students' ability in listening, speaking and reading and writing simultaneously, which she said was quite a surprise to her.
Fang noted that she used to focus on the performance of the students in tests, and now she was aware that the ability of listening, speaking, reading and writing is equally important.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S EARLIEST NON-GOVERNMENTAL NEWSPAPER DIGITALIZED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's earliest non-governmental newspaper "Min Pao", published in the 1940's, has been digitalized.

The newspaper, inaugurated on Oct. 10, 1945 and closed on Feb. 28, 1947, was digitalized by the National Taichung Library under a program of the Council for Cultural Affairs of the Executive Yuan to digitalize valuable old publications. Min Pao is the first newspaper digitalized under the program.

Prof. Y.L. Ho of the National Taipei Normal College said Min Pao is the first Chinese-language newspaper published by Taiwanese after the Second World War. It was closed on the first day of the 228 Incident.

He said the newspaper provides a valuable account of the social and economic conditions of Taiwan prior to the incident, in which many people were killed. The paper will be made available on the Internet for the general public to read. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: BULL SUMMONED BY PROSECUTOR TO GIVE EVIDENCE

TEXT.P: A bull which is at the center of an ownership dispute made headlines Thursday after it was summoned by a prosecutor at the Taoyuan District Court in northern Taiwan to provide evidence Wednesday.
Prosecutor Lee San-ming wanted to examine the bull to determine whether it was the calf stolen from Taoyuan cattle farmer Peng Yun-neng two years ago.

Peng claimed his beloved two-year-old calf, called Aiai, was stolen with three other cows while they were grazing in a riverbed in Hsinwu, Taiyuan County two years ago. Witness said they saw people used stun guns to put the cattle into a truck.
Peng claimed he found Aiai in a herd of cattle raised by another farmer in Tayuan, also in Taiyuan County earlier this year.
His claim was disputed by the farmer, identified only by his family name of Liang.
Peng presented to a prosecutor a copy of Aiai's nose print he had made when the bull was young to support his claim.
Furthermore, Peng said there is a close feeling between he and his two-year-old bull, adding that the bull recognized him immediately after they were first reunite.
The bull rubbed its head against Peng gently and wagging its tail fiercely as if glad to see him again, he said.
However, the bull didn't show any sign of this close attachment to Peng at Wednesday's hearing.

The bull's present owner denied Peng's claim, arguing that he bought the bull five years ago in Kaohsiung for NT$25,000 (US$730), and said the bull had been sold at least nine times before it landed in his ranch. The bull's nose print is not reliable evidence of its identity, as it changes with age, he said.
The bull's former nine owners were also present at Wednesday's hearing. They angrily disputed Peng's claim over the bull.

A cattle breeding expert from the Council of Agriculture helped the prosecutor examine the bull's teeth and nose to determine its age and breed. He also checked Peng's copy of the nose print against the bull's nose, saying they looked similar, but he was not sure if the bull is Aiai.
The prosecutor remanded the bull to Peng's custody, saying further investigation is needed before he can determine whose claim is correct.

A local lawyer said that even if the bull in dispute is the calf stolen from Peng, its current owner who bought it legitimately would get compensation for losing the bull under existing law. Only those who buy stolen goods with knowledge that they are illegal will not be protected.
That means Peng still have to pay damages to the bull's current owner before he can get back his Aiai.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEAVING NUCLEAR WASTE TO NEXT GENERATION A SERIOUS MATTER: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said that the establishment of a nuclear-free homeland is his lifelong goal and leaving behind nuclear waste for future generations is a serious moral issue.

The president made the remarks on his Web site which appears every Thursday. He spoke of his encounter with a courageous teenager, Hsieh Wen-lung, of the Tao tribe, when he received representatives from an international children's human rights summit in April 2002.

The 16-year-old Hsieh came forward to urge the president to remove the low-radioactive wastes currently stored on Orchid Island, and conveyed a letter of petition, which impressed him tremendously, Chen said.
The president said that he returned the letter to Hsieh after carefully reading it, saying that his lifelong goal will be to establish a nuclear-free homeland.

The president said, "One should not think of the convenience of the next 20 or 30 years and leave the nuclear waste to the next generation, " adding that this would be a "very serious moral question."
In answer to a letter to his Web site, the president also urged the public to participate actively in a global campaign on Sept. 20 to clean up the world.

The letter, written by "David, " said that Taiwan is very beautiful, but when one looks around, a person only sees the dirty and chaotic sights. He suggested that the president set a "national clean-up day."

The president responded by saying that Taiwan people are not without respect for public order, citing that there is no graffiti either in or outside Taipei rapid transit stations and the implementation of rules for no dumping of garbage on grounds in Taipei as examples.

The president said that spending 1,000 hours to do good is not as good as 1,000 people spending an hour doing something good, which will help society more, and this is the reason why he set May 20 as "Taiwan Volunteer Day, " and set "volunteer Taiwan " as a social reform movement.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO ASSIST IN SEARCH FOR MISSING FISHING BOAT CREW

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said Thursday it will continue to assist in the search for crew members of a Taiwan fishing boat which was discovered stranded off a port near the Indonesian island of Java a day earlier.

The COA's Fishery Administration said it has asked Indonesian authorities to help search for the nine crew members aboard the "Chanchengchung" fishing vessel which was found aground off Sullivan Port in Java Wednesday after having lost contact for more than two weeks.

The vessel left Tungkang in southern Taiwan June 19, with three Taiwan crew members as well as two mainland and four Indonesian fishery workers on board. The families of the ship's Taiwan crewmen reported to fishery authorities Aug. 2 that they had lost radio contact July 31. According to the report, the ship was operating in waters east of Guam when it made last contact.
With the assistance of Indonesian authorities, the ship was discovered Wednesday off Sullivan Port, but none of its crew and fish catch were aboard.
The fishery administration said the incident might have been caused by three possible scenarios -- encountering a natural disaster, or being robbed by pirates or a crew mutiny.
Sha Chih-yi, deputy chief of the Fishery Administration, said the most urgent task at the moment is to locate all crew members for questioning.

Sha refrained from making any comments on media reports that the incident might be related to the hiring of Indonesian sailors. But he acknowledged that management of foreign crew members has become a tough issue.

With fewer Taiwan people willing to work aboard fishing boats, local shipowners have been forced to hire mainland or foreign sailors. Sha said the government will review the current policy on employment of foreign fishery workers and will open more leadership training programs for local fishing boats skippers or captains to cope with the new situation.
Since May 2002, the skippers and first engineers aboard two Taiwan fishing boats have been killed by their Indonesian crew members.

Local shipowners have been forced to hire Indonesian sailors after mainland China banned exports of fishery workers to Taiwan last February. Local skippers dislike employing Vietnamese workers because they were allegedly lazy and inferior in fishing skills. Philippine sailors were also unwelcome as they were prone to brawling after drinking.

As Taiwan has agreed to improving treatment for mainland fishery workers, mainland Chinese authorities have invited local fishery associations to visit the mainland in the near future to discuss manpower export issues.

Local shipowners like to hire mainland workers because they speak the same language and have a common cultural background. "We hope the mainland export ban can be lifted as early as possible, " a Tungkang fishery association executive said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S OPTICAL COMMUNICATION INDUSTRY PROMISING

TEXT.P: The optical communication industry has become a rising star in Taiwan, with its production expected to reach NT$40 billion (US$1.16 billion) in 2008, accounting for 40 percent of global production.

Liu Jung-sheng, director of the opto-electronics and systems laboratories under the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) , made the remarks in an international optical communication forum held in Taipei Thursday, in which about 100 experts, scholars and government officials from around the world attended.

Liu noted that in the past five years, domestic optical communication firms have been focusing on the production of passive devices, and until the last two or three years they have made considerable progress in active devices.

However, Liu added, their products were mainly for original equipment manufacture (OEM), and crucial components still depended on imports. Liu urged domestic manufacturers to develop high-end products, such as laser diodes and receivers, to sharpen their competitiveness.

Liu, who is also president of the Taiwan Optical Communication Industry Alliance, noted that the world optical communication market is reviving, with many orders flowing into Asia in search of suppliers, and Taiwan manufacturers are well prepared to capitalize on opportunities offered by its neighboring countries like Japan, India and mainland China.

An expert from mainland China said that the optical communication related industries in mainland China are growing considerably thanks to the promotion of the government; however, there still remains much space for the improvement of some technologies. He urged the industries on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to cooperate to create more trade opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN AID GIVEN ACCORDING TO LEGAL PROCEDURES: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said Thursday all of the country's foreign aid is sanctioned by the Legislative Yuan and approved by recipient governments, and is used for infrastructure or other livelihood-related projects.
Chien said the country never gives aid to foreign individuals or political parties.

In case of Costa Rica, whose president, Abel Pacheco, was reported to have been given a political donation of US$500,000 from Taiwan during his 2002 campaign, Chien said Taiwan is currently helping the country to build a bridge and a highway.

He made the comment after La Nacion, a newspaper in San Jose, Costa Rica, reported Pacheco's alleged mysterious political donations from Taiwan Wednesday when he was in Taiwan for a summit on Thursday between leaders of the Republic of China and its Central American allies.
Costa Rica's legislature is looking into Pacheco's receipt of foreign funds, which are forbidden by law, according to La Nacion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SEEKS CLOSER TIES WITH CENTRAL AMERICAN, CARIBBEAN ALLIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian sought to build closer ties with the Republic of China's diplomatic partners in Central America and the Caribbean Thursday, asking allies in the region to help Taiwan join regional groups in bilateral cooperation to explore the world market.

Chen made the call at the Fourth Summit of the Heads of States and Governments of the ROC, Central America, the Dominican Republic and Belize, which lasted through the day. Presidents, envoys and ranking officials from Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, Panama, the Dominican Republic and Belize took part in the event -- the largest ever sponsored by the grouping to date.
Chen said Taiwan hopes very much to enter the System of Central American Integration as a non-regional member and become a dialogue partner at the planned American free trade agreement area.

Challenged by fierce competition from across the globe, the president said Taiwan has been relentless in seeking globalization by taking part in international and regional organizations, including those based in Central and South America which are of vital importance to Taiwan.

In a bid to boost trade and commercial relations with friendly countries in that part of the world, the ROC government has spared no effort to sponsor investment seminars and provide loans as well as securing legal incentives and encouraging Taiwan businesses to invest there, he said, claiming that all the measures have noticeably paid off.

For instance, exports of seven Central American countries and the Dominican Republic to Taiwan in 2002 rose by 29 percent compared to the 2001 level, while Taiwan investments in those countries have totaled more than US$1.4 billion as of the end of June this year, an indication that two-way links have solidified in recent years, he said.

Looking to the future, Chen said Taiwan is willing to share its development experience with those countries and expressed the hope that more business alliances could be set up, both for the government and private sectors, between the two sides to create a mutually beneficial "win-win" relationship.

With the help and assistance of diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean, Taiwan sincerely hopes to become a non-regional member of the System of Central American Integration and a dialogue partner of the proposed American free trade agreement area, which is slated to take shape in 2005, Chen reiterated.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BENEFIT FROM U. S. ECONOMIC RECOVERY: GERMAN ECONOMIST

TEXT.P: Taiwan will benefit a great deal from an economic recovery in the United States, and the country's economic growth rate is expected to reach 4 percent for this year and 6 percent for 2004, a high-profile economist from Europe said Thursday in Taipei.

Norbert Walter, chief economist of Deutsche Bank Group, Germany made the comments while giving a key-note speech on global economic recovery at a seminar sponsored by the European Chamber of Commerce in Taipei.

The current economic rebound in the United States will persist until November next year for President George W. Bush to seek re-election, Walter predicted, claiming that Taiwan, a major outsource of the U. S. information industry, will also "go with the tide."

Taiwan will secure a 4 percent economic growth rate for this year, while the ratio for 2004 will hit 6 percent, he forecast, adding that Asian economies, including mainland China, will be the leading engine behind the global economic upturn. Before traveling to Taiwan, Walter also visited mainland China and Hong Kong.

Commenting on the problem of a stronger renminbi, mainland China's currency, Walter ruled out such a possibility over the next year on the grounds that the new Beijing leadership will try to stabilize its job market and achieve an 8 percent economic growth rate by maintaining the value of its currency at its current level.
However, he pointed out that the renminbi must be freely convertible should mainland China wish to become a world power.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, CENTRAL AMERICAN LEADERS PLEDGE TO FURTHER PROMOTE COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Leaders of the Republic of China and Central American nations pledged Thursday to further promote bilateral and multilateral cooperation after concluding a one-day summit in Taipei.

In a joint communique issued following the meeting, ROC and Central American heads of states and governments said that they discussed and exchanged opinions on various topics of mutual concern during the gathering and pledged to continue to promote the bilateral and multilateral relations and friendship based on existing foundations.

Leaders of the Central American nations praised ROC President Chen Shui-bian's government for political, economic and social development successes and in containing severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) . They reiterated their countries' support for the ROC's bid to join international organizations, particularly the World Health Organization.

Witnessing the signing of a free trade agreement between the ROC and Panama, the ROC and Central American leaders expressed their willingness to start negotiations at an opportune moment for signing similar accords.

The Central American nations also recognized the ROC's participation and cooperation in regional development and integration programs and agreed on expanding their roles in the regional development as members of the Central American Integration System.

For his part, ROC President Chen promised to continue to encourage Taiwan enterprises to do business with and make investments in Central America and the Caribbean area. He also thanked the ROC's Central American allies for their support in the international arena, including the ROC's success in joining the World Trade Organization.
Also, the ROC and Central American leaders condemned Tuesday's terrorist attack against the United Nations office in Baghdad and expressed sympathy for the victims and their families.

Participants of the meeting were Chen, Prime Minister of Belize Said Musa, Costa Rican President Abel Pacheco de la Espriella, President of El Salvador Francisco Flores, Guatemalan President Alfonso Portillo, Nicaraguan President Enrique Bolanos, Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso and Vice President of the Dominican Republic Alberto Diaz Lobo.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60 PERCENT OF TAIWAN PEOPLE SUPPORT DIRECT TRANSPORT LINKS WITH MAINLAND

TEXT.P: A Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) survey released Thursday showed that almost 60 percent of Taiwan people support direct transportation links with mainland China.

The telephone survey conducted Aug. 18-19 followed the recent remarks by President Chen Shui-bian that his administration will promote the opening of direct cross-strait transportation links under a three-stage program by the end of next year.
The survey, queried 860 adults around Taiwan, had a margin of error of 3.4 percent.

A total of 57 percent said they are afraid that direct transportation links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait may jeopardize the island's security, while 34 percent said they are not worried.
Fifty two percent said that direct transportation ties will rev up Taiwan's economy, while 34 percent said they do not think so.

On Chen's statement that there is one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait regarding the status of relations between Taiwan and mainland China, 57 percent said they agreed with it, while 26 percent said no.

Meanwhile, the survey also showed that after Chen's remarks on opening direct transport links with mainland China, the popularity between Chen and the presidential election ticket of opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chen and People First Party Chairman James Soong would be equal, making next year's presidential election a neck-to-neck race.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AND PANAMA SIGN FREE TRADE AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian signed a free trade agreement with visiting Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso Thursday.
Emerging from a summit between Chen and his counterparts of the country's eight Central American allies, both Chen and Moscoso put their names on the agreement in a brief ceremony.

Noting that the pact is the second of its kind signed by her after she took office, Moscoso said the agreement opens a new chapter in bilateral ties and cements the long-standing economic and trade exchanges between Taiwan and Panama.

She said the agreement which provides for a 95 percent cut in tariffs on goods from each nation over the next 10 years will boost two-way trade and give Panama a valuable access to the Asia market through Taiwan.
It also serves as an example for Panama in future negotiations with other countries on free trade pacts.
For his part, Chen said the agreement is significant for his country as it is the first free trade pact ever signed by the Republic of China.
He urged other Central American states to follow Panama's lead in forming free trade agreements with Taiwan, adding that his country is more than willing to become their gateway to the Asia market.

In addition to Chen and Moscoso, Thursday's summit brought together El Salvador President Francisco Flores, Guatemala President Alfonso Portillo, Costa Rica President Abel Pacheco, Nicaragua President Enrique Bolanos, Belize Prime Minister Said Musa, Honduras Vice President Alberto Diaz and Secretary-General to the president of the Dominican Republic, Sergio Grullo.

In a related development Thursday, Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long said the free trade pact with Panama not only will give Taiwan a valuable trade bridgehead in the Americas but also will prompt other countries to talk with Taiwan on similar agreements.

Panama, on the crossroads of the Americas, is set to become a member of the American Free Trade Zone in 2005. ROC's free trade with Panama will provide Taiwan businessmen a strategic highland in this central American state from which to make forays into both north and south America, Chen said.

Furthermore, the favorable treatment Taiwan grants to Panama in the agreement will certainly drive other countries which used to shun Taiwan for fear of offending Beijing into negotiating with Taipei.
The vice minister said it will open the door to more similar pacts for Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RECEIVES EXPORT ORDERS WITH RECORD HIGH VALUE IN JULY

TEXT.P: Taiwan received export orders worth US$14.5 billion in July, an increase of 14.83 percent over the previous year and a monthly record, according to statistics released Thursday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
MOEA officials attributed the rapid growth to the global economic recovery, the end of the United States-led war in Iraq and the containment of severe acute respiratory syndrome outbreaks.

The orders mainly came from the United States, Hong Kong, Japan and Europe with products of the information industry, telecommunications, electronics and transportation equipment enjoying the largest growth rates, the officials said.
At the same time, they added, the manufacturing sector's production index increased to 139.06, hitting a monthly record.
In the first seven months of this year, Taiwan received a total of US$ 93.21 billion in export orders, up US$7.96 billion or 9.33 percent on a year-to-year basis, the statistics showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: SYMPOSIUM SET FOR STRATEGIC COOPERATION AMONG JAPAN, U.S., AND TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A symposium organized to explore the ways for strategic cooperation among Japan, the United States and Taiwan is set to begin in Washington, D.C., Thursday, according to Taiwan Thinktank, the local co-organizer of the symposium.
In the three-day symposium, attendants will review the political situations in the three countries, and work out recommendations on ways of strategic cooperation among them.

Notable among the attendants of the symposium are June Dreyer, professor of the University of Miami, Arthur Waldron, former director of Asian Studies under the American Enterprise Institute, and John Tkacik, a research fellow at the Heritage.
This is the third round of talks under a two-year program organized by the Heritage Foundation in Washington, Okazaki Research Institute in Tokyo and Taiwan Thinktank in Taipei.
Taipei played host to the second round of talks in March, and is expected to hold the fourth round early next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 22, or the 25th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1834: Samuel Pierpoint Langley, American astronomer and aviation pioneer, is born. He built the first successful heavier-than-air flying machines in 1896.
1849: Amaral, the Portuguese governor of Macao, is assassinated for practicing anti-Chinese politics.
1910: Korea is formally annexed by Japan after five years as a Japanese protectorate.
1911: Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa, one of the world's most famous paintings, is stolen from the Louvre in Paris. It was returned two years later.
1919: Some 5,000 Jews are massacred in the Ukraine.
1932: Japanese troops attack Jehol in northern China.
1937: The Chinese Communist Party issues a statement calling on the people to obey the National government and join the War of Resistance Against Japan, and changes its "Red Army" into the Eighth Army.
1941: German troops reach the outskirts of Leningrad.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States for a visit at the invitation of President Franklin D. Roosevelt. FDR announced on March 30 the establishment of the Pacific War Council in Washington, comprised of China, the United States, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Australia, Canada and the Netherlands.
1968: Warsaw Pact tanks enter Prague, the Czech capital, to crush the first flowering of Alexander Dubcek's reforms.
1973: Henry Kissinger is named U.S. secretary of state, succeeding William Rogers.
1981: A Boeing 737 passenger plane owned by the Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes near Miaoli in central Taiwan, killing all 110 people aboard.
1983: China Airlines suspends its CI811 flight to Manila on orders of the Philippine civil aviation authorities. Manila had warned international airlines not to allow opposition leader Benigno Aquino to board their aircraft for a return to the Philippines on the grounds that he did not have legal travel papers.
Aquino was gunned down on Aug. 21 while soldiers were escorting him from his China Airlines flight from Taipei upon his return to Manila after three years of self-exile in the United States.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the appointment by President Chiang Ching-kuo of Ronald H. C. Ho (Ho Hsien-chung) as the new finance political vice minister.
1985: A British Airtour Boeing 747 bound for Corfu catches fire at Manchester Airport shortly after engine failure had forced the pilot to abandon the takeoff. The fire killed 54 people aboard.
1986: Francisco Zepeda Andino, the new Honduran ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1986: Wang Han successfully swims across the Strait of Gibraltar, becoming the first Chinese person to do so.
1986: Typhoon Wayne blasts across central and southern Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu), killing or injuring 256 people and causing property losses estimated at NT$11.5 billion. The typhoon damage is the heaviest in the past twenty years. The Executive Yuan allocates NT$1 billion to help victims.
1995: The KMT convenes its 14th National Congress and Lee Teng-hui, party chairman, announces he will seek the party's presidential nomination. Lin Yang-kang, a KMT vice chairman, declares his intention not to seek the party's nomination and to instead run as an independent.
1996: The 61-nation Conference on Disarmament in Geneva ends in failure after India blocked an agreement on a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.
1999: A China Airlines passenger plane with 315 on board crash-lands at Chek Lap Kok airport in Hong Kong during a typhoon, killing two and injuring 211.
2000: Opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong says that it is still too early to talk about overhauling the Guidelines for National Unification as the government has yet to demonstrate consistency regarding its cross-strait policies.
2000: Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore decorades visiting ROC President Chen Shui-bian with the Order of Grande Croix in recognition of his contribution to promoting bilateral ties.
2001: Republic of China Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya, along with a 20-strong delegation, attends the 2001 Women's Leaders Meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Beijing.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If another man succeeds through one effort, use a hundred efforts. If another man succeeds though ten efforts, use a thousand efforts. Let a man really proceed in this manner, and, though dull, he will surely become intelligent; though weak, he will surely become strong."

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON KROVANH APPROACHING BASHI CHANNEL

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau issued a typhoon warning Friday morning, saying that Typhoon Krovanh is approaching the Bashi Channel from an area near the Luzon island of the Philippines.
Krovanh was located about 580 kilometers southeast of Oluanpi at the southern tip of Taiwan at 8 a.m. Friday. It is moving west at 22 kilometers per hour.
The CWB said Krovanh is unlikely to hit Taiwan directly. However, it may bring strong winds to the Bashi Channel and heavy rains to the eastern and southern parts of Taiwan. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S DEPOSIT INSURANCE CORP. SIGNS MOU WITH KOREAN COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Central Deposit Insurance Corp. (CDIC) signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with its South Korean counterpart Friday to establish formal cooperative ties.
Tsay Chin-tsair, chairman of the CDIC, and Yon Won-Young, chairman and CEO of the Korea Asset Management Corporation (KAMCO) , signed the MOU on behalf of their respective institutions.

ROC Vice Finance Minister Chang Hsiu-lien, in witnessing the signing ceremony, said that South Korea's achievement in addressing its non-performing loans problem in its financial sector has won world recognition, adding that "Taiwan can learn from South Korea's experience."

Tsay noted that South Korea suffered a deterioration in both its financial and corporate sectors during the Asian financial crisis of 1997. As a result, the amount of non-performing loans of financial institutions in the country rose sharply. In order to restore financial stability, the KAMCO was reorganized in 1997 and put in charge of handling the non-performing loans of South Korean banks.

Since then, the KAMCO has adopted aggressive and cutting edge techniques in the overall planning and operation of its Non-Performing Asset Fund in order to effectively resolve the non-performing loan problem of financial institutions and to promote the sound operations of the country's financial institutions and companies, Tsay added.

Tsay said that as state-owned enterprises, the CDIC and KAMCO have the mission of upholding financial stability and promoting the healthy development of the financial sectors of their respective countries.

He said that the signing of the MOU will expand cooperation and exchanges between the two sides in carrying out their mission. In the future, the two sides will share their expertise and experience in order to raise the efficiency of their operations, he added.
Such exchanges will be facilitated by the appointing of official contact representatives and by the arranging of meetings, training programs, and information personnel exchanges, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES UP BY 34.76 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Friday, with the weighted index moving up 34.76 points to close at 5,646.62.
Market turnover amounted to NT$135.3 billion (US$3.96 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and then fluctuated on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 34.76 points to close at 5,646.62.
The bourse opened at 5,648.94 and fluctuated between 5,692.93 and 5,629.2 during trading.

A total of 5.63 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$135.3 billion (US$3.96 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 4.31 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$105.78 billion (US$3.09 billion).

Two of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with textile issues moving down the most at 0.2 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 0.1 percent. Electrical stocks remained unchanged.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 4 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 2.9 percent, cement stocks at 1.3 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.1 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 332 to 323, with 125 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NICARAGUAN PRESIDENT PRESENTED WITH HONORARY DOCTORAL DEGREE

TEXT.P: Nanhua University conferred an honorary doctoral degree in management science on visiting Nicaraguan President Enrique Bolanos Friday in recognition of his achievements in promoting his country's development through entrepreneurship.

The conferment was held at the Fokuangshan Buddhist group's Chin Kuang Ming Temple in Taipei County's Sanhsia township. A traditional Confucianist ritual dance was performed in the ceremony to signify Oriental cultural spirit.

Nanhua University President Chen Miao-sheng said Bolanos had accumulated rich business management experience prior to joining politics. Since assuming his current post, Bolanos has launched many development projects to boost Nicaragua's economic growth.

Under Bolanos' leadership, Chen said, Nicaragua has enjoyed political stability and maintained friendly relations with Taiwan. "Therefore, we decided to present Bolanos with an honorary doctoral degree, " he added.

Buddhist Master Hsin Yun, founder of Nanhua University in Chiayi County in southern Taiwan, said he hopes Taiwan and Nicaragua will increase their cultural and tourist exchanges to enhance mutual understanding and cooperation in various fields.

For his part, Bolanos said it's a great honor for him to receive the honorary academic degree from Nanhua University. Noting that diligence and perseverance have been key to Taiwan's economic success, Bolanos said Nicaragua will learn from Taiwan's experience in economic development. He also pledged to lead Nicaragua to prosperity through the entrepreneurial spirit.

Bolanos arrived in Taipei Wednesday to attend the fourth summit meeting of the heads of state of the ROC and its allies in Central America and the Caribbean. Bolanos had been chief executive officer of many major Nicaraguan companies before joining politics in 1995. He took office in January 2002, and his term will expire in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONTE JADE ASSOCIATION OF TAIWAN HOLDS ANNUAL MEETING

TEXT.P: Executives of science and technology firms as well as experts in legal and financial affairs attended the annual meeting of the Monte Jade Science and Technology Association of Taiwan Friday at the Grand Hyatt Taipei.

As the role of the IT (information technology) industry was chosen as the theme for this year's meeting, the organizer arranged two key-note speeches on the inter-relations between venture capital and IT industry development.

The Monte Jade was established by 36 Chinese-American executives in the San Francisco Bay Area in 1989 for the promotion of entrepreneurial practice in science and technology. Over the past decade, with increasing Chinese-American professionals joining the organization, several Monte Jade associations have been set up in the United States, Canada and Taiwan.

The Taiwan chapter was set up in 2001, with the participation of executives from high-tech corporations, investment banks as well as media organizations. In the past two years, the Taiwan chapter has sponsored a series of seminars, organized overseas business trips, and put out publications on advanced technologies.

DOC.HEADLINE: KROVANH BECOMES MEDIUM TYPHOON MOVING TOWARD BASHI CHANNEL

TEXT.P: Typhoon Krovanh, located at 500 kilometers southeast of Oluanpi at the southern tip of Taiwan as of 11:30 a.m. Friday, has become medium typhoon moving toward Bashi Channel from the Philippines, the Central Weather Bureau said.
The typhoon is moving west at 22 kilometers per hour. Ships sailing in the Bashi Channel and the South China Sea should be cautious against strong winds, the CWB said.
It is unlikely to hit Taiwan directly, but may bring heavy rains to southern and eastern Taiwan, it added. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MIXED ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market reported mixed results on Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved up 2 points to close at 5,613, with 35,158 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October lost 6 points to finish at 5,585, with 3 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,611 for September, 5,624 for October, 5,570 for December, 5,520 for March, and 5,612 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also reported mixed results.
September TE futures fell 0.2 points to close at 253.2, with 4,110 contract transactions, while October TE futures gained 4.2 points to finish at 253, with 6 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
September TF futures moved up 15.2 points to close at 737, with 5,923 contract transactions, while October TF futures rose 15.4 points to finish at 740, with 35 contracts traded.
December TF futures gained 15 points to close at 740, with 2 contract transactions, while March TF futures surged 21.6 points to finish at 740, with 4 contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL CHILDREN'S FILM FESTIVAL KICKS OFF IN ILAN

TEXT.P: The Ilan County Government-sponsored 2003 International Children's Film Festival, the first children's film festival ever to be held in Taiwan, kicked off in Ilan Friday.

To give the festival more publicity, the county government held a press conference at the opening of the festival, inviting Chiu Li-wei, director of the animated film "Dr. Torrado" to explain the significance and influence of children's films on children.

Ilan County Magistrate Liu Shou-cheng and seed teachers who have been trained in animated film production will help children to make their own animation and act out scenes from "Badu's Homework, " the opening film of the festival.

"Badu's Homework," directed by Cheng Wen-tang, was chosen as the best picture at the 2003 Taipei Film Festival. It is a fairy-tale story told through the eyes of aboriginal children. The theme is of an aboriginal culture gradually eroded by modern life.

The festival, which features movies and animation from eight countries--Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, Iran, the Czech Republic, Denmark, the United States and France--is set to run through Aug. 30. (by Nocturne Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO SET UP IMMIGRATION AGENCY SOON

TEXT.P: An association grouping nine Taiwan social welfare organizations suggested on Friday that the government establish an immigration agency as soon as possible.

The Alliance of Fairness and Justice said that in view of Taiwan's declining birth rates and the rapid graying of the island's population, the government should also work out a substantive immigration policy soon.

Alliance officials said that it is estimated that the number of new births in Taiwan for this year will not exceed 220,000, marking the lowest figure in half a decade. The forecasted figure is one-third less than that for 1997, and nearly 50 percent less than the number of annual births seen during the 1960s.

They added that it is estimated that the birth rate will be less than 1 percent for this year, or an average of 1.3 births per couple, even lower than the average of 1.6 birth per couple for industrialized countries.

With declining birth rates in Taiwan, the ratio of senior citizens has risen rapidly, the officials said, citing statistics by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) to back up their claims.
The CEPD estimated that by 2007, senior citizens will account for 10 percent of the total population, and by 2025, the ratio will increase to 20 percent, the alliance officials added.
The officials said that compared with other countries, the speed of graying in Taiwan is the fastest in the world.

The officials suggested that the government work out a comprehensive immigration policy, adding that Taiwan already has a lot of women from mainland China and Southeast Asian nations marrying Taiwan men.

Figures released by the Ministry of the Interior showed that there are around 250,000 foreign spouses of Taiwan residents, and that children born to foreign spouses accounted for over 12 percent of all new births in Taiwan last year, they added.

The officials pointed out that the government has viewed the newly-arrived women as the responsibility of the individual families and has refused to address the issue of the women's civil rights. The related government agencies have only had contingency plans to deal with unexpected situations, they added.

The officials urged the government to establish an immigration agency and work out a substantial immigration policy soon to address and protect the work, education and social welfare rights of the new arrivals.

The officials also urged the Taiwan people not to look down on or view with suspicion the new arrivals after they obtain their residential status in Taiwan, and to give Taiwan a new color of peace, tolerance and pluralism. They added that the new arrivals will help alleviate the problem of Taiwan's graying population.

The alliance, which was formed Aug. 10, is also known as the "pan-purple alliance" to distinguish itself from the "pan-green" camp of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER HEADS TO U.S. FOR INVESTMENT PROMOTION TRIP
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Lin Chuan, accompanied by a group of executives from banking institutions and electronics companies, is scheduled to arrive in New York Friday for a week-long investment promotion trip.
Lin and the business executives will meet with prospective investors in the "2003 Taiwan Investment Forum" to be held in New York on Aug. 26.

Before departing for the United States, the minister told media in Taipei that the group would attend two investment forums, in New York and Boston, to give briefings to representatives from financial establishments and insurance companies on the liberalization and internationalization of Taiwan's capital market.

Lin's itinerary while in New York also includes witnessing the signing of a memorandum of understanding (MOU) between the Taiwan Securities Central Depository Co. and the U.S. Depository Trust Co., attending a press conference jointly hosted by the Central Reinsurance Corp. of Taiwan and the global reinsurer Swiss Re, and visiting factories of the Formosa Plastics Corp.

The 46-member investment promotion group is made up of executives from several financial management companies, including the Cathay Group, the Chinatrust Group, the China Development Group, as well as securities houses, and manufacturers of computers, optoelectronic products and telecommunication service providers.
The group is scheduled to return to Taiwan Aug. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, EL SALVADOR SIGN COOPERATION AGREEMENT TO REDRESS TRADE IMBALANCE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China signed a cooperation agreement with El Salvador Friday, pledging to gradually redress the central American nation's trade deficit with the ROC.

Hsu Chi-jen, chairman of the semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), signed the agreement with El Salvador Minister of Foreign Affairs Maria Eugenia Brizuela de Avila, on behalf of their respective countries.

CETRA officials said that in view of the trade surpluses enjoyed over a long period of time by Taiwan with the five Central American countries, the ROC government began an action plan of promoting exports to Taiwan by the five nations, and promoting investment in the countries by Taiwan manufacturers to redress the trade imbalances.

The officials noted that after the launch of the plan, the ROC's exports to El Salvador totaled US$70.78 million for 2001, down from US$87.66 million for 2000, while imports into Taiwan from El Salvador increased from US$532,000 in 2000 to US$1,177,000 in 2001.

The officials said that after the signing of the agreement, the CETRA will work closely with the economic unit of the Foreign Ministry of El Salvador, exchanging trade delegations, assisting Taiwan manufacturers to invest in El Salvador and encouraging them to export their products back to Taiwan to help redress the trade imbalance.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAPUA NEW GUINEA HONORARY CONSULATE-GENERAL OPENS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Papua New Guinea (PNG) opened an honorary consulate-general in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung Friday to further promote bilateral relations, particularly in fishery cooperation.

Papua New Guinea Honorary Consul-General Tsai Ting-pang presided over the inaugural ceremony, with the participation of representatives from the PNG fishery community, Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, opposition Kuomintang Kaohsiung Chapter Director Lin Hsiang-nung and executives of major Kaohsiung fishery groups.

Tsai, president of the Kaohsiung Fishery Association and a former National Assembly member, said Papua New Guinea appointed him as a consul-general in Taiwan in May this year and that he has received a certificate from the ROC's Ministry of Foreign Affairs to perform consular duties on the island.
During his trip to the South Pacific island nation in July, Tsai said he had met with PNG Prime Minister Michael Somare for wide-ranging talks.

"Somare told me that his country appreciates the ROC's longtime assistance, particularly the dispatch of a technical mission to assist in Papua New Guinea's fishery industry development, " he recalled.

Tsai said the most encouraging result of his visit was that PNG has agreed to directly print its visa stamps on ROC passports, instead of on an additional paper attached to the passports as in the past because of the absence of formal diplomatic ties. Moreover, he said, the PNG visa stamps will identify Taipei, Taiwan as the issuing place.

Papua New Guinea is a major purse seine fishing ground for Kaohsiung-based deep-sea fishing vessels. More than 40 large purse seine fishing vessels from Kaohsiung are currently operating in PNG waters, with tuna, spearfish and bonito as their main catch.
The Taiwan Tuna Fishing Industry Association signed a fishery cooperative agreement with PNG in February 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DECLINES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar declined against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, giving up NT$0.021 to close at NT$34.217.
A total of US$1.01 billion changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$34.253 and was traded between NT$34.172 and NT$34.296.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION ASKS GOVERNMENT TO REMAIN NEUTRAL IN PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan caucuses of the major opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party Friday urged the government to remain neutral in presidential election affairs.
Spokesmen of the two caucuses said in two separate news conferences that the government should not use public resources and the administrative system to help any candidates in elections.

They made the statements after news media reported that Liu Shih-fang, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, has asked government agencies to submit a plan in three weeks to help the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) win the presidential election in March, 2004.
A spokesman for the DPP caucus said Liu did not do anything wrong, because it is natural for a member to campaign for his party after office hours. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC TO ASK PASSENGERS FROM CANADA TO UNDERGO SELF-HEALTH MANAGEMENT

TEXT.P: The ROC's Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health (DOH) said Friday it has come up with a plan to ask arrivals from Canada to undergo self-health management to prevent a recurrence of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).

The CDC made the remarks amid reports that cluster transmissions of a SARS-like disease have occurred at a nursing home in Vancouver. Although the United Nations has yet to confirm whether the outbreak is SARS-related, the new development has caused international concern.
CDC Deputy Director Shih Wen-yi said Taiwan must heighten its alert and adopt appropriate precautionary measures to ward off any possible import of SARS.
"We have presented a preventive measures initiative to the DOH for approval, " Shih said, adding that the date for implementing the measures will be decided in the next few days.

According to the CDC proposal, arrivals from Canada will be asked to take their own temperatures daily. Should they fall ill during a specified period of time, they should go to a designated fever screening center to receive treatment.

At the moment, arrivals from mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau have been subject to such requirements. "We plan to impose similar requirements to arrivals from Canada as part of drive to prevent SARS from returning to Taiwan," Shih said.
Mainland China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Toronto were gripped by SARS between March and June this year. Health experts are concerned about a SARS relapse this winter.

Shih said local people intending to visit Canada in the near future should pay attention to their personal hygiene -- wash their hands frequently and avoid unnecessary visits to hospitals or public places during their stay in Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S JOBLESS RATE CLIMBS TO 5.16 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Some 522,000 Taiwan people were jobless in July, accounting for 5.16 percent of the workforce, an increase of 0.07 percent over the previous month, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics of the Executive Yuan said Friday.
The slight increase in jobless rate is attributable to the arrival of 28,000 school graduates to the job market in the month. There are 10.11 million people in the workforce.
The DGBAS predicted that the jobless rate will decline to 4.7 percent in the fourth quarter. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: NICARAGUA PRESIDENT CONFERS MEDAL ON TAIWAN ENTREPRENEUR

TEXT.P: Visiting Nicaragua President Enrique Bolanos conferred a national medal upon Uni-President Enterprises Group Chairman Kao Ching-yen Friday in recognition of Kao's contribution to Nicaragua's economic development and job creation.

Witnessed by the group's executives, Bolanos bestowed the "Knight Medal" -- one of Nicaragua's highest national honors -- on Kao, and asked the Taiwan-based business mogul to help his country seek greater foreign investment and boost employment.
Kao, one of the leading figures of Taiwan's business community, has long been devoted to promoting Taiwan's trade and economic ties with Central and South America.

During his term as chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries from 1994 to 2000, the Uni-President group also helped set up a jeans factory in Nicaragua, providing many job opportunities for local people.
The four-year-old factory in Nicaragua has a capital worth NT$1.2 billion (US$34.8 million) following a capital increment of NT$300 million in July.
Nien Hsing Textile Corp. Chairman Chen Jong-chiu and Shinkong Group Chairman Wu Tung-chin were also awarded the Knight medal by the Nicaragua government.

The Nicaragua president is in Taipei to take part in the Fourth Summit of the Heads of States and Governments of the Republic of China, Central America, the Dominican Republic and Belize, which concluded a day earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONGRATULATES CLOUD GATE DANCE THEATRE ON ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian extended his congratulation Friday to the Cloud Gate Dance Theatre which celebrated its 30th anniversary the previous day.

In his weekly televised broadcast, the president called the dance troupe the pride of Taiwan, and the troupe named most often by his many friends as one of the joyful things which cheer them up when they or their country were feeling down.

He thanked the troupe's many sponsors for keeping the group performing through numerous financial crises over the last three decades, and promised to be a firm supporter for similar artists' performance groups in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-PANAMA DIPLOMATIC TIES REMAIN SOLID: ROC FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Diplomatic ties between the Republic of China and Panama remain solid despite the fact that Beijing has tried every means to hamper their relationship, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Friday.

In the face of relentless meddling from Beijing, the foreign ministry will do its utmost to maintain and explore the ROC's presence in the international community, the spokesman said, pointing to the ROC-Panama free trade agreement inked Thursday and President Chen Shui-bian's upcoming visit to various countries in Central and South America.

The spokesman's remarks came on the heels of Beijing's claim that it will spare no effort to set up full diplomatic links with Panama, and he added that the foreign ministry was not surprised at such rhetoric.

Joseph Wu, deputy secretary-general to the president, commented that two-way relations between Taiwan and Panama are now better than never. Vice President Annette Lu was warmly welcome by Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso during her recent visit to that country, he noted, adding that he now has greater confidence that "it will become easier for Taiwan in the foreign affairs arena."

According to Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien, President Chen was told by Panamanian President Moscoso during a meeting on Friday afternoon that bilateral relations are progressive and sound and that Moscoso also invited Chen to attend the celebration activities of Panama's 100th founding anniversary Nov. 3.
Chien made the remarks after seeing off Nicaragua President Enrique Bolanos and Costa Rican President Abel Pacheco at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

Presidents, envoys and ranking officials from Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, Panama, the Dominican Republic and Belize met in Taipei to take part in the Fourth Summit of the Heads of States and Governments of the ROC, Central America, the Dominican Republic and Belize, which ended Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN RECEIVES EL SALVADORAN COUNTERPART AT PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met his El Salvadoran counterpart Francisco Flores Friday at the Presidential Office, reaffirming the Republic of China's relations and cooperation with El Salvador.

During the meeting, Chen first thanked Flores for his presence in the just-concluded summit of heads of states and governments of the ROC, Central American nations and the Dominican Republic in Taipei and expressed his appreciation for the support El Salvador has extended to the ROC in the international arena.

Chen told his Salvadoran guest that the ROC and El Salvador share the same spirit of potential and unlimited opportunity under adverse circumstances with limited resources. It is called in Taiwan "the spirit of the sons of Taiwan," he added.

Chen also praised the courage and tenacity demonstrated by the El Salvadoran people in braving adversity, particularly in reconstructing the nation in the aftermath of two devastating earthquakes that hit El Salvador over the past years.

El Salvador was not knocked down by the earthquakes but stood firm and was back to normal in the shortest period possible after the disasters, Chen noted, adding that it represents the spirit of not abandoning the opportunity of success, which is similar to "the spirit of the sons of Taiwan."

In a ceremony held prior to the meeting, Chen conferred the order of Brilliant Star with Special Cordon on El Salvadoran first lady Lourdes Rodriquez de Flores in recognition of her contributions to the promotion of ROC-El Salvador relations and friendship.
In return, President Flores bestowed the order of Libertador de los Esclavos Jose Simeon Canas on ROC first lady Wu Shu-chen on the same occasion.
Flores reiterated El Salvador's friendship with and support for the ROC and assured Taiwan that the relations between the two nations will be further strengthened.
He also praised the ROC for the progress it has made in Taiwan in all aspects, affirming that it can serve as an example for El Salvador.

On hand at the meeting were also ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien, Secretary-General of the Presidential Office Chiou I-jen, Minister of the Department of Health Chen Chien-jen, El Salvadoran Foreign Minister Maria Eugenia Brizuela de Avila and Minister of Economic Affairs Miguel Ernesto Lacayo.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN STRESSES SUSTAINABILITY IN FUTURE POLICY PLANNING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday sustainable development will be the top guiding principle for Taiwan's future policy planning and infrastructure construction.

Chen made the remarks at the opening of the 2003 Science Week program, organized by the National Science Council to promote scientific education and research. This year's program focuses on challenges to Taiwan's sustainable development.

Noting that Taiwan's beautiful natural environment has been seriously polluted over the past decades due to poor planning and unscrupulous exploitation by some business groups, Chen said such practices must be stopped and remedy measures should be taken to preserve the island's natural ecology.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL DEFENDS PURCHASING AIRCRAFT ENGINES FROM GENERAL ELECTRIC

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL), Taiwan's largest air carrier, reiterated Friday that its decision to purchase engines for its 18 newly ordered aircraft from General Electric (GE) was purely based on commercial considerations.
CAL was responding to a protest by the European Union aimed at CAL for its failure to purchase engines from Rolls Royce of Britain, an E.U. member state.

CAL said it had conducted comprehensive evaluations and extensive discussions with the three competitors -- GE, Pratt & Whitney and Rolls Royce -- before coming to a final conclusion earlier this month.
"We believe that the terms offered by GE serve our best interests," a CAL spokesman said. "All three competitors were given a fair opportunity in the negotiation process."

The spokesman stressed that the company has never discriminated against E.U. products. For instance, the airline said it decided to purchase 12 A330-300 jetliners late last year from Airbus, which is jointly invested by four E.U. nations, including Britain.

He pointed out that CAL's latest decision to purchase GE engines for the 12 A330-300 and six Boeing B747-400 jetliners was based on terms of engine quality, price, follow-up maintenance support and technology transfer.
"GE excelled in all categories and provided other benefits, including handling the last B747-200 all-cargo aircraft in our fleet," the spokesman said.

He added that although some CAL departments were in favor of the engine offered by Rolls Royce to be installed on the A330-300s in some assessments, they disagreed with maintenance terms offered by Rolls Royce. "After negotiations, the British company still failed to provide acceptable maintenance terms," he noted.

The spokesman further said that although the U.S. company Pratt & Whitney also failed to secure the contract, it sent a letter to CAL President Wei Hsing-hsiung earlier this week recognizing the fairness in CAL's engine procurement negotiations.
Delivery for the 12 A330-300s and six B747-400s that CAL ordered in late 2002 will begin in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICAN OFFICIAL DENIES ROC GAVE DONATIONS TO PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Costa Rican Vice Foreign Minister Marco Vinicio Vargas denied Friday that Costa Rican President Abel Pacheco received personal political donations from the Republic of China.

Vargas, who accompanied Pacheco on a visit to Taiwan, told a hastily called news conference at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport that ROC aid to Costa Rica was used for construction and that none of it had ever been funnelled to any individuals.
He said he regretted that Costa Rican newspapers published misleading reports saying that Pacheco received US$500,000 from Taiwan during his 2002 presidential campaign.
Vargas held the conference before Pacheco and his entourage boarded a plane and left Taiwan after a one-day summit in Taipei with leaders of the ROC and seven other Central America states.

The La Nacion daily in San Jose, Costa Rica, broke the news about alleged mysterious donations to Pacheco from Taiwan Wednesday when Pacheco was in Taiwan for this summit, to the embarrassment of his host.
ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien categorically denied that the country's foreign aid could ever land in the pockets of any individual or political party.

In a related story Friday, Chien confirmed that ROC Ambassador to San Jose Wang Fei has resigned and will be replaced by former Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Wu Tzu-dan, who serves as chairman in Taipei of the Coordination Council for North American Affairs, a organization set up to deal with the United States after the later switched its diplomatic recognition to Beijing in 1979.
Chien said Wang offered to quit for personal reasons and the personnel change was set in early August.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMICS MINISTER COURTS TAIWAN INVESTMENT TO EL SALVADOR

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu encouraged Taiwan businessmen to invest in El Salvador Friday, citing the country's good location and sound investment climate and the planned American free trade agreement area.

Lin made the call while giving a key-note speech at an investment seminar presided over by Wang Chung-yu, chairman of the Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association. Visiting El Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez and about 100 ranking government officials and business community representatives from the two countries also took part.

Praising El Salvador's diligent workforce and good location, Lin said politics and infrastructure in that country are also sound. He strongly recommended Taiwan companies to consider investing in El Salvador -- one of Taiwan's staunchest diplomatic partners -- especially at a time when the proposed American free trade agreement area is slated to be forged by the end of this year.
El Salvadoran Economics Minister Miguel Ernesto Lacayo also addressed the gathering, providing the attendees with the latest trade information and investment incentives of El Salvador.

According to Lacayo, his country highly welcomes foreign investment in a wide range of sectors, except the small retail and fishing and agricultural sectors, and has devised a set of incentives to protect foreign business interests and boost exports.
Taiwan exports to El Salvador hit US$60.54 million, exceeding that country's exports to Taiwan worth US$9.048 million.

To help Taiwan businesses invest in Central and South American countries maintaining diplomatic relations with Taiwan, the ROC government also offers a string of subsidies and incentives for Taiwan investors willing to operate in that part of the world.

In addition to accords on investment protection and on temporary clearance, Taiwan and El Salvador also are negotiating a free trade agreement in the hope of further enhancing two-way trade and commercial ties.

Presidents, envoys and ranking government officials from Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, Panama, the Dominican Republic and Belize were in Taipei to take part in the Fourth Summit of the Heads of States and Governments of the ROC, Central America, the Dominican Republic and Belize, which wrapped up Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN RECEIVES DOMINICAN REPUBLIC MINISTER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian received visiting Minister of the Presidency of the Dominican Republic Sergio Grullon Friday at the Presidential Office, reaffirming the Republic of China's friendship and cooperation with its Caribbean ally.

Chen first extended a warm welcome to Grullon and thanked him for participating in the just-concluded fourth summit of heads of states and governments of the ROC, Central American nations and the Dominican Republic and Belize in Taipei and asked that his message be relayed to President Rafael Hipolito Mejia.

Chen also thanked the Caribbean nation for the support it has extended to the ROC in the international arena, resisting tremendous pressure imposed by Beijing. He expressed the hope that Santo Domingo will continue to voice support for the ROC's bid to join the United Nations in the upcoming U.N. General Assembly in September.

Prior to the meeting, Grullon conferred the Golden Order of Columbus with Gran Cruz on ROC first lady Wu Shu-chen on behalf of the Dominican government in recognition of her contribution to the promotion of social welfare and democracy.
On receiving the medal, Wu said that it is not only her personal honor but also represents the close relationship between the ROC and the Dominican Republic.
She asked Grullon to convey her gratitude to President Mejia and the Dominican people and expressed the hope that the Dominican first lady will visit Taiwan in the near future.
Grullon assured his host that his country will continue to support the ROC's bid to join the United Nations and other international organizations.
He praised the ROC's progress in all aspects, particularly in the economic field.

Both he and President Mejia have witnessed the way that Taiwan advanced from an agricultural economy to a hi-tech one, Grullon said, noting that he had visited Taiwan twice, in 1979 and 1981, and that President Mejia has visited Taiwan 24 times thus far.
He invited President Chen to visit his country again for further enhancing ties.
