Chen visited Santo Domingo in 2000 in his first overseas trip after assuming the presidency in May of that same year to participate in President Mejia's inauguration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CPI FOR AUGUST REBOUNDS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) stood at 79.07 points for August, a rise of 5.39 points over the year-earlier level and a growth of 1.17 points from July, the results of a survey made public Friday by the Taiwan Research Institute show.

A spokesman for the institute attributed the increase in CPI to a set of incentives unveiled recently by the government, such as President Chen Shui-bian's direct cross-Taiwan Strait transport links proposal, and a rising stock market. He said Taiwan's economy will gradually recover thanks to these stimulus measures.
The telephone survey of 1,104 Taiwan residents aged over 20 was conducted Aug. 16-20 and had a margin of error of 2.9 percent.
Respondents were asked to reply to a questionnaire in respect to six categories, including the timing for buying durable goods and stocks in the coming six months.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LU CALLS FOR DIPLOMATIC FORAYS INTO SOUTH AMERICA

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu called for diplomatic forays into South American Friday, saying that it was a "diplomatic desert" for the Republic of China.

In a news conference called to report her achievements in her just-concluded trip to Paraguay, which is the only South American state recognizing the ROC, Lu said Taiwan should pay more attention to exploring friendships with South American states which are new worlds for Taiwan.
Lu led a 43-member delegation to Asuncion earlier this month to attend the inauguration of President Nicanor Duarte on Aug. 15, and returned to Taiwan Aug. 20.

She boasted about the high-profile reception she received from the host country, including a banquet given by Duarte for the ROC delegation, which was the only delegation out of 95 from around the world to get this honor.

Lu said she was invited to give a speech to the Paraguayan parliament, and that almost all of the parliamentarians were present. The vice president also delivered a speech at National Asuncion University, which has produced 20 Cabinet members.
Noting that the ROC's diplomatic ties with Paraguay date back 46 years, Lu said Taiwan should value its friendship with Paraguay and explore friendships aggressively with countries in South America.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CONFIRMS HE WILL VISIT PANAMA IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian confirmed Friday that he will visit Panama in November to participate in the activities marking the 100th founding anniversary of the Central American nation.

Speaking at a meeting with his Panamanian counterpart Mireya Moscoso at the Presidential Office, Chen said that it is a great honor for him to be invited to participate in the significant celebrations.

He thanked Moscoso for her presence at the just-concluded fourth summit of heads of states and governments of the Republic of China, Central American nations, the Dominican Republic and Belize in Taipei, noting that Moscoso did not participate in the third meeting of its kind held in El Salvador in 2001.
Chen also appreciated the signing of a free trade agreement between the ROC and Panama, noting that it is the first the ROC has ever signed with a foreign country.
Chen assured his guest that his administration will spare no efforts to implement the accord, making it become a model to be followed by others.
Also, he thanked Panama for the support it has extended to the ROC in the international arena.

In response, Moscoso thanked Chen and the ROC government for the assistance it has extended to Panama, noting that the cooperation and mutual support have set a solid foundation for ROC-Panama relations and friendship.
The signing of the ROC-Panama free trade agreement a day earlier will further promote their ties to a higher level, the Panamanian president said.
She expressed the hope that Chen will stay in Panama for more time during his next visit to explore the prosperity and trade opportunities of her country.

On hand at the meeting were also ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien and Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu, Panamanian Foreign Minister Harmodio Arias, Minister of the Interior and Justice Arnulfo Escalona, Minister of Commerce and Industry Joaquin Jacome and Minister of Finance Norberto Delgado.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI WINS ITS FIRST MEDAL IN WORLD UNIVERSITY GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Daegu, South Korea, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan athlete representing Chinese Taipei won a bronze medal Friday in the 22th World University Games being held in South Korea.
Chen Shih-kai won the medal in the men's taekwondo event. It is the first medal Chinese Taipei has won in the games thus far.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC: MAJORITY FEEL IN NO HURRY FOR DIRECT LINKS WITH MAINLAND

TEXT.P: A majority of people believe that there is no hurry to open direct transportation links with the mainland, the mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday.

Citing a survey conducted by National Cheng Chi University, the MAC said more than 52 percent of the people interviewed said the government should "take it easy" when it comes to opening direct links with the mainland.
Those who said "the sooner, the better" accounted for only 28 percent.

Meanwhile, nearly 30 percent of those polled believe the current pace of opening exchanges with the mainland is "just as it should be, " with 20 percent saying "too fast" and 20 percent saying "too slow," the MAC said.

The poll also showed that 32 percent believe developing ties with foreign countries is more important than developing ties with the mainland. That figure is far more than those who believe the opposite and those who said the two are equal in importance.
In case ties with foreign countries strain the island's relations with Beijing, 61 percent said the country should go ahead with efforts to foster ties with foreign countries.

The poll found that 75 percent of the people surveyed oppose Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula for uniting with Taiwan, and more and more people feel Beijing's hostility, with 71 percent, or 6.4 percent higher than the last poll in May, believing that Beijing is hostile towards Taiwan authorities, and 51 percent, or 6.3 percent higher than the last poll, believing that Beijing is hostile toward the Taiwan people.
The poll was conducted Aug. 5-8 by telephone among 1,149 adults in the Taiwan area, with a margin of error of 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN REAFFIRMS ROC FRIENDSHIP WITH GUATEMALA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed Friday the Republic of China's friendship with Guatemala.

In a meeting with his Guatemalan counterpart, Alfonso Portillo, at the Presidential Office, Chen thanked Guatemala for the support it has extended to the ROC in the international arena, just like a faithful friend.

Chen also appreciated his personal friendship forged with Portillo since they met for the first time at the third summit of heads of states and governments of the ROC, Central American nations, the Dominican Republic and Belize in El Salvador in 2001.
Chen noted that he himself and Portillo share many personal characteristics and described Portillo as an honest and faithful friend of the ROC people.
In response, Portillo assured his host that ROC-Guatemala relations will be further strengthened and he will continue to dedicate himself to promoting ties during his present term and afterward.

Also on hand at the meeting was ROC Vice Foreign Minister Francisco Hwang and Secretary-General to the President Chiou I-jen, Guatemalan Foreign Minister Edgar Gutierrez, Secretary to the President Julio Giron and Director of the Information Office of the Presidency Alejandro Perez.

Portillo is in Taiwan for a visit after participating in the fourth summit of the heads of states and governments of the ROC, Central American nations, the Dominican Republic and Belize that wrapped up in Taipei Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 23, or the 26th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1305: Sir William Wallace, Scottish patriot who demanded independence for his country, is hung, drawn and quartered in London.
1754: Louis XVI, king of France at the time of the outbreak of the French Revolution, is born.
1818: The first steamship service opens on the Great Lakes in North America.
1821: Mexico gains its independence.
1912: Gene Kelly, American dancer, choreographer, singer, actor and director, is born. He starred in Hollywood musicals, including "Anchors Aweigh," "Singin' in the Rain" and his "Invitation to Dance."
1914: Japan declares war on Germany.
1926: Screen actor Rudoph Valentino, the idol of millions, dies of peritonitis in New York's Polyclinic Hospital. He was 31. The Italian-born American actor was known for his romantic leading roles in silent films such as "The Sheik" and "Blood and Sand."
1927: In one of the most controversial cases in American legal history, Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti are sent to the electric chair. In July 1921, a jury found the two Italian political anarchists and immigrants guilty of the murder of a factory paymaster and a guard during a robbery in South Braintree, Massachusetts.
1928: Chinese Communist Party leaders, including Mao Tse-tung and Chu Teh, and their troops flee to Chingkangshan in Kiangsi Province after being outflanked and besieged by government forces from both the provinces of Hunan and Kiangsi.
1933: Gandhi is released from Poona jail after his hunger strike almost kills him.
1939: The USSR and Germany sign the Molotov-Ribbentropp Non-Aggression Pact, a terrible shock to the Western European leaders.
1940: German bombers begin night raids on London.
1945: Soviet troops occupy Manchuria.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek sends a third invitation to Mao Tse-tung after inviting him Aug. 14 to come to Chungking for a conference and the again Aug. 20.
1958: The Battle of the Taiwan Strait begins with Communist China firing 57,000 rounds in 2 hours at the islands of Kinmen. Many defenders are killed, including Gen. Chi Sing-wen, deputy commander of the Kinmen Garrison Command.
1963: Ambassador to the United States Tsiang Ting-fu signs the nuclear test ban treaty on behalf of the Republic of China.
1981: One hundred and ten people die in the crash of a Far Eastern Air Transport plane. The incident represents Taiwan's worst air disaster.
1990: East and West Germany choose October 3 as the date for reunification.
1990: Amenia declares its independence from Moscow.
1992: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with South Korea.
1998: Russian President Boris Yeltsin sacks his government and names former premier Viktor Chernomyrdin as acting prime minister.
1999: ROC Premier Vincent Siew is awarded an honorary doctorate in public service by Ohio State University.
2000: Eight mountaineers from Taiwan successfully climb to the 3,776-meter peak of Mount Fuji, thus writing a new page in climbing history.
2001: The 12th Taipei Chinese Food Fair, featuring various kinds of Chinese noodles and delicacies, opens with lively performances at the Taipei World Trade Center.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The Emperor Shun might perhaps be considered in the highest sense of the word a pious man. In moral qualities, he was a saint. In dignity of office, he was the ruler of the empire. In wealth, all that the wide world contained belonged to him."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times:
Buddhist Master Cheng Yen ordered to compensate an elderly doctor NT$1.01 million over slander.
The United Daily News:
The government will offer an additional NT$280 billion for housing loans.
The Liberty Times:
Taiwan's investment climate rated fourth in the BERI survey.
The Taiwan Daily:
Holes found in military intelligence protection.
The Central Daily News:
KMT chairman touts the party's contribution to nation.
The China Post:
Government to set aside NT$280 billion for new housing loans.
The Taiwan News:
Latin American ties crucial, Lu says.
The Taipei Times:
DPP duo wants squatters dealt with.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS FOURTH IN BERI GLOBAL INVESTMENT CLIMATE SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan tied with Japan for fourth place in a global investment climate survey released recently by the U.S.-based Business Environment Risk Intelligence (BERI) market research firm.
BERI has studies the investment climates and overall competitiveness of the world's 50 major economies regularly. Its latest survey report was released earlier this week.
Switzerland boasts the best investment climate among the 50 economies studied, followed by Singapore and the Netherlands in that order.
Among Asian economies, Singapore ranks first in terms of its investment climate, while Taiwan ties with Japan at second.
According to the BERI report, Taiwan's investment climate belongs in the top A category, meaning that Taiwan is a low-risk investment destination.

The report predicts that Taiwan will witness an evident economic recovery next year and that the island's overall investment climate score will rise to 73 points on a zero-to-100 scale from this year's 72 points.

It also foresees further improvement in the island's investment climate five years from now. By 2008, it forecasts, the island's investment climate score will rise to 74 points, with its world rating remaining fourth.

BERI gauges a country's investment climates based on three major indicators -- the business risk index, the political risk index and the currency exchange rate risk. More specifically, BERI evaluates business risks and profitability a multinational company faces while investing in a specific country.

In the business risk index, Taiwan receives a score of 71 points, ranking fourth among the 50 economies studied. But its political risk index is less than ideal, ranking 12th with a score of 62. In contrast, Taiwan ranks third in the currency exchange rate risk, with a score of 84.
The BERI report also forecasts that Taiwan will make steady improvements in all three investment climate indicators in the next five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL OBSTACLES PREVENT TAIWAN JOINING WTO'S GPA
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By C. H. Lu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's failure this year to become a signatory of the Government Procurement Agreement (GPA) of the World Trade Organization (WTO) due to mainland China's heavy-handed political interference is regrettable since the issue is purely an economic one, a high-ranking Republic of China trade official said Friday.
Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, made the remarks while participating in the GPA Committee meeting held in Geneva Friday.
He said that despite the fact that Taiwan has demonstrated a remarkable amount of flexibility, non-economic factors were still used against the island in its quest to be a signatory of the GPA.

Without a consensus being reached by the 28 members of the GPA Committee, issues regarding Taiwan's GPA bid were not placed on the meeting's agenda. The committee has been unable to accept Taiwan as a GPA signatory because of Beijing's political intervention.

The GPA is a plurilateral agreement under the WTO framework. Its goals are to promote market access and transparency in the government procurement sector. The agreement now has 28 signatories and most of them are developed countries. Taiwan promised to join the GPA when it became a WTO member in January last year.

Huang pointed out that Taiwan already completed its bilateral consultations on relevant issues with all GPA signatories in December of last year and has expressed its hope of joining the grouping. He said that non-economic interference prevented the island from making any headway on the issue.

Nevertheless, Huang urged all GPA signatories to do all they can to remove the political obstacles hindering Taiwan's GPA entry. He admitted, however, that the current situation has left him disappointed.
Mainland China's tactic is usually to once oppose Taiwan using its government agencies' names on the GPA government procurement list.

Although Taiwan has again failed to join the GPA this year, Huang said that all the GPA signatories have affirmed the island's hard work and determination to join the agreement. They also expressed the hope that Taiwan will be able to become a GPA signatory soon.

He also emphasized that although Beijing continues to play political hardball with the GPA bid, Taiwan still feels that government procurement is an economic issue that should have nothing to do with politics.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR SUSPECTS ARRESTED FOR FIREARMS TRADING

TEXT.P: Three men and a woman were arrested in the southern county of Pingtung Saturday on charges of illegal firearms trading, police said.
Also seized in the midnight raid on a surveillance-monitoring equipment company were 69 standard and modified guns, a large amount of ammunition and equipment for gun modification.
Police said they were tipped off in March this year that two brothers, identified as Wang Jen-hung, 28, and Wang Jen-chieh, 26, had illegally traded in firearms.
After more than five months of close monitoring, police decided to raid the surveillance equipment shop run by the Wangs late last night.

The Wangs admitted that they had imported air guns and parts for modifying them into rifles for sale at NT$150,000 apiece. To avoid police monitoring, the Wangs sold firearms through the Internet, using e-mail for trading terms negotiations. The Wangs have yet to explain from where they had imported the air guns.
Two staff members of the Wangs' company, including a man and a woman, were also arrested on charges of assisting in the illegal trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BRINGS HOME MEDALS FROM 2003 INT'L OLYMPIAD IN INFORMATICS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's delegation at the 2003 International Olympiad in Informatics (IOI) has performed well, with the four contestants winning one gold medal, one silver and one bronze at the annual event.
A news release from the Ministry of Education said that Taiwan sent four high school students to this year's IOI, which is an international computer science competition for high school students.
The 2003 International Olympiad in Informatics was held in United States Aug. 16-23.

Among the Taiwan contestants, Hou Kun-pan from Taipei Municipal Chien-Kuo High School won a gold medal, Lin Tai-hsu a silver and Tsai Chen-yang a bronze in the competition, in which more than 290 contestants from 77 countries participated.

Another student, also from Chien-Kuo High School, though not a medal winner, has been granted permission to study at the Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering of National Taiwan University, a prestigious department.

The IOC has not announced the group score of a participant country since 1998. Since Taiwan began sending participants to the event in 1994, it has scored 10th, sixth and eighth by nation in 1995, 1996 and 1997, respectively.
After taking part in the IOI, the Taiwan delegation will visit Japan for an educational and cultural tour. They are scheduled to return home Aug. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOEING'S REFUSAL OF LU'S VISIT MEANS NO U.S. POLICY CHANGE

TEXT.P: A research fellow of the Heritage Foundation said Friday that Boeing Co.'s recent refusal to allow Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu to visit does not mean that Washington wants to change its Taiwan policy.

John Tkacik, an expert in the fields of Taiwan, mainland China and Asian trade as well as military strategy of the Washington-based think tank, made the remarks in an interview conducted with the Central News Agency.

The researcher said that as far as he knew, the U.S. government was rather disappointed over the aircraft manufacturer's refusal of Lu's visit and that he himself considered that Boeing Co. was not smart in dealing with the matter.
In her transit stops in the United States after a recent two-leg Latin America visit to Panama and Paraguay, Lu originally planned to visit Boeing Co.

Considering the jobs creation and business opportunities, Washington actually hoped that the vice president would be able to visit Boeing Co., Tkacik said, adding that Douglas Paal, director of the American Institute in Taiwan, had recently made efforts to persuade China Airlines to purchase Boeing aircraft.
He also said that from what he has learned, Boeing Co.'s refusal of Lu's visit absolutely does not mean that the U.S. government wants to change its Taiwan policy.
Talking about the competition between Boeing Co. and Airbus Company in selling aircraft to Taiwan, Tkacik said that the European consortium is very active in promoting its businesses on the island.
He pointed out that despite the fact that Boeing Co. has paid more attention to the mainland Chinese market, records show that the company has profited more from its business with Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Parris Chang, a legislator from ruling Democratic Progress Party, who is currently attending a U.S.-Japan-Taiwan trilateral dialogue seminar being held in the U.S. capital by the foundation, echoed what the American scholar said, indicating that actually, the U.S. government was very disappointed that Lu was not allowed to visit Boeing.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'CALL TAIWAN, TAIWAN' CAMPAIGN WILL RECEIVE WORLD SUPPORT: EX-PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The call to rectify the name of the nation from the Republic of China to Taiwan is gaining momentum every year and the whole world should support the cause, former President Lee Teng-hui said Saturday.

The former president, who will serve as a chief convener of a large rally to call for support for the "call Taiwan, Taiwan" movement in front of the Presidential Office Sept. 6, made the remarks in a flag-presenting ceremony for the upcoming rally at the Ambassador Hotel in downtown Taipei.
Slogans such as "our country is called Taiwan, " "call Taiwan, Taiwan, " and "Taiwan wants to march into the United Nations" were heard throughout the meeting.
Lee, in addition to presenting flags to the groups and volunteers who will take part in the Sept. 6 rally, also delivered a 10-minute speech.

Lee said that Taiwan people need to think about the significance of rectifying the name of the nation: "We are an independent sovereign state, but few countries recognize us because of international convention. This is especially so with the relentless pressure from mainland China...a lot of countries are unable to develop normal relations with us and we cannot walk toward the international community and receive the respect we are due, " the former president said.

Lee said the situation has "adverse effects on national development, and to make our country turn from abnormal to normal, and see Taiwan stand up in the world, the only feasible way is to change the name of the nation, " which he said, in a nutshell, is called " Taiwan."
Lee said that President Chen Shui-bian has no way of saying these things openly now, but as he himself is out of office, the words, "the name of our nation is Taiwan," can be spoken.

He said that the wish to rectify the name of the country could have not been fulfilled mainly because in the past Taiwan was ruled by alien regimes, including the Netherlands, Japan and the Republic of China, which he said "had nothing to do with Taiwan."

He noted the "old forces" of society are still saying that they want to fight to see which is the "real China," the Republic of China or the People's Republic of China, although even late President Chiang Ching-kuo said that he couldn't say that mainland China could be recovered.
"The old guards do not identify with Taiwan, and if they don't identify with Taiwan's culture, how can the nation develop? " he questioned.

Lee said that Taiwan's struggle to be its own master began very early, but it had also encountered enormous obstacles, adding that resistance does not take place in a day, although the call for rectifying the nation's name to Taiwan is gaining momentum.
He said he believes the United States will support the movement, so will Japan and the rest of the world.

The Alliance to Campaign for Rectifying the Name of Taiwan noted that to promote the campaign, it first broached the idea in 2002, setting that year as a campaign year, and this year as the action year. Next year will be the harvest year, officials from the alliance said.

The alliance is calling for 100,000 dedicated Taiwanese to come forward to take part in the rally, to tell President Chen and the people of Taiwan that they want to return the original picture of mother Taiwan, and that the nation will be an equal partner on the world stage as Taiwan and become a true member of the international community.

Taking part in the meeting were Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, Taiwan Independence Alliance Chairman Haung Chao-tang and its vice chairman Huang Er-hsiuan, Presidential Office advisers Huang Tien-lin, Chuan Po-lin, Huang Hua, Chou Ping-te, and Yang Chin-hai, legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chen Tang-shan and Chou Chin-yu, as well as Lin Chih-chia, secretary-general of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, which considers former president Lee as its spiritual leader.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEATHER BUREAU LIFTS WARNING AGAINST TYPHOON KROVANH

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau lifted its warning against Typhoon Krovanh at 2: 30 p.m. Saturday when the storm was moving away from the Bashi Channel.

Krovanh weakened into a light typhoon after making landfall in the Philippines Friday. It was located about 520 kilometers south-southwest of Oluanpi at the southern tip of Taiwan at 8 a.m. Saturday, moving west-northwest at 22 kilometers per hour.
The weather bureau said ships sailing in the area near the Tung Sa Islands in the South China Sea and in the Bashi Channel still should be alert for strong winds.

The typhoon did not hit Taiwan and brought little rain to the island. Temperatures reached 35 degrees Celsius in northern Taiwan and 34 degrees in other parts of the island Saturday. The weather will continue to be hot over the next few days, the weather bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BATTLE OF THE TAIWAN STRAIT COMMEMORATED

TEXT.P: A group of veterans and military authorities in Kinmen visited a public tomb Saturday to salute with flowers those who died in the "Battle of the Taiwan Strait, " which began on Aug. 23, 1958.
The battle played a significant role in the relations between both sides of Taiwan Strait over the last 45 years.

Communist Chinese troops began to shell Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen on Aug. 23, 1958. In the first 36 hours, the island was battered by 94,000 artillery rounds. In the following 42 days, some 400,000 additional shells rained down on the island, which is only 131 square kilometers in area.
Hostilities ceased on January 7, 1959.

Leading more than 70 veterans who fought in the famous battle, Lu Fang-yen, chairman of the Confederation of Veterans of the Aug. 23 Battle, noted that "there would have been no prosperous and peaceful life in Taiwan without the victory in the Aug. 23 battle, " and reminded the government to take good care of the veterans who fought hard for their country.

Meanwhile, a large parade to commemorate the Aug. 23 battle was held Friday in downtown Taipei, in which opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, People First Party (PFP) Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung and some 10,000 people, mostly veterans, participated.

Noting that it was because of the hard fight of those veterans in the battle that successfully deterred the communist influence from spreading to other parts of the world, the KMT and PFP lawmakers present at the parade promised to push for a bill to take special care of the veterans of the Aug. 23 battle.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREE TRADE AGREEMENT WITH TAIWAN WILL OPEN DOORS FOR PANAMA: MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By R. Huang and EH)

TEXT.P: Panamanian Deputy Foreign Minister Nivia Rossana Castrellon said Friday that the free trade agreement signed between Taiwan and Panama Thursday in Taipei will bring various kinds of benefits to Panama, because Taiwan is the world's major investor in Asia.
She said the agreement will come into force after being ratified by the National Assembly of Panama sometime next year.
She made the remarks after being asked by reporters whether the agreement would give rise to retaliation by other countries. She said that there was nothing to worry about.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR MA VISITS PHOENIX, ARIZONA
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angles, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Lawrence Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou led a delegation to visit Phoenix, Arizona Friday, meeting with Phoenix Mayor Skip Rimsza and Taiwan students there.
Ma was accompanied by Jason Yuan, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Los Angeles, to call on Mayor Rimsza.

As Taipei and Phoenix have long had sisterhood relations, Rimsza hosted a luncheon for Ma and his delegation and accompanied him to visit the capital city's baseball stadium, Bank One Field, in the afternoon.
Mayor Ma took part in the inauguration of a Taiwan student organization in the evening, speaking to more than 200 Taiwan students from 26 states from the Taiwan Future Development Association.
Ma urged the students to nurture mercy toward others and concern about their country, learn the true meaning of freedom, democracy and party politics to contribute to Taiwan's democratic development.
Ma will proceed to San Francisco after concluding his stay in Phoenix Saturday.

Ma is near the end of his six-city visit to Canada and the United States. He has visited Toronto, Boston, Washington and Atlanta, during which he exchanged views with health officials on the fight against severe acute respiratory syndrome as well as met business leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-GREEN CAMP' AIMS TO WIN 55% OF VOTE IN PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: An official of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) - an ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -- said Saturday that their "pan-green camp" should garner at least 55 percent of the votes to win the presidential election next year.
Lin Chih-chia, TSU's secretary-general, noted that the presidential election slated for March next year is not the victory or failure of President Chen Shui-bian, but involves the survival of Taiwan.

In a rally of groups that support Chen and former President Lee Teng-hui in Taipei, Lin further explained that the 2004 election represents the crucial moment which will decide whether Taiwan can survive as a sovereign country with dignity, or be a part of mainland China.

"Those who love Taiwan should unite to work for a bright future for the island, " Lin urged, saying that the pan-green camp should try hard to obtain at least 55 percent of the votes, or 60 percent if possible.
Lin estimated that the DPP itself can garner at least 39 percent of the votes, while the remaining 16 percent should depend on the support for Lee, the spiritual leader of the TSU.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SAYS TO TREASURE ETHNIC, CULTURAL DIVERSITY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday diverse ethnic cultures are Taiwan's most precious asset which forms Taiwan's uniqueness in the world community.

Chen made the remarks in a speech delivered at the graduation ceremony for an indigenous people research class at the Ketagelan Academy -- an institute founded by President Chen to nurture a new generation of politically adept professionals.
While pursuing globalization, Chen said, Taiwan must have its unparalleled ethnic cultural assets fully developed to enhance its competitiveness and preserve its uniqueness.
Chen said the previous Kuomintang administration's policy of forcing indigenous people to give up their ethnic cultures and languages and to Sinicize their names was wrong.
Such a biased policy has made aboriginal people become bogged down in a political, economic, social and cultural quagmire, Chen said, adding that the situation should be reviewed and corrected.

Chen said the Ketagelan aboriginal affairs research class focuses on discovering indigenous people's vigor, vitality and perseverance. Over the years, he said, the local aboriginal rights movement has offered valuable inspiration for the government to improve its policy in dealing with aboriginal affairs.
Since taking power, Chen said, his administration has made strenuous efforts to forge new partnerships with all of the island's 11 aboriginal tribes.

Chen especially read out the name of each aboriginal group in his address. He said he hopes all local people can memorize the names of the island's 11 aboriginal tribes because it symbolizes respect for them.

The first Ketagelan indigenous people research class had 32 graduates, including Chen Yi-hsin, a retired professional baseball pitcher. They all donned their traditional tribal costumes. President Chen also wore an aboriginal costume and sang a popular song, "We Are Family," with all new graduates.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATE MALA PRESIDENT VISITS FOKUANGSHAN BUDDHIST TEMPLE

TEXT.P: Guatemala President Alfonso Antonio Portillo Cabrera toured the Fokuangshan Buddhist Temple in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung Saturday.

Portillo, who arrived in Taipei earlier this week to attend a summit meeting of heads of state of the Republic of China and its Central American allies on Thursday, said he was impressed by Fokuangshan's magnificent architecture and solemn religious ambience.

Buddhist Master Hsin Yun, founder of the Fokuangshan Temple which is oen of Taiwan's most important religious center, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing and Buddhist monks and nuns at the temple greeted Portillo during his tour of the Buddhist complex.

Portillo invited Hsin Yun to visit his country at a time of his convenience. Hsin Yun presented Portillo with a Buddha sculpture as a souvenir. Portillo said he hopes to visit the temple again in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE GROUPS VOW TO BACK CHEN'S RE-ELECTION BID

TEXT.P: Supporters of President Chen Shui-bian and former President Lee Teng-hui issued a joint declaration Saturday pledging their unified support for Chen's re-election bid.

Huang Kun-hu, president of the national federation of groups supporting Lee, said the federation will cooperate with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and all "friends of Chen Shui-bian" associations in ensuring Chen's re-election next year.
Huang also announced his determination to resign from his post on the Central Election Commission (CEC) to campaign for Chen's re-election.

"As a CEC member, I must maintain neutrality and refrain from campaigning for a specific candidate. As Chen's re-election is critical to consolidate Taiwan's young democracy, I'm determined to quit the CEC and dedicate myself to stumping for Chen, " Huang told the press after a joint meeting of senior executives of groups from around the island that support Lee and Chen.
Huang said although groups supporting Lee and Chen partially overlap, their formal integration will generate an even greater force in boosting Chen's victory in the 2004 presidential election.

Addressing the joint meeting, Huang said Taiwan still faces serious national identification problems because pro-unification forces refuse to recognize Taiwan's separate identity and want to push for unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Huang said Chen must win next year's election to deepen Taiwan's democratic reforms and safeguard its sovereign status.

Other attendees to the joint meeting included DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung, Taiwan Solidarity Union Secretary-General Lin Chih-jia, Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen and DPP Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan. Also present were senior executives of groups supporting Lee and Chen.

Legislator Kao Chih-peng, who represents all the groups supporting Chen, said the joint meeting was aimed at pooling the resources of all pro-Taiwan groups in support of Chen's campaign and fighting against Beijing's attempt to swallow Taiwan.
"All of Lee's and Chen's friends and supporters must cooperate closely to ensure Chen's re-election, which is crucial to maintaining Taiwan's status as an independent sovereign state," he urged.

DOC.HEADLINE: EL SALVADOR PRESIDENT PRESENTS CITATION TO LARGEST CHARITY IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: El Salvador President Francisco Flores presented a citation to Taiwan's largest charitable organization Saturday in appreciation of the assistance provided by the group to his country during the disastrous earthquake two years ago.

President Flores, who arrived in Taipei earlier this week to take part in a summit meeting Thursday, was accompanied by President Chen Shui-bian when he called on Master Cheng Yen, founder of Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation in Hualien, eastern Taiwan.

President Flores said that this was his second trip to Taiwan, which he described as a trip of "gratitude." He wanted to thank Master Cheng Yen and Tzu Chi Foundation for helping victims after the magnitude 7.6 earthquake off the coast of El Salvador in Jan. 13, 2001.

He said that Tzu Chi had not only delivered needed materials, it had also brought mercy, hope, love and dignity to every family. He said that his meeting with Master Cheng Yen had made him realize more deeply the true love of the foundation.
President Flores then presented the citation, which Master Cheng Yen received on behalf of the foundation.

President Chen also lauded Tzu Chi for its respect for life, saying that its loving spirit has transcended politics and race, and that it is indeed admirable for them to help the victims build temporary shelters in El Salvador.

Master Cheng Yen said that seeing the disastrous earthquake in El Salvador, she was reminded of the Sept. 21, 1999 killer earthquake in Taiwan, saying that Taiwan also received generous assistance from others. She concluded by saying that as long as there is love, then there will always be peace and harmony.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG COUNTY GOVERNMENT TO OPEN CLASS FOR FOREIGN SPOUSES

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung County Government said it Saturday it will open a special class to help foreign spouses of residents in the southern Taiwan county to adapt themselves to life here as soon as possible.
The 65-hour teaching program will open Sept. 9, a spokesman said, adding that aspiring foreign spouses are welcome to attend the class.
In addition to Chinese language study, the program will also offer courses in child rearing, local social customs and computer training.
Kaohsiung County now has more than 3,800 foreign spouses, most of whom come from Vietnam, Thailand, Cambodia, the Philippines and Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUG RING IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN UNCOVERED

TEXT.P: Coast Guard Administration officials raided an illegal drug packaging plant in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, late Friday night, seizing 2.2 kg of heroin and amphetamines and arrested three suspects.

The officials were tipped off recently that a drug smuggling ring in southern Taiwan had used grinding machines to reduce heroin blocks and amphetamines, and then mixed them with unknown white powder and reprocessed and repackaging them in air-tight tinfoil pouches to sell to customers.

After months of monitoring activities, the coast guard found a man surnamed Yeh was the owner of the reprocessing plant, who always hung around Fengshan, Kaohsiung County, peddling drugs. The reprocessing plant was established in a building in a residential area in Chiencheng district in Kaoshiung City.

The coast guard found Yeh was carrying with him several small bags of drugs when he went out of his home in Chiencheng district. The coast guard then searched his home and found the whole room set up like a repacking plant.

The coast guard found a large pile of air-tight bags and ground materials, as well as three blocks of unprocessed heroin and some amphetamines worth a market value of NT$20 million (US$579,710) in Yeh's home.
Yeh and two other accomplices surnamed Huang and Jao were arrested.

The coast guard noted that the suspects had adopted the rare approach of using air-tight bags to evade detection. The drug ring had established its own trade mark and enjoyed some reputation in southern Taiwan, they added.
From the scale of the repackaging plant, the ring must have been operating for some time, and they are now trying to track down the associates, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SCHOLAR STRESSES IMPORTANCE OF REFERENDUM IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan scholar said Friday in a seminar on U.S.-Japan-Taiwan security that the direct expression of ideas by Taiwan people in a referendum plays a very important role in the process of the island's democratization.

Lai Yi-chung, director of the Department of International Affairs under Taiwan Thinktank, made the remarks in the third round of the trilateral dialogue with the main topic focusing on the anti-terrorist strategies of Asian countries and other nations.
Lai noted in the trilateral meeting currently held in Washington that Taiwan's democratic development can serve as an inspiration for other Pacific nations and mainland China.

With mainland China's growing military threat against Taiwan, the security promise from the United States to Taiwan would guarantee the continued democratic development on the island. Meanwhile, the expression of Taiwan people's thinking is of the same importance, Lai added.

Among the participants in the meeting were also China-hand from the U.S.-based Heritage Foundation John Tkacik, member of Congress' U.S.-China Security Review Commission June Dreyer, and scholars from Japanese Okazaki Institute.

A Japanese scholar from the Okazaki Institute noted that democracy and liberty in Taiwan is in great interest of the United States and Japan, urging the Japanese government to strengthen high-level official visits to Taiwan, support Taiwan's bid to participate in the World Health Organization, as well as increase discussions with the island on issues such as anti-submarine, anti-missile and anti-terrorist strategies.

The first round of the trilateral dialogue was inaugurated in Taipei in August last year, with the second round being held in Tokyo in March this year. The fourth round of the meeting will be held in Taipei early next year.
The conclusions of the seminar will be presented to the governments for their reference.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EDUCATION MINISTER VISITS TWO UNIVERSITIES IN SEOUL

TEXT.P: Education Minister Huang Jong-tsun Saturday visited Seoul University and Seoul Normal University.

Huang, who came here to attend the opening ceremony of the 22nd World University Games on Thursday, met with the presidents of the two universities separately. During the visits, they exchanged views on how to strengthen the educational exchanges and cooperation between the universities of the two countries.
The presidents of the two Korean universities agreed to cooperate with universities of Taiwan in solving their common problems in educational development. (by T. P. Wong and EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO GIVE PRIORITY TO NORMALIZATION OF CROSS-STRAIT ECONOMIC TIES

TEXT.P: The "pan-blue" alliance of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) will give priority to the normalization of economic and trade relations between Taiwan and mainland China, if it wins the 2004 presidential election, a high-ranking KMT official said Saturday.

Chang Jung-kung, deputy executive director of the KMT Central Policy Committee and director general of the KMT Mainland Affairs Department, said the controversial issue of "one China" will be set aside, if the pan-blue alliance wins the election.

He said he does not think cross-strait relations will become a hot top of debate during the election campaign, because what most people are worried about are social and economic problems rather than cross-strait relations. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 24, or the 27th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: The small but very bitter war being fought between Britain and the United States continues, with British forces razing many Washington, D.C. landmarks, including the White House.
1923: A "Dr. Sun Yat-sen mission" led by Chiang Kai-shek leaves Harbin for Moscow on a fact-finding tour.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's Nationalist government, signs the ratification instrument of the U.N. Charter.
1945: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China ratifies the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1950: Communist China sends troops into Tibet.
1954: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs into law the Communist Control Act, outlawing the Communist Party.
1954: Brazilian President Getulio Vargas shoots himself to avoid scandal as well as demands that he relinquish power. He was 71.
1968: Taichung's Golden Dragons baseball team defeats the U.S. West team 5A-0 to win the 23rd Little League World Championship.
1981: A Manhattan Supreme Court judge jails Mark David Chapman for 20 years to life for shooting dead John Lennon the previous December.
1983: The auditorium of Fengyuan High School in Taichung County collapses, killing 27 students and injuring 83 others.
1983: Communist Chinese pilot Lt. Col. Sun Tien-chin, who flew to South Korea from mainland China in a MiG-21 jet fighter Aug. 7, arrives in Taiwan.
1985: Communist Chinese pilot Hsiao Tien-jun, 33, flies an H-5 torpedo attack bomber to South Korea and requests political asylum in the ROC.
1986: The ROC Little League baseball team "Kungyuan" defeats Tucson, Arizona, and recaptures the Little League World Series title after four years.
1991: The Ukraine declares independence from Moscow.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as head of the Soviet Communist Party and urges its leadership to disband the party.
1992: Communist China and South Korea establish diplomatic relations.
1995: President Juan Carlos Wasmosy of Paraguay leads a delegation to Taipei for a four-day visit.
1995: Beijing expels Chinese-American human rights activist Harry Wu shortly after he was sentenced to a 15-year prison term for spying and leaking state secrets.
1996: The ROC wins the 1996 Little League World Series in the U.S. city of Williamsport, Pennsylvania.
1999: A UNI Air plane from Taipei crash-lands at Hualien Airport in flames, injuring 28 passengers.
1999: Ever Decent, a Panamanian-flagged container ship owned by Taiwan's Evergreen Marine Corp., is hit by Norwegian Dream, a Bahamas-registered cruise ship, injuring three people aboard the cruise ship.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian wraps up his visit to Chad ahead of schedule after issuing a joint communique with Chadian President Idriss Deby.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian officiates at the opening of the plenary session of the much-anticipated Economic Development Advisory Conference Friday, a series of meetings and discussions designed to invigorate Taiwan's floundering economy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses great moral qualities will certainly attain a corresponding high position, a corresponding great prosperity, a corresponding great name, and a corresponding great age."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
ACTIVISTS SEEK DPP SUPPORT FOR RENAMING COUNTRY 'TAIWAN'

TEXT.P: A group of activists who want to change the country's official name to "Taiwan" will call on President Chen Shui-bian Monday to seek stronger support for their cause from Chen's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Wang Chen-chung, one of the organizers of the "Calling Taiwan Taiwan" movement said that many DPP members who support the movement have urged the party to endorse the cause officially.

The DPP decided in March to initiate a signature-collecting campaign for renaming the country, but the decision was put on hold because of the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak which ravaged the island from March to July and because of the by-election for magistrate in Hualien in August.

Noting that the party's support for the campaign to rename the country has been a vital indicator of the DPP's loyalty to the cause for which it was founded, Wang said he hopes the party will support his campaign more aggressively.
A group of the movement's activists, including many DPP political heavyweights, will call on Chen at the DPP headquarters in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU WON'T GET INVOLVED IN PRESIDENT CHEN'S REELECTION BID

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , a political party that groups political followers of former President Lee Teng-hui, will not get involved in President Chen Shui-bian's reelection bid, a TSU official said Sunday.

Chen Chien-ming said that instead, a group of Lee's followers called the Clubs of Lee's Friends will help Chen with his reelection bid. These clubs are made up of the same TSU supporters, with TSU lawmakers as their heads in different election districts.

The strategy is meant to remind the public that the TSU is a political group separate from Chen Shui-bian's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , although the two parties share similar political views and are competing to win the support of voters who favor Taiwan independence.

If the results of the 2002 city councilor elections in Taipei and Kaoshiung and the Hualien magistrate by-election this August are any indication, then President Chen's support among those who favor independence seems to be subsiding, which doesn't bode well for his reelection bid, the TSU official said.
Lee will play an important role in this regard by using his influence to galvanize the support of these voters behind President Chen, the TSU official said.

In light of the TSU's failure in the 2002 councilor elections in which it did not win a single seat in Taipei and only won two seats in Kaohsiung, the TSU official said, his party had decided to maintain its own identity by standing apart from the DPP.

As a political party, the TSU is competing against the DPP for votes, and it would be inappropriate for the TSU to officially support a DPP candidate in the presidential election even if it itself does not field any candidates in the race, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC OFFICIAL URGES OVERSEAS CHINESE TO STRENGTHEN SOLIDARITY
DOC.DATELINE: San Jose, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By Y. Chiang and EH)

TEXT.P: Liao Sheng-hsiung, deputy minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) of the Executive Yuan, Saturday urged overseas Chinese to strengthen their solidarity in order to prevent Communist China from sowing seeds of discord in their communities.

Liao, who is in San Jose to attend an annual conference of the Taiwanese Amity Association in the United States, said at the meeting that the government of the Republic of China on Taiwan, regardless of which political party is running the country, treats all overseas Chinese communities equally and fairly.

He said the OCAC is doing its best to serve overseas Chinese communities around the world. Currently, the OCAC has 17 cultural centers to serve overseas Chinese. Three more are being set up in Washington, D.C., Sao Paulo, Brazil, and Vancouver, Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL REFORMS TO MAKE TAIWAN MORE COMPETITIVE: FINANCE MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's financial industry will become internationally competitive if it deepens its reform and globalization, Minister of Finance Lin Chuan said in New York Saturday.
Lin made the remarks while giving a key-note speech on Taiwan's financial reform at an academic meeting sponsored by an association of American Chinese on the U.S. East Coast.

Lin said he is optimistic about Taiwan's financial reform and the industry's globalization now that the Legislative Yuan has approved six major economic and financial bills that clear the way for the sector to sharpen its competitiveness and to go international.

According to the finance minister, promoting the financial service industry should be used as a means of countering Taiwan's rising unemployment at a time when the manufacturing sector is no longer the engine of the country's economy.

Stepping up financial supervision, wiping out financial crimes and restructuring financial institutions will be the focal points of the government's financial reform, Lin said, noting that setting up a good system is the key to a country's sustainable prowess.

As long as Taiwan's fiscal and financial reform and development remain on a sound track, the country's economic progress will be secured, Lin said, adding that "we are determined to carry out the reform in depth."

Lin arrived in New York late Friday on the first leg of his U.S tour aimed at attracting foreign capital to Taiwan. He will also visit Boston to given an introduction to the local business community on Taiwan's investment climate.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTHER TREATED FOR HAVING SEX WITH HER TWO MENTALLY-CHALLENGED SONS

TEXT.P: A mother stunned social workers in Kaohsiung city, southern Taiwan, recently by telling them that she had had sex with her two mentally-challenged sons to prevent them from possibly attacking others.
The mother, in her fifties, told psychiatrists at the Kaohsiung Municipal Kaihsuan Hospital that she raises the two sons by herself, although she herself receives financial aid from the government.

She said that after the two sons entered their teenaged years, their emotional states started becoming unstable. Four years ago when her eldest son was 16, she had sex with him for the first time out of fear that his unsatisfied sexual desires could drive him to attack others.
Then, her second son requested to have sex with his mother after seeing what happened between her and his older brother.

The woman sought the psychiatrist's help after her second son began to injure himself because his mother started turning down his requests for sex. The son would hit his head against the wall or beat his mother.
The son was later admitted to Kaihsuan Hospital for psychiatric treatment and then later released after showing improvement.
Social workers said they began to aid the woman to take care of her two sons and to give all of them proper treatment after learning of the family's tragic story.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADING INTERNATIONAL HIGH-TECH FIRMS SET UP R&D CENTERS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Adequate technical backup and qualified technology manpower have become Taiwan's advantages in attracting international technology firms to set up research and development centers on the island, an official from the Technology Transfer Service Center under the Economic Affairs Ministry said Sunday.

Ger Jy-gang, deputy director of the center, said that in addition to the 38 R&D centers affiliated with local enterprises, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. and United Microelectronics Corp., many international manufacturers of computer hardware and software have set up R&D centers in Taiwan over the past two years.

The economics official said that while Taiwan's electronics firms have gained a strong foothold in the international market as reputable original equipment manufacturers (OEMs), the government has sought to advance the island's industrial structure by attracting more international corporations to set up R&D centers in Taiwan.

So far, international computer manufacturers, including Hewlett-Packard, Dell, and IBM, as well as chips and software developer and manufacturer Intel, software giant Microsoft, and Becker Avionics, a developer of sophisticated navigation systems, have employed Taiwan's technology resources to advance their R&D.
Ger said that he believes that more international corporations will use Taiwan as an R&D base when the government's regulations and incentive measures become more flexible.
According to Lin Ferng-ching, president of the Institute for Information Industry, Taiwan is playing an important role in the information industry's manufacturing and R&D.

At the same time, Lin said, the information industry has become ever more predominant in Taiwan's industrial structure. In 1997, the production value of the information industry accounted for 16.3 percent of the island's gross national product (GNP) . By 2002, the ratio had risen to 30.3 percent. It is estimated that the production value of the information industry will represent 33 percent of Taiwan's GNP this year.

Stressing the contributions made by many hardware and software companies, Lin said that companies such as the anti-virus software developer Trend Micro Inc. have helped cultivate many science and technology workers and advance Taiwan's high-tech standards.

An official from the Council for Economic Planning and Development indicated that many international corporations have chosen Taiwan as a base for their product development centers in view of the well-cultivated high-tech personnel and good basic infrastructure.

He said that among the international corporations making Taiwan their R&D base, Hewlett-Packard has set up a product development center; IBM, an R&D center for computational biology as well as an R&D center for e-commerce; Sony, an information products R&D center and a large semiconductor (LSI) and module design and development center; Dell, the Dell Taiwan Design Center; Becker Avionics, an R&D center for navigation systems certification technology; and the semiconductor production equipment manufacturer Aixtron, the Aixtron Manufacturing Oriented Research Lab.

The official disclosed that Intel's chief executive officer, Craig Barrett, who flew into Taipei Sunday, is expected to make an announcement Monday regarding the company's plan to set up an R&D center in Taiwan. On Tuesday, Phoenix Technologies Inc., a Canadian manufacturer of optical motion sensing devices for animation, will also announce its plan to move its R&D facilities to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHOULD HAVE SUFFICIENT WATER SUPPLY THIS YEAR: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Deputy Taipei Mayor Ou Chin-der said Sunday the Taipei area will likely have sufficient water supply this year.
He said that, unlike last year, water supply in Taipei will not be restricted if normal levels of rainfall are seen over the next few weeks.

However, he said, people should continue to conserve water until the water level at Feitsui Reservoir returns to normal. The water level at the reservoir, the major source of water for the greater Taipei area, stood at 136.71 meters as of 1 a.m. Sunday. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING DPP PLANNING ENDORSEMENT CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is planning to launch an endorsement campaign calling for a halving of the number of seats in the Legislature as a means of garnering greater public support ahead of the presidential election next March.

DPP legislative whip Chen Chi-mai said the campaign, aimed at collecting 800,000 signatures, will be held across Taiwan in line with a "Call Taiwan Taiwan" rally slated for Sept. 6 in Taipei, as well as the DPP's Sept. 28 founding anniversary celebration in central Taichung, and an Oct. 18 parade in southern Kaohsiung organized by DPP Legislator Trong Chai to appeal for the people's right to referendum.
According to Chen, the endorsement campaign will help the DPP display its political philosophy and add momentum to President Chen Shui-bian's reelection bid.

DPP lawmaker Lai Ching-teh said the aim of the campaign -- downsizing the Legislature -- and the call for referendums in Taiwan have long been topics high on the DPP's agenda. The series of activities projected by the DPP will not only help win increased public backing but will also set a course for Taiwan's future development, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN PRESENTS 'PRESIDENTIAL EDUCATION AWARD' TO 68 STUDENTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Sunday presented the "Presidential Education Award" to 68 students from elementary, junior high and senior high schools around Taiwan at the Tainan Municipal Cultural Center in recognition of their strength and perseverance in the face of many difficulties in their surroundings.

Calling all of them Taiwan's "little suns, " Chen said he is very happy to have the opportunity to encourage in person those diligent children who always strive for success despite facing hardship. He also vowed to hold the activity every year in the future in cooperation with local authorities and the private sector. This year's ceremony was the third of its kind.
The president also urged the public to be brave enough to dream and to believe that "the dream will come true through hard work."
"This is exactly the meaning and significance of the "Presidential Education Award," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS EMPHASIZE TAIWAN'S STRATEGIC IMPORTANCE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By James Kuo & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Scholars emphasized Taiwan's strategic importance during the last day of a three-day symposium in the U.S. capital Sunday.

If mainland China were to annex Taiwan by force, Beijing would control the sea lanes through the western Pacific and the South China Sea, challenge U.S. predominance in the Pacific, and threaten the strategic interests of the United States and Japan, said Hisahiko Okazaki, a former Japanese ambassador to Thailand.

In a speech at the symposium co-organized by the Heritage Foundation in Washington, D.C., the Okazaki National Research Institute in Okazaki, Japan, and the Taipei-based Taiwan Think Tank, Okazaki warned that the whole of Southeast Asia would fall under mainland China's sphere of influence if Beijing were to gain control of Taiwan.

He and some other Japanese scholars at the symposium were of the opinion that the United States and Japan should step up their security cooperation with Taiwan, and share their strategic intelligence and missile defense technology with Taiwan to help the island stand up against Beijing's military threat.

However, June Dreyer, a political science professor at the University of Miami, dismissed as out of the question any joint military exercises among the three countries because of the Japanese Constitution which renounces war as a means of resolving conflict with other countries.

Tokyo is smart in trying to get rid of the anti-war provision in its constitution in a step-by-step manner, Dreyer said, but before this is accomplished, any discussion about joint military exercises or defense cooperation with Taiwan and the United States would be unwise, she added.

Nonetheless, Lai Yi-chao, a scholar from the Taiwan Think Tank, said the symposium has helped Taiwan to realize its strategic status in the Pacific and Asian regions and to learn what Tokyo and Washington expect from Taiwan.

The symposium is designed to be an unofficial channel of dialogue among Washington, Taipei and Tokyo. The just-concluded symposium was the third of its kinds under a two-year program which envisions the holding of four such symposiums. The fourth and last symposium under the program is slated to be hosted by Taipei early next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION ALLIANCE TO LAUNCH CAMPAIGN AGAINST HIGH TUITION POLICY

TEXT.P: An alliance formed by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) has decided to launch a signature-collecting campaign to express the people's discontent with the administration's high tuition policy for higher education and the hike in premiums and self-payment fees under the National Health Insurance program, a KMT official said Sunday.

Tseng Yung-chuan, director of the KMT Central Policy Committee, said that the alliance will formally announce the campaign starting Tuesday in a press conference, adding that it hopes to collect more than one million signatures from across Taiwan by Sept. 2.

The alliance will urge the KMT's and PFP's lawmakers, local government heads and party officials to organize activities at places where people frequently gather in order to collect the signatures, Tseng said. The signatures will be delivered to the Presidential Office to make the people's voice heard by President Chen Shui-bian, he added.
The campaign is also set to feature the KMT and PFP concerns about the people's livelihood and to test the two parties' grass-roots mobilization capabilities, Tseng stressed.

The KMT and PFP have decided to field a joint ticket to challenge President Chen in the next March presidential election, with KMT Chairman Lien Chan as the presidential candidate and PFP Chairman James Soong as his running mate.
The premiums and self-payment fees under the National Health Insurance program were raised Sept. 1 last year by 0.3 percent, drawing protests from various labor and civil groups around the nation.
The issue of higher tuition fees for university students has recently become a heated topic in the government's education reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEL CEO ARRIVES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Craig Barrett, the chief executive officer of Intel, arrived in Taiwan Sunday evening for a brief visit.
He is expected to announce the company's plan to set up a research and development center in Taiwan during a news conference Monday.
Barrett will meet local business leaders and government officials during his whirlwind visit. He is set to depart Taiwan Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLOUD GATE DANCE THEATRE INVITED TO PERFORM IN EL SALVADOR

TEXT.P: The visiting President of El Salvador Francisco Flores invited the Cloud Gate Dance Theatre Sunday to perform in San Salvador in an opportune moment.

Flores extended the invitation in person to Lin Huai-min, founder of the world-renowed contemporary dance troupe, after spectating the group's performance at the National Theater in Taipei. He gave a high credit to the performance.

Flores arrived in Taiwan Wednesday to take part in the fourth summit of heads of states and governments of the Republic of China , Central American nations and the Dominican Republic held in Taipei the following day.
He made a fact-finding tour of eastern Taiwan following the summit and returned to Taipei on Sunday afternoon.
Flores is scheduled to sign a joint communique with his ROC counterpart Chen Shui-bian before departing Taiwan Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI WINS ONE MORE MEDAL IN WORLD UNIVERSITY GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Daegu, South Korea, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan athlete representing Chinese Taipei won a silver medal Sunday in the World University Games being held in South Korea, increasing its medal tally to one gold, two silvers and two bronzes.
Chang Chiong-fang won the medal in the women's taekwondo event.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT APPRECIATES ROC-GUATEMALA RELATIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed his appreciation Sunday for the relations between the Republic of China and Guatemala, describing the Central American nation a true and faithful friend.

Speaking at a reception held at the auditorium of the state-owned Taiwan Salt Company in Tainan County, southern Taiwan, in honor of visiting Guatemalan President Alfonso Portillo, Chen said "It is necessary for us to maintain the ROC-Guatemala relationship at its best level."
In response, Portillo assured Chen that ROC-Guatemala relations will be further strengthened and he will continue to dedicate himself to promoting the ties during his present term and afterward.
Chen accompanied Portillo Sunday to tour his native Tainan County and Tainan City which has the sisterhood ties with Zacapa, native town of Portillo.

Chen also hosted a state banquet in the evening in Panchiao, Taipei County in honor of Portillo who arrived in Taiwan Wednesday to participate in the fourth summit of the heads of states and governments of the ROC, Central American nations and the Dominican Republic that wrapped up in Taipei Thursday.
Portillo is scheduled to sign a joint communique with Chen before departing Taiwan Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 25, or the 28th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1718: The city of New Orleans, named in honor of the Duke of Orleans of France, is founded.
1819: Allan Pinkerton, Scottish-born founder of the famous Pinkerton National Detective Agency in the United States, which specialized in railroad theft, is born.
1822: Sir William Herschel, the German-born English astronomer who discovered the planet Uranus in 1781, dies at the age of 84. He also cataloged more than 800 double stars and 2,500 nebulae.
1825: Uruguay declares independence from Spain.
1867: Michael Faraday, the English chemist and physicist who invented the first electrical cell (battery), dies at the age of 76.
1875: Englishman Matthew Webb makes history by becoming the first person to swim the English Channel. The 27-year-old master mariner covers the 34-km stretch from Dover to Calais in 21 hours 45 minutes.
1900: Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche, the German philosopher whose written works include "Thus Spake Zarathustra," dies at the age of 55. He reasons that Christianity's emphasis on the afterlife makes its believers less able to cope with earthly life.
1912: The Chung-kuo ke-ming tung-meng hui (Society of the Common Cause) is reorganized as the Kuomintang (Nationalist Party) and holds its inauguration meeting in Beijing.
1917: Dr. Sun Yat-sen forms a military government in Canton, southern China.
1919: The first scheduled international air service begins between Paris and London.
1921: Germany and the United States sign a peace treaty ending the state of war between them.
1930: Sean Connery, the Scottish actor who played the leading role as "007" in seven James Bond movies and won an Oscar for best supporting actor in "The Untouchables," is born.
1940: Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania are incorporated into the Soviet Union.
1943: Lord Louis Mountbatten is appointed Supreme Allied Commander in Southeast Asia.
1944: Paris is liberated when the local German commander, General von Choltitz, surrenders to the Allies, ending a four-year long ordeal that Paris and her citizens suffered at the hands of the Nazis.
1945: Vietnamese communist leader Ho Chi Minh announces the formation of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam (DRV).
1989: The spacecraft Voyager 2 beams back to earth pictures of Neptune.
1960: The Republic of China Olympic team carries a large sign reading "Under Protest" in the opening procession of the Olympic Games in Rome to protest the International Olympic Committee's ruling compelling ROC athletes to compete under the name of "Taiwan" instead of the "Republic of China."
1961: The second phase of the Yangmingshan Forum opens to study the ROC's educational and cultural issues.
1968: Lesotho Premier Leabua Jonathan arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1986: ROC-US trade talks on wine and tobacco imports open in Taipei. Both sides failed to settle disagreements on pricing and advertising for American products during the nine-day talks, and a new round of negotiations was planned.
1991: Byelorussia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1992: Niger's Prime Minister Amadou Cheiffou arrives in the ROC to advance mutual understanding between the two countries.
2001: The opposition People First Party (PFP) unveils the theme of "respect for history, acknowledgment of reality and joint efforts for peace" as the guidelines of its mainland China policy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "For God in giving life to all created things is surely bountiful to them according to their qualities. Hence the tree that is full of life He fosters and sustains, while that which is ready to fall He cuts down and destroys."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO DECIDE WHETHER TO IMPOSE FURTHER WATER RESTRICTIONS SEPT. 4

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) called an emergency "drought-fighting" meeting Monday to review the water supply situation in northern Taiwan.

Chen Shen-hsien, director of the MOEA's Water Resources Agency, said after the meeting that relevant government agencies will meet again Sept. 4 to discuss the timing for beginning the second phase of water restrictions in the Taipei-Taoyuan region.
Chen said that although there have been afternoon thundershowers in northern Taiwan in recent days, rainfall in the Feitsui Reservoir and Shihmen Reservoir areas remains limited.
If the current trends continue, Chen said, Shihmen's water level is expected to fall to 210 meters by around Sept. 5, while Feitsui's water level could drop to 130 meters by around Sept. 10.

According to current regulations, the second phase of water restrictions should be imposed in Taoyuan when the water level at Shihmen Reservoir drops to 210 meters and in the greater Taipei area when the water level at Feitsui Reservoir falls to 130 meters. Feitsui's water level stood at 136.29 meters as of noon Monday.

Against this backdrop, Chen said, the MOEA will call a "drought-fighting" meeting again Sept. 4 to decide whether to impose the second phase of water restrictions in the Taipei and Taoyuan areas. Measures to be adopted during the second phase of water restrictions include cuts in water supply to large users, such as car washes, saunas and swimming pools.
The MOEA began implemented the first phase of water restrictions in the Taipei-Taoyuan area in May, with water pressure being lowered at night to restrict water flow and save water resources.

Thanks to afternoon showers in the Keelung River area in recent days, Chen said, the Hsinshan Reservoir's water level has risen. Therefore, he said, the implementation of the third phase of water restrictions in the Keelung area will be postponed to mid-September.

If the reservoir receives more rainfall in the coming weeks, he added, the third phase of restrictions may not be implemented at all. The northern Taiwan port city began to implement the second phase of water restrictions earlier this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES UP BY 40.23 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Monday, with the weighted index moving up 40.23 points to close at 5,686.85.
Market turnover amounted to NT$94.12 billion (US$2.75 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 40.23 points to close at 5,686.85.
The bourse opened at 5,667.04 and then fluctuated between 5,686.85 and 5,626.6 during trading.

A total of 4.41 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$94.12 billion (US$2.75 billion) , a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 5.63 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$135.3 billion (US$3.96 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with plastics and chemical shares moving down 0.3 percent.

The other major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 6.3 percent, followed by cement stocks at 2.1 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.9 percent, textile issues at 1.4 percent, bank and insurance stocks and foodstuff shares, both at 1.2 percent, and electrical stocks at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 369 to 318, with 106 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CHAIRMAN TO VISIT NEW ZEALAND

TEXT.P: Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Huang Chu-wen will leave for New Zealand Tuesday for a visit aimed at promoting party-to-party diplomacy, a party spokesman said Monday.
TSU Deputy Secretary-General Chen Hung-chi said Huang will head a five-member delegation on his New Zealand visit.

During the visit, Chen said, Huang's group will meet with parliamentarians from various New Zealand political parties for wide-ranging talks, including ways to boost TSU ties with them as well as to promote Taiwan-New Zealand cooperation.
Moreover, he said, the group will attend a ceremony marking the inauguration of an association of TSU supporters in New Zealand.

Chen said the TSU will continue forging ties with major foreign political parties. "We hope to enlist more support from foreign governments and their peoples for Taiwan's cause through increased party-to-party interchanges," he added.
Earlier this year, Chen said, a high-profile TSU delegation visited Canada for similar purposes.
Chen further said associations of TSU supporters in New York and major Southeast Asian nations will be formed later this year.
Those who will accompany Huang on the New Zealand visit include Chen, Legislators Chien-Lin Huei-chun and Lo Chih-ming, as well as Lee Hsien-jen, director of the TSU's policy research department.
