DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved up 52 points to close at 5,665, with 34,148 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October gained 32 points to finish at 5,650, with 60 contract transactions, while December futures rose 99 points to close at 5,680, with 6 contracts traded.
March futures surged 238 points to finish at 5,760, with only one contract traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,613 for September, 5,618 for October, 5,581 for December, 5,522 for March, and 5,614 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
September TE futures moved up 0.6 points to close at 253.8, with 3,560 contract transactions, while October TE futures gained 0.75 points to finish at 253.9, with 5 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
September TF futures gained 9.6 points to close at 746.6, with 4,362 contract transactions, while October TF futures rose 10.2 points to finish at 747.6, with 14 contracts traded.
December TF futures rose 10 points to close at 750, with only one contract traded, while March TF futures increased 9.2 points to finish at 745, also with one contract changing hands.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TAKES PART IN CHARITY JOG IN SAN FRANCISCO

TEXT.P: Visiting Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou took part in a charity jog activity held Sunday near the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco.
The fund-raising activity for children with special needs was cosponsored by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco and the Chinese-language daily World Journal.

Ma's popularity attracted hundreds of citizens in the city with a large Chinese community to take part in the activity, with T-shirts featuring Ma's signature being one of the most popular items available.
Ma originally planned to visit the United States and Canada earlier, but his trip was postponed due to the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak which gripped Taiwan from March to June.
During his North American visit, Ma will also take part in a marathon to be held by the University of California, Berkeley next week. (by Nocturne Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: SUMMIT OF YMCA INTERNATIONAL YOUTH LEADERS OPENS IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The 2003 Summit of YMCA International Youth leaders opened in Kaohsiung Monday with 120 representatives from 17 Asian and Latin American countries and areas participating.
Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsin, and Kaohsiung YMCA President C. T. Chen attended the opening ceremony.

In the week-long meeting, the participants will exchange views on matters of mutual concern, as well as visit cultural and economic establishments in southern Taiwan, including Meinun Hakka Cultural Museum and Pingtung Aboriginal Cultural and Art Park.

The youth leaders gathered at the meeting come from Japan, Thailand, Indonesia, Burma, Hong Kong, Singapore, Mexico, Honduras, Nicaragua, Panama, Belize, Costa Rica, Bolivia, Columbia, Uruguay, Guatemala and Taiwan. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS HAS NO COMMENT ON FORMER PRESIDENT LEE'S REMARKS

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus in the Legislature said Monday it had no comment on former President Lee Teng-hui's remarks over the weekend that the Republic of China no longer exists and that the country should be renamed "Taiwan."
Chen Chi-mai, a leader of the DPP caucus, said that Lee has the freedom to express his opinions and that the DPP caucus respects Lee's remarks.

Chen said however that the DPP's position on the issue is very clear, as can be seen from the DPP's "Resolution on Taiwan's Future, " which clearly states that "Taiwan is a sovereign country, whose name is the Republic of China." (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, giving up NT$0.037 to close at NT$34.180.
A total of US$536 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$34.262 and hit a low of NT$34.167.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT RECOVERING WELL FOLLOWING HEART SURGERY

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui has been recovering well following successful heart surgery Monday, Taipei Veterans General Hospital doctors said Monday.

Lee, who underwent catheterization heart surgery two years ago, recently visited the hospital for a follow-up examination. It was discovered that his heart showed signs of myocardial ischemic -- a condition in which the heart is partially deprived of oxygen.
So Taipei Veterans General Hospital doctors performed the same surgery on Lee as two years earlier.
The 80-year-old showed up at a meeting this past Saturday during which he advocated a change to the official name of the nation from the "Republic of China" to "Taiwan."

Lee, who will serve as the chief convener of a large rally scheduled for Sept. 6 to drum up support for the "Call Taiwan, Taiwan" movement, showed no signs of illness when he delivered a 10-minute speech to the meeting participants Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD BECOME A CAPITAL-RAISING CENTER: SIEW

TEXT.P: Vincent Siew, one of Taiwan's well-known economic planners, said Monday that the government should develop Taiwan into an important center for raising capital.

Siew, chairman of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research and convener of President Chen Shui-bian's economic advisory group, made the remarks at a symposium on economy, finance and accounting sponsored by the Taiwan Hakka Forum.

He said that because of Asian economic integration, the government wants to develop Taiwan into an important business operations center in Asia. To do so, Taiwan should first develop itself into an important center for raising capital. The first step to this goal is to allow Taiwan investors in mainland China to list their stocks on Taiwan's stock exchange.

Siew said that this is his own opinion, and that the president's economic advisory group has not suggested that the president adopt the idea because other members of the group believe that there could be some undesirable side-effects of the plan.
He said the plan does have some drawbacks, but they can be eliminated by appropriate rules. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, EL SALVADOR SIGN JOINT COMMUNIQUE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and visiting El Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez signed a joint communique Monday, reaffirming their commitment to further boosting cooperative relations between the two countries.
Flores arrived in Taipei last week to attend a summit meeting of heads of state of the Republic of China and its diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean and Belize.

In the joint communique, the two presidents expressed their satisfaction with the steady progress in ROC-El Salvador relations and reiterated their determination to promote bilateral cooperation in trade, investment and other fields.

The two heads of state further said they are delighted to see the signing of a cooperative accord between El Salvador's Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council on the promotion of bilateral trade, investment and technology transfer.
The communique was signed at the Presidential Office, with senior ROC officials and members of Flores' entourage witnessing.

Before signing the communique, Chen and Flores held talks on a range of issues of mutual concern, including the global campaign against terrorism, cooperation in maintaining world peace, freedom and democracy, as well as human rights' protection.
Flores expressed his gratitude for Taiwan's long-term assistance in El Salvador's national development.
For his part, Chen said he hopes Flores will continue to speak for Taiwan's cause in the international arena, particularly its bid to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization.

During his visit, Flores visited the Taroko National Park in eastern Taiwan and the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation -- Taiwan's largest charity -- in Hualien. He also watched a performance of the Cloud Gate Dance Theater, a world-class dance ensemble founded by respected Taiwan choreographer Lin Hui-ming.
Flores said he was impressed by Taiwan's advancement in nature conservation, religious and cultural development and charitable services.
Chen said he believes Flores' visit will help cement relations and expand cooperation between Taiwan and El Salvador.

While in Taiwan, Flores also presided over a seminar on his country's general investment climate, regulations and incentives for foreign investors. He said Taiwan entrepreneurs are welcome to invest in El Salvador.
Flores wrapped up his Taiwan visit and left for home Monday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASSOCIATION OF ENGLISH-SPEAKING TAXI DRIVERS FORMED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A group of taxi drivers who have passed the Taipei City Government's English proficiency test formed an association Monday to develop a special channel for foreign passengers to get access to their services.
Chiang Hsien-chou, a founding member, said the association will also help upgrade Taiwan's national image and increase its members' revenues.

Since the city government implemented a taxi drivers' English proficiency certification program two years ago, 711 taxi drivers have passed the test and thus obtained the right to display a yellow sticker reading, "Yes, I speak English" in their car windows.
However, the small sticker has so far not helped bring more business to English-speaking taxi drivers.

"The number of foreign clients has not increased and those who need English taxi services still have no way to contact us, " Chiang said, adding that he and his friends have therefore decided to form an association to pool their wisdom and strength to improve the business prospects for English-speaking taxi drivers.

Chiang said several radio taxi groups have agreed to cooperate with his new association to increase access to foreign customers. The association will also study the feasibility of setting up special taxi stops at public places or hotels where foreign visitors converge, he added.

In a congratulatory speech delivered at the association's inaugural ceremony, Lin Chih-ying, director of the Bureau of Transportation under the Taipei City Government, said the municipal bureau will consult with the National Palace Museum to set up a special taxi stop in its complex for English- or Japanese-speaking taxi drivers.

Moreover, Lin said, the city government is considering adopting a classification system to grade taxi cabs in terms of car condition, driver's manners, service and price. "Foreign language proficiency may also be included in the evaluation," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO LAUNCH SEARCH FOR RUNAWAY FOREIGN LABORERS STARTING SEPT. 1

TEXT.P: An intensive campaign to search for runaway foreign laborers will begin Sept. 1 around the island, government sources said Monday.
The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) and the National Police Administration will join forces with city and county governments in search of runaway foreign workers, the sources said.
According to the latest CLA tallies, Taiwan has legally imported some 300,000 foreign laborers and more than 10,000 have fled their jobs and remain unaccounted for.

A Taipei County Government spokesman said the county had 41,000-plus foreign workers by the end of June this year and 388 of them had fled from their legal employers between April and June. Among the runaways, 303 were women workers and 85 were males. Most of the runaways were house maids or caregivers, the spokesman said, adding that the runaway rate was highest among Vietnamese citizens, followed by Indonesians.

The spokesman urged county residents to report to relevant authorities whenever they discover a runaway foreign laborer. "Local employers should also refrain from hiring runaway foreign workers. Otherwise, they will be fined at least NT$150,000," he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, GUATEMALA SIGN JOINT COMMUNIQUE

TEXT.P: "Small nations united can become giants, " President Chen Shui-bian told his Guatemala counterpart Alfonso Portillo Monday before the two signed a joint communique at the end of Portillo's five-day Taiwan visit.
Echoing a statement made by Portillo that minor states have to unite to make their presence felt, Chen said joining forces can turn small countries into giants.

Praising Portillo as a charismatic orator, Chen said the Guatemalan president has fascinated the host country's 23 million people with his grace. If Portillo would speak out for the Republic of China at the United Nations, it would certainly be a great boost for the ROC's bid to return to the international organization, Chen said.

In the joint communique, both Chen and Portillo gave a pat on the back to each other by admiring the other's contributions to their countries, and pledged to continue their cooperation and friendship.
On the part of the ROC, Chen promised to keep encouraging Taiwan businessmen to invest in Guatemala to create more jobs for that country, and upgrade the living standard of its people.
Meanwhile, Portillo reconfirmed his country's support for the ROC's right to join the international groups, not least its bids for access to the United Nations and the World Health Organization.

They reiterated their countries' pursuit of democracy and freedom, their determination to safeguard world peace and human development, and their believe that any regional conflicts should be solved peacefully through dialogue, and their support for the international community's efforts to wipe out terrorism.
Portillo arrived in Taiwan last Wednesday for a biennial summit on Thursday with leaders of the ROC and Central American states. He is slated to leave Taiwan late Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RESIDENTS READY TO 'MARS-GAZE'

TEXT.P: Taiwan residents are getting ready to view a once in a lifetime sight: the planet Mars as close to the Earth as it has been in around 60,000 years.
Wednesday, Mars will be 55.7 million kilometers from the earth and should be the brightest object in the night sky.
Also, on Aug. 28, the day after the closest passage, the alignment of the sun, Earth and Mars will be perfectly straight, a phenomenon called astronomical " opposition."
"If you miss this time around, " said one amateur stargazer, "you'll have a long wait for the next time. It won't be this close to Earth again until 2287."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEL ANNOUNCES ESTABLISHMENT OF R&D CENTER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Graig Barrett, the chief executive officer of Intel, announced in Taipei Monday that the company will set up a research and development center in Taiwan, the first for the company in Asia.

Barrett said that if Taiwan wants sustainable development, it has to develop high value-added industries. For this reason, Taiwan cannot rely on manufacturing industry alone, it also has to step up its research and development and education.
In other words, education is very important and it will affect the quality of life, Barrett said.

He said that R&D hopes to turn abstract creativity into substantial products, and this is the reason why Intel has promoted the cooperation between colleges and businesses, hoping to develop good products through basic research.

He also said that Taiwan has high quality education, talented people and a good industrial environment, and its achievements in the manufacturing and design of its high-technology industry is outstanding.
He noted that the computer industry couldn't find good design people in Taiwan five years ago, but now it can, showing that Taiwan is now entering a transformation period.

Speaking on the division of work on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, he noted that mainland China is the world's powerhouse for the manufacturing industry, while Taiwan's industry, making good use of the cheap cost in the mainland, has transformed itself to gain a niche in areas of innovation and design.
Barrett arrived in Taiwan Sunday and is scheduled to leave Monday evening after a whirlwind visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO EXERCISE PRUDENCE IN DEALING WITH ABORTION ISSUE: MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will exercise prudence in dealing with abortion issues, a senior official said Monday.

DOH Minister Chen Chien-jen made the remarks after an alliance formed by several religious and social welfare groups spoke against the government's plan to revise the current health law to allow married adult women to abort their pregnancies without their husbands' consent.

Under the current eugenics law, a married woman must consult with her husband and obtain his consent before abortion. Media reports said the Cabinet will draft an amendment to the current law allowing married adult women to decide on their own whether to abort.
Chen said respecting life is the DOH's ultimate health management goal. "We'll handle abortion issues with prudence," he said, without elaborating.
Meanwhile, local women's rights groups threw their support behind the Cabinet's proposal to exempt married adult women from obtaining their husbands' consent before abortion.

"The exemption doesn't mean that married women need not consult with their husbands before abortion. The proposed amendment would allow women to have the final say when their husbands' opinions differ from theirs, " said Chen Yi-ling, secretary-general of the Taipei Women's Rights Promotion Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T MULLS SCHOLARSHIPS FOR FOREIGN STUDENTS TO STUDY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education is considering providing scholarships to foreign students to encourage them to study in Taiwan, officials said Monday.

According to a plan introduced by the Ministry of Education in an inter-ministerial meeting on education reform, the officials said that at least one department, one graduate school and one course of every college must be taught in English to encourage foreign students to study in Taiwan,

The meeting was presided over by Premier Yu Shyi-kun. Officials from the ministries of education and foreign affairs, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, as well as minister without portfolio Chen Chi-nan also attended the meeting.

In such areas such as languages, electronics, electrical engineering and biomedicine, where Taiwan colleges enjoy a international competitive edge, they should at least increase 15 percent of their numbers of foreign students every year.

There are around 300 or 400 foreign students who have officially registered to study in Taiwan, and the ministry is hoping that the figure could rise to 3,000 by 2008, while students in language centers could increase 1,000 a year, and that the number will be increased from the present more than 6,000 to 12,000.
Overseas Chinese students studying in Taiwan could increase to 14,400 by 2008 from the present 10,944, according to the plan.

The participants also discussed the introduction of foreign teachers, a national conference on education development Sept. 13-14, the appropriation of retirement payment for local teachers to facilitate retirement, the 12-year compulsory education program, and the issuing of education coupons to subsidize those students for the tuition difference in public and private schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TOUTS TAIWAN'S FAVORABLE INVESTMENT ENVIRONMENT

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun touted the country's favorable investment environment and his administration's many measures taken to advance industry and business on Monday.

Speaking at a press conference called by Intel to announce its plan to set up a research center in Taiwan, the premier said Taiwan ranks fourth in the world and second in Asia in terms of its favorable environment for investment, citing an annual survey compiled by the Business Environment Risk Intelligence in Switzerland.

He said his administration deserves a significant share of the credit, because of the tax incentives it has offered to investors, the easy investment procedures which can be accomplished in one step and its plan to increase the country's research and development expenditure from 2.16 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) in 2004 to 3 percent GDP in 2008.
The government is also planning to attract multinational companies to set up 30 research and development centers in Taiwan within five years, to make Taiwan one of their foreign partners, Yu went on.
There are 42 domestic businesses which have research and development centers in Taiwan with a combined investment of more than NT$100 billion (US$2.94 billion), Yu said.

The premier didn't forget to mention the government's much-hyped five-year plan of spending NT$500 billion (US$14.74 billion) on public projects in an attempt to bolster the economy, and a program to develop mobile communications to create its own industry with an annual output of more than NT$1 trillion (US$29.41 billion) after the semiconductor and displayer-manufacture industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD DEVELOP VALUE-ADDED, KNOWLEDGE-BASED INDUSTRY: VICE PM

TEXT.P: Taiwan should develop high value-added and knowledge-based industries at a faster pace, Vice Prime Minister Lin Hsin-i said Monday.

Addressing the opening ceremony of the Cabinet's annual conference on strategies for developing industrial technologies, Lin said that Taiwan should focus on transforming and upgrading domestic industries into those that are high value-added and knowledge-based. This should be done by reaping the benefits of the manufacturing sector, which has a solid foundation, much experience, a good business environment and talented people.

Taiwan's economy has already bottomed out, given various indicators, Lin said. Moreover, the economy is expected to recover at a faster pace in the second half of this year, the vice premier, who doubles as chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), predicted.
The overseas relocation of low-end manufacturing industries, which are entering into a micro-profit era, is a global trend and is unavoidable for Taiwan, Lin stressed.

The output of Taiwan's knowledge-based service industry accounts only for 34 percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP) , far less than the 48 percent registered in Japan, 48 percent in the United States and 53 percent in Germany, Taiwan's economic tsar noted.

The manufacturing and electronic product composition industries that led Taiwan to the world economic stage in the past have been gradually replaced by those of mainland China and Southeast Asian nations given that they are relatively less skillful and easy to be imitated, he went on, adding that the average gross profit they can earn now is less than 5 percent.

The semiconductor industry, which is a knowledge-based manufacturing industry, can earn an average gross profit of more than 40 percent, while the semiconductor designing and knowledge-based service industries can make a gross profit of more than 50 percent, even more than 100 percent, he continued.

Lin encouraged domestic industries to be prepared, to seize the opportunity when it comes for making use of their professional knowledge and talents and to face global competition with results of research and development programs they have invested in, including trained, skillful manpower and intellectual properties they have created.

Some 500 representatives from government agencies, industrial and academic sectors and foreign experts are participating in the five-day meeting, which is mainly discussing strategies on the development of medical services and the health care industry, the development of strategic services industry and its supporting environment, and strategies on rooting defense technology in the private sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ENTRY INTO WHO WILL HELP GLOBAL FIGHT AGAINST SARS: VP

TEXT.P: If Taiwan can enter the World Health Organization, it will definitely help the world fight severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), Vice President Annette Lu said Monday.

Lu made the remarks when she met Rosa Lopez Garnica, chairwoman of the health committee of the Senate, and Maria Isabel San Baldomero, chairwoman of joint committees on women's rights of the Senate and Congress from Spain.

Lu noted that as the world turned its focus on the U.S.-led attacks against Iraq in March, Taiwan was being hard hit over the following two months by the potential deadly respiratory disease which claimed 84 lives in Taiwan.

Lu noted that Taiwan experienced "panic and helplessness" in dealing with the unexpected foe, not knowing where the virus came from. "Such an experience will be hard for those who have never experienced it to understand," she said.

Lu noted that SARS could resurface in the winter, and if Taiwan is admitted into the WHO, she believes that Taiwan can contribute a great deal to the global fight against the potentially deadly disease.
On issues concerning women's rights, Lu, who herself is a women's right campaigner, said that great strides have been made since she first campaigned for gender equality in 1971.

Lu cited herself as an example, saying that she is the first woman vice president through popular election in Taiwan. She also said that nearly one quarter of the Cabinet, and 22 percent of the lawmakers are women and that women also shine brilliantly in every walk of life in Taiwan.

Lopez said that her visit was mainly to understand how Taiwan dealt with SARS. As SARS is not confined to one place, and no one can escape it, she supports Taiwan's bid to join the WHO, especially because it is unjust to exclude Taiwan when the island performs well in every area.
San Baldomero also spoke on issues concerning domestic violence, the working rights of women and women's health with the vice president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROTESTS JAPANESE EXTREMISTS' MAKING LANDFALL ON TIAOYUTAI

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs asked its representative office in Tokyo Monday to file a protest with the Japanese government over the landing on the Tiaoyutai Islands, known as the Senkaku Islands to the Japanese, by a group of Japanese right wing extremists.

Calling Tiaoyutai a inalienable part of the country's territory, the ministry said the group of Japanese extremists have infringed on the country's territory, and the Japanese authorities should prevent the incident from happening again.
Nine Japanese, who come from a little-known group called Japan Youth Federation, landed on the island Monday morning to repair a beacon they erected there in 1996.
The uninhabited islands, located some 102 nautical miles northeast of Taiwan, is claimed by both mainland China, Japan and Taiwan.

The United States turned over the islands to Japan in 1971 to the outrage of mainland China and Taiwan. They protested the U.S. move but refrained from doing anything which might disrupt the ties between them.
Japanese patrol ships often sail around the islands to drive away Taiwan and Hong Kong activists who try to land on the islands to underline their countries' territorial claim to them.

In a related story Monday, a councilor from Taipei County in northern Taiwan, Kin Chie-shou, who made headlines in 1996 by trying to raise an ROC flag on the islands, vowed to try again, probably in conjunction with activists from mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN VOWS TO MAKE CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE TOP PRIORITY IF ELECTED

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, reaffirmed Monday that if elected president next year, his party's top priority will be to resume cross-strait dialogue and promote direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait.

Lien made the remarks when he received a delegation from the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) who called on Lien at his party's headquarters to learn about the KMT's trade and economic policies.

Lien said that there are already one million Taiwan businessmen and their dependents in the mainland, with Taiwan's talented individuals, capital and technology all flowing into the mainland and the government must address the cross-strait trade and shipping issues squarely.

He noted that during the KMT administration, it had actively promoted cross-strait dialogues as well as the establishment of direct trade and shipping links, adding that the original plan was direct cargo links first followed by personnel links, which he said was "feasible" and would be beneficial to both sides.

Lien spoke of the Asia and Pacific operations hub plan during the late period of the KMT administration, adding that though the plan made some adjustments due to the environment, the party still thinks it is the best blueprint that can revive Taiwan's economy, and if the KMT regains power, it will put it into practice after some revisions.

He also questioned the government's approach in striving to better the economy, saying that the ratio for private investment and private consumption accounted for up to between 70 and 80 percent of the gross domestic product, while the ratio for public spending was relatively much less.

He said that the best effective way to better the economy is to revive private confidence so that the public is willing to invest and spend, not the current approach by the government to raise the ceiling of debts to finance its public spending.

Lien noted that the "Taiwan miracle" in the past did not come from heaven, but was the result of strenuous efforts over the years. He said he hoped that if the KMT is in power again, it will make Taiwan prosper as it used to be.

ECCT members said that globalization is an unstoppable trend, and that every country has made it the top consideration when mapping out economic policy, but Taiwan's process of globalization seems to be only feet-dragging because of overemphasis on localization.

Lien responded that the biggest problem facing Taiwan's economy is that political factors take precedence over other considerations, adding that this is the reason why many financial experts, including those in his party and the KMT's ally, the People First Party, who had broached substantial proposals, had fallen on deaf ears.

Lien pointed out the other obstacle to the island's economic development comes from social problems, with the cleft between the mainlanders and the local peoples who emigrated to the island before them, as well as the controversy over the future status of the nation.

This, coupled with the widening gap between the rich and the poor, have contributed to the split of Taiwan society, Lien said, adding that national leaders should take on the responsibility to unify the people at a time like this.
After the meeting, the ECCT delegation invited Lien to speak to its chamber members next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR ON TAIWAN-U.S.-ISRAEL NATIONAL SECURITY TO OPEN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A seminar on Taiwan-United States-Israel national security will be opened Tuesday in Taipei with experts and scholars from the three countries participating, organizers said Monday.

The discussions of the two-day meeting, organized by the Institute for National Policy Research (INPR) of Taiwan, will centered on the change and prospects of the development of situations in the U.S., East Asia and Middle East in the aftermath of the U.S.-led war in Iraq, INPR officials said.

Republic of China's Vice Foreign Minister Michael Y. M. Kau and Israeli Representative to Taiwan Ruth Kahanoff have been invited to deliver key-note speeches at the opening ceremony and Douglas Paal, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan will address the luncheon party of the seminar on Tuesday.

In addition to Taiwan scholars and experts, participants of the meeting will include Banning Garrett of the Atlantic Council, Laurent Murawiec of the Hudson Institute and William Drennan of the Institute of Peace from the United States and Efraim Inbar, director of the Israeli BESA Strategic Studies Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEL RESEARCH CENTER IN TAIWAN TO FOCUS ON TELECOMMUNICATIONS

TEXT.P: The Intel Innovation Center, to be set up in Taiwan, will concentrate on the research of telecommunication and network products, according the company's chief executive official, Graig Barrett.

Barrett, who spoke Monday of the establishment of the center, said there will be 18 researchers in the primary stage, and will expand to 25 soon. Eventually the hope is to have 50 to 60 researchers, he said.
The center will work together with local universities and businesses in developing new products, said Barrett.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI WINS ONE MORE MEDAL IN WORLD UNIVERSITY GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Daegu, South Korea, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan athlete representing Chinese Taipei won a bronze medal Monday in the World University Games being held in South Korea, increasing Taiwan's medal haul to one gold, two silvers and three bronzes.
Lin Wen-cheng won the medal in the men's taekwondo event.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 26, or the 29th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1789: The French Assembly adopts the Declaration of the Rights of Man.
1850: Louis Philippe, the "Citizen King" of France who abdicated rather than face a middle-class revolt, dies.
1858: Britain and Japan sign the Treaty of Edo (Tokyo), opening up Japan to British trade.
1873: Lee De Forest, American radio and television pioneer and inventor of the Audion vacuum tube, which made broadcasting possible, is born.
1906: Albert Bruce Sabin, American microbiologist and physician, is born in Poland. He developed a live-virus vaccine against polio in 1957, replacing the killed-virus vaccine invented by Jonas Salk.
1910: American physicians verify that the X-ray, discovered in 1895 by German physicist Wilhelm C. Roentgen, can help detect lung disease.
1920: The US legislature ratifies the 19th Amendment, giving American women the right to vote.
1926: Warner Brothers, an American movie company, is successful with its premiere sound picture.
1936: Egypt and Great Britain agree to a treaty that reaffirms Egypt's independence. This treaty also reduces the number of British troops stationed in Egypt and restricts them to the Suez Canal region.
1952: The Soviet Unions announces that the first successful Intercontinental Ballistic Missile (ICBM) tests have taken place.
1961: Burma becomes the world's first Buddhist republic.
1972: Sir Francis Chichester, English yachtsman who was the first senior citizen to sail around the world alone in his 53-foot yacht in 1966, dies at the age of 71.
1974: Charles Lindbergh, American aviator who made the first solo non-stop flight across Atlantic in 1927, dies at the age of 72.
1977: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Holbrooke, US assistant secretary of state for Asian and Pacific affairs, at the Executive Yuan for a briefing on Secretary of State Cyrus Vance's trip to Peking.
1978: Cardinal Albino Luciani of Venice is elected as Pope John Paul I. He died of a heart attack on Sept. 28.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo decorates visiting vice president of the Republic of Costa Rica Jose Miguel Alfaro Rodriguez with the Order of the Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon.
1987: A sex-crazed elephant "urgently in search of a mate" runs amuck in Bangkok, killing two people and flattening a radio center.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin signs a friendship treaty with the Czech Republic after condemning the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.
1996: Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne, formally divorces Princess Diana Frances Spencer, ending 15 years of marriage.
1996: A court in Seoul sentences former President Chun Doo Hwan to death on charges of masterminding a 1979 coup and his successor, Roh Tae Woo, is sentenced to 22 years and six months in prison for playing a supporting role. Their prison terms were reduced later.
2001: Seven Democratic members of the U.S. House of Representatives write a letter to State Secretary Madeleine Albright, requesting that the State Department "take the necessary steps to end the inappropriate ban on high-level visits between elected Taiwanese officials and U.S. officials, including the democratically-elected president of Taiwan."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses exceedingly great moral qualities will certainly receive the divine call to the Imperial throne."

DOC.HEADLINE: 4 MAINLANDERS DROWN TRYING TO ENTER TAIWAN ILLEGALLY
DOC.DATELINE: Miaoli, northern Taiwan, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Four mainland Chinese drowned to death and 11 others were rescued while trying to sneak into Taiwan off Miaoli, northern Taiwan early Tuesday, coast guard officials reported.
After being tipped off that a group of mainland Chinese were aboard sampans to try to enter Taiwan illegally, the coast guard sent two cutters to try to intercept them.

The sampans were spotted in waters adjacent to the Taichung Thermal Power Plant in Tunghsiao, Miaoli, at around 4 a.m. After seeing the cutters approaching, the mainland Chinese all jumped into the sea and tried to swim to shore.
The coast guard immediately carried out rescue operations. Four bodies were found, while the rescued mainlanders were sent to Taichung for further questioning.
Coast guard forces are continuing to search waters off Taichung and Miaoli for any other mainland Chinese trying to enter Taiwan illegally.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELIGIOUS LEADERS TO PUSH U.N. TO SET UP INTERRELIGION COUNCIL

TEXT.P: More than 200 local religious leaders and social celebrities met in Taipei Tuesday to map out concrete measures to push the United Nations to set up an interreligion council for world peace.
The meeting was cosponsored by the ROC Chapter of the Interreligious and International Federation for World Peace (IIFWP) and the Taipei-based International Culture Foundation (ICF).
ICF Chairman Huang Shih-cheng said the establishment of an interreligion council under the U.N. framework will facilitate the world body's work in promoting world peace.

"We believe that the United Nations should take more active steps to protect the younger generations from the scourge of war and that the formation of an interreligion council under the U.N. framework will contribute to the realization of this ultimate goal, " Huang said.

Buddhist Master Ching Hsin said religious harmony is yet another "Taiwan miracle" after its economic and political miracles. "We ought to better use our experience in interreligion cooperation in helping other peoples and countries in promoting harmony and world peace," he noted.
Rev. Dr. Christopher B. Kim, president of the IIFWP Korean Chapter, also attended the meeting to explain some technical details regarding the proposed U.N. Interreligion Council.
