DOC.HEADLINE: CAL ENGINE DEAL WON'T AFFECT TAIWAN-BRITISH TIES: MOFA

TEXT.P: The row over China Airlines' (CAL's) decision to procure engines from U.S.-based General Electric (GE) for its aircraft will not affect substantive relations between Taiwan and Britain, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.
Chu Chien-sung, deputy director of the MOFA's European Affairs Department, said the CAL engine deal is small in comparison to the value of total annual trade between Britain and Taiwan.
Noting that substantive Taipei-London ties are cordial in many other fields, Chu said that the CAL deal was an isolated case and that it would not have an impact on bilateral relations.

Chu was commenting on reports that the European Union has lodged a protest aimed at CAL -- Taiwan's largest air carrier -- for its failure to purchase engines from Rolls Royce of Britain, an E.U. member state.
Chu said CAL has offered explanations of the reasons behind its decision to purchase engines from General Electric (GE) instead of Rolls Royce for its 18 newly-ordered aircraft.
The MOFA will also assist in communicating with British authorities to secure their understanding of CAL's reasoning and to minimize any possible backlash, Chu said.

As to media reports that Britain may seek a settlement through the World Trade Organization's trade dispute arbitration mechanism, Chu said Britain must first have justifiable reasons to file such an application. It is still too premature to forecast future developments in this respect, he added.
CAL said last week that its decision to purchase GE engines was based purely on commercial considerations.

"We had conducted comprehensive evaluations and extensive discussions with the three competitors -- GE, Pratt & Whitney and Rolls Royce -- before coming to a final decision earlier this month," CAL said in a press statement released last Friday.
"We believe that the terms offered by GE best serve our interests, and all three competitors were given a fair opportunity in the negotiation process," the statement stressed.

Meanwhile, a CAL spokesman said earlier that the company has never discriminated against E.U. products. For instance, the airline said it decided to purchase 12 A330-300 jetliners late last year from Airbus, which is jointly invested in by four E.U. nations, including Britain.

He pointed out that CAL's latest decision to purchase GE engines for the 12 A330-300 and six Boeing B747-400 jetliners was based on engine quality, price, follow-up maintenance support and technology transfer terms.
"GE excelled in all categories and provided other benefits, including handling the last B747-200 all-cargo aircraft in our fleet," the spokesman said.

He further said that although Pratt & Whitney also failed to secure the contract, it sent a letter to CAL President Wei Hsing-hsiung last week recognizing the fairness of CAL's engine procurement negotiations.
Delivery for the 12 A330-300s and six B747-400s that CAL ordered in late 2002 will begin in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONVINCED TAIWAN'S WISH TO JOIN WHO TO BE FULFILLED SOON

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday he is convinced that the Republic of China's wish to enter the World Health Organization (WHO) will soon be fulfilled after domestic efforts and stronger support from the international community.
The president made the remarks when receiving more than 30 members of a delegation comprised of overseas Chinese medical professionals at the Presidential Office.

The president noted that Taiwan spent 12 years working to be admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO), which it achieved in January 1, 2002, but he said he is convinced that "so long as we don't give up, it will take much less time to achieve its goal of entering the WHO."
Taiwan's attempts to join the WHO as an observer were foiled this May at the World Health Assembly -- the top decision-making body of the WHO -- for the seventh straight year.

The president said that Taiwan faced an unprecedented challenge after being hit by severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) earlier this year. He noted that the island was finally removed from the WHO's list of SARS-affected areas July 5 thanks to people in Taiwan and abroad who made a great contribution to combating the potentially deadly respiratory disease. SARS claimed a total of 84 lives in Taiwan.

He noted that the most regrettable part for the Taiwan people in combating SARS was the island's being shut out of the WHO due to Beijing's obstruction, which he said made Taiwan's fight against the disease harder than that of most other countries.

The president said he is convinced that the issues of health and communicable disease prevention are borderless, stressing that political considerations should not be put before humanitarian causes or respect for human life.

Although noting that Taiwan's bid to enter the WHO suffered another blow this year, the president said that compared with previous years, Taiwan's cause won more sympathy and support. He also noted that nine diplomatic allies, including Palau, Honduras, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Gambia, Belize, the Dominican Republic, Senegal and Panama, spoke in support of Taiwan's bid.
He added that U.S. Secretary of Health and Human Services Tommy G. Thompson sent a letter to the WHO and later expressed strong
support for Taiwan's bid to join the WHO as an observer in the May conference.

While welcoming the delegation of overseas Chinese medical professionals, Chen expressed the hope that the members will learn more about Taiwan's process in its battle against SARS during their stay in Taiwan.

He added that the government had asked all health institutions to map out standard procedure operations for dealing with communicable diseases so as to be fully prepared in the event of a resurgence of SARS this winter.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE,

TEXT.P: Six mainland Chinese drowned and four others are still missing at sea after a group of 22 mainlanders in two speedboats tried entering Taiwan illegally early Tuesday, coast guard officials said.
The coast guard said that after they were tipped off the attempt, they sent two cutters to the waters off Tunghsiao, Miaoli, at around 4a.m. to try to intercept the speedboats.

The captains of the two speedboats, after spotting the approaching coast guard cutters, forcefully pushed the mainland Chinese women into the sea before speeding away. The coast guard immediately started rescue operations.
Among the 12 rescued, two were in serious condition when they were pulled out of the sea. One was rushed to a hospital in Miaoli County and the other to a hospital in Taichung County.

When questioned, the rescued mainland women claimed they had been tricked into boarding the speedboats, saying the smuggling ring leaders told them that they could make a lot of money working in Taiwan. They had no food or water for three days at sea.
The smuggling fee was around NT$200,000 (US$5,882) for each person, which they were to pay back with money made working in Taiwan, the women said.
The coast guard has temporarily placed the six bodies of the drowned mainlanders in a mortuary in Tachia, Taichung County.
Prosecutors are continuing investigations to find out who was on the two speed boats that carried the mainland Chinese.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MILITARY TO CONDUCT COMBINED SERVICES LIVE-FIRE EXERCISE: MND

TEXT.P: The military will conduct a combined services live-fire combat training drill in Ilan County's coastal Litze township Sept. 1, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) announced Tuesday.

The drill, part of the Han Kuang No. 19 exercise, is designed to test the ROC armed forces' combined services defense capabilities and the performance of various weaponry systems, MND spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said.
The Han Kuang series of exercises is Taiwan's largest military training drill of the year.

Huang said the combined services drill was originally scheduled for mid-May. "Due to the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreak in Taiwan between March and June this year, the drill has been rescheduled for Sept. 1," he explained.

The upcoming drill will test the three service branches' combined combat prowess in air, sea and amphibious operations, Huang said, adding that the live-fire exercise will also verify the feasibility or adaptability of various defense strategies and combat programs.
"The findings will serve as a reference in our future military deployment, combat training programs and weaponry research and development," Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 369 FOREIGN ENGLISH TEACHERS TO BE INTRODUCED NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) will introduce 369 foreign English teachers into the school system next year to upgrade the quality of English teaching in Taiwan, an education official said Tuesday.

Based on an annual salary of NT$996,000 for each of the 369 foreign teachers -- to come from the United Kingdom, the United States, Australia and Canada -- the cost to the government will be NT$367.83 million for the year.

Minister of Education Huang Jung-chun pointed out that the MOE's international cultural and educational relations bureau will work with representative offices of foreign governments in Taiwan on the "country to country" principle in introducing the foreign teachers.

Among the 369 teachers, a total of 97 will be assigned to the counties of Chiayi, Kaohsiung and Taichung, while a total of 31 will be sent to the counties of Taitung, Hualien, Kinmen and Lianjiang, according to Huang.
The English teachers will first take a one-month class in Taiwan to learn more about the culture and education situation in order to enable them to adapt more quickly to their new environment.

Meanwhile, Chen Ming-ying, deputy director of the MOE's Department of Elementary Education, stressed that introducing foreign English teachers into the school system will not affect the employment opportunities for local English teachers. (by Nocturne Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index moving down 128.6 points to close at 5,558.25, due mainly to reports that government funds are expected to retreat from the market by the end of this year.
The bourse opened at 5,656.07 and then fluctuated between 5,656.07 and 5,542.43 during the trading session.

A total of 4.24 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$93.77 billion (US$2.72 billion) , a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 4.41 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$94.12 billion (US$2.75 billion).

All eight of the major stock categories lost ground, with cement shares moving down the most at 3.1 percent, followed electrical stocks at 3.0 percent, construction issues at 2.4 percent, pulp and paper stocks at 1.7 percent, financial issues at 1.2 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 0.9 percent, and textile issues at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 627 to 107, with 63 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for September moved down 85 points to close at 5,580, with 38,900 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October lost 80 points to finish at 5,570, with 106 contract transactions, while December futures fell 135 points to close at 5,545, with eight contracts traded.
Next March futures lost 180 points to finish at 5,580, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,665 for September, 5,650 for October, 5,680 for December, 5,760 for next March, and 5,666 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
September TE futures decreased 6.95 points to close at 246.85, with 4,573 contract transactions, while October TE futures lost 7.6 points to finish at 246,3, with 13 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
September TF futures moved down 4.6 points to close at 742, with 2,914 contract transactions, while October TF futures fell 13.4 points to finish at 737, with 14 contracts changing hands.
December futures fell 7.8 points to finish at 735, with only one contract traded, while Next March TF futures lost 10.4 points to finish at 735, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.014 to close at NT$34.194.
A total of US$565 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$34.214 and hit a low of NT$34.151.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS TAIWANESE COMPANIES ALLOWED ACCESS TO TAIWAN STOCK EXCHANGE

TEXT.P: International corporations invested by Taiwanese businessmen overseas wishing to raise capital from the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TSE) should set up new companies in Taiwan and apply to the Securities and Futures Commission for first listing, a commission official said Tuesday.

The official said that Taiwanese-invested companies in mainland China or other countries may also raise capital from the TSE through the issuance of Taiwan Depository Receipts (TDRs) , under the condition that they are already first-listed companies in the following 16 stock exchanges -- namely the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange (AMEX) , NASDAQ, London, Frankfurt, Pan-Europe in Paris and Amsterdam, Italy, Toronto, Australia, Tokyo, Osaka, Singapore, Kuala Lumpur, Thailand and Johannesburg.

He added, however, companies listed on the stock exchange of Hong Kong are not entitled to the "secondary listing" practice, due to the complications involving companies with mainland Chinese capital.

Currently, the ASE Test listed on the New York Stock Exchange, Eastern Asia Technology and the Medtecs International Corporation listed on the Singapore Stock Exchange have issued TDRs and the CAL-COMP electronics listed on the Stock Exchange of Thailand is expected to become a TDRs issuer by Sept. 22.

A TSE spokesman said that the stock exchange is encouraging Taiwanese-invested companies based overseas to set up investment holding companies in Taiwan and apply for securities listing on the Taiwan Stock Exchange.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SECURITIES DEPOSITORY CO. SIGNS MEMORANDUM WITH DTCC IN N.Y.

TEXT.P: Executives of the Taiwan Securities Central Depository Co. (TSCD) and the New York-based Depository Trust and Clearing Corp. (DTCC) signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) in New York Monday evening for the exchange of information on clearance and settlement services for equities, bonds and securities, a TSCD spokesman said Tuesday.
The spokesman said that the TSCD will send two groups of its staff to New York next month to receive clearance services training at DTCC headquarters.

TSCD is hoping to learn from the DTCC's risk control experiences in integrating the settlement and clearance of eight stock exchanges in the United States, including the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange, NASDAQ, and the Chicago Stock Exchange.
The signing ceremony was witnessed by Minister of Finance Lin Chuan, who is heading an investment promotion mission on a week-long visit to the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW VERSION OF ROC PASSPORT TO BE ISSUED FROM SEPT. 1 AS SCHEDULED

TEXT.P: The new version of the Republic of China passport will be issued from Sept. 1 as scheduled despite claims by mainland China's official media that some countries will refuse to accept the new version of the passport, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman said Tuesday.

Richard Shih said that most countries have expressed their intention to work with the new version of the passport which will display the word "Taiwan" in addition to the official national designation of "the Republic of China" on its cover.

Shih said that the purpose of adding the word "Taiwan" is to help customs officials of other countries better distinguish between citizens from Taiwan and those from mainland China. He said the move is meant to make customs clearance more convenient for Taiwan people when they travel to other countries.
He said that other than the addition of the word "Taiwan, " the new version of the passport is completely the same as the current version.
He stressed that as an independent sovereign state, the ROC has the right to issue passports.

He also said that following communications with other countries regarding the issue, major countries, including Japan, the United States and the member states of the European Union, have expressed their intention to work with the new version of the passport.

He would not confirm reports by Beijing's Xinhua News Agency that Afghanistan and Pakistan will refuse entry to carriers of the new version of the ROC passport, nor would he speak on the government's contingency plans in the event that the passport holders are refused entry into those countries.
He only said that the ministry "will continue to communicate with certain countries, " and that the new version of the passport will be issued as scheduled on Sept. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIL DEFENSE DRILL TO BE HELD IN NORTHERN TAIWAN AUG. 29

TEXT.P: This year's "wan-an" civil defense drill will be held in northern Taiwan Friday and in other parts of the island in the second half of October, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) announced Tuesday.
MND spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said the "wan-an" series of civil defense drills are aimed at testing city and county governments' emergency response and disaster relief operations.

This year's drill will be for the first time led by city and county governments, with the military playing a supporting role, Huang said, adding that mayors and magistrates are allowed to organize the maneuvers in terms of their unique regional demands.
A total of 11 cities and counties as well as 117 public agencies and private groups will take part in the exercise, Huang said.

"The series of drills will test local governments' vertical command and horizontal coordination capabilities," Huang said, adding that anti-terrorist operations will be included in the training program.
On Friday Aug. 29, the "wan-an" civil defense drills will be held in Taipei city and county, Keelung City, Hsinchu city and county, Taoyuan County and Ilan County.

In metropolitan Taipei, the drill will focus on rescuing hostages held by terrorists at the Shin Kong Building -- a skyscraper near the Taiwan Railway Station in downtown Taipei and handling explosives supposedly hidden there as well as a simulated poison gas attack on the city's mass rapid transit system.

In Ilan, the exercise will center on response to terrorist attacks on an oil depot in Suao; drills in Keelung and Taoyuan will feature response to sabotage to a major power generation plant and a water purification facility.

Meanwhile, a mock anti-terrorist operation at the Formosa Plastics Group's petrochemical complex in Yunlin County's Mailiao township on Taiwan's southwestern coast will be held Thursday afternoon, Huang said, adding that local government officials and industry executives will be invited to watch the exercise.

Similar anti-terrorist, anti-sabotage and anti-abduction drills at selected public places and facilities in central, southern and eastern Taiwan as well as on the frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu will be conducted from mid-October through the end of the month, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIAOYUTAIS ARE PART OF ROC TERRITORY: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reiterated Tuesday that the Tiaoyutai Islets are traditionally part of the Republic of China's territory.

Richard Shih, director-general of the MOFA's Department of Information and Cultural Affairs, made the claim when commenting on the landing on the Tiaoyutais by a group of Japanese right wing extremists a day earlier.

Shih said that the MOFA instructed its representative office in Tokyo to file a protest with the Japanese government over the incident and asked the Japanese authorities to prevent a similar one from happening again.

The Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan then delivered a letter of protest Tuesday in Tokyo to the Interchange Association of Japan, expressing the ROC government's stance on the Tiaoyutais and its concern over the landing on the islets by nine members of the Japan Youth Federation, which it said infringed on the ROC's territory.
The Interchange Association of Japan represents Japanese interests in dealing with the ROC during the absence of diplomatic ties between the two countries.
The uninhabited Tiaoyutai Islets, known as the Senkaku Islands to the Japanese and located some 102 nautical miles northeast of Taiwan, are claimed by both mainland China, Japan and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHOENIX SETS UP WORLD'S LARGEST CORE SYSTEM SOFTWARE CENTER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: American software firm Phoenix Technologies Ltd. expanded its investment in Taiwan Tuesday by establishing the world's largest core system software (CSS) research center in the island aimed at training more Taiwanese in basic input and output systems (BIOS).

A cocktail party was held in Taipei to celebrate the establishment of its CSS center in Taiwan, in which Phoenix Chairman and CEO Albert E. Sisto, Republic of China Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i, and director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan Douglas H. Paal attended.
Sisto noted that the company aims to make Taiwan the global base for BIOS research and an R&D center for the new generation of personal computers.

Explaining why the company chose Taiwan, Sisto pointed to the earlier access to markets and to new technology information offered on the island. He added that Phoenix's presence represents a win-win strategy both for his company and for Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Phoenix Taiwan general manager Jack Huang noted that the company's decision to set up the CSS research center in Taiwan, which has generous computer systems and abundant semiconductor manufacturers, was due to the need to meet the needs of clients and partners, as well as reducing the time for the introduction of a new product onto the market.
Phoenix's establishment of the CSS research center in Taiwan represents its recognition of the information technology industry and economic development prospects in Taiwan, Huang added.

Founded in 1979, Phoenix, the supplier of 80 percent of BIOS in the world, helped launch the digital revolution when it created the industry's leading machine-independent BIOS software, which ships in more than 100 million new systems each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' LAUNCHES SIGNATURE DRIVE AGAINST HIGH TUITION

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) kicked off a signature campaign Tuesday aimed at stealing some of the thunder from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The KMT and PFP legislative caucuses called a joint news conference where they announced the start of the signature campaign against what they see as overly high university tuitions and double hikes in national health insurance premiums and outpatient self-payments.

Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan, who concurrently serves as chief executive of the KMT's Central Policy Coordination Committee, said the signature campaign is also designed to vent public discontent at the rising unemployment rate.

"We hope to collect at least one million signatures from all over Taiwan within a week's time through promotions by 'pan-blue' lawmakers, city and county government chiefs, councilors, township chiefs, borough wardens and social group leaders," Tseng said.

The campaign will close Sept. 4 and the results of the petition drive will be presented to President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Yu Shyi-kun to push them to "listen to the voice of grassroots people, " Tseng explained.

Speaking on the same occasion, PFP legislative whip Chung Shao-ho claimed that the DPP administration's inexperience and incompetence have led to high unemployment, high college tuitions and hikes in health insurance fees.

"The signature campaign is a 'static form' of protest, " Chung said, adding that the alliance has no plan to take to the streets at the moment as it would not like to cause public disorder and social instability.
Nevertheless, Chung said, the "pan-blue alliance" hopes the DPP administration will make a positive response to the petition.
The alliance's two top leaders -- KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong -- will team up to challenge President Chen Shui-bian's re-election bid next March.
Commenting on the signature campaign, DPP legislative whip Chen Chi-mai said the "pan-blue alliance" need not launch such a petition as it controls the majority of seats in the Legislative Yuan.
"They can initiate amendments to current laws or budget cuts in case they truly oppose high tuition fees and double hikes in national health insurance fees," Chen said.

"It's really weird for the 'pan-blue alliance' to launch a signature campaign against high tuitions while opposing the legislation of a referendum bill to let ordinary citizens express their opinions on major policy issues, " Chen said. "I simply cannot understand the logic behind its thinking."
Legislator Yeh Yi-chin, who is also director of the DPP's women's affairs department, said the previous KMT administration was to blame for the rise in college and university tuitions.

Under the KMT administration, Yeh said, the number of colleges and universities around the island registered a 114 percent increase, resulting in a dilution of educational resources and a rise in tuition fees.

As to the health insurance fee hikes, Yeh reminded the "pan-blue alliance" that 80 percent of local residents have expressed satisfaction with the national health insurance program and that its efficiency ranks second in the world.
Yeh also blamed the KMT for the high unemployment rate as it was the previous KMT administration that opened the local job market to foreign laborers.

As for the "pan-blue alliance's" proposal to collect capital gains taxes, Yeh said the KMT chairman will be the first target subject to the tax. Yeh claimed that Lien had dodged inheritance tax payments for the more than NT$20 billion in assets he inherited from his late father.

DOC.HEADLINE: SARS PREVENTION MECHANISM TO BE IMPLEMENTED IN SEPTEMBER: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Various hospitals in Taiwan will coordinate their efforts from September to prevent and control severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) should the disease make a reappearance on the island, the head of the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) said Tuesday.

Su I-jen said that the CDC has laid out a plan for establishing a SARS prevention network around the nation with 19 hospitals designated for exclusively treating patients with the flu-like atypical pneumonia.
The hospitals will take on their SARS-fighting posture if the potentially deadly disease is detected again in Taiwan, Su noted.
Also, he added, health authorities will start a nationwide anti-flu vaccination program Sept. 15 for senior citizens aged over 65 to avoiding possible mistakes in diagnosing potential SARS patients.

The disease, which gripped mainland China, Hong Kong, Vietnam, Singapore, Canada and Taiwan between March and June this year, claimed more than 800 lives around the world, 84 in Taiwan. Health experts are concerned about a SARS relapse this winter.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI KEEN TO HAVE SUNGSHAN AIRPORT TO SERVE DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT LINKS

TEXT.P: The central government should include Taipei Sungshan Airport in its initial stage to open direct cross-Taiwan Strait transport links after Taiwan and mainland China have agreed upon such ties, Taipei City Government spokesman Wu Yu-sheng said Tuesday.

Wu made the remarks as part of the city government's response to an assessment published by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) in mid-August about the impact on Taiwan of opening direct transport services across the Taiwan Strait, in which the Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport was designated by the MAC as the only airport in the north of the island that would be suitable for such links.

Claiming that Sungshan Airport is the only option to allow Taiwan businessmen to travel between the two sides of the Strait within just one day, Wu said the government's failure to include the airport to serve direct cross-strait transport links in its plan will greatly damage businessmen's advantages.

Wu said the Taipei City Government will continue seeking to include the Sungshan Airport in its direct links proposal, in cooperation with the CKS International Airport near Taipei to transport cargo and personnel between Taiwan and mainland China.
To combine Sungshan Airport and the CKS Airport in northern Taiwan to conduct the much hoped for direct cross-strait transport links will much better serve the country's interests, Wu claimed.

MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Sungshan Airport was out of the question for inclusion in the plan because of national security concerns, prompting Taipei municipal authorities to say that such an arrangement will greatly hamper Taipei's development and its international competitiveness.

Citing the results of a recent public opinion survey of residents in the Taipei and Keelung areas, Wu said 68 percent of the respondents agreed on opening the direct transport links, while 50.7 percent said they were aware of the designation of the CKS Airport.

At the same time, more than 50 percent of the people surveyed favored using Sungshan Airport as the link in direct air travel with mainland China, while 51 percent did not think that opening Sungshan Airport would be more dangerous than using the CKS Airport.

Some 30 percent of the public contended that direct transport links will have an impact on Taiwan's national security, while 39.3 percent believed that such ties will help forge peace between the two sides.
About 50 percent thought that Taiwan's global competitiveness will be sharpened, ahead of the 30 percent who thought Taiwan's industries will be hollowed out, according to the result of the survey.

According to Lin Sheng-tsung, director of the municipal Bureau of Commerce and Economy, 67 percent of the overseas Chinese-funded companies, 83 percent of the foreign business groups and 49 enterprises base their headquarters in Taipei.

They are the prime targets to be served by the links and direct cross-strait traffic convenience will be their top concern when deciding whether to keep their roots in Taiwan or make Taiwan their mainland Chinese market management center, he noted.
As northern Taiwan has a much stronger demand for direct cross-strait transport, Sungshan Airport will help businessmen save at least two and a half hours in travel time over the CKS Airport.

Lin Cheng-hsiu, director of the Municipal Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, stressed that using Sungshan Airport and the CKS Airport to carry cargo and personnel across the Strait will create a "win-win" situation for Taiwan, as the CKS Airport is nearing its capacity saturation point.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OFFICIAL ATTENDS SEMINAR IN MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Gueilin, China, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By C. L. Tseng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: More than 30 specialists and scholars from Taiwan, including a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official, are currently in Gueilin in southwestern China attending a seminar on cross-Taiwan Strait ties that opened Tuesday.

Legislator Chen Chung-hsin, who concurrently heads the DPP's mainland Chinese affairs department, kept a low profile at the meeting and is not scheduled to present any paper for discussion. Chen is reputed to be one of the most vocal advocates in the DPP of forging ties with mainland China.
Before coming to Gueilin, Chen visited Nanjing where he reportedly met with officers of the Nanjing Military Region and other mainland officials for exchanges of views on matters of mutual concern.
The three-day Gueilin seminar will focuses on topics related to the current state and future prospects of cross-strait exchanges in political, economic, cultural and other fields.

Wang Zaixi, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under mainland China's State Council, said at the opening session that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should start negotiations for opening direct trade, postal and transportation links, commonly known as the "three links," as early as possible.
Claiming that the "three links" are economic issues, Wang said negotiations should be simplified and need not touch on such thorny issues as the "one China" definition.
He urged Taiwan authorities to show sincerity to "three links" negotiations by shelving disputes over the "one China" principle.

ROC President Chen Shui-bian has on many occasions said Taiwan is unlikely to negotiate "three links" with mainland China under Beijing's cherished "one China" principle which downgrades the Republic of China to a province under Beijing's jurisdiction.

Meanwhile, Tang Shubei, director of the Beijing-based Cross-Taiwan Strait Relations Research Center, also said at a seminar held in Guangzhou that "three links" negotiations need not involve the "one China" principle because they are purely economic issues.
Tang said "three links" negotiations should not be postponed until after Taiwan's next presidential election to be held March 20, 2004.
"Since opening direct 'three links' will benefit to both sides, negotiations should kick off as early as possible," he urged.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO START TALKS ON RESUMING EMPLOYMENT OF MAINLAND SAILORS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said Tuesday it will negotiate with mainland Chinese authorities in September for resuming employment of mainland Chinese fishery workers as early as possible.
COA Vice Chairman Lee Chien-chuan made the remarks after three Taiwan crew members aboard a Pingtung-based fishing boat were allegedly killed by their Indonesian colleagues late last month.
Lee said the COA will review the policy of hiring foreign fishery workers and bar foreigners with previous criminal records from working on Taiwan-registered fishing boats.

"We'll also ask exporting countries to offer pre-job training for those who will work aboard Taiwan-owned fishing vessels," Lee said, adding that the COA will also step up leadership training programs for local fishing ship skippers.

The Taiwan fishing vessel, the Chan Cheng Tsung, disappeared after leaving the Pacific island of Guam late last month. Indonesian police found it abandoned near the island of Java last week. A search in Java turned up four Indonesian and two mainland Chinese crew members, but the three Taiwanese on board, including its captain, had disappeared.
"Police in Java say the Indonesian crew members killed the Taiwanese three days after leaving Guam," Lee said, adding that the motive for the killings is still not clear.

Lee said the Indonesians were believed to have thrown the bodies of the Taiwan crewmen overboard. The four Indonesians and the two mainland Chinese have been detained for questioning in Indonesia, he said.
"We want foreign fishing workers to be investigated for criminal records before they can be employed," Lee said. It was not clear if the four Indonesians had previous criminal records.
Lee said the ROC government will ask Indonesian authorities through diplomatic channels to make further probes into the case.

"The COA will also help the families of the three Taiwan crew members handle relevant affairs and offer them financial aid," Lee said, adding that each family will receive at least NT$1.25 million in relief funds.

As young Taiwan people dislike to work aboard fishing vessels, local shipowners have relied heavily on foreign crews. According to COA tallies, Taiwan fishing vessels have hired a total of 37,000 foreign sailors, with 30,000 of them working on deep-sea fishing trawlers. And about 24,000 of them come from mainland China while the others are from the Philippines, Indonesia and Vietnam.
Last year, the skippers and first engineers aboard two Taiwan fishing boats were killed by their Indonesian crew members.

Local shipowners have been forced to hire Indonesian sailors after mainland China banned exports of fishery workers to Taiwan last February. Local skippers dislike employing Vietnamese workers because they were allegedly lazy and inferior in fishing skills. Philippine sailors were also unwelcome as they were prone to brawling after drinking.

As Taiwan has agreed to improving treatment for mainland fishery workers, mainland Chinese authorities have invited local fishery associations to visit the mainland in the near future to discuss manpower export issues.

Local shipowners like to hire mainland workers because they speak the same language and have a common cultural background. "We hope the mainland export ban can be lifted as early as possible," a Tungkang fishery association executive said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN AFFIRMS SUCCESS OF VP LU'S RECENT OVERSEAS TRIP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian affirmed Tuesday the success of Vice President Annette Lu's recent overseas trip, which took her to the United States, Panama and Paraguay.

Speaking at the weekly Central Standing Committee meeting of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in his capacity as party chairman, Chen said that the vice president had successfully conveyed Taiwan's willingness to share its experiences in its democratic and economic development with its allies.
Chen said that Taiwan is willing to continue to provide assistance in the fields of social welfare, agriculture technology and medicine to its allies.
Taiwan and its allies share the common values of democracy, peace and prosperity which constitute a solid foundation for bilateral relations, Chen noted.

Chen cited the just-concluded fourth summit of heads of state and governments of the Republic of China, Central American nations, the Dominican Republic and Belize in Taipei to show that Taiwan's relations with its Central American and Caribbean allies have been further strengthening.

The one-day summit, held Aug. 21 in Taipei, drew together President Chen and his counterparts from Guatemala, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Costa Rica and Panama, and Belize Prime Minister Said Musa, Honduras Vice President Alberto Diaz Lobo, and Sergio Grullon, Minister of the Presidency of the Dominican Republic to discuss various topics on multilateral and bilateral cooperation programs, including the promotion of trade, investment, tourism and environmental protection.

Chen also thanked Taiwan's allies for their support in the international arena, particularly voicing support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization in this year's World Health Assembly in May in spite of tremendous pressure by Beijing to refrain from doing so. "The people of Taiwan will remember their support," he affirmed.

Taiwan is willing to participate in international activities and assume its responsibility and obligations to the international community when its sovereignty, security and dignity are safeguarded, Chen emphasized.

During her trip, dubbed the "tour of the democratic Pacific" Aug. 7- 20, Lu visited the United States and Panama on her way to and from Paraguay where she attended the inauguration of President Nicanor Duarte on behalf of President Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS BEST PARTNER OF LARGE COMPANIES: ROC VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan has become an indispensable partner to large international companies as can be seen by the establishment of a research center on the island by the American software company Phoenix Technologies Ltd., Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i said Tuesday.

Lin made the remarks at an opening ceremony for Phoenix's core system software (CSS) research center in Taiwan. With this center, the American company will gradually transfer their technology in this field into Taiwan.
Noting that Taiwan has become a global base for products and services, Lin said that the country is also the third-largest information hardware producer in the world.

Lin noted that Phoenix, the supplier of 80 percent of basic input/output systems (BIOS) in the world, has suffered in the last three months a 30-to-40 percent drop in revenues in other areas in the world, except in Taiwan, where it enjoyed a 53 percent growth.
Taiwan's excellent engineers and its highly developed knowledge-based industries prompted Phoenix to set up the world's largest CSS research center on the island, Lin said.

Meanwhile, the Information Service Industry Association of the ROC's honorary chairman Weng Cheng-hsiung said that although Taiwan's software production has lagged that of its hardware production, it still saw two-digit growth in recent years.

Furthermore, the ROC government has allocated NT$40 billion (US$1.16 billion) in its plan to modernize its electronics infrastructure, providing the software industry with abundant opportunities, Weng added.
He noted that Taiwan's software industry will focus on three main categories in the future -- wireless communications, digital content and information appliances.
While a bit weak in the field of wireless communications, Taiwan has good hold on the digital content and information appliances sectors, according to Weng.

With a R&D budget accounting for 3 percent of its gross domestic product and talented individuals, Taiwan is expected to continue playing a key role in the global science and technology industry, Weng added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT PROMOTING DIGITAL CONTENT INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan is eagerly promoting the value-added digital content industry, which is capable of creating a production value worth at least NT$370 billion (US$10.73 billion) and offering 40,000 job opportunities within three years, a government official said Tuesday.

Jerry J. R. Ou, deputy director-general of the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, made the remarks at a 2003 strategic meeting on promoting promising key industries, which focused on the information service and digital content industries.
The two high value-added industries have been touted by the government as the centerpiece in its flagship "two-trillion, two-star" project.

Statistics compiled by a task force under the economics ministry show that production value generated by 1,681 companies in the domestic digital content industry reached NT$153.7 billion last year. It is forecast that the figure may hit NT$370 billion for 2006, with the number of companies growing to 3,000 and the number of employees increasing to 70,000.
However, Ou pointed out that the domestic industry has encountered many difficulties with funding and has so far failed to succeed in forging joint ventures with other sectors.

To achieve this goal, the economics ministry is seeking assistance from a fund under the control of the Executive Yuan and other interested industries to help various Taiwan-based companies with the potential of producing world-class products to set up joint cooperative ventures.

These ventures include the production of several major animation films and video games with well-known leading international companies, such as NEC Interchannel, SO-NET and Plnet/NHK, according to Ou.

At the same time, the government also plans to sponsor seven investment seminars next year in an effort to secure joint ventures worth over NT$4 billion and lure billions worth of investments from the private sector with the financial help of the fund under the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REITERATES GOVERNMENT'S DETERMINATION TO REV UP ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun reiterated Tuesday his Cabinet's determination to stimulate Taiwan's economy and called on the private sector to join the government's efforts.

Addressing the congress of the Taiwan Federation of Industry Association, Yu said that his Cabinet has laid out various programs for national economic development, including the six-year national development plan "Challenge 2008" and that their implementation has produced good results which demonstrate that the policies taken by the government are on the right track.

The government is stimulating the country's economic development and helping transform and upgrade domestic industries to produce innovative and high value-added products in the face of increasing international competition, Yu said.

The announcement of the United States chip giant Intel's intention to establish a research center in Taiwan a day earlier proves that the government's policies and efforts have won international recognition, the premier continued.

However, Yu said that his Cabinet is not satisfied with the achievements it has made in revving up the country's economy and that it will do more to help increase domestic industries' competitiveness.

Intel chief executive officer Craig Barrett announced Monday in Taipei that his company will set up a research center in Taiwan which will have 18 researchers in the primary stage, and will expand to 25 soon. Eventually the hope is to have 50 to 60 researchers, he said.
The center will work together with local universities and businesses in developing new products, said Barrett.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNBALANCED MILITARY FORCE ACROSS TAIWAN STRAIT A PROBLEM: PAAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan should pay heed to the increasing military threat from mainland China and consider it one of the three biggest problems concerning the security in the Asia-Pacific region, an American diplomat said Tuesday.

Douglas Paal, director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , made the remarks in a seminar on Taiwan-United States-Israel national security held in Taipei, in which government officials and scholars of the three countries attended.

After the Sep. 11 terrorist attacks, Paal noted, there were still problems with stability and security in the world, citing as examples three major threats to the Asia-Pacific region -- the unbalanced military forces between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the increasing nuclear threat on the Korean Peninsula, and continued terrorist attacks.

Among these threats, what Taiwan can do is close the increasing military gap between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Paal said, adding that the AIT welcomes the promise from Taiwan leaders to modernize the island's military forces, a goal that will take time to reach.
According to the latest report from the U.S. Pentagon, Paal went on, Beijing is expected to add 75 ballistic missiles targeting Taiwan this year, and the figure may even be an underestimate.

Paal admitted that this year will be a difficult one as the talks on the nuclear threat on the Korean Peninsula will be filled with uncertainty, and Taiwan will hold a presidential election in the next year, which is expected to create tension across the Taiwan Strait. In addition, nobody knows where the next terrorist attack will be, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CHAIRMAN LEAVES FOR NEW ZEALAND

TEXT.P: Chairman of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Huang Chu-wen left Tuesday night for New Zealand at the head of his party's delegation to attend the inauguration of a TSU support group in Wellington.
Prior to his departure, Huang said that the TSU will encourage overseas Taiwanese from around the world to form groups supporting the party in their respective host countries.
The party has already formed groups in the United States, Japan and Thailand, he added.
Taking the opportunity, Huang continued, he and his delegation will visit lawmakers of New Zealand during their stay in Wellington to promote ties.

Members of the TSU delegation include Chien Lin Whei-jun, convener of the party's legislative caucus; Legislator Lo Chih-ming, a caucus whip; Chen Hung-chi, the party's deputy secretary-general and other officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI WINS ONE MORE MEDAL IN WORLD UNIVERSITY GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Daegu, South Korea, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan athlete representing Chinese Taipei won a bronze medal Tuesday in the World University Games being held in South Korea, increasing Taiwan's medal tally to one gold, two silvers and four bronzes.
Chi Shu-jug won the medal in the women's taekwondo featherweight division.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGES MAINLAND COOPERATION IN STOPPING HUMAN SMUGGLING

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Tuesday called for immediate cooperation from mainland China to stop human smuggling across the Taiwan Strait.

Jan Jyh-horng, director of the Planning and Research Department of the Mainland Affairs Council, made the call in the wake of the drowning of six mainland women trying to sneak into Taiwan by boat earlier in the day.
Jan said that human smuggling has long been a serious threat to Taiwan's coastal security and social order, and that help is needed from the mainland to address the problem.
He added that Taiwan will provide the necessary humanitarian aid to the families of the dead.

Meanwhile, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , the agency authorized by the government to deal with the mainland on non-official affairs, elaborated in a letter to its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Strait (ARATS), on the incident, one of the most tragic in recent years.

The six dead were among the 22 women who, aboard two fishing boats, were forced overboard by the captains and sailors in an attempt to avoid being caught redheaded by Taiwan's coast guard while approaching the coast of Tunghsiao, Miaoli County at around 4 a.m.

Immediate rescue operations by the coast guard saved the lives of 10 including two who suffered serious injuries and were rushed to nearby hospitals for treatment. However, the remaining four are still missing.
Latest reports say that the four captains and sailors, all Taiwanese, were arrested in a fishing harbor in Penghu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 27, or the 30th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1813: France's Napoleon Bonaparte, with a force of 130,000, wins his last great battle at Dresden, Germany, against a superior Austrian, Prussian and Russian allied force of 200,000.
1859: The world's first oil well is drilled by Edwin L. Drake at Titusville, Pennsylvania.
1883: The 1,800 meter Krakatoa on the Indonesian island of Rakata erupts with a fury that is heard in Australia, more than 3,541 km away, and gigantic tidal waves of up to 36 meters devastate the coastal towns of Java and Sumatra, leaving an estimated 36,000 people dead, and making the eruption the most catastrophic volcanic event ever recorded.
1891: Russia and France sign an entente cordiale.
1908: Lyndon B. Johnson, the 36th president of the United States, is born. He succeeded to the office after John F. Kennedy was assassinated. He won the 1964 election but faced increasing criticism over the mounting US involvement in Vietnam, and did not stand for reelection in 1968.
1910: Thomas Alva Edison, the American inventor who patented more than a thousand inventions, shows his "talking picture" for the first time at his New Jersey laboratory.
1910: Mother Teresa of Calcutta, the Yugoslavian-born Albanian nun dedicated to the poor and sick, particularly in India, is born. She won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai, in an attempt to impose dictatorial rule after assuming the provisional presidency in Beijing in March, 1912, orders the arrest of eight members of a constitution-drafting committee.
1916: Italy declares war on Germany.
1916: Romania declares war on Austro-Hungary, thus entering World War I.
1928: The Kellogg-Briant Pact, or Pact of Paris, an international agreement to condemn all war as a means of settling dispute, is signed by representatives of 15 nations.
1939: The world's first jet-propelled aircraft, the He-178 developed by German manufacturer Ernst Heinkel, makes its first flight at Marienehe, in northern Germany.
1946: A pilot's ejector seat prototype is successfully demonstrated at Wright Airport in the United States.
1946: France and Laos conclude an agreement establishing a kingdom under French domination.
1952: Israel and West Germany reach agreement in their negotiations on Nazi war crime indemnity. Under the agreement, the West German government will pay 3 billion Reichsmarks in 12 years to compensate Israeli people for their loss of lives and properties caused by the Nazi regime during World War II.
1962: The International Amateur Athletic Federation issues statement revoking its ratification for Indonesia to hold the Fourth Asian Games following the southeast Asian country's rejection of the Republic of China delegation to the games.
1972: The Taipei Little League baseball team wins the world title.
1977: The ROC's Lih Teh Little League baseball team wins the world title. Both Senior League and Big League baseball teams from Taiwan also won the 1977 world titles in earlier competitions.
1979: Lord Louis Mountbatten, former admiral and viceroy of India, is murdered by a bomb planted by the Irish Republican Army as he and members of his family enjoy an outing on his 30-ft. fishing boat off Mullaghmore, County Sligo in the Irish Republic. He was 79.
1986: The ROC Ministry of Finance decides to lower the highest tariff rate to 57.5 percent and reduce duty rates on products with high import tariffs but limited import volume.
1987: A 13-year-old Chinese girl who was left to live with a family of pigs returns to normal life after three years of special training.
1991: Moldova declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1995: Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization sign an agreement in Cairo to expand Palestinian autonomy from Gaza to the West Bank.
2001: Board Chairman Yeh Ming-hsun of Shih Hsin University is elected as new chairman of the National Press Council (NPC) of the Republic of China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The power of spiritual forces in the Universe -- how active it is everywhere! Invisible to the eye and impalpable to the sense, it is inherent in all things, and nothing can escape its operation."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR VISITS FIRMS IN SILICON VALLEY TO COURT INVESTORS
DOC.DATELINE: Silicon Valley, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Chiang Ying and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou has visited many major high-tech companies in Silicon Valley, including Hewlett-Packard and Intel, over the past few days to attract them to invest in Taiwan's largest city.

In a speech delivered Tuesday in Silicon Valley, Ma touted Taipei's strategic location and superb investment climate. He encouraged foreign high-tech companies to set up innovation or research and development (R&D) centers in Taipei for tapping into the vast mainland Chinese market.

Ma said Taipei can serve as a testing market for information technology (IT) products to enter the greater Chinese community and as a springboard for technological cooperation between the East and the West.

"The greater Taipei area has a large cluster of IT companies. For instance, the Yuanshan-Linkou area is the world's largest notebook computer production base, while Taipei City and Taipei County form the world's top motherboard manufacturing hub," Ma said.

Noting that the Nankang software industrial park's annual business turnover has reached NT$120 billion (US$3.49 billion) and that the Neihu industrial park's annual turnover has topped NT$77 billion, Ma said Taipei can be a shortcut for IT firms in Silicon Valley to enter the mainland market.

Ma said Taipei has 27 universities and more than 10 large research institutes. "We have Asia's largest number of MBA degree holders, and those with bachelor's or higher academic degrees make up 39 percent of the city's total population."
An abundant supply of brainpower is key to industrial development, Ma said, adding that Taipei's per capita education expenditure is the second highest in Asia.

Since assuming the mayorship five years ago, Ma said, he has given priority to developing Taipei into an "Internet capital." At present, he said, 900,000 Taipei households have computers, and 50 percent of these households have subscribed to broadband communication services.

Moreover, Ma said, 72 percent of Taipei citizens use Internet services, and 81 percent have cell phones. Taipei City Government will invest more in creating a broadband wireless environment to bring about new business opportunities for the IT industry, he added.

Ma said the annual Taipei international computer trade fair has become the world's third largest exhibition of its kind. In addition to the current 2,600-booth exhibition hall, Ma said, a new exhibition ground that can accommodate 3,000 booths will be inaugurated in two years.

Furthermore, he said, Taipei boasts a convenient living environment, with many round-the-clock services. "We also have rich cultural resources and facilities as well as prestigious international schools and medical services to cater to the needs of high-tech industry professionals," he added.

Ma said the city government will offer more financial incentives and vocational training services to attract foreign investors. He further said semiconductor chip designing firms are most welcome to set up technological support centers, product testing facilities and laboratories in Taipei. Other knowledge-based industry firms and biotechnology companies are also welcome to come to Taipei, he added.
