DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 4.82 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Wednesday, with the weighted index moving down 4.82 points to close at 5,553.43.
Market turnover amounted to NT$96.76 billion (US$2.83 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 4.82 points to close at 5,553.43.
The bourse opened at 5,577.3 and then fluctuated between 5,626.46 and 5,542.45 during trading.
A total of 4.37 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$96.76 billion (US$2.83 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with bank and insurance shares moving up 1.8 percent.

The other major stock categories lost ground, with plastics and chemical shares moving down the most at 1.8 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.3 percent, textile issues at 1.1 percent, construction stocks and pulp and paper issues, both at 0.9 percent, electrical stocks at 0.2 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 467 to 220, with 115 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were generally lower on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved down 32 points to close at 5,548, with 28,153 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October lost 12 points to finish at 5,558, with 58 contract transactions, while December futures gained 80 points to close at 5,625, with 6 contracts traded.
March futures fell 73 points to finish at 5,562, with 6 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,580 for September, 5,570 for October, 5,545 for December, 5,635 for March, and 5,581 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
September TE futures moved down 1 point to close at 245.85, with 3,237 contract transactions, while October TE futures lost 0.2 points to finish at 246.1, with 5 contracts traded.
December TE futures fell 0.95 points to close at 247, with 2 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
September TF futures gained 5 points to close at 747, with 6,701 contract transactions, while October TF futures rose 3.4 points to finish at 747.4, with 34 contracts traded.
December TF futures increased 17 points to close at 752, with 7 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months. (BY Ben Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved up against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.015 to close at NT$34.209.
A total of US$500 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$34.221 and hit a low of NT$34.172.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN REPROACHES BEIJING FOR DROWNING INCIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian took Beijing authorities to task Wednesday for the incident a day earlier off the coast of the central Taiwan county of Miaoli when six mainland Chinese women drowned while trying to enter Taiwan illegally.

Chen said it is regrettable that six mainland Chinese women drowned after being thrown overboard by human smugglers, commonly known as "snakeheads, " to escape pursuing Taiwan coast guard boats early Tuesday.
"While human traffickers and the crew of the vessels are to blame for such a callous move, mainland Chinese authorities should also be held responsible for the tragedy," Chen said.
He made the remarks while meeting with an Australian parliamentary delegation.

A total of 26 mainland Chinese women were thrown overboard by "snakeheads" from two speedboats off the shore of Tunghsiao at around 4 a.m. Six of them drowned while the 20 others were rescued by Taiwan coast guard officers.

All of them were young women lured into going to Taiwan with offers of lucrative work, coast guard officials said, adding that the fee they were charged for the voyage from the mainland to Taiwan was around NT$200,000 each.
Chen claimed that the young mainland women had fled their motherland to express their discontent with Beijing authorities.
"They chose to flee to Taiwan at risk to their own lives, " Chen said. "What bewilders us is the Beijing authorities' disregard for their own people's lives, rights and safety."
Worse still, Chen said, mainland China has persistently spared no efforts in trying to isolate Taiwan in the international community.

"They have blocked our entry into the United Nations and the World Health Organization (WHO) , " Chen said, adding that Beijing's "rude manner" toward Taiwan's plead for observership at the 2003 World Health Assembly -- the WHO's governing body -- held in Geneva in May this year deeply hurt the Taiwan people's feelings.
Equally outrageous is the fact that Beijing has asked its diplomatic allies not to recognize or accept the new version of the ROC passport to be issued from Sept. 1, Chen said.

The new version of the ROC passport will display the word "Taiwan" on its cover in addition to the nation's official designation of the "Republic of China" in order to make it more distinguishable from the passport issued by the People's Republic of China -- mainland China's official title.

Chen said what Beijing urgently must do is to prevent mainland people from trying to enter Taiwan illegally and to refrain from blocking Taiwan's WHO observership or pressuring its diplomatic allies to reject Taiwan's new passport.

The Australian parliamentary delegation is being headed by Sen. Alan Ferguson, who concurrently serves as chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defense and Trade of the Senate and the House of Representatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY EXPECTED TO REBOUND IN SECOND HALF: TIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy is expected to markedly rebound in the second half of this year, with the composite index rising for the third month in a row in July and hitting its highest level since April last year, a Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) spokesman reported Wednesday.

Citing the results of a recent survey of Taiwan business firms and manufacturers, the spokesman noted that 50.5 percent of the polled said they are optimistic about business conditions over the coming six months, while only 9.3 percent said they are pessimistic. The remaining 40.2 percent said they think business conditions will remain about the same for the period.

Fueled by an expected economic upturn in the global market following the containment of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and the conclusion of the U.S.-led war in Iraq, the domestic economy will also regain momentum, with exports booming, private-sector consumption and investment growing, and public construction projects expanding, the TIER official said.

At the same time, a low-interest rate environment will be maintained in the international market in an effort to boost demand, with global economic growth for 2003 expected to be about 2 percent, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT LEE RELEASED FROM HOSPITAL

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui was released Wednesday from the Taipei Veterans General Hospital, where he received catheterization heart surgery Monday and is recovering well.

Accompanied by his wife and family, Lee bid farewell to hospital staff workers before leaving for home following the surgery. The operation was conducted to improve myocardial ischemic -- a condition in which the heart was partially lacking oxygen. Follow-up examinations show that Lee is recovering well.

The 80-year-old Lee was admitted into the hospital Saturday after having taken part in a meeting earlier the same day, which was designed to promote a name change for the country from its official designation of the "Republic of China" to "Taiwan."
A medical team from the hospital performed similar surgery on Lee two years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER BRIEFS ON TAIWAN'S CAPITAL MARKET AT FORUM IN N.Y.
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Chang Sheng-chao and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Lin Chuan told participants at the "Taiwan Investment Forum" in New York Tuesday that Taiwan has undertaken a series of reformatory measures to improve the mechanism of the capital market and further globalization and liberalization of the market.
Lin and his entourage attended the forum sponsored by the Ministry of Finance, which was aimed at attracting more foreign investments in Taiwan's capital market.

Pointing out Taiwan's advantageous geographic position for foreign investors interested in the Asia-Pacific market, Lin said that Taiwan is graced with good industrial infrastructure as well as ample research and development capabilities.

The minister said that as an export-oriented economy, Taiwan's external trade has continued to grow since 1952. Being the 14th-largest exporting country and the 16th-biggest importing country in the world, last year Taiwan's two-way trade amounted to US$243 billion and the foreign reserve accumulated to US$175.2 billion.

While the government is offering numerous incentives to business and industry for the advancement of their R&D capability since 2000, it has also sought to accelerate monetary reforms, in relation to legislation and regulations governing financial control companies, merger of financial institutions, securities of monetary assets, and real estate securities, according to Lin.

He said that in order to consolidate the nation's banking system, the government has applied both stick and carrot to banking institutions, requiring them to limit the overdue loan ratio under 5 percent.

With the establishment of the Resolution Trust Committee (RTC) Fund, the monetary reconstruction initiative has helped dozens of banks clear their debts. The overdue loan ratio of local banking institutions shrank from 8.04 percent in the first quarter of 2002 to 5.68 percent at the end of June, Lin added.

Meanwhile, the minister said, cross-Taiwan Strait monetary exchanges have continued to increase over the past years. While seven local banks have set up offices in mainland China, banking institutions across the Strait will be allowed to set up branches in Taiwan when the revised Provisions Governing the Relations of People on Both Sides of the Taiwan Strait is legislated.

In light of further globalization and liberalization of Taiwan's banking system, Lin said that the government has adopted a series of reformatory measures to improve the market mechanism in order to provide a transparent and trustworthy investment environment.

The minister elaborated that last month the government announced further openness of foreign portfolio investment in the domestic securities market, and the QFII (qualified foreign institutional investor) restrictions will be abolished by the end of this year.

He said that international banking institutions are offered an equal footing with their Taiwanese counterparts to operate in Taiwan's monetary market, and the government has simplify the application procedures for the introduction of new monetary derivatives.

According to the minister, Taiwan's capital market has continued to expand over the past years. As of the end of June, the 638 companies listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange had an overall market capitalization amounting to NT$284 billion. In the first half of this year, the value of securities turnover of the Taiwan Stock Exchange amounted to NT$234 billion, the value of securities changed hands in the OTC (over-the-counter) Securities Market totaled NT$19 billion, and the number of futures contracts exceeded 10 million.
Since the government opened its insurance market in 1986, international insurance companies have become ever more active in this lucrative market, Lin said.

Referring to a report of the Asian Insurance Review in its February 2003 issue, the minister said that Taiwan was the third-largest life insurance market and the fourth-largest property insurance market in Asia, in terms of premium revenues.
Welcoming foreign investments in Taiwan's monetary market, Lin said that Taiwan is making all necessary changes and embracing every opportunity.

Heading an investment promotion mission composed of financial officials, legislators and executives of banks and securities houses, Lin flew into New York last Friday. He will leave for Boston Wednesday to attend a forum on Taiwan's financial system there on Thursday.
The group is scheduled to return to Taipei on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: VINCENT SIEW HAS NO COMMENT ON ATTENDING APEC LEADERS' SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Vincent Siew, vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said Wednesday that he had not heard that the government is planning to send him to attend the leaders' summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum this year.

Siew, who also serves as the chairman of Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research and the head of an economic advisory group to President Chen Shui-bian, said that he was "not aware of" such reports and could not comment on them.
Reports said that Siew could represent President Chen Shui-bian to attend the APEC leaders' summit later this year.
An official of the Democratic Progressive Party also said Wednesday that she was not aware of the matter.

Hsiao Bi-khim, director of DPP's Department of International Affairs, said that President Chen had in the past wanted to invite Siew to attend the APEC leaders' summit, and Siew was willing to go, but the plan was scotched later because the KMT refused to let him go.
Hsiao said that she was not sure if Siew would be asked to attend the summit, and that if he is, the KMT won't obstruct him so that Taiwan's talented people could work for the nation's betterment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ASKS MOTC TO PREPARE FOR EXPECTED STRIKE BY RAIL WORKERS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun on Wednesday asked the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) to be prepared for a possible strike by Taiwan Railway workers on Moon Festival, one of major holidays for Chinese, which falls on Sep. 11 this year.

The Taiwan Railway labor union vowed to strike on one of the most important holidays for Chinese people to make known their opposition to the privatization of Taiwan Railway. They said the government's movement will only benefit the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp., and the plan intends to ultimately eliminate Taiwan Railway.

Yu asked the MOTC to continue strengthening communications with the union to find a resolution, while in the meantime coordinating long-distance bus drivers and air traffic companies to increase services on that day.
Chang Wen-cheng, chairman of Taiwan Railway labor union, said that their decision to strike has not changed and some 12,000 out of 14,000 Taiwan Railway workers have endorsed the idea.

While on the administrative side, Taiwan Railway Administration Director General D.C. Huang said he is sure that railroad services will be kept normal on Sept. 11 because he has faith in Taiwan Railway workers, who, in the eyes of Huang, are devoted to their work.
Huang announced that the company will sell tickets for the Moon Festival starting from Aug. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC SUGGESTS INTERVIEW OF M'LAND SPOUSES TO SCREEN OUT FAKE MARRIAGES

TEXT.P: The government should work out a feasible mechanism to screen out mainland Chinese who have used the cover of marriage to come to Taiwan illegally, the head of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) suggested Wednesday.

MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen made the remarks at the legislature while reporting on the trend of illegal mainland Chinese immigrants using phony marriages to circumvent the law and ways to deal with the situation. The issue was brought into grim focus yesterday as six mainland Chinese women trying to sneak into Taiwan drowned after being pushed from their ship by panicked crew fearing discovery.
Tsai noted that the number of mainland Chinese spouses applying to come to Taiwan to be united with their Taiwan families has risen every year, reaching more than 190,000 at present.

But she said that given the personnel constraints at the Bureau of Immigration, the review of mainland Chinese spouses has been conducted mainly through paperwork with interviews being rare. She said this had resulted in some mainland Chinese women coming to Taiwan under the cover of marriage to engage in illegal activities.

She expressed the hope that the Bureau of Immigration would conduct interviews with mainland Chinese spouses applying to come to Taiwan and that local police stations would call and check on the women regularly so as to foil those who have used the name of marriages to come to Taiwan.

Tsai also pointed out that the problem of accommodation and repatriation of illegal mainland Chinese immigrants lies in the growth of their numbers in Taiwan, far outpacing the number who have been sent back to mainland China.

Tsai cited statistics to show that the number of women among illegal mainland immigrants has risen rapidly in recent years. There were 7 percent before 1999, 22.3 percent in 2000, and 73.3 percent in July 2003.
But she noted that currently, only a Hsinchu detention center accommodates female illegal mainland Chinese. The space is too small and there are too few women guards.

This results in other female illegal immigrants from mainland China being sent to provisional detention centers or police stations, some staying there for up to five to six months, she said, adding that "This problem should not be overlooked."

She noted that the number of illegal mainland Chinese immigrants peaked between 1992 and 1994 and declined afterwards, averaging 1,500 people a year. But the number of illegal mainland Chinese immigrants then climbed in 2002.

It is estimated that the number will be maintained at around 2,000 this year. Repatriation takes place about once a month for around 150 individuals each time. It is estimated that 1,500 will be repatriated a year, a much slower pace than the speed of rounding up new illegal mainland immigrants.

To effectively solve the problem resulting from the delay by mainland China to take back the illegal immigrants, Tsai said that the government had urged Beijing to agree to increase repatriation missions to three times every two months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN E-SERVICES BUSINESS DELEGATION TO VISIT U. S.

TEXT.P: A high-profile delegation composed of government officials and e-services business leaders will depart for the United States Sept. 7 to familiarize qualified Taiwan companies with U.S. technology and expertise.

The delegation, to be led by Minister without Portfolio Tsai Ching-yen and the cabinet-level Research, Development, and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) Chairman Lin Chia-cheng, will first fly to the Greater Seattle area, before proceeding to Philadelphia, the Greater Newark area and Washington, D. C., the Commercial Section of American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) announced Tuesday in a news release.

In addition to the government sector, such as the RDEC and the National Information and Communications Initiative Committee under the Executive Yuan, the Washington State Office in Taipei and the Taipei Computer Association are also supporting the mission, it said.

Private-sector delegates are from Taiwan's hi-tech areas of logistics services/ solutions, financial services and banking, network services, systems integration, e-business, information security, retailing and information technology (IT) -related manufacturing.
The mission will visit leading U. S. hi-tech companies, including Microsoft Corp., IBM, and HP.

As a prime IT producer in the global market, many of Taiwan's key IT companies are shifting resources to e-services and are seeking U.S. suppliers, technology partners as well as facilitating strategic alliances and setting up joint venture activities in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE OUT OF EIGHT BABIES LAST YEAR BORN TO NON-TAIWAN MOTHERS

TEXT.P: One out of eight babies born last year in Taiwan were from mothers who were not Taiwan citizens, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Wednesday.
DGBAS officials said that around 248,000 babies were born last year, and the mothers of 12.5 percent of them had come from mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau and other countries.

In 1998, there were only 13,000 babies born of non-Taiwan mothers, and the number increased sharply to 30,000 last year. That accounted for 12.5 percent of the total babies born in the same year, an increase of 7.4 percentage points over that of the five years ago.

With the rapid growth of non-Taiwan mothers, the officials said that a major task is to help them integrate into local society, offer eugenics information, and provide assistance in the raising of children and helping them with employment to upgrade the quality of life for the next generation.

According to information by the Ministry of the Interior and the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, out of 173,000 couples that registered for marriage last year, nearly 45,000 couples were of Taiwan men and women who were not Taiwan nationals. Among these, 60 percent came from mainland China, Macau and Hong Kong. They are 30 years old on average and have lower than junior high school educations.

Those wives coming from mainland China and Southeast Asia usually have lower than junior high school educations, while wives from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macau and other areas in general have higher educations with 40 to 50 percent of them having higher than college educations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL MAINLAND CHINESE IMMIGRANTS REPATRIATED FROM MATSU

TEXT.P: A group of 154 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants, all of them women, were repatriated from the outlying island of Matsu Wednesday.
The group, including nine infants, boarded a ship sent by Mawei, Fuzhou, under the escort of the staff of Red Cross societies from both sides of the Taiwan Strait as well as security personnel.

The repatriation came on the heels of tragic drowning incident of six illegal mainland Chinese women immigrants the previous day. Mainland Chinese officials aboard the ship expressed concern about the incident, and hoped that the drowned women could be identified soon.

Officials at the Matsu detention center said that after the repatriation operation, the crowded situation of the center was temporarily relieved. There are, however, still 122 mainlanders, 53 men and 69 women, at the center that will be repatriated the next time.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT EARMARKS US DOLLARS 542,900 FOR FORMER PRESIDENT LEE TENG-HUI

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office plans to earmark NT$18.57 million (US$542,900) for former President Lee Teng-hui for fiscal 2004, and the budget plan will be submitted soon to the Legislative Yuan for approval.
According to sources from the Presidential Office, the NT$18.57 million will include retirement pension, premiums, house rental, official spending, and medical expenditures.
For two former vice presidents -- Lien Chan and Li Yuan-zu -- the Presidential Office plans to allocate NT$1.58 million for the two together.
Meanwhile, some NT$110 million will be allocated for the planning of a national human rights memorial hall, and NT$37 million will be earmarked for the presidential inauguration ceremony next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER EXPRESSES DEEP REGRET OVER DEATH OF ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun expressed deep regret Wednesday over the drowning of six illegal mainland Chinese immigrants off the coast of Miaoli County in central Taiwan a day earlier.

Yu was referring to the incident whereby 26 mainland Chinese were thrown into the ocean by human traffickers, commonly known as "snakeheads, " from two speed boats early Tuesday to escape Taiwan coast guard ships, which resulted in the drowning of six mainland women.

Speaking at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Yu said respect for life and human rights is a universal value. "The tragedy was appalling and disheartening, " Yu said, adding that no similar incident should happen again.
Yu said law enforcement authorities should launch an all-out crackdown on cross-strait human smuggling rings and bring to justice masterminds of such criminal operations.
He also directed Cabinet Secretary-General Liu Shih-fang to call an interministerial meeting to craft effective measures to stave off illegal cross-strait human trafficking.

Noting that the steady stream of illegal mainland immigrants has threatened Taiwan's public order and social stability, Yu said mainland China should address the problems. "Otherwise, it seems to us that the Beijing government is assisting and tolerating such criminal operations."

Yu further instructed the Ministry of the Interior and the Mainland Affairs Council to coordinate with the Red Cross Society and the Straits Exchange Foundation in pushing mainland Chinese authorities to take back illegal immigrants as early as possible. Some of them have been detained in Taiwan for more than six months.

The premier also urged mainland China to resume dialogue with Taiwan to discuss certain practical issues, such as repatriation of illegal immigrants, prevention of cross-strait human trafficking and cracking down on other criminal activities. "Cross-strait cooperation is needed to resolve these thorny issues," he added.
Meanwhile, Cabinet Secretary-General Liu said he will invite officials from relevant government agencies to a meeting within a week to address the cross-strait human smuggling issues.

Twenty-six mainland Chinese women were thrown overboard by "snakeheads" from two speedboats off the shore of Tunghsiao at around 4 a.m. Six of them drowned while the 20 others were rescued by Taiwan coast guard officers.

All of them were young women lured into going to Taiwan with offers of lucrative work, coast guard officials said, adding that the fee they were charged for the voyage from the mainland to Taiwan was around NT$200,000 each.

One of the rescued mainland immigrants is still hospitalized for treatment of injuries sustained in the incident. She is conscious but has to rely on a respirator as her lungs were damaged due to inhaling too much water.

The remaining 19 illegal immigrants are healthy and have been sheltered at the Tunghsia police station and a coast guard base in Changhua County's Lukang township. They will be repatriated later, coast guard officials said.

Four crewmen of the two speedboats, identified as Yeh Tien-sheng, Tseng Chun-ming, Ke Ching-sung and Wang Chung-hsing -- have been arrested on charges of homicide. All of the suspects are residents in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
The identities of the six deceased mainland women have yet to be determined. Coroners may perform autopsies Thursday, prosecutors said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY ACADEMIES, COLLEGES TO BE COMBINED: MND

TEXT.P: In conjunction with the military's streamlining program, three military academies and three colleges will be combined into one military university in the coming years to reduce waste of resources, a spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Wednesday.

A total of 44 departments under the Chinese Military Academy, the Chinese Naval Academy, and the Chinese Air Force Academy, as well as the Fu Hsing Kang College, National Defense Management College and Chung-Cheng Institute of Technology will be merged into 10 departments under the newly planned military university, the spokesman said.

According to the MND officer, freshmen students will be required to select their military branches via entrance examination, and they will have to decide their military unit classification one year later in accordance with their academic and physical performance and their disposition.

Graduate and post-graduate schools currently under the three colleges will all be combined into a newly established "military research school" under the National Defense University, he added, pointing out, however, that the National Defense Medical College (NDMC) will be exempted from this initial string of trimming projects because of its unique speciality in the military education system.
The NDMC is for the time being the sole supplier of well-trained military doctors to the Tri-Service General Hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LU PLANS TO OFFER A COOPERATION PLATFORM FOR PACIFIC DEMOCRACIES

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday that the establishment of the Democratic Pacific Union and an upcoming Democratic Pacific Assembly is to offer a cooperation platform for the democracies surrounding the Pacific Ocean.

Lu made the remarks at a meeting with Edwin J. Feulner, president of the U.S. Heritage Foundation, who, being an old friend of Lu, also asked about Lu's recent tour to ROC's diplomatic allies in Latin America.

Lu noted that she will sponsor a Democratic Pacific Assembly in Taipei in mid-September and set up a Democratic Pacific Union with the final goal of developing the abundant resources of the nations on the Pacific rim to build a new "ocean civilization."
During the gathering, Lu and Feulner talked about the dialogue on the nuclear threat on the Korean Peninsula currently being held in Beijing. Lu said that Taiwan was also concerned about the issue.

Regarding the holding of referendums in Taiwan, Lu noted that the island was fighting alone when it was hard hit by severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) earlier this year. Worse yet, mainland China did not extend a helping hand to Taiwan, but humiliated the island in the annual meeting of the World Health Assembly, the decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WHO) , an organization in which Taiwan was eager to enter.
Taiwan wants to hold referendums to let Beijing and other parts of the world understand the real feelings of the people of Taiwan, Lu said.

For his part, Feulner said the Heritage Foundation he leads has been always supportive of Taiwan. With regard to the holding of a referendum, Feulner said that judging from American experience, it is nothing odd as it is a demonstration of democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, PHILIPPINES SHOULD SIGN FREE TRADE ACCORD: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed the hope Wednesday that Taiwan and the Philippines will sign a free trade agreement and increase cooperation in the technological, agricultural and fishery fields.

Meeting with Roberto Romulo, an advisor in the national competitiveness to the Philippine President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo, and the later's daughter, Evangelina Lourdes Arroyo, at the Presidential Office, Chen said that Taiwan and the Philippines are neighboring countries and have long maintained close relations.
Taiwan is the fourth-largest trading partner of the Philippines with two-way trade that amounted to US$5.6 billion last year, leaving a surplus of US$1.6 billion for Manila, Chen noted.
Taiwan is also the fifth-largest capital supplier of the Philippines with investments that accumulated to more than US$1 billion at the end of last year.

More than 100,000 Taiwanese visited the Philippines last year, making Taiwan the fifth-largest tourist source of the Southeast Asian nation, Chen continued, emphasizing that the number represents an annual growth rate of 21 percent.
More than 71,000 Philippine laborers are working in Taiwan, earning more than US$400 million a year for Manila's foreign exchange reserve, Chen went on.

Chen told his guests that he greatly appreciates Taiwan's relations with the Philippines and hopes to further strengthen these ties during his administration. There is still room for improving ties, particularly in the trade, investment, tourism and labor fields, he said.
Suggesting that the Philippines offer more incentives to lure Taiwan investors, Chen said that the signing of a free trade agreement between the two countries would be mutually beneficial.
Chen asked his guests to convey his regards and invitation to President Arroyo. He said that he hopes to meet Arroyo in Taipei at an opportune time.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SUPPORTS NUCLEAR-FREE KOREAN PENINSULA: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday the Republic of China supports a nuclear-free Korean Peninsula and looks forward to seeing a peaceful solution to all disputes between the two Koreas.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with a group of South Korean National Assembly members.

"Our policy toward the Korean Peninsula issue is clear and unequivocal, " Chen said. "We dislike to see any nuclear arms development programs on the peninsula and call on all parties involved to resolve disputes through peaceful dialogue."

As a member of the Asia-Pacific community, Chen said, the ROC is concerned about regional peace, security and stability. For instance, he said, Taiwan is concerned about the results of the current six-nation meeting in Beijing on East Asia's most urgent security concern -- North Korea's nuclear program and U.S. demands that it be halted immediately.

Chen said he earnestly hopes that the three-day conference will be fruitful in helping ease tensions on the Korean Peninsula and eventually resolve the nuclear arms issue to maintain regional security and stability.

Noting that the ROC supports the U.S.-initiated prevention of nuclear arms proliferation plan, Chen said Taiwan's impounding of 158 barrels of a controlled chemical aboard a North Korean freighter earlier this month signifies Taiwan's commitment to opposing arms proliferation and global terrorism.
Touching on Taiwan-South Korean relations, Chen said the two countries have traditionally maintained close ties, particularly in the trade and economic fields.

Two-way trade reached US$11.58 billion last year, with South Korea enjoying a trade surplus of US$3.84 billion. Taiwan was South Korea's fifth-largest trading partner, while South Korea was Taiwan's fourth-largest import source and fifth-largest export market.

Chen said he hopes that senior officials of the two countries can strengthen exchanges of visits and resume the annual ministerial-level economic conference to boost bilateral cooperation. The annual event has been suspended since Seoul switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1992.

As to the resumption of direct flight services between the two countries, Chen said the ROC would like to see an early resumption of direct Taipei-Seoul air links under the principles of dignity, equality and reciprocity.

"Our two countries should increase exchanges to avoid misunderstandings and facilitate cooperation in promoting peace, security, stability and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region, " Chen told his guests.

The North Korean freighter "Be Gaehung" was allowed to leave Taiwan's Kaohsiung Harbor only after it unloaded the 158 barrels of phosphorus pentasulfide -- a chemical that can be used in rocket fuel production.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR RETURNS FROM CANADA AND U.S. TOUR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou returned to Taiwan Wednesday night from his 11-day visit to six major cities in Canada and the United States, an official of the Taipei City Government said.
Ma visited Toronto, Boston, Washington D.C., Atlanta, Phoenix and San Francisco.
The mayor visited hospitals and disease control organizations to study their countermeasures to control severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).
Ma also visited the high-tech showcase of the United States -- Silicon Valley -- and several American universities, as well as met with business leaders to lure investment to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY RETURNS TO STABILITY: GOVERNMENT REPORT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy stabilized in July with the composite index of its economic situation registering 24 points, rating a green light for the first time this year, according to a government report published Wednesday.

The report compiled by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) under the Executive Yuan showed that the composite index increased by four points from the previous month's level which was rated a yellow-blue light.

A yellow-blue light indicates economic sluggishness in the CEPD's five-color grading system. A red light signifies an overheated economy. Yellow-red indicates that the economy is heating up. Green reflects steady growth and blue represents recession.

The report also stated that the leading index was 100.5 points in July, up 1.4 percentage points from that of a month ago, while the current index was 102.6 points, up 0.8 percentage points from that of a month earlier.

Furthermore, a survey of local manufacturers conducted by the CEPD in July indicates that 17 percent of the respondents believe the economy will improve in the next three months, the same registered in the preceding month, while 13 percent predicted that the economy will get worse, up from 8 percent recorded a month ago, with the remaining 70 percent believing the economy will remain unchanged.

Based on the leading index -- a key barometer of economic trends over the next three to six months -- CEPD officials said that the island's economy will continue to recover steadily in the short-term.
The country's stock prices, monetary supply, orders received by the manufacturing sector, production and exports and other economic indicators are back to normal, they noted.

They attributed the economic improvement to the global economic recovery, increase of business confidence and stimulus measures taken by the government, including expansion of public construction programs.

Many foreign economic analysts and forecasting groups have predicted a brighter future for Taiwan's economy, they said, noting that the Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) estimated that Taiwan will enjoy economic growth of 5.4 percent next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SAYS HE ASSUMED THE PRESIDENCY UNDER ROC CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday he assumed the presidency under the Republic of China's Constitution.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with a group of U.S. scholars and experts on cross-Taiwan Strait affairs, headed by John Tkacik, a research fellow with the Washington-based think tank the Heritage Foundation.
Chen's remarks came after former President Lee Teng-hui said over the weekend that the ROC no longer exists.

"It is not disputed that I was sworn in as the ROC's 10th president on May 20, 2000 in line with the nation's Constitution, " Chen said, adding that he is obligated to safeguard national sovereignty, dignity and security as well as work for the well-being of the people of Taiwan in terms of constitutional provisions.
Chen said Beijing issued a white paper during the run-up to Taiwan's 2000 presidential election in which it claimed that the ROC had been dead since 1949 due to the loss of its international status.
Beijing's claim is wrong, Chen said, adding that the ROC has continued to exist on Taiwan since 1949.

Stressing that Taiwan is an independent, sovereign state, Chen said its current national title is the Republic of China. Therefore, he noted, it is a stark reality that there is one state on each side of the Taiwan Strait at the moment, namely, the Republic of China and the People's Republic of China -- mainland China's official title.

Chen went on to say that his administration is determined to hold the nation's first-ever referendum on certain policy issues before or on the day of the island's next presidential election -- March 20, 2004.

The issues will include whether construction on the island's Fourth Nuclear Power Plant should be halted or continued as well as whether Taiwan should join the World Health Organization (WHO), Chen said.

"We want to hold a referendum on our WHO bid mainly because of Beijing's opposition to our participation in the world health watchdog body. We want to demonstrate to the world our people's unanimous desire to join the WHO through a referendum. So long as Beijing stops blocking our bid, we'll not include the issue on the list of topics subject to a referendum," he explained.
Chen further said the planned referendum will not touch on any sensitive issues regarding Taiwan's future -- independence or unification with the mainland.

Meanwhile, Chen said he plans to start negotiations with Beijing for opening direct cross-strait transportations links after next year's presidential election. And if all goes well, he said, direct cross-strait shipping and air links could become a reality by the end of 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC PRESIDENT DECORATES ROC OFFICIALS WITH MEDALS
DOC.DATELINE: Santo Domingo, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: President of the Dominican Republic Rafael Hipolito Mejia decorated visiting Republic of China officials Tuesday in recognition of their contribution to the promotion of cooperative ties between the two countries.

Mejia decorated with medals Chen Pang-chih, director of the Bureau of Political Warfare under the Ministry of National Defense (MND) , and Hsu Szu-ching, president of the Fu Hsing Kang College under the MND.

Chen and Hsu, heading an ROC delegation of seven members, are on a five-day trip to the Dominican Republic. They will visit high ranking officers of this Caribbean country's military force and police departments.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR-DEFENSE DRILL TO BE STAGED IN TAIPEI AUG. 29

TEXT.P: An air-defense drill will be staged in Taipei Friday to test the ability and preparedness of local government agencies and the general public in response to air raids and emergency management, officials of the Taipei City government said Wednesday.
The annual exercise, code named "wan an" No. 26, will be conducted in two phases and will start from 1: 30 p.m. and ends at 4: 30 p.m., the officials said.
The first phase of the exercise, which will last 30 minutes, will focus on a simulation of dispersing people and vehicles, they noted, adding that the second phase will be a disaster relief exercise.

During the exercise period, traffic on in the air, on freeways and the underground section of the Taipei rapid transit system will remain in normal operations, while others in the metropolitan area, including cars and individuals, should follow instructions given by officials who are in charge of conducting the drill.

DOC.HEADLINE: SLOVAK REPUBLIC TO SET UP OFFICE IN TAIPEI SOON: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Slovak Republic will establish its representative office in Taipei soon, Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien said Wednesday.
Chien made the announcement in an oath-taking ceremony he officiated for various diplomats designated to the ministry's overseas posts and senior officials.
Chien said that he cannot say when the Slovak Republic will set up its office in Taipei. However, he said it will be soon.
Taiwan established its representative office in Bratislava months ago and its representative, Chen Cheng-chih was sworn in at Wednesday's ceremony.

Together with Chen, Republic of China's new representatives to Singapore, Israel and Brunei, Roy Y.Y. Wu, Deng Shen-sheng and Chen Chin-hsien, respectively, and the ministry's secretary-general Deng Pei-yin and director-general of the Department of Protocol Lai Chien-chung were also sworn in, in the same ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 28, or the first day of the eighth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: The Scots defeat royalist English forces at the Battle of Newburn, near Newcastle.
1774: Elizabeth Ann Seton, American educator and religious leader who founded the Sisters of St. Joseph, is born. She was canonized as the first US-born saint in 1975.
1828: Lev Nikolayevich Tolstoy, also known as Count Leo Tolstoi, Russian writer and philosopher, is born. His great novels "War and Peace" and "Anna Karenina" offer extraordinary detail and profound psychological insights. His later theories of ethics and morality recommended non-participation in and passive resistance to evil.
1830: Peter Cooper, American inventor who built the first American locomotive, displays his latest creation, a steam-driven locomotive called Tom Thumb.
1849: Venice surrenders to the Australians, having been under siege since July 20 after proclaiming independence from Austrian rule.
1884: Peter Fraser, prime minister of New Zealand from 1940 to 1949 , is born in Scotland.
1910: Montenegro proclaims independence from the Ottoman empire.
1916: Germany declares war on Romania.
1919, Sir Godfrey Hounsfield, British inventor of the EMI medical scanner, is born. He was winner of the Nobel Prize for Psychology in 1979.
1927: The Eighth Far East Games is held in Shanghai.
1929: The Kuomintang (KMT) branch in Shanghai asks the Nanking government to punish Professor Hu Shih, a former student of John Dewey, for publishing an article criticizing Dr. Sun Yat-sen and the KMT.
1931: The Mexican government orders all ethnic Chinese to leave Mexico before Sept. 2.
1945: Mao Tse-tung, accompanied by US Ambassador Patrick Hurley, arrives in Chungking from Yenan to hold a meeting with the KMT to discuss such issues as national unity.
1963: US civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his "I have a dream" speech to some 200,000 people after an interracial march on Washington, a peaceful demonstration in favor of furthering the cause of civil rights.
1973: Princess Anne arrives in Kiev for an equestrian event, becoming the first member of the British royal family to visit the Soviet Union.
1974: The Republic of China and Thailand conclude a maize trade agreement.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Bolivian Vice Foreign Minister Hernando Garcia Vespa and his wife.
1980: Premier Y.S. Sun leaves for Costa Rica, Panama and the Dominican Republic for official visits.
1983: Menachem Begin resigns as prime minister of Israel.
1988: Three jet planes belonging to an Italian Air Force aeronautics display team collide during an exhibition in front of a crowd of 300,000 at the US Air Force base at Ramstein in West Germany, killing 47 people and injuring some 500 others.
1990: Iraq declares Kuwait the 19th province of Iraq.
1993: Ong Teng Cheong, chairman of the ruling People's Action Party, is elected president of Singapore.
1996: El Salvador President Armando Calderon Sol visits the Republic of China.
1999: The ruling Kuomintang convenes the second plenary session of its 15th National Congress to formally approve Lien Chan and Vincent Siew as the party's nominees for the 2000 presidential election of the Republic of China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Like the rush of mighty waters, the presence of unseen powers is felt -- sometimes above us, sometimes around us. Such is the evidence of things invisible that it is impossible to doubt the spiritual nature of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:

Retired professors outraged by government plans to reclaim dormitories.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 30.31 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Thursday, with the weighted index moving down 30.31 points to close at 5,523.12.
Market turnover amounted to NT$90.55 billion (US$2.65 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO STEP UP CRACKDOWN ON HUMAN SMUGGLING RINGS

TEXT.P: Several women's rights groups urged the government Thursday to step up its crackdown on human smuggling rings by establishing a special investigative agency.

The groups made the appeal after human traffickers, commonly known as "snakeheads, " threw 26 mainland Chinese women overboard early on Tuesday near Tunghsiao in Miaoli County to escape pursuing Taiwan coast guard ships, which resulted in the drowning of six of the women.
All of them were young women lured into going to Taiwan with offers of lucrative work. The fee they were charged for the voyage from the mainland to Taiwan was around NT$200,000 each.

Chen Wan-hui, deputy chief executive of the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, said she had interviewed many mainland women detained at local police stations for illegally entering Taiwan to engage in prostitution.

"Their average age was 20. All of them had lost their freedom since being lured into going to Taiwan. In the process, they were sold from time to time. As a result, police have difficulties locating snakeheads even after they have arrested illegal mainland immigrants, " Chen said.

In her view, Chen said, the most important work in preventing human trafficking lies in investigation. "If we fail to track down 'snakeheads' and their accomplices, illegal mainland immigrants, particularly young women, will continue to stream into Taiwan, " she said.

Therefore, Chen said, the government must set up a special agency to investigate human smuggling rings and their operations. "Whenever law enforcement officers round up mainland Chinese prostitutes, they should continue their probes into the criminal rings that control those prostitutes," she said.
Only by going after the "snakeheads" and getting them can Taiwan put an end to cross-Taiwan Strait human smuggling and prevent a recurrence of Tuesday's drowning tragedy, Chen said.
