DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MIXED ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market reported mixed results on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September remained unchanged at 5,548, with 30,422 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October gained 2 points to close at 5,560, with 79 contract transactions, while December futures plunged 104 points to close at 5,521, with only one contract traded.
March futures moved up 50 points to close at 5,605, with 2 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,548 for September, 5,558 for October, 5,625 for December, 5,555 for March, and 5,549 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also reported mixed results.
September TE futures rose 0.85 points to finish at 246.7, with 3,681 contract transactions, while October TE futures gained 0.3 points to close at 246, with 14 contracts traded.
December TE futures lost 0.95 points to finish at 246, with one contract changing hands, while June TE futures lost 4.45 points to close at 246.6, also with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
September TF futures moved up one point to close at 748, with 4,183 contract transactions, while October TF futures decreased 2 points to finish at 745, with 24 contracts traded.
December TF futures fell 2 points to close at 750, with 3 contract transactions, while March TF futures dropped 1.8 points to finish at 744, with one contract changing hands.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: 34 ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS NABBED IN SUBURBAN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Thirty-four illegal immigrants, including 31 from mainland China and three from Russia, were intercepted in suburban Taipei early Thursday, coast guard officials reported.

The officials said that they spotted a suspicious truck in Shihpai, Taipei, at around 2 a.m. which was covered with thick sponge all over. They then stopped the truck and discovered the illegal immigrants, all of them women, hiding inside.
This represents the largest group of illegal immigrants that the coast guard has intercepted this year.

The officials sent the illegal immigrants to the Keelung branch of the Coast Guard Administration for initial questioning, while the driver of the truck, 38-year-old Chang Chou-yao, was handed over to the Shihlin Prosecutors' Office.

The women claimed that they boarded a ship at Pingtan, Fujian Province, on the southeast coast of mainland China, and then changed to another ship on the open seas. They arrived at Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Wednesday night.
The women said that they came to Taiwan to work but would not say what kind of work.
The women, in tears during the questioning, claimed that they had been tricked into coming to Taiwan and that they had little to eat while at sea for five days.
Upon learning the news of the six mainland woman who drowned Tuesday trying to illegally enter Taiwan, some of the women said they were "lucky to be arrested" because at least they didn't die.

As for the three Russian women, the coast guard officials are awaiting translation assistance from the Moscow-Taipei Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission in Taipei to facilitate the investigation. They will decide later whether to send the three women to a detention center for foreigners in Sanhsia, Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 30.31 points to close at 5,523.12.
The bourse opened at 5,596.56 and then fluctuated between 5,618.36 and 5,504.52 during trading.

A total of 3.91 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$90.55 billion (US$2.65 billion) , a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 4.37 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$96.76 billion (US$2.83 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 4.5 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 3.2 percent, cement stocks at 2.2 percent, textile issues at 1.6 percent, Plastics and chemical stocks at 1.2 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.9 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 0.8 percent, and electrical shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 594 to 114, with 91 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOPS WORLD IN CELL PHONE OWNERSHIP RATE

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked first in the world last year in terms of the ratio of cellular phone owners to the overall population, topping the global list for the second year in a row, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said Thursday.

Quoting International Telecommunications Union statistics, the MOTC said Taiwan topped the list with a ratio of 106.1 users for every 100 citizens, followed by Luxembourg at 101.3 users per 100 citizens and Israel's 95.5 users per 100 citizens.

The MOTC said this indicates that Taiwan's telecommunications "digitalization" has gained a competitive advantage in the world and shows that Taiwan's telecommunications liberalization has born fruit.

The ministry also said that cellular phone use in Taiwan has continued to grow through the first six months of this year, reaching 25.11 million owners as of June 2003, indicating the universality of mobile phone use in Taiwan. (by Nocturne Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH ADVISES TAIWAN PEOPLE NOT TO VISIT RURAL CHINA OVER SARS CONCERN

TEXT.P: Taiwan citizens should not head to rural areas nor eat wildlife meat while visiting mainland China in order to avoid contracting severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), a senior Department of Health (DOH) official said Thursday.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the DOH's Center for Disease Control (CDC) , said a team of World Health Organization (WHO) officials traveled to the southern mainland Chinese province of Guangdong earlier this month to conduct coronovirus tests on birds, reptiles and mammals in the wild.

"Most of those animals tested positive, indicating that coronovirus -- the pathogen that causes SARS -- still exists, " Shih said, adding that against this backdrop, SARS is very likely to stage a comeback this fall or winter.

Shih said Taiwan citizens should avoid non-essential trips to mainland China. "Even if they travel to the mainland, they should stay away from rural areas. More important, they should not come into contact with any wild animals nor eat wildlife meat," he cautioned.

In preparation for a possible reemergence of SARS, Shih said, the WHO has unveiled a new reporting system and quarantine regulations. The world health watchdog body has also formally listed SARS as a statutory communicable disease -- a move that will require medical professionals to inform relevant health authorities immediately after they spot a suspected or probable case.
Shih said the Republic of China government will call an interministerial meeting Sept. 1 to discuss precautionary measures.

According to the new WHO regulations, the SARS prevention mechanism should be activated whenever two health care providers or three patients in the same hospital come down with the disease. The preventive measures will include temperature-taking on arrivals at airports as well as various in-hospital infection control practices.

The WHO has also stipulated that those who have possibly been exposed to the SARS virus and have developed respiratory symptoms within 10 days of that possible exposure should undergo a three-day quarantine during which time they should not go to school or work. Such individuals can however do such daily errands as going out to buy boxed lunches or putting out their garbage.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAM TO STEP UP ITS MANAGEMENT OF LABOR BROKERAGE AGENCIES: CLA

TEXT.P: Vietnam agreed during a meeting with Taiwan on Vietnamese laborers earlier this week to step up its management of its labor brokerage agencies, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Thursday.

The two sides held the meeting in Hanoi, Vietnam, Aug. 25-26. They discussed how to cut the Vietnamese laborer runaway rate in Taiwan, with the Vietnamese side promising to revoke the license of any brokerage agency with a runaway rate of 3 percent among the laborers it introduces to Taiwan.
The Vietnamese side also promised to straighten up the pre-work training institutions and to ban the recruiting of laborers in regions that tend to have high runaway rates.

In addition, Vietnam is also planning to have its local governments, instead of brokerage companies, introduce laborers to Taiwan. The fees will also be standardized to avoid exploitation of the laborers.

The Vietnamese side also agreed to cooperate with Taiwan's crackdown on runaway laborers. According to the agreement, if runaway Vietnamese laborers turn themselves in, the brokerage agency that had introduced the laborers into Taiwan will be responsible for paying for their plane ticket home. Also, the Taiwan side agreed to work out a plan to allow those laborers who have turned themselves in to return to Taiwan in the future to work again.

Currently, there are more than 2,600 Vietnamese laborers on the run in Taiwan, for a runaway rate of 6.4 percent among Vietnamese laborers. The figure represents the highest runaway rate among foreign laborers.

Kuo Fong-yu, director general of the CLA's Employment & Vocational Training Administration who attended the Hanoi meeting, said that to effectively mitigate the runaway rate, Vietnam will use the runaway list provided by Taiwan to send notices to the runaway laborers' families in Vietnam in the hope that the families will be able to persuade them to turn themselves in.

As to the question of whether to adopt a similar strategy to deal with runaway laborers from other countries, Kuo said that every country will adopt different measures and that as long as the other countries are willing to reciprocate Taiwan's goodwill, the CLA will study possible cooperation measures within its authority.

CLA officials noted that they will begin a three-month campaign Sep. 1 to search for runaway laborers and crackdown on employers who illegally hire such workers, and complete an assessment report on foreign laborer exporting countries in November, in the hope of effectively cutting foreign laborer runaway rates.

According to the latest CLA tallies, Taiwan currently has some 300,000 foreign laborers that were introduced legally, with more than 10,000 of those having fled their jobs and remaining unaccounted for.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADVISERS TO PRESIDENT PROPOSE SUPPORT TO MONETARY AND SERVICE SECTORS

TEXT.P: The Economic Advisory Group to President Chen Shui-bian will meet with the president Friday to present a proposal on creating an environment for Taiwan to become a center of assets management in the Asia-Pacific region.
Group convener Vincent Siew said asset management companies should be allowed more flexibility to handle the problems of debt-ridden banks.

He said that the group will suggest that the Resolution Trust Committee (RTC) fund should provide guarantee to all depositors as well as other creditors of problematic banking institutions handled by the RTC fund.
In order to grow the monetary sector, Siew said that the four government-controlled funds should be allowed to invest in venture capital companies.
While the services industry is set to become a mainstream in Taiwan's economic development, Siew said that the government should further relax restrictions on the operations of this industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MEMBERS' NEEDS SHOULD BE TAKEN INTO ACCOUNT: TAIWAN'S WTO REP
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is of the position that the needs of new members should be taken into account in the agricultural negotiations at the upcoming Fifth Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organization (WTO), Taiwan's permanent representative to the WTO said Thursday in Geneva.

Yen Ching-chang said that Taiwan is very concerned about the rights of new members in the agricultural negotiations, which will be high on the agenda at the September meeting. The Fifth Ministerial Conference of the WTO is set for Sept. 10-14 in Cancun, Mexico.

As the outcome of the agricultural negotiations is expected to have a significant impact on Taiwan's economy, Yen said, the government has sought to safeguard the rights and interests of Taiwan's farm population.
Referring to the special and differential treatment to new members, Yen said that it is impossible to apply a unified solution to all members, adding that the rules should be more flexible.

He pointed out that the Doha Ministerial Declaration of November 2001 stressed that "the special and differential treatment for developing countries shall be an integral part of all elements of the negotiations and shall be embodied in the schedules of concessions and commitments and as appropriate in the rules and disciplines to be negotiated, so as to be operationally effective and to enable developing countries to effectively take account of their developing needs, including food safety and rural development."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.001 to close at NT$34.210.
A total of US$488 million changed hands.
The U.S. dollar opened at NT$34.216 and was traded between NT$34.200 and NT$34.217.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI TO HOLD SYMPOSIUM ON NANOTECHNOLOGY RESEARCH ACHIEVEMENTS

TEXT.P: The Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) will sponsor a symposium Sept. 3-10 at the ITRI in Hsinchu to present achievements of the National Science and Technology Program for Nanoscience and Nanotechnology.

An ITRI spokesman said that the government has set aside NT$25 billion for the six-year program, which runs 2003-2008, and is co-chaired by ITRI Vice President Dr. Yang Jih-chang and Dr. M.K. Wu, director of the Institute of Physics of the Academia Sinica.

In the initial stage of the program, the task group has put more emphasis on the establishment of core facilities and training of research and development personnel to achieve the long-term target of industrial application of nanotechnology.

The spokesman said that executives of industrial corporations are invited to attend the September symposium to exchange views with academicians on the application and commercialization of new technologies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MILITARY TO FLEX MUSCLES IN 'HAN KUANG' EXERCISE SEPT. 1

TEXT.P: The ROC military will flex its muscles in a combined services live-fire exercise to be held in the northeastern county of Ilan Sept. 1, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Thursday.

The drill is the second round of the "Han Kuang 19" exercise, which is designed to test the armed forces' combined services defense capabilities and the performance of various weaponry systems, MND officials said. The Han Kuang series of exercises is Taiwan's largest military training drill of the year.

The first round of the "Han Kuang 19" exercise was held in mid-May. Due to severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) outbreaks in Taiwan between March and June, the second round was postponed to Sept. 1.

The upcoming drill will test the three service branches' combined combat prowess in air, sea and amphibious operations, an MND official said, adding that the live-fire exercise will also verify the feasibility or adaptability of various defense strategies and combat programs.

President Chen Shui-bian will preside over the training drill, with some 400 other senior government officials, legislators, foreign diplomats and journalists witnessing. The audience will be the largest for a military exercise in recent memory.
During the drill, the ROC Navy will for the first time launch two Hsiungfeng II ship-to-ship missiles from a domestically developed "stealth" speed boat, MND sources said.

Meanwhile, U.S.-made Harpoon missiles will be fired from F-16 jet fighters in the upcoming exercise, the sources said. It will be the second time that airborne-fired Harpoon missiles will have been test-fired outside the United States. In the "Han Kuang 17" exercise two years ago, a Harpoon missile was test-fired for the first time from an ROC F-16 jet fighter.
Earlier this month, a mainland Chinese surveillance vessel believed to be a "spy ship" was found north of Taiwan as the island's military prepared for the large-scale Han Kuang exercise.

In the face of mainland China's mounting military threat, MND officials said, the military will demonstrate to the world through the "Han Kuang" exercise that its has the determination and capability to defend Taiwan's security and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SCHOOL AND U.S. FIRM TO DEVELOP ANTI-FALSIFICATION TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: The U.S.-based Microseal LLC and the I-Shou University in southern Taiwan signed a memorandum Thursday to jointly develop the micro and nano technologies for anti-falsification use.

Li Yien-chie, director of the university's research center, said the school's cooperation with Microseal, which is well-known for developing sculpturing with micro and nano technologies, will help increase the commercial applications of this technology.

For example, Li added, Microseal's sculpturing with micro and nano technologies will give every product its unique and nearly invisible "fingerprint" that cannot be falsified; therefore, the technology can be applied to numerous products, including I.D. cards, passports, visas, bank notes, jewelry, pharmaceuticals, and cosmetics.

Fu Shen-li, president of I-Shou University, said that in addition to offering equipment and experts in engineering, administration and legal services for the cooperation program with Microseal, the school will also set up an exclusive research and development center for further application of Microseal's products.
Fu said the university also welcomes the cooperation from other companies interested in this field.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR SAYS TRIP TO U.S., CANADA FRUITFUL

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday his 11- day visit to Canada and the United States produced good results on methods of dealing with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) , and that some interest was shown in investing in Taiwan.

Ma, who returned to Taiwan Wednesday night after concluding his visit to six major cities in the two countries, said that after visiting Toronto, Washington, D.C. and Atlanta, he thought that the situation in Toronto was similar to Taiwan. He also visited Atlanta, Phoenix and San Francisco.
He noted that after the outbreaks of the potentially deadly disease, medical care staff in Toronto were panicked, and had to ask the United States for a support.

Ma said that reviewing the experience in combating SARS in Singapore, Canada and Taiwan, he believes a better coordination mechanism between cities would help a great deal in combating the disease. He has instructed the Department of Health to conduct prevention drills in the city, and that it work with the Cabinet-level Department of Health on how to deal with the disease and upgrade the efficiency of medical response agencies.
Chang Hang, director of Taipei's Department of Health, noted that during the outbreaks of SARS in Toronto, Singapore and Hong Kong, people were not compelled to wear surgical mask as in Taiwan.

Chang said that a lot of countries had not asked people to wear surgical masks in mass transportation systems as Taiwan did during the peak of the SARS outbreaks when it required the wearing of surgical masks while using the mass rapid transit and railway systems.
If the disease resurfaces in the winter, Chang said that the prevention measures will have to depend on the situation, and may not be as strict as when Taiwan was hit hard between March and June.

On the soliciting of investment in Taiwan, Ma stressed that his biggest achievement was to let high-tech companies in the Silicon Valley know that there is not only the showcase Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in Taiwan, there are also the Neihu Science-based Industrial Park and Nankang Software Park in suburban Taipei.
Ma said that it would be a lie if he said that he had attracted the promise of tens millions of dollars from the first visit, adding that "this is only the start."

"The trade promotion will be even more systematic in the futre, " Ma said, adding that he will take manufacturers from the Nankang Software Park and the Neihu Science-Based Industrial Park on an investment-soliciting trip next year to San Diego which houses many giant computer companies.
Ma said that he has confidence in Taipei's investment environment, as Taipei not only offers tax incentives, it also offers excellent trade, entertainment and leisure conditions.

To create an environment more attractive to foreign businessmen, he said that he had instructed the Department of Health to provide assistance to Taipei American School which has been seeking to expand the school grounds, as well as assisting those schools who cannot recruit enough students to grow, and some bilingual primary schools to help solve the education problem of the children of expatriate businessmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAB DRIVER ARRESTED AFTER TRYING TO STORM PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE COMPOUND

TEXT.P: A cab driver was arrested Thursday afternoon for trying to drive his taxi through a second guard station at the Presidential Office, according to police.
Hsueh Ai-ming, 47, who lives in Taichung City, central Taiwan, was waved down by guards at the first entrance to the Presidential Office when he followed a motorcade driving into the complex.
However, he ignored the military police officers and drove through the first entrance. Four guards came out to stop him at the second gate.

Exiting the car, the man told the guards that he wanted to appeal to the president for help. The guards called in police to take him away after finding two 600 c.c. bottles full of gasoline in the vehicle.

A police officer from the Chungsan Police Station, which is in charge of the investigation, said the man seemed mentally unstable and was unable to keep his account straight as to what exactly he wanted from the president.
Prosecutors are beginning their investigations.
This is the second time that a motorist has tried to storm into the Presidential Office compound, which is located downtown.

In June, a motorist with a record of mental illness breached the Presidential Office gate after quarreling with his mother who was in the car with him. He was stopped by guards and referred to psychiatrists for treatment.

The president's guards have been on heightened alert after a truck driver rammed his truck loaded with containers of gasoline into the building of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications on May 15. The truck was burned and the driver killed, but no other damage or casualties ensued.

Meanwhile, Tsai Jing-lung, a Taichung City councilor, said in Taichung that Hsueh often came to his office asking for help. He visited Tsai's office four of five times a week, complaining that his wife was persecuting him, or that agents from the local office of the Investigation Bureau were out to get him.
Since Hsueh was unable to produce any evidence to support his claims, the councilor said, he suggested that the man seek medical help.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-LIBERIAN TIES WILL REMAIN UNCHANGED: LIBERIAN ENVOY

TEXT.P: Diplomatic relations between Liberia and the Republic of China will remain unchanged even after a transitional government is inaugurated in the West African state in October, the Liberian ambassador in Taipei said Thursday.
Amb. John Cummings made the remarks at a ceremony marking the donation of relief goods to war-torn Liberia by several Taiwan private groups.

Cummings said the aid and assistance the ROC has extended to Liberia over the past decade has exceeded the cumulated total of donations by all other countries around the world. Moreover, he said, the ROC's aid is not given to any individual figure, but to all Liberian people.

"We are not ungrateful people, " Cummings said, adding that he believes that Liberian-ROC relations will not undergo any changes after the transitional government begins operations in his country in mid-October.

All the relief goods donated by the ROC government and private local groups will be delivered to Liberia in two weeks, Cummings said, adding that there will be confirmation receipts to prove that the relief goods are really distributed to needy people.

Meanwhile, Lee Chung-ju, director of the African Affairs Department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said ROC Ambassador to Liberia Chen Yeo-chio is expected to return to the Liberian capital of Monrovia before the Liberian transitional government begins operations Oct. 14. Chen is now staying in neighboring Ivory Coast as civil war in Liberia has yet to fully calm down.

After Liberia's president, Charles Taylor, flew into exile earlier this month, Lee said, Chen has offered felicitations to the head and deputy head of Liberia's transitional government which will replace its current interim government Oct. 14. The transitional government will remain operational until January 2006, according to a cease fire pact reached among Liberia's various warring factions.
Barring unexpected developments, Lee said, Chen will leave Ivory Coast for Monrovia before Liberia's transitional government becomes operational.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH KOREAN VETERAN JOURNALIST PREDICTS CHEN WILL BE RE-ELECTED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that he has faith that he will win the presidential election next year, and the faith has been further boosted by the prediction by a South Korean veteran journalist that he will be re-elected.
Chen made the remarks in a meeting with leaders of the Taiwan Chambers of Commerce around the world.
Though complaining about the chaos and rhetoric among the ruling and opposition parties after the previous presidential election in 2000, Chen said he is prepared to fight.

In the 2000 election, Chen of the Democratic Progressive Party garnered 39.3 percent of the votes, James Soong of the People First Party trailed with 36.8 percent, while Lien Chan of the Kuomintang got 23.1 percent. Chen will face the two on a joint ticket in next year's election.

Chen also mentioned his earlier talks with South Korea's veteran journalist Kim Young-oak, an influential people who got the first exclusive interview with President Roh Moo-hyun in mid-April shortly after Roh's election.
In earlier talks with Kim, Chen told Kim that the road from authoritarian rule to democracy is a correct one, and people should treasure the value of democracy and let it be a part of daily live.

Chen also made known the ROC's position of supporting a resolution to the nuclear arms threat on the Korean Peninsula, expressing the hope that the problems and disputes on the peninsula can be peacefully resolved through dialogues.

DOC.HEADLINE: PACT ON TAIPEI PORT CONTAINER WAREHOUSE CENTER INKED

TEXT.P: Agreement on the first port container warehouse center joint venture between the government and the private sector was forged Thursday, with Premier Yu Shyi-kun presiding over the ceremony.

Keelung Harbor Bureau Director Wang Chung-hsiung and Taipei Port container warehouse corporation chairman Lin Hsing-san inked the pact, while Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Ling-san and Taipei County Magistrate Su Tseng-chang witnessed the ceremony.

Yu hailed the accord on establishing the NT$20.33 billion (US$589.3 million) container warehouse center at the Taipei Port -- the joint venture made on the build-operate-transfer (BOT) model -- will help the port in northern Taipei County develop into a shipping hub in the Asia-Pacific region, especially after Taiwan and mainland China open direct transport links.

Noting that the BOT joint venture will markedly strengthen the partnership between the government and the private sector, Yu stressed that the government will do its best to help participating private companies reduce operational risks and increase their profitability.
Minister Lin said the investment from the shipping sector is proof that domestic enterprises are willing to keep their roots at home and make Taiwan their business operational hub.
Lin added that an assessment made by his ministry shows that the Taipei Port is suitable to be built into a free trade port zone and a container transshipment center.

Su said the 110-hectare Taipei Port, with a projected accommodation of between 8,000 and 12,000 twenty-foot containers, will help Kaohsiung Port in southern Taiwan deal with additional containers, and do a lot to make Taiwan into a global business management center.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA SAYS REFUSAL OF NEW VERSION OF ROC PASSPORT UNTRUE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that reports saying that Afghanistan and Pakistan will refuse to accept the new version of the Republic of China passport are not true.

Chin Jih-hsin, director of the Department of North American Affairs, said that the MOFA had solicited the assistance of the United States to verify the reports by asking the embassies of the two countries in the U.S., both of which denied such was the case.
The MOFA will continue to follow the matter and the U.S. has promised to help.
Even if the two countries refuse entry to holders of the new version of the passport, the U.S. has promised to help with a solution, Chin said.

MOFA spokesman Richard Shih said that new version of the passport, which will display the word "Taiwan" in addition to the official national designation of "the Republic of China" on its cover, will be issued as scheduled on Sept. 1.
He said that the new passport will enable customs officials of other countries to better distinguish between citizens of Taiwan and those from mainland China.

Shih said that the new version of the ROC passport is meant to make customs clearance more convenient for Taiwan people when they travel to other countries and there is no political factors involved, and an overwhelming number of countries have said that they would accept the new passport.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT'S FEES FOR INFORMATION AND INTERVIEWS HAVE CONSUMERS SEEING RED

TEXT.P: The coin has finally dropped for Taiwan citizens wanting to get visas to the United States as complaints have begun to flood in over the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) 's policy of charging people additional money simply to call for information, the ROC Consumers' Foundation said on Thursday.

AIT, the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties, started charging people March 17 this year for asking for information or reserving a visa interview -- rates of NT$8 to NT$15 (US$0.23 to US$0.44) per minute.
Those seeking non-immigrant visas through AIT are required to use the toll prefix 0204.

Foundation officials said in a news conference that a great many Taiwan people apply for U.S. visas every year, and that statistics released by AIT showed that Taiwan people have made around 200,000 non-immigrant visa applications on average each year over the past decade.

The officials said they have received calls from people who complained that the application procedures are too complicated, and that when they call AIT, they are required to use the toll prefix and pay NT$8 per minute even when contacting the automated response number and a whopping NT$15 to talk to the staff of the office.

The officials said that if 200,000 people apply for U.S. visas every year and they talk about three minutes over AIT phones at NT$10 per minute, this would translate to NT$6 million (US$175,428) per year in toll call income.

Compared with AIT's practice, the officials pointed out that Japan's Interchange Association, the New Zealand Commerce and Industry Office, and the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei, do not charge extra for Inquiries or visa interview reservations. Also, the U.S. Consular Office in Hong Kong allows people to make appointments for interviews via the Net.
Defending the move by AIT was Andrew Dickson, AIT's acting spokesman at the Taipei office, who said that AIT has not gained from the new system.
Dickson said that if the new system is actually not workable, it can be modified, but he added that the current setup was better than the one that AIT had been using.

He pointed out that there are two categories of fees: one for application and visa fees, proceeds of which go to the U.S. government, and the other for service fees, including calls and appointments through toll calls. The toll call prefix system is being operated by a Taiwan company, in this case, Chunghwa Telecom Co., which won the contract through an open bid, and AIT does not profit from the pay call service, he said.
He said that the new system aims to cut the waiting time in long lines and will provide better and faster service.
He noted that since the implementation of the new system, waiting times have been reduced.
Moreover, detailed information on how to apply for a visa to the United States and various particulars are found at AIT's Web site: www.ait.org.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CAR ACCESSORY-MAKERS MAKING INROAD INTO RUSSIAN MARKET
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By H. K. Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan car accessory-makers are in the spotlight at a 2003 car exhibition being held in Moscow, as 45 Taiwan-based companies are displaying their products at the largest exhibition area of its kind in the city's world trade center.

A Taiwan businessman surnamed Wang said Taiwan manufacturers have been paying greater attention to the Russian market in recent years, evidence that the number of this year's participating companies is twice that of last year.

Although Taiwan products are popular and often seen in Russia, Wang said most of the goods are indirectly imported from Germany, Italy and Dubai. He said many participants from Taiwan are preparing to take the opportunity to study the Russian market.

As Taiwan-made car accessories are very suitable for Russian-made cars because they are durable and easily replaced, Taiwan manufacturers will try to contact leading car makers while in Moscow, a business source said.

The 2003 Moscow car exhibition attracted more than 800 companies from 31 countries to take part, including top brand names such as BMW, Audi and Ford. It opened on Aug. 25 and will run through Aug. 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC SLAMS BEIJING FOR RELUCTANCE TO STEM CROSS-STRAIT HUMAN SMUGGLING

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) urged Beijing Thursday to consult with Taiwan on issues regarding the drowning of six mainland Chinese women off the coast of Taiwan earlier this week while trying to enter the island illegally.

MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong said the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) should contact Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) as soon as possible to help families of the drowned women handle relevant affairs.
"No matter how mainland authorities are indifferent about their people's human rights and well-being, they cannot adopt a hands-off attitude toward this incident," Chen said.

Human traffickers, commonly known as "snakeheads, " threw 26 mainland Chinese women overboard early on Tuesday near Tunghsiao in Miaoli County to escape pursuing Taiwan coast guard ships, which resulted in the drowning of six of the women. All of them were young women lured into going to Taiwan with offers of lucrative work.

Since the six women died, Chen said, the quasi-official SEF has twice informed ARATS of the tragic incident. However, ARATS has not made any response. ARATS has instead tried to seek the assistance of other Taiwan private groups in handling relevant affairs.
At this moment, Chen said, ARATS should drop all political considerations and cooperate with the SEF in assisting the families of the drowned mainland women in handling the aftermath.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait affairs in the absence of official ties.

Chen said mainland China has often failed to abide by the 1990 Kinmen Agreement regarding repatriation of illegal mainland immigrants to Taiwan. As a result, he said, Taiwan's three detention centers have often been jammed with illegal mainland immigrants, posing a big financial burden to Taiwan.
Worse still, Chen said, mainland China has declined to negotiate with Taiwan on cooperation in preventing cross-strait human trafficking and other criminal activities.

Noting that the steady stream of illegal mainland immigrants has threatened Taiwan's public order and social stability, Chen said mainland China should not continue turning a blind eye to the human smuggling issue.

Chen said the ROC government condemned the brutality of human traffickers immediately after the incident and that four suspects involving in pushing mainland women overboard have been detained on charges of homicide.

President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that although the human traffickers, boat owners and pimps should be blamed for the incident, the authorities in Beijing should take most of the responsibility. His remarks drew a backlash from ARATS which claimed that Taiwan's leader was disseminating absurd comments. "And this was extremely inhuman, " ARATS said in a statement carried by Beijing's state-owned Xinhua News Agency late Wednesday.
In response, Chen Ming-tong said Beijing should face up to the cross-strait human trafficking issues instead of criticizing the ROC's leader.

"ARATS' comments symbolized Beijing's attempt to dodge its responsibility to crack down on cross-strait human smuggling, " Chen said, adding that such an irresponsible attitude will hinder normalization of cross-strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT GIVES THUMBS-UP TO INITIAL ANTI-TERRORISM DRILL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian watched over an anti-terrorism drill Thursday at a petrochemical complex in southern Taiwan and hailed the skillful techniques employed.

The drill is part of a series of "Wan-An" defense exercises to be held in Taiwan in the next few months. This is the first time that the annual "Wan-An" defense exercises have focused on anti-terrorism operations in 26 years.
Thursday's drill was held at the Formosa Plastics Group's petrochemical complex in Mailiao, Yunlin County.
Chen noted that the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States totally changed people's understanding about forms of war.

The petrochemical complex, an important industrial base in Taiwan, is a possible target of terrorist attacks and is strategically important in war time, Chen said, pointing to the reason why the drill was being held here.

Chen stressed that it will be the priority work for the government to integrate various emergency task forces in the country to form a more sufficient security net against attacks or natural disasters.
He said that Yunlin County Government's performance in the drill can serve as a model for other cities and counties in fighting against terrorist attacks.
Similar anti-terrorist drills will be held in northern areas Friday, and in central and southern Taiwan in mid and late October.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUNGSHAN AIRPORT NOT SUITABLE FOR DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT LINKS: MAC

TEXT.P: Taipei Sungshan Airport was not included by the central government to serve direct transportation links between Taiwan and mainland China mainly because of its insufficient facilities and capabilities, a government official in charge of mainland Chinese affairs said Thursday.
Chen Ming-tung, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , Taiwan's top policy-planning agency toward
mainland China, made the remarks following an MAC meeting in response to the Taipei City Government's dissatisfaction about the issue.

Citing statistics to support his argument, Chen said Sungshan Airport was not selected to conduct direct transport links across the Taiwan Strait as a result of its lack of sufficient runways, aprons and cargo and passenger transshipment capabilities.

Sungshan Airport only has a runway of 2,605 meters, which Chen said is unable to accommodate 747 airplanes, making it impossible for the airport to conduct international cargo and passenger transshipment services.

As the airport lacks adequate facilities to operate international transshipment business, it was excluded from the central government's initial direct transportation program with mainland China out of consideration of operation costs, he noted.

In addition, he pointed out that a no-fly regulation from 11: 00 p. m. until 6: 00 a. m. the next day imposed at Sungshan Airport to reduce noise for residents in the neighborhood adds greater inconvenience for it to open direct cross-strait transport links.

The Taipei City Government issued Tuesday an assessment about the negative effects of the MAC's failure to list Sungshan Airport in its direct cross-strait transportation program along with Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport in neighboring Taoyuan County.

Municipal spokesman Wu Yu-sheng claimed that Sungshan Airport in Taipei is the only suitable option to allow Taiwan businessmen to travel between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait within just one day.

To combine Sungshan Airport and the CKS Airport will much better serve Taiwan's business interests, as Taipei is the headquarters of many international multinationals and leading domestic business groups, Wu said, adding that the Taipei City Government will continue seeking to persuade the central government to allow Taipei Sungshan Airport to serve direct air travel links across the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER QUITS TELEVISION STATION HE FOUNDED

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) member Trong Chai resigned his post as chairman of the Formosa Television Company Thursday in line with DPP Chairman Chen Shui-bian's call for freeing the media from the grip of political parties, government and the military.
His post was taken over by Tien Tsai-ting, the vice chairman of the company.

Chai, who founded the Formosa Television Company in 1997, said at a ceremony to mark the change of chief executive officer that the company is the island's fourth and first private terrestrial television company. He named it in Chinese "chuan ming", or of all people, to underline the fact that it was founded by people and belongs to the people.

Claiming that he had devoted his whole life to fighting for a democratic, independent and free Taiwan, Chai said the Formosa Television Company is part of his efforts to spread his political ideas and to teach his fellow countrymen to love the island.
He said he was glad to see that Formosa has become the most popular and most pro-Taiwan television company in the country.
However, as a DPP member, Chai said he has to follow party chairman Chen Shui-bian's call to give the country's media a scope free from political influence.
He said he will release a book Friday giving a detailed account of the process by which he founded the Formosa Television Company.
Chai's departure from the television company was lauded by his DPP comrades.
Legislator Chen Chi-mai, the DPP whip at the Legislative Yuan, said it gives the party a free hand to push for a change of law to prohibit political parties from running media enterprises.

He criticized the major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) for stubbornly stonewalling the change of law and refusing to give up its stake in the Broadcasting Corporation of China and the China Television Company.
But KMT Legislator Hung Hsiou-chu said her party favors the withdrawal of political parties from the field of media, and is pressing ahead with a plan to sell its stakes in media companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE MAY GET US$ 516 MORE IN PER CAPITA GNP NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: A budget plan released Thursday by the Cabinet predicted that the per capita gross national product (GNP) for Taiwan people will reach US$13,683 next year, an increase of US$516 over this year.

According to the budget plan, which was submitted to the Legislative Yuan Thursday, the economic growth of Taiwan is expected to reach 3.81 percent in 2004 in comparison with the 3.06 percent forecast for this year.
The GNP of the country is expected to total NT$10.63 trillion (US$308 billion) next year in comparison with NT$10 trillion expected for this year.
In foreign trade, the Cabinet estimated that Taiwan's exports will grow by 7.5 percent in 2004, while exports will be up 8.2 percent.

The Cabinet estimated that prices for agricultural and industrial materials on the international market will be stable next year, with domestic consumer price and wholesale prices increasing by 0.45 percent and 0.28 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 BUDGET PRESENTED TO LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The government's 2004 budget was presented to the Legislative Yuan Thursday, with a total outlay of NT$1.3 trillion (US$32.28 billion).
Notable among the budget items was a 4 percent increase in social welfare, which is NT$285.6 billion (US$8.41 billion) or NT$10.8 billion (US$318 million) more than the previous year.
The defense budget has increased by NT$9.5 billion (US$279 million) or 3.9 percent to NT$265 billion (US$7.8 billion).
The budget for economic development has increased by NT$21.8 billion (US$641 million) or 9.6 percent to NT$247.9 billion (US$7.29 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CRITICIZES BEIJING FOR FAILING TO STOP ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: Illegal immigrants from mainland China has become an international problem plaguing all countries in the region if Beijing doesn't do its part to intervene, and Taiwan might have to turn to international organizations such as the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum for help, Lin Chia Lung, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Thursday.

Citing media reports that 73 illegal immigrants from the mainland were caught in the last three days, Lin said illegal immigrants from mainland Chinese are problematic not only for Taiwan but also for Japan, South Korea, the United States and Southeast Asian states, and the situation has taken on an international dimension.
The inflow of these illegal immigrants poses a threat to the island's security, the spokesman said.

Noting that Beijing can crack down on the democratic activists in the mainland and check the flow of information on the Internet, he wondered why it could not stop its people from migrating to other countries illegally. The only explanation is that the mainland does not have the political will to act, he said.
He warned that the threat posed by illegal mainland Chinese immigrants could discourage Taipei authorities from launching quicker shipping links across the Taiwan Strait.
