DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC PASSPORTS WILL WORK IN U.S. AS NORMAL AS BEFORE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government said Thursday that the issuance of the new version of the Republic of China passport from Sept. 1 will not affect Taiwan citizens' travel to the United States, and that it is not a question of whether the United States recognizes it or not.

In response to a question from a CNA reporter, a U.S. State Department official said that Taiwan has reiterated that the new version of the passport is purely for the purpose of making it more distinguishable from the passport issued by the People's Republic of China and that it by no means represents that the ROC's policies have changed in any way.

The new version of the passport, which will display the word "Taiwan" in addition to the official national designation of "the Republic of China" on its cover, will not have any impact on the United States' "one China" policy, the official said.
The new ROC passport will not affect how the United States deals with travel to the country by Taiwan citizens or their travel documents, the official added.
The official noted that Taiwan has been talking about the issuance of a new version of its passport since last year and that it is a decision for Taiwan alone to make.

The new version of the passport will be issued from Sept. 1 as scheduled despite claims by mainland China's official media that some countries will refuse to accept the new version, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Richard Shih said earlier this week.

Shih said that the purpose of adding the word "Taiwan" is to help customs officials of other countries better distinguish between citizens from Taiwan and those from mainland China. He said the move is meant to make customs clearance more convenient for Taiwan people when they travel to other countries.

He said that other than the addition of the word "Taiwan, " the new version of the passport is completely the same as the current version, stressing that as an independent sovereign state, the ROC has the right to issue passports.

Shih also said that following communications with other countries regarding the issue, major countries, including Japan, the United States and the member states of the European Union, have expressed their intention to work with the new version of the passport.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN EXPRESSES RESPECT AND APPRECIATION TO ROC ARMED FORCES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that next week will be a "military week" featuring a variety of war game drills and related activities, and he exhorted all members of the Republic of China armed forces to do their utmost in safeguarding the country.
A series of war game and related anti-terrorism drills kicked off Thursday and are expected to continue islandwide throughout October.

The president expressed his respect and appreciation to the ROC military for their devotion in ensuring Taiwan's security. Chen made the remarks at the Presidential Office while officiating at a ceremony marking the decoration of two brass hats upon promotion.
He congratulated the two officers, saying that greater honor means greater responsibility.

Gen. Chen Chen-hsiang, president of the National Defense University, was decorated with a Second-class Medal of Pao Ting upon his being appointed a strategic adviser to the president, while Hsieh Chien-tong, commander-in-chief of the Reserves Command, was appointed to fill the vacancy left by Chen. Hsieh was decorated with the Third-class Medal of Pao Ting.
Hsieh's vacancy will be filled by Gen. Hsueh Shih-min, chief of the Military Intelligence Bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM ASKS FOR SPEEDY ESTABLISHMENT OF IMMIGRATION ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday that the problem of illegal mainland Chinese immigrants is serious and that it is necessary to set up an immigration administration.

The premier said that "the rising number of illegal mainland Chinese immigrants will affect the quality of life of the 23 million people of Taiwan as well as social order," adding that "the problem has to be dealt with cautiously."

He said that "it is necessary to set up an immigration administration, and the pace has to be quickened, " adding that he has instructed Minister without Portfolio Yeh Chun-jung to take charge of the coordination work among the various government agencies concerning the draft organization bill of the immigration administration.
Yeh noted that the review of the immigration administration draft bill is expected to be completed by Sep. 4 and that the bill will then be sent to the Legislature for approval.

If the draft bill is passed into law, the Bureau of Immigration will be expanded to include several units currently under the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, as well as the National Police Administration's foreign police unit, and other related organizations. It's functions will also be adjusted.

He said that major business of the immigration administration will be passport checking and verification of passengers arriving via international air or sea routes, as well as interviewing immigrants before they come to Taiwan, and providing counseling services for arriving immigrants.

The problem of illegal immigrants was brought into focus recently with the tragic drowning deaths of six out of a group of 26 mainland Chinese women who attempted to enter Taiwan illegally earlier this week.

MAC Vice Chairman Johnnason Liu said that the Executive Yuan had originally wanted to have the Cabinet organization adjustment bill to go hand in hand with the immigration administration organization bill, but due to the urgency of the illegal immigrant problem, MAC Chairman Tsai Ing-wen and Interior Minister Yu Cheng-hsien had asked the premier to delink the two so that the immigration administration organization bill can be legislated as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK PRICES UP BY 127.71 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Friday, with the weighted index moving up 127.71 points to close at 5,650.83.
Market turnover amounted to NT$104.63 billion (US$3.05 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP BLASTS CAMPAIGN LAUNCHED BY OPPOSITION ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Friday blasted a campaign launched by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and its ally People First Party (PFP) , saying that the campaign aims to bring the chaos in the Legislature out onto the street.

Lee Ying-yuan, DPP vice secretary-general, made the remarks in the wake of an announcement by the KMT Taipei branch that the KMT and the PFP would set up pavilions around Taipei to solicit 1 million signatures nationwide to express opposition to high tuitions, the dual hikes in health insurance fees, and high unemployment. The campaign is set to run through Sep. 4.
Lee said that the KMT and the PFP aim to bring the reckless practice of "random boycotts, random increases and random smearing" in the Legislature out onto the streets.
He said that it is not important how many signatures one can collect, stressing that "what counts is policy."

Lee said that the DPP was a responsible opposition party before it came to power in 2000, pointing out that whenever it voiced opposition to a certain policy, it would state its position and put forward its own alternative policy.

He asked whether the KMT, if it opposes high tuitions, wants colleges or universities to close. He added that the KMT tried to put through an increase in subsidies to senior citizens and college students in the Legislature without success and that it has therefore resorted to what he called the smear campaign.
Lee also said that unemployment is a global problem and that Taiwan's unemployment is not so serious compared with that of other countries and regions.

He said that the DPP has addressed the problem squarely, adding that he hopes that the KMT would come up with substantive suggestions and alternative measures instead of scaring away investors at a time when Taiwan's economy is on the road to rebound.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 127.71 points to close at 5,650.83.
The bourse opened at 5,561.54 and then fluctuated between 5,657.05 and 5,542.39 during trading.

A total of 4.32 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$104.63 billion (US$3.05 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 3.91 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$90.55 billion (US$2.65 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 4.7 percent, followed by electrical issues at 3.1 percent, cement stocks at 2.6 percent, paper issues at 2.1 percent, textiles shares at 1.7 percent, foodstuff stocks at 1.4 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 1.1 percent, and financial shares at 0.8 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 603 to 125, with 78 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS VISIT DETAINED ILLEGAL MAINLAND CHINESE IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: A group of legislators from the Democratic Progressive Party and the Kuomintang paid a visit Friday to illegal mainland Chinese immigrants being temporarily held at a detention center in the northern city of Keelung.

The seven lawmakers visited the Keelung detention center where more than 200 mainland Chinese women are being held. Meeting the legislators, many of the detainees appeared on the verge of collapse, crying over their plight as well as their homesickness.
The visit by the legislators comes on the heels of Thursday's tragic drowning deaths of six of a group of 26 mainland Chinese trying to enter Taiwan illegally off Tunghsiao, Miaoli County.

Meanwhile, Liu Shih-lin, deputy director-general of the National Police Administration, paid a visit to another detention center for illegal mainland Chinese immigrants located in Hsinchu, listening to the detainees' outpouring of grief.

Liu exhorted the illegal mainland Chinese immigrants to each write a letter to government leaders in their respective hometowns to ask for arrangements to be made for their early repatriation back to the mainland.
According to Liu, the Hsinchu Detention Center currently has 745 female illegal mainland Chinese immigrants, among whom 14 are pregnant and 17 have infants with them.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT LINKS WILL ENCOURAGE MORE FIRMS TO KEEP ROOTS IN TAIWAN: CHIANG

TEXT.P: When direct transportation links between Taiwan and the Chinese mainland are realized and the inconvenience of cross-strait travel is reduced, Taiwan businesspeople will have more of a reason to keep their roots in Taiwan, the deputy speaker of the Legislature said Friday.

Addressing a seminar co-sponsored by IBM Taiwan and the Taiwan Academy of Banking and Finance, P.K. Chiang said that when more Taiwan businesses choose to stay in Taiwan, the pace of business relocations to the Chinese mainland will slow down.

Chiang pointed out that while the timetable for the implementation of direct transportation links remains a major concern of foreign businesses investing in Taiwan, international corporations also expect that the government will improve its administrative efficiency and be precise in drafting and implementing laws and regulations.
Meanwhile, the former economics minister stressed that at a time of low profit margins, there are too many banking institutions competing in too small a market in Taiwan.
Suggesting that Taiwan's market can accommodate no more than 10 financial management companies, Chiang said that the banking institutions could improve their competitiveness through mergers.

Chiang also said that the most serious risk facing local banking institutions remains the tremendous amount of non-performing loans. Only when this problem is properly handled, will normal operations of the banking system be possible, he added.

Referring to local banks' services to Taiwan companies on the mainland, Chiang said that although several banks have set up liason offices on the mainland, they are not allowed to open branches there. The Taiwan banks expect that the mainland Chinese authorities will open the mainland's financial and service markets, Chiang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TROPICAL DEPRESSION COULD FORM INTO TYPHOON AND AFFECT TAIWAN: CWB

TEXT.P: A tropical atmospheric depression that has formed in the sea near Guam could develop into a typhoon and may affect Taiwan next week, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Friday.
The tropical depression was located west-northwest of Guam, about 1,850 kilometers away from Taiwan, moving westward at a speed of 10 kilometers per hour as of Friday afternoon, the CWB said.

Meanwhile, hot temperatures continued around Taiwan Friday, with forecast highs of 36 degrees Celsius for northern Taiwan and 33-34 degrees Celsius for the central and southern parts of the island, while western parts of Taiwan could experience torrential afternoon downpours, the CWB said. (by Nocturne Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL MAINLANDER NABBED AFTER 12 YEARS IN TAIWAN UNDER ASSUMED ID

TEXT.P: An illegal mainland Chinese immigrant who has lived in Taiwan for 12 years under a false identity was finally nabbed Thursday by Miaoli police.

Ouyang Zhixiang, 31, a native of Shanghai, sneaked into Taiwan in 1991 after paying a "snake head" ring some 100,000 renminbi (US$12,077) . After arriving in Taiwan, Ouyang obtained a stolen identification card of Republic of China citizen Liu Chih-chiang at a cost of another NT$40,000 (US$1,170), according to the Miaoli County Police Department.

From that time, Ouyang worked at several small-scale factories in Taoyuan County, gradually developing his skills and know-how. Currently the owner of an information technology company, "Liu" even won second prize in a national online games competition two years ago. Nobody was aware at the time that he was using an assumed identity, according to Miaoli police.

The Miaoli police began tracking down "Liu" in recent weeks after receiving complaints from the real Liu Chih-chiang -- a native of Hsinwu, Miaoli, who is also 31 -- that he was constantly receiving notices of overdue taxes from the National Tax Administration, to the tune of over NT$1 million, despite dutifully paying his taxes on time every year.

Miaoli police nabbed the fake Liu at his Taoyuan-based company Thursday, arresting him on a variety charges, including fraud, forgery, embezzlement, and violations of the Taxation Law and the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMIC PLANNERS TO HELP SAN TOME MAP OUT ECONOMIC PLAN

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan economic planners, led by Chang Jing-sen, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, will leave for Sao Tome and Principe Saturday to help the country map out an economic development plan, a diplomat said Friday.

C.R. Lee, director general of the African Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said the economic planning advisory group will study Sao Tome's potential for economic development under a bilateral cooperation program.
The two countries are also carrying out an academic cooperation project and an anti-malaria project in the African country, Lee said. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC BUDGETS FUNDS FOR STUDYING CHINESE HARBOR FACILITIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) has budgeted NT$78,000 (US$2,260) for sending an official to mainland China to study its harbor facilities next year.

The MOTC said in the budget plan that, in tandem with the government's plan to establish direct shipping links with mainland China, the ministry wants to send an official to visit the harbor facilities of Guangzhou, Dalian, Shanghai, Qingdao, and Tianjin.
The official would also exchange views with harbor authorities at these locations on some technical problems relating to direct shipping links between Taiwan and mainland China, the MOTC added.
The MOTC had canceled all similar plans in recent years. Whether this year's budget plan can be carried out remains to be seen. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher on Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for September moved up 120 points to close at 5,668, with 45,448 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures October gained 105 points to finish at 5,665, with 186 contract transactions, while December futures rose 104 points to close at 5,640, with five contract traded.
Next March futures gained 15 points to finish at 5,620, with seven contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,548 for September, 5,560 for October, 5,536 for December, 5,605 for next March, and 5,549 for next June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
September TE futures increased 7.7 points to close at 254.4, with 6,208 contract transactions, while October TE futures gained 7.1 points to finish at 254.5, with 14 contracts traded.
December TE futures rose 6.4 points to finish at 252, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
September TF futures moved up 8.0 points to close at 756, with 3,605 contract transactions, while October TF futures gained 9.6 points to finish at 754.6, with 12 contracts changing hands.
December TF futures dropped 8.0 points to finish at 745, with five contracts traded, while next March TF futures gained 11.2 points to finish at 758, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI TENNIS PLAYER WINS GOLD AT WORLD UNIVERSITY GAMES

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei's Lu Yen-hsiun defeated his Slovakian opponent in the men's singles tennis championship match Friday to win gold at the 22nd World University Games being held in Daegu, South Korea.
Chinese Taipei has so far won two gold, two silver and five bronze medals at the games, which opened Aug. 21. (by H.C. Wu and EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: ADMINISTRATION BUDGETS NT$168.4 B. FOR NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: The administration has budgeted NT$168.4 billion (US$4.91 billion) for the national development plan in fiscal 2004.

Under the administration's 2004 budget submitted to the Legislative Yuan Friday, NT$94.2 billion has been budgeted for public construction projects, NT$27.4 billion for science and technology development, NT$4.7 billion for social development, and NT$3 billion for basic necessities.

The administration has also budgeted NT$247.9 billion for economic development, an increase of NT$21.8 billion, or 9.6 percent, over the level for fiscal 2003. The total budget for 2004 is NT$1.3 trillion. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN FIRMS: DEREGULATION VITAL TO TAIWAN'S INVESTMENT ENVIRONMENT

TEXT.P: International corporations investing in Taiwan suggest that transparency and simple laws and regulations are vital to the improvement of Taiwan's investment environment.

Nearly half of the foreign companies in Taiwan answering a questionnaire on the island's investment environment were not satisfied with the administration's performance in processing investment applications, and 45 percent said that the existing taxation system and administrative regulations have confined their operations and business growth.

The survey was conducted by the Chinese-language magazine Global Views Monthly among members of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taiwan, the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei, and some companies listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange.

According to the survey report, 68.5 percent of the companies replying to the questionnaire suggest that deregulation is of top priority in order to improve Taiwan's investment environment; 63.7 percent consider an early realization of cross-strait direct transportation links most important; and 55.6 percent say that the government should first improve its administrative efficiency.

Regarding the attractiveness to international corporations, mainland China tops the list in luring foreign investments, followed by Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore, Japan, Hong Kong, Malaysia and Thailand in that order.
The international corporations point out that Taiwan maintains the advantages of having well-educated, qualified manpower and being geographically adjacent to mainland Chinese.

As to the most potential sectors, the international corporations say that Taiwan's computer, electronics, telecommunications and biotechnology industries as well as the monetary sector are most favored by foreign investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar declined against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, giving up NT$0.040 to close at NT$34.170.
A total of US$714 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$34.221 and hit a low of NT$34.156.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL FOREIGN WORKERS ENCOURAGED TO GIVE THEMSELVES UP

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) announced a plan Friday to encourage illegal foreign workers to give themselves up during the three-month period between Sept. 1 and Nov. 30.

More than 10,400 foreign workers have deserted their jobs and have thus become illegal foreign workers in Taiwan. Of them, 4,116 are from Indonesia, 2,880 from Vietnam, 1,581 from Thailand, and 1,091 from the Philippines, according to statistics released by the National Police Administration.

The CLA said that under the plan all those who give themselves up within the three-month period will not be fined, and their own government has agreed to give them free air tickets to go home. Their own government will also give them job training and help them find a job in another country. If they have lost their passports, their government will give them a new one.

The CLA also reminded all those who are employing illegal foreign workers and those employment agents who are helping illegal foreign workers find work that they will be severely penalized for violating the law. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL SAYS TIME IS RIGHT FOR ENHANCED EXCHANGES WITH JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 29 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The time is ripe for Taiwan and Japan to enhance exchanges since mainland China's new leadership has moved away from its previous harsh attitude toward the two countries, Hsu Shui-teh, chairman of the quasi-official Association of East Asian Relations, said Friday

Hsu said in a recent interview with the Japanese daily Sankei Shimbun that recently elected Chinese president Hu Jintao's focus away from Taiwan and Japan will allow the two nations to better interact with each other.
The Association of East Asian Relations was established in Taipei to deal with Japanese affairs on behalf of the ROC government in the absence of diplomatic ties between the two countries.
Hsu said that the youth of the two nations should be harnessed to strengthen exchanges.
In line with this, the ROC Ministry of Education in conjunction with the association will send a delegation of several presidents of junior and senior high schools to Japan Sept. 8-12.

Members of the delegation are expected to visit Fukuoka, Sendai and Sapporo to discuss with Japanese educators the possibility of exchanging graduation tours of senior high school students of both countries.

Also noting that Beijing's criticism of Japanese Primer Minister Junichiro Koizumi's visit to the Yasukuni Shrine to honor the war dead is only an expression of a long-term stance, Hsu stressed that Koizumi was acting in the best interests of Japan.
Hsu also maintained that the confrontational situation between Taiwan and mainland China is on the wane.
Hsu urged Japan to be more open to global changes and increase visits by high-ranking government officials as well as civil exchanges between the ROC and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC PASSPORTS WILL HAVE NO ENTRY PROBLEMS FOR JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 29 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The new version of the Republic of China passport will not be a problem for ROC citizens entering Japan, a Japanese Foreign Ministry official said Friday.
Hatsuhisa Takashima, the ministry's press secretary, made the remarks in a regular news briefing with foreign journalists.

The Japanese official said that he did not want to comment on the ROC's move to amend the cover of its passports, but did say that ROC citizens coming to Japan on the passport would not face any problems.

In the new version of the passport, the word "Taiwan" in addition to the official national designation of the "Republic of China" will be on the cover. The ROC government has stressed that the move is to make the country's passports more distinguishable from those issued by the People's Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF HEAD BLAMES BEIJING FOR TAIWAN'S ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: Mainland China should be blamed for the drowning of six illegal mainland immigrants off the coast of Taiwan because it severed contact with Taiwan for political reasons which led to the problem, Shi Hwei-yow, secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Friday.

In a public hearing at the Legislative Yuan, Shi said although the problem lies in the mainland's failure to prevent its people from venturing into Taiwan illegally, Taiwan is left to hold the bag. It has to accommodate these illegal immigrants caught in Taiwan, house them in detention centers waiting for repatriation, and compensate those who have died accidentally.

The problem is worsening because Beijing stopped exchanges between its Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait and the SEF, and stopped cooperating with Taiwan to combat people-smuggling operations, Shi said. Beijing has also turned its back on efforts to speed and streamline the repatriation of illegal immigrants, he added.
Beijing stopped all contacts with Taiwan in 1999 to protest what it claims was Taiwan's retreat from a consensus that both Taiwan and the mainland belong to one China.
Shi said Beijing should at least resume dialogue with Taiwan to speed up the two sides' efforts to stop illegal immigrants.
At the same hearing, Su You-cheng, a human rights adviser to the president, suggested that local authorities do not do all they can to keep illegal immigrants from landing on the island.

Noting that there are no more than 10 beaches in Taiwan where illegal immigrants could land, Su wondered why the country's law enforcers and armed forces are unable to keep a close watch on these sites and prevent illegal immigrants from approaching the beaches.

The hearing was organized after six female illegal immigrants were drown off the coast of Tunghsiao, Miali County Tuesday. They were pushed into sea by local people-smugglers after the smugglers found they were being followed by coast guard patrol boats.
The bodies of the six immigrants were stored in the morgue of Tachia Crematorium in Taichung County Friday.

SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng went to Taichung to collect forensic evidence of the women, including photographs. This information will be sent to the mainland in an attempt to identify the deceased.
Jan said the SEF will help the victims' family members to come to Taiwan to claim the bodies. In case no one come to claim them, the bodies will be cremated and the remains sent back to the mainland.

Noting that many illegal immigrants from the mainland are caught in Taiwan, Jan said the current repatriation rate, 150 persons per month, is too slow. Beijing should step up its operations to take back its people.
It is inhuman to keep these illegal immigrants in Taiwan's detention centers for months or even years waiting repatriation, Jan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL GOVERNMENTS' EMERGENCY RESPONSE CAN BE IMPROVED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday that to increase local governments' capability in anti-terrorism, emergency response and disaster relief operations is one of his Cabinet's priorities.
Inspecting the annual civil defense drill "Wan An" No. 26 in Taipei City, Yu said that the government should not lower its guard against any possible threat to national security.

Citing the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States in 2001 and a series of terrorist explosions afterward around the world as examples, Yu said that the threat to national security of a country can come in various forms.

The exercise, which was conducted in two phases, started at 1: 30 p.m. and ended at 4: 30 p.m. The first phase of the exercise, which lasted for 30 minutes, was focused on a simulation of dispersing people and vehicles and the second phase was centered on disaster relief operations.

In metropolitan Taipei, the second phase of the drill featured rescuing hostages held by terrorists at the Shin Kong Building -- a skyscraper near the Taiwan Railway Station in downtown Taipei and handling explosives supposedly hidden there as well as a simulated poison gas attack on the city's mass rapid transit system.

The exercise was staged simultaneously in Taipei city and county, Keelung City, Taoyuan County and Hsinchu city and county with the participation of the related local governments and 117 public agencies and private groups in northern Taiwan. It was described by government officials as successful.
Yu said that the exercise is a valuable reference for the government in integrating all security and emergency management operations in response to attacks from hostile forces.

Similar anti-terrorist, anti-sabotage and anti-abduction drills at selected public places and facilities in central, southern and eastern Taiwan as well as on the frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu will be conducted from mid-October through the end of that month.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY WARNS ABOUT BEIJING'S MILITARY BUILDUP

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) warned Friday that Beijing's military buildup could pose a threat to Taiwan after 2008 if Taiwan fails to upgrade its armed forces's combat capability by then.

In its first annual report on Beijing's military strength, the MND said Beijing's armed forces are much larger than Taiwan's, and its recent economic development gives Beijing the means to upgrade its weapons systems.

Noting that Beijing has acquired advanced Russian-made Sukhoi jet fighters, new destroyers, Kilo-class submarines, and ship-to-ship SS-N-22 Sunburn missiles, the report said the capability of Beijing's armed forces are significantly improved with these new weapons in its arsenal.

Furthermore, Beijing has deployed more than 100 strategic ballistic missiles, in addition to 400 regular missiles, and is upgrading their precision by directing them at targets through Beijing's own global position system. All of the missiles are positioned in bases where they can bring Taiwan within their ranges.
Also, there are 1,000 jet fighters posted in bases within a radius of 600 miles from Taiwan.
This development has shortened the time Taiwan will have to react after learning of an attack, and has brought within its striking range U.S. military bases in Japan and South Korea.
However, this won't tip the military balance across the Taiwan Strait before 2008, thanks to the advanced weapons Taiwan obtained in the last few years.

The situation could change after 2008, unless the country's armed forces can successfully boost its combat capability before then. That means the likelihood that Beijing could attack Taiwan with force is slim before 2008.

Beijing's defense budget has increased by an unprecedented 9.6 percent this year, or the highest rate in the world, not counting its secret military spending which is usually three or four times the public defense budget, the report said.

There are three potential crises between Taiwan and mainland China: their conflicting views about "one China, " the disparity between their military forces, and the lack of trust with each other, according to the report.
Therefore, the ministry said, it cannot rule out the possibility that military conflicts might break out accidentally because of small friction or miscalculations.

The report was presented to the Legislative Yuan along with the 2004 defense budget which revealed the country's armed forces are working closely with neighboring states, contrary to the country's diplomatic isolation. The armed forces will join several foreign military drills.
Notably among them is a U.S. Air Force exercise whereby the ROC Air Force will send an eight-member delegation to observe.

The ROC Navy will sent observers to three U.S. Naval exercises, in addition to sending 864 officers to the United States to undergo training to operate the Kidd-class destroyers, of which four will be sold to Taiwan.
The ROC Army will also send a team to the United States to undergo training for helicopter night bombing.
These military exchanges were not the first of their kinds but were made public for the first time.

DOC.HEADLINE: 29TH TSENG HSU-PAI JOURNALISM AWARD CEREMONY HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The award ceremony for the 29th Tseng Hsu-pai Journalism Award was held Friday in the headquarters of the Central News Agency, with reporters from the Chinese-language China Times receiving the most award in various categories.
The award was set up in commemoration of former Central News Agency (CNA) President Tseng Hsu-pai.

Cheng Chia-lin, chairwoman of Chinese Press Institute, said that the Tseng Hsu-pai award does not offer a huge prize - NT$50,000 (US$1,460) for each winner; however, it is the most respected due to its accuracy and impartiality in news reportage.
CNA President Hu Yuan-huei said the award is to honor those journalists who have fulfilled the spirit of public service and promoted culture in society.

The journalism academic award went to Ni Yen-yuan of the China Times, the newspaper critic award, Chang Juei-chan of the China Times; the newspaper reportage award, Yang Su-ming of the China Times; the television reportage award, Tseng Wan and Luo Yi-ming of Chinese Television System; the radio news reportage award, Huang Li-feng of Broadcasting Corporation of China; and the photography award, photography team from United Daily News.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INVITES POPE JOHN PAUL II TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Friday expressed gratitude to Pope John Paul II for receiving the ROC's first lady, Wu Shu-chen, on her recent Europe tour, and invited him to visit Taiwan, which Chen said is the wish of many people on the island.
Chen extended the invitation during a meeting with Ambrose Madhta, the charge d'affaires of the Embassy of the Holy See in Taipei, who also transmitted Chen a letter of regards from the Pope.
In the letter, the Pope expressed thanks to President Chen for the support of his call to help reconstruct Iraq and for the long-term support extended to him from the Taiwan people.
President Chen noted that the Republic of China government and the Vatican have long shared the same ideals -- the respect of human rights, mercy and the pursuit of peace.

Not only the ROC government, many charity organizations in Taiwan are ready to help with the reconstruction work in Iraq, Chen said, adding that these philanthropic groups have also fulfilled the spirit of mercy promoted by the Pope.
Expressing his gratitude to the long-term support from the Holy See to ROC's bid to enter international organizations, Chen added that most Taiwan people hope the Pope can visit Taiwan some day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY SHOULD BE GLOBALIZED: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that liberalization and globalization are the two principles for Taiwan's future economic development.

Speaking at a meeting with members of his economic advisory panel held at the Presidential Office, Chen said that Taiwan's economy is export-oriented and that it can only have better and sustainable development by making its manufacturers keep their bases on the island and enhance development of the service industry.

Facing the trend of globalization and increasing international competition, Chen affirmed, the government has the responsibility to reform thoroughly the country's economic structure and system to maintaining its dynamism, and due role and status its deserves in the world economy.

He presented a six-point conclusion after hearing reports and opinions by the panel members, emphasizing that relevant laws and regulations on development of the service industry should be eased in order to make the domestic service industry operate in the international framework.

Besides, he said, it is important to speed up financial reforms, to privatize state-owned financial institutions at a faster pace and to increase monitoring of financial operations for developing Taiwan into an assets management hub for the Asian-Pacific region.
He also called on the opposition parties to support the approval of a draft bill to revise the statute on the financial reconstruction fund for facilitating needed financial reforms.

The presidential economic advisory panel is headed by Vincent Siew, a former premier and an incumbent vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, who concurrently serves as chairman of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CHIER).
Other members of the advisory panel are Taiwan Thinktank Chairman Chen Po-chih, CHIER President Chen Tien-chih and Wu Rong-i, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSMAN TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: United States Representative Jim Leach, who is the chairman of the Subcommittee for Asia-Pacific Affairs under the Commission on International Relations, will arrive in Taiwan on Monday for a visit, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

The Republican from Iowa will exchange views with President Chen Shui-bian on issues such as the country's defense needs, Beijing's military threat, and the trade between Taiwan and the United States.

This will be the first time Leach has visited the island after he was elected a representative, although he was ranked a friend of the country long ago and received a medal from Taiwan in 2000 for his concern for the Taiwan people, the MOFA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUNISHMENT FOR PEOPLE-SMUGGLERS TO BE TIGHTENED

TEXT.P: Smugglers who bring in illegal immigrants to the country will be subject to heavier punishment according to a decision taken Friday by a meeting of related government agencies under the Executive Yuan.

In an all-out effort to stem the ever-increasing influx of illegal immigrants, mostly young women from the mainland who are forced to work as sex slaves in Taiwan, the officials decided to increase the maximum jail term for people-smugglers, their accomplices and aides, from five years to seven years, according to Lin Chia-lung, spokesman for the Executive Yuan.
The government might suspended the licenses of captains and chief engineers of boats used to transport illegal immigrants and may confiscate the boats, Lin went on.
The meeting also decided to step up the monitoring of the 82 beaches used by smugglers to bring in immigrants.

The meeting brought together officials from the Mainland Affairs Council, the Ministry of Justice, the National Police Administration, the Coast Guard Administration and the Criminal Investigation Bureau, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI GETS ONE MORE MEDAL IN WORLD UNIVERSITY GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Daegu, South Korea, Aug. 29 (CNA) (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei won one more medal in the 2003 World University Games which is going on here Friday.
Taiwan woman tennis players Chuang Chia-jun and Chan Jing-wei won a gold medal in the woman's double's tennis event.
It brought the total gold medals earned by Chinese Taipei in the games to three, in addition to two silvers and five bronzes.
That figures rank Chinese Taipei ninth among all participants.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 30, or the third day of the eighth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
30 B.C.: Mark Antony, the ruler of the eastern part of the Roman Empire, commits suicide at the court of his lover, Cleopatra, queen of Egypt, who later commits suicide by allowing an asp to bite her breast.
1483: Louis XI, king of France who was responsible for the unification of his country after the Hundred Years War, dies and is succeeded by his son, Charles VIII.
1862: Thomas Jonathan Jackson, known as "Stonewall," American Confederate general, leads his forces to victory against the Union Army at the Second Battle of Bull Run in Virginia. He was accidentally killed by his own troops at Chancellorvile in 1863.
1901: The vacuum cleaner is patented by Scotsman Hubert Cecil Booth.
1916: Turkey declares war on Romania.
1918: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, known as "Nikolai Lenin," first head of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, is shot and wounded by Fanya Kaplan and her sister Dora in Moscow.
1928: Jawaharlal Nehru founds the Independence of India League.
1932: Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Nazi politician and military leader, is elected president of the German Reichstag. He was responsible for the buildup of the German air force, directed Germany's wartime economy and was designated Hitler's successor in 1939.
1937: American boxer Joe Louis flattens Britain's Tommy Farr to win the heavyweight title at Madison Square Garden in New York.
1940: Sir Joseph John Thomson, British physicist, dies at the age of 84. He won a Nobel Prize in 1906 for investigating the electrical conductivity of gases.
1945: Hong Kong is liberated when the British Navy under Rear Adm. Cecil Harcourt sails into Victoria harbor to accept the Japanese surrender.
1949: The Southeast China Governor's Office, which was established in Taipei on Aug. 15, appoints Gen. Sun Li-jen as commander-in-chief of the Taiwan Garrison Command.
1958: Mainland China's Resolution Concerning the Establishment of People's Communes in the Rural Areas is promulgated. In a period of less then three months, 26,578 people's communes involving 127 million peasant household were established all over the mainland.
1963: The "hot line," a direct telephone line between the White House and the Kremlin linking the US president with the Soviet leader, becomes operational.
1974: A bomb planted by leftist guerrillas explodes in the main office of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries at Marunouchi in Tokyo, killing eight people and injuring 376 others.
1979: Ding Mou-shih, former vice minister of Foreign Affairs, leaves for Seoul to assume his post as ROC ambassador to the Republic of Korea.
1981: Muhammad Ali Rajai, president of Iran, and his prime minister, Mohammed Javad Bahonar, become victims of a bomb planted in the premier's office in Teheran.
1981: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives US Senator John Glenn.
1988: Republic of China-US talks on finance and banking open in Washington. The ROC negotiators agree to open the Taiwan market to credit card companies and to expand credit for foreign banks.
1989: Guatemalan President Marco Vincicio Cerezo Arevalo arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1990: Chien Mu, a great master in the study of Chinese classics, dies in Taipei at the age of 96.
1991: Azerbaijan declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1999: New Salvadoran Ambassador Francisco Ricardo Santana Berrios presents his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew leaves Taipei for Los Angeles en route to Panama to attend the inauguration of President-elect Mireya Moscoso on Sept. 1 as the special envoy of President Lee Teng-hui.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian receives Brisbane Mayor Jim Soorley, and welcomes his visit aimed at strenthening exchanges between the ROC and Australia.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is truth, there is intelligence; where there is intelligence, there is truth."

DOC.TEXT:
