DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S WTO RESEARCH CENTER TO BE INAUGURATED SEPT. 8

TEXT.P: Taiwan will inaugurate a World Trade Organization (WTO) research center Sept. 8 to draft various initiatives to be presented to the world trade regulatory body, Cabinet sources said Saturday.

The new think tank will be managed by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CHIER) at the request of the ROC government, the sources said, adding that all relevant government agencies will jointly finance the new center.

In addition to initiating proposals to be referred to formal WTO conferences for discussion, the center will also offer legal counseling and assist the government in handling trade disputes under the WTO framework and in cultivating human resources.

Since Taiwan became a WTO member, the sources said, the government has been mulling over how to more actively participate in WTO activities and how to more effectively cope with the impact of trade liberalization in the wake of the island's WTO accession.
Moreover, the sources said, WTO negotiations have evolved from bilateral consultations on market opening issues to multilateral talks on complicated, dynamic regional economic integration topics.

The new research center is expected to help the government craft innovative, forward-looking strategies to sustain Taiwan's market niches in the international trade and economic arenas, the sources said.
CHIER President Chen Tien-chih said the WTO research center will be staffed by scores of international trade and legal experts from the CHIER and other domestic think tanks and local universities.

On the new research center's inaugural day, Chen said, a special WTO databank will be posted on the Internet, which will be connected to the WTO's official Web site, while a WTO library will also be inaugurated to offer more information services.

Moreover, Chen said, the CHIER will organize a WTO retrospective show on that day, which will exhibit documents, graphics and photos featuring Taiwan's decade-long effort to join the WTO and its achievements in trade liberalization and economic globalization.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON DUJUAN HAS FORMED NEAR GUAM

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau said Saturday morning that a tropical depression near Guam has become a light typhoon, and forecast that the typhoon, named "Dujuan," will continue to gather strength.
The CWB said however that it is too early to forecast its impact on the weather of Taiwan, because it is still very far away from the island.
Dujuan was located about 1,600 kilometers east south-east of Heng Chun in southern Taiwan at 8 a.m. Saturday. It is moving west at nine kilometers per hour. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GOV'T CONTINUES TO SELL THERMOMETERS AT DISCOUNT PRICE

TEXT.P: In order to help prevent the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in the autumn and winter, the Taipei City Government has made 1.1 million thermometers available at the city's more than 3,000 chain drug stores and convenient shops.
An official of the Taipei City Health Bureau said the thermometers are being sold at a discount price of NT$50 (US$1.47) per piece.
The official encouraged people to take their own temperatures every day, eat balanced food, wash their hands often, and do exercises regularly to keep themselves healthy. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN TO CALL FOR DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH TAIWAN: FAPA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 29 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: U.S. Rep. Peter Deutsch (D-Fla.) is expected to urge the U.S. government to establish diplomatic relations with Taiwan, the Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) said in a press release Friday.

According to the press release, the congressman sent to the FAPA Friday a copy of a statement which he will present in the upcoming session of Congress. In the statement, Deutsch urges the U.S. government to diplomatically recognize what he calls the sovereign country of Taiwan.

Deutsch will urge President George W. Bush to fulfill what his father strived for when he was U.S. ambassador to the United Nations in the early 1970s - namely representation of both Taipei and Beijing in the United Nations, Taiwan's participation in world organizations, and U.S. diplomatic recognition of Taiwan, according to the FAPA.
The congressman stresses in the statement that the U.S. government should recognize Taiwan as an independent and sovereign country, and as a democratic ally in the global fight against terrorism.

The Republic of China, a U.N. founding member, was excluded from the organization in 1971 after the General Assembly passed U.N. Resolution No. 2758 which gave the China seat to Beijing at the expense of Taipei.
Deutsch says in the statement that this decision produced an extremely unfair situation, depriving the Taiwan people of their representation in the United Nations.

The pro-Taiwan Deutsch is most appreciated by the Taiwan people for his successful efforts in 1994 with other congressmen in pushing to give Taiwanese-American citizens the right to choose "Taiwan" for their place of birth in their passports.
Before 1994, the U.S. government used the designation "China" for place of birth for naturalized citizens from both Taiwan and mainland China.

FAFA President Wu Ming-chi said that although the establishment of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and the United States will be a hard task to accomplish, Deutsch's statement at least represents a beginning for the U.S. Congress in reviewing this issue which Wu said is long overdue.

Wu went on that complicated historical factors have resulted in Taiwan losing many diplomatic allies and consequently its representation in the United Nations and other major international organizations.

He noted that the United States' decision to break off formal diplomatic ties with Taipei in 1979 produced a domino effect among other countries, adding that he believes that if Washington reestablishes formal diplomatic relations with Taipei, other countries will follow suit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAILS RESTORATION OF CRITICAL PASSWAY IN SCENIC SHANLINHSI

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that he is very happy to see the restoration of the Anting Bay tunnel -- the sole connecting pass between Nantou County's two popular mountain resorts of Hsitou and Shanlinhsi in central Taiwan.
Addressing an inaugural ceremony for the new tunnel, Chen said he still remembers the distress he felt when he first saw the seriously damaged Anting Bay tunnel more than three years ago.

The tunnel tumbled in the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake that rattled Taiwan Sept. 21, 1999. Military servicemen managed to repair it a year later, but it was heavily damaged again in July 2001 when Typhoon Toraji swept across the island.

The collapse of this only connecting pass between Hsitou and Shanlinhsi dealt a severe blow to the local tourist industry, Chen said, adding that he has made four visits to the construction site over the past four years.

"I felt a bit of comfort only after I saw during my visit this May that the boring work on the tunnel had been completed, " Chen recalled, adding that he appreciates the concerted efforts of the relevant government agencies and private contractors in completing the difficult construction project ahead of schedule.

The project was originally scheduled for completion in October 2004. Thanks to the exceptional efficiency demonstrated by the relevant government agencies and private contractors in carrying out bidding and construction work, the project was completed more than a year ahead of schedule.

Many senior officials, including Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san, Public Construction Commission Chairwoman Kuo Yao-chi and Nantou County Magistrate Lin Chung-nan, attended the ribbon-cutting ceremony.
After the ceremony, Chen joined with 12 local couples who have been married for more than 60 years in walking through the tunnel in celebration of its restoration.

In tandem with the inauguration of the new tunnel, the Shanlinhsi recreational park, which boasts the island's only peony garden, as well as centuries-old trees, interestingly designed wooden houses and tourist hotels, was also re-opened to the public Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND VOWS TO BUILD UP ELITE FORCE TO COPE WITH MAINLAND THREAT

TEXT.P: Taiwan will build up an elite deterrent force to cope with the mounting military threat from mainland China, Defense Minister Tang Yiau-min said Saturday.

Tang said at a news conference that the ROC military will upgrade its overall defense capabilities through a structural overhaul, as well as refinement of manpower quality, renovation of its arsenal, and upgrading of combined services combat operations.

"We must focus on quality refinement because we cannot afford to engage in an arms race with mainland China, " Tang said, adding that the ROC military has drafted its military buildup plan in reference to mainland China's combat strength.

Tang said mainland China has officially set aside US$22.3 billion for its defense budget for 2004. But according to estimates by major military powers around the world, Tang said, the actual amount of mainland China's spending on defense for 2004 should reach US$65 billion. In contrast, he said, Taiwan's annual defense budget is below US$8 billion.
Against this backdrop, Tang said, Taiwan must upgrade its combat prowess through manpower restructuring and quality refinement.
Tang said the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has come up with a 10-year troops-reduction plan which will be carried out in two phases.

In the first stage, from 2003 through 2007, Tang said, the total number of ROC troops will be cut by 45,000 through integration of military units and strengthening of combined services combat operations.
The second phase of the reduction plan will be carried out from 2008 through 2012, during which time the military will trim personnel by a further 40,000.
Tang said the second phase will focus on military transformation and an upgrading of Taiwan's deterrent force.
By 2012, Tang said, the number of service members will be trimmed to 300,000. He further said that ground forces will account for 75 percent of all the military personnel to be cut.
"We hope to upgrade manpower quality through restructuring of the service branches," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA-ROC FTA WON'T CAUSE PROBLEMS WITH BEIJING: PRESIDENT MOSCOSO
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso said on Friday that the free trade agreement (FTA) Panama has signed with the Republic of China is not expected to cause problems with Beijing.
Moscoso, who made the remarks while presiding at a highway inauguration ceremony, stressed that Panama has diplomatic relations with Taiwan, and only trade ties with mainland China.

The Panamanian president and ROC President Chen Shui-bian signed a bilateral free trade agreement in Taipei earlier this month when Moscoso came to Taipei to attend a summit meeting among the heads of state of the ROC and its diplomatic allies in Latin America held Aug. 21.

Moscoso added that she believes that Panama's Legislative Assembly will ratify on Sept. 2 the free trade agreement signed with Taiwan, noting that if the agreement is not approved, the industrial, agricultural and livestock sectors in the nation will not forgive the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: 75% OF WORKERS THINK THEY ARE OVERWORKED: INTERNET SURVEY

TEXT.P: With the job market remaining tight, some 75 percent of workers in Taiwan think that they are overworked, according to the results of an Internet survey released Saturday.

In the survey, conducted by Cheers magazine and udnjob.com between Aug. 7-13, 30 percent of the respondents said they work for more than 62 hours in a week, 20 hours more than the maximum legal number of weekly working hours set by the government. And more than one-quarter of the polled said they often work on their off days.

According to a survey conducted by the Cabinet-level Council for Labor Affairs in July last year, only 11.3 percent of Taiwan businesses have overtime, with the average overtime for employees of these companies being 5.32 hours per week, or about one hour a day.
However, the results of Saturday's poll indicate that the results of the Council for Labor Affairs survey may be far from the actual situation in Taiwan.

Broken down by job description, workers in the research and development field work the most overtime, with 42.9 percent of them working more than 20 hours of overtime per week and 20.3 percent working more than 30 hours of overtime per week, according to the Internet poll.

The survey also indicated that many workers in Taiwan feel that increasing their competitiveness and actively taking on more responsibilities at work are keys to survival in the new industrial structure. The poll found that the fear of being laid off is the main factor behind their situation of being overworked.

A total of 72.3 percent said they spend part of their leisure time studying or receiving training to improve their professional skills, while a minority of those surveyed said they have opted for other activities in their leisure time in order to enjoy a balanced life.

Although overworked, most of the surveyed said they think the situation will not change in the short term, with only 35.5 percent saying they think the situation will improve within one year. Another 35.1 percent said they think the situation will improve only after five years.

Although somewhat pessimistic about the future, most of the workers are actively trying to find a solution to their overworked lives, with a majority of the respondents mentioning that working at a job they like or strengthening their professional skills to make themselves more indispensable are the best ways to accomplish this.
A total of 1,383 valid responses were collected in the Internet survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI GRABS ANOTHER SILVER AT WORLD UNIVERSITY GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Daegu, South Korea, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei women's volleyball team won a silver medal Saturday at the 2003 World University Games.
The mainland Chinese squad defeated Chinese Taipei in the finals to grab the gold.

Coach Lin Chu-mao said that tough matches against Ukraine and France on consecutive days ahead of the final match drained the Chinese Taipei side, leaving them with little energy to take on the mainland squad. He added that the fact that the mainland players are 10 centimeters taller on average than the Chinese Taipei players didn't help.
As of Saturday, Chinese Taipei has three gold, three silver and five bronze medals, for 11th place in the overall medal standings.
Meanwhile, the Chinese Taipei men's basketball team finished fourth after losing 112-105 to Japan in the bronze medal game Saturday.

The Chinese Taipei women's basketball team also lost their bronze medal game to the Russians. Although failing to win a medal, the fourth place finish marked the best result for Taiwan women basketballers at the World University Games in years.
Meanwhile, Huang Tze-kuei finished fourth in the pommel horse event in the men's gymnastics competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTORS WANT GREATER POLICY TRANSPARENCY: POLL

TEXT.P: Simplified and transparent investment policy and regulations are one of the most urgent tasks for the ROC government to lure foreign investors, according to the results of an opinion poll released Saturday.

The survey was conducted by a local magazine "GlobalView" from Aug. 7-15. The monthly magazine distributed 619 questionnaires to members of the American and European chambers of commerce in Taipei and collected 124 valid replies for an about 20 percent return rate.
The poll found that 48.4 percent of the respondents were dissatisfied with the ROC government's overall performance in dealing with investment affairs.

Asked what Taiwan should do to improve its investment climate, 68.5 percent cited "simplified and transparent policy and regulations"; 63.7 percent singled out "the opening of direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait"; and 55.6 percent said "upgrading of government efficiency."

Poll results showed that mainland China is the most attractive investment destination in Asia, while Taiwan and South Korea tie at second place; followed by Singapore, Japan, Hong Kong, Thailand and Malaysia in that order.

The respondents said South Korea has clear and consistent investment policy and has adopted a series of bold financial reform steps since the 19978-98 Asian financial crisis. These were reasons that South Korea becomes more attractive than Singapore and Hong Kong as an investment destination, according to the poll.

If direct cross-strait air and shipping links cannot be forged in the next two years, 19.4 percent said they will trim their presence in Taiwan, but 66.1 percent said they will not change their current operational scales.
As to Taiwan's advantages in attracting foreign investors, 62.9 percent cited "manpower quality"; 50 percent said "geographical location"; and 37.9 percent said "market scale".

Computer and electronics products topped the list of Taiwan's most promising industries cited by foreign investors (82.3 percent); followed by telecommunications equipment (52.4 percent); financial and investment services (49.2 percent.)

According to government tallies, foreign investments in Taiwan have continued falling in the past three years. Accumulated foreign investments in Taiwan in the first half of this year amounted to US$1.45 billion, less than half of last year's total of US$3.22 billion.

Speaking at a GlobalView-sponsored seminar whereby the poll results were unveiled, Andrea W. Wu, vice president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei, said politics should not interfere with economic operations. Otherwise, she said, foreign investors will become reluctant to invest in Taiwan.

Even though the opening of direct cross-strait transportation links is not an essential condition for foreigners to invest in Taiwan, Wu said, such links will certainly help enhance Taiwan's appeal to would-be foreign investors.
Moreover, Wu said, Taiwan's government should further improve its operational efficiency.
Dirk Sanger, president of the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei, seconded Wu's views, saying that political interference should be minimized in order to attract foreign investors.

Noting that market predictability is most critical in luring foreign investors, Sanger said the Taiwan government must give priority to forging a clear and transparent legal framework and effectively enforce all relevant regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREAN COURT RULES CAA CAN BE LISTED AS DEFENDANT IN SQ-006 CASE

TEXT.P: Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) director general Chang Kuo-cheng declined Saturday to comment on a Singaporean court's ruling that the CAA can be listed as a defendant in the law suit relating to a Singapore Airlines plane crash at Chiang Kai-Shek International Airport in 2000.

On the evening of Oct. 31, 2000, a Singapore Airlines jumbo jet hit construction equipment on a closed runway at CKS Airport during takeoff, killing 83 people and injuring 44 others, according to investigations by the Aviation Security Council (ASC) of the Executive Yuan.

Some of the families of victims of Flight SQ-006 sued Singapore Airlines for compensation, and the airline then requested that the Singaporean court list the CAA as a defendant, claiming that the signal facilities at the airport were inadequate.

Chang said that the ASC has completed its investigations and that the cause of the accident has been clearly explained in the investigation report. He said the CAA has authorized lawyers to handle the whole case and serve as the CAA's spokesman.
Meanwhile, the CAA filed a lawsuit against Singapore Airlines in a Taiwan court for compensation for damage to airport facilities during the accident. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: STREET PERFORMERS TO APPEAR IN TAIPEI FROM MONDAY

TEXT.P: From Monday, people with performance art talents will be allowed to show their skills in Taipei's underground malls and mass rapid transportation (MRT) stations.

The Culture Bureau of Taipei City Government issued street-performing licenses Saturday to talented performers and performing groups for the first time since Taipei became a city many decades ago. The purpose of the move is to enrich city life in Taiwan's capital.
The licenses must be renewed every three months. Licensed performers are allowed to accept tips from onlookers. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL WATER RESOURCES CONFERENCE TO BE HELD SEPT. 1

TEXT.P: A national water resources conference will be held Sept. 1 to chart the nation's future water resources development policy, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Saturday.
Chen Shen-hsien, director of the MOEA's Water Resources Agency (WRA), said the agenda will also include issues regarding water price adjustments.

The conference is expected to reach a conclusion on raising domestic water prices, Chen said, adding that an upward adjustment is necessary to stimulate development of water resources industry and encourage local people to cut water consumption.

As domestic water prices have traditionally remained at low levels, Chen said, few local enterprises are interested in investing in desalination and commercial utilization of deep-sea water. Low prices have also made local people indifferent with water conservation, he added.

Because of abnormal climatic changes, Chen said Taiwan has been gripped by water shortage problems in recent years. "We must address water supply issues by reviewing and adjusting our water pricing formula to encourage water conservation and investment in exploration of water resources," he noted.

Nevertheless, WRA officials said they don't think that the proposed water price hikes are likely to be implemented before next year's presidential election. "Political factors will hinder upward adjustment of water prices before the presidential election," predicted a WRA official who preferred anonymity.

Meanwhile, WRA officials said the conclusions reached at the upcoming conference will serve as reference for the government to draft a white paper on water resources development and relevant policy guidelines.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUNGSHAN AIRPORT UNSUITABLE FOR DIRECT CROSS-STRIAT LINKS: MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) will consider opening Taipei's Sungshan Airport for direct cross-Taiwan Strait flight service only after mainland China renounces its attempt to use force against Taiwan, a senior official said Saturday.

Defense Minister Tang Yiau-min said at a news conference that the MND's insistence on ruling out Sungshan Airport for direct cross-strait flight service is purely based on national security consideration and has nothing to do with political consideration.

According to a newly released evaluation report on the impact of opening direct cross-strait transportation links, the Cabinet singles out Chiang Kai-shek International Airport and Kaohsiung International Airport as the first two airports that may be opened for direct cross-strait flight service. However, the Taipei City Government has been pushing for including Sunghsan Airport for such service.

Tang said mainland China has deployed 500 guided ballistic missiles along its southeastern coast opposite Taiwan in addition to deploying many troops in its coastal region and conducting large-scale military exercises in the area regularly.
In the face of mainland China's mounting military threat, Tang said, the MND cannot agree to the Taipei City Government's proposal out of security concern.

"The safety of the 23 million people of Taiwan is our top concern in dealing with the issue," Tang said, adding that unless mainland China dismantles its missiles targeting at Taiwan and forsakes its attempt to take Taiwan by force, the MND will not consider adjusting its position.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AEROSPACE MISSION TO VISIT DALLAS

TEXT.P: A Taiwan aerospace mission, led by Industrial Development Bureau Director General C. Y. Chen, will arrive here Sunday to promote cooperation between the aerospace industries of the United States and Taiwan.
The 20-member mission will be composed of representatives from 12 aerospace industrial companies and organizations.

While in Dallas, they will exchange views with their American counterparts on how to strengthen their cooperation in producing aerospace components and parts, C. Y. Ling, director of the economic section of Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Houston, said Saturday.

He said there is a good potential for cooperation between the aerospace industries of the two countries, because American aerospace companies are looking for partners in Asia in order to reduce their production costs. (by H.Y. Chang and EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: 40 ILLEGAL MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS SENT TO MATSU FOR REPATRIATION

TEXT.P: A 40-member group of illegal mainland Chinese immigrants, including 35 women and five infants, were sent to the ROC-held frontline island of Matsu Saturday for repatriation to mainland China next week.
The illegal immigrants who were originally detained at the Hsinchu detention center in northern Taiwan arrived in Matsu early in the morning via ship.

The steady stream of illegal mainland immigrants has posed a financial burden and serious social problems to Taiwan. Mainland China's reluctance to take back seized illegal immigrants has left Taiwan's three detention centers often jammed with illegals.

Its inaction to punish human traffickers has also led to deterioration of cross-Taiwan Strait human trafficking. Last week, 26 mainland women were thrown overboard by human smugglers to escape pursuing Taiwan coast guard ships and six of them drowned.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 31, or the fourth day of the eighth month of the Year of the Goat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
12AD: Caligula, originally Gaius Caesar, Roman emperor remembered for his murderous reign, is born. He succeeded his adopted father Tiberius. After a severe illness, he displayed the ruthlessness, extravagance and megalomania that led to his assassination.
1422: Henry V, King of England, who reopened the Hundred Years' War, defeating the French at Agincourt in 1415 and capturing all of Normandy by 1419, dies of dysentery in France at the age of 35. His son Henry VI accedes to the throne at the age of nine months.
1907: The Anglo-Russian Convention is signed in St. Petersburg, settling differences between the two over Tibet, Afghanistan and Persia.
1907: Ramon Magsaysay, president of the Philippines from 1953 to 1957, is born.
1939: Adolf Hitler announces the invasion of Poland. Three days later, both Britain and France declared war on Germany, marking the outbreak of World War II.
1945: The Nationalist government divides the three northeastern provinces in Manchuria into nine provinces.
1957: Malaysia achieves independence from Britain with Tengku Abdul Rahman as its first president.
1961: President Chiang Kai-shek tells 70 visiting American reporters that Kinmen and Matsu "are as important as West Berlin."
1962: The former British possessions of Trinidad and Tobago become an independent nation.
1962: The Republic of China recognizes the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago.
1965: Pakistan and India threaten war over Kashmir.
1968: A strong earthquake rocks northeastern Iran, killing 12,000 people and injuring over 100,000 others.
1974: The first plant to produce high-density polyethylene resins in the Republic of China is dedicated at Toufen in Miaoli County.
1976: Little League, Big League and Senior League teams return to Taipei after winning world titles in the United States.
1980: The ROC Mulan soccer team wins the championship at the first International Women's Soccer Tournament held in the United States.
1989: Buckingham Palace officially confirms that the marriage of Queen Elizabeth II's daughter, Anne, and Captain Mark Phillips is on the rocks.
1990: Premier Hau Pei-tsun advises the Legislative Yuan that ROC relations with mainland China will operate under the concept of "one country, two areas."
1992: Former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher expresses support for the ROC's entry into the GATT during her visit to Taipei.
1993: Beijing makes public a white paper reiterating its position of solving the Taiwan problem by "peaceful reunification" and "one country, two systems," while refusing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.
1994: Russian President Boris Yeltsin and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl jointly preside over a farewell ceremony marking an end to half a century of military presence on German soil by troops of the former Soviet Union.
1994: The IRA declares an unconditional end to its 25-year armed struggle for a united Ireland and its war against British rule of Northern Ireland.
1995: The ruling Kuomintang nominates incumbent President Lee Teng-hui as its presidential candidate.
1997: Britain's Princess Diana and her millionaire companion Dodi Al Fayed are killed in a Paris car crash.
1999: Raymond F. Burghardt, the newly appointed director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
2000: ROC Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen says that the military will continue to try to obtain an early warning system after recent war games revealed Taiwan's limited means to counter mainland Chinese missile attack.
2001: Compaq Computer Inc. and Taiwan's Academia Sinica, the highest academic researrch institute in Taiwan, sign a cooperative memorandum to engage in gene and biotechnology research in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only he, in the world, who possesses absolute truth who can get to the bottom of the law of his being. He who can get to the bottom of the law of his being will be able to get to the bottom of the law of being of other men."

DOC.HEADLINE: EARLY MORNING FIRE KILLS 13, INJURES 68 IN TAIPEI COUNTY

TEXT.P: A fire took place in an apartment in Luchou, Taipei County, Sunday morning killed 13 persons and injured 68, according to police.
The fire started from the first floor at 1:53 a.m. when most inhabitants were asleep, and rapidly engulfed the high-rise apartments through the atrium.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
TYPHOON DUJUAN MOVING CLOSER TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Typhoon Dujuan, located about 1,100 kilometers east south-east of Taitung in southern Taiwan at 8:00 a.m. Sunday, is moving west north-west in the direction of Taiwan at 27 kilometers per hour.

The Central Weather Bureau said it will issue a typhoon warning Sunday afternoon to ships sailing in the Bashi Channel and in the waters near eastern Taiwan, if Dujuan maintains its current speed and direction.
Dujuan, which became a medium typhoon at 2 a.m. Sunday, is forecast to reach the area about 460 kilometers east south-east of Taitung at 8:00 a.m. Monday.
The CWB said that the weather of Taiwan will be hot in the next few days, and there will be afternoon thunder storms in the western part of the island. It may rain Monday in eastern Taiwan. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: YU ASKS FIVE MINISTRIES TO CONDUCT DAILY PRESS MEETING

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun has asked the heads of five ministries Sunday to preside over a press meeting each morning from next week to "keep society and the media informed."

Yu asked the Ministries of education, interior, economic affairs and transportation and communications, as well as the Council of Agriculture late last week to convene a daily meeting every morning to review major events and issues in society and facilitate interactions and understanding with the media.

Yu's directive came in the wake of remarks made by President Chen Shui-bian last week that the Cabinet has done well administratively for national development over the past three-plus years, but the Executive Yuan needs more publicity to allow the public to have a better understanding of its works.

Since three other Cabinet agencies -- the Ministry of National Defense, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Council of Mainland Affairs -- have long conducted regular press conferences to facilitate understanding between the government and the media, Yu said the five other ministries also need to do likewise.
Premier Yu, Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i and Executive Yuan Secretary-General Liu Shih-fang have maintained regular meetings at 8:30 a.m. each day to gauge the state of society and the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANK EXECUTIVES OPTIMISTIC ABOUT TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC PROSPECTS

TEXT.P: Economic recoveries in the United States and Japan will help stimulate Taiwan's economy and Taiwan will benefit from positive economic developments in mainland China, regional executives of two international banks said Sunday.

Cheng Cheng-mou, vice president of Citibank's Taipei branch, said that Citibank has recently revised its forecast of Taiwan's economic growth in 2003 from 2.3 percent to 2.7 percent, while the United States is expected to attain a 2.5 percent growth, Japan 1.9 percent, mainland China 7.5 percent, and the Euro-zone 0.6 percent.

He said that the 2.7 percent projection remained conservative in comparison with the forecast of 3.06 percent by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics under the Executive Yuan.

While economists of the international bank have revised upwards their forecast regarding Taiwan, Cheng pointed out that although Taiwan suffered the impact of the spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in April and May, foreign capital has been coming into Taiwan since early this year, especially in the hi-tech sectors.

Saying that different industries may expect various paces of recovery in the following months, Cheng foresees accelerated recoveries in the semiconductor, TFT (thin-film-transistor) display, and digital camera manufacturing industries.
With promising prospects for these locomotive industries, Cheng said that Taiwan is projected to achieve a 4.2 percent economic growth next year.

Meanwhile, economists of the Standard Chartered Bank are even more optimistic about economic recoveries around the globe, as they forecast the U.S. will be able to attain a 4 percent economic growth in the second half of this year, and a 3.8 percent growth in 2004; Japan will have an annual growth between 1.5 percent and 2 percent this year; and mainland China's economic growth this year is projected at 8.5 percent.

With the stimulus of economic recoveries in the U.S. and Japan, Taiwan's economy is expected to grow by 3.5 percent in the coming months until summer 2004, according to Kwok Kwok-chuen, regional chief economist for north and eastern Asia of the Standard Chartered Bank.

Kwok said that the world economy had suffered in the wake of the burst of hi-tech stock bubbles. As international information technology-related industries are gradually recovering and demand increasing, Taiwan, Singapore and South Korea, as leading IT products suppliers, will benefit, he added.

Stressing the international competitiveness of Asian economies, Kwok said that Asian economies stagnated in the first half of this year due to the impacts of the U.S.-led war against Iraq and SARS outbreaks. The prospects have been turning for the better over the past two months, he said.
A Standard Chartered Bank forecast indicates that Taiwan can achieve a 3.5 percent economic growth this year, while exports will continue to expand.

The economist pointed out, however, in terms of domestic demand and investment willingness, the recovery will be slow, with a sluggish jobs market and the increasing number of factories relocating to the mainland by Taiwanese businesses.

On the other hand, Kwok suggested that positive economic developments in mainland China will benefit Taiwan's economy, the hi-tech industrial sector in particular, because Taiwan is still a leading supplier of electronics parts and components to the mainland market.

DOC.HEADLINE: LU CALLS FOR CLOSER TIES WITH LATIN AMERICA

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu on Sunday called for comprehensive efforts by Taiwan's official and private sectors to enhance relations with Latin America.

Terming the relations between Taiwan and Latin America the "new cross-strait" relations, Lu urged the Taiwan people to move their focus of attention farther from the narrow Taiwan Strait to the much wider Pacific Ocean, where Latin America is.

In an exclusive interview with CNA at the Presidential Office Sunday morning, Lu advocated stepped-up "peoples' diplomacy" with Central and South America, given that 15 out of the 27 nations that maintain formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China on Taiwan are in that part of the world.

Lu called for Taiwan legislators as well as the industrial and business sectors to shift their fact-finding tours and investments from mainland China to Central and South America, saying "What's the point of focusing all your efforts and money in mainland China while cross-Taiwan Strait relations are mired in hostility and crisis?"

The vice president also called for Taiwan students and online species to increase interactions with the peoples in Central and South America. She said after the frenzy of enthusiasm for the Japanese and Korean pop cultures, it's time now for the Taiwanese young generation to change their appetite for some Latin American flavors to help broaden their global perspective.
Lu said she will also push for efforts by cities and counties islandwide to gear up tourism, cultural and agricultural sales exchanges with counterparts in Central and South American countries.
Taking Paraguay as an example, Lu said Paraguay is actually an oasis in the "diplomacy desert" that Taiwan is experiencing in the vastness of South America.
Lu visited South America recently and said that the existing "Taiwan village" there should be further enlarged to become a "Taiwan town" to accelerate bilateral exchanges.
She has advocated that 1,000 Taiwan citizens financially support 1,000 Paraguayan orphans to make the poor children their Paraguayan protegees.
Lu also urged the government to help the private industrial and business sectors invest in Paraguay, turning the backwater country into the "factory of South America."

DOC.HEADLINE: WEATHER BUREAU ISSUES TYPHOON WARNING

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau has issued a warning against Typhoon Dujuan, advising ships sailing in the Bashi Channel and waters near southeastern and northeastern Taiwan to take precautionary measures against strong winds.
The weather bureau said Dujuan could affect the weather of Taiwan because it is moving fairly quickly in the direction of the island.
Dujuan was located about 1,010 kilometers east of Oluanpi at the southern tip of the island at 11 a.m. Sunday, moving west-northwest at 27 kilometers per hour.

Weather forecasters said Sunday afternoon that it is too early to tell weather Dujuan, which gathered strength to become a medium typhoon at 2 a.m. Sunday, will bring plentiful rainfall to northern Taiwan. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: 13 KILLED, 68 INJURED IN APARTMENT FIRE IN TAIPEI COUNTY

TEXT.P: Thirteen people were killed and 68 injured in an early morning fire which engulfed a high-rise apartment in Luchou, Taipei County, Sunday, according to police.

The fire broke out at 1: 53 a.m., while most people were asleep. It set alight motorcycles parked in a lower level and the fire spread rapidly as the adjoining stairwells acted as flues. The blaze had quickly engulfed the entire building.
Reports said that a couple, who had been drinking, began to argue in the underground parking bay and had tossed paint thinner at each other then set the accelerant ablaze.

Alleys leading to the apartment were so narrow that the location was inaccessible to large fire engines. More than 50 fire engines had to park one or two block away to fight the fire using long hoses.

As a result, the pressure coming from the fire hydrants was so weak that the water could only be sprayed up to the second floor, even though the blaze was by then on every floor up to the eighth story.
Many people who scrambled to escape in their pajamas through stairway were forced to retreated to their own flats after finding the building's only exit was blocked by burning motorcycles.

They waved clothes from their windows, crying for help, but the ladder trucks couldn't approach the building because of the narrow alleys. Some lucky residents managed to find ropes and rappelled to safety from windows; others lost their grip on the rope and fell to the ground, while others simply jumped and were injured seriously.
All of the injured were rushed to hospitals in Taipei County and Taipei City.

The local government opened a temporary shelter to accommodate people evacuated from the apartment building and promised to offer aid of NT$200,000 (US$5,878) to each victim and NT$100,000 (US$2.939) to every person who was seriously injured.
Government leaders from President Chen Shui-bian down were alarmed by the incident.
President Chen called for a forensic investigation to find the cause of the tragedy and bring to justice those responsible.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun asked government agencies to do their utmost to help the families who suffered in the fire.

The Executive Yuan's spokesman, Lin Chia-lung, said the premier had been told of the fire almost immediately and was kept informed hourly all Sunday morning until the fire was put out. However, Lin said, the premier would refrain from visiting the site for the time being to avoid disrupting the work of firefighters.

Minister of the Interior Yu Cheng-hsien visited the injured at hospitals Sunday morning, presented each of them with NT$50,000 (US$1,469) . For the families of the dead, the aid is NT$100,000 (US$2,939) per victim.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDIA CAN GIVE MESSAGE IN MAINLAND TO STOP HUMAN TRAFFICKING

TEXT.P: Taoyuan police urged the government Sunday to launch media drives in mainland China to help curb human trafficking across the Taiwan Strait.

In the light of the drowning of six mainland Chinese women off waters in western Taiwan while trying to sneak onto the island last week, Taoyuan police said it would be more effective for the Taiwan authorities to educate the Chinese people and smash their illusions about Taiwan via media publicity on the mainland than pressing for added hands in coast guard forces to bust human cargo and traffickers.
Last week, 26 mainland Chinese women were thrown overboard by human traffickers to escape pursuing Taiwan coast guard ships offshore Miaoli, northern Taiwan. Six of the group drowned.
Taoyuan County, also on the west coast in northern Taiwan, has been one of the major places where human traffickers dump ashore their human cargoes.

Taoyuan police say they are often called to arrest mainland Chinese women from motels on charges of engaging in illegal sex trade. At the police stations, most of the Chinese women say they paid a fortune to have them secreted into Taiwan to marry Taiwanese men or start a new life, the policemen said.

Many said that the traffickers promised them a much better life once they succeed in landing in Taiwan, but often the reality was that setting foot on Taiwan soil was just the beginning of their nightmares, according to police.

The Taoyuan police said stopping human trafficking is a daunting task for Taiwan law enforcement authorities, saying that while at sea it is the responsibility of the coast guard to capture smuggling vessels and human beings, while on land it is the job of the police to find illegal mainland Chinese immigrants.
Unless a case is reported and the police are alerted, finding the illegal mainland Chinese immigrants in Taiwan society is as hard as finding needles in haystacks, the police said.

They argued instead that educating the Chinese while they are still on the mainland and shattering their illusions about the prospects of going to Taiwan by illicit means would be a better way of stemming a further wave of human trafficking than pressing Taiwan's already small law enforcement organization for extra hands to handle the ever-increasing waves of illegal immigrants.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS TAIWAN-FUNDED COMPANIES SHOULD BE ALLOWED TO INVEST IN TSE

TEXT.P: To replace Hong Kong as a capital-raising center in Asia, the government should allow foreign-based Taiwan companies to apply for listing on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TSE) , according to a report presented recently by a presidential economic advisory panel.

Such a move will fuel private-sector investment in Taiwan and help boost capital movements between Taiwan and mainland China, thus reducing one-way capital flight to the mainland, members of the panel commented in a meeting late last week.

The government ought to gradually ease restrictions on capital use by listed companies and should provide Taiwan-invested and overseas Chinese enterprises operating abroad with access to the domestic stock market, they suggested, adding that Taiwan stands a good chance to replace Hong Kong as a capital-raising hub in Asia by doing so.

Hong Kong has been losing its status and functions as a regional financial center since its reversion to Beijing's rule in 1997, and Taiwan should be able to succeed it to play that role, panel members said.

The panel's comments are indicative that a proposal suggesting to allow foreign-based Taiwan companies to invest and raise capital in the Taiwan Stock Exchange may take effect in the near future after complementary measures are due, officials of domestic institutional investors contended.

Once entrepreneurs are permitted to collect funds from Taiwan to develop their own businesses, they will be more willing to invest at home and set up their business operational centers here, helping in Taiwan's economic progress and increasing capital movements between Taiwan and mainland China. Most foreign-based Taiwan businesses are headquartered in the mainland.

Banning mainland-based Taiwanese enterprises from being listed on the domestic stock market out of political considerations has caused a great deal of capital flight to mainland China through a third country or area, they pointed out.

Allowing foreign-based Taiwan companies to make listings on the domestic bourse will not only increase their affiliation with the country, but also will set up official mechanisms for relevant authorities to supervise their operations and finances, they said, urging the government to quicken its pace in obtaining the goal before mainland China to secure Taiwanese capital for the homeland.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRY DISCUSSES LISTING OF O'SEAS TAIWANESE COMPANIES ON TSE

TEXT.P: By allowing international corporations invested by Taiwanese businessmen overseas to become listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange, the government will help Taiwanese businessmen abroad to have a new channel to raise capital, which will advance Taiwan's position as a financial center in the Asia-Pacific region, an industrial association executive said Sunday.

Lo Huai-chia, executive officer of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association, said that the association first made the proposal years ago to allow overseas Taiwanese companies to become listed and their stocks be traded in a "fourth market, " in addition to the TSEC (Taiwan Stock Exchange Corporation) market, OTC (over-the-counter) market, and the market for emerging hi-tech stocks.

In order to develop a supervisory mechanism over capital flow, the association suggested that the "fourth market" should open only to institutional investors from the United States, Japan, Hong Kong and other parts of the world at first, according to Lo.

He pointed out that between 1991 and 2002, the government approved 27,276 applications for making investments on the Chinese mainland, and the investment amount totalled US$26.61 billion, representing 45.7 percent of the overseas investments by Taiwan's business and industry.

With the establishment of a "fourth market" for the trading of stocks of overseas Taiwanese companies, overseas Taiwanese companies which have difficulties becoming listed on the stock exchanges in Hong Kong and mainland China will have a new channel to raise capital, Lo said.
He added, however, the "fourth market stocks trading" remained a vague idea because the drafting and implementing of such a policy involves a lot of work in revising regulations.

Some members of the industrial association suggested that at the moment, it is more practical for the government to negotiate with Beijing on an agreement to solve problems facing Taiwanese businesses, such as double taxation by authorities on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

They said that many Taiwanese businessmen have set up overseas controlling companies to manage their investments in mainland China. While these companies are using accounting and auditing systems different from local companies in Taiwan, they may have problems meeting the listing requirements in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDDHA'S LIGHT ASSOCIATION DONATES USED BOOKS TO CHILDREN

TEXT.P: The Vancouver branch of Buddha's Light International Association donated 1,740 used English books to school children in remote areas of Taiwan Saturday through the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO).
The Buddhist organization also donated more than 1,400 used Chinese books to libraries in the greater Vancouver area through TECO.
The books were given by Buddhists from the greater Vancouver area in a campaign by the association to "share happiness with other people."

A leader of the Buddhist organization said at the donation ceremony that a used book is as valuable as a new one because a book may help change someone's life, regardless of whether the book is new or used. (by EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: GRANDMAS RALLY TO SUPPORT 'CALL TAIWAN, TAIWAN' MOVEMENT

TEXT.P: About 100 grandmothers aged over 70 took part in a rally in front of the Presidential Office Sunday to support the "Call Taiwan Taiwan" movement slated to kick off Sept. 6 islandwide.
Ninety-year-old grandmother Chen Hua said she has been living in Taiwan all her life -- a short time compared with the time that future generations will live on the island.
An 80-year-old, grandmother in a wheelchair, surnamed Cheng, said she supports the notion that the Taiwanese people call the land where they have lived for ages "Taiwan" rather than any other name.
Another elderly lady said it is time to repay Taiwan and its people by calling the country by its original name, Taiwan.
The rally, organized by the Alliance to Campaign for Rectifying the Name of Taiwan, concluded orderly and peacefully after the grandmothers walked around the Presidential Office Building.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILIES OF CAL AIR CRASH VICTIMS SUE BOEING IN LOS ANGELES
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Two family members of victims of the 2002 air crash of a China Airlines (CAL) plane filed suit for damages against the airplane's United States builder, Boeing, in a Los Angeles court Saturday.

Attorney Steven Archer said his two Taiwan clients, Chung Chi-hua and Chung Yen-hua, are seeking reasonable compensation from Boeing on grounds that it failed to duly supervise the maintenance of a Boeing 747-200 it sold to CAL in 1979 which lead to its crash in the ocean on May 25, 2002 on its way from Taipei to Hong Kong, killing all 225 on board.

He claimed that evidence suggested the plane broke up in midair because of metal fatigue and investigators suspect the breakup started from a 15-inch, old crack in the plane's tail. The crack was covered with a stainless steel plate rather than a plate of aluminum alloy as is usually used to patch cracks.

Boeing should share part of the blame for the crash as it undertook to monitor the maintenance of airplanes built by it according to its contract with CAL, and CAL fixed the crack in question under the supervision of Boeing technicians.
Margaret Morrow, a judge at the Los Angeles Federal Court set Nov. 3 for the first hearing of the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY EXERCISE RESCHEDULED FOR SEPT. 4 BECAUSE OF TYPHOON

TEXT.P: A live ammunition war exercise initially set for Monday has been rescheduled for Thursday because of the approach of Typhoon Dujuan, according to the Ministry of National Defense Sunday.
In a brief statement, the ministry said the amphibious war exercise, code-named "Hankuang No. 16, " will be held at the same beach location, which was not disclosed.

Government leaders from President Chen Shui-bian on down as well as foreign ambassadors and representatives to Taiwan have been invited to observe the drill in which the armed forces will showcase its newly acquired weapons systems and the military's combat skills in a mock landing strike operation jointly conducted by the ROC Army, the navy and the air force

The ministry issued the statement several hours after the Central Weather Bureau posted a sea warning for Typhoon Dujuan, which is moving on a path toward the island and is picking up strength. The storm is forecast to affect the island late Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT WORKING ON NEW PROJECTS TO SECURE ECONOMIC GROWTH

TEXT.P: Following the impact of two major events in the international community in the first half of this year, the government has being working on a new public works project worth billions of dollars to help maintain Taiwan's economic growth in the coming years, according to a report by the Executive Yuan.

The administration has earmarked NT$500 billion (about US$14.5 billion) for public construction projects over the next five years to help secure the country's economic growth, including aiming for a 3.06 percent economic growth rate for this year, Premier Yu Shyi-kun stressed in the administrative report submitted to the Legislative Yuan.
The report is about the agenda of all government agencies in the first half of this year, with issues surrounding the country's economic development being the focal point.

Yu said in the report that the country has performed brilliantly after overcoming the negative effects of the U.S.-led war in Iraq and the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS ), thanks to a series of effective measures taken by the administration.

Looking to the second half of the year, which will see an economic recovery taking place in the U. S. and most Asian countries, Yu said the top priority for the administration is to revive Taiwan's economy and improve its business environment in the post-SARS era.

The premier expressed the hope that all government agencies concerned should effectively implement a NT$57.7 billion public works expansion plan, a NT$20 billion employment stimulus package and a special SARS relief and prevention project, which have already been approved by the Legislative Yuan, in addition to the projected NT$500 billion program.

He urged relevant government agencies to do their best to attract foreign capital and promote Taiwan in order to help the country maintain stable economic expansion, including a 3.06 percent economic growth rate for 2003 as had been forecast by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN ADMIRES INDUSTRIES' CONTRIBUTION TO ECONOMY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian acknowledged Sunday the contributions made by the country's basic industries to help the economy in defiance of an international economic slowdown.

Speaking at a conference of an association concerned with rejuvenating the economy of Taiwan through its basic industries, the president blamed the unfavorable international economic climate for the country's slower-than-expected economic recovery.
However, the president said, it is admirable that the country's basic industries are capable of bucking the worldwide trend and posting remarkable growth.
Citing various governmental data, the president said the country's economy is looking up and the efforts of basic industries will soon pay off.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN-TAIWAN LOCAL LAWMAKERS' UNION ESTABLISHED IN TOKYO

TEXT.P: A 70-member union of Japanese local lawmakers was established Sunday in Tokyo to help promote friendly relations between Japan and Taiwan.

Former President Lee Teng-hui and Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara sent written congratulatory messages to the inauguration ceremony. The meeting was attended by many dignitaries from Taiwan and Japan, including representative Lo Fu-chuan of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan.

Participants at the meeting adopted a resolution to support Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, send a visiting group to Taipei to show their support for the "Call Taiwan, Taiwan" movement in Taiwan, and invite Vice President Annette Lu to visit Japan. (by Amy Huang and EH)

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR BEGINS SIX-DAY JAPAN VISIT SEPT. 1
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Southern Taiwan, Aug. 31 (CNA) (By Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh will fly to Japan at the head of a trade and tourism promotion mission Sept. 1 for a six-day visit.
Speaking at a press conference held on Sunday afternoon, Hsieh said that his upcoming trip is aimed at selling the port city in southern Taiwan to Japanese businessmen and tourists.
During their stay in Japan, Hsieh said that he and the mission will call on Japanese business and labor groups, organize trade talks and tourism fairs and visit tourist spots and trade facilities.
Hsieh said that Japan is an important tourism source for Kaohsiung given that more than 68,000 of the 986,000 Japanese tourists who visited Taiwan last year entered from the port city.
However, he said that the city's tourism industry was hit hard this year by outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) on Taiwan which resulted in a sharp decrease of Japanese arrivals.
The potentially deadly disease did not spread widely in Kaohsiung and was put under control quickly, the mayor noted.

Members of the mission include Huang Chin-hsiang, president of the Kaohsiung Visitors Association; Yeh Chih-chung, president of the Multiple Trade and Business Association, representatives of enterprises and city government officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: FATAL FIRE CAUSED BY WOMAN SETTING FIRE TO SELF IN SUICIDE ATTEMPT

TEXT.P: The fatal fire that killed 13 persons and injured another 71 in an apartment in Taipei County, northern Taiwan Sunday morning was caused by a woman who set fire to herself in a suicide attempt, a public prosecutor who is in charge of investigating into the tragedy said in the afternoon.

Ling Poh-chih of the prosecutors' office of Panchiao District Court said that Hsu Ruey-kim set fire to herself in a suicide attempt at the parking bay of the eight-floor apartment where she lives after a fierce argument with her husband on the later's alleged sexual affairs.
The fire on Hsu's body set alight scores of motorcycles parked on the parking bay and spreaded rapidly as the adjoining stairwells acted as flues, Lin explained.
Hsu was seriously injured in the suicide attempt and was admitted to a hospital with burns to 90 percent of her body, the police said.
The fire broke out at 1: 53 a.m. and quickly engulfed the entire building while most people were asleep.
Government leaders from President Chen Shui-bian down were alarmed by the incident.
President Chen called for a forensic investigation to find the cause of the tragedy and bring to justice those responsible.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun asked government agencies to do their utmost to help the families who suffered in the fire.

Both Chen and Yu also visited the injured at hospitals Sunday to extend them their regards. The local government opened a temporary shelter to accommodate people evacuated from the apartment building and promised to offer aid of NT$200,000 (US$5,878) to each victim and NT$100,000 to every person who was seriously injured.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEATHER BUREAU ISSUES LAND WARNING FOR TYPHOON DUJUAN

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land warning Sunday night for Typhoon Dujuan which is expected to affect Taiwan on Monday afternoon.

Dujuan was located about 760 kilometers east-southeast of Oluanpi at the southern tip of the island at 8 p.m. Sunday, moving west-northwestly at 28 kilometers per hour, CWB meteorologists said, adding that the radius of Dujuan's storm-force winds had reached 250 kilometers, with maximum wind speeds of 35 meters per second.

The weathermen said that residents in Taitung, Hualien and Ilan of eastern Taiwan, Pingtung of southern Taiwan, Green Island and Orchid Island off the eastern coast should keep special alert on the medium typhoon which continues to gather strength.

The CWB issued a sea warning earlier on that same day, advising ships sailing in the Bashi Channel and waters near southeastern and northeastern Taiwan to take precautionary measures against strong winds.
